sections.title: Research Design and Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: Multi-phased study involving interviews with CISOs, review of cybersecurity products, and assessment of software vulnerability discovery processes.  Data from these three components were used to develop a heuristic model.

sections.title: Questionnaire
sections.methods_summary: A 21-item questionnaire was administered via one-on-one telephone conversations (45-60 minutes) with 18 CISOs.  In two cases, email responses were accepted.

sections.title: Heuristic Model Specification
sections.methods_summary: A heuristic model was developed to examine the global course of cybersecurity.  The model includes equations for initial external hardness, training, tools, BYOD/smart device policies, and air-gapping.  The model simulates the actions of over 100 types of organizations, varying in size, value at risk, and diligence.  Sensitivity analyses were conducted by varying key parameters.

sections.title: Model Parameters
sections.methods_summary: Lists the parameters used in the model, including cost parameters, growth parameters, effect parameters, step parameters, intensity cost parameters, and tool parameters.  Also specifies other parameters that can be user-set.

sections.title: Baseline Parameters
sections.methods_summary: Specifies the user-set parameters used in the base-case model run.

analysis.sample_description: 18 CISOs were interviewed, with a non-random sample drawn from various sectors (military, communications, government, finance, manufacturing). The heuristic model simulates over 100 types of organizations.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data was used to inform the development of a quantitative heuristic model.  Sensitivity analyses were conducted to assess the impact of varying key parameters on model outcomes.

sections.title: Search Strategies and Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: Scientific databases (e.g., PubMed) were searched for systematic reviews, monographs, and meta-analyses. Primary research studies were included to clarify specific perspectives or contexts. Content search terms were combined to address the report's objectives. Guidance and reports from national organizations (e.g., NIAAA) were also reviewed.

sections.title: Sleep Measurement Methods
sections.methods_summary: Sleep patterns were measured using various methods: polysomnograms, Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MSLT), Psychomotor Vigilance Test (PVT), actigraphy, sleep logs, and questionnaires.  The study notes the advantages and disadvantages of each method, considering cost, invasiveness, and suitability for different populations and settings.

sections.title: Alcohol and Drug Use Measurement Methods
sections.methods_summary: Alcohol and drug use were measured using validated screening instruments (CAGE, AUDIT, AUDIT-C, RAPS4), items from population-based questionnaires, and objective measures such as breathalyzers, blood, and urine analysis.  The study discusses the strengths and weaknesses of self-report versus objective measures, including considerations of social desirability bias and the potential for tampering with objective tests.

sections.title: Smoking Measurement Methods
sections.methods_summary: Tobacco use was primarily measured using large, population-based surveys (Global Adult Tobacco Survey, Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance System) and the DoD's Health Related Behavior (HRB) survey.  The study also mentions the use of cotinine, a biomarker, to validate self-reported smoking data and discusses the limitations of self-report measures.

analysis.sample_description: The study primarily focuses on research conducted with adult populations in the United States, with some inclusion of research on children and adults in other Western nations.  The study prioritizes literature reviews, meta-analyses, and ongoing bodies of research over smaller-scale studies.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study analyzes existing research on the relationship between behavioral fitness constructs (sleep, alcohol and drug use, tobacco use) and resilience, well-being, and stress.  The analysis focuses on identifying key constructs, measures, and interventions, and evaluating the effectiveness of different interventions based on the available evidence from systematic reviews and meta-analyses.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: A systematic search of electronic databases (PubMed, PsycINFO, CINAHL, AMED, CENTRAL, and Web of Science), bibliographies of existing systematic reviews and included studies was conducted to identify English-language reports of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) testing the efficacy and safety of MBRP. Two independent reviewers screened the literature, abstracted study-level information and outcome data, and assessed study quality. Meta-analyses were conducted using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for random-effects models. Quality of evidence was assessed using the GRADE approach.

sections.title: Chapter Two: Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the key questions, search strategy (databases searched: PubMed, PsycINFO, CINAHL, AMED, CENTRAL, and Web of Science; search terms related to mindfulness-based meditation, alcohol and other drugs, and abuse or dependence), eligibility criteria (PICOTSS framework used: Participants - adults 18+ with alcohol, opioid, stimulant, and/or cannabis use disorder; Interventions - MBRP as monotherapy or adjunctive therapy; Comparators - no limitations; Outcomes - relapse, frequency/quantity of substance use, withdrawal/craving, dropout, functional status, recovery, quality of life, adverse events; Timing - any; Setting - any; Study design - parallel group controlled trials, individually or cluster-randomized), inclusion screening (two independent reviewers screened titles/abstracts, then full texts), data extraction (two independent reviewers abstracted data, checked by a biostatistician), risk of bias assessment (Cochrane Risk of Bias tool and U.S. Preventive Services Task Force criteria), data synthesis (random-effects meta-analyses using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method), and quality of evidence assessment (GRADE approach).

primary_methods: U.S. Preventive Services Task Force criteria
analysis.sample_description: Adults (18 years or older) diagnosed with alcohol, opioid, stimulant, and/or cannabis use disorder.  Samples varied across studies in terms of gender, age, and specific substance use patterns.
analysis.analysis_approach: Random-effects meta-analyses using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method were conducted to pool effectiveness results across included studies.  Subgroup and sensitivity analyses were performed where data allowed.  The GRADE approach was used to assess the quality of evidence.

sections.title: Estimating Servicemembers’ Willingness to Engage in Longer Tours
sections.methods_summary: Collaboration with DMDC to develop survey questions focusing on individual propensities to extend tours and influencing factors, particularly for overseas tours.  Used a simple "yes" or "no" survey question to estimate stated inclinations to extend tours. Collected demographic and attitudinal data to explore the impact of financial incentives on willingness to extend.

sections.title: Cluster Analysis Methodology and Results
sections.methods_summary: Used Ward's minimum variance method, an agglomerative clustering technique, to organize observations into clusters based on similarities in multidimensional data (using Euclidean distance).  The Calinski-Harabasz stopping rule was used to determine the number of clusters.  Respondents were assigned to clusters related to attitudinal questions on factors influencing extension decisions, impact of tour extensions, and general attitudes toward military service.  Respondents who didn't answer all questions were assigned to a cluster based on minimum Euclidean distance.

sections.title: 2013 Status of Forces Survey of Active Duty Members
sections.methods_summary: The 2013 SOFS-A survey used a single-stage stratified design.  Stratification variables included unaccompanied tours by country, service, pay grade, race/ethnicity, duty location, and family status.  Within each stratum, individuals were selected with equal probability and without replacement.  Nonproportional allocation was used to achieve adequate sample sizes for key reporting domains. Sample allocation was based on precision requirements for key reporting domains, estimated survey costs, and anticipated eligibility and response rates, using an optimization algorithm.

sections.title: Estimating the Supply of Voluntary Overseas Tour Extensions (With and Without Incentives)
sections.methods_summary: Used data from DMDC's 2013 SOFS-A survey.  A probit model was used to analyze the decision to voluntarily extend tours without incentives, including demographic, attitudinal, and tour characteristic variables.  Attitudes were incorporated via indicator variables representing cluster membership (clusters created using the methods described in Appendix H).  An interval regression model was used to analyze the decision to extend with financial incentives, incorporating additional information from a series of questions about willingness to extend at different incentive levels. Marginal effects were calculated to interpret the results.

sections.title: Estimating the Supply of Voluntary Overseas Tour Extensions with Incentives
sections.methods_summary: Used an interval regression model to estimate the minimum incentive level needed to induce tour extension.  The model included demographic, tour characteristic, and cluster membership variables. Marginal effects were calculated at the mean incentive level inducing a 50% probability of extension for the baseline respondent.  A supply curve was constructed from the results of both the probit and interval regression models.

sections.title: Policy Implications
sections.methods_summary: Summarized the major policy implications derived from the multivariate models, highlighting the influence of demographics, tour characteristics, and attitudes on the supply of tour extensions and the upward-sloping nature of the supply curve.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative sample of active-duty members of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force (up to pay grade O-6), at least 18 years old at the start of the survey period.  Included both those currently serving overseas and those who had served overseas previously.  Sample size of 11,306 for questions related to tour extension.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, multivariate statistical modeling (probit and interval regression), cluster analysis to group attitudinal data.  Marginal effects were calculated to interpret the results of the statistical models.  Steady-state analysis was used to estimate long-run costs and savings of tour extensions.

sections.title: Case Study Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research employed a case study methodology, involving on-site visits to three locations (Newport News Shipbuilding, Austal USA, and Saab Aeronautics in Linkoping, Sweden).  Researchers conducted in-depth interviews with subject-matter experts, both those affiliated with the firms and independent experts on local economies.  Publicly available data and open literature were also utilized. The authors acknowledge limitations of the case study approach, such as the reliance on anecdotes rather than large datasets and the challenges of data access due to the involvement of a foreign government sponsor.  The case studies are regionally focused, providing upper-bound estimates of potential economic consequences.

sections.title: Economic Multiplier Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This section reviews the existing literature on economic multipliers, focusing on studies that utilize input-output modeling techniques (e.g., RIMS, IMPLAN).  The authors discuss the limitations of economic multiplier estimates, including their sensitivity to economic conditions, the potential for displacement effects, and the challenges of capturing long-run benefits and spillovers.  They also explore different theories of technological externalities (MAR, Porter, Jacobs) and their relevance to shipbuilding.

analysis.sample_description: Three case studies: Newport News Shipbuilding (USA), Austal USA (USA), and Saab Aeronautics' Gripen program (Sweden).  Additional interviews and literature reviews were conducted on other shipbuilders (Bath Iron Works, Ingalls Shipbuilding, Marinette Marine Corporation), but these were not as in-depth.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of case studies, supplemented by quantitative data where available (e.g., employment figures, revenue data).  Critical review and interpretation of existing economic multiplier studies and their limitations.

sections.title: Research Design and Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: This report is part of a larger series examining eight domains of Total Force Fitness (TFF) to understand resilience.  The study used a literature review approach focusing on the past decade of research primarily from the United States on adult populations.  Priority was given to literature reviews, meta-analyses, and established research bodies over smaller, singular studies. The search included individual and organizational actions to promote resilience in each TFF domain.  The focus was on stress-buffering aspects of each domain, regardless of whether 'resilience' was explicitly used.  The study did not examine the relationship between fitness and military outcomes like performance or retention.

sections.title: Measures of Physical Fitness and Physical Activity
sections.methods_summary: The study reviewed methods for measuring physical fitness and physical activity, distinguishing between objective and self-reported measures. Objective measures included indirect calorimetry, heart rate monitors, pedometers, gait assessment, accelerometers, and GPS devices. Self-reported measures included diaries, logs, and surveys, with a focus on the International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ).  The chapter also discusses measures of physical abilities (fitness) drawing on Fleishman's work and common tests like the one-mile walk, 1.5-mile run, sit-ups, push-ups, and sit-and-reach test.  The limitations of each measure are discussed, particularly the challenges of using fitness tests to evaluate resilience programs due to factors like body weight and genetic inheritance.

sections.title: Review of Interventions to Promote Physical Fitness
sections.methods_summary: This section reviews existing meta-analyses and reviews of interventions to promote physical activity.  The interventions are categorized into three types: informational approaches (motivational campaigns), behavioral and social approaches (behavior modification, social support programs), and environmental and policy approaches (improving access to facilities). The effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of each type of intervention are discussed, including the use of point-of-decision prompts, community-wide campaigns, family-based support, health behavior change programs, and environmental modifications.  The role of key behavioral determinants (motivation, self-efficacy, stress, social support, time constraints, and injury) in the design and effectiveness of interventions is also analyzed.

analysis.sample_description: The literature review primarily focused on research from the past decade, conducted in the United States, on adult populations.  Studies on children were included when relevant, and some research from other Western nations was also considered.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved a systematic review and synthesis of existing research on physical fitness, physical activity, and interventions to promote them.  The findings were categorized and discussed in relation to the Total Force Fitness framework and the concept of resilience.

sections.title: Study Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Primarily qualitative, due to data limitations preventing statistical analysis of the relationship between narrative and public opinion.  The report assesses changes in public opinion from historical and strategic perspectives, emphasizing social currency of airpower ideas, public narratives, and ongoing military operations.

sections.title: Methodology for Chapter Four
sections.methods_summary: Primarily qualitative analysis of polling data from over 50 opinion surveys conducted over 80 years.  Does not use statistical techniques to explore relationships between social science variables and attitudes toward the USAF.  Does not attempt to measure statistical relationships between narrative changes and changes in public opinion or USAF budget share due to data limitations.

analysis.sample_description: The study draws on polling data from more than 50 opinion surveys conducted over the past 80 years (1935-2014), supplemented by a RAND American Life Panel survey in 2014.  Specific sample sizes for each survey are mentioned throughout Chapter Four.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of survey data within the context of USAF narratives, social currency, contemporary operations, and broader strategy discussions.  Quantitative data is used descriptively to illustrate trends, but formal statistical analysis is avoided due to data limitations.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: A systematic search of electronic databases (PubMed, CINAHL, PsycINFO, CENTRAL, Embase, AMED, MANTIS, Web of Science, and ICTRP) without language restriction to November 2014, as well as bibliographies of existing systematic reviews and included studies, to identify reports of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) testing the efficacy and safety of SJW—used adjunctively or as monotherapy—to treat adults with MDD. Two independent reviewers screened the identified literature using predetermined eligibility criteria, abstracted prespecified study-level information, and assessed the quality of included studies. Outcomes of interest included changes in depressive symptomatology, quality of life, and adverse effects. Meta-analyses for efficacy outcomes and the number of patients with adverse events were conducted using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for random-effects models to estimate the relative risk (RR) and standardized mean differences (SMDs), together with the 95- percent confidence interval (CI). For specific adverse events, many of which are very rare, we used exact conditional methods to estimate odd ratios (ORs). The quality of evidence was assessed using the Grades of Recommendation, Assessment, Development, and Evaluation (or GRADE) approach.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Searched electronic databases (PubMed, CINAHL, PsycINFO, CENTRAL, Embase, AMED, MANTIS, Web of Science, and ICTRP) without language restriction from 2007 to November 2014 to identify reports of RCTs.  Two independent reviewers screened titles and abstracts, then full texts against inclusion criteria.  Data extraction included study characteristics, interventions, comparators, outcomes, and study design features.  Risk of bias was assessed using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool and USPSTF quality criteria. Meta-analyses used the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for random-effects models. Quality of evidence was assessed using the GRADE approach. Subgroup and sensitivity analyses were conducted.

analysis.sample_description: Adults (18+) with a diagnosis of Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), including those with comorbidities.  Studies included various SJW extracts and dosages, with comparators including placebo and various antidepressants.
analysis.analysis_approach: Random-effects meta-analysis using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for efficacy and number of adverse events.  Exact conditional methods used for specific adverse events.  GRADE approach used for quality of evidence assessment.  Subgroup analyses explored monotherapy vs. adjunctive therapy, different extracts, and depression severity.  Sensitivity analyses tested robustness of results.

sections.title: Measures of Food Intake
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methods used to measure food intake, including real-time measures (weighted record technique and estimated record) and estimates of past consumption (24-hour recall, dietary history, and food frequency questionnaires).  It also discusses the use of dietary biomarkers and their limitations.

sections.title: Measurement of Psychosocial Variables
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the challenges in measuring psychosocial variables related to diet, including inconsistencies in variable definitions and the use of truncated scales. It highlights the Food Belief Survey and the Gimme 5 study as examples of multi-item scales used to assess psychosocial constructs in adults and children, respectively.  It also mentions supplementing self-report measures with other data collection approaches (e.g., taste tests, social network methodology).

sections.title: Evidence of the Relationship Between Psychosocial Factors and Weight-Related Outcomes
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the analysis of existing studies on psychosocial determinants of dietary behavior, comparing the predictive value of different theoretical frameworks (Social Cognitive Theory, Theory of Planned Behavior, Health Behavior Model) and study designs (longitudinal vs. cross-sectional).  It summarizes findings from studies on adults and children.

sections.title: Measurement of Environmental Variables
sections.methods_summary: This section discusses the measurement of environmental variables influencing diet, focusing on the ecological framework and existing instruments (e.g., Nutrition Environment Measures Surveys [NEMS], Nutrition Environment Tool [NEAT]). It highlights the limitations of many existing measures in terms of reliability and validity testing and mentions the development of more robust measures like NEMS and NEAT.

sections.title: The Association Between the Neighborhood Food Environment and Diet
sections.methods_summary: This section reviews studies examining the relationship between food environments and dietary behaviors/body weight.  It notes the inconsistencies in metrics and operationalization of the built environment across studies (e.g., use of census tracts, Euclidean buffers, undefined neighborhoods) and summarizes findings on the effects of supermarkets, fast food restaurants, and food marketing.

sections.title: Overview of Interventions
sections.methods_summary: This section provides an overview of the types of interventions studied (environment-level, context-specific, individual-level), target populations, primary outcomes (weight change, weight loss maintenance), theoretical frameworks used in intervention design (Theory of Planned Behavior, Social Cognitive Theory), and study designs employed (randomized controlled trials, nonequivalent control/comparison design).

analysis.sample_description: The study does not involve a new data collection effort.  Instead, it analyzes existing research on nutritional fitness, focusing primarily on studies conducted in the United States and involving adult populations.  Some studies on children and other Western nations are included where relevant.
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis approach is a systematic review and qualitative synthesis of existing research findings on nutritional fitness constructs, measures, and interventions.  The authors identify and summarize key findings from various studies, highlighting methodological strengths and weaknesses.

sections.title: Vignette 3: Invasion Air Defense Analytic Method
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the capabilities and vulnerabilities of Taiwan’s SAMs, including assumptions about missile inventories, engagement rates, and attrition rates for radars.  It details the methodology for calculating SAM engagement outcomes, considering threats from ballistic missiles, MRLs, and SEAD weapons. The analysis incorporates assumptions about radar survivability, engagement timelines, and the effectiveness of air defense platoons in protecting Patriot/TK III batteries.  The method involves calculating the number of SAM batteries and missiles needed to engage specified numbers of targets within two-hour windows, considering attrition rates.

sections.title: Vignette 2: Disarming Strikes Analytic Method
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the methodology for analyzing the Disarming Strikes vignette, focusing on the survival of Sentinel radars and the attrition inflicted on PLA aircraft.  It details the factors influencing exchange ratios between attacking aircraft and air defense platoons, including geolocation accuracy, weapon speed, and weapon effectiveness.  The analysis incorporates assumptions about engagement frequency, radar survivability, and the effectiveness of defensive interceptors.  A parametric analysis is used to calculate exchange ratios and assess the sufficiency of different air defense platoon deployments.

sections.title: Vignette 1: Air Sovereignty Analytic Method
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the methods used to estimate aircraft loss rates in air-to-air engagements between Taiwanese and Chinese fighters. A heuristic approach based on analytic judgment is used to explore force structure implications, considering factors like combat scenarios (2v4), support assets (ISR), weapon effectiveness, and electronic attack. Equations are presented to calculate Pk (probability of kill), kills per engagement, and losses per day.  Data on system effectiveness (Phit, Pk/h, EA factor) are presented in tables, reflecting expert judgment on the relative strengths and weaknesses of different fighter systems.  The analysis considers different conflict intensities (low, medium, high) and scales up loss rates based on engagement frequency.  The results are expressed in terms of aircraft survivability and exchange ratios.

sections.title: Appendix A: Cost Estimation Methods
sections.methods_summary: Three types of cost estimates were conducted: overall funding for air defense modernization, operating costs for current programs, and costs for acquiring and operating new platforms.  These are rough-order-of-magnitude estimates.  Assumptions include a flat budget, 20-year life cycle for systems, and a 3% real discount rate. Costs are normalized to fiscal year 2013. Future modernization funding is estimated using an average of past spending. Current spending on air defense is estimated using cost data from the Ministry of National Defense for 2007. Projected costs for new systems are estimated using Selected Acquisition Reports (SARs) and Foreign Military Sales (FMS) data, using the Program Acquisition Unit Cost (PAUC).

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is not a study involving human subjects.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses vignettes to simulate different conflict scenarios and assess the performance of various force structure options.  Parametric analysis is used to explore the impact of key variables on outcomes. Cost-benefit analysis is used to compare different force structure options.

sections.title: Study Overview and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative analysis of current issues in AF management; review of research literature and clinical guidelines; 60 interviews with doctors, patient representatives, and others; PESTLE analysis of factors impacting AF management; discussion of possible future scenarios for AF management.

sections.title: Study Aims and Methods in Brief
sections.methods_summary: Multi-method approach: literature assessment, 60 expert interviews, future scenarios development and refinement with a steering committee. PESTLE analysis of findings.  Note:  Not a systematic review; sample not representative.

sections.title: Detailed Methodology (Annex A)
sections.methods_summary: The full methodology is detailed in Annex A, which is referenced but not included in the provided text chunks.

analysis.sample_description: 60 interviewees (doctors, patient representatives, and others) from six European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the UK).  The sample is not representative of the entire population of these countries.
analysis.analysis_approach: PESTLE analysis was used to analyze findings from the literature review and interviews.  Future scenarios were developed and refined through a workshop with a steering committee. The analysis focused on identifying challenges and developing recommendations.

sections.title: Frequency Model Estimation
sections.methods_summary: The study re-estimated existing travel frequency models (zero/one-plus and stop/go sub-models) using a revised dataset representing an average school day instead of an average workday.  The models' parameters were analyzed to assess the impact of this change.  No changes were made to mode-destination models.

sections.title: Model Validation
sections.methods_summary: The updated models were validated against 2006 base year data from the Household Travel Survey (HTS).  Home-based tour rates from the models were compared to those observed in the HTS data.  Non-home-based (NHB) models were also validated, and recalibrated to match HTS totals where discrepancies were significant.  The analysis compared tour and detour rates from the models to those in the HTS data, considering both weighted and unweighted samples.

analysis.sample_description: The study used data from the Household Travel Survey (HTS), specifically focusing on data from school days and comparing it to existing data representing workdays.  The sample size was reduced by approximately 20% when switching to the school day definition.
analysis.analysis_approach: The core analysis involved comparing parameters and predictions from the re-estimated school-day models to those of the original workday models and to observed data from the HTS.  This included calculating differences in tour and detour rates and assessing the statistical significance of parameter changes.

sections.title: Summary of Changes and Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the data updates (Household Travel Survey data, level-of-service data, attraction data, car cost data, taxi cost data) and model adjustments made to the Sydney Strategic Transport Model (STM3) to reflect a 2011 base year.  It details the selection of HTS waves for different model purposes (frequency, mode-destination, car ownership), model fit assessment using log-likelihood per observation, analysis of accessibility parameters, treatment of public transport out-of-vehicle time, and changes to the toll choice model.  The methodology is primarily descriptive, outlining the changes made rather than explicitly detailing statistical techniques.

sections.title: Model Parameters and Statistical Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This section presents a detailed comparison of the 2006 and 2011 model parameters for frequency and mode-destination models.  It includes t-ratios for the difference in parameter values between the two base years, highlighting statistically significant changes.  The analysis involves comparing log-likelihoods (LL) and LL/obs to assess model fit.  The implied values of time (VOTs) are calculated and compared to guidance values.  Elasticities (fuel cost kilometrage, car time tour, PT fare tour, PT in-vehicle time tour) are also calculated and analyzed.

sections.title: Car Ownership Model Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the methodology for updating the car ownership models. It details the use of a pivoting approach with updated Census data (2011 instead of 2006) to predict changes in car ownership.  A car availability adjustment is also described, using a pivot-point model to account for changes in commuter accessibility.  The analysis involves comparing parameter values and assessing the statistical significance of changes.

sections.title: Company and Total Car Ownership Model Parameter Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This section presents the parameter values and t-ratios for the company car and total car ownership models, comparing the 2006 and 2011 base years.  It discusses changes in model specification (e.g., dropping insignificant income terms) and interprets the results, including an analysis of car ownership rates over time.

sections.title: Mode-Destination Model Validation
sections.methods_summary: This section validates the mode-destination models.  It calculates implied values of time (VOTs) using a formula that accounts for non-linear cost forms, comparing these to guidance values.  It also analyzes elasticities (fuel cost, car time, PT fare, PT in-vehicle time) to assess the model's sensitivity to changes in various factors.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the Household Travel Survey (HTS) for various years (1999-2013), with different waves of data used for different model purposes and to maximize sample sizes for specific user groups (e.g., toll road users, park-and-ride users). Census data (2006 and 2011) is also used for car ownership calibration.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis is primarily comparative, examining changes in model parameters, fit statistics (log-likelihood), implied values of time, and elasticities between the 2006 and 2011 base years.  Statistical significance is assessed using t-tests.  The methodology is largely descriptive, focusing on documenting and interpreting the changes made to the models.

sections.title: Methodology: Survey Design and Sample
sections.methods_summary: A survey was emailed to all California K–12 public school principals with a listed email address (as per the California Department of Education).  The survey asked principals to rate the severity of various school problems related to student mental health on a four-point scale and to indicate implemented or planned PEI activities.  The survey was open for one month, with no incentives offered.  The response rate was 14%, comparable to similar surveys.  Respondent schools were comparable to all California schools in terms of elementary/secondary school proportions and percentage of students receiving free or reduced-priced lunches.

analysis.sample_description: 1,272 California K–12 public school principals (14% response rate).  Respondent schools were demographically similar to all California schools in terms of school type (elementary vs. secondary) and percentage of students receiving free or reduced-priced lunches.
analysis.analysis_approach: Comparisons were made among responses of elementary, middle, and high school principals.  The report focuses on the severity of reported problems and the implementation of PEI activities, including comparisons across school levels and between schools reporting moderate or severe problems versus those not reporting such problems.

sections.title: Model Validation
sections.methods_summary: Comparison of observed and predicted mean tour lengths for each main and access mode.  Analysis of tour length distributions (detailed in Appendix D).  Model specifications were modified to improve predictions for train access modes based on validation findings.

sections.title: Modelling Assumptions and Data Selection
sections.methods_summary: Defines the study area (Sydney Statistical Division, Newcastle, and Wollongong).  Describes the use of tours and trips in the model. Lists the travel purposes modeled (seven home-based and two non-home-based).  Describes the travel modes represented.  Explains the time periods distinguished in the highway networks. Details the selection of Household Travel Survey (HTS) data waves (1999/2000 to 2007/2008) for model estimation, balancing sample size with representativeness for the 2006 base year.  Analysis of sample sizes for toll road choices and train access mode choices to ensure sufficient data for model extensions.

sections.title: Level of Service Data and Toll Road Modeling
sections.methods_summary: Describes the car level of service data (highway LOS for four time periods, separate skims with and without toll road links).  Details the calculation of car operating costs (fuel and non-fuel components, wave-specific petrol prices, speed-based fuel consumption formulation from Austroads).  Explains parking cost calculations (full and half-day costs, assumed percentages paying for parking).  Describes train level of service data (generalised time function for path building, zone-to-zone and station-to-zone level of service).  Details bus level of service data (bus-only assignment, zone-to-zone and zone-to-station level of service).  Explains taxi level of service data (taxi times equal to car times in toll assignment, taxi fare schedule).  Toll road modeling:  Test runs with varying values of time (VOT) for toll road users to determine appropriate level of service data.  Analysis of toll road usage (unweighted and weighted demand).  Definition of toll and non-toll alternatives based on HTS data (best estimate of toll road usage selected).

sections.title: Access Mode and Station Choice Modeling
sections.methods_summary: Defines access mode alternatives (P&R, K&R, bus, walk/bike).  Describes level of service data used for access mode and station choice modeling (highway LOS for car access, bus-only assignment for bus access, train assignment for train leg).  Explains the selection of station alternatives for P&R and K&R (most attractive stations based on level-of-service attributes).  Merging of bus and walk/bike access alternatives based on model tests (Emme used to determine chosen station for bus and walk/bike access).

sections.title: Model Specification and Exclusions
sections.methods_summary: Describes mode and destination alternatives, including toll road, access mode, and station choices.  Summarizes variables used in utility functions (level of service, cost sharing, socio-economic variables, attraction variables).  Details data exclusions (half tours, lack of attraction variable, destination outside study area, specific mode exclusions, etc.).  Describes structural tests using nested logit structures to investigate the relative sensitivity of different choice decisions.

sections.title: Model Results and Parameter Estimation
sections.methods_summary: Summarizes cost term specifications (linear and logarithmic cost terms, income segmentation, cost sharing).  Describes level of service terms (separate valuations of wait time, public transport constant for UNSW zone).  Details socio-economic terms (car availability, income, gender, age, adult status).  Describes destination effects (CBD effects, income-segmented attractions, school bus usage, large shopping centers).  Presents toll road results (minimum toll threshold, distance effect).  Details access mode and station choice results (analysis of selected stations, car access time parameter valuations, improvements to access mode shares by distance).  Summarizes structural tests (commute, business, primary education, secondary education, tertiary education, shopping, other travel, work-based business, non-home-based business detours).

sections.title: Model Validation
sections.methods_summary: Elasticity tests (fuel cost, car time, public transport fare, public transport in-vehicle time).  Analysis of values of time (VOTs, variation with cost and income).  Comparison of observed and predicted tour length distributions.

analysis.sample_description: Household Travel Survey (HTS) data from nine waves (1999/2000 to 2007/2008) were used.  Specific waves selected varied by travel purpose to balance sample size and representativeness for the 2006 base year. Sample sizes for toll road choices and train access mode choices were analyzed to ensure sufficient data for model extensions.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study used a tour-based approach to model home-based travel.  The model structure included nested logit and multinomial logit components to represent various choice decisions (mode, destination, access mode, station, toll road).  Model parameters were estimated using maximum likelihood estimation.  Model validation involved elasticity tests, value-of-time analysis, and comparison of observed and predicted tour length distributions.  Model specifications were refined iteratively based on model fit, elasticity values, and validation results.

sections.title: Licence and Car Ownership Analysis: Data and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of nine waves of Household Travel Survey (HTS) data (1999-2008) to investigate licence holding and car ownership.  Data exclusion criteria varied by model component (weekday only vs. all days, full response households only vs. all households).  Analysis included examination of licence holding by gender, age, and country of origin; and car ownership trends over time.  Methodology for identifying household head and partner was also explored.

sections.title: Licence-Holding Models: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Re-estimation of two licence-holding model components: a cohort projection spreadsheet and disaggregate models.  The cohort model uses a formula to predict licence holding based on past rates, net acquisitions, and a saturation level.  Data from four waves of HTS data (2004-2008) were used for the 2006 base year.  Smoothing was applied to acquisition rates to address negative values.  Migrant licence-holding rates were analyzed separately and incorporated into the model. The disaggregate model uses two sub-models: one for household heads and partners, and another for additional adults in households with three or more adults.  Model specifications were tested and refined.

sections.title: Disaggregate Licence-Holding Model: Model Estimation and Refinement
sections.methods_summary: Re-estimation of the disaggregate licence-holding model using HTS data (1999-2007).  The initial estimation used the existing model specification, followed by investigation of different specifications.  The final model included new variables for age, work status, household characteristics, and migrant status.  Model parameters were assessed for significance, and some were dropped from the final model.

sections.title: Other Adults Licence Model: Model Estimation and Refinement
sections.methods_summary: Re-estimation of the 'other adults' model (for households with 3+ adults) using HTS data (1999-2007).  The initial estimation used the existing model specification, followed by investigation of different specifications.  The final model included new variables for work status, age, and migrant status. Model parameters were assessed for significance, and some were dropped from the final model.

sections.title: Car Ownership Models: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Re-estimation of two linked car ownership models: one for company cars and one for total cars.  HTS data (1999-2007) were used, excluding part-response households.  Model specifications were tested and refined, with new parameters added to improve model fit.  The impact of income, age, household characteristics, and migrant status on car ownership was investigated.

sections.title: Company Car Ownership Model: Model Estimation and Refinement
sections.methods_summary: Re-estimation of the company car ownership model using HTS data (1999-2007).  The initial estimation used the existing model specification, followed by investigation of different specifications.  The final model included new variables for household characteristics and migrant status. Model parameters were assessed for significance, and some were dropped from the final model.

sections.title: Total Car Ownership Model: Model Estimation and Refinement
sections.methods_summary: Re-estimation of the total car ownership model using HTS data (1999-2007).  The initial estimation used the existing model specification, followed by investigation of different specifications.  The final model included new variables for distance to CBD, household characteristics, and migrant status. Model parameters were assessed for significance, and some were dropped from the final model.  Empirical testing was used to determine the optimal maximum distance for the distance-to-CBD term.

sections.title: Frequency Models: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Re-estimation of frequency models to predict the number of daily trips for various travel purposes.  HTS data (1999-2008) were used, with some models restricted to 2004-2008 data to account for variations in tour rates over time.  A two-stage model structure was used: a zero/one-plus model and a stop/go model.  Model specifications were refined based on parameter significance and plausibility.  Accessibility, measured using logsums from mode-destination models, was incorporated into most models.

sections.title: Commute, Home-Based Business, and Home-Based Education Frequency Models: Model Estimation and Refinement
sections.methods_summary: Re-estimation of frequency models for commute, home-based business, and home-based education trips using HTS data.  Model specifications were refined based on parameter significance and plausibility.  New parameters were added to reflect variations in trip frequency based on socio-economic characteristics and accessibility.

sections.title: Home-Shopping, Home-Other, and Work-Based Business Frequency Models: Model Estimation and Refinement
sections.methods_summary: Re-estimation of frequency models for home-shopping, home-other, and work-based business trips using HTS data. Model specifications were refined based on parameter significance and plausibility.  New parameters were added to reflect variations in trip frequency based on socio-economic characteristics and accessibility (where applicable).

sections.title: Non-Home-Based Business Detour Models: Model Estimation and Refinement
sections.methods_summary: Re-estimation of models for non-home-based business detours during home-work and home-business trips. Separate models were developed for outward and return detours. Model specifications were refined based on parameter significance and plausibility.

analysis.sample_description: The primary data source is the Household Travel Survey (HTS) data from New South Wales, spanning multiple years (1999-2008).  Specific samples were used for different models, often based on adult status groups and travel purposes.  Data exclusion criteria varied by model and included considerations such as weekday-only data, full-response households, and consistent data.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved re-estimating existing models with updated HTS data and refining model specifications through iterative testing and evaluation of parameter significance.  The approach involved comparing initial estimations using existing model structures with subsequent estimations incorporating new variables and adjustments to improve model fit and address issues such as negative acquisition rates or implausible parameter signs.  The final models were selected based on statistical significance and the plausibility of the estimated parameters.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: Retrospective analysis of three large-scale research projects (arthritis, cardiovascular disease and stroke, mental health) conducted over the previous 10 years.  Each study traced research projects (10-20 years prior) to assess impact using the Payback Framework (five impact categories).  Researchers analyzed characteristics of the research, researchers, and research environment associated with high impact in each category.  A total of 63 case studies were included. Comparisons were made across studies, accounting for methodological differences.  Individual case studies were also referenced.

analysis.sample_description: Three large-scale research projects (arthritis, cardiovascular disease and stroke, mental health) with a total of 63 case studies of separate research projects, ideas, or programs. Case studies included a mix of low, mid, and high impact research, selected using various methods (citation analysis, PI surveys, etc.) depending on the study.  The research projects themselves were conducted 10-20 years prior to the analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: The impact of each research project was rated in five categories of the Payback Framework.  Researchers then analyzed what characteristics of the research, researchers, and research environment were associated with high impact in each category.  Findings were compared across the three studies, accounting for methodological differences.  The analysis involved both grouping of findings (e.g., academic vs. wider impact) and separate analysis by impact category.

sections.title: Model Development and Data
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the history of the Sydney Strategic Transport Model (STM), its updates, and the data used.  It mentions the use of existing models (mode-destination and frequency models for commuting, license holding, car ownership, etc.), re-estimation using more recent data (2011 base year), and implementation in Emme code.  It highlights model validation and the iterative process of model application.

sections.title: Licence-Holding and Car-Ownership Model Estimation
sections.methods_summary: Multinomial logit models were used to predict licence holding (for household heads, partners, and other adults).  A two-stage model predicted company car ownership and then total household car ownership, conditional on company car ownership.  The models used socio-economic variables (income, age, worker status, etc.) and accessibility terms.  Specific model parameters and t-ratios are presented in tables.

sections.title: Frequency Model Estimation
sections.methods_summary: A two-stage model (0/1+ and stop/go) was used to predict the number of daily tours for each travel purpose.  Accessibility terms were incorporated.  The models used various socio-economic variables (age, occupation, income, etc.) and parameters are detailed in tables for each travel purpose.

sections.title: Mode-Destination Model Estimation
sections.methods_summary: Multinomial logit models were used to predict mode choice for each travel purpose.  Up to eight modes were considered, with variations for toll roads and train access modes (P&R, K&R, etc.).  The models incorporated cost, time, and socio-economic variables.  Specific model parameters and t-ratios are presented in tables for each travel purpose.  A gamma cost specification is mentioned, combining linear and log cost effects.

sections.title: Model Validation: Implied Values of Time
sections.methods_summary: Implied values of time (VOTs) were calculated for each purpose (except primary education) using mean tour costs by mode.  The variation of VOT with journey cost and income is illustrated in figures.

sections.title: Model Validation: Elasticities
sections.methods_summary: Elasticities to cost and time increases were calculated for the 2006-base mode-destination models (not re-run for the 2011-base models).  First-order effects were considered, increasing times or costs by 10%. Results are summarized in tables.

sections.title: Model Implementation: Segmentation
sections.methods_summary: The population was segmented based on person and household characteristics to implement the models.  Different segmentations were used for different travel purposes.  Mode-destination and frequency segments are detailed in tables for each purpose.  Some socio-economic terms were implemented using mean proportions to reduce computation time.

sections.title: Base-Year Travel Demand Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the comparison of model predictions (tours, kilometers, mode shares) with data from the expanded 2004-2009 Household Travel Survey (HTS). Root Mean Square (RMS) measures were calculated to quantify the differences between observed and predicted values.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the Sydney Strategic Transport Model (STM), updated to reflect a 2011 base year.  Data sources include the expanded 2004–9 Household Travel Survey (HTS).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves model estimation using various statistical techniques (multinomial logit), model validation through calculation of implied values of time and elasticities, and comparison of model predictions with observed data using RMS measures.  The models are implemented using segmentation to account for variations in travel behavior.

sections.title: Study Design and Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: A two-wave longitudinal survey of 2,568 California adults (18+) was conducted in May-September 2013 (baseline) and May-September 2014 (follow-up).  1,285 respondents completed both waves.  Survey questions assessed exposure to the 'Know the Signs' campaign and confidence in intervening with suicidal individuals (7-item scale, 1-7). Weights were used to ensure the sample represented the California adult population.

sections.title: Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Regression analysis was used to determine if newly exposed individuals to the campaign showed increased confidence in intervening, controlling for baseline confidence levels.  The regression model was Y2 = β0 + β1Y1 + β2X, where Y is confidence level, and X is exposure to KTS at follow-up.

sections.title: Exposure Measurement
sections.methods_summary: Exposure to the KTS campaign was measured by asking respondents if they had seen or heard specific advertisements, visited the website, or seen advertisements including the website in the past 12 months.

analysis.sample_description: 2,568 California adults (18+) at baseline; 1,285 completed both waves.  Weights were used to make the sample representative of the California adult population.
analysis.analysis_approach: Regression analysis was used to assess the change in confidence to intervene among those newly exposed to the campaign, controlling for baseline confidence levels.  The analysis focused on those who reported no exposure at baseline.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: A systematic review was conducted using a search strategy across multiple databases (PubMed, CINAHL, PsycINFO, Web of Science, Embase, CENTRAL, clinicaltrials.gov, DARE, and PILOTS) for English-language RCTs published through January 2015.  Two independent reviewers screened studies, abstracted data, and assessed study quality using the GRADE approach.  Data extraction included participant demographics, intervention details (type of acupuncture, dosage, co-interventions), comparators, outcomes (depressive symptoms, response, remission, relapse, quality of life, adverse events), timing, setting, and study design characteristics. Risk of bias was assessed using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool and USPSTF criteria.  A narrative synthesis was used for data synthesis.  The quality of evidence was assessed using the GRADE approach, considering study limitations, directness, consistency, precision, and reporting bias. A protocol deviation involved limiting included studies to those requiring a clinical diagnosis of MDD.

analysis.sample_description: Adults (18 years or older) diagnosed with MDD at the time of study enrollment, with some studies including formerly depressed patients if the primary outcome was relapse/recurrence.  Studies excluded patients with dysthymia, bipolar disorder, depression due to another medical condition, or schizophrenia.
analysis.analysis_approach: Risk of bias assessment using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool and USPSTF criteria.  GRADE approach used to assess the quality of evidence. Narrative synthesis summarized findings for each key question.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A multi-method approach was used, including document and data review, inception meetings, in-depth interviews (n=14), a survey (unsuccessful applicants: n=89; successful applicants: n=37; Call 3 seed-funded applicants: n=2), and an online focus group with 10 DFID staff.  The survey instrument was developed based on previous work, document review, and inception interviews, and modified based on feedback from SIEF and DFID staff.  The online focus group used a protocol similar to the interview protocol, but with some questions transformed into polls.  Data limitations are discussed, including self-selection bias in the focus group, potential desirability bias in the survey, and challenges in tracing impact evaluation costs.

analysis.sample_description: The survey included all task team leaders (TTLs) and principal investigators (PIs) named on applications to the first three SIEF calls for funding.  The online focus group included 10 DFID staff. In-depth interviews were conducted with SIEF staff, NGOs, peers (e.g., 3ie, DIME), and donors (CIFF).
analysis.analysis_approach: Data from different methods were synthesized to answer six core research questions and several secondary research questions.  Analysis included comparing SIEF costs with those of peer funders, examining survey response rates and disaggregating data by respondent characteristics (position, cluster, call for proposal), and assessing workshop data through pre- and post-tests and overall assessments. Qualitative data from interviews and focus groups were also analyzed.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Systematic search of databases (PubMed, CINAHL, PsycINFO, Web of Science, Embase, CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, clinicaltrials.gov, and PILOTS),  using pre-established eligibility criteria to screen studies. Two independent reviewers screened studies, abstracted information, and assessed quality. Meta-analysis using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for random-effects models. GRADE approach used for quality of evidence assessment.

sections.title: Chapter Two: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Database search (PubMed, CINAHL, PsycINFO, Web of Science, Embase, CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, PILOTS, ClinicalTrials.gov) with specified search strings (Appendix A). Eligibility criteria defined using PICOTSS framework (Participants, Interventions, Comparators, Outcomes, Timing, Settings, Study design). Two independent reviewers screened titles/abstracts and full texts. Data extraction using electronic forms, discrepancies resolved by PhD-level staff. Risk of bias assessed using Cochrane Risk of Bias tool and USPSTF criteria. Data synthesis involved calculating SMDs and RRs, meta-analysis with Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method, and investigation of publication bias. Quality of evidence assessed using GRADE approach.

analysis.sample_description: Adults (≥18 years) diagnosed with MDD according to DSM or ICD criteria.  Studies of populations with a history of MDD included if data on depressive symptoms or relapse were reported.  Specific inclusion and exclusion criteria detailed in the Methods section.
analysis.analysis_approach: Standardized mean differences (SMDs) and relative risks (RRs) calculated. Meta-analysis using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for random-effects models.  Publication bias investigated using Begg's and Egger's tests. Subgroup analyses and meta-regression used to explore effect modifiers. GRADE approach used to assess quality of evidence.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The California Statewide Survey (CASS) is a longitudinal telephone survey of California adults (18+) using landlines and cell phones.  Baseline data (May-June 2013) collected from 2,006 individuals, with an oversample of 567 Asian and African Americans (August-September 2014). Follow-up conducted one year later (May-September 2014), reinterviewing 1,285 adults (50% of baseline). Weights were used to align sample characteristics with the California population, adjusting for oversampling and accounting for dropout.  Data analysis involved reporting percentages and within-sample (McNemar) tests for differences in proportions between baseline and follow-up.  Significance tests (p<0.05) were reported unless otherwise noted.

analysis.sample_description: A longitudinal telephone survey of California adults aged 18 and older, with an oversample of African, Chinese, Vietnamese, Cambodian, and Laotian Americans to better detect differences in key racial/ethnic groups.  The follow-up survey re-interviewed approximately 50% of the baseline participants.
analysis.analysis_approach: Percentages and within-sample (McNemar) tests were used to analyze differences in proportions between baseline and follow-up survey responses.  Statistical significance was determined using p<0.05 unless otherwise noted.  Percentage-point changes were presented for comparison with other SDR campaigns, but statistical differences were not tested.

sections.title: Civilian Employment Plan (CEP) Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Mandated methodology by CHCO Ronald Sanders to address congressional concerns.  Agency-specific CEPs developed, aligning with strategic and operational guidance.  CEPs contained four sections: agency overview and strategic link, human capital requirements, current workforce profile and composition, and major human capital initiatives. RAND assisted in structuring CEPs and working with individual agencies.

sections.title: Accounting for Core Contractors Methodology
sections.methods_summary: ODNI initiated an inventory of the contractor workforce using an OMB data-collection template (FYs 2007 and 2008).  A Contractor Inventory Working Group was established to develop working definitions and address data inconsistencies.  An expanded data element template was used in FY 2009 and continues to be used.  The ODNI established a formal policy for integrating core contractor personnel into the intelligence workforce based on mission requirements and comprehensive workforce planning.

sections.title: Workforce Demand Forecasting Methods
sections.methods_summary: A systematic approach to forecasting demand, linking requirements to national intelligence priorities.  Three levels of forecasting methodologies are described: Level 1 (Baseline Data Analysis), Level 2 (Subject-Area Expert Workshops), and Level 3 (Detailed Work Measurement and Advanced Modeling). The choice of methodology depends on the level of detail needed, data requirements, accuracy needs, and timeliness.

sections.title: Aligning Resources with National Priorities Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Utilizes the National Intelligence Priorities Framework (NIPF) to communicate national security priorities.  A RAND-developed 'uncertainty tool' incorporates a methodology to understand risks associated with resource allocation, considering volatility of intelligence priorities over time.  The methodology uses a data warehouse of NIPF data and an analytical tool to create objective and reproducible information that accounts for relative risk. Three types of analysis are described: trend analysis, forecasting and weighting, and hedging.

sections.title: Base Force Concept Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Adapts the Department of Defense's base force concept to intelligence workforce planning.  The intelligence community's base force is derived from CEP data and compares requirements with the existing workforce.  Unlike DoD's scenario-based approach, the intelligence community's base force is based on the existing capability and aims to protect gains from previous workforce rebuilding efforts.

sections.title: Analysis of Department of Defense Military Intelligence Personnel Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of the status of military intelligence personnel at the end of FY 2007, using data from the Defense Manpower Data Center.  Examines continuation rates, year-of-service personnel profiles, and post-service employment patterns for Air Force and other services' intelligence personnel.  Uses gross and net continuation rates to account for interservice transfers.  Analyzes data on security clearance status from the Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System (DEERS).

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from various sources, including the Defense Manpower Data Center, the Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System (DEERS), and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI).  Specific samples include Air Force intelligence personnel, and broader samples of the intelligence community workforce across different agencies and personnel types (civilian, military, contractor).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves quantitative analysis of workforce data (e.g., continuation rates, personnel profiles), qualitative analysis of policy documents and reports, and a comparative analysis of different workforce planning tools and methodologies.  The study also adapts existing models (e.g., the DoD base force concept) to the context of the intelligence community.

sections.title: Research Design and Hypotheses
sections.methods_summary: The study tests three hypotheses related to the National Guard's role in American national security, its ability to prevent controversial wars, and its embodiment of the 'citizen soldier' ideal.  The hypotheses are evaluated by examining historical records and sociological literature to determine if observable implications of the claims are supported by evidence.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses historical data from various periods in the National Guard's history, including the militia era, the volunteer period, the strategic reserve period, and the operational reserve period.  The analysis also incorporates relevant sociological literature on the concept of the 'citizen soldier'.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study employs a qualitative approach, analyzing historical records and sociological literature to assess the validity of three claims regarding the National Guard.  The analysis focuses on identifying observable implications of each claim and evaluating whether the historical record supports these implications.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A multimethod approach including a review of relevant statutes and policies, an analysis of DMDC data from FYs 2004-2012 on military-to-civilian conversions, and discussions with DoD human resource, manpower, and budget experts.

analysis.sample_description: Data from the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC) covering fiscal years 2004-2012 on military-to-civilian conversions.  The analysis focused primarily on conversions filled by federal civilian employees.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis of DMDC data to understand patterns in conversions, including substitution ratios, variations across services, and occupational trends.  Qualitative analysis of expert interviews to identify impediments to authorizing and executing conversions.

sections.title: Data Analysis and Findings
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative data analysis of interviews and web surveys (judges, stakeholders). Quantitative analysis of case management data (regression analysis, chi-squared tests) focusing on remand, sentencing, and health outcomes.  Notes limitations of quantitative data due to missing data.

sections.title: Research Objectives, Approach, and Limitations
sections.methods_summary: The evaluation aimed to compare the National Model for L&D with locally-developed services and to assess the general benefits of L&D compared to areas without such services.  Four strands of data collection and analysis were used: process evaluation (interviews, web surveys of stakeholders and judiciary, service user feedback, case studies), descriptive analysis of the trial minimum data set, before-and-after comparison using the minimum data set, and economic analysis.  The study acknowledges significant limitations due to data availability, lack of a control group, and missing data, particularly regarding criminal justice and health outcomes.  It emphasizes the qualitative data's strength in providing a detailed picture of the National Model's operation.

sections.title: Detailed Methodology: Scoping, Data Collection, and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: A six-month scoping phase involved workshops, site visits, interviews, and data reviews.  Data collection included stakeholder interviews (177 respondents), web surveys (77 stakeholders, 227 judges/magistrates), service user feedback (18 participants), and case studies (impact on courts, role of support workers, referred-to agencies, impact on police custody, L&D pathways for young people).  Data analysis involved qualitative thematic analysis of interviews and open-ended survey responses, descriptive analysis of the minimum data set, before-and-after comparisons using fixed-effects multilevel regression models in four sites, and an economic evaluation. The economic evaluation used a cost-benefit analysis comparing the National Model to local models in four sites, incorporating Bayesian expert elicitation to estimate health benefits due to data limitations.  It considered three scenarios for criminal justice outcomes to account for uncertainty about the counterfactual (what would have happened without the National Model).  The methodology section extensively details the data sources, cost calculations, and assumptions made in the economic evaluation, including the use of national averages for sentence lengths and costs, and the estimation of health benefits using QALYs.

analysis.sample_description: Ten trial sites in England implementing the National Model for Liaison and Diversion (L&D), with a focus on four sites for quantitative before-and-after comparisons and economic analysis.  Data included adults and young people, but the economic analysis focused on adults.  Service user feedback was limited (18 participants).
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative thematic analysis for interviews and open-ended survey responses.  Quantitative analysis included regression models (fixed-effects multilevel models) to account for site-level clustering and time-constant differences, chi-squared tests for comparing proportions, and cost-benefit analysis for the economic evaluation.  Bayesian expert elicitation was used to estimate health benefits due to data limitations.

sections.title: Annex 1 Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study involved a literature review, a scoping workshop with the Digital Catapult's senior leadership team (16 attendees), follow-up communications with key staff, a rapid evidence assessment exploring the relationship between productivity growth and the Digital Catapult's four challenge areas, and the development of a framework for understanding the Catapult's contribution to productivity growth.  Data sources included desk-based research and the workshop outputs. A 'theory of change' approach was used to understand how the Catapult's activities contribute to productivity gains.

sections.title: Annex 2 Rapid Evidence Review
sections.methods_summary: A rapid evidence assessment was conducted to review literature on the relationship between data innovation and productivity.  The search included three categories: wider literature on data and creative content innovation and productivity; literature on the effect of public funding and intermediaries on private sector productivity; and literature on productivity-related aspects of the Digital Catapult's four challenge areas.  Search terms were used across EBSCOhost, Google Scholar, and standard Google search. The first 100 results (ordered by relevance) of each search were screened.

analysis.sample_description: The scoping workshop included 16 staff from the Digital Catapult's senior leadership team and those with challenge area responsibilities. Follow-up communications were conducted with the CEO, Commercial Officer, Marketing Director, and Senior Manager of Creative Programmes.
analysis.analysis_approach: The evidence was analyzed and synthesized within a productivity conceptual framework to contextualize the Digital Catapult's activities and their potential contribution to productivity gains.  A 'theory of change' approach was used to understand the causal links between the Catapult's activities and productivity outcomes.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach combining document review, case study analysis, qualitative interviews, and workshops.  The document review involved examining previous TACTICS project deliverables. Eight case studies were selected based on five criteria (relevance to counterterrorism, deployability in urban environments, use of technology for decision-making, impact on civil liberties, and EU deployment).  Semi-structured interviews were conducted with academics, policymakers, law enforcement practitioners, and human rights experts. Internal and external workshops were held to refine the deployment strategy and policy recommendations.  The case law analysis focused on five European Court of Human Rights cases, selected based on relevance to counterterrorism practices and human rights.

analysis.sample_description: Eight case studies of counterterrorism technology applications in Europe and the US were analyzed.  27 semi-structured interviews were conducted with academics, policymakers, law enforcement practitioners, and human rights experts from various European countries and the US. Five European Court of Human Rights cases were analyzed.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of case studies and interview data; thematic analysis to identify key themes and policy implications; review and synthesis of findings from previous TACTICS deliverables and relevant case law.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Longitudinal data from the Defense Manpower Data Center on officers entering between 1971 and 2005, tracked from 2000-2010.  Regression decomposition methodology based on the Blinder-Oaxaca method to decompose gender differences in career progression into observed characteristics and associations between characteristics and outcomes.

sections.title: Overview of Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Utilizes longitudinal data from the Defense Manpower Data Center's Proxy-PERSTEMPO and DEERS-PITE files.  Data includes occupation, service branch, grade, source of commission, deployments, demographics, and family characteristics. Career progression measured as a series of retention and promotion milestones.  Linear probability regression models used for each milestone.  Data limitations discussed, including the focus on wartime cohorts (2000-2010).

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Blinder-Oaxaca method used to decompose observed differences in milestones for male and female officers into explainable (differences in observed characteristics) and association (differences in the association between characteristics and outcomes) components.  Three methodological issues addressed: benchmark choice, categorical variable specification, and self-selection/endogeneity bias. Linear probability models used with heteroscedasticity-robust standard errors.  Causal interpretation cautioned against due to self-selection and endogeneity.

analysis.sample_description: Longitudinal data on officers from the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC), covering cohorts entering between 1971 and 2005, with career progression tracked from 2000 to 2010.  Data supplemented with DMDC Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System Point-in-Time Extract (DEERS PITE) for family-related factors.  Officers in professional occupations excluded.
analysis.analysis_approach: A regression decomposition methodology, based on the Blinder-Oaxaca method, was used to decompose gender differences in career progression.  The analysis considered ten career milestones, each conditional on the preceding outcome.  Linear probability models were estimated using ordinary least squares with heteroscedasticity-robust standard errors.  The results were interpreted cautiously due to potential self-selection bias and endogeneity.

sections.title: Literature Review Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A review of existing literature on the relationship between financial advisors and savings behavior.  The studies reviewed used various methodologies including surveys (SCF, online surveys, proprietary surveys), and analysis techniques (index creation, regression analysis).  The limitations of these studies, particularly the inability to establish causality due to potential reverse causation and simultaneity bias, are discussed.

sections.title: Literature Review Methodology: Who Saves for Retirement?
sections.methods_summary: This section reviews studies examining factors influencing retirement savings. Methodologies include surveys (TIAA-CREF participants, college faculty and staff, Health and Retirement Study, CentER Panel, RAND American Life Panel), administrative data matching (TIAA-CREF administrative data, college human resources data), and analysis techniques (regression analysis, propensity to plan index creation).

sections.title: Literature Review Methodology: Impacts of Workplace Retirement Seminars
sections.methods_summary: This section reviews studies on the impact of workplace retirement seminars. Methodologies include surveys of corporations, household surveys, surveys of seminar attendees, and administrative data (asset allocation, 401(k) participation and contribution rates). Analysis techniques include regression analysis and comparisons of pre- and post-seminar data.

sections.title: Study Methodology: Marsden, Zick, and Mayer (2011)
sections.methods_summary: Used propensity score matching with data from a survey of 2,191 university employees to control for endogeneity.  Created a predicted probability of meeting with a financial advisor based on various factors. Matched individuals who visited an advisor with those who did not based on predicted probabilities.  Compared outcomes such as savings, retirement planning behaviors, and confidence levels between the two groups.

sections.title: Study Methodology: Martin and Finke (2014)
sections.methods_summary: Used data from the 2004 and 2008 waves of the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth (NLSY79). Created four planning groups based on survey questions about consulting a financial planner and calculating retirement needs.  Used quantile regression to analyze the relationship between planning groups and retirement savings accumulation.

analysis.sample_description: The report primarily analyzes existing studies with diverse samples including university employees,  mutual fund holders,  TIAA-CREF participants,  college faculty and staff,  and participants in various surveys (SCF, NLSY79, etc.).  Specific sample sizes and characteristics vary across the reviewed studies.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report's analysis is primarily a qualitative review of existing literature, synthesizing findings and highlighting methodological limitations of previous research.  Specific quantitative analysis techniques used in the reviewed studies include regression analysis, propensity score matching, and quantile regression.

sections.title: Research Objectives, Approach, and Organization
sections.methods_summary: The author employed an empirical and inductive method to review and evaluate authoritative and current sources of information.  This included an extensive review of publicly available primary and secondary documents, discussions with policymakers and implementers of the strategy, site visits to Iraq, Jordan, and Kuwait, and discussions/briefings with U.S., coalition, and Iraqi officials and citizens.
