Data on anti-ISIL forces was gathered through visits to training sites and commands, briefings from officials, and analysis of ISIL's own literature and statements.

analysis.sample_description: The study involved discussions with approximately 200 U.S., coalition, and Iraqi and regional military and civilian officials, experts, and Iraqis displaced by ISIL.  Informants included officials from various levels of the Iraqi government, U.S. Department of State, U.S. Embassies in Baghdad and Amman, National Security Council, National Counter-Terrorism Center, CIA, Department of Defense, Joint Chiefs of Staff, Joint Special Operations Command, U.S. Special Operations Command–Central Command, Combined Joint Task Force–Operation Inherent Resolve, and Iraqi commands.
analysis.analysis_approach: Inductive analysis of data from multiple sources to evaluate the U.S. counter-ISIL strategy and its implementation.

sections.title: About This Report
sections.methods_summary: Web-based surveys administered to the American Teacher Panel (ATP) and American School Leader Panel (ASLP) in February 2015.  ATP comprised approximately 1,129 teachers, ASLP approximately 557 school leaders.  Respondents received a $25 incentive. Data weighted to account for differential sampling and nonresponse, based on a model incorporating teacher subject, school level, region, size, and free/reduced lunch eligibility rate.  Weights updated in October 2016 to account for misclassification in school-level characteristics.

analysis.sample_description: American Teacher Panel (ATP) of approximately 1,129 teachers and American School Leader Panel (ASLP) of approximately 557 school leaders.  Sample was randomly selected from across the nation and included full-time public school teachers in grades K-12 in all subjects, including special education and English language learners.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data were weighted to account for differential sampling and nonresponse.  Specific statistical tests (e.g., significance testing with p-values) were used to compare responses across different groups (e.g., PARCC vs. other tests, high vs. low FRL schools).

sections.title: Appendix A: Methods for Interview Data Collection and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Annual in-person interviews with central-office administrators and stakeholders; spring in-person and telephone interviews with school staff (principals, teachers, focus groups); semi-structured interview protocols; qualitative data analysis using NVivo 10; thematic coding; inductive coding.

sections.title: Appendix B: Methods for Coding Implementation Status
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of central-office interviews and site documents (stocktake reports, reform status updates); classification of practices as 'implementing' or 'not implementing' at five time points; point values assigned to implementing practices; summation of point values for each lever; conversion to percentages; confirmation of classifications with site leaders.

sections.title: Appendix C: Methods for Survey Data Collection and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Web-based surveys administered to all school leaders and a stratified random sample of teachers; stratified sampling based on subject area and years of experience; weekly contact with nonrespondents; $25 gift cards for completion; calculation of response rates; weighting of survey responses using sampling weights and nonresponse adjustments; two-level hierarchical generalized linear models for nonresponse analysis; survey analysis in Stata using survey estimation procedures; two-stage design with finite population corrections.

analysis.sample_description: The study included three school districts and four charter management organizations.  Interviews were conducted with central office staff, school leaders, and teachers. Surveys were administered to all school leaders and a stratified random sample of teachers.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data analysis of interviews using NVivo 10, thematic coding, and inductive coding. Quantitative analysis of survey data using Stata, including sampling weights and nonresponse adjustments.  Implementation status coded using a point system and converted to percentages. Nonresponse analysis conducted using two-level hierarchical generalized linear models.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study uses school-level data on student achievement, graduation rates, and dropout rates from Florida, Pennsylvania, and Tennessee to estimate the impact of the Intensive Partnerships initiative.  Two primary methods are employed: a school-level difference-in-differences (DiD) regression and a district-level synthetic-control-group (SCG) model.  The DiD approach involves forecasting school outcomes using pre-intervention data and then comparing the difference between actual and forecasted outcomes for Intensive Partnership schools versus comparison schools. The SCG method constructs a synthetic control group from other districts to compare with the intervention district.  Both methods use publicly available aggregate data obtained from state department of education websites.  The analysis accounts for demographic variables and pre-intervention performance.  The DiD method uses a multivariate regression procedure with a district-level random effect to account for correlation within districts. The SCG method uses permutation tests for statistical inference.

analysis.sample_description: School-level data from Florida, Pennsylvania, and Tennessee.  The treatment group consists of schools in Hillsborough County Public Schools (HCPS), Memphis City Schools (MCS), and Pittsburgh Public Schools (PPS). The comparison group includes the remaining schools in each respective state. Charter schools are excluded from the treatment group.  Data from the 2006-2007 to 2008-2009 school years are used as pre-intervention data.  Some adjustments are made to account for the merger of MCS with Shelby County Schools and the transfer of some MCS schools to the Achievement School District.
analysis.analysis_approach: A two-step process is used for the DiD analysis.  First, a linear regression model is fit to pre-intervention data to predict post-intervention outcomes. Second, a regression is run on the differences between actual and predicted outcomes to estimate the treatment effect.  The SCG method involves constructing a weighted average of comparison districts that closely resembles the intervention district in pre-intervention characteristics.  Statistical inference for the DiD method uses a random-effect model to account for within-district correlation.  The SCG method uses permutation tests (placebo effects) for inference.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: This section provides a high-level overview of the methodology, including the use of a common value-added model with teacher-linked data on mathematics and reading performance of students in grades 3-8 from 2006-2007 to 2013-2014.  It mentions examining teacher sorting by value-added, within-school and between-school associations, and changes over time.  It also notes the use of site-provided achievement growth measures and composite effectiveness measures.

sections.title: Empirical Approach: Value-Added Model and Sorting
sections.methods_summary: This section details the two-stage generalized least squares hierarchical fixed-effects approach used to estimate teacher value-added.  It describes Equation 3.1, which models student achievement as a function of lagged achievement, student-level covariates, classroom-level covariates, teacher value-added, and random noise.  It explains the use of weighted least squares (WLS) with weights based on the proportion of the year students were taught by a given teacher.  The method for addressing measurement error in test scores (using two-stage least squares and instrumenting lagged test scores) is described.  The section also explains the three second-stage regressions (Equations 3.2, 3.3, and 3.4) used to estimate overall, within-school, and between-school sorting of teacher effectiveness by student LIM status.  It discusses the choice of using current-year value-added estimates and the rationale behind this decision.  Finally, it addresses the use of site-provided effectiveness estimates (value-added or SGP estimates and composite measures), their rescaling, and the focus on a subsample of teachers for whom VAM could be calculated.

sections.title: Mechanisms Analysis: Changes in LIM Composition
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the method for analyzing changes in the LIM composition of teachers' classes from one year to the next based on teachers' prior performance.  Teachers are categorized into three performance levels, and the LIM composition of their classes in the following year is compared to the current year's composition.  This is done separately for three time periods: prereform, early reform, and recent reform.

sections.title: Mechanisms Analysis: Decomposing Changes in Access
sections.methods_summary: This section explains the decomposition of changes in the association between teacher performance and the percentage of LIM students taught into three components: (1) changes in value added differing between teachers with many and few LIM students ('improve'), (2) changes in LIM enrollment differing between teachers with high and low value-added scores ('reassign'), and (3) changes in teaching staff ('replace').

analysis.sample_description: The study includes three large urban school districts (Hillsborough County Public Schools, Memphis City Schools, and Pittsburgh Public Schools) and four California charter management organizations (CMOs) in the College-Ready Promise (TCRP) coalition.  Data on mathematics and reading performance of students in grades 3-8 from 2006-2007 to 2013-2014 were used.  The sample size varies across sites and years, with Aspire Public Schools having a smaller sample size than the districts.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves estimating teacher value-added using a common model across sites, then examining the sorting of teachers by value-added between LIM and non-LIM students.  Three relationships are estimated: overall, within-school, and between-school.  The analysis also uses site-provided teacher effectiveness measures (value-added or SGP estimates and composites) and decomposes changes in access over time into components attributable to teacher replacement, improvement, and reassignment.

sections.title: METHODS
sections.methods_summary: The study used the COMPARE microsimulation model.  A synthetic population was created using data from the 2008 Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP), the 2010 and 2011 Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS), and the 2010 Kaiser Family Foundation Annual Survey of Employer Benefits.  Statistical matching was used to link datasets.  A utility maximization approach was used to model individual and family decisions. The model was calibrated to approximate the pre-ACA health insurance market in 2010. Premiums in the ACA-compliant market were calculated dynamically through an iterative process until equilibrium was reached.

analysis.sample_description: A synthetic population of individuals, families, health expenditures, and firms was created using data from the 2008 SIPP, 2010/2011 MEPS, and the 2010 Kaiser Family Foundation Annual Survey of Employer Benefits.
analysis.analysis_approach: The COMPARE microsimulation model was used to estimate the impact of two policy options for modifying the ACA's affordability firewall.  The model incorporates individual and family decision-making based on a utility maximization framework, dynamically calculating premiums and achieving equilibrium through iteration.

sections.title: Chapter Two: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used a resource cost model approach to estimate the costs of the CAS-Carrera in-school model.  Data were collected on explicit on-budget resources, in-kind resources, and off-budget resources.  The approach involved creating a comprehensive list of resources, defining each resource with natural units, assigning prices to each item, and calculating total costs. Data collection relied on documents and interviews with the central CAS-Carrera program management team.  A structured data collection form (Appendix A) was used and reviewed by peers and CAS-Carrera staff.  Some key information on resources used by the site program sponsor was not obtainable.

analysis.sample_description: The study focused on one school district in Tulsa, Oklahoma, with a target enrollment of 880 students in grades 6-9 during the 2014-2015 school year.  The sample is not representative and limits generalizability.
analysis.analysis_approach: The total costs were calculated by summing across individual resource ingredients.  Personnel costs were aggregated to protect employee salary information.  Natural units (e.g., FTEs) were used to value resources in a way that is less sensitive to local cost variations.

sections.title: Study Overview and Sample Description
sections.methods_summary: Ongoing study of 62 foundation-funded schools implementing personalized learning.  A smaller subset of 32 schools is used for detailed implementation analysis.  Schools were selected from three Gates Foundation initiatives: Next Generation Learning Challenges (NGLC), Charter School Growth Fund’s Next Generation School Investments, and the Gates Foundation’s Personalized Learning Pilots.

sections.title: Achievement Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Comparison of student achievement gains in mathematics and reading in the 62 personalized learning schools versus a matched comparison group of similar students from comparable schools.  Effect sizes are calculated and statistical significance is assessed (p < 0.05).

sections.title: Implementation Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Data collected from 32 NGLC-funded schools.  Analysis focuses on five key strategies of personalized learning: Personal Learning Paths, Competency-Based Progression, Learner Profiles, Flexible Learning Environments, and Emphasis on College and Career Readiness. Data sources include school administrator and teacher reports, and student assessments (Northwest Evaluation Association’s Measures of Academic Progress).

sections.title: Relating Implementation to Outcomes
sections.methods_summary: Analysis to identify elements of personalized learning implementation associated with stronger achievement outcomes.  Focuses on three key elements: data-driven student grouping, providing data to students and discussing personal learning goals, and supportive learning spaces.

sections.title: National Comparison of Survey Results
sections.methods_summary: Comparison of teacher and student survey results from the 32 schools in the implementation analysis with results from a national sample of teachers and students (administered by Grunwald Associates).  National survey results were weighted to match the personalized learning sample in terms of geographic locale, grade level, subject taught, and gender (family income could not be matched).

sections.title: Comparison Group Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A matched comparison group was used to assess the effectiveness of personalized learning. Northwest Evaluation Association’s “virtual comparison group” (VCG) was used to identify students with similar starting performance and school characteristics to the personalized learning students.  The authors acknowledge potential limitations of this approach, including unobserved differences between groups and the inability to verify that comparison schools were not using personalized learning practices.

analysis.sample_description: 62 public charter and district schools implementing personalized learning practices; a subset of 32 schools used for detailed implementation analysis; a matched comparison group of students from comparable schools.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis of student achievement data (effect sizes, statistical significance); qualitative analysis of school design characteristics, teacher and administrator reports, and student perceptions; comparison of personalized learning schools to a national sample of schools.

sections.title: Workforce Demographic Context and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for analyzing Air Force pilot and maintenance workforce demographics.  It involves examining personnel flow through active duty and reserve components, assessing the attractiveness of airline employment to Air Force personnel, and analyzing the impact of airline hiring on Air Force workforces. Data sources include Air Force Personnel Center (AFPC) personnel files, FAA Airmen Certification Branch records, and publicly available airline data (salaries, hiring numbers).  Analysis includes descriptive statistics (histograms, figures showing workforce distributions and flows over time), correlation analysis (examining relationships between airline hiring and Air Force personnel losses), and comparisons of Air Force and airline salaries.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the Air Force Personnel Center (AFPC) on Air Force pilots and maintainers,  FAA data on pilot certifications, and publicly available data on airline employment and salaries.  Specific sample sizes are not always explicitly stated but are implied within the figures and tables presented.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis primarily involves descriptive statistics to characterize the Air Force and airline workforces.  Correlation analysis is used to assess the relationship between airline hiring and Air Force personnel losses.  Comparative analysis is used to compare Air Force and airline salaries and to assess the relative attractiveness of airline employment to Air Force personnel.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Quantitative analysis of PLAAF SAM training activities reported in Kongjun Bao (KJB), supplemented by qualitative analysis of Chinese and English language resources.  Data collection involved coding articles from approximately 250 issues of KJB from November 1, 2013, to October 31, 2014, resulting in a sample size of 254 entries.  Training activities were categorized into basic training, drills, and exercises. Nine categories were used to capture key training dimensions (mobility, opposition-force, live-fire, nighttime, ECM, complex physical environments, unscripted, combined-arms, joint). A secondary dataset from 2004-2006 was used for comparison. Methodological limitations acknowledged include reliance on the quality and nature of KJB reporting, potential biases in reporting, and the possibility of overcounting due to lack of precise details.

analysis.sample_description: 254 entries from Kongjun Bao (PLAAF's official newspaper) covering SAM training activities from November 1, 2013, to October 31, 2014. A secondary dataset of 88 entries from 2004-2006 was also used for comparison.
analysis.analysis_approach: The data were categorized by type of training activity (basic training, drills, exercises) and by nine key training dimensions.  Geographic and temporal variations in training were analyzed.  The 2013-2014 data were compared with the 2004-2006 data to identify changes over time.

sections.title: Research Methods
sections.methods_summary: The research used a variety of Chinese-language primary-source documents on PLA Army and PLAAF training, operations, and doctrine.  This included daily newspapers of the PLAAF and PLA strategic missile forces, defense white papers, PLA encyclopedias, and books by military officers and academics affiliated with the PLA.  The authors acknowledge limitations of relying on open sources.

analysis.sample_description: Chinese-language primary-source documents on PLA Army and PLAAF training, operations, and doctrine, including newspapers, white papers, encyclopedias, and books.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis of the content of the collected documents to understand PLAAF pilot training.

sections.title: Data Sources and Selection
sections.methods_summary: The report draws on a wide variety of Chinese primary sources, including official PLA media reports (Kongjun Bao and China Air Force magazine), focusing on strategy, doctrine, personnel, education, and training.  The authors acknowledge limitations of relying solely on open-source, official military media, noting both strengths (authoritative descriptions) and weaknesses (gaps in coverage).

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consists of a wide variety of Chinese primary sources, primarily official PLA media reports, focusing on the PLAAF.
analysis.analysis_approach: The authors analyze the content of these sources to understand how the PLAAF selects and trains its elite fighter pilots, focusing on the Golden Helmet competition, Aviadarts participation, and the Bayi Aerobatics Team.  The analysis identifies trends and patterns in the PLAAF's approach to pilot training and development.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This study used a mixed-methods approach over two years (fall 2012-January 2015).  It involved a literature and document review (federal policy, installation and community partnership documents, ICMA data, trade press, media, industry, and academic literature), attendance at relevant conferences (Municipal Partnership seminar, ADC conferences), interviews (60+ OSD, Service, installation, and community staff), and analysis of a database of over 250 installation PuPs (selected to represent diversity across Services, functional areas, and partnership types). In-depth case studies of over a dozen installations were also conducted, including interviews with installation and community members involved in partnerships.

analysis.sample_description: A representative PuP database of over 250 installation PuPs was created, selected to represent the diversity of existing partnerships across all Services, functional areas, and partnership types.  In-depth case studies included at least one interview with an installation or community member directly involved in the partnership.
analysis.analysis_approach: The PuP database was analyzed to understand the range of partnership types, approaches, benefits, and other key aspects.  The case studies examined partnership development and implementation, including benefits and barriers and how they were addressed.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: Cost-benefit analysis using a break-even analysis framework.  Data on costs were gathered from structured interviews with refinery personnel.  Data on benefits were derived from analysis of historical incidents and macroeconomic modeling (IMPLAN).

sections.title: Detailed Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Cost-benefit analysis using a break-even approach comparing implementation costs with potential cost savings from reduced major refinery incidents (MRIs).  Costs to industry estimated through structured interviews with refinery personnel, focusing on marginal costs added by the new regulations. Costs to society estimated as pass-through of industry costs. Benefits to industry estimated by calculating avoided revenue losses from reduced MRIs. Benefits to society estimated by analyzing historical incidents' costs to the California economy and modeling the reduction in the probability of future MRIs using IMPLAN, a macroeconomic input-output model.  Analysis of historical data on MRIs and worker deaths under different regulatory regimes to assess the potential impact of the proposed regulations on safety.  The break-even analysis uses a risk reduction calculation (ΔR = (Pp – Pc)C = ΔP × C), where P represents probability and C represents consequence, assuming constant consequence (Cp = Cc = C).

analysis.sample_description: The study sample includes all 12 oil and gas refineries operating in California.  Data were collected from structured interviews with refinery personnel.  Historical data on refinery incidents and worker deaths were analyzed to compare incidents under different regulatory regimes (ISO and NISO refineries).
analysis.analysis_approach: A break-even analysis framework was used to compare the costs and benefits of the proposed regulations.  The analysis considered costs to industry and society, and benefits to industry (costs avoided and safety improvements) and society (costs avoided and other improvements).  Macroeconomic impacts were assessed using the IMPLAN input-output model.  Statistical analysis was used to determine the significance of differences in incident rates and worker death rates between ISO and NISO refineries.

sections.title: Data and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Researchers used data from the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC), which uses the Contingency Tracking System (CTS) to track personnel involved in contingency operations. The analyses focused on the active components (ACs) of the services, but with particular attention to the Army’s AC.

analysis.sample_description: Data from the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC) Contingency Tracking System (CTS) focusing on active components of the US military, particularly the Army.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis of DMDC data to determine the number of soldiers deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan, cumulative deployment time, and Army deployment capacity.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach. Data were gathered through a literature review and interviews with subject matter experts.  Current Navy processes and capabilities were documented based on military guidance and interviews. Some capability aspects (e.g., transport times) were calculated using spreadsheet models with data from guidance, interviews, and assumptions. No operational tests were conducted.

primary_methods: Data analysis from existing military documents
analysis.sample_description: The ashore force used in the analysis was a Marine Expeditionary Unit (MEU) of approximately 3,000 Marines.  The study assumed 10% of the force (300) were contaminated, including 24 litter casualties and 75 ambulatory casualties.  This scenario also included 100 service members with conventional injuries.
analysis.analysis_approach: The assessment of current Navy capability was structured around four amphibious mission functions: transporting forces, receiving casualties, decontaminating forces, and returning ships to full mission capability.  Data from various sources were used to evaluate existing capabilities and identify potential improvements.  Spreadsheet models were used to calculate transport times and throughput rates.

sections.title: Methodology for Our Review of the Literature on School Leadership–Improvement Activities
sections.methods_summary: The review of the evidence is framed by ESSA funding streams and evidence requirements. Two waves of literature searches were conducted, identifying and prescreening more than 3,500 articles based on titles, conducting a two-stage screening of more than 500 articles based on abstracts, and fully reviewing 128 articles. Two coders reviewed each article, with senior staff reconciling differences.  The final studies were examined by five researchers. The discussion of evidence is organized around three broad categories of school leadership–improvement activities: monitoring whether principals meet performance expectations; improving the likelihood that school leaders meet expectations through effective management structures, operations, and requirements (including principal preparation programs, strategic staff management, professional learning, and working conditions); and improving school leadership through broader school improvement efforts.

analysis.sample_description: More than 3,500 articles initially identified; 500+ articles screened by abstract; 128 articles fully reviewed.
analysis.analysis_approach: Studies were categorized according to ESSA evidence tiers (I-IV), based on study design and findings.  Findings are organized by type of school leadership improvement activity.

sections.title: Motivation and Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the rationale for focusing on school leadership and outlines the approach to assessing the evidence base on school-leadership initiatives.  It mentions a review of the literature focusing on the relationship between school-leadership-improvement activities, intermediate outcomes, and student outcomes.  The approach is guided by a simplified theory of action (Figure 1).

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The evidence review is framed by ESSA funding streams and evidence requirements (Table 3).  The review focuses on identifying and describing studies that provide Tier I, II, or III evidence.  Tier IV evidence is acknowledged as having a broad scope, with a more detailed discussion planned for a future volume.  Table 4 details the study inclusion criteria, which includes U.S. K-12 public schools (including charters and magnets with open admission), relevant outcomes (student achievement, progression, affective outcomes, teacher outcomes), and a recency requirement (documents released 1995 or after).

analysis.sample_description: U.S. K–12 public schools (including charters and magnets with open admission)
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis focuses on identifying studies that meet ESSA's evidence tiers (I, II, III). Tier IV evidence is acknowledged as having a broad scope and will be further analyzed in a future publication.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: The analytic approach involved five tasks: stakeholder meetings to characterize resource allocation problems, data collection from NAVSEA 04 and shipyards (budget exhibits, WARRs, workforce demographics, platform maintenance requirements, maintenance policy), development of mathematical models and analytical tools to test hypotheses, and summarization of results with recommendations.

sections.title: Chapter 2 Methodology: How Is Shipyard Work Changing?
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of man-day trends for each platform and availability type using shipyard WARRs.  Statistical analysis (autoregressive moving average) to identify statistically significant changes in workload over time, considering shipyard, ship class, and combinations thereof.  Review of re-baseline letters to understand causes of increased workload in SSBN maintenance.

sections.title: Chapter 3 Methodology: Are More Personnel Now Required to Perform the Same Work?
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of workforce data to understand the impact of an increasingly inexperienced workforce on man-days required.  Expert elicitation to define relative output of individuals with varying experience levels. Development of a mathematical model to estimate future workforce needs, considering factors like hiring rates, attrition, retirement, productivity levels (based on experience and accelerated training), and NAVSEA's planned workforce.

sections.title: Chapter 4 Methodology: Future Risks and Challenges
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of historical trends in budget increases from initial submission to execution.  Analysis of the aging of nuclear assets and its impact on maintenance needs. Analysis of increased operational tempo and its effect on maintenance.  Review of maintenance planning during acquisition and production.  Assessment of risk using NAVSEA's performance factor methodology.

analysis.sample_description: Data from four US Navy public shipyards (Norfolk, Pearl Harbor, Portsmouth, Puget Sound) from FY2004-2018 (and projected to 2023).  Data includes direct and indirect man-days, workforce demographics, platform maintenance requirements, and budget information.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis using statistical methods (autoregressive moving average) and mathematical modeling to assess trends, test hypotheses, and quantify the effects of various factors on shipyard workload and workforce productivity. Qualitative data from stakeholder meetings and document reviews provides context and explanation.

sections.title: Analytical Framework to Support AFIMSC Decisions
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines an analytical framework built on guiding principles (relating I&MS resources to operational capabilities, integrating expeditionary and home-station requirements, taking an enterprise approach, and focusing on long-range operational objectives).  It analyzes the current Air Force process for determining I&MS requirements (bottom-up) and resource allocation (top-down), highlighting the challenges of transitioning to an enterprise-wide approach. The section also presents a process view of the proposed AFIMSC analytical framework, detailing analytic inputs (demand-side requirements, supply-side resources, and guidance), and the establishment of an analytical capability within AFIMSC.

sections.title: Implementing the Proposed Framework
sections.methods_summary: This section details the three enabling mechanisms for the proposed framework: output-focused metrics (using Common Output Level Standards or COLS), transparent business rules (separating installation and mission support, classifying installations and missions, and developing allocation rules), and a performance-monitoring construct (modeled after the Weapon System Enterprise Review or WSER).  It describes the COLS system and provides examples of its application.  The section proposes a new measurement system (ISCR and MSCR) and outlines notional business rules for determining rating levels.  A step-wise approach for implementing the enterprise-wide measurement system is presented, along with a discussion of integrating the ISCR/MSCR system into long-term planning.

sections.title: Summary of Prior RAND Research on ACS C2
sections.methods_summary: This section summarizes previous RAND research on Agile Combat Support (ACS) command and control (C2), highlighting key findings and recommendations.  The methods involved analyzing Air Force processes, conducting interviews with personnel, and observing contingencies and exercises to identify shortfalls in ACS planning, execution, monitoring, and control.  The section then outlines RAND's recommendations to mitigate these shortfalls, focusing on process enhancements, doctrine expansion, training and education improvements, systems and tools implementation, and organizational strengthening.

sections.title: Quantifying the Effects of Home-Station ACS Shortfalls
sections.methods_summary: This section describes a method for quantifying the impacts of deployments on home-station operations.  The methodology involved analyzing existing Air Force data (manpower requirements, historical deployments, personnel levels) and conducting interviews with subject-matter experts.  Metrics used include effective workload per person, service reduction, backfill funding requirements, training load, and deploy-to-dwell ratio.  The analysis used these metrics to assess the impacts of deployments on home-station operations and to illustrate how these impacts can be mitigated through various strategies (extending work hours, reducing services, backfilling personnel).

analysis.sample_description: The study does not have a specific sample in the traditional sense.  The analysis is based on existing Air Force data and policies, and the findings are generalized to the Air Force I&MS enterprise.
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis approach is qualitative and involves developing a conceptual framework, analyzing existing processes, and proposing a new measurement system.  Quantitative analysis is used to a lesser extent, primarily to illustrate the impacts of deployments on home-station operations using existing Air Force data and metrics.

sections.title: Research Design
sections.methods_summary: This RAND Corporation report examines the governmental organizational structures used during three Australian-led interventions in the Southwest Pacific region: Bougainville, East Timor, and the Solomon Islands.  The research involved a review of existing literature (books, research papers, articles, and Australian official sources), and numerous interviews with current and former Australian military and civilian officials.  The interviews were not for attribution, to protect the confidentiality of participants.

analysis.sample_description: Numerous current and former Australian military and civilian officials with experience in the Bougainville, East Timor, and Solomon Islands interventions.  Specifics on sample size and selection criteria are not provided.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data and existing literature to examine interagency issues, identify successes and challenges, and draw insights for future operations. The analysis focuses on the organizational structures and processes used in Canberra, with theatre-level events considered only insofar as they relate to strategic themes or provide context.

sections.title: Research Design
sections.methods_summary: The research examined governmental organizational structures used in three Australian-led interventions (Bougainville, East Timor, and the Solomon Islands).  It used a mixed-methods approach: reviewing existing literature (published and Australian official sources), and conducting numerous interviews with current and former Australian military and civilian officials.  Interviewees were not named to protect confidentiality.

analysis.sample_description: Numerous interviews with current and former Australian military and civilian officials with experience in one or more of the three interventions.  Interviewees' names were not disclosed to protect confidentiality.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data and existing literature to identify organizational structures, lessons learned, and challenges encountered in the three interventions.

sections.title: Research Questions and Analytic Techniques
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach, combining descriptive, confirmatory causal (randomized controlled trial), and exploratory correlational analyses.  Data collection included administrative records (attendance), classroom observations (instructional quality, time on task, site climate), teacher surveys, teacher interviews, program documents, cost data, and student surveys. Causal analyses compared outcomes of treatment and control groups, while correlational analyses examined relationships between implementation features and student outcomes, controlling for student baseline characteristics.  Multiple hypothesis testing corrections were applied to causal analyses.  ESSA evidence rating standards were used to assess the strength of evidence.

sections.title: Summer Programs Implementation: Data Collection and Measurement
sections.methods_summary: Data on program implementation were gathered through various methods: attendance data from administrative records, daily classroom observations (783 in 2013, 608 in 2014), daily site climate surveys (154 in 2014), teacher surveys (95% response rate in 2013, 98% in 2014), interviews with over 75 teachers and administrators, program documents (schedules, curricula), cost data (2014), and student surveys (fall 2013 and 2014).  Specific measures included teacher qualifications, curriculum alignment, instructional quality (using a rubric), academic time on task (calculated from multiple data sources), site discipline and order (teacher reports), and daily site climate (observer ratings).

sections.title: Attendance Data Collection and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Detailed attendance data were collected for all students.  Students were categorized into four attendance groups: no-shows (0 days), low attendance (1-19 days), high attendance (20+ days), and those who exited the district.  Average daily attendance (ADA) was calculated.  Analysis examined attendance patterns across summers, district differences in attendance, and the relationship between attendance and student characteristics (using statistical models).

sections.title: Causal Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Causal analyses used data from the randomized controlled trial (RCT) to compare outcomes of treatment (offered two summers of programming) and control groups (not offered programming).  Intent-to-treat (ITT) effects were estimated. Multiple hypothesis testing corrections were applied to account for multiple outcomes and time points.  Models controlled for student baseline characteristics (prior achievement, socioeconomic status, race, gender, special education status, ELL status).

sections.title: Correlational Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Correlational analyses examined relationships between program implementation features (attendance, academic time on task, instructional quality, curriculum appropriateness, teacher experience, site climate, discipline) and student outcomes.  These analyses compared subgroups of the treatment group (not randomly assigned) to the control group.  Statistical models controlled for student baseline characteristics to mitigate selection bias.  Multiple hypothesis testing corrections were not applied to these exploratory analyses.

analysis.sample_description: The study included over 3,000 third-grade students from five urban school districts. Students were randomly assigned to treatment (offered two summers of programming) and control groups.  The sample was largely non-white and low-income.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study used a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative (RCT, regression) and qualitative (observations, interviews) data.  Causal inferences were drawn from the RCT, while correlational analyses explored relationships between program features and outcomes.  Multiple hypothesis testing corrections were used in causal analyses to control for Type I error.

sections.title: Methodology and Data
sections.methods_summary: This section details the conceptual framework for nonradicalization, focus group methodology (six groups, 10 participants each), and survey methodology (1200 participants, cluster-based sampling across six governorates and Sana'a).  It also discusses the sample design, including the challenges of conducting research in a conflict zone, and provides descriptive statistics comparing the sample demographics to the 2004 Yemeni Census.  Intracluster correlation and margin of error calculations are presented.

sections.title: Dependent and Independent Variables
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the dependent variables (opposition to political violence and personal choice not to engage in violence) and independent variables (perceived ineffectiveness of violence, perceived costs of violence, social ties, religiosity, and religious conservatism) used in the analysis.  Descriptive statistics for each variable are provided.

sections.title: Empirical Model
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the empirical model used: logistic regression with clustered standard errors to account for the clustered sampling design.  It explains that two logistic regressions were computed, one for each dependent variable.

sections.title: Survey and Sampling (Appendix)
sections.methods_summary: This appendix section provides further detail on the survey instrument, the clustered sampling approach, intracluster correlation coefficient (ICC) and margin of error calculations, and power calculations. It also discusses weighted versus unweighted results to address educational differences in the sample.

analysis.sample_description: Six focus groups (three male, three female, 10 participants each) and a national survey of 1200 adults (ages 18-64) in Yemen. Clustered sampling across six governorates and Sana'a, accounting for local conflict conditions.  Sample compared to 2004 Yemeni Census data.
analysis.analysis_approach: Logistic regression models were used to analyze the data, with standard errors clustered by enumeration area to account for the clustered sampling design.  Margin of error and minimum detectable odds ratios were calculated to assess the precision and power of the analysis.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods approach using desk research (review of EU agency and Member State contributions to the 2015 Commission Progress Report, additional documentation, Member States' drug strategy documents), stakeholder interviews (91 interviews with various stakeholders), a survey of European External Action Service (EEAS) representatives (16 responses), a roundtable discussion with the Civil Society Forum (8 members attended, additional written responses), a public consultation (121 contributions), and consultation with expert advisors (3 experts).  Analysis involved a traffic light assessment of Action Plan implementation and synthesis of data to answer evaluation questions.  Limitations of each method are discussed.

analysis.sample_description: The sample included representatives from all EU Member States, European institutions, EU agencies, EU-funded projects, international organizations, third countries, civil society, and the chemical industry.  The EEAS survey included responses from 16 delegations. The public consultation received 121 contributions.  The sample for the expert consultation consisted of 3 experts.  Limitations regarding representativeness of the public consultation are noted.
analysis.analysis_approach: A traffic light system (green, amber, red) was used to assess Action Plan implementation. Data from various sources were triangulated and synthesized using an evaluation framework (Annex H) to answer the 13 evaluation questions. Limitations regarding data availability and the attribution of observed trends are acknowledged.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Used individual-level data from the 2009-2014 National Health Interview Survey (NHIS).  Restricted the analysis to childless adults in poverty who were not beneficiaries of SSI or SSDI. Excluded 13 states with categorical eligibility for nondisabled childless adults before 2014.  Used a regression-adjusted differences-in-differences approach to model the effect of Medicaid eligibility, comparing changes in insurance over time between expansion and nonexpansion states. Controlled for various demographic factors and nationwide changes.  Addressed limitations related to potential undercounting of Medicaid participation in the NHIS and pre-implementation activities.

sections.title: Appendix: Methods and Sensitivity Analyses
sections.methods_summary: Details sample construction, starting with the 2009-2014 NHIS public-use file and applying criteria for age, income (below 100% FPL), family structure (childless), and exclusion of SSI/SSDI recipients.  Describes the protocol for defining 2014 expansion states, including the process of coding state Medicaid eligibility rules using MAGI conversion plans and other sources to identify states where childless adults were categorically eligible for Medicaid before 2014. Explains the use of MAGI conversion plans as a data source on Medicaid limits and the process of data collection and coding. Presents sample means for insurance coverage and demographic variables.  Discusses the handling of states with missing MAGI conversion information (Massachusetts and Texas).

sections.title: Statistical Methods
sections.methods_summary: Employs a regression-adjusted differences-in-differences approach. Models the outcome variable as a function of state-specific intercept, time effects, demographic characteristics, linear time trend (for expansion states), a binary variable indicating Medicaid expansion status, and an error term.  Discusses the assumptions of the differences-in-differences approach and the inclusion of a linear time trend specific to expansion states.  Addresses potential limitations related to pre-implementation activities and the number of pre- and post-implementation time periods. Describes alternative specifications, including a model without differential trends. Explains the use of ordinary least squares (OLS) regression and the handling of standard errors, addressing issues of clustering and conditional heteroskedasticity.  Uses standard errors clustered by state to account for correlation of the error term within states.

sections.title: Results and Robustness Checks
sections.methods_summary: Presents regression estimates from various model specifications to assess robustness.  Compares models with and without covariates, differential trends, and with/without 2013 data.  Discusses the sensitivity of estimates to assumptions about differential trends and the inclusion/exclusion of 2013 data.  Explores a quadratic specification for differential time trends and models omitting the employment status control variable.

sections.title: Subgroup Analyses
sections.methods_summary: Interacted the treatment variable with indicators for group membership (race, gender, age, self-reported health status) in the differences-in-differences regression models to allow the effect of the Medicaid expansion to vary across groups.  Presents results for any insurance coverage, Medicaid, and private coverage.

sections.title: Differences-in-Differences Effects of Medicaid Expansion for Wider Groups of States
sections.methods_summary: Expands the sample to include states excluded from the main analysis due to pre-existing Medicaid eligibility for childless adults.  Compares estimates for different sample sizes (main sample, including partial expansion states, and all states) with and without differential time trends.  Discusses the implications of including states with pre-existing eligibility.

analysis.sample_description: Nondisabled, childless adults aged 19-64 with family income below 100% of the FPL, excluding states with pre-existing Medicaid eligibility for this group.
analysis.analysis_approach: Regression-adjusted differences-in-differences approach comparing changes in insurance coverage over time between Medicaid expansion and non-expansion states, controlling for demographic factors and nationwide changes.  Sensitivity analyses explored different assumptions about pre-existing trends and the inclusion of specific data years.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research was organized into three phases. Phase One involved developing a baseline understanding of DoD's role in the Leahy vetting process through document analysis and preliminary interviews. Phase Two included interviews with DoD and DoS Leahy vetting practitioners, review of embassy standard operating procedures (SOPs), and analysis of INVEST data. Phase Three focused on identifying challenges and developing recommendations for improvement.  The study selected 20 focus countries based on factors such as Leahy process type, aid amount, and geographic combatant command. Data collection involved interviews with over 75 officials, review of Leahy vetting SOPs, and analysis of aggregated INVEST data.  The analysis in Phase Three identified trends and best practices.

analysis.sample_description: 20 focus countries were selected from 156 countries receiving U.S. military and police aid, considering factors such as Leahy process type (fast-track or traditional), amount of aid received, and geographic combatant command.  The sample aimed to represent various vetting processes, aid levels, and geographic regions. Over 75 officials from various DoS bureaus, U.S. embassies, CCMDs, and DoD agencies were interviewed.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data (including coding of interview transcripts), quantitative analysis of aggregated INVEST data, and analysis of embassy SOPs to identify trends, best practices, and problem areas related to the six research questions.

sections.title: Approach to Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The study used existing data and analysis.  It first identified influential features of transportation and water policies and programs.  It then examined the supply side by reviewing government documents and other sources on spending trends over the past 60 years.  On the demand side, it examined the value and limitations of needs surveys, considering urbanization, technological innovations, and other factors.  It also examined federal decision-making processes, reviewing scholarly papers, government reports, and policy studies. Finally, it summarized recent initiatives and recommendations, evaluating them to identify promising options for Congress and the Executive Branch.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; the study used existing data and did not involve a specific sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative analysis of existing data on infrastructure spending, policies, and programs.  The analysis involved identifying trends, comparing different funding and financing models, and evaluating policy options based on their potential to improve infrastructure investment and maintenance.

sections.title: Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: Examined Single Stop program at four community college systems using program use data from Single Stop's database and administrative data from the institutions. Focused on first-time-in-college students in fall 2014.  Used multiple regression and coarsened exact matching to compare Single Stop users with similar peers. Examined five postsecondary outcomes: persistence (one-term and one-year), credits attempted, credits earned, and ratio of earned to attempted credits.  Also analyzed outcomes for three definitions of Single Stop use and conducted subgroup analyses (adult learners, race/ethnicity, dependent status) and institution-specific estimates.

sections.title: Our Approach to Evaluating Single Stop
sections.methods_summary: Used Single Stop's BEN system data (client intake, services provided, benefit confirmation) and administrative data from four community colleges (demographics, financial aid, enrollment, academic performance).  Focused on first-time-in-college (FTIC) students in fall 2014 due to data quality concerns in earlier semesters.  Defined Single Stop use broadly (all BEN-registered clients) and specifically (benefit screenings, tax services).  Examined five postsecondary outcomes: one-semester persistence, one-year persistence, credits attempted, credits earned, and ratio of earned to attempted credits.  Used multiple regression analysis and coarsened exact matching (CEM) to account for selection bias.  CEM involved coarsening variables into bins, stratifying observations, and weighting observations based on stratum composition.  Assessed baseline equivalence before estimating outcomes using weighted regression models.  Conducted subgroup analyses (age, dependent status, race) and institution-level analyses.

analysis.sample_description: First-time-in-college students enrolled in fall 2014 at four community college systems (Bunker Hill Community College, City University of New York, Delgado Community College, and Miami Dade College).  Sample size restricted due to data quality concerns in earlier semesters.  Further sample reduction occurred due to the matching process.
analysis.analysis_approach: Multiple regression and coarsened exact matching (CEM) were used to analyze the relationship between Single Stop use and five postsecondary outcomes.  Subgroup and institution-level analyses were also conducted.  Conditional outcome means (predicted persistence rates and credit outcomes) were calculated to aid interpretation.

sections.title: Tract-Level Data: Creation and Contents
sections.methods_summary: This section details the creation of the tract-level data file, including data sources (U.S. Census Bureau's Internet-based data portal, decennial census short-form and long-form data, and American Community Survey (ACS) 5-year estimates), conversion of 1990 and 2010 census tract boundaries to 2000 census tract definitions using reweighting and the Longitudinal Tract Data Base (LTDB), and linear interpolation for missing intercensal years.  It also describes the types of tract-level measures included (demographic, social and economic, housing, cultural) and the handling of median caps.

sections.title: County-Level Data: Creation and Contents
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the creation of the county-level database, focusing on the sources of data for income inequality (Gini coefficients from the U.S. Census Bureau and RTI International's Spatial Impact Factor Data, with linear interpolation for missing years), urbanization (Ewing compactness and sprawl index and USDA RUCCs, with linear imputation for missing 2000 data), and segregation indices (calculated from tract-level data using a Stata program by Reardon (2002)).  It also addresses handling of county boundary changes over time.

sections.title: Metropolitan Statistical Area (MSA) and Core-Based Statistical Area (CBSA) Level Data
sections.methods_summary: This section explains the creation of MSA and CBSA level data.  It notes that spatial interpolation wasn't used to address the change from MSA to CBSA in 2003.  Data sources include segregation indices (created using the same methods as the county level) and Gini coefficients (from the U.S. Census Bureau, with linear interpolation for missing years).  The section also discusses handling of MSA and CBSA code changes over time.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from U.S. census tracts, counties, metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs), and core-based statistical areas (CBSAs) covering the period from 1990 to approximately 2010.
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis approach involves creating a longitudinal contextual database by integrating data from various sources, transforming data to consistent geographic boundaries, and using interpolation techniques to fill in missing data points.  Specific indices and measures are calculated from the integrated data.

sections.title: Study Approach and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This report synthesizes findings from relevant research on social media analytic concepts, applications, and challenges, as well as the literature on IO writ large. Literature sources were primarily academic and DoD-sponsored research, but they also included legal journals, industry reports, and some journalistic sources.  Five interviews were conducted with subject-matter experts within the DoD IO enterprise and the functional and commercial social media analysis communities.

sections.title: Social Media Analytical Methods for Supporting Information Operations
sections.methods_summary: This chapter details several social media analytic approaches, focusing on methodological approaches to measuring popular reception of an extremist group’s propaganda, identifying cultural or regional concerns in support of messaging strategies, and solving other IO problems.  Specific methods discussed include: Network description (using hand-curated seed lists to extrapolate and track support networks); Publics analysis (lexical and network analysis to detect, characterize, and map networked communities); Resonance analysis (lexical and statistical measures of the spread and uptake of extremist messaging); Stance analysis (digital analysis of tradecraft in messaging); and Automated image analysis (geospatial detection and mapping of imagery using DNN image classification and geolocation/inferencing).

analysis.sample_description: Five interviews with subject-matter experts from DoD IO, functional, and commercial social media analysis communities.  Note that this is not a generalizable sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: Synthesizing research findings from literature review and interviews.  Applying various social media analytic methods to address common IO challenges.  Combining multiple analytic methods for richer insights.  Using statistical tests to analyze word frequencies, word distance, and other textual characteristics.  Employing machine learning and deep neural networks for image classification and analysis.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section details the conceptual framework, data sources, cost analysis (projected health care expenditures and administrative costs), microsimulation model (COMPARE-VT), and financing strategies used in the study.  The framework involves four components: insurance coverage, healthcare costs, Dr. Dynasaur revenues, and new revenue requirements. Data sources include the Vermont Household Health Insurance Survey (VHHIS), Vermont Health Care Uniform Reporting and Evaluation System (VHCURES), Vermont demographic projections, and Vermont tax data.  Cost analysis projects healthcare expenditures based on VHCURES data and demographic projections, considering various reimbursement rate scenarios. Administrative costs are modeled with four scenarios based on different administrative cost rates.  The microsimulation model, COMPARE-VT, is used to project insurance coverage, healthcare expenditures, and wage changes.  Three alternative financing strategies (income tax increase, payroll tax, and business enterprise tax) are modeled to meet Dr. Dynasaur 2.0 revenue requirements.

sections.title: Appendix: Detailed Approach
sections.methods_summary: This appendix provides detailed information on data sources (VHHIS, VHCURES, demographic projections, tax data), cost analysis (projected healthcare expenditures and administrative costs), the microsimulation model (COMPARE-VT), and financing strategies (income tax, payroll tax, business enterprise tax).  It describes the methods used for projecting healthcare expenditures under different reimbursement rate scenarios, including the handling of inflation and adjustments for unreported costs.  Administrative cost projections are detailed, including one-time costs and variable costs based on enrollment and healthcare utilization. The adaptation of the COMPARE model to the Vermont context (COMPARE-VT) is explained, including reweighting to match VHHIS data and calibration to match 2014 enrollment rates.  The assumptions and simplifications made in the microsimulation model are discussed, particularly regarding wage passback rates and health care utilization.  Finally, the methods for calculating the revenue requirements for each financing strategy are detailed.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses Vermont-specific data to create a microsimulation model representing the Vermont population and health insurance market.  Data sources include the VHHIS (Vermont Household Health Insurance Survey) and VHCURES (Vermont Health Care Uniform Reporting and Evaluation System).
analysis.analysis_approach: The study uses a microsimulation model to project the effects of expanding the Dr. Dynasaur program, considering various scenarios for enrollment rates and reimbursement rates.  Actuarial analysis is used to estimate healthcare expenditures.  Three alternative financing strategies are modeled to determine the tax rates needed to fund the program expansion.

sections.title: Survey Instruments
sections.methods_summary: Details on the survey instruments used to collect data on unit and soldier operational effectiveness.  Describes the different surveys administered (BCTs, Maneuver Battalions, Engineer Battalions, Engineer Companies, Military Police Companies, Individuals), the scenarios presented within each survey, and the specific attributes assessed for each unit type or individual.

sections.title: Research Approach: Stated Preference Methodologies
sections.methods_summary: Explains the use of stated preference analysis, specifically choice experiments, to estimate the underlying preferences of Army officers regarding unit and individual characteristics.  Describes the experimental design, the creation of trade-offs between attributes, and the use of statistical models to analyze the data.

sections.title: The Choice Experiment Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Detailed explanation of the choice experiment methodology.  Covers unit type selection, survey development and validation (including focus groups), sample population description, statistical model development (conditional logit model), interpretation of statistical models, and analysis of qualitative data from open-ended survey questions.

sections.title: Analysis of Qualitative Data
sections.methods_summary: Describes the analysis of qualitative data from open-ended survey questions, categorizing responses into comments reiterating existing attributes, comments introducing new attributes, and comments on scenario clarity.  Explains how this qualitative data was used to validate the quantitative results.

sections.title: Synthesizing Findings
sections.methods_summary: Describes how the quantitative and qualitative findings were synthesized to develop overarching findings and policy recommendations.  Emphasizes the extrapolation from the hypothetical scenarios to real-world implications.

sections.title: Exercise Design
sections.methods_summary: Describes the design of the 360º Discovery Exercise conducted in Canberra, Australia.  Details the scenarios presented (Internet of Things and Intellectual Property), the division of participants into breakout groups with specific goals (deterrence, protection, innovation, economic vitality), and the range of participants involved (public and private sectors, academia, etc.).

analysis.sample_description: The study used a web-based survey of Regular Army, ARNG, and USAR colonels and general officers with experience in various branches.  Response rates were low (around 10%).  Significant differences existed in the average deployment experience between Regular Army and ARNG/USAR respondents.
analysis.analysis_approach: Conditional logit models were used to analyze the stated choices in the choice experiments.  The models estimated the relative importance of various unit and individual characteristics in predicting the choices made by respondents.  Qualitative data from open-ended questions were also analyzed to provide additional insights and validate the quantitative results.

sections.title: Our Approach to Evaluating Startup Tech
sections.methods_summary: This section details the research methods used to evaluate the Startup Tech program.  It describes two main approaches: cross-sectional analysis using doubly robust estimation and propensity score weighting, and difference-in-differences analysis.  Both approaches compare Startup Tech students to similar non-participating students, controlling for various student characteristics.  The study also outlines the key assumptions and limitations of the analysis, including the non-random assignment of students to the program and the limited timeframe of the data collection.

analysis.sample_description: The study focused on a convenience sample of students in a single New York City high school.  The sample included two classrooms of 39 high school seniors in the web design subtrack who took the Startup Tech course.  Comparison students were drawn from the same school, considering students in grades 10-12.  Due to limitations, two model specifications were used: one including students across grades 10-12 with controls for grade and subtrack fixed effects, and another limited to 12th-grade students with controls for admissions track fixed effects.
analysis.analysis_approach: Two main analytical approaches were employed: 1) Cross-sectional analysis comparing spring 2016 survey responses of Startup Tech students with those of comparison students, adjusting for observable differences using doubly robust estimation and propensity score weighting.  Two model specifications were used here, one with subtrack controls and one with admissions track controls. 2) Difference-in-differences analysis examining changes in individual student survey responses between two survey waves (January and April 2016), comparing changes among Startup Tech students to changes among non-participants.  Again, two model specifications were used, one with subtrack and grade-level controls and one with admissions track controls.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach.  An expert panel of 13 practitioners, legal scholars, and technology experts was convened.  Panel members completed a pre-workshop questionnaire based on a literature review.  A workshop discussion followed, exploring the implications of emerging technologies on individual rights.  The panel identified 37 needs, which were ranked by importance and probability of success to create three tiers of priority.  Five overarching themes were identified to structure the needs.

analysis.sample_description: An expert panel of 13 participants from various organizations (practitioners, legal scholars, technology experts) was convened.
analysis.analysis_approach: The panel ranked needs based on importance and probability of success.  A clustering algorithm was used to group needs into three tiers.  Five overarching themes were identified to categorize the needs.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: An expert panel of prison and jail administrators, researchers, and health care professionals was assembled.  A structured brainstorming approach was used to develop a set of research needs. Panelists were selected based on review of published documents and recommendations from various organizations, ensuring representation from both jail and prison settings.  A pre-workshop questionnaire gathered input on mortality types, challenges, and rankings of impact and preventability.  The BJS report on deaths in correctional facilities was provided as background material.

sections.title: APPENDIX: CORRECTIONS MORTALITY DETAILED METHODOLOGY
sections.methods_summary: Pre-workshop activities included providing panelists with materials (including the BJS report) and a questionnaire assessing impact, preventability, and challenges associated with minimizing different mortality types.  The workshop involved two breakout groups (jails and prisons) discussing issues and identifying needs. A modified Delphi method was used, involving individual assessments of needs on a 1-9 scale for importance, technical feasibility, and operational feasibility.  A web-based survey (Qualtrics) was used for this assessment.  Results were summarized, and panelists discussed areas of disagreement. A second round of responses was collected, and needs were clustered into tiers using median expected value (EV) scores.  Algorithmic clustering was initially used, but manual tier cutoffs were chosen to avoid disproportionately weighting needs from one group over the other.  Closely related needs from both groups were combined, retaining the highest assigned tier.

analysis.sample_description: An expert panel of 16 participants (prison and jail administrators, researchers, and healthcare professionals) was convened.  The panel aimed for representation from both jail and prison settings.
analysis.analysis_approach: Needs were ranked based on expected benefit and probability of success (technical and operational feasibility).  An expected value score was calculated and used to group needs into tiers.  A modified Delphi method was used to achieve consensus and allow for dissenting views.  Algorithmic and manual clustering methods were used to categorize needs into priority tiers.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study uses satellite-based remote sensing methodologies to analyze economic activity in Iraq and Syria.  It combines publicly available low-resolution data with high-resolution commercial imagery data to create indicators of economic activity (industrial activity, agricultural activity, population levels, electrification, market activity, building damage, and commercial vehicle counts).  Statistical methods are used to analyze how economic activity changes with ISIL control and in five case study cities (Mosul, Raqqah, Ramadi, Deir ez-Zor, and Tikrit).

sections.title: Measuring the Islamic State’s Control of Territory; Violence and Control; The Islamic State’s Impact on Electricity Consumption; The Islamic State’s Impact on Population Movements; The Islamic State’s Impact on Agricultural Activity
sections.methods_summary: Data on ISIL territorial control is created using publicly available media reports.  An event study methodology and linear regression are used to analyze violence levels associated with ISIL takeover and retreat. Fixed-effects regression and duration treatment modeling are used to examine ISIL's impact on nighttime lighting (electricity consumption), LandScan population data (population levels), and NDVI (agricultural activity).  A long-difference specification is used to compare 2008 and 2016 population levels.

sections.title: Methodological Considerations for Within-City Analysis of Remote Sensing Data
sections.methods_summary: To analyze within-city variation, the study resamples nighttime lighting and LandScan population raster data sets to a higher resolution (30m x 30m). Area-weighted averages are used when calculating average values across infrastructure types or zones. Regression analyses correct for spatial autocorrelation using Moran's I to calculate an effective sample size.

sections.title: Analysis Sample
sections.methods_summary: The analysis sample includes all cities in Iraq and Syria with populations greater than 10,000, based on the GeoNames database.  Urban core and periphery borders were manually drawn using pre-ISIL satellite imagery.  Overlapping periphery zones were partitioned using Thiessen polygons.

analysis.sample_description: All cities in Iraq and Syria with populations exceeding 10,000 inhabitants, as identified from the GeoNames database.  Five case study cities: Mosul, Raqqah, Ramadi, Deir ez-Zor, and Tikrit.
analysis.analysis_approach: Panel data analysis, event study analysis, fixed-effects regression, duration treatment effect modeling, and detailed case studies combining quantitative and qualitative data.

sections.title: Overview of Methods and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study uses 2014 prescription drug utilization and spending data from the Workers' Compensation Information System (WCIS).  A series of sequential adjustments are applied to model the formulary's effects on prescriber decisionmaking, prescription fills, and spending.  The adjustments are informed by literature review and expert opinion. Five modeling modules are applied sequentially: physician dispensing, generic substitution, prospective review, bulk drug, and preferred drug modules.  The IMPLAN macroeconomic model is used to estimate broader economic impacts.

sections.title: Modeling
sections.methods_summary:
The analysis uses a five-module approach applied sequentially to the baseline data (2014 WCIS data adjusted for fee schedule changes).  Each module models a specific aspect of the formulary: 
1. **Physician Dispensing Module:** Reduces physician-dispensed prescriptions, shifting some to pharmacy-dispensed alternatives. 
2. **Generic Substitution Module:** Shifts volume from brand-name to generic drugs. 
3. **Prospective Review Module:** Reduces prescription fill volume for drugs subject to prospective review (PR), shifting some to preferred drugs. 
4. **Bulk Drug Module:** Reduces volume of bulk drug ingredients used in compounded drugs. 
5. **Preferred Drug Module:** Increases volume of prescription fills for preferred drugs.  The IMPLAN macroeconomic input-output model is used to convert changes in prescription drug spending into broader impacts on Gross State Product (GSP) and employment. Sensitivity analyses are conducted by varying key assumptions in each module.

sections.title: Data and Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: Primary data source is the Workers' Compensation Information System (WCIS) database, containing comprehensive information on prescription fills from claims administrators.  Data includes physician-dispensed and pharmacy-dispensed fills, with National Drug Codes (NDCs). The study uses 2014 data, acknowledging limitations such as potential underreporting of claims and medical bills.  The California WC drug listing file (February 2017) is used to categorize drugs based on formulary provisions (preferred/non-preferred, special/perioperative fill).

analysis.sample_description: 2014 California Workers' Compensation Information System (WCIS) data on outpatient prescription drug utilization and spending.
analysis.analysis_approach: Sequential application of five modeling modules to estimate the impact of a formulary on prescription drug utilization and spending, followed by macroeconomic impact assessment using the IMPLAN model. Sensitivity analyses are performed to assess the impact of varying key assumptions.

sections.title: Methodological Approach
sections.methods_summary: A rapid evidence review was conducted, drawing on scholarly and grey literature (149 articles, reports, and web pages).  57 articles and reports underwent systematic data extraction after full-text review; the remainder were analyzed for complementary thematic insights.  Findings were enriched with insights from 12 key informant interviews and a project roundtable discussion with 22 participants.

analysis.sample_description: 12 key informant interviews with representatives from academia, patient associations, government/policy, and the private sector.  22 participants from diverse stakeholder groups at a roundtable discussion.
analysis.analysis_approach: Thematic analysis of scholarly and grey literature; findings from the literature were enriched with insights from interviews and the roundtable discussion.

sections.title: Appendix A: Personnel Database Descriptions
sections.methods_summary: Data from the Army's Total Army Personnel Database (TAPDB) and Regular Army (RA) Analyst files, as well as test scores from Defense Manpower Data Center’s Military Entrance Processing Command file were used.  The sample included non-prior service accessions who enlisted in the regular Army from FY 2001 to FY 2015.  Observations with missing data for key variables were excluded. The American Community Survey (ACS) data (2010-2014) was used to analyze civilian cyber jobs.  ACS data was weighted to be representative of the U.S. population.

sections.title: Appendix B: Regression Results
sections.methods_summary: Logistic (logit) regression models were used to analyze continuation rates as a function of soldier characteristics (gender, age at entry, AFQT score), length of initial contract, fiscal year of accession, and an indicator of qualification for 17C.  Continuation was coded as 1 for soldiers who continued in the Army and 0 otherwise.  Marginal effects were calculated to determine the differences in continuation rates between those who qualified for 17C and those who did not, holding other factors constant.

sections.title: Methodology: Qualifying for Cyber Operations Specialist MOS
sections.methods_summary: Army personnel data (FY 2001-2015) were used to determine the proportion of new enlistees meeting the 17C MOS criteria.  A comparison group of MOSs with similar attributes (skills or training pipeline length) was selected.  The proportion of enlistees meeting the criteria for each MOS was calculated.  Analysis focused on the impact of test score requirements, education credentials, citizenship, and waivers on qualification rates.
