The distribution of line scores among enlistees was analyzed to assess the sufficiency of the potential supply under various enlistment criteria.

sections.title: Methodology: Retention in Cyber-Relevant Occupations
sections.methods_summary: Army personnel data were used to analyze attrition and continuation rates among soldiers qualified for 17C and those in other cyber-relevant occupations.  Attrition was defined as leaving the Army before completing the first term for reasons classified as failure to adapt. Continuation was defined as remaining in the Army.  Regression models were used to analyze the relationship between personal characteristics and continuation rates, controlling for initial obligation length.  Predicted differences in continuation rates between 17C-qualified and non-qualified soldiers were calculated.

analysis.sample_description: The study used Army personnel data from FY 2001-2015 for enlisted accessions and American Community Survey (ACS) data from 2010-2014.  The sample included non-prior service enlisted accessions in the regular Army.  For civilian data, the sample included full-time workers in IT-related occupations, with a focus on information security analysts. A subset of civilian workers mirroring the demographic characteristics of enlisted soldiers (age 20-34, high school diploma but no four-year college degree) was also analyzed.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study used descriptive statistics to analyze qualification rates and continuation rates.  Logistic regression models were used to analyze the relationship between soldier characteristics and continuation rates.  Comparative analysis was used to compare the qualification rates of 17C with other MOSs and to compare military pay with civilian wages in relevant occupations.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This project uses a qualitative approach to understand what would convince North Korean elites that unification would be beneficial.  It analyzes North Korean regime statements, media coverage of North Korean and other elites' attitudes, and draws on a previous report by the author.  The author postulates conditions for elite acceptance of unification, then tests these presumptions through interviews with approximately a dozen North Korean elite defectors from various backgrounds.  Two case studies (NKPA generals and North Korean physicians) are used to illustrate the conditions and policies needed.

analysis.sample_description: Approximately a dozen North Korean elite defectors from university, scientific, diplomatic, security, military, and merchant communities.
analysis.analysis_approach: The author postulates conditions for elite acceptance of unification based on existing literature and regime statements. These presumptions are then tested and refined through interviews with North Korean elite defectors.  Case studies of NKPA generals and North Korean physicians illustrate the application of the findings.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The Criminal Justice Technology Forecasting Group (CJTFG) held four meetings (three in-person, one virtual). Meetings 1 and 2 involved guest speakers and breakout groups focusing on specific technology areas and their potential impact. Meeting 3 used a structured discussion to develop trends, impacts, and potential responses, employing a Futures Wheel concept and mind-mapping tool to capture deliberations.  Post-meeting 3, analysis involved reviewing the mind map, creating a social network using NodeXL, and performing analyses to consolidate trends into themes and identify central trends.

sections.title: Technical Appendix
sections.methods_summary: Details the methodology of meetings 1-3. Meetings 1 and 2 used guest speakers and breakout groups to identify trends and impacts. Meeting 3 used a structured discussion guided by a Futures Wheel and mind mapping to capture trends, impacts, responses, and relationships. Post-meeting 3 analysis involved reviewing the mind map, creating a social network using NodeXL, clustering trends into themes, and identifying central trends using eigenvector centrality.  The appendix also describes the process of identifying recommendations and action items, emphasizing criteria for selecting recommendations (specific, substantive, comprehensive, non-redundant).

analysis.sample_description: The Criminal Justice Technology Forecasting Group (CJTFG) comprised practitioners and researchers in criminal justice.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of CJTFG discussions, social network analysis to identify relationships between trends and themes, and centrality analysis to identify key trends.

sections.title: Methods and Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used in the study, focusing on the updated Coastal Louisiana Risk Assessment (CLARA) model (version 2.0).  It describes the model's structure, including input preprocessing (combining storm parameters with historical data), flood depth estimation (considering overtopping and system fragility using Monte Carlo simulation and bootstrapping), and economic damage assessment (based on FEMA Hazus).  The section also explains data sources and updates for coastal Mississippi, including asset inventories (residential structures, vehicles, transportation infrastructure), and the conversion of data to CLARA 2.0 grid resolution.  Finally, it outlines assumptions about future scenario conditions (sea level rise, land subsidence, asset growth), enclosed area hurricane protection heights, parametric uncertainty, and the experimental design (evaluating a future without action and five proposed barrier configurations using ADCIRC and SWAN hydrodynamic models).

analysis.sample_description: The study used a sample of 77 simulated coastal storms (eastern half of set 11 from the CLARA Model Improvement Plan report) for the analysis.  These storms varied in central pressure (900 to 960 millibars) and storm size (radius of maximum winds).  The study area included portions of coastal Louisiana and Hancock, Harrison, and Jackson counties in Mississippi.
analysis.analysis_approach: The CLARA 2.0 model was used to estimate storm surge and wave heights, flood depths, and direct economic damage at various annual exceedance probabilities (AEPs) (10, 50, 100, and 500-year).  The analysis compared a future without action (FWOA) scenario with five proposed barrier configurations.  Parametric uncertainty was incorporated to provide a range of damage and damage reduction estimates.  Results were aggregated by parish or county to assess regional impacts.

sections.title: Appendix A: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Two online surveys were conducted, one for academic researchers and one for industry researchers.  For academic researchers, a stratified sample of HEIs, PSREs, and RIs was selected based on geographic region, research income, and institution size, prioritizing institutions with a high proportion of international staff.  The survey was distributed via central contacts at the institutions and through social media. For industry researchers, a sample of R&D-intensive companies was selected based on size and R&D intensity, and approached through various channels.  Both surveys used branching logic to minimize respondent burden. Data analysis for the academic survey was conducted using R, including descriptive statistics, cross-question analysis, and chi-squared tests where appropriate. The industry survey data, due to low response rates, was not formally analyzed quantitatively.

sections.title: Appendix B: Respondent profile and characteristics
sections.methods_summary: This section details the characteristics of the academic survey respondents and compares them to national-level data from the Higher Education Statistics Agency (HESA) to assess the representativeness of the sample.  It provides information on the number of responses, institutional affiliations, disciplines, career stages, personal demographics (gender, age, relationship status, children, nationality, ethnicity), and discusses the over- and under-representation of certain groups in the sample compared to the overall UK researcher population.

analysis.sample_description: The academic survey sample was stratified by geographic region, research income, institution size, and aimed to include a mix of UK and non-UK nationals and diverse mobility experiences.  The industry survey sample was stratified by company size and R&D intensity.  Both samples were not designed to be fully representative of the UK researcher population.
analysis.analysis_approach: For the academic survey, data analysis involved descriptive statistics, cross-question analysis to examine relationships between variables, and chi-squared tests for statistical significance testing.  The industry survey data was not formally analyzed due to low response rates.

sections.title: Appendix A: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Two online surveys were conducted, one for academic researchers and one for industry researchers.  For academic researchers, a stratified sample of Higher Education Institutions (HEIs), Public Sector Research Establishments (PSREs), and Research Institutes (RIs) was selected based on geographic region, research income, and institution size.  The survey was distributed via central contacts at the institutions and through social media.  For industry researchers, a sample of R&D-intensive organizations was selected based on size and R&D intensity. The survey was distributed through various channels, including sector-level bodies and networks.  Both surveys used branching logic to minimize respondent burden. Data analysis for the academic survey was conducted using R, including descriptive statistics, cross-question analysis, and chi-squared tests where appropriate. The industry survey data, due to low response rates, was not formally analyzed quantitatively.

sections.title: Appendix B: Respondent profile and characteristics
sections.methods_summary: This section details the characteristics of the academic survey respondents and compares them to national-level data from the Higher Education Statistics Agency (HESA) to assess the representativeness of the sample.  It provides information on the number of responses, institutional affiliations, disciplines, career stages, personal demographics (gender, age, relationship status, children, nationality, ethnicity), and discusses the over- and under-representation of certain groups in the sample compared to the population.

analysis.sample_description: The academic survey sample was stratified by geographic region, research income, and institution size to include HEIs, PSREs, and RIs, aiming for a mix of UK and non-UK nationals and diverse mobility experiences. The industry survey sample was stratified by size and R&D intensity, targeting R&D-intensive organizations.  Appendix B details the sample characteristics and compares them to national data, revealing over-representation of certain groups (e.g., life sciences researchers, women, EU nationals, white ethnicity) and under-representation of others (e.g., social sciences researchers, men, UK nationals, black and Asian ethnicities).
analysis.analysis_approach: For the academic survey, data analysis was performed using R.  Methods included descriptive statistics, cross-question analysis (exploring relationships between variables), and chi-squared tests (for statistical significance testing).  Qualitative analysis was also used to interpret open-ended responses. The industry survey data was not formally analyzed due to low response rates.

sections.title: Preface and Executive Summary
sections.methods_summary: The preface mentions the collaboration between RAND Europe and the London School of Economics, and that the study was funded by the UK's Prosperity Fund.  The executive summary provides an overview of the research findings but does not detail the methodology.

sections.title: Overview of Air Transportation Sector
sections.methods_summary: This section provides background information on the air transportation sector in Brazil, citing sources such as the CIA World Factbook, Steer Davies Gleave, and Morgan Stanley.  It does not describe the research methods used in the study.

sections.title: Chapter 6 Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This chapter describes the research methods used in the study.  The authors state that their analysis is based on a document review and interviews conducted in Brasilia with key stakeholders in November 2016.  They also mention the use of data from various sources, including the World Bank's Logistics Performance Index (LPI).

analysis.sample_description: Interviews were conducted in Brasilia with key stakeholders in November 2016.  The exact number of interviewees is not specified, but the report mentions multiple respondents.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis is based on a review of documents and interviews.  Data from sources like the World Bank's LPI are also used to support the analysis.  The report does not explicitly mention specific statistical techniques beyond descriptive statistics.

sections.title: Appendix A: Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used in the study, including program selection (four steps: creating a master list of programs, reviewing program descriptions, searching literature databases, and screening full-text publications), data abstraction (using a protocol and a team of analysts), effect size calculation and meta-analysis (using Cohen's d, 95% confidence intervals, p-values, and CMA software), and economic evaluation methods (identifying formal cost analyses, CEAs, and BCAs).

analysis.sample_description: The study included 115 early childhood programs serving children from the prenatal period to age 5.  The programs encompassed various approaches (ECE, home visiting, parent education, transfers, and combinations).  A total of 3,183 child outcomes were measured across 269 publications and 312 individual abstractions. For effect size calculations, data from 95 outcomes were identified, with 85 having sufficient data to calculate effect sizes.  25 of the 115 programs had formal economic evaluations.
analysis.analysis_approach: Meta-analysis and meta-regression were used to synthesize the evidence for program impacts.  A random-effects model was employed in the Comprehensive Meta-Analysis (CMA) software to calculate pooled effect sizes.  Economic evaluations included cost analyses, CEAs, and BCAs, with the societal perspective generally adopted for BCAs.  Sensitivity analyses were conducted to assess the robustness of estimates to various assumptions.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: From June to August 2017, RAND conducted in-person site visits with CBOs and their MHPs, including key informant interviews and focus groups with leadership, staff, and clients.  Interview guides were used, tested in previous evaluations and adapted for C2C. Qualitative data was collected on implementation experiences, training, service delivery, crisis management, collaboration, client engagement, and client perspectives. Thematic analysis using Dedoose software was employed to identify recurring patterns. A team of four coders conducted iterative rounds of data analysis to develop a hierarchical code tree.  This report focuses on interviews with 35 CBO leaders from 15 CBOs.

analysis.sample_description: 35 CBO leaders from 15 CBOs;  additional interviews with MHP leadership, CBO staff, and CBO clients were ongoing.
analysis.analysis_approach: Thematic analysis using Dedoose software to identify recurring patterns in qualitative data. Iterative rounds of data analysis by a team of four coders to develop a hierarchical code tree.

sections.title: Survey of Foreign Hypersonic Activity
sections.methods_summary: A literature review of aerospace periodicals from 2000-2016 was conducted to gather information on foreign hypersonic programs.  The review focused on technological capabilities, R&D programs, projected capabilities, wind tunnel facilities, testing ranges, and rationales for developing hypersonic technology.  Information was gathered from various sources including Defense & Aerospace Week, Aviation Week & Space Technology, Aerospace America, and websites of relevant organizations and universities.

analysis.sample_description: The sample consisted of aerospace periodicals and websites of relevant organizations and universities published between 2000 and 2016.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved a descriptive review of the collected data to identify trends and the scope of hypersonic developments across different countries.

sections.title: Decision Support Tool Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The DST uses a methodology successfully deployed for Louisiana's Coastal Master Plan. It summarizes baseline risks and investment effects, allowing users to specify priorities and assumptions for transparent comparison of results across different metrics.  It supports deliberations by summarizing information about baseline risks and the effects of different investments on baseline risk, and then identifying portfolios of investments that reflect State interests. The user can specify priorities over performance metrics and assumptions about future risks.

sections.title: Risk Evaluation Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The analysis prioritizes investments based on their effectiveness in reducing flood risks to lives, property, water supply, and Delta ecosystem function.  It uses a probability × consequence framework to calculate risk, with proxy metrics for water supply and Delta as Place (DAP) due to data limitations. Risk calculations are performed for current (2012), near-term (2030), and long-term (2050) conditions, incorporating sea level rise projections.  Specific metrics include Expected Annual Fatalities (EAF), Expected Annual Damage (EAD), probability of flooding for water supply and DAP, and expected flooding of high-value non-tidal habitat.  Uncertainty analysis considers factors like levee fragility, seismic events, and population projections.  The DST uses risk thresholds and user-specified weights to aggregate risks and develop investment portfolios based on cost-effectiveness (CE) scores.

analysis.sample_description: The study includes over 170 islands and tracts in the Sacramento–San Joaquin Delta.  Data used includes 2010 census data, 2012 sea levels, and asset inventories. Future projections are based on California Department of Finance population projections and sea level rise estimates.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a decision support tool (DST) to explore flood risk and investment options.  The DST incorporates probability of flooding estimates, asset vulnerability data, and investment costs to calculate risk metrics.  Users can adjust weights for different risk metrics and explore different investment portfolios based on cost-effectiveness thresholds.

sections.title: Methodology: Discrete Choice Experiment and Follow-up Questions
sections.methods_summary: A discrete choice experiment (DCE) was conducted via an emailed survey. Employers were presented with hypothetical job candidates with a nonviolent felony conviction, each supported by different policy features (tax credit or staffing agency discount).  Employers ranked candidates based on likelihood of advancement. A conditional logit model was used for analysis. Follow-up questions assessed employer considerations when hiring workers with criminal records using a Likert scale and ranking tasks.

sections.title: Methodology: Study Participants and Sampling
sections.methods_summary: A stratified random sample of employers from Hoover's database was used, stratified by establishment size and industry using Bureau of Labor Statistics data.  The survey was emailed to primarily private-sector firms (97%).

sections.title: Methodology: Survey Design and Procedure
sections.methods_summary: Two survey-based, modified-discrete choice experiments were conducted, one focusing on tax credits and the other on staffing agencies.  Policy features were selected based on literature review, existing policies, and pretests.  Employers ranked candidates or opted out. Follow-up questions assessed employer concerns and views on work performance information.

analysis.sample_description: A stratified random sample of employers from a business research company's database, primarily private-sector firms (97%), with a response rate of 3.4%.  The sample largely represented the national average in terms of establishment size for each industry sector but had some over- and under-representation in specific industry-size combinations.
analysis.analysis_approach: Conditional logit model was used to analyze the discrete choice experiment data.  For follow-up questions, proportions were calculated for ranking and Likert scale responses.

sections.title: Study Objective and Approach
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative methodology using focused literature reviews and facilitated discussions with senior service leaders and personnel managers.  The literature review included research on organizational change and successful mergers and consolidations.  Informational discussions were held with personnel from the military services and other U.S. government agencies to identify relevant programs, understand their goals, and assess barriers and constraints.  Findings were synthesized to identify potential actions for DoD and the military services.

analysis.sample_description: Senior service leaders, personnel managers from the military services and other U.S. government agencies (31 individuals total).
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of literature and interview data; synthesis of findings to identify potential actions.

sections.title: Approach for Developing Schedule-Estimating Relationships
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for developing schedule-estimating relationships (SERs).  It describes the data used (a RAND database of SARs spanning 40+ years, excluding canceled programs), the key schedule durations analyzed (MS B to first LRIP contract award and MS B to IOC/IOD/RAA), and the program characteristics considered (MS A completion, RDT&E budget allocation, joint vs. single-service, development cost, procuring service, acquisition era, weapon system type, and procurement type).  Regression models (specifically, heterogeneous variance models estimated using maximum likelihood techniques) were used to correlate these program characteristics with the log of schedule durations. Model refinement involved examining regression statistics, residuals, and addressing potential collinearity issues.  The resulting SERs provide schedule point estimates (median and mean) and s-curves representing the distribution of expected schedule outcomes.

sections.title: Steps Performed to Conduct Benchmarking
sections.methods_summary: This appendix outlines the six steps involved in the benchmarking analysis: 1) Assembling schedule and program characteristic data from SARs; 2) Data adjustment for comparability (e.g., converting costs to a common base year); 3) Relating historical schedule outcomes to program characteristics using regression (heterogeneous variance model with SAS's "proc mixed" procedure); 4) Assembling data for programs to be benchmarked; 5) Applying the regression models from Step 3 to the data from Step 4 to generate s-curves; and 6) Overlaying proposed/planned program schedules onto the generated s-curves.

analysis.sample_description: The study used a RAND database of cost and schedule information from Selected Acquisition Reports (SARs) for major defense acquisition programs (MDAPs) over 40+ years.  Canceled programs were excluded.  The analysis focused on two schedule durations and several program characteristics.  The sample size varied depending on the specific regression (e.g., 94 MDAPs for one regression, 116 for another).
analysis.analysis_approach: Heterogeneous variance models were used to relate program characteristics at Milestone B to the natural logarithm of schedule durations. Maximum likelihood estimation techniques were employed.  Model refinement involved examining regression statistics and residuals, and addressing potential collinearity.  The models were used to generate schedule point estimates (median and mean) and s-curves representing the distribution of expected schedule outcomes.  These s-curves were then used to benchmark the schedules of five Air Force MDAPs.

sections.title: Methodological Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach involving three core tasks: 1) A brief online survey of teachers who opted out of the trial (n=83), assessing reasons for non-participation using Likert-scale questions and open-ended responses. 2) A documentary review of all communication materials related to the trial recruitment, analyzing clarity, frequency, and completeness of information. 3) Semi-structured interviews (n=13) with teachers (both opt-in and opt-out) and headteachers to explore perceptions of the trial and reasons for participation decisions.  The interviews were conducted by three RAND researchers who took detailed notes and direct quotes.

analysis.sample_description: The survey included 83 teachers who actively opted out of the trial.  13 semi-structured interviews were conducted with 11 teachers (6 opt-out, 5 opt-in) and 2 headteachers.
analysis.analysis_approach: Survey responses were analyzed quantitatively (frequencies, percentages) and qualitatively (themes from open-ended responses).  Documentary review involved qualitative analysis of communication materials. Interview data were analyzed qualitatively, identifying recurring themes and using direct quotes.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: An online survey with five open-text questions was distributed to 486 experts in health and social care across the UK.  A grounded theory approach was used for data analysis, involving coding, thematic analysis, and reporting.  The responses were not intended to be representative, and the analysis focused on identifying common themes and considering diverse viewpoints.

analysis.sample_description: 299 stakeholders responded to the survey. Over half (153/299) answered in their capacity as a ‘professional representative’ of their organisation and 146 in their capacity as a ‘private individual’.  The respondents represented a wide range of fields, including public health, social care, primary care, cancer, genomics, mental health, geriatrics, child health, patient advocacy, and health policy.
analysis.analysis_approach: A grounded theory approach was used to identify emergent themes. Three researchers coded the responses in Microsoft Excel, iteratively adding themes. The coded responses were then synthesized, highlighting common themes, discordance, and unique viewpoints.  The analysis did not aim for quantitative representation of the responses.

sections.title: Purpose and Approach
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods approach using existing survey data from 13 garrisons (at least 200 unweighted responses per garrison) and qualitative data from focus groups and interviews at four selected installations (Fort Gordon, Fort Hood, Fort Huachuca, and Fort Meade).

sections.title: Mixed-Methods Approach
sections.methods_summary: Detailed description of survey methodology, including instrument, sampling (stratified sampling by installation characteristics and soldier demographics), procedure (online administration), response rate (12%), and weighting (poststratification).  Qualitative methodology involved site visits to four installations, conducting 12 interviews and 40 focus groups with soldiers, spouses, and service providers. Data analysis for the survey used multiple regression models (linear and logistic), controlling for paygrade and family status. Qualitative data analysis used Dedoose software with a coding scheme developed and refined iteratively by the research team.

analysis.sample_description: Active component enlisted soldiers and officers stationed at CONUS installations.  A stratified sample design was used, stratifying by installation workforce category and soldier paygrade and family status.  13 garrisons with at least 200 unweighted survey responses were selected for in-depth analysis. Four installations were selected for site visits based on survey results.
analysis.analysis_approach: For survey data, multiple regression models (linear and logistic) were used, controlling for paygrade and family status.  Comparisons were made between each selected garrison and the overall average of all garrisons.  Qualitative data from focus groups and interviews were analyzed using Dedoose software, with an iterative coding scheme developed and refined by the research team.

sections.title: Methodological Notes: Literature Review
sections.methods_summary: Extensive literature review across multiple disciplines (psychology, neuroscience, public policy, law, etc.) using Google, academic databases, and journal archives.  Search terms included keywords related to terrorism, deception detection, behavioral indicators, and relevant technologies. Key sources included National Academy of Sciences studies and prior RAND research.  The review was supplemented by interviews with experts and organizations.

sections.title: Methodological Notes: Searches and Interviews
sections.methods_summary: Internet searches and email correspondence with government institutions, academic and research laboratories, and private organizations. Interviews were conducted with selected organizations and individuals (listed in Table A.2).

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is a literature review and not an empirical study.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of existing research and expert opinions.  The report uses a conceptual framework to organize and analyze the information, and presents findings in a narrative format with tables summarizing key findings and assessments.

sections.title: Chapter Three: Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology, including an overview of Robust Decision Making (RDM) and the RAND Model of Automated Vehicle Safety (MAVS).  It describes the experimental design, defining three HAV introduction policies (Improve10, Improve75, Improve90) and outlining how uncertainties in various factors (VMT growth, fatality rates, HAV adoption rates, HAV safety improvement rates, etc.) are incorporated using RDM and Latin Hypercube sampling to generate 500 plausible future scenarios.  The analysis uses MAVS to simulate fatalities under each policy across these scenarios.

analysis.sample_description: 500 plausible future scenarios generated using Latin Hypercube sampling to represent uncertainty in various factors affecting HAV safety and adoption.
analysis.analysis_approach: The RAND Model of Automated Vehicle Safety (MAVS) is used to simulate fatalities under different HAV introduction policies across the 500 generated scenarios.  The results are then analyzed to compare the cumulative lives saved under each policy in the short and long term, and to identify the conditions under which each policy performs better.

sections.title: Study Design and Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: The study convened an expert panel of judges, legal practitioners, and academics.  The panel reviewed existing literature and case examples related to the impact of electronic communication and devices (ECD) on fair trials.  The focus was on ECD use to intimidate witnesses and juror misconduct due to ECD use.  The panel discussed solutions and best practices.

sections.title: Participant Selection
sections.methods_summary: Participants were selected based on expertise and experience in handling cases and conducting research related to witness intimidation and juror misconduct involving ECD.

analysis.sample_description: The sample consisted of judges, legal practitioners, and academics with significant experience in addressing the impact of ECD on fair trials.  The selection criteria emphasized expertise in witness intimidation and juror misconduct related to ECD.
analysis.analysis_approach: The panel discussed the challenges, solutions, and lessons learned regarding the impact of ECD on fair trials.  The analysis involved identifying promising and less promising practices based on the panel's collective experience and discussion.

sections.title: Chapter Two: Conceptual Framework, Data Sources, and Measures
sections.methods_summary: This chapter details the data sources used in the study, including the American Community Survey (ACS), the National Center for Education Statistics Common Core of Data (NCES CCD), Uniform Crime Reporting Program data, STARBASE administrative data, a STARBASE directors' survey, LexisNexis Academic, Department of Defense (DoD) data, Google Analytics data, Facebook data, and Joint Advertising Market Research & Studies (JAMRS) data.  The chapter also describes the measures used, such as an index of neighborhood disadvantage, direct outreach measures (relationship building, social media activity, Google search activity), indirect influence measures (geographic measures of youth program outreach, military presence, military influence, and military recruiters), and long-term outcome measures (number and quality of military applicants and accessions, public attitudes toward the military).  A model of DoD's outreach is presented as a framework for the analysis.

analysis.sample_description: The primary analysis uses data aggregated at the school district level, encompassing 13,012 school districts.  Subsamples are used for specific analyses, with variations in sample size due to missing data.  A survey of STARBASE program directors (n=65) is also used.  Analysis of JAMRS Influencer Poll data (n=1188) is conducted separately.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study employs various analytical techniques.  Factor analysis is used to create a composite measure of neighborhood disadvantage. Regression models are used to analyze the relationship between various predictors (including the presence of youth programs) and outcomes such as military applicants and accessions.  Qualitative analysis is performed on news articles about STARBASE.  Geographic analysis is used to map the locations of DoD youth programs and assess their proximity to military bases and recruiters.

sections.title: Summary of Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A rescue model was built to simulate the effects of prevailing conditions, including costs of new rescue capabilities, locations and numbers of US personnel in Africa, trends in injury occurrences in combat theaters, survival rates of injured personnel as a function of time and medical care received, and current and projected locations of rescue assets.  The model estimates how additional rescue capabilities could raise survivability rates and compares alternative investments based on marginal cost-effectiveness.

sections.title: Cost Analysis Approach
sections.methods_summary: Commercial analogies were used to estimate costs for unique military capabilities (like DCS teams) lacking existing DoD cost estimates.  This involved reviewing DoD contracts for commercial airlift service providers in Africa and responses to RFIs, supplemented by a bottom-up build approach for DCS teams using data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Salary.com, the US Department of State, and other sources.  The approach leverages the similarity of inputs between commercial and military entities providing aviation and DCS capabilities.

sections.title: Construction of Survivability Timelines
sections.methods_summary: The methodology uses data from the Joint Medical Planning Tool (JMPT) and the Medical Planners’ Toolkit (MPTk).  Survival data from the JMPT (covering various injury severities, care levels, and time spent at each level) and mortality risk distribution data from the MPTk (across 15 historical datasets representing diverse locations and conflict conditions) were combined.  The JMPT survival curves were based on expert opinion (for prehospital care) or medical records (for hospital care).  A weighted average of survival rates across the historical datasets was calculated, considering the levels of care received for different mortality risks.  This allowed for the creation of average survival timelines showing the expected survival rates over time for personnel receiving different levels of care for varying injury severities.

sections.title: Rescue Model Outputs and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The rescue model identifies optimal rescue paths (most life-saving routes to medical care) and optimal asset-location pairings (most cost-effective marginal investments in rescue capabilities).  The model considers four investment options: light fixed-wing aircraft node, medium rotary-wing aircraft node, fixed DCS team, and mobile DCS team.  Each additional investment is paired with an airfield location.  The model assesses the marginal effectiveness (in terms of increased expected survival rates) of these investments, considering standard (N+3) and accelerated (N+1) aircraft alert times.  The analysis compares the cost-effectiveness of these options under various conditions (fixed vs. mobile DCS, standard vs. shortened alert times) to identify the most effective combinations.

primary_methods: data analysis (survival curves, mortality risk distributions)
analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from various sources, including 15 historical MPTk datasets representing a range of locations and conflict conditions over the past 50 years, and data on US personnel in Africa.  The analysis does not focus on a specific sample of individuals but rather on aggregate data to model the overall effectiveness of different rescue strategies.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a simulation model to assess the cost-effectiveness of different rescue capabilities and strategies in the AFRICOM area of responsibility.  The model considers various factors, including costs, locations of resources, personnel at risk, survival rates, and historical injury data.  The analysis compares the marginal effectiveness of different investments under various conditions to identify the most cost-effective options.

sections.title: Acknowledgments and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The report's methodology involved structured discussions with RAND staff and external audiences, followed by literature reviews.  The structured discussions, involving 8-10 people per group or one-on-one sessions, covered definitions, causes, consequences, risks, and potential solutions to Truth Decay.  A coding framework was used to organize insights. Literature reviews involved searching databases and analyzing peer-reviewed journals, books, and reports. Publicly available data sets from organizations like Pew Research Center and Gallup were used.  The analysis was iterative, refining the framework based on findings.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Structured discussions with approximately 170 RAND staff (including 145 researchers from various disciplines) and external audiences (educators, journalists, entrepreneurs, donors, trustees).  Discussions covered definitions, drivers, consequences, historical analogues, and research questions. A coding framework categorized insights. Literature reviews used online databases (Social Science Abstracts, PubMed, JSTOR) and analyzed peer-reviewed journals, books, newspaper articles, public opinion data, and government reports. Data from Pew Research Center, Gallup, and the General Social Survey were used, comparing trends across sources.  Historical analysis identified three analogous periods in US history.

sections.title: Additional Information About Our Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Structured discussions were conducted in groups of 8-10 or one-on-one, covering definitions, causes, consequences, risks, opportunities, solutions, and research agendas. Guiding questions and prompts were used.  A coding framework (listed in the appendix) organized insights from the discussions.  Literature reviews used search terms (listed in the appendix) to find relevant articles and books from peer-reviewed journals and other sources.  The analysis was iterative, refining the framework based on findings.

analysis.sample_description: Approximately 170 RAND staff (including 145 researchers), external audiences (educators, journalists, entrepreneurs, donors, trustees).  The sample for historical analysis included three periods in US history.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative analysis.  Coding framework used to organize insights from discussions.  Data analysis involved comparing trends across multiple data sources and considering margins of error.  Historical analysis involved identifying analogous periods and comparing them to the current period.

sections.title: Transition Implementation Planning
sections.methods_summary: Five-phase transition process: define, measure, analyze, implement, and assess.  The 'measure' phase involved a countrywide data-gathering effort to identify all tasks to be transitioned.  The 'analyze' phase involved evaluating the effectiveness of each activity and determining whether to transfer, modify, or terminate it. The 'implement' phase involved taking steps to transition each activity. The 'assess' phase involved macrolevel and microlevel assessments of the effectiveness of the transition process.

sections.title: Transition Management Working Groups
sections.methods_summary: A multilevel interagency framework for managing the transition of enduring activities.  This included a Joint Campaign Working Group, an Executive Core Group, and a LOO Core Group, which met regularly to assess implementation, identify challenges, and develop strategies.

sections.title: Changes to Transition Management Processes Under Operations Order 11-01
sections.methods_summary: Establishment of additional interagency working groups (Embassy Support Group, Base Transition Working Group, Operations Transition Working Group, USCENTCOM Iraq Transition Working Group) to address administrative and logistical aspects of the transition.  A Joint Plans and Operations process was established to develop USF-I positions on transition issues.  The process involved a Joint Plans and Operations Group, a Joint Plans and Operations Council, and a Joint Plans and Operations Huddle.  A transition dashboard was used to track progress numerically and qualitatively.

sections.title: Iraqi Participation in Transition Planning and Execution
sections.methods_summary: Description of the methods used for coordination between U.S. forces and their Iraqi counterparts at the tactical and operational levels.  This included a joint committee for implementing the SA and a receivership cell in the Prime Minister's office.  The limitations of Iraqi participation in transition planning are discussed.

sections.title: U.S. Policy, Strategy, and Plans for Security Sector Transition
sections.methods_summary: The chapter describes the U.S. policy, strategy, and plans for security sector transition, including the definition of Minimum Essential Capabilities (MEC) and the shift towards a more traditional security assistance model.  It also discusses the transition of funding mechanisms from ISFF to FMF and INCLE.

sections.title: Base Closure Direction, Planning, and Tasks
sections.methods_summary: The USF-I J7 staff orchestrated the base closure and transfer process using a Base Closure Smartbook, which outlined tasks and milestones.  The process involved four parallel processes: Real Estate Management, Environmental Oversight, Property Distribution, and Contracting.  The Base Management Operational Planning Team coordinated closure and transfer with other joint staff sections and external groups and agencies.

sections.title: Equipment Disposal: A Major Logistics Challenge
sections.methods_summary: Description of the logistical operation for withdrawing equipment from Iraq, including the methods used for accounting for and transporting equipment.  This involved a tiered approval system for determining the disposition of equipment.  The chapter also discusses the methods used for transferring equipment to the embassy, the Iraqi government, Afghanistan, and other destinations.

sections.title: Operational Maneuver
sections.methods_summary: The redeployment was planned and executed as a combat mission.  The chapter describes the methods used for planning and executing the operational maneuver, including the use of a sustainment spine, hub-and-spoke logistics system, and a systematic transfer of bases.  The chapter also discusses the methods used for managing security risks and the concept of operations for the retrograde of forces.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from various sources, including internal documents from the U.S. Forces–Iraq and the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, as well as interviews with key personnel involved in the transition.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach is qualitative and quantitative, using both document analysis and interviews to understand the transition process and its challenges.  The study also uses data analysis to track progress and identify trends.

sections.title: Website Development and User Experience Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The methodology involved developing a website, gathering user feedback through surveys (198 responses), user assessments, and direct interviews with law enforcement and prosecutors.  Web traffic was analyzed using Google Analytics to understand user behavior and inform website improvements. A user typology was created based on initial page visits to categorize users for traffic pattern analysis.

sections.title: Utah Model Report Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used to create a report on the Utah Model for cybercrime units.  The methods included consultations with Utah Department of Public Safety (DPS) staff, representatives from the Utah State Cyber Intelligence Network, and site visits and interviews with other cybercrime units across the nation (San Diego CATCH team, San Diego County prosecutor, New York City Wellspring Cybercrime Unit).

sections.title: Justice Executive Cyber Roundtable Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The methodology for the Justice Executive Cyber Roundtable involved soliciting feedback from stakeholders to determine topics and format.  The event included morning presentations and afternoon working groups using a semi-structured protocol to identify key concerns, challenges, and best practices.  A briefing pack was distributed to participants.

analysis.sample_description: For the user experience analysis, the sample included 198 respondents from local law enforcement agencies, representing various roles and interests.  The Utah Model report involved interviews with DPS staff, the Utah State Cyber Intelligence Network, and other cybercrime units. The Justice Executive Cyber Roundtable included 27 participants representing police executives, investigators, prosecutors, and judges.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis of website traffic data using Google Analytics. Qualitative analysis of user feedback from surveys and interviews.  The Utah Model report involved a descriptive analysis of the challenges, lessons learned, and promising practices. The Justice Executive Cyber Roundtable involved identifying key themes and concerns from the discussions.

sections.title: Appendix 2. Evaluation Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the mixed-methods approach used in the evaluation.  Methods included document and literature reviews, attendance at events (for observational purposes and informal discussions), semi-structured interviews and focus group discussions with various stakeholders (Q members, unsuccessful applicants, project team, external stakeholders), case studies with Q members, citizen ethnography with Q members at events, online surveys (application, annual, new member, unsuccessful applicant), and social network analysis.  Data analysis involved separate analysis of each method's findings, followed by synthesis into a single narrative using NVivo 10 (for most interviews) and manual coding.

sections.title: 1.5. Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section provides a summary overview of the methods used in the evaluation.  It lists document review, literature review, observation at events and meetings, semi-structured interviews (n=55) and focus groups (n=19), case studies (n=4), citizen ethnography, surveys (n=11), and social network analysis.  It also mentions the formative nature of the evaluation and the sharing of findings with the Q project team.

analysis.sample_description: The sample included Q members (various phases), unsuccessful applicants, Q project team members, external stakeholders, and members of the Q Lab volunteer group.  Sampling for interviews and focus groups involved random number generation, with some stratification by subgroup (e.g., recruitment phase, region).  Survey samples included applicants (successful and unsuccessful) and existing members.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data from each method was analyzed separately.  Qualitative data (interviews, focus groups, citizen ethnography) was analyzed using NVivo 10 (for most) and manual coding.  Quantitative data (surveys) was analyzed using descriptive statistics and social network analysis techniques.  Findings were then synthesized into a thematic narrative.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the quantitative and qualitative methods used in the evaluation.  Quantitative data sources included the DMH Services Dataset (claims data for all mental health services) and the DMH Program Dataset (clinical assessments for PEI and FSP clients).  Analyses focused on the period 2012-2016.  Descriptive statistics, chi-square tests, McNemar's test, and comparisons to clinical trial benchmarks were used. Qualitative data were collected through interviews with PEI and FSP clients (purposeful sampling) to gather information on program impacts and experiences.  Thematic analysis was used to analyze interview data.

analysis.sample_description: The study included administrative data on PEI and FSP clients in Los Angeles County from 2012-2016.  Qualitative interviews were conducted with a purposefully sampled subset of PEI and FSP clients in late 2017.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analyses involved descriptive statistics, chi-square tests of association, McNemar's test of paired proportions, and comparisons to existing benchmarks from clinical trials. Qualitative data were analyzed thematically.

sections.title: Methodology: Assessing Potential Savings in DoD Operations
sections.methods_summary: The study examined alternative approaches to estimating savings in defense operations.  It consulted experts in economics and utilized U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) data from 2000 to the present on labor productivity and multifactor productivity (MFP) changes across U.S. industries.  The researchers analyzed BLS data to determine the prevalence of 4-8% annual productivity gains.  The study also considered factors like offsetting investments needed to increase labor productivity and differences in MFP between DoD and the private sector.  Due to data limitations and the unique nature of DoD operations (including wartime demands), a bottom-up approach focusing on identifying and removing specific barriers to efficiency was proposed as a more realistic method for estimating savings.

primary_methods: Data analysis of BLS data on labor productivity and multifactor productivity
Comparative analysis of DoD and private sector operations
analysis.sample_description: The study used U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) data covering a broad range of U.S. industries (208 industry categories for labor productivity, 62 for multifactor productivity) from 2000 to 2016.  Specific industries with analogs in DoD were analyzed comparatively.
analysis.analysis_approach: The researchers analyzed BLS data to assess the frequency of high annual productivity growth (4-8%). They compared productivity trends in various industries, including those with DoD counterparts.  They also considered the impact of investments on productivity and the challenges of comparing DoD and private sector activities due to factors like wartime demands.  The study ultimately advocated for a bottom-up approach to savings estimation, focusing on identifying and removing specific barriers to efficiency within DoD.

sections.title: Study Objectives and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Literature review of academic papers, vendor tool presentations, and conference presentations; review of US Department of Defense research on counterinsurgency and counter-IED operations; review of case studies of departments using predictive policing techniques; development of a taxonomy of operational applications supported by predictive policing.

sections.title: Prediction Methods
sections.methods_summary: The chapter organizes predictive techniques around six analytic categories: hot spot analysis (grid mapping, covering ellipses, kernel density estimation), regression methods (linear, nonlinear, regression splines), data mining techniques (clustering, classification, ensemble methods), near-repeat methods, spatiotemporal analysis (heat maps, ST-GAM, LST-GAM, seasonality adjustments), and risk terrain analysis (heuristic approach, statistical approach).  The methods are further classified into four classes based on complexity: classical statistical techniques, simple methods, complex applications, and tailored methods.  Specific techniques within each category are described, including their strengths, weaknesses, and applications in predictive policing. The chapter also discusses data collection and analysis procedures, software used (e.g., CrimeStat, Excel, R, SAS, SPSS, WEKA), and the process of training and testing predictive models.

analysis.sample_description: The study draws on various sources, including academic literature, vendor materials, conference presentations, US Department of Defense research, and case studies of police departments using predictive policing.  Specific case studies are detailed throughout the document.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative analysis methods are used.  Qualitative analysis involves reviewing and interpreting case studies and interview notes to identify common themes and promising practices. Quantitative analysis includes statistical methods such as regression, clustering, classification, and spatiotemporal modeling.  The analysis also involves developing a taxonomy to organize and categorize the various predictive policing methods and interventions.

sections.title: Scenario Development Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach combining backcasting, assumption-based planning (ABP), and Three-Horizon Foresight (3HF).  Data was collected through three intensive workshops involving Road to Zero Coalition stakeholders.  The workshops involved focus groups, breakout sessions, presentations, and group discussions to develop a vision of a zero-roadway-death future and identify pathways to achieve it.  ABP was used to evaluate the identified pathways by analyzing underlying assumptions and potential risks. Backcasting was used to work backward from the envisioned future to understand the steps needed to get there.

analysis.sample_description: The sample consisted of stakeholders from the Road to Zero Coalition, including representatives from professional engineering and planning organizations, public-sector organizations, safety advocates, vehicle manufacturers, technology developers, public health, emergency medical and trauma organizations, and law enforcement and judicial system representatives.  The number of participants varied across the three workshops.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of workshop discussions and narratives to develop a scenario for achieving zero roadway deaths by 2050.  Assumption-based planning was used to identify and assess key assumptions underlying the scenario.

sections.title: About This Report
sections.methods_summary: This report draws on publicly available materials, previous RAND national security research, and RAND wargaming and analytic expertise to evaluate how NATO and Russian force levels and capabilities have evolved in the post–Cold War era and what recent trends imply for the balance of capabilities in the NATO member states that border Russia in the Baltic Sea region.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; the study analyzes publicly available data and existing research, not a specific sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative analysis of military force levels, capabilities, and trends.  Comparisons are made between NATO and Russian forces, focusing on the Baltic region.  Data visualization (figures and tables) is used to present findings.

sections.title: Research Approach and Framework
sections.methods_summary: The research involved an extensive review of literature on ERP planning (private and public sector) and discussions with experts from ERP software vendors, system integrators, academics, and consultants.  In-depth investigation of major Air Force ERP programs (AF-IPPS, DEAMS, ECSS) was conducted using program documentation and interviews with government and contractor stakeholders.

analysis.sample_description: The study examined major Air Force ERP programs (AF-IPPS, DEAMS, ECSS) and included interviews with government stakeholders (functional sponsors, PMOs, FMOs, acquisition leadership, Service and OSD DCMO staff, and Service CIO staff) and contractor stakeholders (system integrators, software vendors, and ERP expert consultants).
analysis.analysis_approach: The research team organized conditions for successful ERP-enabled business transformation into five categories: business case, governance, business process reengineering (BPR), organizational change management (OCM), and IT acquisition.  These categories were used as a framework for analyzing the planning issues and challenges faced by the Air Force.

sections.title: Analytical Methods
sections.methods_summary: The report details three analytical approaches: quantitative (using multivariate panel regression and quasi-experimental methods), qualitative (using process tracing), and triangulation (combining quantitative and qualitative methods).  Each approach's suitability is determined by data availability and the number of cases.  The report also discusses bias considerations (sampling, response, social desirability, cultural, validity, and reliability) and the importance of addressing causality in the analysis.

sections.title: Data Collection and Types
sections.methods_summary: The report outlines three data types: operational (SITREPs, SIGACTs, CONOPs, intelligence reporting), ambient (social media, satellite imagery, news), and assessment-specific (polling, interviews).  It emphasizes using multiple data types for a more comprehensive assessment.

sections.title: Emerging Data Streams and Technologies
sections.methods_summary: This section explores the use of social media and other emerging data sources for assessment, acknowledging challenges like data access and bias.  It also discusses emerging technologies in computational text analysis (document clustering, human-supervised classification, topic modeling, lexical analysis, sentiment analysis, stance analysis), image analysis, and audio/video analysis for processing unstructured data.

sections.title: Research Approach and Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: The report's methodology addresses general assessment challenges (establishing causality, measurement, assessment process, timeliness) and SOF-specific challenges (indirect effects through partner forces, flexibility, denied environments, cognitive influence).  It uses a seven-step process: determine objectives, identify activities, define MOEs, develop indicators and collect data, conduct LOE-specific analysis, consolidate analysis, and commander review.  The research involved reviewing SOF efforts, assessment literature, consulting with private sector assessment experts, and a consultative process with SOF practitioners.

sections.title: Seven-Step Assessment Process
sections.methods_summary: A detailed, seven-step process for conducting operational-level SOF assessments is presented.  Each step includes pre-deployment and deployment phases, challenges, and mitigation strategies.  The steps are: 1) Determine Objectives (SMART criteria emphasized), 2) Identify Activities (using a mission tracker and five Ws), 3) Define MOEs (relevance, measurability, malleability, distinctness), 4) Develop Indicators and Collect Data (operational, ambient, assessment-specific data; inclusion/exclusion criteria), 5) Conduct LOE-Specific Analysis (qualitative, quantitative, triangulation), 6) Consolidate Analysis (summary measures, visualizations), and 7) Commander Review (validation, feedback).

analysis.sample_description: A fictional scenario involving a conflict between Atropia and Ariana is used to illustrate the seven-step assessment process.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach involves a combination of qualitative and quantitative methods, depending on the data available and the research question.  The report emphasizes the importance of longitudinal data and the use of quasi-experimental methods to establish causality.

sections.title: Appendix A. Evaluation Methods
sections.methods_summary: The methodology section details the PHCS survey (a statewide effort to understand how the GPP is shaping care delivery to uninsured individuals), its development (literature review and use of the GPP tier table), administration (to 12 participating GPP teams in February and March 2018, resulting in 100% response rate), and estimated completion time (55-65 minutes).  It also describes the derivation of uninsured costs and uncompensated costs using P14 workbooks, and acknowledges limitations such as the inability to draw causal inferences due to the lack of a control group and the coarse nature of the data (only two time points, aggregate utilization data, and no granular cost data).

sections.title: Methods and Limitations
sections.methods_summary: Primarily descriptive statistical methods were used to analyze utilization, survey, and cost data.  A pre-post evaluation design was employed, acknowledging limitations due to the lack of a control group and the small sample size (12 PHCS), making causal inferences difficult.  Formal hypothesis testing was not performed; instead, multiple performance measures were examined for each hypothesis to provide evidence for or against each.

analysis.sample_description: The study included 12 of California's public health care systems (PHCS) participating in the Global Payment Program (GPP).  The survey had a 100% response rate.
analysis.analysis_approach: Primarily descriptive statistical methods were used.  Multiple performance measures were examined for each of three hypotheses to provide evidence for or against each.

sections.title: Methodology: Overview of Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: A structured literature review and interviews with experts were used to create an overview of existing methods for handling ethical issues in various sectors (military, intelligence, police, counterterrorism, healthcare, and social work), primarily focusing on the Netherlands and the United Kingdom, with some consideration of France.  The literature on healthcare methods was more extensive than for other sectors.

sections.title: Methodology: Data Collection and Literature Review
sections.methods_summary: The primary data source was expert interviews (30 individuals with diverse perspectives across sectors and countries).  A structured literature review was conducted using Google Scholar and Google, encompassing academic and grey literature, with a snowballing approach to identify relevant sources.  The literature review focused on ethical problems, available methods, and their effectiveness.  A disparity in publicly available evidence was noted between security sectors and healthcare/social work sectors.

analysis.sample_description: 30 expert interviews, opportunistic and illustrative sampling;  interviewees provided insights across multiple sectors and countries.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data and literature review findings to identify and categorize methods for supporting ethical decision-making in counterterrorism.  The analysis also focused on identifying common characteristics of ethical decision-making in counterterrorism and tailoring methods to address these characteristics.

sections.title: Empirical Trends in Life-Cycle Management
sections.methods_summary: Examination of multiple databases (VAMOSC, NMD, NAVSUP One Touch) to analyze cost escalation in ship equipment.  Analysis focuses on identifying trends in different measurements related to ship life cycle, including ship depot maintenance costs, the impact of deferred maintenance, and analysis of 'troubled systems' data from NSWC-C.  Data from the Arleigh Burke DDGs and Ticonderoga class are used as exemplars. Comparisons are made between planned and actual maintenance, and between high-cost infrequent failures and low-cost frequent failures.

analysis.sample_description: Data from multiple Navy databases, focusing on the Arleigh Burke DDG-51 class and Ticonderoga class ships as exemplars.  The sample includes data on maintenance costs, casualty reports, and parts replacement.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved examining various data sets to identify trends in life-cycle costs, comparing planned versus actual maintenance, and analyzing the cost and frequency of equipment failures.  The researchers used comparative analysis to highlight discrepancies between different data sources and to identify areas where organizational practices were hindering a more systematic approach to life-cycle management.

sections.title: Data Sources and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The analysis draws on a variety of sources, including reports by governments and international organizations, policy papers by think tanks and research institutes, media and news reports, and off-the-record conversations with current and former Israeli and Palestinian government officials and diverse experts from the United Nations, World Health Organization (WHO), the Office of the Quartet, and nongovernmental organizations.

analysis.sample_description: Reports from government and international aid organizations, policy papers, media reports, off-the-record conversations with dozens of experts from the UN, WHO, NGOs and current and former Israeli, Palestinian, and U.S. government officials.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of diverse sources to understand the technical and political complexities of Gaza's water crisis.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Designing an Approach to Strategic Surveillance - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach.  Qualitative data was gathered through semi-structured interviews with senior FSA stakeholders (n=5, 60-90 minutes each).  Thematic analysis was used to identify principles and steps for a strategic surveillance approach.  A top-down approach utilized existing FSA models, while a bottom-up approach analyzed interview data. The resulting approach was tested against two previous FSA use cases (olive oil adulteration and Vibrio contamination in shellfish). A validation workshop with FSA stakeholders (date not specified) generated a long-list of implementation steps, which were then evaluated for impact and feasibility using a 2x2 matrix.  The feasibility and impact were assessed by consensus among workshop participants.

sections.title: Annex B: Identification of Skills Capture, Analytic Tools, and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details various analytical tools and methods used in the study, excluding software packages.  Methods described include RACI matrices for clarifying roles and responsibilities, Stirling matrices for analyzing risk issues and selecting appropriate analytical approaches, horizon scanning and foresight exercises for identifying future challenges, the Delphi method for building consensus among experts, the STREAM methodology for project prioritization, hackathons for collaborative problem-solving, and crowdsourcing for engaging non-traditional stakeholders.

analysis.sample_description: Five semi-structured interviews with senior FSA stakeholders; two FSA use cases (olive oil adulteration and Vibrio contamination in shellfish); participants in a validation workshop with FSA stakeholders (number not specified).
analysis.analysis_approach: Thematic analysis of interview data; 2x2 matrix for evaluating implementation steps based on impact and feasibility;  application of various analytical frameworks (RACI, Stirling, etc.)

sections.title: Exercise Design and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A tabletop exercise (TTX) was conducted with 50 subject-matter experts (SMEs) from various U.S. commands. The TTX combined elements of an air planning exercise, a command and control (C2) wargame, and an innovation workshop.  Participants were divided into operational planning groups (OPGs) by mission area (PR, CAS, and ISR) and tasked with developing concepts of operation, asset beddown, and command arrangements.  The exercise scenario involved a growing non-state adversary network in eastern Libya and western Egypt.  Randomized operational events were introduced to stress-test participant concepts.

analysis.sample_description: 50 subject-matter experts (SMEs) from U.S. Africa Command (USAFRICOM), U.S. Central Command (USCENTCOM), U.S. European Command (USEUCOM), U.S. Special Operations Command (USSOCOM), and other select U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) entities.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis of discussions from the TTX, including examination of boundary frictions across different mission areas (PR, CAS, ISR).  Post-TTX analysis of aggregate potential time on station for airborne ISR operations was conducted to illustrate the impact of impermeable theater boundaries. The analysis focused on identifying operational frictions and approaches to mitigating them.

sections.title: Approach and Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: Review of relevant laws and DoD guidance; review of committee reports and witness testimony; collection of CAPE cost estimates from 2010-2016; structured interviews with cost analysts from CAPE and military services; review of data sources available for cost analyses; analysis of O&S estimates in Selected Acquisition Reports (SARs); interviews with government cost and logistics subject-matter experts; review of law, regulations, and literature; development of recommendations to improve cost analysis of MDAP O&S costs.

sections.title: Activities, Workload and Processes
sections.methods_summary: Structured interviews with CAPE O&S cost analysts; unstructured interviews with CAPE analysts specializing in legal requirements and product support cost estimation methodologies; structured interviews with O&S cost analysts and/or managers from each military service's independent cost-estimating organizations; tabular comparison of interview results; analysis of Annual Report on Cost Assessment Activities for FYs 2010-2016.

sections.title: O&S Cost Estimates in Selected Acquisition Reports
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of DoD unit O&S cost-estimating results as reported in SARs; calculation of proportions of estimated lifetime acquisition and O&S costs by system type; tracking of unit O&S estimates for MDAPs with large O&S costs; characterization of MDAPs by complexity level; comparison of SAR estimates to actual costs; calculation of percentage of SARs updated each year and average percentage change in estimates; review of SARs, CARDs, LCSPs, service databases, and SME insights to understand reasons for cost estimate growth.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample included CAPE cost estimates of MDAPs from 2010 to 2016,  Selected Acquisition Reports (SARs) for various MDAPs, and interviews with cost analysts from CAPE and the independent cost-estimating organizations in each military service.  Appendix A focuses on a subset of 20 MDAPs with the largest life-cycle O&S costs.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved quantitative analysis of cost data from SARs, including calculations of proportions, growth rates, and differences between estimates and actual costs.  Qualitative analysis was also conducted through document review and interviews to understand the reasons behind cost estimate changes and identify factors influencing O&S costs.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: A rapid evidence assessment was used, which is a methodological, rigorous and repeatable approach that compromises on breadth compared to a full systematic review.  The Maryland Scientific Methods Scale was used to assess study quality.

sections.title: Detailed Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research involved expert interviews, database searches (Web of Science, Scopus, PsycInfo, Social Sciences Abstracts, OpenGrey, IssueLab, OAISTER, and Advanced Google search), snowball sampling, and screening of studies against inclusion/exclusion criteria.  Data extraction was performed using a standardized template.  Inclusion criteria included articles in English reporting primary research published after 2005.  Exclusion criteria included commentaries, editorials, research on sports other than football, and narrative reviews. Specific search terms are listed.

analysis.sample_description: The sample consisted of studies identified through database searches and snowball sampling, meeting pre-defined inclusion and exclusion criteria.  The studies varied in methodology and quality, with only a small number considered methodologically robust.
analysis.analysis_approach: Studies were assessed for quality using the Maryland Scientific Methods Scale.  Findings were synthesized and interpreted across studies.  Quantitative analyses within individual studies varied, including regression models and pre/post comparisons.

sections.title: Methodology: Budgetary Impact Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used to analyze the budgetary effects of Medicaid expansion in Pennsylvania.  It describes the use of the COMPARE microsimulation model to estimate costs, the consideration of alternative assumptions regarding Medicaid administrative costs (including and excluding IT costs), the gross receipts tax (GRT) on Medicaid MCOs (with varying assumptions about its applicability), costs associated with children moving from CHIP to Medicaid, tax revenue from economic growth, and savings from the General Assistance Program.  Data sources include the Commonwealth’s budget, the Governor’s Executive Budget, and estimates from the Pennsylvania Independent Fiscal Office (IFO).

analysis.sample_description: The analysis focuses on the state of Pennsylvania and its budget.  Specific data points are drawn from various sources, including the Commonwealth's budget and the Independent Fiscal Office.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses the COMPARE model to estimate costs and revenues under different assumptions.  Sensitivity analysis is performed by varying key assumptions (administrative costs, GRT applicability, CHIP to Medicaid transition costs, economic growth tax revenue, and General Assistance savings) to assess the robustness of the findings.  Results are presented in a table showing the budgetary impact under various scenarios.

sections.title: Sampling and Weighting
sections.methods_summary: Probabilistic sampling methods were used to recruit AEP members.  Calibration weights (one main weight and 80 replicate weights) were created to ensure that estimates reflect the national population of teachers and school leaders.  Replicate weights were used in calculating jackknife standard errors.

sections.title: Data Collection: May 2018 MLI Survey
sections.methods_summary: The Measurement Learning and Improvement (MLI) Survey was administered to the ATP and ASLP samples in May 2018.  The survey was developed by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in consultation with RAND staff.  The survey aimed to gather data on teacher and principal perspectives on various educational topics.

sections.title: Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Primary estimation strategy involved simple weighted averages of survey responses.  Jackknife standard errors were calculated using replicate weights. Subgroup comparisons were conducted using regression analysis (Equation 1).  Supplemental analyses (Equation 2) included additional covariates and state fixed effects.  Survey weights and jackknife standard errors were used in all analyses.  Robustness checks included clustering standard errors at the state level.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative samples of K–12 public school educators (American Teacher Panel and American School Leader Panel).  Oversampling in 20 states.  Sample sizes: ATP >25,000 teachers, ASLP >12,000 school leaders.
analysis.analysis_approach: Weighted means were calculated using a main weight to ensure national representativeness.  Subgroup comparisons used regression analysis with an indicator variable for subgroup membership.  Supplemental analyses included additional covariates and state fixed effects to control for confounding variables. Jackknife standard errors were used to account for sampling variability.

sections.title: Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used multiple data sources: interviews with HR practitioners from 19 organizations (purposive sampling based on criteria like workforce size, mission, and recognition for exemplary practices) and analysis of MSPB Merit Principles Survey responses from DoD supervisors.  A document review of academic literature, business publications, and government reports was also conducted. Interviews were semi-structured, audio-recorded, transcribed, and analyzed using qualitative data analysis software (NVivo 11).  The MSPB survey data used random sampling and response weights to allow generalization to the larger federal workforce.

analysis.sample_description: 19 organizations: a mix of public (federal, state, local) and private sector entities.  Public sector organizations were selected to represent a range of innovation sources and perspectives from military service departments and the DoD's Fourth Estate. Private sector organizations were chosen based on Fortune 100 Best Places to Work recognition.  DoD supervisor data came from the MSPB Merit Principles Survey (Path L survey) with 5,170 respondents.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data analysis software (NVivo 11) was used for interview data.  For survey data, response weights were applied to allow generalization to the larger federal workforce.  Frequency analysis was conducted on survey responses.

sections.title: Empirical Methodology
