sections.methods_summary: The study used a quasi-experimental design with a difference-in-difference (DID) multivariate matching regression estimator.  Schools in the state outside of the PPI districts served as controls. Matching was conducted using a one-to-many algorithm with replacement.  The analysis included school and year fixed effects, and controlled for various school characteristics. Sensitivity checks included comparative interrupted time series (CITS) analysis, pooled regression across states, alternative matching bandwidths, alternative treatment start years, exclusion of charter schools and newly opened schools, and an alternative baseline year. Exploratory analyses examined correlations between treatment effects and PPI components, and between treatment effects and school characteristics.

sections.title: Matching Algorithm
sections.methods_summary: A multivariate matching DID estimator was used.  Schools were matched on year of placement, whether newly opened, school type, baseline free/reduced lunch eligibility, baseline minority student population, and baseline outcome scores (except for principal retention, where baseline retention was not matched).  A one-to-many matching algorithm with replacement was used, generating weights for subsequent regressions.  Sensitivity checks were conducted using different bin sizes.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used multiple methods to address research questions.  District data on students, schools, and principals were analyzed to develop descriptive summaries.  A DID methodology was used to compare principal retention and changes in school outcomes for PPI district schools relative to similar non-PPI schools. Statewide data were used to identify comparison schools. Subgroup analyses were conducted by grade level, district, cohort, new to district hires versus reassigned principals, and school characteristics (achievement quartile, proportion of non-white students, proportion of students eligible for free/reduced lunch). Sensitivity checks were performed. Exploratory analyses examined additional outcomes and the relationship between PPI effects and implementation of specific PPI components.

analysis.sample_description: Six large urban school districts in the US,  with data from at least SY 2010-2011 through SY 2016-2017.  Comparison schools were selected from non-PPI districts in the same state as the PPI districts, matched on various characteristics.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quasi-experimental design using DID regression with multivariate matching to estimate causal effects.  Subgroup analyses and exploratory analyses were also conducted.  Academic ROI was calculated using cost data from a separate study.

sections.title: Research Aims, Design and Methods
sections.methods_summary: A rapid evidence assessment (REA) of the literature was conducted, complemented by interviews with key informants. The REA involved searching academic and grey literature, screening titles and abstracts against inclusion/exclusion criteria, and full-text review of selected articles.  A total of 47 articles were included (35 with a primary focus on NHS staff involvement and 12 additional papers selected for relevance). Six semi-structured interviews with experts were also conducted.

sections.title: How NHS Staff Engage in Research: Methods Used
sections.methods_summary: The section categorizes various types of NHS staff involvement in research based on a literature review, identifying consultation, involvement, and collaboration models.  It details tasks and activities at different research stages (preparation/design, implementation, cross-cutting activities) and the methods used (e.g., Delphi surveys, focus groups, interviews, systematic reviews).

sections.title: Appendix B: Study Design and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used a rapid evidence assessment (REA) approach, consistent with systematic review principles but adapted for speed.  This involved iterative refinement of search terms (detailed in Table 10), searching PubMed and Scopus databases, screening titles and abstracts (with a second reviewer for uncertain cases), and full-text review.  A snowballing technique was used to identify additional studies.  Inclusion/exclusion criteria are detailed in Table 11.  Data extraction was performed using an Excel template and Endnote, focusing on various aspects of the studies (article type, study design, staff engagement methods, motivations, impacts, enablers/challenges).  Semi-structured interviews with six experts were also conducted, covering key motivations, awareness-raising strategies, methods of involvement, enablers/challenges, successful initiatives, and future engagement strategies.  Thematic analysis was used for interview data.

analysis.sample_description: 47 articles (35 core, 12 case studies) published from 2000 onwards, focusing on active NHS staff engagement in research (excluding passive participation and fellowship models). Six expert interviews with individuals from various organizations involved in NHS research and engagement.
analysis.analysis_approach: Narrative synthesis of literature findings, thematic analysis of interview data.  Limitations of included studies were noted and considered during synthesis.

sections.title: Background and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Quasi-experimental design using contemporaneous and historical comparison groups, propensity score matching for some programs, pre/post design for others.  Data collected by Los Angeles County Probation Department from databases; big six outcomes from official records, supplemental outcomes from CBOs, schools, and other county departments.  Statistical analysis using chi-square tests and difference-of-means tests (p<0.05 for significance). Difference-in-differences analyses added for programs using previous year's cohort as comparison group to account for differences in baseline risk profiles.

sections.title: Difference-in-Differences Analyses
sections.methods_summary: Logistic regression analysis used to compare changes in outcomes between current and previous year's cohorts (six months before and after program entry). Odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals calculated for interaction term (year x post) to assess significant differences in improvement between cohorts.

analysis.sample_description: The study included 31,781 youth who received JJCPA services in FY 2011-2012.  Comparison groups varied by program, including contemporaneous groups (matched on various characteristics), historical comparison groups (previous year's participants), and pre/post comparisons within the same youth.  Sample sizes varied across programs and outcome measures.
analysis.analysis_approach: Statistical significance assessed using chi-square tests and difference-of-means tests, with p<0.05 indicating significance.  Difference-in-differences analyses used logistic regression to control for baseline differences between cohorts when comparing current and previous years' data.  Mean and median costs were calculated and compared for cost analyses.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the five-step analytical approach used.  Step 1: Defined the study population (beneficiary-months) based on enrollment data and inclusion/exclusion criteria. Step 2: Extracted all relevant encounter data (ED) lines for 2015 and 2016. Step 3: Categorized lines into utilization categories using bill type, revenue center codes, and other ED information. Step 4: Aggregated individual ED lines into stays and visits. Step 5: Calculated utilization measures per beneficiary per year, including monthly and yearly calculations, means, standard deviations, and test statistics for changes between 2015 and 2016.  Specific details are provided for each step, including data sources and handling of missing data.

sections.title: Considerations for ED Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This section discusses key considerations in using encounter data (ED) for analysis, focusing on analytical decisions related to plan types, handling enrollment mismatches and switching, and differences between ED and Medicare fee-for-service (FFS) claims data.  It also addresses data field considerations such as service date ranges and units of service.

analysis.sample_description: The study population included all 2015 and 2016 beneficiary-months where the beneficiary was enrolled in Medicare Part A or B, enrolled in an MA contract, and whose reason for entitlement was not ESRD.  Beneficiary-months for MSA, cost, PACE, and MMP plans were excluded.  The final sample included local and regional coordinated care plans (CCPs) and private fee-for-service (PFFS) plans.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved calculating monthly and yearly utilization measures for five main categories (inpatient hospital stays, outpatient hospital visits, emergency department visits, other outpatient facility visits, and professional visits) and additional line-level measures.  Descriptive statistics (means, standard deviations, and proportions) were calculated for each measure, separately for 2015 and 2016, and for different plan types.  Test statistics were used to assess statistically significant changes in means between 2015 and 2016 at the beneficiary-month level.

sections.title: Receiver Aircraft Demand and Scheduling
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for calculating receiver aircraft fuel demands and scheduling their missions.  It involves routing aircraft from bases to targets via tanker orbits, minimizing the number of refueling stops using the NetworkX Python package.  Feasibility checks ensure sufficient aircraft, fuel, and runway availability at each base.  The process generates a schedule of receiver fuel requests at tanker orbits.

sections.title: Tanker Allocation Algorithm
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the greedy algorithm used to allocate tankers to refueling requests.  It prioritizes tankers based on a score combining fuel offload capacity and flight time.  The algorithm iteratively assigns tankers to requests, considering on-orbit and ground tankers, and handles cases where multiple tankers are needed for a single request.  It includes backtracking to re-optimize allocations if necessary and incorporates optional features like en-route buddy tanking and intra-orbital fuel transfers. The Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno numerical solver is used to optimize buddy tanking meet points.

sections.title: Incorporating Air Base Attacks
sections.methods_summary: This section explains how air base attacks are modeled.  The effects of attacks on fuel, runways, and aircraft are input using data files (potentially generated by TAB-VAM).  The model re-checks receiver takeoff feasibility and recalculates the tanker ATO after each attack, considering resource degradation.  A 24-hour window is used for replanning to avoid unrealistic foresight.  Aircraft damage is calculated based on ramp coverage and shelter availability, with fractional kills rounded to the nearest integer.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the U.S. Air Force Synthetic Theater Operations Research Model (STORM) and the RAND Combat Operations in Denied Environments (CODE) family of models, specifically the Theater Air Base Vulnerability Assessment Model (TAB-VAM), to generate scenarios and input data for the KARMA model.  The specific scenarios and data used are not explicitly detailed but are described as user-defined and changeable.
analysis.analysis_approach: The KARMA model is a deterministic, event-stepped simulation that uses a greedy algorithm to allocate tanker resources to meet receiver refueling requests.  The model incorporates feasibility checks for resources at air bases and considers various constraints such as aircraft performance, fuel capacity, runway availability, and attack damage.  The output includes amended ATOs, tanker ATOs, and detailed mission histories.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Review of documents and literature on insider threats and continuous evaluation (CE), and interviews with experts involved in efforts to improve the process.  The authors reviewed literature on CE approaches, considered cost estimates, examined efficacy and best practices, and assessed practicalities of employing CE.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Review of documents (executive orders, legislative requirements, policy memorandums, DoD and IC guidance, OPM and PAC reports, news articles, online media) and peer-reviewed academic journals and conference reports on insider threats and CE.  More than a dozen semi-structured interviews with subject-matter experts from government, industry, and academia.

analysis.sample_description: The study focused on three sectors: government, industry, and academia.  Specific sample sizes for interviews and documents reviewed are not explicitly stated, but the methodology indicates a broad range of sources were consulted.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach involved identifying commonalities and differences in definitions, practices, and challenges related to insider threats and CE across the three sectors.  The findings and recommendations were developed based on the answers to four research questions: What capabilities exist to combat insider threat? What aspects of CE are being implemented to address insider threats? What are some costs and benefits of CE? What could be considered in the future?

sections.title: References
sections.methods_summary: This section lists the references used in the study, not the methodology itself.

sections.title: References
sections.methods_summary: This section lists the references used in the study, not the methodology itself.

sections.title: References
sections.methods_summary: This section lists the references used in the study, not the methodology itself.

sections.title: References
sections.methods_summary: This section lists the references used in the study, not the methodology itself.

sections.title: About the Authors
sections.methods_summary: This section provides biographical information about the authors, not the methodology.

sections.title: Chapter Two: Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the simulation study design, including data sources (state-level firearm death rates from 1979-2014 and state-specific demographic and economic variables), simulation conditions (three effect conditions: true negative, null, and true positive; three law prevalence conditions: 3, 15, and 35 states; two phase-in conditions: instantaneous and five years), statistical models (linear, log-link, log-linear, negative binomial, Poisson, quasi-Poisson; with variations in link function, logarithmic transformation, population weights, autoregressive effects, coding for law's effect, fixed/random effects, state-specific linear trends, general estimating equations, standard error adjustments), and criteria for assessing model performance (type 1 error rate, correct rejection rate, directional bias, magnitude bias, robustness to omitted covariates, resistance to regression to the mean, temporal precedence).

sections.title: Appendix A: Technical Description of Evaluated Models
sections.methods_summary: Provides the mathematical formulas for the statistical models used in the simulation study, clarifying the notation and specifying the different coding schemes for the law's effect (effect coding and change coding).

analysis.sample_description: Actual state-level, annual firearm death rates from 1979 to 2014 (excluding the District of Columbia), along with state-specific demographic and economic covariates.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study used simulations to assess the performance of various statistical models in estimating the effect of state laws on firearm death rates.  Model performance was evaluated based on four criteria: type 1 error rate, correct rejection rate, directional bias, and magnitude bias.  The simulations varied the true effect of the law, the number of states implementing the law, and the phase-in period of the law's effect.  A wide range of statistical models and standard error adjustment methods were examined.

sections.title: Analysis of @GoArmy Twitter Account
sections.methods_summary: Lexical analysis (RAND-Lex software) of tweets, retweets, and mentions from May 1, 2016 to July 31, 2016.  Comparison with a baseline corpus of tweets from US military and Peace Corps accounts. Thematic analysis of keywords, word pairs, and triplets.

sections.title: Comparison of @GoArmy with Similar Twitter Accounts
sections.methods_summary: Collection of social media data from Twitter accounts associated with the U.S. Army, Air Force, Navy, Marines, and Peace Corps (May 1-July 31, 2016). Comparative analysis of posts, shares, retweets, and mentions. Creation of a "return on content" metric to compare account productivity, accounting for differences in follower count.

sections.title: Analysis of GoArmy Facebook Page
sections.methods_summary: Text mining to identify themes in posts and comments (January 2014-October 2016). Categorization of themes into six broad subjects.  Analysis of user engagement (likes, shares, comments) by time of day, day of week, and time of year. Categorization of commenters into three groups (general public, military personnel, military families).

sections.title: Facebook A/B Testing Experiment
sections.methods_summary: A/B testing of Facebook posts (July 1, 2017-September 10, 2017) to assess audience reaction to images of female soldiers.  Experimental posts systematically varied the presence of female soldiers in photos and text, and whether family members were depicted.  Comparison of engagement metrics (likes, shares, comments) between experimental posts and control posts.  Analysis of commenter gender and use of positive phrases.

sections.title: Analysis of GoArmy.com Website Data
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of website visits (July 2014-July 2016), including pages viewed, session duration, and geographic location of visitors. Regression analysis to examine the relationship between website visits and Army contracts, controlling for DMA, fiscal year, and month.  Analysis of website usage patterns by DMA size and demographic characteristics (using ACS data).

sections.title: Appendix A: Additional Results and Methodological Details
sections.methods_summary: Detailed descriptions of data sources and analytical techniques used in the study.  Includes information on lexical analysis methods, follower characterization, age estimation based on baby names, and regression models used for GoArmy.com data analysis.  Provides additional tables and figures detailing results.

analysis.sample_description: The study analyzed data from GoArmy.com, @GoArmy Twitter account, and GoArmy Facebook page.  Data collection periods varied by platform (e.g., July 2014-July 2016 for GoArmy.com, May 1-July 31, 2016 for Twitter analysis). The Facebook experiment used posts from July 1, 2017 to September 10, 2017.  Data on contracts were obtained from the Regular Army (RA) analyst database. Demographic data were from the American Community Survey (ACS).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved quantitative methods such as regression analysis, lexical analysis, and descriptive statistics, as well as qualitative analysis of post and comment content.  A/B testing was used to evaluate the impact of specific features in Facebook posts.  The study linked website data with census data and contract data to understand the audience and the relationship between website usage and recruitment outcomes.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: An online survey was designed and piloted with 10 non-native English speakers.  The survey was distributed through social media, email, and press releases.  After two weeks, additional outreach was conducted to underrepresented regions. 2769 responses were received and analyzed using R version 3.5.0.  Analysis included descriptive statistics, subgroup analyses (by career stage, nationality, country of work, research sector, and international mobility), and qualitative analysis of 1089 free-text responses.  Limitations of the analysis, including non-representative sampling and potential response bias, are discussed.

analysis.sample_description: 2,769 responses were received, with 2,465 identifying as researchers. The sample was not representative of the international research population, with overrepresentation from academic settings, medical and health sciences, and certain countries (UK, US, India).  Some regions (Oceania, South America) had insufficient responses for robust statistical comparisons.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data were analyzed using R version 3.5.0.  Quantitative analysis included descriptive statistics and subgroup analyses to compare responses across different groups (career stage, nationality, region, research sector, mobility experience). Qualitative analysis involved thematic coding of free-text responses to identify emerging themes and issues not captured by the structured questions.

sections.title: Model Overview
sections.methods_summary: A two-part simulation model is used.  A Markov model simulates transitions between disease states (normal cognition, MCI, Alzheimer's dementia) using annual transition probabilities from the literature. A system dynamics model, within the MCI state, simulates healthcare system capacity constraints during diagnosis and treatment, using stocks and flows to model delays when capacity is exceeded. A one-year time step is used.  The model includes decision points where patients may exit the model based on specified probabilities.

sections.title: Model Parameters and Capacity Projections
sections.methods_summary: The model uses parameters derived from various sources (listed in Table A.1), including population estimates, mortality rates, disease transition probabilities, and healthcare capacity data.  These parameters are adjusted for the Canadian context, including the inclusion of the 50-55 age group and updated transition and mortality rates.  Projections for the number of specialists, PET scanners, and infusion capacity are made based on historical trends and expert input.  A health care system capacity index is calculated based on four indicators (hospital beds, active nurses, MRI scanners, PET scanners) relative to the US.

primary_methods: Data synthesis from literature and expert input
analysis.sample_description: The model uses population data for Canadians aged 50 and older, broken down into disease states (normal cognition, MCI, Alzheimer's dementia).
analysis.analysis_approach: The model simulates the flow of patients through the healthcare system under different capacity scenarios.  Results are presented as projections of wait times and other relevant metrics.

sections.title: Study Framework and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach including document reviews, identification of best practice models, key informant interviews, focus groups, analysis of existing data, and collection of new data.  Data sources included publicly available information on city demographics, parent survey data from the city and SMMUSD, five focus groups with Santa Monica parents, an inventory of local programs (from city, SMMUSD, and other partners, and interviews with providers), cost data from a sample of ESAC providers, and interviews with parents and representatives from various organizations.  The study also involved a review of relevant documents and identification of service delivery approaches and funding strategies in other communities.

analysis.sample_description: The study included data from publicly available information on Santa Monica demographics, parent survey data collected by the city and SMMUSD, five focus groups with Santa Monica parents, cost data from a small sample of ESAC providers, and interviews with a broad range of stakeholders including parents, representatives from organizations such as the local community college and the Parent-Teacher Association, and providers.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved constructing an inventory of local programs, analyzing parent survey data, and identifying best practice models from other communities.  The findings were organized around four key themes: access and participation, quality of care, service delivery, and financing.

sections.title: Overview of Methodologies Used
sections.methods_summary: Literature review, questionnaire design, expert workshop, development of cost models.

sections.title: Overview of Methodologies Used
sections.methods_summary: Figure 2 visually depicts the methodologies: Overview of non-European armoured vehicles landscape, Overview of European armoured vehicles landscape, Cost model development, Overview of key demand trends and fleets, Overview of key industrial suppliers.  Specific methods listed are: Literature review, Cost model design, Literature review, Collaborative Database update, Government questionnaire design, Industry questionnaire design.

analysis.sample_description: The study considered EDA partner countries Norway, Serbia and Switzerland, following the EDA’s recommendation.  The study also involved EDA member states (pMS) representatives in an expert workshop.
analysis.analysis_approach: High-level overview of supply and demand elements related to current and future trends in armoured vehicle servicing, research and development (R&D) and procurement.  Development of cost models to estimate potential savings for five collaboration models and two PESCO scenarios.  Analysis of publicly available cost information and operational knowledge of the study team and experts. Parametric cost estimates used where data was unavailable.

sections.title: Approach and Limitations
sections.methods_summary: Two complementary methods: (1) collecting expenditure information from 10 illustrative providers (5 public, 5 private); (2) developing a cost model informed by the interviewed providers to estimate per-pupil costs under baseline and alternative assumptions (program scale, local price differences, teacher qualifications, transportation).

sections.title: Approach and Limitations
sections.methods_summary: Two approaches: (1) collecting information on CERDEP expenditures from a small number of illustrative public and private providers; (2) developing a cost model informed by the providers to estimate CERDEP per-pupil cost under baseline assumptions and variation in cost under alternative assumptions (program scale, local price differences, teacher qualifications, transportation).

sections.title: Approach and Limitations
sections.methods_summary: Two complementary approaches: (1) collecting information on CERDEP expenditures from a small number of illustrative public and private providers; (2) developing a cost model informed by the providers to estimate CERDEP per-pupil cost under baseline assumptions and variation in cost under alternative assumptions (program scale, local price differences, teacher qualifications, transportation).

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Purposive selection of 5 public school districts and 5 private center-based CERDEP providers to capture variation in program setting, scale, and region. Telephone interviews (except one district that submitted data electronically) focusing on program features, staffing, revenue, and expenditures.  Allocation of shared resources to CERDEP classrooms based on enrollment or classroom share. Per-pupil cost calculation, with adjustments for occupancy, transportation, and class size to improve comparability.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Developed a cost model (cost-estimation model or cost calculator) for the traditional year program option (6.5 hours/day, 180 days/year) based on PCQC, benchmarked against 10 providers from Chapter 2.  Model considers four illustrative provider types (public school district, private center with public school compensation, private center with private center compensation, private center with associate degree lead teacher) and sensitivity analyses (salaries/unit costs, program size, class size, rent, transportation).

analysis.sample_description: Purposive sample of 10 CERDEP providers (5 public school districts, 5 private centers) selected to represent variation in program setting, scale, and geographic location.  Not a representative sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: Illustrative per-pupil cost estimates from provider data, with adjustments for occupancy, transportation, and class size.  Model-based estimates of per-pupil costs under baseline and alternative scenarios, comparing costs with CERDEP reimbursement rates.

sections.title: Objectives of the Project
sections.methods_summary: Annual data collection from each ChalleNGe site to support the program’s yearly report to Congress.  This includes measures of program participation, credentials awarded, standardized test scores, community service, and voter/Selective Service registration.  Site-specific information on participants, staffing, and funding is also collected, along with post-ChalleNGe placement data.  The second objective is to identify longer-term metrics for program effectiveness, using data from annual reports, qualitative data from site visits, and analysis of existing data (e.g., national samples).

sections.title: Cross-Site Metrics for the 2017 ChalleNGe Classes
sections.methods_summary: Quantitative information collected from ChalleNGe sites in fall 2018 using an Excel spreadsheet template.  The template was revised in 2017 and 2018. Data requested included program-level and cadet-level information on program characteristics, budget, applicants, participants, graduates, credentials, physical fitness, community service, staffing, class dates, and post-residential placements. Data were requested for cadets who entered the program in 2017 (Classes 48 and 49).

sections.title: Focus of This Report and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Combined methodologies:  (1) Collection of quantitative data from ChalleNGe sites (program characteristics, budget, applicants, participants, graduates, credentials, physical fitness, community service, staffing, class dates, post-residential placements); (2) Development of tools (theory of change model, program logic model) to help determine preferred outcome metrics; (3) Collection of qualitative data through site visits (interviews with program leadership and staff on various program aspects); (4) Planning and execution of additional analytic efforts (benchmarking, mentoring analysis, CTE examination).

sections.title: Assisting ChalleNGe Through Benchmarking Youth Outcomes and Research on Mentoring
sections.methods_summary: The chapter describes the program logic model, site visits (interviewing program leadership and staff), and additional analytic efforts.  These efforts include research on mentorship, career and technical education (CTE), and community service, as well as empirical analysis of data (value-added model to examine characteristics associated with higher TABE score gains).

sections.title: Site Visits
sections.methods_summary: Site visits to ChalleNGe sites to interview program leadership and staff. Topics covered included program mission, resources, staffing, outreach, data collection strategies, mentor training, cadet placements, recruiting, instruction, credentials, and occupational training.  A detailed protocol was used.

sections.title: Other Analytic Efforts
sections.methods_summary: Multiple data sources used: annual data from program sites, qualitative data from site visits, and publicly available data from nationally representative surveys.  Analytic efforts included research on mentorship, CTE, and community service; development of benchmarks for at-risk youth; analysis of ChalleNGe graduation rates and program-level differences; and pilot programs to improve data collection and mentor training.

sections.title: Developing Benchmarks for At-Risk Youth
sections.methods_summary: Used nationally representative surveys of young adults (NLSY, Current Population Survey, American Community Survey) to compare three groups: high school dropouts without GEDs, high school dropouts with GEDs, and high school graduates who didn't attend college.  Compared these groups across metrics during dropout (ages 14-18) and outcome (ages 19-29) windows.  Developed a high-low range of expected outcomes for each metric.

sections.title: Insights from the Literature and Site Visits on Mentorship
sections.methods_summary: Reviewed literature on youth-initiated mentoring (YIM). Analyzed interview notes from 22 site visits (2017 and 2018) using qualitative analysis to identify barriers to implementing a robust mentoring program.  Coding scheme was revised iteratively until no new codes emerged (grounded theory approach).

analysis.sample_description: Data from 39 ChalleNGe sites across 28 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico.  Data primarily focused on Classes 48 and 49 (2017 cohorts), with some longitudinal data from previous years.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, trend analysis, t-tests, multivariate regression analysis (mentioned but not detailed).

sections.title: Field Study Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Semistructured interviews, observations of workflow, and process analysis were conducted at SMU and RIP facilities in each of the three MEFs.  Initial meetings with unit leadership and key staff were held, followed by walkthrough tours of the facilities.  Discussions were held with various personnel (CWOs, officers, NCOs, enlisted Marines, civilians, and contractors) to understand tasks, challenges, and best practices.

sections.title: Workload Demand Modeling
sections.methods_summary: A task-frequency-duration workforce demand model was used to estimate average daily hours worked per Marine on intermediate supply tasks.  Data sources included I MEF SOPs, a III MEF time study (2017), and SME input where data were missing.  The model calculated total time spent on tasks (receiving, stowing, picking, packing, shipping, inventory, and secondary tasks) per day and divided by the number of Marines on hand to estimate average daily hours per Marine.  A Monte Carlo simulation was used to account for variation in task times and personnel on hand.  The model was primarily applied to the III MEF storage section due to data availability, but the methodology is recommended for other sections.  Analysis of the relationship between demand and the number of supported units was also conducted using GCSS-MC requisition data.

analysis.sample_description: Data were collected from three Marine Expeditionary Forces (MEFs): I MEF (Camp Pendleton), II MEF (Camp Lejeune), and III MEF (Camp Butler).  The study focused primarily on the Supply Management Units (SMUs) and Repairable Issue Points (RIPs) within each MEF, with additional visits to maintenance and customer units.  Data on task times and frequencies were primarily from III MEF, with SME input used to supplement missing data.
analysis.analysis_approach: A bottom-up task-frequency-duration model was used to estimate workload.  A Monte Carlo simulation was used to assess the impact of variability in task times and personnel availability.  Correlation analysis was used to examine the relationship between demand and the number of supported units.

sections.title: Chapter Three: Considering the “Right” Cases: Identifying Relevant Subsamples
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the process of selecting the cases for analysis.  Initially, 71 cases were considered.  Cases fought against the tide of history (end of colonialism or apartheid) were excluded, as was one case with a mixed outcome (La Violencia in Colombia). This resulted in a core set of 59 cases.  Subpopulations within the core cases were also identified: iron fist, motive-focused, and external actor cases.

sections.title: Appendix A: Methods and Data
sections.methods_summary: This appendix details the methodology.  It describes the use of Charles Ragin's Qualitative Comparative Analysis (QCA), specifically crisp-set QCA using fsQCA software.  The process of case selection is explained, starting with a larger list of insurgencies and narrowing it down to 71 based on criteria. The exclusion of La Violencia is justified. Factor generation, evaluation, and scoring are detailed, highlighting the iterative and inductive process of refining factors based on literature review, data collection, and analysis.  Outcome assessment is explained, including the logic for assigning binary outcomes (COIN win/loss) even for cases with ambiguous results. Data collection procedures are described, emphasizing the use of secondary sources.  The use of phased data to capture changes over time is explained. Finally, the four types of analysis used are summarized: narrative analysis, bivariate analysis, QCA, and survival analysis.

sections.title: Appendix B: Details of Qualitative Comparative Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This appendix provides further detail on the QCA methodology. It explains the use of crisp-set QCA and the iterative process of identifying prime implicants by repeatedly running analyses with different combinations of factors.  The limitations of the approach due to computational constraints are discussed. The results are presented, showing the identification of a simple two-factor prime implicant and a set of nine concepts that consistently contributed to prime implicant patterns.

sections.title: Appendix C: Details of Survival Analyses
sections.methods_summary: This appendix details the survival analysis methodology. It describes the analysis of insurgency duration and peace intervals using Cox proportional hazard models with a robust variance estimator. The selection of factors for analysis is explained, and the reasons for focusing on the 28 COIN wins are justified.  The issue of right-censoring in the analysis of peace intervals is addressed.  Results are presented in tables showing statistically significant hazard ratios for various factors.

analysis.sample_description: 71 insurgencies begun and completed worldwide between World War II and 2010.  A core set of 59 cases was used for most analyses after excluding cases fought against the tide of history and one case with an indeterminate outcome. Subpopulations were also analyzed: iron fist, motive-focused, and external actor cases.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study employed a mixed-methods approach, combining qualitative case narratives with quantitative analysis.  Bivariate analysis examined relationships between individual factors and outcomes. QCA identified minimally sufficient configurations of factors explaining success and failure. Survival analysis investigated the impact of factors on insurgency duration and post-conflict peace intervals.

sections.title: Case Selection and Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: This research quantitatively tested the performance of 24 COIN concepts against the historical record.  These concepts were identified through a review of existing literature and prior research.  The analysis used detailed case studies of 71 insurgencies, incorporating both quantitative data on nearly 300 factors and qualitative narratives.  Qualitative narratives suggested hypotheses tested quantitatively, and vice-versa, iteratively refining the analysis.  Cases fought against historical trends (end of colonialism, end of apartheid) were removed from quantitative analysis, leaving 59 core cases.  The core cases were further divided into 'iron fist' and 'motive-focused' categories, and those with external actor involvement were analyzed separately.

analysis.sample_description: 71 resolved insurgencies from World War II to 2010; 59 core cases after removing those whose outcomes were primarily driven by exogenous factors; further sub-divided by COIN approach (iron fist vs. motive-focused) and external actor involvement.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative testing of 24 COIN concepts against historical data; iterative process of qualitative and quantitative analysis to refine hypotheses and factors; scorecard approach to discriminate wins and losses based on good and bad COIN practices.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Literature review of 200 most-cited peer-reviewed articles on ethics in scientific research and codes of ethics from various scientific disciplines.  Interviews with experts in the US, Europe, and China to address gaps in the literature. Data collection involved searching Scopus and Web of Science for highly cited articles and codes of conduct, followed by thematic coding and analysis.  Interviews were semi-structured.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a two-stage approach. First, a literature review was conducted using Scopus and Web of Science to identify the 200 most-cited articles on research ethics and codes of conduct.  These documents were then coded thematically. Second, semi-structured interviews were conducted with experts in the US, Europe, and China to address gaps identified in the literature review.  The interviews were reviewed by RAND’s Human Subjects Protection Committee and deemed not to involve human subjects.

analysis.sample_description: 200 most-cited peer-reviewed articles on ethics in scientific research and codes of ethics across scientific disciplines; 15 interviews with experts in the US, Europe, and China.
analysis.analysis_approach: Thematic coding and analysis of literature; semi-structured interviews to address gaps in the literature.

sections.title: Research Approach and Game Design Process
sections.methods_summary: The research involved an extensive literature review of books, articles, and white papers on the gray zone and related concepts like hybrid war.  This was followed by a systematic categorization of actions considered to fall under the gray zone, identifying key characteristics and developing a definition of gray zone tactics.  Further literature reviews focused on Russian gray zone threats in Europe, examining the strengths and weaknesses of European states and Russian influence tactics.  Finally, the research explored countermeasures taken by the US and European nations.  The game design was iterative, starting with matrix games (argumentation-based with probabilistic adjudication), progressing to a semi-structured game with a menu of options and partial rules, and culminating in a structured board game with a fully specified set of rules and a combat results table (CRT) for adjudicating outcomes.  The structured game used simple physical components (cards) and a transparent adjudication model, allowing for player feedback and iterative rule refinement.

sections.title: Game Design Choices and Development
sections.methods_summary: Key design choices included limiting the geographic scope to the Balkans, creating a three-sided game (Russia, US, Europe), incorporating a two-pronged timeline (short-term 3-month turns and long-term yearly turns), and including a wide variety of gray zone and non-gray zone tactics.  The game board included country scores (orientation, governance, media freedom, economic dependence), NATO unity tracker, and Russian regime stability tracker.  Country scores were determined using various indexes (Freedom House, World Bank, etc.) and expert review.  The timeline facilitated tracking of actions and their cumulative effects.  Action cards represented available tactics, with rules for determining success probabilities based on CRTs and contextual factors.  The game design was iterative, with earlier games informing the development of the final structured game.

sections.title: Game Play, Adjudication, and Special Rules
sections.methods_summary: The game involved three teams (Russia, US, Europe) competing over influence in the Balkans.  The Red team (Russia) aimed to expand influence and undermine NATO unity, while the Blue and Green teams aimed to defend allies.  The game used a card-driven system with a timeline and map.  Adjudication was largely transparent, using probabilistic outcomes based on CRTs and contextual factors (country scores, prior actions).  Special rules were included for covert actions (probabilistic revelation), elections (random draw with modifiers), and instability (emerging organically or through actions, requiring countermeasures).

analysis.sample_description: RAND experts on Russian, European, and U.S. defense and intelligence policy participated as players in multiple iterations of the game.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis incorporated game results into a larger body of research on Russian gray zone tactics.  The game itself was not presented as an experiment, but rather as an exploratory tool to generate insights.

sections.title: Appendix. Metrics: Methods for Generating Dashboard Metrics
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methods used to calculate each metric included in the dashboard.  It describes the specific steps and calculations involved for each metric, including those related to teacher effectiveness, equity of access to effective teaching, student achievement, and college readiness.  The methods often involve data aggregation, calculations of percentages, percentiles, and deciles, and comparisons across different subgroups of students and teachers.  The section also notes variations in methods across different sites and adjustments made to account for data limitations and changes in data collection procedures over time.

analysis.sample_description: The study involved data from seven initial sites (three school districts and four charter management organizations) and an eighth site added later.  Data included administrative data, teacher and school leader surveys, classroom observations, and student and parent satisfaction surveys.  The data covered a 12-year period (SY 2006–2007 to SY 2017–2018).  Specific subgroups of students (e.g., low-income minority students) were analyzed.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved calculating various metrics annually and presenting them in dashboards.  The methods for calculating each metric are described in detail in the appendix.  The analysis also involved comparing trends over time and across different sites, accounting for changes in data collection procedures and testing regimes.  Statistical tests (e.g., t-tests) were used to compare averages across subgroups.  The analysis also addressed issues of missing data and data standardization across different sites.

sections.title: Description of Study Methods and Limitations
sections.methods_summary: The study used document review and interviews.  Researchers reviewed DHS, USCG, and CG-9 guidance and documentation, as well as documents provided by CG-9325.  More than 25 interviews were conducted with members of the Boats Program, USCG stakeholders, and other acquisition organizations inside and outside the USCG.

analysis.sample_description: Interviews included members of the USCG Boats Program, stakeholders within the USCG, and other acquisition organizations (both internal and external to the USCG) managing similar acquisition programs.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis based on interviews with SMEs and research.  Comparative assessment of alternative program structures and funding strategies using four criteria: ability to add projects, flexibility, ability to interface with stakeholders, and staffing.

sections.title: Overview of Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The project used a mixed-methods approach with two streams: a forward-tracing stream starting from hot research topics and tracing their impacts, and a backward-tracing stream starting from treatment advances and tracing their contributing factors.  Data collection involved interviews, desk research (academic literature, practice guidelines), and bibliometrics. Data validation included review by interviewees and peer review for case studies.

sections.title: Case Study Selection Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The unit of analysis was 'research clouds,' defined as units of research sharing a common purpose.  Case studies were selected using a bibliometric approach, identifying highly cited papers (85th-95th percentile) published between 1985-1990 in neuroscience and mental health research from the Web of Science. Papers were grouped by research type (basic, clinical, interventional) and country. A matrix was populated, and papers were randomly selected within each group.  The selection process aimed for a range of research types and countries, mitigating bias but acknowledging pragmatic limitations (e.g., researcher contact).

sections.title: Perspectives Selection Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Perspectives aimed to identify recent advances in schizophrenia care. Selection used a Delphi-like survey of experts, supplemented by a review of clinical guidelines and expert advisor input.  The survey had a low response rate, particularly from service users. The final selection aimed for a balance of pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions, considering various stages of translation and uptake across countries.

sections.title: Case Study Development Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Case studies followed the Payback Framework's logic model, structured into 13 sections covering research origins, inputs, processes, primary and secondary outputs, dissemination, adoption, and outcomes. Data collection involved interviews (48 people across 18 case studies), desk research (scientific literature, policy documents, etc.), and bibliometric analysis of publications. Validation included review by interviewees and independent peer review by experts.

sections.title: Perspectives Development Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Perspectives provided detailed views on the development and translation of interventions.  The structure was iterative, including summary, scope, timeline, historiograph, narrative, and observations. Data collection involved interviews (34 interviews across 6 perspectives) and desk research. Validation involved review and approval by interviewees.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis involved coding case studies for factors influencing impact using NVivo software, a scoring process by an expert panel (rating impact across five categories), and a statistically guided narrative analysis.  The panel's scores were analyzed for consensus and correlation between impact categories.  Possible confounding characteristics (basic/clinical classification, case study authorship, resources, research domain) were examined.  Perspectives were analyzed thematically to identify contributing and hindering factors.

analysis.sample_description: 18 case studies of research clouds from 1985-1990 in mental health and neuroscience, focusing on schizophrenia, across Canada, the USA, and the UK. 6 perspectives on recent advances in schizophrenia treatment.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative coding of case studies, quantitative scoring of impact by expert panel, statistical analysis (Fisher's exact test) to assess associations between factors and impact, thematic analysis of perspectives, examination of potential confounding factors.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative comparative study using a mixed-methods approach: crowdsourcing, desk research (rapid evidence assessment), key informant interviews, and a workshop.

sections.title: Annex A. Methodological Approach
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods approach across three phases. Phase 1: Selecting case vignettes through crowdsourcing (Google Sheet template) with experts and online searches (Google and Google Scholar). Phase 2: Developing case vignettes using accelerated evidence assessment of academic and grey literature, key informant interviews (semi-structured, up to one hour each), and a reporting template. Phase 3: Comparative analysis of case vignettes in a workshop with Wellcome, followed by report writing.

analysis.sample_description: Ten case vignettes (historical and current) encompassing diverse geographical contexts, sectors, and science and technology areas, selected through crowdsourcing and online searches.
analysis.analysis_approach: Comparative analysis of case vignettes to extract common themes and lessons learned, primarily through a workshop involving the study team and Wellcome representatives.  Triangulation of findings across vignettes to identify common themes from successful and unsuccessful oversight approaches.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This report examines a range of possible means to extend Russia by analyzing Russia’s economic, political, and military vulnerabilities and anxieties using quantitative and qualitative data from Western and Russian sources.  It then analyzes potential policy options to exploit these vulnerabilities, assessing benefits, costs, risks, and likelihood of success.  The analysis includes economic, geopolitical, ideological, informational, and military (air and space, maritime, land, and multidomain) options.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is a policy analysis report, not an empirical study with a defined sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report uses a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative data (e.g., economic statistics, military budgets) with qualitative data (e.g., expert opinions, policy documents, news reports) to analyze potential policy options for extending Russia.  The analysis focuses on assessing the benefits, costs, risks, and likelihood of success for each option.

sections.title: Prioritization of Needs Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Participants used coins to vote on strategies and actions for mitigating the opioid crisis.  Needs were categorized into four topics (overdose response, cooperation, officer safety, forensics).  A hierarchical clustering algorithm (Ward's method) was used to group needs into top, middle, and lower tiers based on total votes received.  Clustering was performed both overall and within each topic category.  Analysis also examined the distribution of votes across action categories (disseminate, resolve resource shortfalls, solve technology shortfalls, address community concerns, resolve legal barriers, research/evaluate).

sections.title: Prioritization of Needs: Technical Appendix
sections.methods_summary: Details on participant recruitment (invitations to experts via professional networks and literature review).  The hierarchical clustering algorithm used Ward's method implemented via the 'hclust' function in R's stats package.  Needs were categorized into three tiers (top, middle, lower).

analysis.sample_description: More than 100 participants initially, 28 remaining for the final prioritization session.  Participants included established researchers and leading practitioners with significant knowledge of and experience with the opioid epidemic, representing law enforcement, public health, first responders, and community leaders.  Note that the final prioritization sample may have been biased due to participant attrition.
analysis.analysis_approach: Hierarchical clustering to categorize needs into tiers based on vote counts.  Analysis of vote distribution across action categories to identify priorities for implementation, research, and barrier resolution.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for measuring four key variables: power, threat perception, economic complementarity, and ideology.  For power, an aggregate measure integrating military capabilities, economic capacity, and technology is used.  Military power is assessed through an index of key capabilities (strategic capabilities, global power projection, A2/AD capabilities). Economic capacity is measured by multiplying GDP by GDP per capita. Technological capacity is measured by an index of R&D expenditure, number of researchers, triadic patents, and high-tech exports. Threat is assessed by considering the balance of offensive capabilities and perceived aggressive intentions.  Economic complementarity is measured using factor endowments (capital stock, labor force, skilled labor force, oil and gas reserves, arable land). Ideology is assessed by examining the system of domestic government, views on the international political order, and views on the international economic order, using a 1-5 scale for each component and summing for an overall score.

primary_methods: Index creation (aggregate power, military capabilities, technological capacity)
analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is a policy analysis report, not an empirical study with a defined sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach involves using the measured variables to explain changes in the Sino-Russian relationship over time, categorized using a six-point scale (conflict, confrontation, calculation, cooperation, collaboration, coalition).  The analysis seeks to identify which factors (power, threat, ideology, economic complementarity) best explain the observed changes in the relationship.

sections.title: Research Approach: Objectives
sections.methods_summary: Developed a framework for assessing benefits of interoperability; illustrated framework with examples of recent Army initiatives; drew on interoperability literature and stakeholder interviews (nearly four dozen individuals) to formulate current perceptions and expectations for interoperability; targeted individuals in the Pentagon, combatant commands, service component commands, and other areas involved in implementing interoperability; used snowball interviews.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: Multipronged approach: literature review (research studies, senior leader statements, national security strategy documents, bilateral and multilateral strategic vision statements, Army operational guidance, lessons learned), stakeholder discussions (interviews with over 100 people from various Army and DoD entities, focusing on personnel with backgrounds in operations, intelligence, plans, fires, sustainment, and communications).  Interview protocol included questions about past examples of interoperability, linking values of interoperability to goals, ongoing activities, and costs.

analysis.sample_description: Nearly four dozen individuals in the Pentagon, combatant commands, service component commands, and other areas involved in implementing interoperability.  Over 100 people in total from various Army and DoD entities, including personnel from operations, intelligence, plans, fires, sustainment, and communications.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data and literature review findings to identify benefits, objectives, and strategies related to interoperability.  The findings were used to develop a framework for understanding the value proposition of interoperability.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods approach using a survey of intended users (convenience sample) from public health, environmental health, food regulatory agencies, and public health laboratories, and in-depth interviews with staff from local jurisdictions and state agencies familiar with the CIFOR Guidelines and Toolkit (purposive sample).

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods approach using a survey of intended users (convenience sample) from public health, environmental health, and food regulatory agencies, as well as public health laboratories, and in-depth interviews with staff from local jurisdictions and state agencies familiar with the CIFOR Guidelines and Toolkit (purposive sample).

sections.title: Survey Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Electronic survey (SurveyMonkey) distributed through CIFOR member organizations (AFDO, APHL, ASTHO, CSTE, NACCHO, NEHA) to public health professionals involved in foodborne disease outbreak response.  The survey addressed awareness, use, implementation of recommendations, barriers and facilitators, and feedback on content and ease of use.  Data analysis included descriptive statistics.

sections.title: Interview Methodology
sections.methods_summary: In-depth interviews conducted via conference call with two groups: CIFOR Council representatives (purposive sample) and staff from local jurisdictions and state agencies (purposive sample selected for diversity and prior use of resources).  A semi-structured interview protocol was used.  Data analysis involved content analysis and pile sorting.

analysis.sample_description: Survey: Convenience sample of intended users from various organizations, jurisdictional levels, and job functions. Interviews: Purposive sample of CIFOR Council representatives and staff from local jurisdictions and state agencies selected for diversity and prior use of resources.  Both samples may not be fully representative of the entire population of intended users.
analysis.analysis_approach: Survey: Descriptive statistics. Interviews: Content analysis and pile sorting of interview notes to identify major themes.

sections.title: Preface
sections.methods_summary: This report documents research and analysis conducted as part of a project entitled Lessons Learned from 13 Years of Conflict: The Battle for Baghdad, 2003–2008, sponsored by the Office of Quadrennial Defense Review, U.S. Army. The project was intended to capture key lessons to help the U.S. Army and U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) retain institutional knowledge and capabilities, as well as to serve as a history of the U.S. Army’s efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan from 2001 to 2016.

sections.title: Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study on which this report is based consisted of the following four tasks: 1. Build the evidentiary base for a history of the battle and analysis of urban combat using primary and secondary sources. 2. Develop an initial historical outline and analytical framework for subsequent analysis. 3. Interview key players from all phases of the battle. 4. Finalize the history of the battle, draw key lessons for urban combat, and examine the strategic lessons learned from the conflict.

analysis.sample_description: 51 key military and civilian leaders were interviewed, representing a cross-section of perspectives.  The interviews included former senior military commanders and national security officials.
analysis.analysis_approach: The evidentiary base for the report’s history of the war comes from a broad literature review, primary sources, and interviews.  The Iraq War and the Battle for Baghdad are divided into periods (prewar planning, occupation, GEN George Casey’s command, the troop surge, and withdrawal) to frame the analysis.

sections.title: Methodological Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a qualitative approach involving cognitive interviews with clinicians and patients.  Participants were recruited from three VA medical centers.  The interviews presented various displays of PHQ-9 and PCL-5 mock scores, exploring participants' familiarity, impressions, preferences, and suggestions for improvement. Data analysis involved detailed note review, checked against audio recordings, to identify themes and preferences regarding display features (directionality, interpretive guidance, color use, treatment milestones).  The number of participants expressing specific preferences was counted, but thematic analysis was prioritized due to the semi-structured interview format.

analysis.sample_description: 15 clinicians (psychiatrists, clinical psychologists, behavioral health nurse practitioners) and 17 patients receiving behavioral health treatment at participating VA clinics (VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System and VA Long Beach Healthcare System). Most patients (88%) had some familiarity with symptom measures.
analysis.analysis_approach: Detailed notes from interviews (checked against audio recordings) were analyzed to identify themes and preferences regarding display features.  Counts of participants expressing specific preferences were provided where meaningful, but thematic analysis was the primary approach due to the semi-structured nature of the interviews.  Recommendations for additional features were also extracted and categorized.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach.  It involved literature reviews to understand drivers of medical product invention and adoption, 50 one-on-one interviews with healthcare experts, and case studies of eight healthcare products. A technical expert panel was also convened to review findings and policy options.

analysis.sample_description: 50 one-on-one interviews with health care industry leaders, drug and device inventors, regulators, health care payers and insurers, venture capitalists, and researchers.  Eight case studies of medical products (three drugs, three devices, two HIT).  The case studies and interview samples are not representative.
analysis.analysis_approach: Information from literature reviews, interviews, and the technical expert panel were synthesized to develop five themes highlighting features of the U.S. healthcare environment affecting the incentives of primary actors.  These themes informed the development of policy options. Case studies were used for illustrative purposes, not inference.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The evaluation used a combination of survey, interview, aggregate utilization, encounter, and cost data to assess the GPP’s implementation and impact. A pre-post design was used to assess changes in utilization of services between SFY 2015-2016 and SFY 2017-2018, and changes in payments and costs between SFY 2014-2015 and SFY 2016-2017. An interview protocol was developed and fielded for GPP team leads and their teams to describe infrastructure investments.

sections.title: Data Sources and Statistical Methods
sections.methods_summary: The evaluation used survey, interview, aggregate utilization, encounter, and cost data. A pre-post design was used.  Statistical methods were primarily descriptive, focusing on changes in utilization measured in points and shares of total points.  No statistical significance tests were performed due to concerns about p-values and small sample size. Survey responses were summarized using means, standard deviations, and sample sizes.

primary_methods: Analysis of administrative data (utilization, cost, payments)
analysis.sample_description: The study included data from 12 of California's Public Health Care Systems (PHCSs) participating in the Global Payment Program (GPP).  The uninsured population included those lacking insurance entirely and those uninsured for specific services due to restricted-scope Medi-Cal coverage.
analysis.analysis_approach: Primarily descriptive statistics were used to analyze utilization, cost, and survey data. Changes in utilization were measured in points earned under the GPP point system, and shares of total points were calculated to understand relative changes.  Changes were assessed between specific fiscal years (SFY 2015-2016 and SFY 2017-2018 for utilization; SFY 2014-2015 and SFY 2016-2017 for payments and costs). Qualitative data from interviews and surveys were analyzed using inductive and deductive coding approaches to identify themes and variations across PHCSs.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Review of prior analyses of WRM and CDO environments; academic literature review of global management; investigation of global management in industry; evaluation of conditions under which global management of WRM could provide better support to the warfighter; review of other armed services’ WRM practices; comparison of current Air Force WRM practices with how WRM could be globally managed; suggestion of processes, analytic capabilities, tools, and systems that the Air Force could employ to improve global management of WRM.

sections.title: A Visualization Tool to Map WRM Processes
sections.methods_summary: Used Air Force Instructions (AFIs) and discussions with Air Force WRM SMEs to develop a high-level view of the WRM process.  Translated information from AFIs, creating a database.  Pulled out keywords, offices, and tools, attributing weights to the most relevant items. Used Gephi visualization software to create network visualizations.  Created five distinct sets of visualizations based on different combinations of organizations, tools, and keywords.

sections.title: Global Management in Academic Literature
sections.methods_summary: Literature review of global and regional management strategies in multinational firms, focusing on the centralization vs. decentralization of decision-making and the trade-offs between responsiveness, reliability, and efficiency.  Analysis of the benefits and drawbacks of global management strategies, considering various risk factors (supply, operational, demand, security, macroeconomic, and policy risks).

sections.title: SPRAT Motivation and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Literature review of political risk assessment in logistics and supply chain literature; consultations with SMEs; study of the RAND Security Cooperation Prioritization and Propensity Matching Tool; review of previous RAND studies on U.S. overseas military presence; identification of 15 measures organized into two broad categories to capture factors affecting a host nation’s willingness and capacity to reliably secure, store, and provide access to prepositioned WRM assets; data collection from open-source data and information sources; development of a coding scheme to present data in a simplified spreadsheet.

sections.title: Tools to Enhance Air Force Management of WRM
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of joint policy requirements for WRM global management; description of Lean-START tool for lean force package planning; comparison of equipment requirements between USAFE and PACAF using Lean-START; development of a capability-based framework for classifying WRM; creation of a decision tree framework to connect capabilities to posture options; use of the PRePO model to analyze WRM prepositioning postures; development of SPRAT to assess political, economic, and strategic risks; recommendation for tools and metrics to measure readiness for mission support assets.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from various sources, including Air Force Instructions, academic literature, industry reports, and government agency data.  Specific samples are described within the relevant sections (e.g., the sample of countries in the SPRAT analysis).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a mixed-methods approach, combining qualitative analysis of policy documents and expert interviews with quantitative analysis using optimization models (PRePO) and a newly developed risk assessment tool (SPRAT).  The analysis also includes comparative analysis of different management strategies and case studies of global management practices in various sectors.

sections.title: Data Collection Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach, drawing on survey data, phone interviews, and in-depth case studies.  A survey was administered to principals approximately two years after they began the EDP, with a 63% response rate.  Phone interviews were conducted with 74 principals (48% participation rate) who had completed at least 10 of the 12 EDP units. Nine in-depth case studies were conducted, selecting principals from a list of 26 best-practice candidates nominated by NISL.  Case studies involved multiple site visits, interviews with principals and key implementers, focus groups with staff, classroom observations, and collection of supporting documentation.  Additional phone interviews were conducted with principals and their NISL coaches.

analysis.sample_description: The study included 192 principals from various school contexts (rural, suburban, urban; elementary, middle, high schools; 1-17 years of experience as principal).  All completed at least some of the EDP's 12-unit program; 89% completed 10 or more units. 116 principals received approximately two years of one-on-one NISL coaching.  The case study sample of nine principals was selected from 26 best-practice candidates nominated by NISL, aiming for diversity in school improvement topics, school levels, and urbanicity.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report analyzes principals' self-reported views and patterns in applying EDP lessons in their schools.  While the report focuses on qualitative findings from surveys, interviews, and case studies, it mentions that it complements a future independent, causal analysis of the EDP's effect on student achievement.  The appendix provides more details on sample, data collection, and analysis methods.

sections.title: Methodology: Case Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: This case study uses a qualitative approach, drawing on data from interviews and focus groups with the principal, assistant principals, teacher-coaches, and teachers.  Classroom observations and school documents were also used.  The analysis focuses on the principal's actions and their connection to the Executive Development Program (EDP) principles.

sections.title: Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: Series of interviews and focus groups over two school years; day-long visits to the school for interviews, focus groups, and classroom observations; hour-long phone interviews with the principal; interviews with the principal's NISL coach; interviews with two of the principal's direct supervisors.

analysis.sample_description: The case study focuses on one principal (Owen Walter) at Terrace Middle School (TMS) and his implementation of an Action Learning Project (ALP).  The principal was selected from among 26 best-practice candidates nominated by NISL.  Data also includes information from assistant principals, teacher-coaches, and teachers at the school.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of transcribed interviews and school documents. The analysis highlights connections between the principal's actions and core EDP principles and concepts.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used ODR data on participants enrolled in a supportive housing program from April 2016 to April 2019.  Data included demographics, clinical diagnoses, housing status (move-in/move-out dates, reason for exit, destination), and arrest information from the LASD. Housing stability was classified using HUD definitions.  Arrest data was reviewed against court records to classify arrests as new felonies or other outcomes.  New felony rates were examined among participants housed for at least 12 months.

primary_methods: Data analysis of existing administrative data
analysis.sample_description: 311 participants enrolled in the Los Angeles County Office of Diversion and Reentry's supportive housing program between April 2016 and April 2019. Sub-samples used for outcome analyses (housed for at least 6 or 12 months).
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics were used to summarize participant characteristics and housing stability rates were calculated for 6 and 12 month periods.  Felony conviction rates were calculated for participants housed for at least 12 months.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research involved site visits and extensive interviews with DPW staff at three installations (Fort Detrick, Fort Irwin, Fort Riley) and a telephone interview with USAG Rheinland-Pfalz.  More limited interviews were conducted at other installations to verify findings.  Detailed Installation Status Report for Infrastructure (ISR-I) data were collected and analyzed for 19 installations, examining trends in facility quality, mission, and readiness ratings. Interviews and literature reviews were conducted to identify best practices in facility sustainment across different military services, government organizations, and the private sector.  The study also drew on information from previous RAND Arroyo Center studies.

analysis.sample_description: Three Army installations (Fort Detrick, Fort Irwin, Fort Riley) were selected for extensive site visits and interviews, representing a variety of missions, locations, and sizes.  A telephone interview was conducted with USAG Rheinland-Pfalz.  Additional limited interviews were conducted at other installations. ISR-I data were collected for 19 installations.
analysis.analysis_approach: The ISR-I data were analyzed to identify trends in facility quality ratings, mission ratings, and readiness ratings over time, as well as transition rates between different facility quality ratings.  The analysis used the R language and statistical packages.

sections.title: Evaluation Methods
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods approach combining structured interviews with SDSC personnel, site visits, policy reviews, limited ethnographic research (daily briefing observations and dialogues in Districts 7 and 25), and difference-in-difference Poisson regression modeling with bootstrapped standard errors to assess crime reduction effects.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Difference-in-difference Poisson regression models with bootstrapped standard errors to account for serial correlation in crime counts. Independent variables included dummy variables for years (2013-2018), months, site effects (districts receiving SDSCs), and an SDSC presence variable.  Models estimated effects for ten major crime types using data from January 2013 to August 2018, and also from shorter periods (2014-2018, 2015-2018, 2016-2018) to analyze the impact of the 2016 crime surge.

analysis.sample_description: The study included data from the Chicago Police Department's Strategic Decision Support Centers (SDSCs) and crime data from January 2013 to August 2018.  Ethnographic research focused on two districts (7 and 25).
analysis.analysis_approach: Difference-in-difference Poisson regression models were used to estimate the effect of SDSC implementation on crime rates, controlling for year, month, and district-specific effects. Bootstrapped standard errors addressed serial correlation in the crime data.  Analysis was conducted using R statistical software.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the quasi-experimental design comparing outcomes of students in community schools with those in a matched comparison group of similar schools.  It describes the data sources (NYCDOE administrative data, school surveys, program data), outcome measures (student-level: attendance, educational attainment, academic performance, disciplinary incidents; school-level: teacher shared responsibility, student connectedness, family empowerment), matching procedures (using principal component analysis to create a smaller number of dimensions from baseline outcome measures, demographic measures, and AIDP application information), and the difference-in-difference estimation approach.  Subgroup analyses are described for student characteristics (poverty, temporary housing, English language learner status, disability, gender, race/ethnicity) and school characteristics (size, zoning, principal experience, Renewal School status).
