Implementation measures (core capacity scores and mental health implementation profiles) are also detailed.  A grade-by-year analysis is described to decompose year-by-year changes in impact into maturity and exposure components.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from New York City Department of Education (NYCDOE) schools.  Community schools are compared to a matched comparison group of similar schools that were not designated as community schools. Subgroup analyses are conducted for various student and school characteristics.
analysis.analysis_approach: A difference-in-differences approach is used to estimate the impact of the NYC Community Schools Initiative (NYC-CS).  School-level average outcomes are used in the primary analysis.  Weighted least squares regression is employed, with standard errors clustered by school.  Subgroup analyses are conducted to examine heterogeneity in program impacts based on student and school characteristics.  A grade-by-year analysis decomposes changes in impact over time into maturity and exposure components.

sections.title: Preface: Overview of Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A multi-method approach was used, including a targeted literature review, case vignettes, in-depth stakeholder interviews, and a synthesis workshop.

sections.title: Summary of Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach: (i) a targeted literature review of articles published between 2009 and 2018; (ii) development of 12 case vignettes illustrating health data reuse, with interviews conducted with seven industry authors across five vignettes; (iii) key informant interviews with ten stakeholders (eight from industry, two from regulatory authorities); and (iv) a synthesis workshop with EFPIA and steering group members.

sections.title: Targeted Literature Review
sections.methods_summary: A targeted literature review was conducted using Google Scholar, focusing on articles published between 2009 and 2018.  Search terms included combinations of "Prescription data", "electronic medical records", "EHR", "health registr*", "health systems data", "use", "reuse", and "pharma* industry".  41 documents were analyzed, with 23 included in the review. Information extracted included country, purpose, data type, reasons for use, methods, enablers, challenges, and implications.

sections.title: Case Vignettes
sections.methods_summary: Twelve case vignettes were identified through literature searches and snowballing, focusing on publications with at least one European pharmaceutical industry author.  Information extracted included study aims, data use, enablers, challenges, implications, and current/prospective use.  Seven interviews were conducted with industry authors across five vignettes.

sections.title: Stakeholder Interviews
sections.methods_summary: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with ten stakeholders (eight from the pharmaceutical industry and two from regulatory authorities). Interviewees were identified through literature review, professional networks, Google searches, and suggestions from EFPIA and other interviewees.  Interviews were audio-recorded and notes taken.  Two case vignette interviewees also participated.

sections.title: Synthesis Workshop
sections.methods_summary: A synthesis workshop was held with EFPIA and members of the study's steering group to discuss key findings and implications for future action.  Findings were captured on Post-it notes and detailed minutes were taken.

sections.title: Annex A: Methodological Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section provides a detailed description of the methodology, including the targeted literature review (search terms, inclusion criteria, data extraction), case vignette selection and development (criteria, data extraction template), stakeholder interviews (interview protocol, participant selection), and the synthesis workshop.

analysis.sample_description: The study focused on the reuse of health data by the European pharmaceutical industry.  Data sources included academic papers, grey literature, and interviews with industry and regulatory representatives.  The case vignettes were selected based on the involvement of at least one European pharmaceutical company author.
analysis.analysis_approach: A mixed-methods approach was used, combining qualitative and quantitative data.  Data from the literature review, case vignettes, and interviews were narratively synthesized. The synthesis workshop served to 'stress test' the analyses and identify implications for future action.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Considerations for Survey-Based Collection of Practice Expense - Methods
sections.methods_summary: Environmental scan using PubMed and citation snowballing, supplemented by interviews with RAND survey experts.  Data abstraction focused on survey administration mode, communication techniques, respondents, sampling, length, timing, response rates, respondent burden, data accuracy, and administration feasibility.  Excluded considerations unrelated to a CMS-directed PE survey of physician practices.

sections.title: Chapter 3: Practice Expense Components and Practice Characteristics - Methods
sections.methods_summary: Review of public, government, and proprietary physician surveys relevant to PE identified in the environmental scan. Extraction of questions pertaining to practice characteristics, expenses, and labor force. Compilation of PE components from prior survey questions, literature review, and expert feedback. Categorization of PE components and characteristics into groups based on prior surveys, accounting systems, compatibility with the MPFS algorithm, and expert recommendations.

sections.title: Chapter 4: Survey Instrument Model - Methods
sections.methods_summary: Iterative construction of a PE survey instrument model. Gathering survey items from prior surveys and organizing them into sections corresponding to PE categories. Development of additional questions for uncovered PE components.  Drafting decisions based on expense size, variation across practices, changes over time, ease of data collection, and respondent/administrator burden.  Development of hypothetical question archetypes for different expense types (general goods, staffing, big-ticket items).

sections.title: Chapter 7: Using Outpatient Prospective Payment System Relative Values to Determine Practice Expense - Analytic Updates and Methodological Refinements
sections.methods_summary: Updated analyses to reflect 2019 MPFS payment rules and 2017 claims data. Updated set of procedure codes for OPPS-based valuation. Modified impact assessment to align with OPPS APCs. Methodological refinements included:  reducing postoperative visits based on actual visits (using a fractional logit model), grouping pre-services by clinical labor activity and costs, and including MPFS packaged supplies incident to radiology and diagnostic services.  Simulations conducted to assess the impact of using OPPS-based relative values to establish total PE RVUs in two scenarios (with and without methodological refinements).

analysis.sample_description: The study uses various data sources, including existing surveys (PPI, MGMA), administrative data (Medicare claims, OPPS data), and public data sources (SAS, Economic Census, BLS OES).  Specific sample sizes and descriptions vary depending on the data source and analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach involves descriptive statistics, comparisons across data sources, regression modeling (logit model for postoperative visit estimation), and simulation modeling to assess the impact of different methodologies and data sources on PE RVU calculations.  The analysis focuses on identifying and addressing methodological issues in PE rate setting, updating data inputs, and exploring alternative frameworks for allocating PE.

sections.title: Overall Approach and Study Design
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach combining forward-tracing case studies and backward-tracing perspectives.  Forward-tracing involved selecting highly cited papers from 1985-1990, contacting corresponding authors, and conducting interviews to construct 'research clouds'.  Backward-tracing involved selecting six interventions and developing narratives through interviews and literature reviews.  A nine-member international panel rated the impact of each case study.  Attributes influencing research translation were identified and analyzed.

sections.title: Methods: Forward-Tracing Case Studies and Backward-Tracing Perspectives
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for both the forward- and backward-tracing components.  Forward-tracing: 18 case studies were selected based on highly cited papers (1985-1990), stratified by country and research type.  Research clouds were defined through interviews with researchers. Data collection included interviews, literature reviews, and bibliometric analysis. The Payback Framework was used to categorize impacts.  Backward-tracing: Six interventions were selected using a survey, review of clinical guidelines, and expert input.  Perspectives were developed through interviews, archival material review, and literature reviews. A narrative approach was used for analysis.

analysis.sample_description: 18 forward-tracing case studies based on highly cited papers from 1985-1990, stratified by country (Canada, UK, USA) and research type (basic, clinical, interventional). 6 backward-tracing perspectives focusing on specific interventions in schizophrenia treatment.
analysis.analysis_approach: For forward-tracing, a nine-member international panel numerically rated the impact of each case study across five payback categories.  Attributes were identified and analyzed to determine associations with high and low impact using the Fisher Exact Test. For backward-tracing, a narrative approach was used to extract and describe attributes that promoted or hindered translation.

sections.title: Data and Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: The study uses data from the U.S. Department of Defense's Selected Military Compensation Tables (Greenbook) and Active Duty Pay Files, March supplements to the Current Population Survey (CPS), Status of Forces Surveys, and 2015 Demographics: Profile of the Military Community.  Civilian wage data are weighted by the military gender mix.  Regression models are estimated to examine the relationship between recruiting outcomes and the ratio of RMC to the median civilian wage, controlling for other variables.  Analysis also involves comparing RMC with civilian wages across different geographic areas (urban vs. non-urban).

sections.title: Methods: Comparing Military and Civilian Pay
sections.methods_summary: Education attainment data from Status of Forces Surveys are used to adjust RMC measures.  RMC data from the Greenbook and civilian wage data from the CPS are used. Civilian wage data are weighted by the military gender mix. Assumptions are made to map age and education to years of labor-force experience for civilians.  RMC percentiles are computed for officers and enlisted by year of service, and overall RMC percentiles are calculated for 2017 and 2009 using a weighted average across education levels based on the military education distribution.

sections.title: Methods: Analyzing Recruit Quality
sections.methods_summary: Reduced-form regression models are estimated for two recruiting outcomes: recruiting rate for HSDGs and the non-HSDG share of accessions.  These are calculated for each AFQT score category (I-IIIB) and for non-prior service accessions. Data from 2000-2017 are used. Explanatory variables include military/civilian pay ratio, recruiting goal, deployment, unemployment, gender, and a post-2009 indicator.  The model is a reduced-form model that considers both supply and demand influences on recruiting.

sections.title: Methods: Geographic Differences in RMC Percentiles
sections.methods_summary: The study builds upon existing research on geographic influences on wages and social mobility. Data from the 2010 U.S. Census are used to split states into the ten most urban and ten least urban, comparing RMC with civilian wages for each group.  Analysis considers how the changing dynamics of civilian wages by geography affect how RMC compares with civilian wages in urban and less urban areas.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data on active-component military personnel and civilian workers, with specific age and education groups analyzed in different sections.  Civilian wage data are weighted to match the gender distribution of the military.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves comparing military pay (RMC) to civilian wages using percentiles and ratios. Regression analysis is used to examine the relationship between RMC and recruit quality, controlling for various factors.  Geographic comparisons are made between urban and non-urban areas.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used a confidential, web-based survey administered to active component personnel in the U.S. Air Force, Army, Marine Corps, Navy, and Coast Guard.  A stratified random sampling approach was used, oversampling women, Coast Guard and Marine Corps personnel, and junior enlisted members.  Missing data were imputed using predictive mean matching (PMM) and polytomous regression.  Analytic weights were calculated in two stages: design weights to account for oversampling and nonresponse weights to adjust for differences between respondents and nonrespondents.  Analysis involved Rao-Scott chi-square tests and pairwise comparisons with Tukey-Kramer adjustments for multiple comparisons.  Results were compared to Healthy People 2020 objectives and the 2015 HRBS using regression models with adjusted risk ratios (ARRs).

analysis.sample_description: The sampling frame included all active component personnel (excluding cadets) as of September 2018.  Women, Coast Guard and Marine Corps personnel, and junior enlisted members were oversampled. The final analytic sample consisted of 17,166 surveys.
analysis.analysis_approach: Weighted analyses were conducted using a two-stage procedure.  First, Rao-Scott chi-square tests assessed overall differences across groups.  Second, pairwise comparisons with Tukey-Kramer adjustments were used to identify specific group differences.  Comparisons with Healthy People 2020 objectives and the 2015 HRBS were made using regression models that controlled for demographic differences.

sections.title: Objectives and Approach
sections.methods_summary: Exploratory study to understand privacy and bias concerns related to FRT implementations.  Review of academic literature and current examples on privacy and bias. Keyword searches of academic databases. Development of two scenarios for deeper analysis.

sections.title: Selected Face Recognition Technology Policies in the United States
sections.methods_summary: Highlighting selected public policies and laws that constrain or guide the use of FRTs. Brief description of some FRT programs and applications affected by these policies. Compilation of sectors in which FRT is applied.

sections.title: Study Overview
sections.methods_summary: Multidimensional exploration of challenges and implications from FRT deployments. Focus on issues for government organizations implementing FRTs. Literature review and case studies. Identification of considerations for ensuring privacy and addressing bias concerns. Two use cases: border control scenario (one-to-one authentication) and faces-in-a-crowd surveillance scenario (some-to-many surveillance).

sections.title: Areas for Future Research
sections.methods_summary: Characterizing disparate FRT privacy and bias practices at different government levels using case studies and text extraction of public comments. Evaluating relevant DHS policies and processes through systematic review of PIAs. Identifying appropriate types and conditions for implementing PETs through empirical and theoretical methods, including experimental studies. Evaluating the privacy and bias effects of algorithmic transparency through empirical research. Determining training and target data representativeness for relevant populations. Identifying privacy and bias considerations in government acquisition of FRTs through interviews and focus groups. Assembling a centralized repository of FRT accuracy information. Exploring privacy expectations of FRT targets through surveys.

analysis.sample_description: Not explicitly defined, but the study analyzes existing FRT policies, programs, and applications in various sectors and levels of government in the US.  Two specific use cases (border control and airport surveillance) are examined in detail, but no specific sample size is given for these case studies.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of literature, policies, and case studies.  The study identifies trends, patterns, and potential issues related to privacy and bias in FRT systems.  Future research directions are suggested, including quantitative methods such as measuring accuracy rates and surveying public opinion.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study involved survey development, refinement to reduce respondent burden and remove infrequently used items, and the use of validated measures for comparison with civilian populations.  The survey was approved by multiple Institutional Review Boards (IRBs) and underwent security review.  RAND partnered with Westat for web-based survey administration.  The sampling frame included all reserve component personnel (excluding cadets, etc.) and utilized 70 strata based on service branch, pay grade, and gender.  Statistical weighting was used to correct for differences between respondents and nonrespondents.  Missing data were imputed using mice in R, employing predictive mean matching (PMM) and polytomous regression.  Analysis involved weighted data and a two-stage procedure for comparisons across military subpopulations (Rao-Scott chi-square test and pairwise comparisons with Tukey-Kramer adjustment). Comparisons were also made with Healthy People 2020 objectives and the 2018 HRBS active component sample using regression models controlling for demographic and military characteristics.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the weighting procedures used to adjust for differences between respondents and nonrespondents, aiming to improve the generalizability of findings.  It explains the two-stage weighting process (design weights and nonresponse weights) using data from the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC).  The generalizability of the weighted findings is discussed, highlighting assumptions about response likelihood.  The section then describes the handling of missing data through imputation using the mice package in R.  It explains the use of predictive mean matching (PMM) for various variable types, the handling of skip logic, and the iterative process (five iterations of MCMC) used for imputation.  Finally, the analysis approach is outlined, emphasizing the use of analytic weights and a two-stage procedure for comparisons across military subpopulations (Rao-Scott chi-square test and pairwise comparisons with Tukey-Kramer adjustment).  The handling of suppressed estimates and the overall approach to multiple comparisons are also discussed.

analysis.sample_description: The sampling frame comprised all reserve component personnel as of September 2018, excluding certain groups.  A stratified random sampling approach was used, with oversampling of specific groups (women, Marines, junior enlisted).  The final analytic sample consisted of 16,475 surveys.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analyses used analytic weights and imputations.  A two-stage procedure was used for comparisons across military subpopulations, involving the Rao-Scott chi-square test and pairwise comparisons with Tukey-Kramer adjustment for multiple comparisons.  Comparisons were also made with Healthy People 2020 objectives and the 2018 HRBS active component sample using regression models that controlled for demographic and military characteristics.

sections.title: Overview of the Analytic Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study employed four parallel data collection and analysis efforts: 1) 68 semi-structured interviews with DoD and other federal government personnel; 2) 34 semi-structured interviews with academics and industry experts; 3) six historical case studies; and 4) a quantitative review of DoD's AI investment portfolio (not publicly available).  The interview protocols were developed through internal brainstorming and reviewed by RAND's Survey Research Group to ensure expansive questioning. Interviews were not recorded to encourage candid responses.  Case studies involved mapping timelines of events, developing narratives, and extracting relevant insights. Data analysis for interviews used Dedoose software and a code tree aligned with the six dimensions of posture assessment. The portfolio review used raw data from President's Budget 2019 and 2020 data calls.

sections.title: Details of the Analytic Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the four lines of effort:  1) Government interviews (68 total, mostly in-person, focusing on 1-2 dimensions of posture assessment per interviewee); 2) Academic and Industry interviews (25 industry, 9 academic, staggered relative to DoD interviews); 3) Historical Case Studies (six case studies developed using exploratory methodology, drawing on literature and, in one case, personal correspondence; no multiple case study analysis was performed); and 4) Portfolio Review (quantitative review of DoD's AI investment portfolio, details in a separate, non-public annex).  Interview preparation involved internal brainstorming, development of generic interview protocols reviewed by RAND's Survey Research Group, and derivation of individual interview protocols tailored to interviewees.  A coding approach using Dedoose software and a code tree (shown in Box A.1) was used to analyze interview notes.  Integrative analysis combined insights from the three exploratory lines of effort, the team's expertise, and literature review to develop recommendations.

sections.title: Analytical Framework and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used a framework of six dimensions to assess DoD's AI posture: Organization, Advancement, Adoption, Innovation, Data, and Talent.  Four data collection and analysis efforts were undertaken: 1) Government interviews (59 DoD, 9 other federal); 2) Academic and industry interviews (25 industry, 9 academic); 3) Historical case studies (6 studies); and 4) Portfolio review (quantitative, non-public).  All three exploratory efforts aimed to cover all six dimensions.  An integrative analysis combined the findings from these three efforts, team expertise, and literature review.

analysis.sample_description: The study included 68 interviews with DoD and other federal government personnel, 34 interviews with academics and industry experts, and six historical case studies.  The quantitative portfolio review used data from the President's Budget 2019 and 2020.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data analysis of interview notes using Dedoose software and a pre-defined code tree.  Quantitative analysis of the DoD AI investment portfolio (details not publicly available).  Integrative analysis combined qualitative and quantitative findings from multiple sources.

sections.title: Approach and Structure
sections.methods_summary: Comparative analysis of publicly available information and Arabic and Farsi sources to create typologies describing Iranian objectives and the role of various groups within the Iran Threat Network (ITN).  The study focuses on open-source research to make it accessible to a wide audience.

analysis.sample_description: The study analyzes various groups within the Iran Threat Network (ITN), using publicly available information and leveraging Arabic and Farsi sources where possible.
analysis.analysis_approach: Comparative and contrastive analysis of ITN members to create typologies based on Iranian objectives.  The analysis groups organizations together to identify commonalities and unique attributes, providing insights into strengths, weaknesses, and potential counter-strategies.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study compiled data on successful embassy seizures (fully or partially successful, involving 5 or more assailants) from 1979 to 2019 from various public and government sources (news articles, reports, etc.).  It excluded attacks ending immediately (bombings, shootings, assassinations) and those in active conflict zones.  Attack timelines were measured in two ways: (1) attack initiation to culmination (estimated in one-hour or 30-minute increments), and (2) indication of elevated risk (in days) based on official warnings.  Data on security measures taken were considered qualitatively but not statistically due to insufficient data.

analysis.sample_description: 33 partially or fully successful seizures of Western diplomatic facilities from 1979 to 2019, involving five or more assailants and excluding attacks in active conflict zones or those ending immediately.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study calculated the duration of each attack and the advance warning time.  It used one-hour or 30-minute increments for attack duration and days for advance warning.  Basic regression models and a Kruskal-Wallis test were used to analyze attack duration trends. Qualitative analysis was also conducted, considering security measures taken before attacks, but these were not included in statistical analysis due to limited data availability.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: Extensive survey of relevant academic and professional literature.  The analysis is structured around four key areas: differences between modern knowledge organizations and traditional ones; characteristics of work appealing to STEM workers; human capital functions related to STEM worker performance; and organizational structure changes to improve STEM worker productivity.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is a literature review, not an empirical study.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report synthesizes findings from existing literature to draw conclusions and make recommendations.  No specific statistical or qualitative analysis techniques are described beyond the general overview of the literature review process.

sections.title: Analysis of the Method
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of publicly available sources and information to examine the methods Russia uses for COFM assessments, identifying problem areas such as limitations of expert evaluations and focus on quality instead of effectiveness.

sections.title: Soviet and Russian Approaches to Determining Combat Potential
sections.methods_summary: This section details various methods used by Soviet and Russian analysts to calculate combat potential, including: operational testing and analysis of tactical-technical characteristics; statistical approaches (retrospective data analysis and ensemble methods); modeling and simulation approaches (Lanchester and Osipov equations, Model of Strategic Operations); expert evaluations and systems analysis; and potentialometry.  The strengths and weaknesses of each approach are discussed, with a focus on the limitations of expert evaluations and the challenges of generalizing combat potential across various scenarios.

sections.title: Russian Definitions of COFM and Combat Potentials
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of Russian military and defense dictionaries and literature to define COFM and combat potentials.  Comparison of broad definitions with narrower definitions used in COFM calculations.  Discussion of the use of coefficients of combat potential and their limitations.

sections.title: Technical Overview of COFM and Combat Potential
sections.methods_summary: Explains terminology used in COFM assessments (weapon, asset, formation, homogenous/heterogenous assets). Discusses thematic challenges in COFM calculations: general vs. specific combat potentials; multiple criteria and systems complexity; homogeneity and heterogeneity.  Illustrates concepts using the game of chess as an analogy.

sections.title: Illustration of Concepts and Terminology
sections.methods_summary: Uses the game of chess as an analogy to illustrate the concepts of combat potential and COFM.  Assigns point values to chess pieces to represent their combat potential and demonstrates how COFM can be calculated and used for strategic decision-making in chess.  Compares the simplified nature of chess with the complexities of real-world warfare.

sections.title: Methods for Calculating Commensurability Coefficients
sections.methods_summary: Describes methods for calculating commensurability coefficients (combat potential values) including: operational testing and analysis of tactical-technical characteristics; statistical approaches (retrospective data analysis and ensemble methods); modeling and simulation approaches (Lanchester and Osipov equations, Model of Strategic Operations); expert evaluations and systems analysis; and potentialometry.  Compares these methods with similar U.S. approaches (WEI, WUI, ADE, KV scoreboards, SFS).

sections.title: Toward a Unified Russian Approach to COFM
sections.methods_summary: Describes the transition from the Model of Strategic Operations (MSO) to the unified Method used in modern Russia. Explains the Method, which is based on qualimetry and expert elicitation.  Details the application of the Method and discusses criticisms of the Method, including its limitations in accounting for the information component of modern warfare and its reliance on potentially biased expert evaluations.

primary_methods: Comparative analysis of Soviet and Russian military literature
analysis.sample_description: Publicly available sources and information on Russian military doctrine, publications, and statements by military officials.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative analysis of the methods used by Soviet and Russian military analysts to assess COFM, including identification of strengths and weaknesses of different approaches and comparison with similar U.S. methods.

sections.title: Chapter 5 Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of Russia's behavior toward its neighbors to understand its grand strategy claims.  Examination of coercion, military posture, training, and basing to assess consistency with interventionist and imperialist strategies. Case studies are used to illustrate the analysis.

sections.title: Chapter 6 Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Evaluation of whether Russia's force posture, readiness, and procurement decisions reflect its stated strategy on non-contact warfare and small-scale local wars.  Comparison of observable behaviors for large-scale contact war versus non-contact war. Analysis of changes over time in force posture, procurement, mobilization, and training.  Pre-2014 and post-2014 periods are compared.

sections.title: Chapter 6: Data Analysis (Posture Revisions Initially Consistent with Stated Strategy Until 2014)
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of Russian force posture, procurement, mobilization, and training from 2008 to 2014.  Examination of the New Look defense reform program and its impact on force structure, equipment modernization, and readiness.

sections.title: Chapter 6: Data Analysis (Posture Revisions Initially Consistent with Stated Strategy Until 2014)
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of Russian procurement programs from 2008 to 2014, focusing on the State Armaments Program to 2020 (SAP-2020). Examination of spending by service and prioritization of air power, precision strike capabilities, and C4ISR.

sections.title: Chapter 6: Data Analysis (Evolution of Military Thinking Since 2014)
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of debates among Russian strategists about the nature of future conflict and the direction of military strategy since 2014. Examination of critiques of the overemphasis on non-contact warfare and the role of ground forces.

sections.title: Chapter 6: Data Analysis (Posture, Procurement Decisions Increasingly Inconsistent with Stated Strategy Since 2014)
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of force posture, procurement, and mobilization decisions since 2014. Examination of inconsistencies with the stated strategy on non-contact warfare. Analysis of changes in Ground Forces structure, procurement of armored vehicles and artillery, and mobilization system enhancements.

sections.title: Chapter 6: Data Analysis (Exercise Scale Since 2014)
sections.methods_summary: Evaluation of the scenarios and activities of Russia's largest strategic exercises since 2012. Analysis of trends in the size and complexity of exercises and their focus on large-scale operations versus local war or non-contact warfare.

sections.title: Chapter 7 Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Evaluation of the extent to which Russia's resource decisions and behaviors are consistent with its stated strategy on expeditionary capabilities.  Development of a model for expeditionary force requirements, characteristics, and observable behaviors using Gongora's models. Assessment of Russia's power-projection forces across readiness, mobility, and sustainability. Comparison of Russia's capabilities with those of a regional power-projection force and an out-of-area expeditionary force.

sections.title: Chapter 8 Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of Russia's cooperation with and interference in the West to assess its objectives. Development of a framework for distinguishing between different propositions regarding Russian objectives. Examination of Russia's cooperation with the West (2012-2018) and its interference in Western domestic politics. Assessment of whether Russia's actions match its stated strategy.

sections.title: Chapter 9 Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Measurement of Russia's rebalancing away from the West using three unique data sets: frequency of Russia's bilateral intergovernmental commissions (MPKs), international visits of select Russian ministers, and activities of the Russian Direct Investment Fund (RDIF) and state-owned enterprises (SOEs).  Analysis of trends in engagement with Western and non-Western countries.

sections.title: Appendix A Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of Russian federal budget expenditures from 2012 to 2021 (2020 and 2021 are government projections) to assess resource allocation for external and internal threats.  Examination of the National Defense and National Security budget chapters and their subchapters. Analysis of spending patterns in real terms, adjusted for inflation.

sections.title: Overall Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research uses a mixed-methods approach.  It begins with an exhaustive review of official Russian strategy documents, statements from leaders, and interviews conducted in Moscow to outline the broad contours of Russia's stated grand strategy.  Then, six key elements of this stated strategy are selected for closer examination and tested against empirical observations of Russian actions and resource decisions.  This involves analyzing data on resource allocation, military posture, training, and international engagement.  The analysis uses case studies and quantitative data to assess the consistency between Russia's stated and revealed grand strategies.

analysis.sample_description: The study focuses on Russia's grand strategy from 2012 to 2018, examining its stated strategy and comparing it with its actions and resource decisions.  Specific case studies are used to illustrate the analysis of Russia's relations with its neighbors and the West.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a comparative approach, comparing Russia's stated grand strategy with its revealed grand strategy (actions and resource decisions).  Quantitative data are used to analyze trends in resource allocation, international engagement, and military activities.  Qualitative data from documents and interviews are used to understand Russia's beliefs, interests, and strategic logic.

sections.title: Literature Review and Program Selection
sections.methods_summary: A 2018 literature search yielded 1,136 articles. After screening titles and abstracts, 74 articles underwent full-text review.  13 programs were selected for inclusion based on their focus on healthy relationships, positive outcomes, and adaptability to a military environment.

sections.title: Program Adaptation Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A multi-step process for adapting existing healthy relationship programs to a military context. Steps include: 1. Identifying essential program elements (what, how, who); 2. Developing a logic model; 3. Considering required adaptations (e.g., addressing military hierarchy, cultural norms, legal definitions); 4. Identifying adaptation risks using a traffic-light framework (green, yellow, red); 5. Estimating adaptation workload; 6. Seeking buy-in from stakeholders; 7. Avoiding duplication of effort; 8. Ensuring program fidelity; and 9. Evaluating the adapted program (process and outcome evaluations, including pre-testing).

sections.title: Program Evaluation
sections.methods_summary: The report recommends both process and outcome evaluations. Process evaluations assess program implementation fidelity and output. Outcome evaluations measure changes in short-term and long-term outcomes, informed by the logic model and pre-testing.

analysis.sample_description: The study does not have a single, unified sample.  Instead, it analyzes existing programs and proposes a methodology for adapting them.  The programs themselves have various target populations (e.g., high school students, military personnel, couples).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis is primarily qualitative, involving a systematic review of existing programs and a structured approach to program adaptation.  Quantitative data from the original program evaluations are presented to support the selection and adaptation recommendations.

sections.title: Research Methodology: Priority Criminal Justice Needs Initiative
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a five-year Priority Criminal Justice Needs Initiative.  This involved 24 workshops and panels (May 2014-November 2018) bringing together criminal justice practitioners, technologists, civil-society representatives, and others. Structured brainstorming sessions were used to identify challenges, solutions, and opportunities to improve the criminal justice system.  The results of each panel are documented in detailed reports. The analysis in this report draws on the full set of issues raised during all events, particularly the reports from the 2014 Corrections, 2015 Courts, and 2016 Law Enforcement Advisory Panels.

analysis.sample_description: Nearly 550 criminal justice practitioners, technical experts, staff from relevant sector or civil-society organizations, and other specialists participated in the workshops and panels.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of data collected from workshops and panels, focusing on common needs and solutions across law enforcement, courts, and corrections sectors.  The analysis categorized challenges into societal and operational challenges.

sections.title: Student Growth Percentile (SGP) Calculation
sections.methods_summary: The document describes the calculation of Student Growth Percentiles (SGPs).  SGPs rank student test score growth compared to peers with similar prior academic performance.  Multiple years of prior test scores can be used.  Teacher scores are aggregated from student SGPs using either the mean or median.  The methodology focuses on relative ranking of student growth within peer groups, not on absolute growth or achievement levels.

analysis.sample_description: Students with similar prior academic performance (based on one or more years of prior test scores) are compared within their grade and subject.
analysis.analysis_approach: Students are ranked based on their growth relative to their peers. Teacher scores are calculated by averaging (mean) or finding the middle score (median) of the SGPs of students in their classroom.

sections.title: Overview of Research Questions and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study aimed to answer several policy questions regarding the US Army's enlistment waiver policies.  The approach involved analyzing data from FY 2001 to FY 2012 on Regular Army enlistments, merged with personnel records through FY 2018.  Methods included comparing outcomes of waivered and non-waivered recruits, regression analysis to estimate the relationship between waivers and outcomes while controlling for other factors, and extending the Recruit Selection Tool (RST) to simulate the effects of increasing waivers on an enlistment cohort.  A review of the literature on marijuana use was also conducted.

sections.title: Data and Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: Data were collected from three sources: waiver workflow data, RA Analyst data, and TAPDB data.  These datasets were merged to create a comprehensive record for each recruit.  The study used two main analytical methods: regression analysis (binomial logistic regression) to estimate the relationship between waivers and outcomes, controlling for recruit characteristics; and an extended Recruit Selection Tool (RST) to simulate the effects of changing waiver policies on an entire enlistment cohort, accounting for correlations between characteristics.  The study also included a review of existing literature on marijuana use and legalization.

sections.title: Estimated Relationships Between Waivers and Outcomes
sections.methods_summary: Binomial logistic regression models were used to estimate the relationship between waivers and outcomes, controlling for recruit characteristics.  Relative risk ratios (RRRs) were calculated to show the probability of an outcome for a recruit with a given waiver category relative to a similar recruit without that waiver category.  Joint effects of multiple variables were also assessed using a chi-squared test.

sections.title: Prospective Cohort Outcomes from Changing Waiver Policy Using the Recruit Selection Tool
sections.methods_summary: The Recruit Selection Tool (RST) was used to simulate the effects of increasing the share of recruits with different waiver categories on the aggregate performance of an enlistment cohort.  The RST uses weights to adjust the representation of recruit characteristics to meet specified targets, considering correlations between characteristics and their joint effects on outcomes.

sections.title: Estimated Effects of Legalization on Recruit Characteristics and Outcomes
sections.methods_summary: A difference-in-differences approach was used to assess the impact of marijuana legalization on recruit outcomes.  Regressions were estimated separately for medical and recreational marijuana legalization, comparing pre- and post-legalization outcomes within states that legalized marijuana with those in states without legalization.  Sensitivity analyses were conducted to address potential biases.

analysis.sample_description: All Regular Army (RA) enlistments from FY 2001 to FY 2012, tracked through FY 2018.  Data included recruit characteristics and enlistment contract details, merged with Army personnel records.
analysis.analysis_approach: Regression analysis controlled for individual recruit and contract characteristics.  The RST simulated changes in cohort characteristics and outcomes by adjusting weights to meet user-specified targets.  Difference-in-differences analysis compared outcomes before and after marijuana legalization in different states.

sections.title: Methodology: Assessing Airpower Options in Syria
sections.methods_summary: The report uses a qualitative methodology, analyzing potential airpower missions in Syria based on operational and strategic considerations.  It examines five principal missions (negate Syrian airpower, neutralize Syrian air defenses, defend safe areas, enable opposition forces to defeat the regime, prevent the use of Syrian chemical weapons) by outlining the requirements, military potential, and risks of each. The analysis draws on existing literature, expert knowledge, and comparisons with past military interventions to assess the feasibility and potential consequences of each mission.  No quantitative data or statistical analysis is presented.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is not an empirical study with a defined sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report uses a comparative case study approach, drawing parallels between potential interventions in Syria and past military operations.  The analysis is primarily qualitative, focusing on the operational and strategic implications of different airpower missions.  The authors assess the feasibility, potential effectiveness, and risks associated with each mission based on their understanding of military capabilities and the Syrian conflict.

sections.title: Study Details and Participant Information
sections.methods_summary: Details of individual studies including participants, interventions, comparators, outcomes, and study design.  Information is presented in a tabular format for each study.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Describes the systematic review methodology, including database searches (Allied and Complementary Medicine Database, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature, Embase, Published International Literature on Traumatic Stress, PubMed, PsycInfo, Clinicaltrials.gov, and WHO’s International Clinical Trials Registry Platform), search strategy (Appendix A), eligibility criteria (PICOTS framework), inclusion screening (dual review), data extraction (standardized form, dual check), risk of bias assessment (Cochrane Risk of Bias tool), data synthesis (Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for random effects meta-analysis, subgroup analyses, meta-regressions, sensitivity analyses, Begg and Egger tests, trim and fill method), quality of evidence assessment (GRADE approach), and summary of findings (Table 4.1).

analysis.sample_description: Adults (18 years or older) with PTSD, including both male and female participants with various trauma types (military, sexual assault, physical abuse, etc.). Comorbidities were allowed.
analysis.analysis_approach: Random effects meta-analysis using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for continuous and categorical outcomes. Subgroup analyses and meta-regressions were conducted to explore effect modifiers. Sensitivity analyses were performed to assess robustness. Publication bias was assessed using Begg and Egger tests, with trim and fill method applied if necessary.  GRADE approach used for quality of evidence assessment.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: Examination of training strategies for 14 weapon systems, including simulator use and ammunition expenditure rates.  Focused examination of small arms (M16/M4 rifle, M249 SAW, M240B machine gun) to compare doctrinal use with qualification standards and unit readiness processes.  Comparison with strategies of other nations and the USMC.

sections.title: Research Activities
sections.methods_summary: Review of relevant Army documents (DA Pamphlet 350-38, AR 350-1, AR 5-18, TRADOC Pamphlet 350-70-1, etc.), interviews with weapon employment and training staff at HQ DA, TRADOC's Combined Arms Center, Army Training Support Center, live and virtual capability managers, and weapon system training proponents at Centers of Excellence. Vetting of findings with contacts to ensure accuracy and feasibility.

sections.title: Improving Small-Arms Training Strategies: Considerations, Principles, and Directions
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative analysis based on findings, conclusions, and input from small-arms training community (trainers from Army Marksmanship Unit, Special Forces, Maneuver COE).  Alignment with Maneuver COE revision efforts. Consideration of operational requirements, ARFORGEN processes, maneuver CTC rotation design, manning strategies, unit training time constraints, and training program funding difficulties. Development of principles to guide strategy improvement and specific directions for applying those principles.

sections.title: Developing and Assessing Options for Making Weapon Training Strategies More Efficient
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative analysis of M4/M16 individual rifle record-fire training and qualification.  Identification of three general options for reducing training ammunition: reduce rounds/engagements per event, reduce number of events, reduce frequency of events.  Expansion of options to five.  Comparison of options with baseline (196 rounds per individual per year).  Discussion of research designs to support informed decisions, including collection of rifle marksmanship outcome data, predictive model studies, and quasi-experimental design to assess skill decay with and without EST use.

analysis.sample_description: The study examined 14 weapon systems, with a focused analysis on small arms (M16/M4 rifle, M249 SAW, M240B machine gun).  Data from other nations' armies and the USMC were also used for comparison.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis was the primary approach, with quantitative data used to support comparisons and inform the development of research designs.  The study used a comparative approach to examine the Army's small arms training strategies against those of other nations and the USMC.  For the efficiency analysis, the study proposed quasi-experimental designs to test the impact of different training strategies on soldier proficiency.

sections.title: Data Collection and Categorization of Armed UAV Development
sections.methods_summary: The researchers compiled a list of UAVs in development worldwide using open-source data.  They categorized these UAVs based on criteria such as designation (attack systems, precision strike systems, etc.) and the Missile Technology Control Regime (MTCR) categories.  A separate 'other systems' category was created for technology demonstrators, concepts, research programs, micro-UAVs, and suicide drones.

sections.title: Analysis of U.S. Operational Use of Armed UAVs
sections.methods_summary: The researchers analyzed U.S. operational use of armed UAVs across various conflicts, categorizing them based on whether they occurred in recognized war zones, whether there was clear congressional authorization, the types of targets, and the targeting criteria (vetted list, signature strikes, combat support).  This categorization allowed for an analysis of how U.S. use corresponds to traditional norms of the use of force.

sections.title: Comparative Analysis of International Norms for Military Technologies
sections.methods_summary: The researchers used a comparative case study approach, examining existing international norms for blinding lasers, autonomous weapon systems, and antipersonnel landmines.  They analyzed the guidelines on use, U.S. leadership role in norm development, and the impact of U.S. actions on international use. This analysis informed their recommendations for developing international norms for armed UAVs.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consists of worldwide UAV development projects identified through open-source data, and examples of U.S. armed UAV operations across various conflicts.  The comparative analysis includes international norms for blinding lasers, autonomous weapon systems, and antipersonnel landmines.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves categorizing UAVs based on various criteria, comparing U.S. UAV use to established norms of the use of force, and drawing lessons from existing international norms for similar military technologies to inform recommendations for armed UAVs.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This study employed a mixed-methods approach.  Data was collected through an online survey of staff in schools and colleges (107 schools invited, 54 responded, response rate 50%), and semi-structured interviews with career guidance providers (29 invited, 10 participated). The survey included both closed and open-ended questions.  A pilot survey was conducted with two schools to refine the questionnaire. Data cleaning involved checking for consistency and completeness; in cases of multiple responses from the same school, data from the careers leader was prioritized.  Qualitative data from open-ended survey questions and interviews were analyzed thematically to provide context and illustrate quantitative findings. Subgroup analyses were conducted based on school type, careers leader budget, geographical location, school size, and Ofsted rating. Interview notes were analyzed using the interview protocol to identify areas of agreement and divergence among providers.

analysis.sample_description: The survey targeted 107 public and independent secondary schools and colleges in Cambridgeshire and Peterborough.  54 responded (50% response rate).  Interviews were conducted with 10 out of 29 invited career guidance providers.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics were used for multiple-choice survey questions. Qualitative data from open-ended survey questions and interviews were analyzed thematically. Subgroup analyses were conducted to explore differences across schools and colleges based on various characteristics.  For the interviews, notes were analyzed using the interview protocol to identify areas of agreement and divergence among providers.

sections.title: Methods and Methodology Report
sections.methods_summary: Iterative narrative approach. A researcher not involved in assembling perspectives reviewed the full set, extracting attributes that promoted or hindered translation. Further details are in the Methods and Methodology Report.

analysis.sample_description: Not explicitly described in this section, but implied to be the full set of perspectives assembled for the study.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of attributes extracted from perspectives to identify factors promoting or hindering translation.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This chapter details the research approach, including a literature review, primary data collection through semi-structured interviews with individuals and Senior Investigative Officers (SIOs), and analysis of trial evidence and computer registries.  A triangulation approach combining these data sources was used. The study aimed to answer questions about internet use in radicalization and the relationship between online and offline activity.

analysis.sample_description: The study included 15 cases: 10 convicted terrorists (Category A, including one former member of a proscribed terrorist group) and 5 individuals identified as vulnerable to extremism (Category B, participating in the Channel program).  Cases were identified through a combination of media reports and collaboration with the Association of Chief Police Officers (ACPO). This constitutes a convenience sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: The researchers tested five hypotheses derived from the literature review using the primary data collected.  The analysis involved comparing the primary data findings to the hypotheses, identifying cross-cutting themes, and exploring the relationship between online and offline behavior in the radicalization process.  A word cloud analysis was used to visualize search terms from computer registries.

sections.title: Methodology: Insurer Interviews and Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The study conducted interviews with insurers to understand their responses to TRIA expiration.  Actuarial data on workers' compensation (WC) combined ratios were also analyzed to assess the financial performance of WC compared to other commercial lines.  The analysis focuses on how insurers manage terrorism exposure, particularly the concept of probable maximum loss and concentration limits.

sections.title: Methodology: Analysis of Residual Markets and Risk Allocation
sections.methods_summary: The research analyzes the structure and function of residual markets in workers' compensation insurance across different states.  It examines two main mechanisms: assigned-risk mechanisms and state funds. Case studies of Illinois, California, and New York are presented to illustrate how different residual market designs affect the allocation of catastrophic losses from terrorist attacks.  The analysis considers the role of guaranty associations and the potential impact on employers, workers, and taxpayers.

primary_methods: Case studies of state-level WC systems
analysis.sample_description: The study interviewed workers' compensation insurers and other stakeholders.  The quantitative analysis used data from the National Council on Compensation Insurance (NCCI) and the National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC). The case studies focused on Illinois, California, and New York, selected to represent different residual market mechanisms.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved qualitative interpretation of insurer interviews to understand their decision-making processes regarding terrorism risk. Quantitative analysis of actuarial data was used to compare the financial performance of WC to other insurance lines.  The case studies used descriptive analysis to illustrate how different state-level institutions would allocate catastrophic losses in the absence of TRIA.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: A six-week survey was conducted in spring 2013, sent to all ASA members (except those without email addresses or who opted out).  The response rate was approximately 25% (6800 responses).  Data were weighted to account for differences between respondents and nonrespondents based on location, age, and gender.  External data from the Area Health Resource File (AHRF) and the National Resident Matching Program were used to supplement the survey data for the econometric analysis.

sections.title: Econometric Analysis
sections.methods_summary: A disequilibrium model was estimated using maximum likelihood to analyze the shortage of anesthesiologists.  Shortage indicators from the survey were aggregated into a single shortage variable. This variable was used to estimate the probability of a state being in a shortage, which informed the estimation of demand and supply functions.  Different strategies were used to aggregate the shortage indicators.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consisted of ASA members (anesthesiologists), with a response rate of approximately 25%.  The sample was weighted to be representative of the national anesthesiologist population.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved descriptive statistics, weighting of survey data to account for nonresponse bias, and econometric modeling to assess the supply and demand of anesthesiologists and identify potential shortages.  The econometric model accounted for market imperfections and used shortage indicators to estimate the probability of shortage in different states.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study uses data from the RAND Health Reform Opinion Study (HROS), a monthly survey conducted using the RAND American Life Panel, a nationally representative panel of individuals.  The analysis examines changes in health insurance enrollment between September 2013 and March 2014.  The sample consists of 2,641 individuals aged 18-64, with 2,425 having valid insurance status in September 2013. Sample weights are used to ensure representativeness, benchmarking to the Current Population Survey.  The study tracks transitions in insurance coverage, calculating net and gross changes.  Extrapolation from the sample to the national level is performed using weighted percentages and the total population aged 18-64.  Margins of error (95% confidence intervals) are reported.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the RAND Health Reform Opinion Study (HROS), a monthly survey of a nationally representative panel of individuals (RAND American Life Panel). The analytical sample includes 2,425 individuals aged 18-64 who reported valid insurance coverage status in September 2013 out of 2641 respondents in March 2014.  Sample weights are applied to match the demographics of the 2012 March Supplement of the Current Population Survey.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis tracks changes in health insurance enrollment between September 2013 and March 2014, focusing on transitions between different insurance categories (uninsured, employer-sponsored insurance, Medicaid, individual market, other).  Net and gross changes in enrollment are calculated and extrapolated to the national level using weighted percentages and the total population aged 18-64.  Margins of error (95% confidence intervals) are reported to account for sampling error.

sections.title: Definitions, Data, and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the definition of STEM and non-STEM disciplines, data sources (Air Force personnel records from May 2010 and Air Force manpower files from June 2010), and the methodology for collecting information on soft STEM needs.  The methodology involved structured interviews with Career Field Managers (CFMs) and subsequent verification with Functional Managers/Authorities.  Data was analyzed at three levels: core career field, duty career field, and functional area.  Positions were categorized as having hard or soft STEM requirements.

analysis.sample_description: Data for this analysis were obtained from snapshot records for all nonmedical officers and officer-equivalent civilians (defined here as all administrative and professional civilians) for May 2010. Data on required (including unfunded) and authorized (funded) manpower positions were from the June 2010 Air Force manpower file.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data was analyzed at three levels: core career field, duty career field, and functional area. Positions were categorized as having hard or soft STEM requirements.  Analysis included calculating weighted averages of degree requirements and comparing them to actual accessions.

sections.title: Introduction, Study Scope, and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the qualitative methodology employed.  It involved a literature review of civilian and military educational assistance programs, development of logic models to illustrate program activities and relationships, creation of an eligibility framework and use paths to identify gaps or redundancies, and exploration of benchmarks for program success, considering the unique characteristics of service members as nontraditional students. Data sources included academic literature, government websites, program documentation, and interviews with program administrators.

sections.title: Description of Programs’ Design Features
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the use of logic models to analyze the in-scope benefit programs.  It presents an overarching program logic model and individual close-up models for each program, illustrating inputs, activities, outputs, and outcomes. The models help identify commonalities and differences among programs and provide a better understanding of how each operates.

sections.title: Program Eligibility and Usage
sections.methods_summary: This section uses the findings from Chapters Two and Three to develop conceptual frameworks for program eligibility and usage relationships. It examines how program oversight and eligibility requirements change over a service member's lifetime, explores potential pathways for pursuing higher education goals, and discusses inefficient benefit usage and program overlap.

sections.title: Considerations for an Evaluation of Federal Education Assistance Programs for Service Members
sections.methods_summary: This section assesses the readiness of the programs for evaluation, examining data collection processes and available data sources.  It discusses the need for individual-level data and the use of external data sources (DMDC, NSC, SSA, LEHD, ED) to measure program outputs and outcomes.  It proposes benchmarks for program effectiveness, considering nontraditional students as a comparison group and highlighting the importance of including individual characteristics in the evaluation.

analysis.sample_description: The study focuses on federal education benefit programs available to active-duty and reserve service members while still serving.  It excludes programs exclusively for post-service veterans and those not directly resulting in academic credits, degrees, licenses, or certificates.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of program design features, logic models to illustrate program activities and relationships, identification of gaps and redundancies in services, exploration of benchmarks for program success considering the unique characteristics of service members as nontraditional students.

sections.title: Economic Analysis Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Three-phase analysis: 1) Study identification using NETSCC suggestions and HTA journal scans, applying inclusion criteria (cost-effectiveness or cost-saving, QALYs reported, ICER below £20,000 threshold, >60% probability of cost-effectiveness). 2) Data extraction using a template, standardizing costs to 2012 prices using NHS Pay and Price index. 3) Data analysis: calculating net benefit per case (monetized QALY gain - incremental cost) and total net benefit, comparing to HTA Programme costs (adjusted to 2012 prices using GDP deflator).

sections.title: Case Studies Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Pragmatic selection of 10 case studies (including some from economic analysis) to explore wider impacts. Data collection involved document review (HTA publications, journal articles, NICE guidance, project websites) and semi-structured interviews with chief investigators.  Case studies used a standardized reporting template covering study description, context, findings, and impact.

analysis.sample_description: For the economic analysis, a sample of 10 HTA studies was selected from a larger pool of 743 reports, based on criteria of likely high potential benefit.  For the case studies, 10 projects were selected pragmatically to reflect a range of potential impacts.
analysis.analysis_approach: Economic analysis compared monetized benefits (based on QALYs and costs) of a subset of HTA studies to the total cost of the HTA program. Case studies qualitatively assessed the impact of selected HTA projects on policy and practice.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Data were collected through site visits to nine mental health clinics across New York State and surveys of mental health clinics and affiliated providers. Site visits involved touring facilities and conducting interviews with clinic staff and consumers.  Clinics were purposively selected for their innovative efforts in integrated care, aiming for geographic diversity and representation of three integrated care initiatives. Surveys were administered to mental health clinic administrators and providers (primary care, mental health, and case management). The clinic administrator survey sample included 22 clinics, while the provider survey included 34 providers.  The study design is descriptive and qualitative, focusing on identifying factors that facilitate or hinder integrated care implementation.

analysis.sample_description: Nine mental health clinics purposively selected for their innovative integrated care approaches, aiming for geographic diversity and representation of three initiatives.  A stratified random sample of additional clinics was also used for the surveys.  The provider survey included 34 providers from the participating clinics.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive and qualitative analysis of site visit data and survey responses.  The report focuses on identifying factors that facilitate or hinder integrated care implementation and does not conduct inferential statistical analysis.

sections.title: Mapping Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Two-phase mapping process. Phase 1: Data collection on diaspora groups and general populations in the EU and US. Phase 2: Expanded analysis to include selected countries of origin, comparative analysis across diaspora groups, countries of origin, and receiving countries. Data sources: national censuses, Barro-Lee dataset, OECD Migration Database.

sections.title: Desk Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Structured literature review of academic and grey literature on diaspora engagement.  Targeted reviews on sending and receiving country strategies, intra-diaspora dynamics, and recommendations for diaspora engagement.

sections.title: Surveys and Interviews Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Online questionnaire distributed to diaspora organizations internationally.  Methods included desk research, respondent referrals (snowballing), and working through key stakeholder groups. Eight follow-up interviews with survey respondents.

sections.title: Literature Review Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Four-stage process: 1) Defining the review's scope; 2) Developing a search strategy using specific terms in databases (EBSCO, Sociological Abstracts, Google Scholar, Social Science Abstracts, JSTOR) and websites (COMPAS, CREAM, European Commission, GFMD, ICMPD, IOM, MPI, NBER, OECD, UN, World Bank); 3) Assessing eligibility for inclusion based on criteria (e.g., geographical scope, publication date, empirical component); 4) Synthesizing results.  Snowballing technique used to identify additional sources.  Quality assessment of included studies.

sections.title: Diaspora Expert Survey (DES) Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Four steps: 1) Questionnaire development (building on literature review findings, categorized diaspora organizations by size, longevity, structure, and main activities); 2) Respondent identification (prior relationships, literature review database, embassy/consulate contacts, EU migration/integration office contacts, web search, snowballing); 3) Survey implementation (online questionnaire in eight languages, anonymous, no obligatory fields, no deadline, no time limit); 4) Data analysis (SPSS for quantitative analysis, NVivo 10 for qualitative thematic analysis of free-text responses and interviews).

analysis.sample_description: The mapping section used data from national censuses, supplemented by other sources like the Barro-Lee dataset and OECD Migration Database.  The engagement section involved a survey of diaspora organizations (53 complete responses) and 8 follow-up interviews. The literature review included 129 sources (45 academic articles and 84 grey literature sources).
analysis.analysis_approach: The mapping analysis involved comparative analysis across diaspora groups, countries of origin, and receiving countries.  The engagement analysis used descriptive statistics and grounded theory analysis for qualitative data.

sections.title: Methodology: Mapping
sections.methods_summary: Two-phase mapping process. Phase 1: Collected information on diaspora groups and general populations in EU and US using country of birth variable and supplemented with data from Barro-Lee and OECD Migration Database. Phase 2: Expanded analysis to selected countries of origin, collecting same data on general populations and conducting comparative analysis across diaspora groups, countries of origin, and receiving countries.  Most recent national censuses formed the primary data source.

sections.title: Methodology: Desk Research
sections.methods_summary: Structured literature review of academic and grey literature on diaspora engagement to understand models, effectiveness, and challenges. Targeted reviews of sending and receiving country strategies, diaspora group dynamics, and recommendations from prior reports.

sections.title: Methodology: Surveys and Interviews
sections.methods_summary: Online questionnaire distributed to diaspora organizations internationally using online contact information, referrals, and existing networks.  Eight follow-up interviews with diaspora representatives identified through the survey.  The questionnaire aimed to understand diaspora representatives' views and experiences on diaspora engagement strategies. Quantitative analysis of survey responses.

primary_methods: Mapping (two-phase process using census data, Barro-Lee data, OECD Migration Database)
analysis.sample_description: 53 survey responses representing over 25 diaspora communities; 32 responses from the selected sending countries; ~1/3 of respondents based in the US; 3 from high-income countries outside the EU/US; remaining 2/3 based in EU Member States.  Additional 8 interviews conducted.
analysis.analysis_approach: Comparative analysis of socioeconomic indicators across diaspora groups, countries of origin, and receiving countries. Quantitative analysis of survey data. Qualitative analysis of interview data and literature review findings.

sections.title: Our Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study integrated findings from a literature review with perspectives gathered from a one-day stakeholder forum.  The forum involved plenary sessions and breakout groups with 45 participants representing advocates, educators, researchers, policymakers, funders, and parents.  The policy brief integrates these findings, but is not considered comprehensive or definitive.

primary_methods: stakeholder forum with plenary sessions and breakout groups
analysis.sample_description: 45 forum participants representing advocates, educators, researchers, policymakers, funders, and parents.
analysis.analysis_approach: Integration of findings from the literature review and stakeholder forum.  The results are presented as suggestions to advance knowledge and encourage further conversation.

sections.title: Our Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study integrated findings from a literature review with perspectives gathered from a one-day stakeholder forum.  The forum involved 45 participants representing advocates, educators, researchers, policymakers, funders, and parents.  Data was collected through plenary sessions and smaller breakout groups.

primary_methods: stakeholder forum with plenary sessions and breakout groups
analysis.sample_description: 45 forum participants representing advocates, educators, researchers, policymakers, funders, and parents.
analysis.analysis_approach: Findings from the literature review were integrated with the perspectives of forum participants.

sections.title: Our Approach
sections.methods_summary: Literature review and a one-day stakeholder forum with 45 participants (advocates, educators, researchers, policymakers, funders, and parents).  Findings from the literature review were integrated with perspectives from forum participants (plenary sessions and breakout groups).

analysis.sample_description: 45 forum participants representing advocates, educators, researchers, policymakers, funders, and parents.
analysis.analysis_approach: Integration of findings from the literature review with perspectives gathered from the forum participants through plenary sessions and breakout groups.  The resulting policy brief is presented as suggestions to advance knowledge and encourage further conversation, not as a comprehensive or definitive analysis.

sections.title: Our Approach
sections.methods_summary: Literature review and a one-day stakeholder forum with 45 participants (advocates, educators, researchers, policymakers, funders, and parents).  Findings from the literature review were integrated with perspectives from forum participants (plenary sessions and breakout groups).

analysis.sample_description: 45 forum participants representing advocates, educators, researchers, policymakers, funders, and parents.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis integrating findings from a literature review with the perspectives gathered from the stakeholder forum.  The report notes that the findings are not considered comprehensive or definitive.

sections.title: Our Approach
sections.methods_summary: Literature review and a one-day stakeholder forum with 45 participants (advocates, educators, researchers, policymakers, funders, and parents).  Findings from the literature review were integrated with perspectives from forum participants (plenary sessions and breakout groups).

analysis.sample_description: 45 forum participants representing advocates, educators, researchers, policymakers, funders, and parents.
analysis.analysis_approach: Integration of findings from the literature review with perspectives gathered from the forum participants through plenary sessions and breakout groups.  The resulting policy brief is described as not comprehensive or definitive, but rather offering suggestions to advance knowledge and encourage further conversation.

sections.title: Methodology: Dynamic Retention Model (DRM)
sections.methods_summary: The study uses the Dynamic Retention Model (DRM), a pre-existing model adapted to analyze federal civilian worker retention.  The DRM simulates employee decisions to stay or leave based on compensation changes (pay freezes, retirement contribution increases).  Three scenarios were modeled for the pay freeze (permanent cut, immediate restoration, 10-year delay).  For retirement benefit changes, two scenarios were modeled: no wealth effect and fully protecting personal savings by reducing consumption.  The model uses real (inflation-adjusted) dollars for civil service and private sector pay.  Hiring was assumed unchanged in all scenarios.

analysis.sample_description: The primary sample focused on DoD General Schedule (GS) employees with at least a bachelor's degree.  The analysis also considered specific demographic groups (e.g., those with four or more years of college).
analysis.analysis_approach: The DRM simulates employee retention under different compensation scenarios.  The results show the percentage change in the size of the GS workforce under each scenario, comparing it to a baseline with no compensation changes.  The analysis examines long-run effects and effects at different points in time (e.g., year 5, year 10, year 20).

sections.title: Study Design and Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: A statewide telephone survey of 2,568 California adults (ages 18+) was conducted in spring and summer 2013.  The sample included oversampling of African American and Asian American adults to enhance diversity.  The survey was administered in multiple languages (English, Spanish, Cantonese, Mandarin, Vietnamese, Hmong, and Khmer). A weighting procedure was applied to approximate the adult population of California.  One question asked respondents about their likelihood of using various resources for suicidal thoughts (rated 1-4). Preference was defined as a rating of 1 or 2.

analysis.sample_description: 2,568 California adults (ages 18 and older), with oversampling of African American and Asian American adults. Survey administered in multiple languages. Weighting applied to approximate California adult population.
