analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive analysis of survey responses to determine preferences for suicide crisis services.  The rank order of preferences was examined across age and gender.

sections.title: Study Design and Sampling
sections.methods_summary: A statewide survey of 2,568 California adults (ages 18+) was conducted in spring and summer 2013 via telephone (landline or cell phone).  The initial sample of 2,001 adults was supplemented with additional African American and Asian American adults to improve sample diversity.  The sample included 1,014 White, 631 Latino, 401 Asian American, and 360 African American individuals.  A weighting procedure was applied to approximate the adult population of California.  The survey was offered in multiple languages (English, Spanish, Cantonese, Mandarin, Vietnamese, Hmong, and Khmer).

sections.title: Data Collection and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The survey included questions on exposure to suicide prevention messaging, preferences for suicide crisis services, and confidence in intervening with at-risk individuals.  A weighted logistic regression model was used to analyze differences in resource preferences across racial/ethnic groups.  A confidence score (1-7) was created from seven questions about confidence to intervene.  The report notes that more complex analyses controlling for language, education, and location were planned for future work.

analysis.sample_description: A statewide telephone survey of 2,568 California adults (18+), with oversampling of African American and Asian American adults to ensure representation.  The sample was weighted to approximate the California adult population.
analysis.analysis_approach: Weighted logistic regression was used to analyze differences in resource preferences across racial/ethnic groups.  A composite confidence score was calculated from multiple survey items.  Further analysis controlling for confounding variables was planned but not yet conducted.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: A total of 466 students completed a pre- and post-performance survey.  Measures were drawn or adapted from previous studies. T-tests were used for mean estimates and chi-square statistics for percentage estimates (p < 0.05 considered significant).

analysis.sample_description: Participants were students (N=466) attending a performance of Walk In Our Shoes at a Santa Barbara County middle school.  The sample was predominantly Latino (89%), with a mean age of 12.51 years (SD = 0.60), 55% female. 81% reported speaking a language other than English at home.
analysis.analysis_approach: Pre- and post-test scores were compared using t-tests for mean estimates and chi-square tests for percentage estimates.  A p-value less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Document reviews, key informant interviews, and participant surveys were used to collect data on the development, function, and goals of collaborative activities; challenges and facilitators to successful collaboration; and the degree to which collaboration activities contributed to short- and long-term outcomes.

sections.title: Next Steps/Further Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A brief collaboration survey will be disseminated to participants in SMH collaborative activities.  Quantitative findings from the survey will be integrated with qualitative data from key informant interviews to investigate how characteristics of collaborative entities or participants affect partnership success.

analysis.sample_description: Key informants were identified by the California Department of Education (CDE) and California County Superintendents Educational Services Association (CCSESA) program staff.  The sample for the planned survey includes participants in SMH collaborative activities (e.g., CCSESA county consortia members, SMHPW members).
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data.  Quantitative analysis of survey data will be conducted to investigate the relationship between characteristics of collaborative entities and participants and the success or challenges of forming partnerships.  The report does not specify statistical methods.

sections.title: Study Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study focused on five fields (nursing and four applied science fields) and four distinct Texas regions representing urban and rural areas.  Researchers conducted interviews with over 300 stakeholders (employers, institutional leaders, departmental experts), literature reviews, surveys, and quantitative data analysis from various sources (Texas Workforce Commission, American Community Survey, etc.).  The study acknowledges limitations, including the lack of a full shortage assessment and the focus on only four regions.

analysis.sample_description: The study focused on five occupational fields (nursing, computer and information technology, management in fire sciences, management of production/operations technicians, and health information technology) and four geographically diverse regions of Texas (Dallas-Fort Worth, Gulf Coast, South Texas, and West Central Texas).  Over 300 stakeholders were interviewed, including employers, institutional leaders, and departmental experts from universities and community colleges.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative data from various sources (Texas Workforce Commission, American Community Survey, etc.) were analyzed.  The study also involved qualitative analysis of interview data and literature review findings.  The analysis considered indicators of supply and demand for baccalaureate-level workers in the chosen fields and regions.

sections.title: Expert Panel Review
sections.methods_summary: A panel of 12 experts in suicidology, suicide prevention, and media campaigns reviewed the "Know the Signs" campaign in two phases. Phase 1 involved developing a best practices checklist. Phase 2 involved applying the checklist to the campaign materials.  Experts rated the campaign's adherence to each checklist item.

analysis.sample_description: A panel of 12 experts in suicidology, suicide prevention, and media campaigns.
analysis.analysis_approach: Experts rated the campaign's alignment with best practices based on a checklist.  The ratings reflect an aggregate assessment of the campaign materials.

sections.title: Research Approach Overview
sections.methods_summary: The research employed a multi-method, exploratory approach.  Methods included: UK football policing unit and police officer survey data analysis; a daily diary activity-sampling exercise with mounted officers; structured content analysis of newspaper articles; analysis of national mounted police Performance Framework data; analysis of the relative and absolute costs of mounted policing; and an international questionnaire of mounted sections in other countries. Preliminary findings were presented at validation workshops with police practitioners.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research used an exploratory approach to examine mounted police across various deployment scenarios (neighbourhood policing, football policing, public order policing).  Methods included: a quasi-experiment with before-and-after surveys and systematic social observation (SSO); focus groups with mounted and non-mounted officers and football fans; observations of mounted police in demonstrations, peaceful events, and festivals; a costing exercise using operational order data; and an international survey of senior mounted police officers.

sections.title: Limitations
sections.methods_summary: This section discusses limitations of the study, including non-random sampling in several data collection methods (quasi-experiment, officer survey, focus groups, international questionnaire), problematic cost data due to inconsistent reporting across police forces, lack of systematic testing of crime reduction deployments, potential limitations in international transferability of findings, and lack of data from protest groups.

analysis.sample_description: Samples were largely non-random due to time and resource constraints.  Specific samples included mounted police officers, football fans, police officers at football matches, and international mounted police sections.  The study also analyzed national performance framework data and newspaper articles.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data analysis techniques included statistical analysis (e.g., examining associations between variables), content analysis of newspaper articles, and qualitative analysis of focus group data and observations.  Cost analysis involved examining operational order data and conducting a costing exercise with Directors of Finance at four constabularies.

sections.title: Appendix A: Project methodology resources
sections.methods_summary: This appendix lists five research tools used: Systematic Social Observation (SSO) Codebook, survey of police officers, international questionnaire for senior mounted officers, daily diary tool, and focus group schedules.  The SSO used a mobile app ('Forms') guided by a codebook. Researchers attended a workshop on the SSO approach.

sections.title: International Mounted Policing Questionnaire
sections.methods_summary: A questionnaire was distributed to senior mounted police officers internationally to gather information on the organization and practice of mounted policing.  The questionnaire was available in PDF and Word formats and was sent via email.  The cover letter emphasized the voluntary and confidential nature of participation.

sections.title: Daily Diary Tool
sections.methods_summary: A daily diary tool, based on a previous NPIA study, was used to understand the day-to-day activities of mounted officers.  Officers completed physical copies of the diary, which were then returned by mail. The basic unit of analysis was 'activity-events'.

sections.title: Football Fan Focus Group Schedule
sections.methods_summary: Two focus groups with football fans were conducted to understand citizen views on mounted policing in public order contexts.  A structured script guided the discussions, which were audio-recorded.  Participants were recruited through the Football Supporters Foundation.

sections.title: Non-Mounted Police Officer Focus Group Schedule
sections.methods_summary: Two focus groups with non-mounted police officers (one with public order officers, one with neighborhood officers) were conducted to understand police officers' opinions on the value of mounted police.  A structured script guided the discussions, which were audio-recorded. Participants were ideally drawn from the same units or area of operations.

sections.title: Football Policing Post-Match Survey
sections.methods_summary: A post-match online survey was administered to officers to analyze the quality of policing at matches with and without mounted police.  The survey focused on aspects like response time, readiness to intervene, and public interaction.  Supervisory officers were the target audience.

sections.title: Appendix B: Data Tables and Quasi-Experimental Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This section details the quasi-experimental design used in Gloucestershire and London, employing a difference-in-differences approach with matched pairs.  Fixed effects linear regression models (in Stata 12.1) were estimated to account for clustering of individual responses within geographical pairs.  The analysis examined changes in trust and confidence in police before and after the intervention in test and control sites.

sections.title: Appendix C: Football Data
sections.methods_summary: Ground-level data from the UK Football Policing Unit (UKFPU) and the MWG on mounted police presence, ejections, disorder, and arrests at Premier League and Championship matches during 2010/11-2012/13 seasons are presented.

analysis.sample_description: The study involved international senior mounted police officers, UK police officers (mounted and non-mounted), football fans, and data from Premier League and Championship football matches.
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis methods included difference-in-differences regression analysis (using Stata) for the quasi-experimental data and descriptive statistics for the survey and focus group data. Binary logistic regression models were used to predict trust in police community engagement, fairness, and effectiveness, as well as overall confidence.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study population included Medicare FFS beneficiaries receiving at least one of the gastroenterology and cardiology study procedures. The study sample was drawn from a 2012 100-percent sample of national Medicare FFS claims files.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study population included Medicare FFS beneficiaries receiving at least one of the gastroenterology and cardiology study procedures.  A 2012 100-percent sample of national Medicare FFS claims files (Carrier, Outpatient hospital, and MedPAR) was used.  A nine-day episode of care was defined around each index procedure.  Claims were categorized into service categories.  A nine-day episode duration was selected in consultation with CMS and expert panels.

sections.title: 2. Methods Data Sources and Study Sample
sections.methods_summary: The study population included Medicare FFS beneficiaries with at least one of the gastroenterology and cardiology study procedures (listed in Table 2.1) between January 2 and December 24, 2012. Data came from a 100% sample of national Medicare FFS claims files (Carrier, Outpatient hospital, MedPAR).  A nine-day episode was defined. Denied claims were excluded.  Eligible HCPCS procedure codes were identified using place of service variables and specific rules for professional and facility lines.  Index procedures were defined using a hierarchical process.  Matching of facility and professional claim lines was done using six tiers of criteria.  Gastroenterology and cardiology procedures were categorized.  For gastroenterology, screening, diagnostic, and therapeutic procedures were distinguished.  The most common multiple procedure scenarios were investigated.  Health care services within the nine-day episode were categorized (Table 2.9).

analysis.sample_description: Medicare FFS beneficiaries receiving at least one of the specified gastroenterology and cardiology procedures in 2012. Data from 100% sample of national Medicare FFS claims files.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis of claims data to identify index procedures, categorize services, and calculate utilization and payments for services within a nine-day episode around each index procedure.  Analysis of practice and patient characteristics to inform eligibility criteria.

sections.title: Approach and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Systematic review of studies on consumer grocery shopping choices and responses to price changes in the US.  Studies sourced from academic journals, market research firms, consulting companies, industry groups, and government reports (GAO and CBO).  Supplemented by interviews with DeCA officials and subject matter experts to identify relevant data for more precise estimations.  The limitations of generalizing from private sector retailers to commissaries are acknowledged due to differences in consumer responses based on demographics and store/market attributes.  The need for original research using commissary operational data or data from commissary patrons is highlighted.

sections.title: Previous Estimates of the Effect of Price Increases on Store Choice
sections.methods_summary: Review of literature on grocery store choice in competitive retail environments to obtain quantitative estimates of own-store price elasticities.  Discussion of the concept of own-store price elasticity and its distinction from own-price elasticity.  Summary of findings from several studies, including Dove/Willard Bishop (2004), Chan et al. (2006), Smith (2004), Ellickson, Griecob, and Khvastunovb (2014), Richards and Hamilton (2006), Artz and Stone (2006), Briesch, Chintagunta, and Fox (2009), and Rhee and Bell (2002), focusing on own-store elasticities associated with permanent changes in overall store price levels.  The limitations of these studies in relation to the unique characteristics of commissaries are noted.

sections.title: Future Research
sections.methods_summary: Proposes a future research project to obtain more precise estimates of the effect of price increases on commissary sales.  Suggests using individual-level shopping behavior data to model store choice probability as a function of various factors (price levels, geographic distribution, shopping habits, store characteristics, demographics).  Mentions the use of statistical methodologies illustrated in Figurelli (2013) and Ellickson, Griecob, and Khvastunovb (2014).  Also suggests using methods to estimate the loss of nonmarket benefits, such as willingness-to-pay surveys.

analysis.sample_description: The study does not involve a specific sample of individuals.  Instead, it analyzes existing data and research from various sources related to consumer behavior in the grocery industry.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis primarily involves a review and synthesis of existing literature on consumer behavior and price elasticity, with a focus on extrapolating findings from the private sector to the unique context of military commissaries.  Quantitative analysis is used to estimate the potential impact of price increases on commissary revenues and consumer expenditures under different assumptions about price elasticity.

sections.title: Study Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the purposive sampling of 100,000 Jobs Mission coalition companies based on company size, industry, time in coalition, and level of involvement.  50 companies were contacted, with 26 participating in semi-structured interviews conducted between June and August 2014.  Interviews lasted 30-75 minutes and covered five key themes: veteran employment programs, recruitment strategies, management and retention strategies, coalition membership, and desired policy changes.  Interview notes were coded using NVivo software, and data were analyzed according to company characteristics to identify themes and assess relationships between characteristics and responses.

analysis.sample_description: A purposive sample of 100,000 Jobs Mission coalition companies was selected to ensure diversity across company size, industry, length of coalition membership, and level of involvement.  50 companies were contacted, resulting in 26 interviews.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data analysis was performed using NVivo software.  Thematic analysis was conducted, and relationships between company characteristics and responses were examined.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Comparative analysis of fuel costs for historical AMC flights with and without tankering.  Uses a more extensive flight dataset and incorporates independently gathered price data than previous research.  Simulates the effects of informational barriers within DoD and considers how future flying patterns might affect estimates of tankering savings. Focuses exclusively on C-5, C-17, and C-130 aircraft. Considers real market prices in addition to DLA standard prices.

sections.title: Flight and Fuel Price Datasets
sections.methods_summary: Flight data obtained from the Global Decision Support System (GDSS).  Data includes sorties, date, departure/arrival information, and payload.  Assumptions made about aircraft performance characteristics and the impact of tankering on operational capability. Data cleaning steps described, resulting in 94,726 sorties eligible for analysis. Jet fuel procurement process described, including DLA's standard pricing system.  Market price estimation methodology detailed, including use of DLA's Into Plane Contract Information System (IPCIS) and independently gathered spot prices.  Method for assigning market prices to unknown locations described, using distance to nearest known location and averaging across four flight subsets to account for uncertainty.

sections.title: Four Decision Factors to Consider When Tankering Fuel
sections.methods_summary: Describes four factors influencing tankering decisions: capacity, fuel burn penalty, fuel requirement for the next leg, and fuel price difference.  Mathematical model for fuel requirement as a function of distance and payload.  Calculation of burn factor (ξ).  Simplified approach for modeling multi-leg missions using average profiles for next mission leg.  Decision algorithm presented.

sections.title: Is Tankering Fuel on AMC Aircraft a Cost-Saving Strategy?
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of tankering savings from AMC and DoD perspectives.  Baseline scenario using FY 2012 data and DLA standard prices.  Sensitivity analysis examining temporal and spatial fluctuations in savings.  Wartime and peacetime scenarios defined.  Simulation of scenarios with complete and incomplete information (DLA sharing market price data with AMC).  Comparison of results across scenarios.

sections.title: Fuel Offloading: Economic Effect and Feasibility
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of the impact of fuel offloading on tankering savings.  Assumptions about fuel demand, storage, and offloading methods.  Simulation of scenarios with and without fuel offloading, considering different configurations (wartime/peacetime, complete/incomplete information, offloading from tank only or tank and cargo hold).  Assessment of potential barriers to implementation (time, manpower costs, fuel quality, ground logistics).

analysis.sample_description: Over 94,700 flights completed by C-5, C-17, and C-130 aircraft during FY 2012.  Data cleaned to exclude training flights and those requiring air refueling.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis compares fuel costs of historical flights with and without tankering, considering various factors (fuel prices, burn penalty, capacity, etc.). Simulations are used to model different scenarios (wartime/peacetime, information sharing, fuel offloading) and assess the impact on cost savings from both AMC and DoD perspectives.

sections.title: Research Overview
sections.methods_summary: Literature review, interviews with U.S. regulators, global companies, international consulting firms, international non-profit organizations, and global law firms; data source evaluation; model development; statistical testing.

sections.title: Development of the Business Bribery Risk Index: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Review of existing corruption and governance indices; stakeholder interviews (U.S. regulators, global non-profit institutions, general counsel of global companies, partners at international consulting firms, and partners in global law firms); indicator selection based on public availability, published methodology, lack of bias, country coverage, and data longevity; multiple imputation to handle missing data; weighted average of domain scores with variance penalty to calculate total risk score.  Quantitative legal review approach used for some indicators.

sections.title: Stakeholder Interviews: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Structured interviews with 13 stakeholders (U.S. regulators, global non-profit institutions, general counsel of global companies, partners at international consulting firms, and partners in global law firms) conducted via telephone and in-person between December 6, 2013, and February 27, 2014. Each interview lasted approximately one hour.

sections.title: Statistical Model Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Aggregation of indicators from indicator level to subdomain level to domain level; multiple imputation to handle missing data; standardization of indicators; calculation of subdomain and domain scores; weighted average of domain scores with variance penalty to calculate total risk score.  The weighting of Domain 1 was determined by statistical testing, interviews, and TRACE International's experience.

analysis.sample_description: 13 stakeholders representing various perspectives on anti-bribery indices, including U.S. regulators, global non-profit institutions, general counsel, consultants, and law firm partners.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data aggregation from multiple sources using a weighted average approach with a variance penalty, multiple imputation to address missing data, and statistical testing to inform weighting of domains.

sections.title: Appendix A. Literature review methodology
sections.methods_summary: A team-based approach was used for the literature review in Phase 1a, with team members conducting focused research in ten thematic areas. Academic literature was accessed through team expertise and Google Scholar searches, while grey literature was reviewed from UK and EU sources, including TSB, BIS, ONS, MOD, and the European Commission. Phase 1b involved continued review of relevant grey literature, focusing on government and third sector sources.  Over 120 academic and grey literature sources were reviewed.

sections.title: Appendix B. List of stakeholder interviews & Appendix C. Interview protocol for stakeholder engagement
sections.methods_summary: In the main report, 27 stakeholders were interviewed from the MOD and the wider innovation landscape.  The interviews were semi-structured, using a standardized protocol (Appendix C) to gather insights on innovation processes, characteristics, and challenges.  The study extension involved 16 interviews with stakeholders from the academic, defense, and industry sectors to explore the operationalization of recommendations. Appendix C details the interview protocol used in both phases.

sections.title: Appendix C. Interview protocol for stakeholder engagement
sections.methods_summary: A semi-structured interview protocol was used for both the main study and the study extension.  The protocol included questions on drivers of innovation, enabling factors, absorptive capacity, networking, organizational practices, cross-sectoral innovation, and global rankings of the UK's innovation capabilities.  The protocol was tailored to the interviewee's role and expertise.  The study extension protocol included additional sections on changing the internal MOD context, stimulating external actors, changing interaction dynamics, and changing the location of innovation.

sections.title: Appendix D. First expert workshop
sections.methods_summary: A first expert workshop with 20 high-level stakeholders from across the UK innovation landscape was conducted to enhance understanding of the UK innovation ecosystem and the MOD's role.  The workshop involved collaborative mapping exercises and moderated discussions on innovation processes and networks.

sections.title: Appendix E. Options for action derived from the framework
sections.methods_summary: 24 options for action were generated based on the innovation framework.  These options were investigated systematically using stakeholder interview transcripts and academic and grey literature. A consistent template was used to assess the evidence base for each option, considering factors such as drivers, capital, talent, knowledge assets, infrastructure, networks, culture, and structure.

sections.title: Appendix F. Second expert workshop
sections.methods_summary: A second expert workshop with entrepreneurs, MOD and industry experts assessed the feasibility and impact of the 24 options for action.  Participants ranked each option as high or low on feasibility and impact.  The workshop used interactive exercises and moderated discussions.

sections.title: Appendix G. Measuring innovation in the MOD
sections.methods_summary: The appendix discusses methods for measuring innovation at both the departmental/enterprise level and the project level, using the innovation framework as a basis.  Suggestions for metrics are provided for each level, considering factors such as drivers, input resources, enabling resources, shaping factors, and outputs.  The appendix also discusses measuring the maturity of innovation projects using frameworks like Technology Readiness Level and System Readiness Level.

sections.title: Chapter 2. Study objectives and methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study was conducted in three phases: Phase 1 focused on mechanisms and relationships within the innovation ecosystem, identifying eight critical factors for innovation; Phase 2 involved forming and validating recommendations through literature review, stakeholder interviews, and an expert workshop; Phase 3 extended the study to investigate the application of recommendations in the academic sector.  The study used an analytical framework of innovation to structure findings and recommendations.

sections.title: A1. Study objective and methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study extension used a structured methodology with two phases: Phase 3a involved developing draft options for action, interview protocols, and targeted literature review; Phase 3b involved reviewing and validating options for action against collected evidence and relevant case studies.  The extension involved 16 key informant interviews.

analysis.sample_description: The main study involved 27 stakeholders from the MOD and wider innovation landscape, while the study extension included 16 stakeholders from the academic, defense, and industry sectors.  Interviewees were selected based on their expertise and informed perspectives.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study used a structured methodology with distinct phases for evidence collection and analysis.  An analytical framework of innovation was developed and used to structure findings and recommendations.  The feasibility and impact of recommendations were evaluated through expert workshops and analysis of the evidence base.

sections.title: Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: RAND researchers conducted 31 semistructured interviews with 67 individuals from July 7 to September 19, 2014.  The sample included individuals from federal agencies, state and local governments, and NGOs, some of which received Sandy supplemental funds.  A purposive sampling technique was used to obtain a diverse sample. Interviewees provided documentation. A keywords-in-context technique was used to identify qualitative themes in interview notes and documents.  Appendix B provides more detail.

sections.title: Detailed Methods
sections.methods_summary: 31 individual and small-group telephone interviews with 67 individuals from July 7 to September 19, 2014. Purposive sampling was used to obtain a diverse sample of federal and non-federal organizations, perspectives (received funding vs. did not receive funding), and sectors.  A snowball approach was also used.  A semistructured interview protocol (Appendix A) guided discussions.  Documents were reviewed. A keywords-in-context technique (Tesch, 1990) was used to identify qualitative themes.  A summary of themes was reached by consensus between two authors.  Data quality was ensured by considering heterogeneity and diversity, confirmability, credibility, and trustworthiness.

analysis.sample_description: A diverse sample of 67 individuals from 14 federal departments or agencies, 10 state and local governments, and NGOs.  About 71% received Sandy supplemental funds. Purposive sampling was used to ensure diversity of organization types, decisionmaker perspectives, and sectors.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative thematic analysis using a keywords-in-context technique (Tesch, 1990) to identify themes in interview notes and documents.  Consensus among two authors was used to summarize themes.

sections.title: Future Research Directions
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines suggestions for future research, including multivariate analysis, factor analysis, cluster analysis, and observational analysis of predefined subgroups.  It also suggests leveraging natural sources of clinical care variation and examining a clinical cohort with persistent mTBI-related problems.

sections.title: Appendix A: Using ICD-9 Codes to Identify mTBI
sections.methods_summary: This appendix discusses the complexities of using administrative data to identify mTBI patients and the limitations imposed on the study. It addresses challenges in patient presentation, diagnosis, and coding accuracy, including interrater reliability, content validity, and predictive validity.  It also describes the study's approach to addressing these challenges, focusing on a broad definition of mTBI and presenting robustness analyses.

sections.title: Appendix B: Comparison and Variation Using the Project and Other ICD-9 Definitions
sections.methods_summary: This appendix details the ICD-9 codes used in the study's definition of mTBI and compares it to other definitions from the literature (DoD, CDC). It analyzes relationships between code subsets and explores the impact of coding modifications on results.

sections.title: Appendix C: ICD-9 to ICD-10 Considerations
sections.methods_summary: This appendix discusses the transition from ICD-9 to ICD-10 coding and its implications for future research on TBI. It presents recommended ICD-10 codes for TBI mortality and reviews the frequency of ICD-10 code use in the literature.

sections.title: Appendix D: Variable Definitions
sections.methods_summary: This appendix provides detailed definitions of the variables used in the study, including ICD-9 codes for behavioral health conditions and symptoms commonly or occasionally co-occurring with mTBI, and CPT codes for diagnostic assessments, therapies, and medications.

sections.title: Appendix E: Additional Analyses
sections.methods_summary: This appendix presents additional analyses of mTBI diagnosis and treatment locations, TBI history, and deployment history, broken down by service, TBI history, and deployment history.

sections.title: Chapter Two: Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the study's methodology. It describes the data sources (MHS Data Repository, Defense Manpower Data Center), the process of selecting a case definition for mTBI (literature review, expert consultation), the identification of service members with new mTBI diagnoses (using a six-month clean period), and the descriptive and relative risk analyses conducted.

analysis.sample_description: Nondeployed active-duty service members who received a new mTBI diagnosis in calendar year 2012, excluding National Guard and Reserve members.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive analyses were conducted to characterize the sample and their care. Relative risk analysis was used to identify risk factors for persistent care needs.  T-tests and chi-square tests were used to compare groups. Multivariate regression was used to adjust for confounding variables.

sections.title: 1. Introduction and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A twofold approach was used: a wide-ranging literature review and semistructured interviews with 26 companies and organizations.  The literature review covered academic, business, and military publications on cyber education, workforce, organization, and outsourcing, focusing on research from the past ten years.  Interview participants were selected based on similarities to the USAF in size, cyber functions, threat exposure, and operational environment. Only practices pervasive in the interviews and supported by the literature were considered. The National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) Framework was used to standardize terminology across organizations.

analysis.sample_description: 26 companies and organizations from various sectors (financial institutions, manufacturing firms, defense industrial base firms, energy companies, network security specialists, and large government agencies) were interviewed.  22 contributed to the analysis.  Selection criteria included similarity to the USAF in size, cyber functions performed, threat exposure, and operational environment.
analysis.analysis_approach: Practices were considered only if they were common across many interviewed organizations and supported by the literature.  The NICE Framework was used to categorize and standardize cyber functions across organizations.

sections.title: Literature Review Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A literature review was conducted using PubMed, CINAHL, and Google Scholar databases.  Studies were rigorously reviewed based on research design, provider definitions, data sources, peer-review status, mechanisms of effect, and plausibility of findings.  The analysis focused on quantitative studies assessing longitudinal changes in SOP laws within states, excluding cross-sectional studies and those not focusing on NPs.

sections.title: Appendix: Literature Review Methods and Detailed Findings
sections.methods_summary: Detailed description of the literature search strategy using PubMed, CINAHL, Google Scholar, and relevant websites. Inclusion and exclusion criteria for studies are specified, with reasons for exclusion provided.  Focus was on quantitative studies with longitudinal designs examining changes in SOP laws within states.  Three studies met the inclusion criteria.

sections.title: Ohio-Specific Impact Estimation Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Point estimates from the literature review were used to assess changes in quality, access, and costs resulting from changes in SOP laws in Ohio. Ohio-specific population estimates were used to determine the specific effect on Ohio. Confidence intervals were calculated to account for uncertainty.  National estimates were used for many utilization figures due to data limitations. Assumptions about Ohio's population and the generalizability of national estimates to Ohio were made.

analysis.sample_description: The primary sample for the analysis was the body of literature on the impact of scope-of-practice laws on APRNs.  Ohio's population was used for applying the findings.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved a systematic review of the literature, followed by the application of point estimates from selected studies to project the potential impact on Ohio, incorporating confidence intervals to reflect uncertainty.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A literature review was conducted using EBSCOHost, Thomson Reuters’ Web of Science, Google Scholar, and RAND library databases. Search terms included various terms related to problematic internet use. Priority was given to peer-reviewed empirical research and clinical articles published within the past ten years, focusing on adult, Western, organizational, and military populations.  Additional research was identified through consultations with experts and by reviewing cited publications.

analysis.sample_description: The literature review focused on adult, Western, organizational, and military populations, prioritizing research from the past ten years.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved identifying and synthesizing relevant information from the selected literature.

sections.title: Sample and Recruitment
sections.methods_summary: The study uses the RAND American Life Panel (ALP), a nationally representative internet panel.  Recruitment involved contacting potential participants through the ORC Caravan Survey, a weekly survey using random digit dialing of landlines and cell phones.  Those agreeing to participate completed a screener survey, and those agreeing to join the ALP were added to the panel.  The sample was refreshed with 800-1000 new recruits.  The final sample is limited to US citizens and consists of approximately 5000 potential respondents.

sections.title: Survey Design and Administration
sections.methods_summary: Six surveys were conducted, each lasting seven days.  Surveys included questions on voting intentions (using a probabilistic approach based on Delevande and Manski (2010) and Gutsche et al. (2014)),  and generic congressional ballot questions.  Respondents received payment for participation.

sections.title: Weighting and Imputation
sections.methods_summary: Weights were applied to ensure representativeness, matching sample characteristics to the 2013 Current Population Survey (CPS) using a raking algorithm.  Missing values were imputed sequentially using mode imputation for basic demographics and linear/logistic regression for other variables.  A two-stage weighting procedure was used for data from multiple surveys, incorporating inverse probability weights to account for participation bias.

sections.title: Predicting Election Results
sections.methods_summary: Likely voter turnout was calculated as the weighted average of reported voting probabilities.  Expected vote percentage for each party was calculated using a weighted formula incorporating responses to questions about voting probability and party preference. Standard errors were calculated according to Kapteyn et al. (2012).

analysis.sample_description: The study uses a refreshed sample from the RAND American Life Panel (ALP), a nationally representative internet panel, limited to US citizens.  Approximately 5000 potential respondents were available, with actual participation varying.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses weighted data to ensure representativeness.  Methods include calculating voter turnout and vote share for each party using weighted averages of probabilistic voting responses.  Additional analyses will explore various topics using both cross-sectional and longitudinal data from the ALP.

sections.title: Sample
sections.methods_summary: The sample consisted of members of the RAND American Life Panel (ALP), an internet panel representative of the U.S. population aged 18 and older.  In June 2012, 5,301 ALP members were invited to participate.  More than 3,500 agreed.  One-seventh of the panel was invited weekly to answer questions, with a seven-day response window.  A rolling seven-day window was used to construct daily samples.  If a respondent answered multiple surveys within the window, all were included.  The 'previous' survey used for change calculations was the most recent consistently answered survey before the current one.

sections.title: Data Cleaning
sections.methods_summary: Surveys with inconsistencies (e.g., percentages outside 0-100%, Q2 and Q3 components not summing to 100%) were removed from the sample before analysis.  Blanks were treated as zeros.

sections.title: Reweighting
sections.methods_summary: Two-stage weighting was used.  First, a base weight (w0i) was calculated to match the sample's socio-economic and demographic characteristics to those of the U.S. population (estimated from the BLS/Census Bureau's Current Population Survey).  Second, daily samples were post-stratified to match known 2008 voting behavior, using information from the first survey and external data sources (CPS and the United States Election Project).  Individuals with unknown 2008 voting behavior were handled using a specific weighting approach described in detail.

sections.title: Voter Turnout, Popular Vote, Predicted Winners, Numbers of Supporters, and Voter Turnout Among Supporters
sections.methods_summary: Voter turnout was predicted as a weighted average of individual probabilities of voting (Q1).  Popular vote for each candidate was predicted using weighted averages of individual probabilities of voting for that candidate (Pji = Q1i × Q2ji/100).  Predicted winner probabilities were calculated as weighted averages of individual predictions (Q3ji).  Obama and Romney supporters were defined probabilistically, and their numbers and voter turnout were calculated using weighted averages of relevant probabilities.

sections.title: Changes (Shifts)
sections.methods_summary: Day-to-day changes were computed as differences in predicted totals.  Changes in individual preferences were analyzed by combining probabilities of non-voting and voting for 'other' candidates (P0i), calculating changes in probabilities (ΔPji), and identifying 'donors' and 'recipients' to estimate shifts between candidates. Aggregate flows were computed as weighted sample means.

sections.title: Standard Errors and Shaded Areas
sections.methods_summary: Standard errors were calculated using methods and formulas from StataCorp (2009a, 2009b), adapted for the specific estimators used.  Formulas are provided for averages, ratios of means, and differences between means.  Shaded areas in graphs represent ranges where differences between Obama and Romney were not statistically significant at the 5% level, based on the standard error of the difference.

sections.title: Statistics and Graphs Broken Down by Other Characteristics
sections.methods_summary: Statistics were also computed and graphed by demographic characteristics (e.g., sex, ethnicity) using dummy variables and adapting the formulas for standard errors.  Respondents without the characteristic contributed to standard error calculations.

analysis.sample_description: Members of the RAND American Life Panel (ALP), a nationally representative internet panel of U.S. citizens aged 18 and older.
analysis.analysis_approach: Weighted averages were used to estimate various quantities, with standard errors calculated using StataCorp methods.  Probabilistic polling data was used to model voting behavior.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: The study used a five-phase methodology: 1) Literature Review of doctrine, ASP audit reports, and investigations; 2) Data Collection using the RAND ASP Benchmarking Tool, drawing data from SAAS-MOD, TAMIS, and WARS-NT; 3) U.S. Marine Corps Case Study to identify best practices; 4) Ammunition Community Insights gathered through a RAND-developed survey and semi-structured interviews at ten ASPs and IAMOs; 5) Final Analysis and Creation of Recommendations by combining data from information systems, the benchmarking tool, the Marine Corps case study, survey responses, and interview information.

sections.title: RAND Ammunition Supply Point Benchmarking Tool
sections.methods_summary: A benchmarking tool was developed to overcome the lack of standardized metrics.  The tool used data from multiple sources, categorized ASPs by structural and activity characteristics, calculated efficiency metrics (percentage of unforecasted requests, percentage of expended ammunition, percentage of storage capacity used, percentage of unserviceable assets, and number of annual transactions per worker), and presented results in tables for comparison.  Data were collected from ten ASPs, selected to represent a range of characteristics.  The tool also employed a 'binning' methodology to group similar ASPs for more appropriate comparisons.

sections.title: Case Study of the United States Marine Corps
sections.methods_summary: A case study of the USMC training ammunition supply chain was conducted to identify best practices.  Methods included policy analysis, interviews with USMC ammunition stakeholders, and a site visit to Camp Pendleton's ammunition supply point.

sections.title: Study Methods and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The study focused on the retail level of the supply chain (ASPs).  Data were collected through semi-structured interviews in 2011 and 2012, a survey to ASP personnel, and interviews with stakeholders.  The RAND ASP Benchmarking Tool was developed to allow comparisons of ten sample ASPs. A case study of Fort Hood was conducted, and a case study of the USMC ammunition supply chain was also performed.

analysis.sample_description: Ten CONUS-based Ammunition Supply Points (ASPs) were selected for in-depth analysis, chosen to represent a range of sizes, types of units supported, geographic locations, and personnel assignments.  A case study was also conducted on the USMC's ammunition supply chain.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative comparisons of ASP attributes were made using the RAND ASP Benchmarking Tool and five key metrics. Qualitative data from surveys and interviews provided context for understanding these comparisons.  The findings were then used to develop recommendations.

sections.title: Collaboration Surveys Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A brief collaboration survey was developed and administered electronically via email to participants in SMH collaborative activities, including members of the SMHPW and county consortia.  The survey, derived from validated surveys in existing literature, included approximately 25 Likert-rated items on a three-point scale, assessing governance, function, goals of collaborative activities; perceived improvements in SMH service delivery; challenges and facilitators to collaboration; personal participation; and group goal achievement.  Consent was obtained electronically; no incentives were offered.  Demographic information was collected but responses were not linked to identifying information.

sections.title: County Consortia Survey Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Researchers invited respondents from all 11 CCSESA regions via a stratified random sample, selecting two county consortia per region (except Region 11, which only included Los Angeles County).  The final sample included consortia from 21 counties, with 113 consortia members responding.  Demographic information was collected.  The survey assessed similar constructs as the SMHPW survey.

analysis.sample_description: The study involved two main groups: members of the Student Mental Health Policy Workgroup (SMHPW) and members of county consortia.  For the SMHPW, all 35 members were invited, with 18 responding. For the county consortia, a stratified random sample was used, resulting in 113 respondents from 21 counties.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report presents descriptive statistics summarizing responses to the survey items.  Chi-square tests were used to examine associations between certain factors and beliefs about the collaboration's impact on student mental health outcomes (e.g., the relationship between similar policy goals and improved SMH outcomes).

sections.title: Simulation Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The methodology relies on Kepler's laws, specifically Lambert's problem (rendezvous/intercept problem) and the solution to Kepler's problem to calculate interceptor launch velocity and simulate trajectories.  The universal formulation method is used for numerical solving, implemented in Matlab.  Assumptions include impulsive interceptors and missiles, no air drag, a non-rotating Earth, perfect tracking, and no countermeasures.  The endgame of interception is not modeled.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is a simulation study, not an empirical one.
analysis.analysis_approach: The simulation uses the universal formulation method to solve Lambert's and Kepler's problems, providing a first-order estimation of kinematic reach.  Several simplifying assumptions are made to reduce mathematical complexity.

sections.title: Concepts, definitions and methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines the research methodology employed in the study.  It describes the use of a cyclical model of conflict to analyze both short- and long-term preventive measures. The study conducts a structured comparative analysis of four national case studies (France, UK, US, and Germany) across conceptual, administrative/ministerial, and practical/operational levels. Data collection involved a literature review and high-level interviews with policy representatives from the four countries.  Qualitative analysis of documents and interviews is used to address key research questions.

analysis.sample_description: Four national case studies: France, the United Kingdom, the United States, and Germany.  High-level interviews with government officials and academic experts in these countries.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of policy documents (White Papers, doctrines, military concepts), interview data from government officials and experts. Comparative analysis across the four case studies to identify common challenges, trends, and best practices.

sections.title: Methodology: Reorganizing the KRG’s Ministry of Education
sections.methods_summary: Literature review of organization design; case studies of ministries of education in six countries; interviews with 10 directors general and 11 directors of the KRG Ministry of Education; workshop with the Minister of Education and his leadership team.

sections.title: Methodology: Developing a School Quality Assurance System
sections.methods_summary: Review of literature on school quality assurance and monitoring systems; reviews of school assurance systems in other countries; analysis of current approaches to quality assurance in the KRI.

sections.title: Methodology: Monitoring Quality and Encouraging Growth of Private Schools in the KRI
sections.methods_summary: Interviews with MoE officials and supervisors; review of the KRG private school law and regulations; analysis of MoE data on private schools; visits to three Kurdish and three international private schools; case studies of private school monitoring and support in ten countries and one U.S. state.

sections.title: Methodology: Assessing Teacher Training
sections.methods_summary: Interviews with officials of the General Directorate of Institutes and Training; school visits to speak with school leaders and teachers; analysis of administrative data on training programs and participants; analysis of results from a 2010 survey of teachers.

analysis.sample_description: The study included case studies of ministries of education in six countries, interviews with KRG Ministry of Education staff, visits to KRI schools (both public and private), and analysis of a 2010 survey of KRI teachers.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative data analysis methods were used, including descriptive statistics and comparisons across countries and within the KRI.

sections.title: BMT Trainee Survey Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Development of a BMT trainee survey to assess the prevalence and reporting behaviors of abuse and misconduct in five core domains: trainee bullying, maltreatment and maltraining by MTIs, unprofessional relationships with MTIs, sexual harassment, and unwanted sexual experiences.  The survey also measures perceptions of squadron climate and BMT feedback systems.  Data analysis includes creating dichotomous and ordinal variables, summed scale scores, and analysis of follow-up questions.  The methodology section also discusses excluded topics and reasons for exclusion, and details the analysis and interpretation of results, including preliminary data validation, prevalence of abuse and misconduct, follow-up questions, reporting, and perceptions of squadron climate and BMT feedback systems.

sections.title: MTI Survey Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Development of an MTI survey to complement the trainee survey, assessing MTI awareness of abuse and misconduct, perceptions of squadron climate, reporting behaviors, and policy clarity.  It also includes a section on MTI quality of life.  The methodology section details the integration of constructs from the existing MTI Quality of Life Survey (QOLS). Data analysis includes factor analysis (CFA and EFA), reliability analysis (Cronbach's alpha), and descriptive statistics.  The section also discusses excluded topics and reasons for exclusion, and details the analysis and interpretation of results, including preliminary data validation, MTI quality of life, abuse and misconduct awareness, perceptions of squadron climate, reporting norms, and policy clarity.

sections.title: Survey Participation and Administration
sections.methods_summary: Recommendations for survey administration, including participant selection (all trainees and MTIs with at least one month of experience), survey timing (end of BMT for trainees, every six months to a year for MTIs), and methods for promoting open and honest responses (anonymity, civilian administration, limited demographic questions, privacy screens).  Analysis of test survey data on attitudes toward survey timing and alternative administration conditions is presented.

sections.title: Reporting Results and Taking Action
sections.methods_summary: Recommendations for data analysis and reporting, including statistical analysis by a qualified analyst, trend tracking, triangulation with other data sources (trainee data, MTI data, general population surveys, official incident data, hotline data, chaplain data, SARC data, BMT production data, security camera surveillance), and a systematic process for reporting results to different leadership levels and stakeholders.  The process of prioritizing problem areas and setting goals for improvement, and implementing new policies and improvement plans is also discussed.

sections.title: Methodological Details on Survey Content Development
sections.methods_summary: Detailed description of the survey development process, including: (1) selection of survey content domains (based on AETC reports, DoD and AETC policies, scientific literature, and stakeholder meetings); (2) selection and development of survey measures (drawing on existing scales and developing new measures, with factor analysis used to refine scales); (3) review and refinement of draft surveys (feedback from AETC leaders, MTIs, and trainees); and (4) testing of the surveys (administration to trainees and MTIs, analysis of item and scale performance, and item reduction).

analysis.sample_description: Trainee survey: 1042 trainees (76% male, 24% female); MTI survey: 240 MTIs (67% line, 13% supervisor, 19% other).  Test surveys included larger samples.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, factor analysis (exploratory and confirmatory), reliability analysis (Cronbach's alpha), analysis of variance, trend analysis.  Data from multiple sources triangulated to provide a comprehensive understanding of the BMT environment.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Standardized case study approach. Activities included pre-site visit interviews, review of program documentation, on-site interviews with program staff, and on-site feedback sessions. Site visits occurred January through April 2014 and were coordinated through the National Guard Bureau. Interviews collected information on program background, goals, inputs, activities, outcomes, impacts, facilitators, challenges, and promising practices.  Detailed program write-ups were prepared after each site visit, forming the basis for individual program assessments and cross-program analysis.  Write-ups were coded to identify cross-cutting themes.

sections.title: Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: Standardized case study approach used to assess BYR programs in ten states.  Data collection involved pre-site visit interviews, review of program documentation, on-site interviews, and on-site feedback sessions. Site visits were coordinated by the National Guard Bureau and took place January-April 2014. Interview protocols covered program background, goals, inputs, activities, outcomes, impacts, facilitators, challenges, and promising practices.  Detailed program write-ups were created after each site visit, serving as the basis for individual program assessments and cross-program analysis. Write-ups were coded to identify cross-cutting themes.

analysis.sample_description: 13 programs in 10 states that received FY13 Beyond Yellow Ribbon (BYR) funding.  The programs were selected by the research sponsor.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of program write-ups.  Write-ups were coded to identify cross-cutting themes related to facilitators, challenges, promising practices, and areas for improvement.

sections.title: Analytical Framework and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A three-part methodology was used: 1) A limited number of interviews were conducted within the Office of the Secretary of Defense (OSD) to understand how acquisition personnel view and practice tailoring. 2) Interviews were supplemented with a literature review focusing on DoD 5000 series acquisition regulations (1975-2015). 3) A large number of program Acquisition Strategies (ASs) and Acquisition Decision Memoranda (ADMs) were examined for evidence of tailoring.  Criteria for identifying tailoring included changes from strict policy interpretation, use of 'tailoring' or 'streamlining' terms, and mention of waivers.

analysis.sample_description: Eight OSD acquisition personnel were interviewed.  58 ADMs and 60 ASs were analyzed from a larger pool of 900 ADMs and 66 ASs, respectively. The selection criteria for the analyzed ADMs and ASs focused on those showing evidence of tailoring or streamlining.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis examined the content of the interviews and documents to identify definitions of tailoring, examples of its use, challenges and constraints, and recommendations for improvement.  The analysis of ADMs and ASs focused on identifying evidence of tailoring based on pre-defined criteria.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This report integrates and extends an analysis that was originally commissioned by 13th Air Force and Headquarters Air Force Operational Planning Policy and Strategy, as well as research conducted in support of the fiscal year 2014 U.S. Air Force Scientific Advisory Board study “Defense of USAF Forward Bases.” The research described in this report was conducted within the Strategy and Doctrine Program of RAND Project AIR FORCE.

sections.title: Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Used USAF spacing guidelines to estimate parking densities as inputs for a Monte Carlo simulation to assess the vulnerability that aircraft parked in the open had to attacks by TBMs armed with unitary warheads or submunitions.

sections.title: Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Simulated attacks on four of the bases that the USAF used during ODS (Dhahran, Doha, Riyadh, and Al Kharj) and found that an attack with roughly 100 missiles could achieve a 0.9 probability of kill against aircraft parked in the open at these bases.  A 2009 RAND study of the China–Taiwan military balance conducted combat simulations of Chinese missile attacks on Taiwan’s airfields.

sections.title: Research Findings and Methodology Summary
sections.methods_summary: The research involved a historical review of air base attacks from 1914 to 2014, identifying at least 26 conflicts with such attacks.  The analysis also examined the evolution of air base defense measures, the development of a 'new American way of war' after the Cold War, and the impact of emerging long-range strike capabilities.  Modeling and simulation were used to assess optimal mixes of defensive capabilities.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample includes data from at least 26 conflicts spanning the past century, focusing on air base attacks and defensive measures employed.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach combines historical analysis of air base attacks and defenses with combat simulations and modeling to assess the effectiveness of various defensive strategies in the context of emerging threats.

sections.title: Methodology: Modeling Motorists' Responses to Toll Changes
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used to model motorists' responses to toll changes.  It includes a description of the 183/183A Travel Survey, including sample selection using license plate reader (LPR) data, survey execution (online administration, mail and phone contact, incentives), and respondent demographics.  The stated preference choice model is described, focusing on two choice experiments (value of time and departure time/route choices).  Discrete choice models (nested logit) were estimated using the survey data, separately for mandatory and nonmandatory trips.  Finally, the traffic and revenue model is explained, including its calibration using LPR data, 183A transaction data, and historical data.  The model predicts the probability of travel time and route choice under different tolling schedules.

analysis.sample_description: A random sample of 10,000 license plates from a subset of 48,982 unique license plates observed in the 183/183A corridor during the morning peak (approximately 6 a.m. to 10 a.m.) over five weekdays in November 2012.  The sample excluded vehicles registered outside nearby counties, company vehicles, and trucks.  The final survey yielded 551 completed responses (5.5% response rate).
analysis.analysis_approach: Nested logit models were estimated to predict departure time and route choice. Separate models were estimated for mandatory and nonmandatory trips. The models were calibrated to LPR data, 183A transaction data, and historical revenue data to create a traffic and revenue model that could simulate the impacts of different toll structures.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Identifying Case-Study Sites and Activities: Environmental scan (literature reviews, website analysis, semistructured interviews), discussions with 15 health departments, selection of seven sites in consultation with OSPE based on various factors (expansion status, urbanicity, region, data use, partnerships, leadership). Site Visits: Two- or three-day site visits conducted between June and October 2014 with LHD leadership, staff, and other key players using an open-ended discussion guide.  Four case studies conducted jointly by RAND and NACCHO, two by RAND alone, and one by NACCHO alone.

sections.title: Eagle, Garfield, and Pitkin Counties Case Study
sections.methods_summary: Eight meetings with representatives of the health departments' network involved in outreach and enrollment activities conducted in June 2014 by RAND and NACCHO staff.  Selection rationale: Model of public LHD engagement in a coalition and value of LHD efforts in rural areas.

analysis.sample_description: Seven case study sites selected to represent a range of models for LHD involvement in ACA outreach and enrollment, including differences in expansion status, urbanicity, region, use of public health data, participation in partnerships, and leadership by public health.  Specific focus on Eagle, Garfield, and Pitkin counties due to their model of public LHD engagement and work in a rural setting.
analysis.analysis_approach: Thematic analysis of data collected through interviews and document review to identify models of LHD involvement, facilitators and barriers, and lessons learned.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used a case study approach.  Researchers identified state and local health departments representing a range of ACA outreach and enrollment models. This involved literature reviews, website analysis, and semi-structured interviews with stakeholders.  Seven sites were selected based on various factors (expansion status, urbanicity, etc.). Site visits (2-3 days) were conducted with LHD leadership, staff, and other key players.  An open-ended discussion guide was used for interviews, focusing on implementation strategy, evaluation, sustainability, and replicability.  The West Virginia case study involved seven meetings with representatives from various organizations and attendance at a state coalition meeting.

analysis.sample_description: Seven sites were selected to represent a variety of models of LHD involvement in ACA outreach and enrollment, considering factors such as expansion status, urbanicity, region, use of public health data, participation in partnerships, and leadership by public health.  The West Virginia case study focused on the Kanawha-Charleston Health Department and its interactions with other state and local organizations.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data and documents to identify models, facilitators, barriers, and lessons learned.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Identifying Case-Study Sites and Activities: RAND researchers and NACCHO staff identified state and local health departments representing a range of models for participation in outreach and enrollment activities.  An initial environmental scan (literature reviews, website analysis, semistructured interviews) identified activities.  Discussions with key staff at 15 health departments were conducted. Seven sites were selected highlighting various models of LHD involvement.  Site Visits: Two- to three-day site visits were conducted between June and October 2014 with LHD leadership, staff, and other key players.  An open-ended discussion guide was used.  Houston Case Study: Five meetings were conducted with representatives of the health departments’ network involved in outreach and enrollment activities in October 2014.

analysis.sample_description: Seven case study sites were selected to represent a range of models of LHD involvement and contexts, reflecting differences in expansion status, urbanicity, region, use of public health data, participation of public health in partnerships, and leadership by public health.  The Houston case study focused on the Houston Department of Health and Human Services and its collaborative partners.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of data gathered through interviews and document review.  The Houston case study analyzed the implementation strategy, evaluation, sustainability, and replicability of the collaborative's approach.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A three-stage virtual workshop was conducted. Stage 1 involved individual interviews with participants to gather initial views and identify challenges and potential solutions. Stage 2 consisted of three 2.5-hour virtual group sessions to review, revise, and prioritize a consolidated list of needs. Stage 3 involved participants ranking the needs on importance and probability of success.  The Delphi method was used for prioritization. A technical appendix provides further detail.

analysis.sample_description: Experts from across the country representing survivors, victim service providers, law enforcement, prosecution, court programs, judges, statewide trafficking task forces, and researchers.  Participants had specific focus on sex trafficking and many had lived experience.
analysis.analysis_approach: Needs identified in the interviews were refined and prioritized in group sessions.  A final ranking was based on importance and probability of success scores, using a method equivalent to that in Jackson et al. (2016).  Needs were clustered into three tiers using a hierarchical clustering algorithm ('ward.D' spherical algorithm from the 'stats' library in R).

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A three-stage virtual workshop was conducted.  Stage 1 involved individual interviews with panelists to gather initial perspectives and identify knowledge gaps. Stage 2 consisted of three 2.5-hour virtual group sessions to review, revise, and prioritize a list of needs derived from the interviews. Stage 3 involved ranking the finalized list of needs based on importance and probability of success.  A more detailed description of the methodology is in the appendix.

sections.title: Appendix: Workshop Scope and Panel Selection, Identification and Prioritization of Needs
sections.methods_summary: The workshop topics were selected through consensus between NIJ action officers, subject matter experts, and research staff. Panel members were recruited through professional networks and literature review.  A multi-stage process was used: individual interviews, shorter focused virtual sessions for group refinement, and a final voting stage using Delphi techniques and a 1-9 scale for importance and probability of success.  A hierarchical clustering algorithm was used to categorize needs into three tiers.  A third round of voting allowed participants to adjust the tiering of needs.

analysis.sample_description: A panel of experts with diverse perspectives and experiences related to IPAS programs, including practitioners, criminal justice practitioners, and researchers.
analysis.analysis_approach: Needs identified were prioritized into three tiers based on importance and probability of success using a 1-9 scale and a hierarchical clustering algorithm.  A third round of voting allowed for adjustments to the initial tiering.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A workshop was convened with experts, practitioners, and stakeholders to identify prioritized recommendations.  The process, modified due to the COVID-19 pandemic, involved individual interviews followed by three group sessions using Zoom.  A preliminary list of needs, compiled from interviews, was reviewed by participants before the workshop. The Delphi method was used for ranking needs.

analysis.sample_description: The workshop participants consisted of ten police practitioners (four sworn officers and six civilian staff), two individuals from the Vera Institute of Justice, one retired journalist, and one communications consultant.
analysis.analysis_approach: Needs identified in the workshop were sorted into four themes and then ranked using the Delphi method, considering importance and probability of success.  The ranked needs were then clustered into tiers (top, middle, bottom) using a hierarchical clustering algorithm.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A three-stage virtual workshop was conducted with experts from various fields (law enforcement, academia, advocacy, civil liberties).  Stage 1 involved individual interviews to identify needs. Stage 2 involved three 2.5-hour virtual sessions to refine and prioritize needs. Stage 3 involved ranking needs based on importance and probability of success.  A Delphi method was used for prioritization.  A literature review informed participant selection and the initial list of needs.

sections.title: Technical Appendix: Workshop Scope and Panel Selection; Identification and Prioritization of Needs
sections.methods_summary: Describes the process of selecting workshop participants (literature review, networking),  the multi-stage virtual workshop design (individual interviews, group virtual sessions, voting), and the Delphi method used for prioritizing needs based on importance and probability of success.  Hierarchical clustering was used to categorize needs into three tiers.

analysis.sample_description: Experts from federal, state, and local law enforcement; academic research; mental health advocacy; and civil liberties.  32 potential participants were identified, 16 participated.
analysis.analysis_approach: Needs identified in the interviews were refined and prioritized in group sessions.  A Delphi method was used to rank needs based on importance and probability of success.  Hierarchical clustering was used to categorize needs into three tiers.

sections.title: Workshop Design and Participant Selection
sections.methods_summary: A multi-stage process was used involving individual interviews, shorter focused virtual sessions, and a final voting stage using Delphi techniques.  Participants were selected based on literature review and consultation with federal partners and known law enforcement practitioners.

sections.title: Identification and Prioritization of Needs
sections.methods_summary: A voting process based on the Delphi method was used to elicit prioritization information from the group about the identified needs.  A 1-9 scale was used for two dimensions: importance and probability of success.  A minimum variance method was used to hierarchically cluster the median expected value scores into three tiers.  A third round of voting allowed participants to adjust the tiering of needs.

analysis.sample_description: 14 workshop participants: law enforcement practitioners and experts with experience in blockchain technologies and their nexus with the criminal justice system.  Participants were recruited through professional networks and literature review.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data from interviews and virtual sessions were consolidated and categorized.  Quantitative data from Delphi voting (importance and probability of success ratings) were used to calculate median expected values and hierarchically cluster needs into three tiers.  A third round of voting refined the tiering based on participant feedback.

sections.title: Approach and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A comprehensive environmental scan was conducted involving a literature review, individual interviews with stakeholders (researchers, practitioners, and policymakers), group discussions, and iterative feedback from additional stakeholders to refine the research priorities.  The stakeholders were selected by RTI researchers in consultation with NIJ representatives and were identified through the literature review. The research priorities were categorized into three groups based on the type of issue or challenge addressed.

analysis.sample_description: The sample consisted of leading practitioners, researchers, and policymakers working in indigent defense across diverse contexts and jurisdictions in the United States.  The selection of stakeholders was informed by a literature review and consultation with NIJ representatives.
analysis.analysis_approach: The research priorities identified through the environmental scan were categorized into three groups: jurisdictional context, defense counsel, and defendant outcomes.  This categorization facilitated the analysis and organization of findings.

sections.title: Data Collection and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Survey data from a nationally representative sample of 1,479 K–12 public school teachers (48.3% completion rate) from RAND’s American Teacher Panel, administered in January and February 2024. Data weighted to be representative of the national population of teachers. Weighted descriptive means and proportions presented.  Regression analysis conducted as a robustness check.

sections.title: How We Defined the Terms Used in This Report
sections.methods_summary: Ten social and political topics were categorized into those explicitly subject to state restrictions (race, gender, sexual orientation related) and those not explicitly subject to restrictions.  Teachers were categorized as addressing topics rarely, regularly, or often based on their responses.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative sample of 1,479 K–12 public school teachers from RAND’s American Teacher Panel.  48.3% completion rate. Data weighted to be representative of the national population of teachers.
analysis.analysis_approach: Weighted descriptive means and proportions. Regression analysis used as a robustness check.  Statistical significance assessed at p < 0.05.

sections.title: Appendix A. Focus Group and Task Panel Participants and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used focus groups and task panels with AFE personnel, aircrew, leadership, and civilians.  A semistructured interview protocol was used for focus groups, while task panels reviewed a list of AFE tasks and rated them on frequency, proficiency problems, time to complete, difficulty, and training adequacy. Qualitative data were coded and analyzed to identify recurring themes and viewpoints. Inter-coder reliability was assessed using two agreement ratios (0.92 and 0.78).

sections.title: Appendix C. Exploring Skill-Level Changes over Time
sections.methods_summary: Monthly active enlisted personnel extract files (AAE) from 2000 to 2018 were used to analyze changes in skill levels over time.

sections.title: Our Approach
