sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach.  It involved reviewing Air Force personnel data, base-level trend analyses, AFI guidance, and other documentation.  The primary data collection method was qualitative discussions (focus groups and task panels) with AFE personnel at eight Air Force bases, selected to capture a wide range of views and experiences. Quantitative data were also explored but found to be insufficient for in-depth analysis.

analysis.sample_description: The study intentionally selected eight Air Force bases to include AFE personnel working with a wide range of mission design series (MDS) and across a range of Major Commands (MAJCOMs).  Participants included Regular Air Force (RegAF) personnel at various skill levels, civilians, reservists, guard personnel, aircrew (AFE customers), OSS leadership, and AFE leadership.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data from focus groups and task panels were coded and analyzed to identify recurring themes and viewpoints.  Frequency counts were used to quantify the prevalence of certain opinions.  Quantitative data were explored but were limited in scope and consistency.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources used, including medical claims data from self-insured employers, state all-payer claims databases (APCDs), and information on hospital systems and ambulatory surgical centers (ASCs).  Methods include defining price as the allowed amount, calculating standardized prices (total allowed amount divided by standardized units of service), and calculating relative prices using Medicare reimbursement as a benchmark. Quality metrics from CMS star ratings and Leapfrog Hospital Safety Grades were incorporated.  The section also discusses limitations of the study, including data representativeness and potential inaccuracies in provider identifier matching.  Medicare price simulation involved grouping services into case-mix groups and applying Medicare pricing algorithms.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from all U.S. states except Maryland, including claims from self-insured employers, state APCDs (11 states), and several state employee plans.  The data include hospital inpatient, outpatient, and non-hospital services from 2018-2020.  The sample includes approximately 1.3 million inpatient hospital stays, 12.2 million hospital outpatient services, and 798,000 ASC procedures.
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis involves calculating standardized and relative prices. Standardized prices are calculated by dividing the total allowed amount for a basket of services by the number of standardized units of service. Relative prices are calculated as the ratio of the allowed amount from private health plan claims to the Medicare allowed amount for the same services at the same hospital.  Regression analysis is used to examine the correlation between hospital market share and prices, and the relationship between hospital prices and the share of non-private insurance discharges.  The study also analyzes the relationship between hospital prices and quality metrics (CMS star ratings and Leapfrog Hospital Safety Grades).

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources used, including medical claims data from self-insured employers, all-payer claims databases (APCDs) from 12 states, and state employee plans.  It describes the process of linking hospitals to hospital systems and ambulatory surgical centers (ASCs) to ownership data.  Methods for analyzing administered drug prices and incorporating quality metrics (CMS star ratings) are explained.  The core methodology focuses on defining and calculating two types of prices: standardized prices (total allowed amount divided by standardized units of service) and relative prices (allowed amount from private health plans divided by Medicare allowed amount).  The process of simulating Medicare prices is also described, along with limitations of the study, such as data representativeness and potential inaccuracies in provider identifier matching.

sections.title: Detailed Method
sections.methods_summary: This section provides a detailed explanation of the data collection and processing procedures, including data use agreements (DUAs), data security protocols, and criteria for selecting claims. It describes the subsetting of data to include only hospital inpatient and outpatient services and community hospitals.  The definition of standardized prices and the rationale for using Medicare as a price benchmark are elaborated.  The process of simulating Medicare payment amounts for inpatient and outpatient services is detailed, including the use of MS-DRG grouper software and Integrated Outpatient Code Editor (IOCE) software. A numerical example illustrates the calculation of relative prices.

analysis.sample_description: The study used data from all U.S. states except Maryland, including claims data from self-insured employers, state all-payer claims databases (APCDs), and state employee plans.  The data covered hospital and other provider spending from 2020 to 2022. The sample included over 4,000 hospitals and over 4,000 ASCs.  The analysis included approximately 1.3 million inpatient hospital stays, 11.2 million hospital outpatient services, and 1.2 million ASC procedures.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis focused on calculating and comparing two types of prices: standardized prices (average allowed amount per standardized unit of service) and relative prices (actual private insurer allowed amount divided by the Medicare allowed amount for the same services at the same hospital).  Medicare's pricing algorithms were used to simulate Medicare payments.  Regression analysis was used to examine the relationship between hospital prices and factors such as quality, patient composition, and market share.

sections.title: Research Approach and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study was structured around three analytical Work Packages (WPs): WP1 (Project Inception and Scoping) involved data collection and initial analysis to understand challenges and threats concerning human rights and fundamental freedoms in the digital age and to take stock of existing capacity-building interventions. WP2 (Identifying and Selecting Interventions) comprehensively identified and mapped interventions on HURDA, collecting data on potential impact, benefits, limitations, barriers, and enablers. WP3 (Final Analysis and Reporting) consolidated the evidence base, gathered expert and stakeholder perspectives, and produced recommendations.  Data collection included a limited number of key informant interviews (16 interviewees from academia, government, international organizations, and civil society) and a Systematic Technology Reconnaissance, Evaluation, and Adoption Methodology (STREAM) workshop.  The study focused on capacity-building interventions and acknowledged limitations due to the limited timeframe and resources.

analysis.sample_description: Sixteen interviewees from academia, government, international organizations, and civil society.  Participants in a STREAM workshop (number unspecified).
analysis.analysis_approach: Three work packages, data triangulation (combining interview data with publicly available literature), comparative analysis of interventions using a STREAM scoring exercise.

sections.title: Study Objective and Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study aimed to identify and evaluate alternative disability compensation structures feasible under a Fitness-for-Duty Evaluation System (FES).  Four alternatives were developed and evaluated by comparing benefits under each alternative with benefits under the current system.  The study also examined effects on personnel readiness and costs, and discussed legal and policy implications. Data came from the Veterans’ Tracking Application (VTA) database and Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC).

sections.title: Approach for Estimating the Change in the Net Department of Defense Disability Benefit Under Alternatives
sections.methods_summary: For Alternatives 1 and 2, the study used simulations based on the 2019 pay table and disability benefit formulas, supplemented by data from DMDC and VTA.  Alternative 1a compared transition benefits with RMC. Alternative 2a used RAND's dynamic retention model (DRM) to estimate the value of a lost military career.  For Alternative 3, the study analyzed variation in ratings assigned to conditions using ANOVA and simulated changes in compensation if a fixed payment were used.  Alternative 4 combined analyses from Alternatives 2 and 3 and considered differences in disability and healthcare systems between the US and its allies.

sections.title: Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: Data sources included the 2019 pay table and disability benefit formulas (Alternatives 1 & 2), RAND's DRM (Alternative 2a), and an analytic file integrating data from the Retiree Pay file, ADP file, DEERS file, ADM files, and VTA header and condition files (Alternatives 1 & 2, Chapter 5, Chapter 7).  For Alternative 3 and Chapter 5 analyses, the study used VTA data on service members referred to the IDES from 2012-2018.

sections.title: Results: Estimating the Change in the Net Department of Defense Disability Benefit Under Alternatives
sections.methods_summary: The study analyzed changes in net monthly DoD disability benefits under each alternative, considering variations in grade, YOS, family composition, DoD rating, VA rating, and VA combat-related disability rating.  Specific methods included comparing transition benefits to RMC (Alternative 1a), using the DRM to estimate lost career value (Alternative 2a), analyzing rating variation within VASRD codes (Alternative 3), and combining analyses from Alternatives 2 and 3 (Alternative 4).  The analysis also used ANOVA to assess variation in ratings within and between conditions (Alternative 3).

sections.title: Implications of a Fitness-for-Duty Evaluation System on Processing Time, End Strength, and Human Capital Loss
sections.methods_summary: The study used VTA data from 2018 to estimate the reduction in IDES processing time under a FES by comparing the duration of the ratings step in the IDES.  It then used service-specific models to estimate the reduction in active-duty members in the IDES under a FES.  To assess human capital loss, the study analyzed the grade, YOS, and occupations of discharged service members.  The cost-effectiveness of restoring end strength was evaluated by simulating the effects of pay raises, reenlistment bonuses, and increased accessions using RAND's DRM, considering recruiting and training costs.

analysis.sample_description: The study used various samples depending on the analysis.  Key samples included: all service members medically discharged in FY 2015 (Chapter 2, Appendix B); service members referred to the IDES in 2012-2018 with a single unfitting condition (Alternative 3, Appendix C); and service members in the IDES on September 30, 2018 (Chapter 5).
analysis.analysis_approach: The study used a combination of quantitative and qualitative methods.  Quantitative methods included simulations, regression analysis, ANOVA, and the DRM.  Qualitative methods included a review of prior proposals, U.S. civilian systems, and systems used by U.S. allies.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: An environmental scan of available literature from peer-reviewed sources and gray literature (consumer advocacy groups, research organizations, state and federal agencies) was conducted.  The scan covered four healthcare markets: health care professionals, hospitals and facilities, pharmaceuticals, and medical devices.  For each market, information was gathered on ten key policy issues related to cost and quality transparency, grouped into three broad topics: price setting, influences on consumer price and quality transparency, and the relationship between price, quality, and advertising. A targeted literature search was conducted using PubMed, Business Source Complete, and EconLit databases, supplemented by gray literature and snowball searching.  The initial search yielded 1,095 articles, with an additional 56 from gray literature.  Research assistants conducted an initial triage, identifying 197 peer-reviewed and 56 gray literature articles as potentially relevant. The research team reviewed and abstracted information from 113 articles.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consisted of peer-reviewed and gray literature articles related to price and quality transparency in four healthcare markets.
analysis.analysis_approach: The researchers conducted a targeted literature search, triaged articles based on title and abstract, and abstracted information from relevant articles.  The results were summarized in the context of three categories: price setting, influences on consumer price and quality transparency, and the relationship between price, quality, and advertising.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research involved a review of DHS policy documents, research literature, and existing guidance on inclusive language.  A series of interviews were conducted with representatives of populations under DHS jurisdiction using convenience sampling to identify trusted messengers within the community.  Interview data was coded based on a protocol.  The study also included automated and manual searches for publicly available inclusive language guidance from other organizations.

analysis.sample_description: Convenience sampling of 15 individuals representing nine different organizations that interact with DHS.  The organizations represented individuals across the racial, national, religious, and social group spectrum.
analysis.analysis_approach: Interview data was coded based on protocol questions.  The literature review involved searching scholarly databases and grey literature, initially yielding 5165 references, narrowed down to 120 relevant sources after removing duplicates and irrelevant publications.  The study also involved manual searches and scanning of reference lists to supplement the database searches.

sections.title: Strengths and Limitations of Administrative Data for the Study of Chronic Pain
sections.methods_summary: This section discusses the advantages and disadvantages of using administrative data for chronic pain research.  It details limitations such as incomplete capture of over-the-counter medications and alternative therapies, lack of detailed encounter information, and absence of patient-reported outcome measures.  It also explores different approaches to defining chronic pain using administrative data, including using diagnosis codes (ICD-9/ICD-10) and treatment receipt (e.g., opioid analgesics).  The section reviews various strategies employed in prior research to identify individuals with chronic pain, comparing their strengths and weaknesses.  It highlights the challenges in determining the duration of pain conditions and the lack of a universally accepted approach to defining chronic pain using administrative data.

sections.title: How Can the Quality of Chronic Pain Treatment Be Assessed Using Administrative Data?
sections.methods_summary: This section focuses on assessing the quality of chronic pain treatment using administrative data. It discusses challenges in quality measurement for chronic pain, including limited evidence on effective treatment modalities, evolving treatment guidelines, narrow scope of existing quality metrics, and the importance of measuring functional status and shared decision-making.  It explores common approaches and challenges, such as defining the assessment period, specifying treatments to be included, accounting for the stage of chronic pain treatment and patient churn, and considering the differences between direct and private-sector care data within the Military Health System (MHS).

sections.title: Research Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the research methodology.  The authors used targeted searches of peer-reviewed literature (PubMed) and gray literature, including DoD reports, to identify relevant studies on chronic pain among active-duty U.S. service members.  The analysis draws lessons from prior studies using MHS administrative data and the civilian literature on measuring chronic pain treatment quality using administrative data from health care claims and EHR databases.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consists of existing research and data on chronic pain treatment in both military and civilian settings, primarily using administrative data from the Military Health System (MHS) and other sources.
analysis.analysis_approach: The authors conducted a qualitative analysis of existing literature and data to identify approaches to identifying patients with chronic pain and measuring the quality of their care.  They compared different strategies used in prior research and discussed their strengths and limitations.

sections.title: Appendix: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data collection methods used in the study, including feedback forms and interviews.  Feedback form data are described, including response rates and limitations. Interview data collection is explained, including the number of interviews conducted and the types of respondents.  Data analysis techniques are also described, including iterative coding, memoing, analytic matrices, and descriptive analyses. Triangulation of data across multiple sources is mentioned to enhance validity.

primary_methods: Qualitative Data Analysis (Iterative coding, memoing, analytic matrices)
analysis.sample_description: Feedback forms were administered to individuals who engaged with CISELSS (response rates varied by year). Interviews were conducted with CISELSS staff, external partners, and technical assistance recipients (n=37 total).
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive analyses were used for feedback form data. Interview data were analyzed through iterative coding, memoing, and analytic matrices to identify patterns.  Triangulation of data across multiple sources was used to enhance validity.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology employed in the study.  It used an embedded, illustrative case study design. Data collection involved in-depth, semi-structured interviews (n=41) with CISELSS leadership and staff, partner organizations, and Tier 2 and 3 technical assistance recipients. Purposive sampling was used to select participants with in-depth knowledge and diverse perspectives.  The timing of data collection allowed for analysis of capacity building over time.  Data analysis involved iterative coding, memoing, and analytic matrices using Dedoose software.  Triangulation of data from multiple sources was used to enhance validity.  The study also utilized feedback form data (n=24 in FY2023) from individuals who received Tier 2 or 3 support.  Descriptive analyses were used to summarize feedback form responses.  Limitations of the sampling approach and interview data, as well as limitations of the feedback form data (anonymous responses, low response rate, inability to link responses to specific individuals or organizations) are discussed.

primary_methods: Qualitative data analysis (iterative coding, memoing, analytic matrices)
analysis.sample_description: The sample included CISELSS leadership and staff, leaders of partner organizations, and recipients of Tier 2 and 3 supports. Purposive sampling was used to select participants with in-depth knowledge and diverse perspectives, including representation from each collaborative and a variety of states and organizations.  The feedback form data included responses from individuals who engaged in Tier 2 or Tier 3 supports in FY2023 (n=24).
analysis.analysis_approach: Interview data were analyzed through iterative coding, memoing, and the use of analytic matrices to identify patterns.  Feedback form data were analyzed using simple descriptive analyses. Triangulation across multiple data sources was used to enhance the validity of findings.

sections.title: Project Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research involved reviewing academic literature and USAF documents, and conducting interviews with subject-matter experts in the USAF, other U.S. military services, and the private sector.  The goal was to identify elements leading to successful technology-enabled talent management transformation.

analysis.sample_description: The study included subject matter experts from the USAF, Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and private sector (vendors, consultants, and end-users of HR software).  The private sector sample was not representative of all organizations undergoing digital transformation, and was limited by the unwillingness of large corporations to participate.
analysis.analysis_approach: The researchers identified key insights from interviews and document reviews.  No specific statistical analysis is mentioned.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Three methods were used: 1. Interviews with subject-matter experts in programming technology-enabled HRM and related initiatives in the DAF and other services; 2. Reviews of previous initiatives for lessons learned; 3. Examination of PPBE processes with a focus on attributes that place technology-enabled HRM initiatives at risk when competing with other initiatives.

analysis.sample_description: Subject matter experts in the Department of the Air Force and other services; previous initiatives for technology-enabled HRM; PPBE processes.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data and document reviews; descriptive analysis of PPBE processes to identify risk factors for technology-enabled HRM initiatives.

sections.title: Study Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study uses a futures-focused assessment centered around three logically consistent scenarios.  The methodology involved a literature review, scenario development using hierarchical cluster analysis, expert interviews (27 interviewees: 18 European, 9 US), and an internal expert workshop to synthesize findings and identify policy options.

sections.title: Future Scenarios Methodology: Detailed Explanation
sections.methods_summary: This section details the five steps of the scenario methodology: 1) Identification of factors influencing European strategic autonomy; 2) Shortlisting of factors through influence analysis (quantitative scoring by four team members, resolving discrepancies through discussion); 3) Application of projections to shortlisted factors (literature review and internal workshop); 4) Engagement with experts to identify consistent projections (quantitative consistency matrix scoring by six experts, resolving discrepancies through team discussion and expert review); 5) Generation of scenario narratives from consistent projection clusters using scenario software.

sections.title: Interview Approach
sections.methods_summary: Interviews with 27 senior experts (18 European, 9 US) were conducted between January and March 2021 (plus one in June).  An interview protocol was used (see Box C), and summary notes were taken and entered into an analysis matrix to capture high-level themes.

analysis.sample_description: 27 senior interviewees from across the transatlantic community (government, EU, NATO, academia, and think tanks). 18 based in Europe, 9 in the US.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data, synthesis of findings through internal expert workshop, and development of policy options based on the combined evidence base.

sections.title: Study Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the recruitment strategies (street outreach, non-VA service referrals, veteran outreach), eligibility criteria (self-reported living status for >15/30 nights in unsheltered locations, veteran status verified via VA records), data collection methods (longitudinal in-person and phone interviews, ecological momentary assessment (EMA) pilot, COVID-19 assessment surveys and interviews), measures used (K6, MCSI, PC-PTSD, substance use measures, quality of life measures, physical health measures, victimization measures, system involvement measures, health care utilization measures), follow-up tracking procedures (tracking and locating form, reminder cards and incentives, field staff practices), and data analysis techniques (quantitative descriptive and mixed-effects regression models with imputation for missing data, qualitative thematic analysis using ATLAS.ti).

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consisted of 26 veterans experiencing homelessness in West Los Angeles, recruited between August 6 and September 9, 2019, using street outreach, referrals from homeless service staff, and VA outreach events.  The sample was diverse in terms of age, gender, race/ethnicity, military service experience, and length of time experiencing homelessness.  A comparison with the 2019 Point-In-Time Count data is provided to highlight differences in demographic characteristics.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative data analysis involved descriptive statistics and mixed-effects regression models to examine the relationship between stable housing and various outcomes. Missing data were imputed using a random selection method. Qualitative data analysis employed a thematic analysis approach using ATLAS.ti software, involving coding, theme development, and consensus-building among researchers.

sections.title: Study Methods and Approach
sections.methods_summary: 1. Literature review of refugee returns; 2. 15 interviews with global experts, multilateral officials, national officials, and NGO leaders; 3. Analysis of cross-national trends in refugee returns over 30 years from 53 case studies; 4. Case studies of refugee returns in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, and the Kurdistan Region–Iraq, including in-depth interviews and focus groups with 105 returnees, refugees, and IDPs, and interviews with 30 stakeholders.

sections.title: An Approach to Measuring Postconflict Refugee Return
sections.methods_summary: Defines three dimensions to measure post-conflict refugee return: 1. Conflict termination (using UCDP Georeferenced Event Dataset to define when annual battle-related deaths fall below 1000 for two consecutive years); 2. Measurement period (10 years after conflict ends, labeled Y0-Y10); 3. Metrics of return (cumulative returns as a percentage of cumulative refugee population using UNHCR data from 1989-2018).  Excludes cases with fewer than 1000 refugees at conflict end or cumulative refugees below 10,000 in the 10-year period. Analysis includes 53 cases.

sections.title: Appendix B: In-Depth Interviews and Focus Groups
sections.methods_summary: Focus groups and in-depth interviews conducted in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, and the Kurdistan Region of Iraq.  Initially planned in-person focus groups were converted to virtual groups due to the COVID-19 pandemic. One-on-one interviews were also conducted in person or by phone to ensure inclusivity.  Ipsos conducted interviews in local languages, translated transcriptions, and transmitted them to RAND for analysis.  Participants were recruited by Ipsos using criteria developed by the RAND team, and provided with incentives.

sections.title: Study Methods
sections.methods_summary: Literature review, interviews with global experts and government/multilateral officials, analysis of cross-national trends in displacement and returns over 30 years, analysis of UNHCR data on 53 postconflict return cases, case studies in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, and the Kurdistan Region–Iraq (including focus groups and discussions with 105 returnees, refugees, and IDPs, and interviews with other stakeholders).

analysis.sample_description: The study included 15 interviews with global experts and government/multilateral officials, analysis of UNHCR data on 53 postconflict return cases, and case studies in three regions (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, and the Kurdistan Region–Iraq) involving focus groups and interviews with 105 returnees, refugees, and IDPs, and interviews with 30 stakeholders.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved examining cross-national trends in displacement and returns over 30 years, developing a new way of measuring returns, and analyzing commonalities and differences across the case studies.

sections.title: Expert Interviews Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Semi-structured interviews with 11 experts (3 architects, 1 structural engineer, 1 market-rate developer, 1 Northern California developer, 2 Los Angeles affordable housing developers, 3 Northern California affordable housing developers) conducted between February and October 2021.  Interviews lasted 30-60 minutes and were transcribed.  Thematic analysis was used to identify key takeaways.

sections.title: Quantitative Data Analysis Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study uses CoStar data on commercial real estate (CRE) properties in Los Angeles County, supplemented by U.S. Census data (NHGIS, LODES), Los Angeles County Assessor data, and open data portals for the City and County of Los Angeles and LA METRO.  Two regression models were used to analyze cost differences between adaptive reuse (AR) and new construction projects for affordable housing.  A separate analysis compares sale prices of CRE and multiunit housing across three submarkets to assess AR feasibility. Spatial analysis overlays CRE data onto maps of different geographic definitions (City of Los Angeles, Los Angeles County, and rail transit service areas) to examine the spatial distribution of underutilized CRE relative to social and environmental goals. A socioeconomic index (SEI) was created to rank areas based on median gross rent, commute time, and employment density.

sections.title: Data Collection and Sample Definition
sections.methods_summary: Primary data source is CoStar, supplemented by US Census data and other public data sources.  The sample is limited to underutilized commercial real estate (CRE) in Los Angeles County, defined as: class B and C office and retail properties (10,000-100,000 sq ft) with vacancy rates of 20% or more; and economy hotels/motels.  Two scenarios are presented for estimating potential housing units from CRE: one assuming a mix of studio, one-bedroom, and two-bedroom units, and another assuming only studio units.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses three types of commercial properties: hotels/motels, retail, and office.  The sample is limited to underutilized properties in Los Angeles County, defined by specific criteria for each property type (see methods summary above).  A smaller subset focuses on the City of Los Angeles and four adjacent municipalities.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis using regression models and price comparisons, qualitative analysis of expert interviews, and spatial analysis using a socioeconomic index.

sections.title: Salary and Benefit Comparison Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: Compared Army and civilian experience and compensation profiles for civil service occupations using data from DCPDS and a Census Bureau crosswalk.  Aligned federal occupations with private-sector counterparts. Analyzed average salary and total compensation, comparing Army data with private sector, non-profit, and state/local government data.

sections.title: Analysis of Prospective Hiring Needs Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: Used the RAND Inventory Model (RIM) to project Army hiring needs by occupation over the next ten years.  RIM estimates new hires needed based on separation rates from historical data. Assumed average unemployment rate of 4.9% and constant workforce size and grade structure. Compared projected hiring needs with average hiring over FYs 2015-2018. Compared current experience distribution with projected distribution if current trends continued.

sections.title: Exploring Army Online Marketing to Civilian Job-Seekers Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: Focused on four mission-critical occupations. Identified Army commands and locations with high concentrations of civilian employees in those occupations. Recorded how civilian employment was marketed on command and location websites. Explored job-seeker websites (USAJOBS, LinkedIn, Facebook, Monster) for Army civilian job marketing information.

sections.title: Exploring Army Online Marketing to Civilian Job-Seekers Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: Focused on four mission-critical occupations. Identified Army commands and locations with high concentrations of civilian employees in those occupations. Recorded how civilian employment was marketed on command and location websites. Explored job-seeker websites (USAJOBS, LinkedIn, Facebook, Monster) for Army civilian job marketing information.

sections.title: Overall Research Approach and Major Findings
sections.methods_summary: The research involved three major categories of findings: (1) findings about the external market (surveys of job preferences, job search activities, awareness of Army civilian jobs, perceptions of Army civilian jobs, and concerns about Army civilian jobs); (2) findings about what the Army has to offer (focus groups and interviews with current Army civilian employees, data on working conditions, and compensation comparisons with the private sector); and (3) findings about requirements (inventory modeling of workforce size and composition over the next decade).

sections.title: Survey Questionnaire for Qualitative Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Semi-structured online questionnaire administered to professionals and students.  Open-ended and closed-ended questions covered job preferences, job search activities, awareness and perceptions of Army civilian employment, and concerns about Army civilian jobs.  Follow-up questions were asked to a subsample of participants.

sections.title: Survey Used in Quantitative Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Online survey administered to professionals and students.  Closed-ended questions (with some open-ended questions and interactive features) covered demographics, job characteristics, job satisfaction, job search methods, perceptions of Army civilian jobs, and concerns about Army civilian jobs. MaxDiff analysis used for job characteristic preferences.  Data cleaning procedures used to remove low-quality responses.

analysis.sample_description: The study involved both qualitative and quantitative data collection.  Qualitative data came from semi-structured interviews and focus groups with current Army civilian employees and a smaller sample of students and professionals. Quantitative data came from a larger online survey of students and professionals (with separate samples for younger and older professionals).  Samples were designed to include representation across four key occupations (Civil Engineers, Electronics Engineers, Contracting Specialists, and IT Managers).
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data were analyzed to identify themes and patterns in respondents' perceptions of Army civilian employment. Quantitative data were analyzed using descriptive statistics, correlation analysis, regression analysis, and factor analysis to examine relationships between variables such as job preferences, awareness of Army civilian jobs, perceptions of Army civilian jobs, and concerns about Army civilian jobs.  MaxDiff analysis was used to scale job characteristics.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The RAND Corporation administered the American Instructional Resources Survey (AIRS) to a nationally representative sample of American Teacher Panel (ATP) and American School Leader Panel (ASLP) participants in K–12 schools, as well as state-representative samples of ATP teachers in 12 states.  The survey aimed to gather information on curricula used in ELA, math, and science, the extent of modification, and the support teachers received.  The methodology section details the survey development, participant demographics, response rates, and data analysis techniques, including the categorization of curriculum alignment based on EdReports ratings and the creation of teacher curriculum use profiles.  Scale reliabilities are reported, and subgroup comparisons are outlined.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative sample of ATP and ASLP participants in K–12 schools, plus state-representative samples of ATP teachers in 12 states (including IMPD Network states).  Table 1 summarizes national and state-level response rates. Table 2 provides descriptive characteristics for both the ATP and ASLP.
analysis.analysis_approach: Categorization of curriculum alignment based on EdReports ratings. Creation of four mutually exclusive teacher curriculum use profiles (By-the-Book, Modifier, DIY, Cobbler). Construction of measures for student engagement in standards-aligned classroom practices, evaluative feedback, frequency of professional learning, and helpfulness of professional learning.  Regression analyses were used to examine relationships between variables. Subgroup comparisons were conducted across subject area, grade level, state (IMPD Network states), and school poverty level (FRPL enrollment quartiles).

sections.title: Study Design and Sampling
sections.methods_summary: The study used the RAND American Educator Panels (AEP), consisting of nationally representative samples of teachers, school leaders, and district leaders.  Probabilistic sampling methods were used for recruitment since 2014.  The 2021 American Instructional Resources Surveys (AIRS) were administered to a sample of AEP members (teachers and school leaders) in spring 2021.  Specific sampling targets were set for the number of completed surveys in different states to balance precision, sample availability, and costs.  The survey screened out teachers not currently teaching ELA, mathematics, or science.  A revised survey was sent to special education teachers inadvertently screened out initially. No screen-ins were possible.

sections.title: Data Weighting and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The 2021 AIRS includes weights to ensure the sample reflects the national population of teachers and principals.  The weighting process accounts for selection probability and response likelihood, calibrated to match population distributions at national and state levels.  Three interim weights were calculated: 1) calibrated weight of the ATP/ASLP sampling frame; 2) sample selection weight (inverse probability of selection); and 3) survey response weight (inverse of modeled probability of completion).  These weights were recalibrated and trimmed to address outliers. The weights facilitate cross-sectional analysis but are not designed for longitudinal analysis.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative samples of K-12 teachers and school leaders from the RAND American Educator Panels (AEP). Oversampling in 16 states.  Sample size of 7,217 teachers and 1,757 school leaders.
analysis.analysis_approach: Weighted descriptive statistics were used to analyze the survey data.  The weights were designed to produce estimates that reflect the national population of public school teachers and principals and state-specific populations in 16 oversampled states.

sections.title: How We Defined Use of Standards-Aligned Curriculum Materials
sections.methods_summary: Surveyed teachers on curriculum materials used regularly (once a week or more).  Used EdReports ratings to code materials as fully, partially, or not standards-aligned.  Assigned teachers a single best-case rating based on the highest rating received across all materials used.

sections.title: How This Analysis Was Conducted
sections.methods_summary: Used teacher responses from the American Instructional Resources Survey (AIRS) in 2019, 2020, and 2021 (n=4,447, 4,494, and 5,425 respectively).  Matched teacher responses to EdReports ratings.  In 2021 AIRS, teachers also reported on digital availability of materials. Pairwise t-tests used for statistical significance across subgroups (p=0.05). No formal significance testing between years due to lack of longitudinal weights.

sections.title: Research Methods
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of open-source information on 65 potential or actual Russian advanced conventional arms sales involving 33 countries.  A database of over 5,500 entries of publicly available information (July 2017-May 2021) was compiled.  Case studies of three countries were conducted to illustrate challenges and prospects of using third-party sanctions.

analysis.sample_description: For the education document: Nationally representative samples of teachers from the American Educator Panels (AEP) and state-representative samples from 13 states in the IMPD Network.  For the arms sales document: 65 cases of Russian arms sales to 33 countries, based on open-source data.
analysis.analysis_approach: For the education document:  Descriptive statistics, comparison of means across groups, and regression analysis (mentioned but not detailed). For the arms sales document: Case study analysis of selected countries to illustrate the impact of sanctions and diplomatic efforts on Russian arms sales.

sections.title: How This Analysis Was Conducted
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data source (2021 American Instructional Resources Survey (AIRS) with 7,217 K–12 public school teachers), data used (items relating to anti-bias education, teachers' perceptions of materials, importance placed on material characteristics, professional learning, and preparation programs), comparisons made (across school and teacher characteristics), and analysis of open-ended responses (keyword generation, categorization, matching with demographic data).  Statistical significance testing using t-tests (p<0.05) is mentioned, and the robustness of findings was checked using regression models controlling for school and teacher characteristics.  Unadjusted descriptive results are presented in the report.

analysis.sample_description: 7,217 K–12 public school teachers from the 2021 American Instructional Resources Survey (AIRS).  The sample included early childhood/general elementary teachers and departmentalized ELA, math, or science teachers.  Social studies teachers were not included, potentially underestimating anti-bias education prevalence, especially at the secondary level.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics were used to compare teacher responses across various school and teacher characteristics.  Open-ended responses were analyzed using qualitative methods, including keyword identification and categorization.  T-tests were used to assess statistical significance (p<0.05). Regression models were used to check the robustness of findings by controlling for school and teacher characteristics.  The report presents unadjusted descriptive results.

sections.title: Overview of the Methods and Organization of This Report
sections.methods_summary: The study uses a mixed-methods approach.  Chapter Two uses documentation and interviews with state officials and CCSSO staff to describe IMPD Network strategies. Chapter Three uses data from the spring 2021 American Instructional Resources Survey (AIRS) to analyze standards-aligned material adoption, use, and supports.  AIRS surveyed nationally representative samples of K–12 principals and teachers, along with state-representative samples of teachers in IMPD Network states.  Additional methodological details are provided in Chapter Three and the AIRS technical documentation.

sections.title: Standards-Aligned Material Adoption, Use, Buy-In, and Supports
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the ten indicators used to assess adoption, use, buy-in, and supports of standards-aligned materials.  Data comes from the 2021 AIRS, which surveyed ELA and math teachers.  The indicators include measures of school/district adoption, principal support, professional learning participation, teacher buy-in (perceived adequacy of materials), and teacher use (regular and intensive).  The methodology for determining each indicator is detailed, including how standards alignment was determined using EdReports ratings and how Likert scales and other response formats were used.  Analysis uses teacher self-reports, acknowledging potential self-report bias.  Pairwise t-tests are used for comparisons, but formal significance testing across years is not done due to limitations in longitudinal survey weights and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

sections.title: Connecting Supports with Teachers’ Use of Standards-Aligned Materials
sections.methods_summary: Teachers are categorized into four conditions based on IMPD Network participation and adoption of standards-aligned materials.  The study examines how these conditions relate to use and supports for materials.  Multinomial logistic regression models are used to analyze the relationships between supports, use, and the four conditions, controlling for school characteristics and teacher demographics.  The results are presented in tables summarizing the direction and significance of relationships.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative samples of K–12 teachers (ELA, math, science) and principals; state-representative samples of teachers in IMPD Network states (and California, Florida, New York, Washington).  Focus on ELA and math teachers in this report.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, comparisons of IMPD Network states to national averages using t-tests, multinomial logistic regression to examine relationships between supports, use of standards-aligned materials, and IMPD Network participation/material adoption status.

sections.title: Survey Administration and Content; Survey Completion Results; Calibrated Weighting
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology of the 2022 American Instructional Resources Surveys (AIRS).  It describes the probabilistic sampling methods used to recruit participants from the American Educator Panels (AEP), including the target sample sizes for teachers and principals and the oversampling of specific states.  The survey administration process, including the survey length and branching logic based on respondent characteristics, is explained.  The section also covers the weighting process used to adjust for nonresponse and ensure the sample reflects the national population of teachers and principals.  Finally, it discusses the survey completion rates for both teachers and principals.

analysis.sample_description: The 2022 AIRS used the RAND American Educator Panels (AEP), which includes nationally representative samples of K-12 public school educators and leaders.  The teacher sample aimed for 7900 completed surveys, with 400 completed surveys in each of 16 oversampled states and 1500 across the remaining states. The principal sample aimed for 1500 completed surveys nationally.  Oversampled states included those participating in the CCSSO IMPD Network and other states of funder interest (California, Florida, New York).
analysis.analysis_approach: The final analysis weights are a product of three interim weights: calibrated weight of the ATP/ASLP sampling frame, sample selection weight, and survey response weight.  These weights were recalibrated and trimmed to ensure representative sample and limit design effect.  Replicate weights were not produced; variance estimation using the provided single weight was deemed sufficient.

sections.title: How This Analysis Was Conducted
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources (2022 American Instructional Resources Survey [AIRS]), specific survey items used, and the calculation of key metrics (e.g., percentage of teachers using new materials).  It describes the weighting of data for national representation and the use of pairwise t-tests for comparisons.  Analysis of open-ended responses is also described, including the coding process by research assistants.

sections.title: Definitions of Key Terms Used in this Report
sections.methods_summary: This section defines key terms used in the analysis, such as 'instructional materials,' 'curriculum materials,' 'supplemental materials,' and 'standards-aligned curriculum.'  The definition of standards-aligned curriculum clarifies the use of EdReports ratings in the analysis.

analysis.sample_description: Data from 6,399 ELA and mathematics teachers from the 2022 AIRS.  The AIRS uses the RAND Corporation’s American Educator Panels (AEP) to access nationally representative samples of K–12 teachers.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis focuses on sample-wide and subgroup-specific means and proportions of variables, weighted using nationally representative weights. Pairwise t-tests (p=0.05) were used to test statistical significance across subgroups.  Open-ended responses were analyzed through a coding process involving multiple research assistants to ensure reliability.

sections.title: Pilot Test Methods
sections.methods_summary: A pilot test of eGTO was conducted with three VSOs (Veteran Service Organizations). Data collection involved an online survey using the Post-Study System Usability Questionnaire (PSSUQ) and semi-structured discussions with VSO representatives.  The PSSUQ assessed satisfaction with the system's usability.  Discussions focused on ease of use, actions taken within eGTO, time spent on each step, and helpfulness of instructions.  Rapid qualitative analysis was used to analyze discussion notes.

analysis.sample_description: Three VSOs participated in the pilot test, with two participants from each VSO (total of six participants).  Descriptive information about each VSO is provided in Table 2. Four of the six participants completed the online survey.
analysis.analysis_approach: For the PSSUQ, means, standard deviations, and ranges were calculated for each scale (system usefulness, information quality, interface quality) and individual items.  For the interviews, rapid qualitative analysis was conducted, summarizing detailed notes using domains from the interview questions.  A summary of key points from each meeting across all three VSOs was drafted and agreed upon by the authors.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The analysis uses data from the five-year 2022 extract of the American Community Survey (ACS).  A veteran household is defined as one where the head of household or spouse is a veteran.  Specific clarifications are given for households with active military members and unmarried partners. Descriptive statistics are used to compare veteran and non-veteran households across various demographic and socioeconomic characteristics.

sections.title: APPENDIX A: Data and Methods Deep Dive
sections.methods_summary: This section details the American Community Survey (ACS) data used, including its design as a nationally representative annual survey of 3.5 million households.  It explains the use of five-year extracts for improved statistical efficiency.  The section describes the variables of interest (veteran status, era of service, labor force participation, marital status, income) and how household-level data are used, including the definition of household head and how household characteristics are determined.  It also details the methodology for determining when couples married relative to military service, including handling of missing data and complexities in assigning marriage timing to service eras.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the 2018-2022 five-year extract of the American Community Survey (ACS), a nationally representative survey of 3.5 million U.S. households.  The analysis focuses on veteran households, defined as those where the head of household or spouse is a veteran.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics are used to compare veteran and non-veteran households across various demographic and socioeconomic characteristics, including household composition, marital status, presence of children, race/ethnicity, age, employment, and income.  The analysis also explores the timing of marriages relative to military service.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used three data sources: the Current Population Survey Food Security Supplement (CPS-FSS) from 2015-2020 to characterize food-insecure veterans and nonveterans and their SNAP participation, using descriptive statistics and covariate-adjusted regression models; the SNAP Policy Database to identify factors associated with SNAP use, including state-level policies, using regression analysis; and the Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP) from 2013 and 2019 to explore reasons for SNAP enrollment, ending participation, or losing benefits, and differences in benefits received, using descriptive statistics and a negative binomial regression model for duration of SNAP participation.  All analyses used weights provided by the Census Bureau to ensure national representativeness.

sections.title: APPENDIX A: Data Sources, Measures, and Analytic Methods
sections.methods_summary: This appendix details the methodology for each data source.  For CPS-FSS data, it describes the use of pooled data (2015-2020), descriptive statistics, and logistic regression models to examine associations between individual-level characteristics and SNAP enrollment.  It also explains the incorporation of SNAP Policy Database data to analyze state-level policies' influence on SNAP participation. For SIPP data (pooled 2013 and 2019), it describes the use of descriptive statistics and a negative binomial regression model to analyze reasons for SNAP enrollment, program participation, and duration of SNAP participation.  The appendix also defines key variables like veteran status and food insecurity for both datasets, and outlines the covariates used in the analyses.

analysis.sample_description: The study used pooled data from the CPS-FSS (2015-2020) and SIPP (2013 and 2019) to increase sample sizes of food-insecure veterans.  The CPS-FSS is a nationally representative survey of households, while SIPP is a nationally representative longitudinal survey.  Neither survey is fully representative of the veteran population.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics were used to characterize the samples and explore relationships between variables.  Logistic regression was used to model the probability of SNAP enrollment, controlling for individual and state-level factors.  Negative binomial regression was used to model the duration of SNAP participation among food-insecure veterans.

sections.title: Regression Model for Homeownership
sections.methods_summary: A basic regression model was estimated to examine the relationship between homeownership and income, controlling for sex of the head of household, the interaction of sex and income, and geography at the PUMA level. The model was estimated separately for veterans and nonveterans using data from 2011, 2016, and 2021.

sections.title: Geographic Analysis of Housing Expenditures
sections.methods_summary: Estimates of expenditure differences between veterans and nonveterans were generated, controlling for various levels of geography (state, MSA, PUMA). Comparisons used only variation in housing costs within each geographic level.

sections.title: Data and Analytical Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used five-year American Community Survey (ACS) data from the Integrated Public Use Microdata Series (IPUMS) for the periods 2007-2011, 2012-2016, and 2017-2021.  Household-level analyses were conducted using provided household weights, excluding households with negative income.  The analysis compared veteran and nonveteran households by income and housing characteristics, further disaggregating by income categories.  National-level analyses were primarily conducted, with some regression analyses controlling for geography (MSAs and PUMAs).

analysis.sample_description: The study primarily used data from the five-year American Community Survey (ACS) focusing on heads of households with non-negative income.  Veteran households were defined as those where the head of household or spouse was a veteran.  Subgroup analyses were conducted based on sex, race/ethnicity, income, and geographic location (national, state, MSA, PUMA).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved comparing veteran and nonveteran households across different time periods (2011, 2016, 2021) based on income, housing tenure (ownership vs. renting), housing costs, and housing cost burden (HCB).  Regression analysis was used to examine the relationship between homeownership and income, controlling for various factors. Geographic controls were incorporated in some analyses.  The study also compared HCB across different income levels and veteran service eras (pre-9/11 and post-9/11), with age-matching conducted in some comparisons.

sections.title: Our Approach to Characterizing Veteran-Serving Organizations’ Efforts to Promote Social Connectedness
sections.methods_summary: A mixed-methods approach was used, combining a national web-based survey of veteran-serving organizations with follow-up semi-structured interviews.  The survey collected data at both the organizational and program levels, covering background information, organizational capacity, program evaluation experience, and program details.  A purposive sampling approach was used for the interviews, selecting organizations based on size, location, and program type.  Qualitative data from interviews were analyzed using QSR NVivo software with a structural coding approach.  Quantitative data from the survey were also analyzed. The study acknowledges limitations related to non-random sampling and the lack of a comprehensive national directory of veteran-serving organizations, impacting generalizability.

analysis.sample_description: A national sample of veteran-serving organizations was recruited through multiple methods, including directories, keyword searches, and professional networks.  The final survey sample included 87 organizations, with a smaller subset (15) participating in follow-up interviews.  The interview sample was purposively selected to ensure variation in organization size, geographic location, and program type.  The study acknowledges limitations in generalizability due to non-random sampling.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data from interviews were analyzed using QSR NVivo software with a structural coding approach to identify major themes.  Quantitative data from the survey were also analyzed, including descriptive statistics and comparisons between different program types. The study notes that the findings from the interviews are not necessarily generalizable to the full population of veteran-serving organizations.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Data Sources and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of one-year American Community Survey (ACS) Public Use Microdata Sample (PUMS) data from 2007-2019 (excluding 2020 due to COVID-19 concerns).  Data restricted to respondents aged 18+. Survey weights used for all estimates. Significance testing: omnibus tests for categorical variables, weighted t-tests for continuous variables (age).

sections.title: Chapter 3: Data Sources and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of pooled 2015-2019 National Survey on Drug Use and Health (NSDUH) data.  Data collected via in-person interviews with computer-assisted self-interviewing.  Sample includes 11,876 veterans (5.5%) from a total of 214,505 adult respondents.  Survey weights used for all prevalence estimates. Significance testing using survey-weighted F-tests (omnibus test for categorical variables).

sections.title: Chapter 4: Data Sources and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of 2015-2019 March Current Population Survey (CPS) Annual Social and Economic Supplement (ASEC) data (excluding 2020 due to COVID-19 impact).  Sample restricted to civilian veterans and nonveterans.  Estimates weighted using basic monthly CPS final weight; significance tests incorporate survey design factors through replicate weights.

analysis.sample_description: The report uses data from multiple nationally representative surveys, including the American Community Survey (ACS), the National Survey on Drug Use and Health (NSDUH), and the Current Population Survey (CPS).  Specific years and sample sizes vary by dataset and are detailed within each chapter's methodology section.  Data from 2020 are generally excluded due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics and prevalence estimates are calculated, accounting for the complex survey design of each dataset.  Statistical significance testing is conducted to compare veterans and nonveterans, and in some cases, subgroups within the veteran population.  Methods for significance testing vary by variable type (categorical vs. continuous).

sections.title: Chapter 2: Methodology and Demographic Overview
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources used (American Community Survey [ACS] Public Use Microdata Sample [PUMS] from 2016-2020, Current Population Survey [CPS] Food Security Supplement [FSS] from 2016-2020, Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System [BRFSS] from 2016-2020), and the qualitative data collection method (11 semi-structured interviews with student veteran single parents recruited through Student Veterans of America).  The data were analyzed using descriptive statistics; no regression analysis was performed.  The sample was limited to parents aged 18-59 with children under 17 living with them full-time. Active-duty service members were excluded from the ACS data.  Qualitative interviews were transcribed and coded using Dedoose software, with inter-rater reliability checks.

sections.title: Definitions and Measures
sections.methods_summary: This subsection provides operational definitions for 'single parent' and 'veteran' as used across the different datasets.  It then details the specific measures used to assess financial well-being (income, employment, public assistance, food security, housing), and mental and physical health (self-reported health ratings, health care access and utilization).

analysis.sample_description: The study used data from the ACS-PUMS, CPS-FSS, and BRFSS from 2016-2020, focusing on parents aged 18-59 with children under 17 living with them full-time.  Active-duty service members were excluded from the ACS data.  Qualitative data came from 11 semi-structured interviews with student veteran single parents.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics were used to analyze the quantitative data.  Qualitative data were analyzed using thematic analysis with inter-rater reliability checks.  No regression analysis was conducted.

sections.title: Data and Methods Used
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources used in the study.  It describes the American Life Panel (ALP), a nationally representative probability-based panel of over 6,000 U.S. adults aged 18+.  The study primarily uses data from two ALP surveys (#586 in February 2022 and #591 in June 2022). Survey #586 focused on views of the U.S. military, while #591 focused on perceptions of veterans.  Specific questions asked in each survey are listed, along with response rates.  The study also linked this data with data from previous ALP surveys (#566 and #574) to include information on political party identification and military service history of respondents and their family members.  Sample sizes for each survey and linked datasets are provided.

sections.title: Stereotypes About Veterans in Relation to Encouragement to Join the Military; Views of Veterans in Relation to Perceptions of How the Military Is Viewed by Most Americans
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the statistical analyses performed. Logistic regression models were used to examine the relationship between veteran stereotypes (positive and negative indices) and willingness to encourage military service (via officer path, enlistment path, or any path).  A second set of models included sociodemographic covariates (sex, age, race/ethnicity, residence, education, income, own/family military service, political party). Results are presented as odds ratios.  A multinomial logistic regression model was used to predict how respondents believe most Americans view the military, based on veteran stereotype indices and the same sociodemographic controls. Results are presented as relative risk ratios.  Figures are used to visually represent the predicted effects of variables on the outcomes.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative probability-based panel of over 6,000 U.S. adults aged 18+, drawn from the American Life Panel (ALP). Data linked across multiple ALP survey waves to include additional variables.
analysis.analysis_approach: Logistic regression models were used to assess the relationship between veteran stereotypes and willingness to encourage military service, controlling for sociodemographic factors.  Multinomial logistic regression was used to analyze perceptions of how most Americans view the military, also controlling for sociodemographic factors and veteran stereotype measures. Odds ratios and relative risk ratios were reported, and results were visualized using figures.

sections.title: Data Sources and Measures
sections.methods_summary: The study used data from the 2015–2021 Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) and 2015 Movement Advancement Project (MAP) state LGBTQ+ policy ratings.  Details on BRFSS data collection, including core survey items, optional modules (SOGI and Sex at Birth), and response rates are provided.  The definition of veteran status, sex, sexual identity, gender identity, and demographic covariates used in the analysis are described.  MAP's 2015 LGBTQ+ policy ratings are also explained.

sections.title: Analyses
sections.methods_summary: Two types of comparisons were made among U.S. veteran respondents in BRFSS data from 2015–2021: differences by sexual identity (comparing heterosexual veterans with sexual minority veterans, stratified by sex) and differences by gender identity (comparing transgender and cisgender veterans). Age-adjusted prevalence estimates were calculated using BRFSS survey design and response weights. Logistic regression was used to compare age-adjusted estimates across groups, with p < 0.05 considered statistically significant.

sections.title: Associations Between State LGBTQ+ Policy Climate and Health-Related Outcomes
sections.methods_summary: Multiple logistic regression analyses were conducted to examine associations between 2015 state LGBTQ+ policy climate (from MAP) and health-related outcomes for LGBTQ+ veterans in the BRFSS data (2015–2017). Models adjusted for survey year and respondent demographics (age, sex, race/ethnicity, education).

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative data from the 2015–2021 Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) on U.S. adult residents, focusing on veterans.  Data on sexual orientation and gender identity came from optional BRFSS modules.  The sample included approximately 185,944 veterans.
analysis.analysis_approach: Age-adjusted prevalence estimates were calculated and compared across groups using logistic regression.  Associations between state LGBTQ+ policy climate and health outcomes were also examined using logistic regression, adjusting for covariates.

sections.title: Scope of This Assessment
sections.methods_summary: High-level analysis focusing on two questions for each of the 55 National Critical Functions (NCFs): 1) What categories of systems using vulnerable cryptography are used by the NCF? 2) Could exploitation of vulnerabilities by an adversary with a quantum computer lead to degradation or disruption of the function?  The analysis focused solely on remotely accessible systems using cryptography vulnerable to quantum computing, excluding other cybersecurity issues.  The analysis focused on a singular outcome: whether exploited vulnerabilities could significantly degrade or disrupt the function, considering cascading impacts and the CIA triad (confidentiality, integrity, availability).  Detailed assessments of specific threat actors were intentionally excluded.

sections.title: Overview of Our Approach
sections.methods_summary: High-level analysis of 55 NCFs.  Key definitions of terms are provided.  Distinction is made between remote authentication vulnerabilities and catch-and-exploit vulnerabilities.  Table 1.2 summarizes the key steps in the assessment: identifying relevant information systems and sensitive data, identifying quantum computing vulnerabilities, rating the urgency of addressing vulnerabilities, rating the scope of organizations and systems requiring updates, rating the relative cost per organization, identifying other exacerbating or mitigating factors, and ranking the NCF's priority for assistance.  Each NCF assessment form includes a summary table, a synopsis providing context, and justification for ratings and priority assessment.

sections.title: Methods Used in the Assessments
sections.methods_summary: Individual assessments of each of the 55 NCFs using available literature, databases (including FactSet), prior reports, and NIST PQC migration scenarios.  The analysis used a high-level taxonomy of issues based on the CIA triad and MITRE ATT&CK framework.  Distinction was made between catch-and-exploit and remote authentication vulnerabilities.  Three categories of remote authentication issues were considered: database access, network account access, and cyber-physical system access.  Ratings were assessed for urgency (low, medium, high), scope (low, medium, high), cost per organization (low, medium, high), and other factors (mitigating, neutral, exacerbating).  These ratings were combined to rank the NCF's priority for assistance (low, medium, high).

analysis.sample_description: 55 National Critical Functions (NCFs) identified by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative assessment of urgency, scope, cost, and other factors to determine priority for assistance.  Categorization of NCFs based on commonalities in ratings and context.

sections.title: Study Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a futures methodology to analyze future possibilities and formulate recommendations.  It involved kick-off meetings, stocktaking of current knowledge and policy on cybercrime, horizon scanning, stakeholder engagement (including expert elicitation and a table-top exercise), and reporting of findings.  The study aimed to identify future trends, challenges, and opportunities for cybercrime and harm reduction over a ten-year timeframe.

analysis.sample_description: The study did not involve a specific sample in the traditional sense.  Instead, it drew upon existing knowledge, expert opinions, and stakeholder perspectives to project future trends.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of future trends and challenges based on horizon scanning, expert input, and a table-top exercise to explore policy options.  The analysis aimed to identify main drivers, trends, and opportunities likely to materialize in the next decade.

sections.title: Research Objective and Approach
sections.methods_summary: Developed a new approach to computing ASLs that pooled demand history across BCTs of the same type and shifted from a two-step heuristic to a mathematical optimization approach using a mixed-integer programming (MIP) algorithm.

sections.title: The Mathematical Optimization Formulation
sections.methods_summary: A mixed-integer programming (MIP) algorithm was used to maximize a weighted readiness benefit function subject to storage configuration and value constraints.  The benefit function was derived from pooled demand histories and weighted by factors such as the fraction of demands on high-priority work orders, MSP designation, fraction of BCTs with demand, equipment weighting factors, and churn factors.  Constraints included storage configuration (number of locations, extended cubic feet, by storage category), and value constraints (total value or transition costs).

sections.title: Conversion of the Army’s Armored, Infantry, and Stryker BCTs to CASLs
sections.methods_summary: A composite ASL was developed as a set point for the MIP algorithm.  Churn-weighting factors were used to limit upfront inventory investment.  Storage constraints were initially set based on the range of values in pre-conversion ASLs.  The CASLs were implemented using a staggered schedule. ASL performance was tracked using accommodation, satisfaction, and fill rates for MSPs and Class IX parts, simulated against pooled demand streams.

sections.title: Updates to the Common ASL
sections.methods_summary: Trade-off analysis was conducted using the MIP algorithm, varying input parameters such as storage constraints (by storage category and opening capacity), equipment weighting factors, and churn-weighting factors.  Simulated ASL performance (MSP and Class IX fill rates, job fill rates) was used to assess the impact of these changes.  Analysis was conducted to extend the CASL methodology to CABs, ADA brigades, and UASLs.

analysis.sample_description: Data from the Army's Global Combat Support System—Army (GCSS-A) for multiple Brigade Combat Teams (BCTs) over a period of several years.
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis approach involved using a mixed-integer programming (MIP) algorithm to optimize the composition of common authorized stockage lists (CASLs).  Simulation analysis was used to forecast the impact of changes and to evaluate the performance of the CASLs.  Trade-off analysis was used to explore the impact of different parameter settings on performance, cost, and workload.

sections.title: Methodology (brief overview)
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative methods were used to address three research objectives: characterize the landscape of RAS-AI technologies and missions; characterize their trajectory to 2040; and identify technological enablers shaping future missions.  A more detailed methodology is promised in a later section.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A two-pronged qualitative approach was used.  A top-down, mission-centered activity involved desk research and review of open-source literature (including past RAND reports) to capture high-level findings on technology maturity and trends. A bottom-up, technology-driven activity leveraged RAND Europe's horizon-scanning database of emerging S&T trends to identify key advances in emerging technologies.  Crosscutting analysis was then conducted to identify high-level mission and technology trends.  The analysis was guided by the RAN's taxonomy of RAS-AI missions and enabling technologies.  The research team did not make explicit assumptions about system size or cost, but focused on systems of likely interest to the RAN. The analysis aimed to illustrate the breadth of S&T developments and operational opportunities, but did not prioritize missions or provide an implementation roadmap.  Time and resource constraints limited the methodological options; a desk research approach was prioritized over other futures and foresight methodologies.

primary_methods: Analysis of RAND Europe's horizon-scanning database
analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is not an empirical study with a defined sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: Crosscutting analysis to identify high-level mission and technology trends, guided by existing taxonomies.

sections.title: Research Method
sections.methods_summary: The research involved an unstructured desktop literature review of open-source academic and grey literature focusing on human-machine teaming (HMT) and its implications for workforce development.  The team used RAND Australia's access to academic and scholarly databases, screening article titles and abstracts to identify relevant sources.  The analysis prioritized integration of diverse sources over an exhaustive catalogue.

analysis.sample_description: The sample consisted of open-source academic and grey literature related to human-machine teaming and its impact on workforce development, primarily published after 2010.
analysis.analysis_approach: Unstructured desktop literature review, categorizing findings into subcategories to allow for a comprehensive and integrative analysis.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research employed a mixed-methods approach combining literature reviews focusing on military innovation, experimentation, and rapid acquisition; a survey of current practices in exceptional innovation organizations (both within and outside of the Australian and UK militaries); and elicitation of subject-matter experts to provide insights and recommendations.

analysis.sample_description: The survey focused on exceptional innovation organizations in Australia, the U.S., and the UK, including both traditional and non-traditional defense stakeholders.  The literature review focused on business and military innovation, experimentation, and rapid acquisition.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved synthesizing findings from the literature review, survey, and expert elicitation to develop approaches the RAN might consider for innovation and rapid acquisition of RAS-AI capabilities.  The analysis also involved categorizing and comparing different innovation models and organizations.

sections.title: Data Description and Personnel Flow Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Data was compiled from the Defense Manpower Data Center (including the Work Experience file, Active Duty Master File, Reserve Master File, and corresponding transaction files), and the Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System.  Analysis involved examining personnel flows into and out of the Selected Reserve (SELRES) between FY 2016 and FY 2018, visualizing immediate sources and destinations, analyzing military service histories, and employing automated clustering techniques (K-means) on a dimensionality-reduced dataset (using a neural network autoencoder) to identify groups of reservists with similar career patterns.

sections.title: Modeling Tools and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study utilized five modeling tools:  1) Recruiting Difficulty Index (RDI) - forecasting model; 2) Reserve Recruiting Resource Model (RRRM) - econometric model; 3) Reserve Recruit Selection Tool (R-RST) - econometric model; 4) Dynamic Retention Model (DRM) - econometric model; and 5) a machine learning (ML) approach (neural network).  Each tool's purpose, inputs, outputs, data sources, and limitations are described. The ML approach, developed as a proof-of-concept, used a neural network with both recurrent (GRU) and feedforward components to predict individual-level retention behavior, using static and time-varying characteristics of SELRES members.  The study also notes the different stages of development of each tool.

sections.title: Integrated Modeling Concept (IMC) Development and Application
sections.methods_summary: The IMC integrates the outputs of the five modeling tools to generate 24-month end strength forecasts.  The study details how the base year population and potential entrants are partitioned to align with the capabilities of each tool.
