A flow chart illustrates the model integration plan for forecasting exits and retained entries.  The relative prevalence of each tool is quantified using actual personnel flows from FY 2016-2018. A numerical example demonstrates how the IMC aggregates tool outputs to generate forecasts, both for total end strength and for subpopulations (with caveats about accuracy for subpopulations).

sections.title: Decomposition of Personnel Flows (Appendix A)
sections.methods_summary: Provides a detailed breakdown of the inflow and outflow sources shown in Figure 2.2, further decomposing the data to clarify the sources and destinations of reservists entering and leaving USAR.

sections.title: Clustering Approach to Understanding SELRES Career Paths (Appendix B)
sections.methods_summary: To analyze career patterns, a neural network autoencoder was used for dimensionality reduction on the large, sparse dataset of SELRES careers. K-means clustering was then applied to the reduced dataset to identify groups of reservists with similar career paths.  The analysis considers the impact of censoring and explores the characteristics of the resulting clusters (career length, prior service, job specialty, demographics).

sections.title: Machine Learning Model Details (Appendix C)
sections.methods_summary: This section details the machine learning model used, a neural network with recurrent (GRU) and feedforward components.  It describes the input data (time series and static variables), data preprocessing steps (handling missing data, encoding categorical variables, scaling numerical variables), model architecture, loss function (survival loss function), training procedure (batching, epochs), and a proof-of-concept application to predict 12- and 24-month retention for a specific cohort of enlisted reservists.  The accuracy of the model is assessed using ROC-AUC and C-index scores, and the potential for extending the model to predict accessions is discussed.

analysis.sample_description: Close to 1.3 million unique service members who had been in SELRES between FY 1990 and FY 2018.  A subset of approximately 760,000 individuals with complete career data was used for detailed analysis of career paths.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study uses a mixed-methods approach, combining data analysis of personnel flows with the application and integration of multiple modeling tools (econometric and machine learning) to develop a forecasting framework (IMC).

sections.title: Modeling Costa Rica’s Economy
sections.methods_summary: The study uses the Integrated Economic-Environmental Modeling (IEEM) platform, a dynamic computable general equilibrium model, calibrated with a Social Accounting Matrix (SAM) for Costa Rica.  The model simulates the effects of COVID-19 through adjustments to parameters representing labor productivity, elasticity of real capital return, elasticity of wages on unemployment, and demand for goods and services. Three COVID-19 recovery trajectories (1-year, 3-year, 5-year) are simulated by relaxing these parameters over time.  Decarbonization investment scenarios are modeled by introducing capital shocks to different economic sectors based on investment cost estimates from multiple sources (Groves et al., 2020; South Pole, 2019, 2021). Three decarbonization scenarios are created based on varying total investment costs.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses a model of the Costa Rican economy, not a sample of individuals.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis compares model simulations of employment and value added under different COVID-19 recovery trajectories and decarbonization investment scenarios.  The model is calibrated to match observed economic data from 2019-2020.  The results are analyzed to assess the potential benefits of decarbonization investments on economic recovery and their alignment with Sustainable Development Goals.

sections.title: Chapter Two: Research Design
sections.methods_summary: A mixed-methods process and outcome evaluation was conducted.  Process evaluation used quantitative data from service providers (sociodemographic characteristics, risk assessment data, services received), observations, site visits, discussions with providers, focus groups (23 Fellows), and interviews (11 current Fellows, 14 alumni). Outcome evaluation tracked changes from baseline on employment and recidivism outcomes, using data from service providers.  Decision-making was assessed using the Decision-Making scale of the TCU Psychological Functioning Assessment.  An observational design was used due to challenges in identifying a comparison group.  Qualitative data were analyzed using Atlas.ti and a grounded theory approach.

analysis.sample_description: 432 individuals enrolled in Project imPACT Cohort 1.  Participants were largely male; African American/Black or Hispanic, Latino, or Spanish; and determined to be medium or high risk based on a structured risk-needs assessment.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative data were analyzed using statistical tests (e.g., significance testing, correlation). Qualitative data were analyzed using Atlas.ti software and a grounded theory approach.  An intent-to-treat approach was used for some analyses to account for missing data.

sections.title: Research Design
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods process and outcome evaluation. Process evaluation used quantitative data from service providers (quarterly data on demographics, risk assessment, service utilization), observations, site visits, and discussions with providers, and interviews with Fellows (two rounds, 35 total). Outcome evaluation used provider-reported data and Los Angeles County Superior Court data on recidivism.  Analysis included thematic analysis of qualitative data and quantitative analysis of service utilization and outcomes.

analysis.sample_description: 384 individuals enrolled in Project imPACT between June 2020 and September 2022.  The sample included significant regional differences in age, gender, and race/ethnicity, reflecting the broader demographics of the Los Angeles areas served. Most Fellows were unemployed at enrollment and many were staying with family or friends.
analysis.analysis_approach: Thematic analysis of interview transcripts using Atlas.ti software and a grounded theory approach. Quantitative analysis of service utilization data, including calculations of percentages and means. Statistical tests (e.g., t-tests) were used to compare groups (e.g., program completers vs. non-completers).

sections.title: 2. Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section details the definitions of sexual harassment and gender discrimination used, the data sources (2018 Workplace and Gender Relations Survey of Active Duty Members (WGRA) and Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC) data), the definition of high-risk installations (based on rates of sexual harassment exceeding the Army average), and the statistical methods employed.  The methods include using analytic weights to account for survey design and nonresponse, creating profiles based on respondents' most serious experiences, and using Clopper-Pearson exact confidence intervals and Rao-Scott chi-squared tests for statistical analysis.  The rationale for choosing this approach over alternatives like small area estimation is also discussed.

primary_methods: Statistical analysis (Rao-Scott chi-squared test, Clopper-Pearson confidence intervals)
analysis.sample_description: The analytic sample consisted of 2,482 active-component Army soldiers (1,582 women and 900 men) with nonzero weights who experienced sexual harassment in the 12 months prior to the 2018 WGRA and completed the online survey version.  Soldiers assigned to the Pentagon or military academies were excluded.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved creating profiles of sexual harassment and gender discrimination experiences based on respondents' most serious incidents.  These profiles included the types of behaviors, perpetrator characteristics, and time and place of the incidents.  Statistical significance was assessed using Rao-Scott chi-squared tests with a p-value cutoff of 0.05.  Clopper-Pearson exact confidence intervals were used to account for uncertainty in the estimates.  Installations with fewer than 30 respondents were grouped to protect privacy.

sections.title: Data Analysis and Statistical Methods
sections.methods_summary: Descriptive analysis of data from the 2016 and 2018 Workplace and Gender Relations Survey of Active Duty Members (WGRA).  Statistical tests (Rao-Scott chi-squared test) used to identify statistically significant differences across groups (year, gender, sexual orientation, installation risk level).  Confidence intervals (Clopper-Pearson method) calculated for percentages.  Data cleaning and recoding procedures described.  Power calculations performed to assess the minimum detectable differences.

sections.title: Statistical Methods and Power Analysis
sections.methods_summary: 95% confidence intervals calculated using the Clopper-Pearson method.  Hypothesis testing using Rao-Scott chi-squared test.  No correction for multiple tests.  Data weighted to correct for nonresponse bias.  Power calculations performed to determine minimum detectable differences in proportions between groups (year, gender, sexual orientation, installation risk level).

sections.title: Data Cleaning and Preparation
sections.methods_summary: Imputation of missing data for certain variables.  Recoding of responses to 'mark all that apply' questions to handle missing data and logical inconsistencies.  Specific recoding procedures detailed for questions on perpetrator rank, professional relationship, personal relationship, and time of assault.  Handling of alcohol-related questions and imputation of missing data described.

sections.title: Data Aggregation and Variable Creation
sections.methods_summary: Aggregation of response options for certain variables (e.g., personal relationship, place of assault, time of assault) to create composite variables for analysis.  Combination of response options explained for clarity.

sections.title: Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: Data from the 2016 and 2018 Workplace and Gender Relations Survey of Active Duty Members (WGRA) and the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC) Active Duty Master File.

analysis.sample_description: Active-component Army soldiers who responded to the 2016 and 2018 WGRA and reported being sexually assaulted in the year prior to survey administration.  Sample size of 1022 (776 women and 246 men).
analysis.analysis_approach: Exploratory descriptive analysis to identify differences in sexual assault experiences across various subgroups (year, gender, sexual orientation, installation risk level).  Focus on identifying differences of practical importance for policymaking.

sections.title: Detailed Description of Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used Latent Class Analysis (LCA) to analyze data from the 2018 Department of Defense Workplace and Gender Relations Survey of Active Duty Members (WGRA).  The LCA was employed to identify profiles of sexual assault and sexual harassment experiences among active-duty soldiers, accounting for the complex interplay of various characteristics. The analysis involved creating a specific number of classes (types) and sorting each case into the type it most resembled.  The goal was to explain the associations between dimensions and achieve approximate independence of characteristics within each type.  The analysis was conducted using the Mplus 7.3 statistical package, handling missing data through the expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm. Model selection involved fitting LCA models with increasing complexity, using the Bayesian Information Criteria (BIC) to determine the best-fitting model.  The final models identified five types of sexual assault and eight types of sexual harassment.  Effect sizes were calculated to determine the distinctiveness of characteristics within each type.

sections.title: Data and Statistical Methods
sections.methods_summary: Data were drawn from the Army respondents to the 2018 WGRA, using survey weights to ensure representativeness.  Separate samples were used for sexual assault (N=499) and sexual harassment (N=2482). Data simplification involved combining similar incident features, dropping near-collinear features and rare characteristics, and limiting victim characteristics to gender, pay grade group, and sexual orientation.  The LCA was estimated in Mplus 7.3, treating characteristics as binary outcomes except for pay grade and perpetrator gender (ordered logistic). Multiple random starting values were used to ensure the maximum likelihood solution was found. The expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm handled missing data.  A series of LCA models were fit, increasing the number of classes until a unique solution could not be found. Model fit was assessed using the Bayesian Information Criteria (BIC).

analysis.sample_description: Data from the Army respondents to the 2018 WGRA. Separate samples were used for sexual assault (N=499) and sexual harassment (N=2482). Survey weights were used to make estimates representative of the full Army.
analysis.analysis_approach: Latent Class Analysis (LCA) was used to identify distinct types of sexual assault and sexual harassment experiences based on various characteristics (victim characteristics, perpetrator characteristics, specific behaviors, context, location).  Model fit was assessed using the Bayesian Information Criteria (BIC). Effect sizes were calculated to determine the distinctiveness of characteristics within each type.

sections.title: Research Methods
sections.methods_summary: This report is based on a legal review of California state laws, regulations, and guidance documents; a high-level review of academic and gray literature on best practices for regulatory analyses; informal discussions with DOF staff; the authors' experience in conducting SRIAs and supporting economic analyses; a review of completed SRIAs submitted to DOF between 2014 and 2022; and a review of publicly available comment letters from the Chief Economist of the DOF. Additional information was collected from the websites of DOF and OAL.

sections.title: Review and Selection of Macroeconomic Models for Standardized Regulatory Impact Assessments
sections.methods_summary: This section reviews the macroeconomic models used in SRIAs, focusing on three commercially available models: RIMS II, IMPLAN, and REMI.  It describes the characteristics of input-output (I-O) models and computable general equilibrium (CGE) models, comparing their strengths and weaknesses for different types of analyses. The section also analyzes the frequency of model use in past SRIAs.

sections.title: Describe the Economic Methodology and Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines the economic methodology for conducting SRIAs, emphasizing benefit-cost analysis. It discusses minimum quality standards for regulatory analysis, including clearly stating methods and data choices, using high-quality evidence, seeking stakeholder opinions, addressing uncertainties (qualitative discussion, sensitivity analysis, probabilistic analysis), and using nonmarket valuation methods.  The section also addresses the estimation of direct and secondary impacts, including the treatment of early compliance and the use of opportunity cost for valuation.  Methods for incorporating unquantified impacts are described (qualitative discussion, breakeven analysis, cost-effective analysis, bounding analysis).

sections.title: Estimate Direct Costs and Estimate Direct Benefits
sections.methods_summary: This section details methods for estimating direct costs and benefits.  Cost estimation includes labor costs (wages, fringe benefits, overhead), administrative burdens, and cost savings associated with behavioral changes.  Benefit estimation focuses on monetizing policy outcomes (e.g., health risk reduction) using revealed-preference and stated-preference methods.  The use of market measures as proxies and existing government estimates for valuing health impacts and greenhouse gas emissions are also discussed.

sections.title: Estimate Secondary Impacts
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the estimation of secondary impacts (direct, indirect, and induced effects) using macroeconomic models. It defines these effects and explains the requirements for quantitative estimates of economic variables (job creation/elimination, business creation/elimination, competitive advantages/disadvantages, investment changes, innovation incentives, and benefits to health, safety, and welfare). The section also notes the use of various economic models by California state agencies and the challenges in reliably producing quantitative estimates.

sections.title: Evaluate Distributional Impacts and Address Uncertainty
sections.methods_summary: This section discusses distributional analysis, focusing on reporting impacts across industries, business sizes, and demographic groups.  It also addresses methods for addressing uncertainty, including qualitative discussions, quantitative sensitivity analysis, and probabilistic analysis (e.g., Monte Carlo simulation).  Expert elicitation is mentioned as a potential method for quantifying uncertainty when data are limited.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample includes completed SRIAs submitted to the California Department of Finance between 2014 and 2022.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach involves a review of existing SRIAs, relevant literature, and government guidance to identify best practices and common issues in conducting SRIAs in California.  The analysis also compares different macroeconomic models used in these assessments.

sections.title: Evaluation of the Effectiveness of U.S. Government-Funded Counternarcotics Programs in Colombia
sections.methods_summary: This section evaluates the effectiveness of joint efforts from 2000-2020.  The methodology involves analyzing four key lines of effort: coca crop eradication; cocaine, precursor chemicals, cash, and other assets interdiction; security and rule of law efforts; and alternative development programs. The analysis draws on data from various sources, including the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, and interviews with key government officials.  The evaluation focuses on assessing the effectiveness of each line of effort individually and collectively, considering both successes and limitations.  Qualitative analysis of program effectiveness is presented alongside quantitative data on coca cultivation and cocaine production.

analysis.sample_description: The study covers the period from 2000 to 2020, analyzing the effectiveness of U.S. counternarcotics efforts in Colombia. Data sources include government reports, UN data, and interviews with key stakeholders.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves examining four key lines of effort (eradication, interdiction, security and rule of law, and development) individually and collectively.  Quantitative data on coca cultivation and cocaine production are used, along with qualitative assessments of program effectiveness based on document review and interviews.

sections.title: Data Analysis and Calculations
sections.methods_summary: The study uses data from the 2016 and 2018 Workplace and Gender Relations Survey of Active Duty Members (WGRA).  The authors calculate the proportion of sexual assaults against service members who did not identify as heterosexual by using the reported sexual assault rates for LGB and non-LGB service members, along with population proportions from the WGRA.  They acknowledge and address potential uncertainties in their calculations, such as rounding errors and the ambiguity in how the WGRA defined 'non-LGB'.

sections.title: Appendix: Addressing Uncertainty in Non-LGB Grouping
sections.methods_summary: This section details the analysis conducted to assess the robustness of the main findings to different possible ways the WGRA might have grouped respondents into LGB and non-LGB categories.  Six possible approaches are considered, and the authors demonstrate that their primary conclusions are largely unaffected by the uncertainty in the non-LGB grouping.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the 2016 and 2018 WGRA surveys of active duty U.S. military personnel.  The sample includes both men and women.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis primarily involves calculating proportions and percentages based on data from the WGRA.  The authors use these calculations to estimate the proportion of sexual assaults targeting service members who do not identify as heterosexual.  Sensitivity analyses are conducted to assess the impact of potential uncertainties in the data and methodology.

sections.title: Methodology: Denial Rates of Claims
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of denial rates across different types of claims administrators (TPA vs. self-administered) using data from the Workers' Compensation Information System (WCIS).

sections.title: Methodology: Denial Rates of Claims (Continued)
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of denial rates for claims involving PTSD and other presumption conditions, comparing TPAs and self-administered employers.  Statistical significance testing (p-values) used to compare denial rates.

sections.title: Methodology: Indemnity Benefit Receipt
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of indemnity benefit receipt (TD, PD, settlements) by initial claim denial status, comparing TPAs and self-administered employers.  Focus on differences in probabilities of benefit receipt between initially accepted and denied claims.

sections.title: Methodology: Access to Mental Health Care
sections.methods_summary: Examination of accessibility and timing of mental health treatment for first responders. Analysis of types of treatment, avenues for seeking care, and mental health resources provided by fire and police departments.  Includes first responder perspectives on barriers to care and differences in accessing treatment inside and outside the workers' compensation system.

sections.title: Methodology: Access to Mental Health Care (Continued)
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of WCIS medical bill data for mental health claims by first responders to answer research questions 7 and 10.  Discussion of stigma, department resources, and cultural competence of providers.

sections.title: Methodology: Future Research Recommendations
sections.methods_summary: Recommendations for future research including revisiting study questions in 2023, qualitative investigation of stigma reduction, and cost impact modeling of PTSD associated with turnover, training, or early retirement.  Also, gathering more information on claims administrator requests and exploring mental health provider availability within MPNs.

sections.title: Methodology: Cost of PTSD Claims and SB 542
sections.methods_summary: Estimation of future costs to state and local governments due to SB 542 and retroactive application.  Modeling of potential changes in claim-filing decisions and denial rates.  Use of a formula: Total Costs = Number of Claims × Cost per Claim.

sections.title: Methodology: Cost of PTSD Claims and SB 542 (Detailed)
sections.methods_summary: Cost modeling using scenarios based on PTSD incidence rates, probability of seeking care, probability of filing a claim, probability of denial, and cost per denied/accepted claim.  Data from BLS, CHIS, WCIS, and relevant literature used to define scenarios.  Calculation of number of claims filed and total costs for each scenario.  Modeling of retroactive application of SB 542.

sections.title: Methodology: Qualitative Methods
sections.methods_summary: Description of the script used for recruiting first responders. Outline of interview topics for each stakeholder type (department chiefs, mental health providers, claims administrators, first responders, applicants' attorneys). Information about participating departments and samples of applicants' attorneys and first responders.  Use of semistructured interviews, inductive and deductive content analysis, and Dedoose software for qualitative data analysis.  Inter-rater reliability assessment using Kappa coefficients.

sections.title: Methodology: Quantitative Methods
sections.methods_summary: Detailed description of CHIS and NHIS data analysis, including definitions of outcome variables (K6 scores, suicidal ideation, suicide attempts), weighting procedures, and statistical inference methods (Wald tests).  Description of WCIS data analysis, including definition of key outcome variables (benefit type codes, claim denials, indemnity benefits, settlements), methods for identifying claims administrators, and weighting procedures to address missing data.  Description of occupational comparison groups and use of O*Net data.  Discussion of limitations of CHIS, NHIS, and WCIS data.

analysis.sample_description: The study used a mixed-methods approach. Qualitative data was collected through interviews with various stakeholders (first responders, applicants' attorneys, department chiefs, claims administrators, mental health providers). Quantitative data was drawn from the California Health Interview Survey (CHIS), the National Health Interview Survey (NHIS), and the Workers' Compensation Information System (WCIS).  The sample of departments was chosen to reflect geographic diversity and variations in claim denial rates.  The first responder sample was recruited through mental health providers and consisted of individuals who had received treatment for work-related trauma.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data was analyzed using inductive and deductive content analysis. Quantitative data was analyzed using descriptive statistics, regression analysis (implied in some sections), and statistical significance testing (e.g., Wald tests, chi-squared tests).

sections.title: Data Matching and Cleaning
sections.methods_summary: Fuzzy matching using Jaro-Winkler distance for business name and street address.  Standardization of punctuation, capitalization, and common abbreviations. Manual review of edge cases to remove unlikely matches. Only DoD contractors reporting employee count and industry were included.

sections.title: Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of PPP loan data (through August 8, 2020) for loans above $150,000.  Data compared for all businesses and FY2020 DoD contractors.  DoD contractors identified by matching PPP data with a dataset of organizations receiving DoD awards in FY2020 using business name, street address, and zip code (fuzzy matching allowed for name and address). Analysis included descriptive statistics (average loan size, number of jobs protected, loan value by industry, employee distribution by industry and company size, geographic distribution).  Limitations acknowledged regarding incomplete information on total small businesses in the DIB and jobs at risk.

analysis.sample_description: The sample included DoD contractors who received PPP loans and reported their number of employees and industry.  The analysis also used data on all businesses receiving PPP loans for comparison.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive analysis of PPP loan data, focusing on loan amounts, number of jobs protected, industry distribution, and company size.  Geographic trends were also examined. Comparisons were made between DoD contractors and all businesses receiving PPP loans.

sections.title: Survey Methods and Weighting
sections.methods_summary: A survey of parents of school-age children (ages 5-18) was conducted using the Ipsos Knowledge Panel (KP), a high-quality online panel employing probability-based sampling.  2,015 parents completed the survey after screening for eligibility.  Ipsos weighted the completed surveys to match the national distribution of demographic characteristics among parents of children ages 5-18, using data from the U.S. Census Bureau's American Community Survey (ACS) and the March supplement to the 2020 Current Population Survey.  Weights were calibrated to account for gender, age, race/ethnicity, region, metropolitan status, education, income, and language proficiency. Extreme weight values were trimmed.

sections.title: Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Percentages of parents selecting each survey response were calculated and compared across 20 subgroups based on gender, urbanicity, region, race/ethnicity, household income, and educational attainment. Significance testing (p < 0.05) was conducted to assess whether subgroup responses differed statistically from the overall sample.  Multiple hypothesis test corrections were not applied.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative sample of 2,015 parents of school-age children (ages 5-18) recruited from the Ipsos Knowledge Panel.  The sample was weighted to match the national distribution of demographic characteristics.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics (percentages) were calculated for each survey response.  Subgroup comparisons were made using significance testing (p<0.05) to determine statistically significant differences between subgroups and the overall sample.  Multiple hypothesis testing corrections were not used.

sections.title: Technical Appendix Reference
sections.methods_summary: A technical appendix describing the survey methods is available at www.rand.org/t/RRA1393-2.

sections.title: Overview of the July 2021 Parent Survey
sections.methods_summary: Survey administered from July 16 to July 29, 2021, to 3,146 parents of children ages 5–18. Completion rate was 43 percent. Results weighted to be nationally representative of U.S. parents of children ages 5–18.  Survey methods and a description of the parent sample are available in the technical appendix at www.rand.org/t/RRA1393-2.

sections.title: How to Read the Figures
sections.methods_summary: Describes the use of asterisks and bold font to indicate statistically significant differences (p < 0.05). Explains how to interpret heat maps and bar charts, including confidence intervals in the bar charts comparing May and July 2021 responses.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative sample of 3,146 U.S. parents of children ages 5-18.  43% completion rate.  Weighted to be nationally representative.
analysis.analysis_approach: Statistical significance testing (p<0.05) used to compare responses across subgroups and time points.  Heat maps and bar charts used for visualization. Confidence intervals displayed for bar charts.

sections.title: How This Analysis Was Conducted
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data source (a nationally representative survey of 957 public school principals administered via the AEP in late April and early May 2020),  control variables (school grade level, urbanicity, charter school status, district enrollment, percentage of non-White students, and percentage of students eligible for free or reduced-price lunch), and the specific survey items used for analysis, including how the data was categorized and linked to external data sources.  It also describes the dependent variables used in the linear regressions for Figures 1 and 2.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative survey of 957 public school principals administered via the American Educator Panels (AEP) in late April and early May 2020.
analysis.analysis_approach: Linear regression analysis was used to investigate the relationship between school preparedness indicators and outcomes of interest.  Control variables were included to account for school demographics.  The dependent variables varied depending on the specific outcome being analyzed (e.g., assigning letter grades, concerns about equitable instruction).

sections.title: How This Analysis Was Conducted
sections.methods_summary: This report uses data from nationally representative surveys of 1,045 K–12 public school teachers and 1,183 school principals administered via the AEP in March 2021. Data were weighted to provide nationally representative estimates. Pairwise tests compared weighted means of subgroups to assess statistical significance (p < 0.05). No adjustments were made for multiple comparisons. School and student demographic data were linked to the 2019–2020 Common Core of Data.  Urbanicity was defined using the NCES four-category locale definition.  Schools were categorized by percentage of minority (non-White) students and FRPL-eligible students. School grade levels were categorized based on self-reported data from teachers and principals.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative samples of 1,045 K–12 public school teachers and 1,183 school principals. Data were weighted to be nationally representative.
analysis.analysis_approach: Pairwise tests were performed to compare weighted means of subgroups (e.g., fully in-person vs. fully remote teachers). No adjustments were made for multiple comparisons because the report aimed to provide descriptive information rather than test specific hypotheses. Data were linked to the 2019-2020 Common Core of Data for demographic information.

sections.title: Methodology: Effectiveness Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Development of an optimization model to maximize squadron access to upgraded ranges.  The model considers range upgrades, squadron movements, constraints on allowable moves (number of squadrons per base, MDS types, active-duty/reserve colocation), and prioritization of fighter aircraft based on mission design series (MDS) and operational/training squadron status. A second optimization stage minimizes the sum of distances between squadrons and ranges when multiple optimal solutions exist.

sections.title: Methodology: Cost Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Estimation of one-time costs for relocating squadrons, including personnel move costs (based on USAF FY 2019 budget estimates and personnel counts from various squadron types) and infrastructure costs (using Air Force planning factors, the Civil Engineering Planning Template, and UFC cost factors).  A baseline cost estimate assumes 100% new construction. A capacity-informed estimate, using data from AFIMSC, accounts for existing base capacity and developable land.  Comparison of these costs with AF/A3T range upgrade cost estimates.

sections.title: Methodology: Risk Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Collection and analysis of publicly available data: NOAA sea level rise inundation maps, USFS Wildfire Hazard Potential maps, USGS seismic hazard maps, and downscaled climate projections (MACA dataset from the Northwest Knowledge Network, using outputs from 12 GCMs). Calculation of additional metrics from climate projections (hundred-degree days, black flag days, etc.). Analysis of historical electric grid reliability data (SAIFI, SAIDI, FOR) from the U.S. Energy Information Administration and NERC.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses a snapshot of the 2025 projected fighter force structure, including active-duty, reserve, and Air National Guard units.  Specific bases and ranges are identified in the analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: Effectiveness is assessed by the weighted number of fighter squadrons within 150 nautical miles of upgraded ranges. Costs are compared for range upgrades and squadron restationing. Risks are evaluated using hazard maps, climate projections, and power reliability data.  The analysis explores the interaction of range upgrade and squadron restationing policies under various constraints.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Methodology - Analysis of Publicly Available Online Government and Nongovernment Information
sections.methods_summary: Convenience sampling of online resources (government directives, ancillary government documents, secondary sources, media sources) related to security clearance applications, adjudication process, and clearance requirements.  Analysis included identifying relevant material using general search terms on Google, focusing on sources aimed at clearance applicants. Readability analysis using the Flesch-Kincaid test was also performed.

sections.title: Chapter 3: Methodology - Analysis of Information Shared in Online Discussions About the Security Clearance Process
sections.methods_summary: Three-step approach: 1) Identification of social media platforms (Reddit, Federalsoup, Clearancejobsblog) with communities focused on security clearance discussions. 2) Identification of relevant communities within those platforms. 3) Application of an automated topic modeling tool (using BERT embeddings, UMAP, and HDBSCAN algorithms) to identify frequently discussed themes.  A random sample of 20 posts was manually coded for accuracy by cross-referencing with SEAD-4 guidelines.  Frequency of URLs and government URLs was also analyzed.

sections.title: Appendix A: Methodological Details
sections.methods_summary: Detailed description of the topic modeling technique used in Chapter 3. This involved using BERTopic, a method that utilizes BERT embeddings, UMAP, and HDBSCAN algorithms for sentence embedding, semantically similar sentence clustering, and topic representation. Data preprocessing steps (removing stop words, punctuation, emojis, platform-related noise, stemming) are also described.

analysis.sample_description: Chapter 2: Convenience sample of online resources related to security clearances. Chapter 3:  Posts from Reddit (24,306 posts from 2017-2019), Federalsoup (4,846 posts from 2010-2022), and Clearancejobsblog (3,500 posts from 2017-2022). A random sample of 20 posts from these platforms was manually coded.
analysis.analysis_approach: Chapter 2:  Qualitative analysis of online resources, readability analysis using Flesch-Kincaid. Chapter 3: Automated topic modeling using BERTopic (BERT embeddings, UMAP, HDBSCAN), manual coding of a random sample of posts for accuracy, frequency analysis of URLs.

sections.title: Expert Interviews
sections.methods_summary: Eight semi-structured interviews were conducted with subject matter experts (SMEs) from six national security and non-national security agencies.  Interviews were conducted via Microsoft Teams, lasted 45-60 minutes, and used a discussion guide focusing on security concerns, observed behavioral changes during the pandemic, and modifications to risk assessment processes. Notes were reviewed, and common themes were identified and synthesized.

sections.title: Research Design and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach.  First, risk factors were identified and categorized from SEAD-4 and SF-86 documents.  A literature review of academic literature and open-source data (focusing on alcohol use, drug use, mental health, and unemployment) was conducted to assess the impact of the pandemic on these factors.  Finally, subject-matter expert (SME) interviews were conducted to understand the impact on investigation and adjudication processes.

sections.title: Literature Review and Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: A literature review was conducted using PubMed and open-source databases.  PubMed searches focused on "alcohol abuse", "drug abuse", and "mental health" in relation to COVID-19, yielding 29, 12, and 10 articles respectively after screening. Open-source data searches focused on economic and employment trends from sources like the Bureau of Labor Statistics and the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities.  The analysis involved summarizing findings from the reviewed literature and open-source data regarding the impact of the pandemic on identified risk factors.

analysis.sample_description: Eight subject matter experts from various agencies;  literature review sample included studies on alcohol use, drug use, mental health, and unemployment related to the COVID-19 pandemic; open-source data included economic and employment data from various US government sources.
analysis.analysis_approach: Thematic analysis of interview data;  descriptive analysis and synthesis of findings from the literature review and open-source data.

sections.title: Study Scope and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study involved collecting information from three sources: (1) three requests for information (RFIs) fielded to DoD educational institutions and military services, (2) stakeholder discussions with each educational institution, service talent management community, and the Joint Staff, and (3) case studies of five comparable civilian institution programs.  The information was analyzed through a thematic review organized according to a framework categorizing inputs, processes, outputs, and outcomes.

analysis.sample_description: Thirteen DoD educational institutions (nine strategic/operational, four technical) and five comparable civilian institutions offering professional master's degree programs.
analysis.analysis_approach: Thematic review of data from RFIs, stakeholder discussions, and case studies, organized according to a framework of inputs, processes, outputs, and outcomes.

sections.title: Our Approach: Vignettes Showing WPS Principles in Action at DoD
sections.methods_summary: The study uses vignettes, brief accounts or stories of personal experiences, collected from service members and DoD civilians through email, Facebook posts, and snowball sampling.  Follow-up interviews were conducted to gather further details.  The researchers also consulted with gender advisors (GENADs) and subject-matter experts and conducted a literature review to identify areas of concern for WPS implementation.

analysis.sample_description: DoD civilians, active-duty and reservist service members, and veterans.  The sample was gathered through multiple methods, resulting in a focus on GENADs and subject matter experts.
analysis.analysis_approach: The vignettes are presented as examples of WPS principles in action.  The researchers also identify areas of concern for WPS implementation based on their data collection and literature review.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: Extensive literature reviews, discussions with RAND subject-matter experts, and analysis of the results were used to develop a framework to aid in thinking about joint program formation.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consists of existing and past joint programs within the DHS and Department of Defense, as well as relevant academic literature and expert opinions.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved developing a framework for organizing thinking about joint program formation, including a decision aid, a taxonomy of joint program types, a tool for selecting program types, and guidelines for structuring joint programs.  The framework was developed based on the literature review, expert interviews, and analysis of the selected joint programs.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: A modified Delphi panel approach was used, implemented via RAND's ExpertLens platform.  This involved three phases: Phase 1 (identification of measure constructs), Phase 2 (expert assessment of constructs against criteria: importance, scientific acceptability, feasibility, usability), and Phase 3 (virtual convening of experts to discuss ratings and refine them).

analysis.sample_description: A diverse group of 15 experts in quality measurement, clinical care, and health economics.
analysis.analysis_approach: Numeric and written expert assessments were summarized. Median and interquartile range of ratings were calculated to identify constructs for Phase 3 discussion.  Phase 3 involved a virtual convening to discuss ratings and allow for adjustments.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research team examined a range of case studies (five international and two domestic) to identify options and highlight challenges for Australia in establishing a Sovereign Guided Weapons Enterprise.  The international case studies involved literature reviews focusing on the contexts of capability development, public-private partnerships, industrial base requirements, and export strategies.  The domestic case studies synthesized prior RAND research. The analysis aimed to provide insights and explore options, not to provide definitive recommendations.

analysis.sample_description: Five international case studies (Japan, UAE, UK, Canada, Norway) and two domestic Australian case studies (Australian Naval Shipbuilding Enterprise and Australia’s munitions manufacturing industry).
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative synthesis of lessons learned from the case studies to inform the discussion of options for Australia's Sovereign Guided Weapons Enterprise.

sections.title: Research Questions and Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines the research questions guiding the study and the approach taken to answer them.  The approach involved a literature review of existing energy equity frameworks, focusing on the California Energy Commission's (CEC) indicators and the U.S. Department of Energy's Clean Energy for Low-Income Communities Accelerator (CELICA) partnership.  The researchers assessed the relevance of these indicators for Southern California Edison's (SCE) goals, considering applicability to the utility power sector, relevance to Southern California's geography and climate adaptation, and the indicators' specificity and alignment with current research.  The study also reviewed federal, state, and local energy equity frameworks to identify additional relevant metrics.  Finally, the researchers ensured the resulting metrics covered equity concerns across the logic model of climate adaptation projects (inputs, activities, outputs, and outcomes).

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable. This is not an empirical study with a defined sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of existing frameworks and indicators to determine their relevance and applicability to the research questions.  The analysis involved evaluating the existing metrics against criteria related to their applicability, relevance, and alignment with current research on equity.

sections.title: Design and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study describes the design and implementation of a software harness that integrates reinforcement learning (RL) agents trained in a Python environment with a C++-based constructive simulation (AFSIM).  The methodology involves creating a C-based 'shim' using Python's ctypes module to bridge the language gap.  The harness isolates agent training from employment, allowing for efficient execution by running slow steps only once at the start. The RL gym trains agents using an abstract training space, where actions are interpreted as heading changes and observations are scaled values representing simulation elements.  The study also details the reward and penalty system used in the RL training, including strategies for avoiding reward hacking and optimizing training effectiveness through staged approaches and evaluation gyms.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses two constructive simulations: the RAND Target Accessibility Model and AFSIM.  In both, the scenario involves hostile aircraft attempting to penetrate an integrated air defense system (IADS).
analysis.analysis_approach: The effectiveness of the RL harness is demonstrated by training agents for the simulated scenarios.  Performance is compared with standard methods. The report focuses on the design and implementation of the harness, not on statistical analysis of the simulation results.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Combined Army physical fitness data (ACFT) with Defense Health Agency (DHA) injury data.  Used primary diagnosis codes (ICD-10-CM) to identify mechanical energy injuries, applying the APHC injury taxonomy.  Analyzed data for Regular Army soldiers from October 1, 2020, to March 31, 2023 (with primary focus on April 1, 2022, to October 1, 2022).  Divided injury risk analysis into three time windows: six months pre-ACFT, test day and seven days following, and six months post-ACFT. Descriptive statistics and Cox regression (survival analysis) were used.

sections.title: Literature Review Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Searched EBSCO, PubMed, and DTIC databases using PICTOSS terms (population, intervention, comparator, timing, outcome, setting, study).  Included military, first responders, and similar occupations; excluded elite athletes, pediatric, and geriatric populations.  Screened articles for military/military-like setting, physical fitness test prior to injury monitoring, and correlation between test performance and injury risk.  41 articles included for full-text analysis.

sections.title: Literature Review Results and Discussion
sections.methods_summary: Analyzed 41 articles.  Categorized studies by test type (periodic military PFTs, one-time tests), and test component event (cardiorespiratory, upper-body strength, core strength, functional fitness, lower-body strength). Summarized findings for each category.  Discussed limitations of studies (variability in injury definitions, measurement methods, follow-up periods, participant fitness levels).

analysis.sample_description: Regular Army active component soldiers; data from October 1, 2020, to March 31, 2023, with primary focus on April 1, 2022, to October 1, 2022.  Literature review included 41 studies on military, first responders, and similar physically demanding occupations.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, Cox regression (survival analysis) to examine the relationship between ACFT performance and injury risk, considering various time windows. Logistic regression used to calculate predicted probabilities of injury.  Literature review findings summarized by test type and component event.

sections.title: Data Sources and Estimation Approach (Enlisted Personnel)
sections.methods_summary: Quarterly TAPDB data (October 2001-July 2021) merged with RA Analyst data from time of accession.  Multiple observations per soldier.  Actual and adjusted outcomes estimated using linear probability models.  Simulation of racial-ethnic composition changes over career using chained predicted probabilities.

sections.title: Outcomes (Enlisted Personnel)
sections.methods_summary: Definition of key outcome variables: failure-to-adapt attrition, completion of initial service obligation, retention after first term, early promotion to E-5, reduction in grade from E-5, suspension of favorable personnel action.

sections.title: Key Predictors and Covariates (Enlisted Personnel)
sections.methods_summary: Definition of key predictors and covariates: race (White, Black, Hispanic, AAPI, Native American, Other), MOS (first two digits), demographic covariates (accession year, education, gender, marital status, age, AFQT score), military covariates (enlistment bonus, contract length, paygrade, MOS at enlistment).

sections.title: Approach (Enlisted Personnel)
sections.methods_summary: Two estimates for each outcome: actual (identical to average outcome by race/ethnicity) and adjusted (controlling for soldier characteristics using linear probability model). Sensitivity analyses comparing linear probability and logistic models.  Simulation of racial-ethnic composition changes over career using chained predicted probabilities.

sections.title: Quantitative Methods (Enlisted Personnel)
sections.methods_summary: Quarterly TAPDB data (October 2001-July 2021) merged with RA Analyst data.  One observation per soldier, covariates measured at first observation.  American Community Survey data used to determine local labor market strength.  Linear probability models (OLS) used to estimate actual and adjusted outcomes.  Simulation of career progression using chained predicted probabilities.

sections.title: Data and Outcomes (Commissioned Officers)
sections.methods_summary: Monthly TAPDB data (October 2001-January 2022).  One record per officer per grade.  Analysis of career progression as sequential decision points (retention and promotion).  Eligibility month for promotion imputed using data on 90th percentile of promotions.

sections.title: Estimation Approach (Commissioned Officers)
sections.methods_summary: Logistic regressions used to estimate actual and adjusted retention and promotion rates.  Adjusted rates control for gender, age, marital status, children, accession source, branch, FY, and (where relevant) below-the-zone promotion.

sections.title: Interview Materials
sections.methods_summary: Semi-structured interviews with 33 Army unit leaders (14 officers, 19 senior NCOs). Separate protocols for officers and senior enlisted.  Transcript-style notes coded using Dedoose software. Three-member coding team (one senior coder, two junior coders).  Inter-rater reliability check on four transcripts.  Secondary coding to analyze themes across codes.

sections.title: Qualitative Coding Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Transcript-style notes coded using Dedoose. Three-member coding team (one senior coder, two junior coders). Inter-rater reliability check on four transcripts. Coding structure developed based on interview questions, refined during coding process. Secondary coding conducted to analyze themes across codes.

analysis.sample_description: 33 Army unit leaders (14 officers, 19 senior NCOs) interviewed;  Quantitative data from TAPDB and American Community Survey.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive analysis of racial-ethnic composition changes over time.  Regression analysis to estimate effects of observable factors on retention and career outcomes.  Qualitative analysis of interview data to identify themes and potential barriers to retention.

sections.title: 1.3. Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methods used for the formative evaluation.  These include document and data review (monthly, quarterly, and annual reports; minutes from panel meetings; ESRC meetings; business and policy stakeholder group meetings; audit reports; applicant and award holder data), process mapping (mapping the governance structures of the PIP, TPI, and POID), key informant interviews (15 interviews with stakeholders categorized into wider POID and TPI research teams, representatives from TPI regional forums, the Productivity Commission, and the POID advisory board, wider UKRI stakeholders, and initial consultations with thematic investments), and a workshop with key PIP stakeholders (POID, TPI, ESRC, RAND Europe, and Frontier Economics).

analysis.sample_description: The key informant interviews included 15 stakeholders categorized into four groups: wider POID and TPI research team members (n=9), representatives from TPI regional forums, the Productivity Commission, and the POID advisory board (n=2), wider UKRI stakeholders (n=3), and initial consultations with thematic investments (n=1).
analysis.analysis_approach: The data collected through the various methods were used to address the process evaluation questions (PEQs) agreed upon with the client (ESRC).  Findings were mapped to the evaluation questions, and a workshop was used to test and validate emerging findings and share learnings.

sections.title: Field Familiarization and Training Operations
sections.methods_summary: Observations of trainings at one HSI SRT and one ERO pilot site (15 and 9 participants respectively).  Observations included gear issuance, BWC operation, practical exercises, docking/uploading, VMS use, legal issues, and video review.  Observations of one HSI SRT operation staging. Observations of ERO officers in training at the Federal Law Enforcement Training Center with abbreviated BWC familiarization. Ride-alongs at three ERO pilot sites to observe operations while wearing BWCs, including briefings, surveillance, and arrests. Feedback collected through one-on-one or focus group interviews.

sections.title: Interviews
sections.methods_summary: Semi-structured interviews with HSI SRT and ERO personnel at pilot sites and after pilot conclusion.  Interview questions covered benefits, drawbacks, challenges, BWC wear, safety, VMS use, and policy considerations.  One-on-one and focus group interviews (up to 25 personnel).  Five interviews with subject-matter experts and NGO representatives focusing on policy, implementation, and operational environment considerations.

sections.title: Quantitative Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of HSI SRT survey data (10-week periods), complaint data, use-of-force data, and OFTP-collected training data (surveys, observations on BWC placement and activation).  Note: Limited quantitative analysis of ERO data due to study scope and timing.  Outcome analysis limited by low incident rates and lack of statistical power.

sections.title: Analytic Framework
sections.methods_summary: Used the Body-Worn Camera Policy Review Scorecard (modified and extended with recommendations from other sources) to assess the pilot program and ICE policy.  Observation and interview notes coded to match key policy areas. Findings and recommendations presented in approximate order of items in the framework.

sections.title: Summary of the Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods ethnographic approach.  Combined data analysis, literature review, policy considerations, and observations of trainings and field use. Semi-structured interviews with ICE personnel after observed field activities.  Data collected by ICE used to support observations.  Specific areas of work included field familiarization and training observations, interviews, quantitative analysis, literature review, application of an analytic framework, interviews with subject-matter experts and NGO representatives, and provision of results and recommendations.

analysis.sample_description: HSI SRT and ERO personnel at seven pilot sites (four HSI and three ERO).  Data for Newark and New York HSI sites pooled.  ERO pilot delayed due to labor negotiations; some ERO data from training environments.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data coded to reflect key areas of interest. Quantitative data analyzed to assess BWC associations with outcomes (use of force, complaints).  Outcome analysis limited by low incident rates and lack of statistical power for HSI SRT data; no analysis of ERO data for these metrics.  Analytic framework based on Body-Worn Camera Policy Review Scorecard and other sources.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach combining literature reviews, subject-matter expert elicitations (meetings, workshops, electronic contacts, in-person interviews), and an online assessment of policing agencies in California and Massachusetts.  Coverage maps were developed using the Naval Research Laboratory Builder radio frequency modeling package. The study acknowledges limitations due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the limited scope of providers and agencies included.

analysis.sample_description: The study included in-person interviews with experts from four agencies and an online assessment of over 30 policing agencies in California and Massachusetts.  The sample was not exhaustive, representing a subset of agencies and providers.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved synthesizing information from literature reviews, interviews, and online assessments to inform the guidance document.  Coverage modeling was conducted using the Naval Research Laboratory Builder radio frequency modeling package to compare different communications technologies.

sections.title: Prototyping an Acquisition Policy Game
sections.methods_summary: A structured seminar-style game was designed and prototyped to examine the Middle-Tier Acquisition (MTA) pathway.  Nine RAND experts (former project managers, PEOs, and leaders of acquisition research programs) played the game, reviewing program descriptions using a structured assessment tool. They made recommendations on acquisition pathways (middle-tier prototype, middle-tier fielding, traditional 5000 series, or urgent capability), and assessed program risk (performance, cost, schedule).  An adjudication process, combining program risk assessment and player-developed acquisition strategies, projected program performance two and four years into the future, incorporating an element of chance to reflect uncontrollable factors. Players could update their acquisition strategies and pathway choices based on the projected outcomes.

analysis.sample_description: Nine RAND experts with diverse acquisition experience, including former project managers, former service program executive officers (PEOs), and leaders of RAND’s acquisition research programs.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of player decisions and observations from the game, focusing on insights into MTA policy design and implementation.

sections.title: Chapter 3. Needs Assessment Components and Approach
sections.methods_summary: This chapter details the methodology used in the needs assessment.  It involved a literature review of relevant journal articles, gray literature, policy documents, and websites focusing on U.S.-based women veterans' experiences since 2010.  A quantitative assessment utilized the U.S. Census Bureau's American Community Survey (ACS) data for 23 counties in the Adagio Health service area to analyze demographic characteristics of women veterans and non-veterans.  A patient data analysis examined de-identified individual-level data from Adagio Health's systems on 890 veteran women patients and 25,846 non-veteran women patients.  Statistical tests (t-tests and chi-squared tests) were used to compare groups. A landscape analysis involved a document review of Adagio Health materials and an inventory of programs, services, and supports for women veterans using the National Resource Directory, United Way's 211 database, and RAND's MATTR database. Finally, a qualitative assessment involved semi-structured interviews with 13 stakeholders and 12 women veterans.

analysis.sample_description: The quantitative assessment used data from the 2016-2020 American Community Survey (ACS) for 23 counties in the Adagio Health service area. The patient data analysis included de-identified data from 890 veteran women patients and 25,846 non-veteran women patients at Adagio Health from January 2018 to April 2022. The qualitative assessment involved semi-structured interviews with 13 stakeholders and 12 women veterans.
analysis.analysis_approach: T-tests and chi-squared tests were used to compare veteran and non-veteran women in the quantitative analyses.  The qualitative data from interviews were analyzed thematically to identify key challenges and gaps in support.

sections.title: Appendix: Methods Used in This Report
sections.methods_summary: The report is based on qualitative interviews conducted with Sheppard Pratt leadership and a small group of patients and family members. Twelve interviews were conducted with Sheppard Pratt leadership in December 2021, focusing on the scope of operations, perceived advantages, and ongoing challenges.  A structured interview protocol was used. Interview notes were coded using an open coding system and then a common coding structure developed through team discussions. The three major themes (continuum of care, integration, and financing) structured the report's chapters.

analysis.sample_description: Twelve interviews with Sheppard Pratt leadership and a small number of patients and family members.
analysis.analysis_approach: Open coding system initially, followed by development of a common coding structure based on team discussions of codes and emerging themes.  Thematic analysis used to structure the report.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This report is a combined effort of the RAND Corporation and the Asan Institute. Chapters 2 through 6 were each drafted by one RAND expert and one Asan expert.  The authors draw from their threat assessments and policy analyses experiences, updating this expertise to current Korean peninsula circumstances.  It draws on the authors' substantial examination of Korean security and WMD, decades of monitoring open literature, discussions with numerous U.S. and ROK officials and experts, experts on North Korean WMD and cyber threats, officials and experts from China, Japan, and Russia, and senior North Korean escapees. The authors have performed many analyses of North Korea and its WMD and cyber threats and directed/participated in dozens of wargames.  The authors identify how North Korea could plausibly use its WMD and cyber threats, using their knowledge of military operations in Korea and tools such as online damage assessment procedures and rules of thumb.  The report uses only open information (including information from North Korean escapees).

analysis.sample_description: The study draws on the authors' expertise and decades of experience, including discussions with hundreds of U.S. and ROK officials and experts, dozens of experts on North Korean WMD and cyber threats, dozens of officials and experts from China, Japan, and Russia, and dozens of senior North Korean escapees.
analysis.analysis_approach: The authors identify how North Korea could plausibly use its WMD and cyber threats.  They use their knowledge of military operations in Korea and various tools to assess the potential impact of these uses, including online damage assessment procedures and previously prepared simple rules of thumb.  The analysis considers North Korean capabilities and vulnerabilities to identify and evaluate means for countering the North Korean capabilities and exploiting the North’s vulnerabilities.

sections.title: Sampling and Survey Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used a stratified sampling design to select 173 census blocks across California.  Stratification was based on geographic (7 regions, 15 land-cover classifications) and demographic (5 major cities, 7 regions, California Hard-to-Count Index tertiles) factors.  Data collection involved three phases: 1) Block observations (in-person visits to verify boundaries and identify challenges); 2) Address listing (complete canvassing of each block to identify and document every housing unit); 3) Enumeration (complete enumeration of residents in each housing unit using web, mail, CATI, and CAPI surveys).  Extensive community outreach was conducted to promote the study and gain cooperation.

sections.title: Data Collection Methods
sections.methods_summary: Detailed descriptions of the three phases of data collection are provided: Phase 1: Block Observations (in-person visits by field supervisors to verify boundaries, identify challenges, and gather information); Phase 2: Address Listing (using electronic forms and iPhones, door-to-door canvassing to create a complete list of housing units, including updates to block maps and multiple attempts to verify information with residents); Phase 3: Enumeration (multi-mode survey administration—web, mail, CATI, and CAPI—with multiple attempts to contact households, including refusal conversion strategies and COVID-19 safety protocols).

sections.title: Strategies to Maximize Response Rates, Interviewer Productivity, and Quality Assurance
sections.methods_summary: Multiple strategies were employed to maximize response rates, including multiple reminders, outreach to gatekeepers, refusal aversion training, and a shortened survey.  To increase interviewer productivity and reduce attrition, a bonus scheme was implemented.  Quality assurance involved shadowing interviewers, regular staff meetings, phone validation of surveys, and review of timesheets and incentive receipts.

sections.title: Response Rates, Imputation, and Adjustment Strategies
sections.methods_summary: Response rates are reported for partial and full responses, broken down by various characteristics.  Missing data were addressed using imputation, with 83 different imputation approaches considered.  The preferred approach used random forests with tree depth 1, leveraging auxiliary data from address canvassing, administrative records (real estate tax data, voter registration data, Medi-Cal data), and the Bayesian Improved Surname Geocoding (BISG) method. A staged imputation approach was used, first imputing the total number of residents, then race/ethnicity/age for the primary respondent, and finally for other household members.  Extrapolation to higher geographic levels (county and state) was done using weights that account for the sample design.

sections.title: Comparison of 2020 Census Counts with CNC Responses
sections.methods_summary: Comparisons between CNC estimates and 2020 Census counts were made at the block, county, and state levels.  Block-level comparisons are presented graphically, showing the relationship between CNC estimates and census counts.  County-level comparisons used survey weights to extrapolate from sampled blocks to the county level.  Housing unit counts are also compared, with and without occupancy status.

primary_methods: Multi-phase data collection (block observation, address listing, enumeration)
Multi-mode survey administration (web, mail, CATI, CAPI)
analysis.sample_description: A stratified sample of 173 census blocks in 43 California counties, aiming for approximately 25,000 housing units. Oversampling of hard-to-count blocks was conducted.
analysis.analysis_approach: Comparisons of CNC estimates and census counts at block, county, and state levels.  Graphical representations and weighted extrapolations were used.  Sensitivity analysis of imputation methods was performed.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This chapter describes the data and methods used in the analysis.  It includes information on the CMS reporting requirement, data sources (Medicare FFS final action professional claims from the CMS Integrated Data Repository), exclusion criteria for modifiers and ASC facility records, use of the Physician Time File from the 2018 Physician Fee Schedule to obtain expected post-operative visits, inclusion criteria for analyzing procedures, linking procedures and post-operative visits, and calculation of outcomes (share of procedures with post-operative visits and observed-to-expected ratios).

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Describes the CMS reporting requirement, data sources (Medicare FFS claims from the CMS Integrated Data Repository), data exclusions (modifiers, ASC facility records), identification of claims for post-operative visits, use of the Physician Time File for expected visit counts, identification of expected reporters (practitioners in nine states with practices of 10+ practitioners), linking procedures and post-operative visits (based on service dates, beneficiary ID, and global period length), calculation of outcomes (share of procedures with post-operative visits and observed-to-expected ratios), identification of practitioners who frequently report post-operative visits (those performing 10+ clean procedures with 90-day global periods and reporting at least one post-operative visit for at least half of these procedures), and identification of other services and procedures occurring during global periods (E&M visits and other procedures, with variations in the scope of inclusion).

sections.title: Chapter 4: Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: Focuses on the nine states with mandatory reporting. Analyzes procedures meeting specific inclusion criteria (required procedure codes, performed between January 1, 2018, and December 31, 2018, by an expected reporter). Examines post-operative visits within the specified period, including visits up to January 10, 2019 (10-day global periods) and March 31, 2019 (90-day global periods). Reporting rates are examined by specialty, state, and practice size.

sections.title: Chapter 5: Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: Uses procedures as the unit of analysis, focusing on 'clean procedures' (one billed unit of service, not within the global period of another procedure).  Analyzes procedures meeting specific inclusion criteria. Reports timing of post-operative visits, share of procedures with any reported visits, and observed-to-expected ratios of post-operative visits. Outcomes are reported separately for 10- and 90-day global periods, and by practice size, place of service, and specialty.

sections.title: Chapter 6: Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: Analyzes clean procedures performed by 'robust reporters' (practitioners performing 10+ clean procedures with 90-day global periods and reporting at least one post-operative visit for at least half of these procedures).  Compares patterns of care among robust reporters with high-volume reporters (those billing 10+ procedures with 90-day global periods). Outcomes are reported separately for 10- and 90-day global periods, and by practice size, place of service, and specialty.

sections.title: Chapter 7: Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: Uses procedures as the unit of analysis, focusing on 'clean procedures' and specific inclusion criteria.  Expands the definition of post-operative visits in three ways: (1) adding E&M visits by the original procedure practitioner; (2) adding E&M visits and procedures by the original procedure practitioner; (3) adding E&M visits and procedures by anyone in the same practice with the same specialty as the original procedure practitioner.  Counts total days with these services. Reports share of procedures with any post-operative visits and observed-to-expected ratios.

sections.title: Appendix A: Examining Characteristics of Clean Procedures - Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: Examines all procedures with 10- or 90-day global periods (January 1, 2018 - December 31, 2018), not limited to expected reporters. Groups beneficiary episodes of care into four categories: clean procedures, multiple procedures on the same day (same or different global period lengths), and subsequent procedures on different days within a prior procedure's global period.  Examines procedure volume by specialty, HCPCS codes, and CPT book headings.

sections.title: Appendix B: Identifying Robust Reporters of Post-Operative Visits - Defining Robust Reporters
sections.methods_summary: Explores different definitions of 'robust reporters' by varying thresholds for total procedures furnished with 90-day global periods (1+, 10+, 20+, 30+) and the percentage of eligible procedures with post-operative visits (25%, 50%, 75%, 90%, 95%, all).  Focuses on clean procedures with 90-day global periods.

sections.title: Appendix D: Exploring Visits Immediately Following Global Periods - Approach
sections.methods_summary: Examines clean procedures linked to post-operative visits during global periods. Counts post-operative visits (HCPCS code 99024) during global periods and within the first five days after global periods end.  Acknowledges limitations due to potential association of post-global-period visits with new procedures.

sections.title: Appendix E: Comparison of the Timing of Post-Operative Visits and the Fraction of Expected Post-Operative Visits Reported Using Two Methods to Identify Clean Procedures - Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: Replicates Chapter 5 analyses using two clean procedure definitions: (1) primary clean procedures (as defined in the main report); (2) alternative clean procedures (excluding procedures with overlapping global periods).  Details on linking post-operative visits to clean procedures remain unchanged.

analysis.sample_description: Medicare fee-for-service beneficiaries in nine states who received procedures with 10- or 90-day global periods from July 1, 2017 to December 31, 2018.  Sub-samples include only those in practices with 10 or more practitioners, and further sub-samples focus on 'robust reporters' and 'high-volume reporters'.  Analysis is primarily limited to 'clean procedures' (single procedures not overlapping with other procedures with global periods).
analysis.analysis_approach: The study uses claims data to determine the number of post-operative visits reported using HCPCS code 99024.  This is compared to the expected number of visits from the Physician Time File.  Various sensitivity analyses are conducted to address potential underreporting and alternative definitions of post-operative care.  The primary outcomes are the share of procedures with any post-operative visits and the ratio of observed-to-expected post-operative visits.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources (Medicare FFS final action professional claims from the CMS Integrated Data Repository), inclusion/exclusion criteria for procedures (modifiers, ASC facility records), data linkage methods (procedure-level linking based on dates of service, beneficiary ID, and global period length; handling of multiple procedures), definition of clean procedures, calculation of outcomes (percentage of practitioners reporting post-operative visits, share of procedures with any reported post-operative visits, observed-to-expected ratio of post-operative visits), identification of frequent reporters, and methods for identifying other services/procedures during global periods (counting E&M visits and other procedures, handling of double-counting).

sections.title: Chapter 3: Examining the Number of Post-Operative Visits Reported - Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: Weekly counts of HCPCS code 99024 claims from January 1, 2017, to December 31, 2019, were calculated for the nine states with mandatory reporting.  Comparison of pre- and post-July 1, 2017 (start of mandatory reporting) visit counts was performed to assess the impact of the reporting requirement.

sections.title: Chapter 4: Examining the Share of Practitioners Engaged in Claims-Based Reporting of Post-Operative Visits - Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: Analysis focused on the nine states with mandatory reporting. Inclusion criteria for procedures were the same as in Chapter 2. Reporting rates were examined by specialty, state, and practice size.  Post-operative visits were included regardless of who performed them.

sections.title: Chapter 5: Timing of Post-Operative Visits and the Share of Expected Post-Operative Visits Reported - Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: Analysis was limited to clean procedures (as defined in Chapter 2).  The unit of analysis was the procedure. Timing of post-operative visits was reported. The share of procedures with any reported post-operative visits and the observed-to-expected ratio of post-operative visits were calculated. Outcomes were reported separately for 10- and 90-day global periods and by practice size, place of service, and specialty.

sections.title: Chapter 6: Sensitivity Analysis: Examining Procedures Performed by Practitioners Actively Reporting Post-Operative Visits - Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: Analysis focused on clean procedures performed by "robust reporters" (defined as practitioners who performed ≥10 clean procedures with 90-day global periods and reported ≥1 post-operative visit for at least half of those procedures).  Robust reporters were compared with high-volume practitioners (≥10 clean procedures with 90-day global periods, regardless of reporting). Outcomes were reported separately for 10- and 90-day global periods and by practice size, place of service, and specialty.

sections.title: Chapter 7: Sensitivity Analysis: Using an Expanded Definition of Post-Operative Visits - Methods Overview
