sections.methods_summary: Used the procedure as the unit of analysis and analyzed clean procedures meeting the inclusion criteria from previous chapters. Three expanded definitions of post-operative visits were used: (1) adding E&M visits by the original procedure practitioner; (2) adding E&M visits and procedures by the original procedure practitioner; (3) adding E&M visits and procedures by any practitioner in the same practice and specialty as the original procedure practitioner. Total days with services were counted to avoid double-counting. The share of procedures with any post-operative visits and the observed-to-expected ratio were calculated.

sections.title: Appendix A: Examining Characteristics of Clean Procedures - Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: Examined all procedures with 10- or 90-day global periods from January 1, 2019, to December 31, 2019, without limiting to expected reporters. Procedures were categorized into four groups: clean procedures, multiple procedures on the same day (same or different global period lengths), and subsequent procedures on different days within a prior procedure's global period.  Volume of these categories was examined by specialty, HCPCS codes, and CPT book headings.

sections.title: Appendix B: Identifying Robust Reporters of Post-Operative Visits
sections.methods_summary: Explored different definitions of "robust reporters" by varying thresholds for total procedures with 90-day global periods and the percentage of those procedures with post-operative visits.  The final definition used was ≥10 clean procedures with 90-day global periods and reporting of at least one post-operative visit for at least half of those procedures. Characteristics of procedures furnished by robust reporters and high-volume practitioners were compared.

sections.title: Appendix D: Exploring Visits Immediately Following Global Periods
sections.methods_summary: Examined clean procedures linked to post-operative visits during global periods.  Counted post-operative visits (HCPCS code 99024) within and up to five days after global periods ended. Determined the percentage of procedures with post-operative visits (HCPCS code 99024 and E&M codes) on each of the first 15 days after global periods ended.  Acknowledged limitations in linking visits to specific procedures after the global period.

sections.title: Appendix E: Comparison of the Share of Post-Operative Visits Using Two Methods to Identify Clean Procedures
sections.methods_summary: Replicated analyses from Chapter 5 using two definitions of clean procedures: (1) primary (as defined in the main text) and (2) alternative (excluding procedures with overlapping global periods).  Compared the share of procedures with post-operative visits and the observed-to-expected ratio under both definitions.

analysis.sample_description: Medicare fee-for-service claims data for procedures furnished during calendar year 2019 in nine states with mandatory reporting of post-operative visits (Florida, Kentucky, Louisiana, Nevada, New Jersey, North Dakota, Ohio, Oregon, and Rhode Island).  The sample included practitioners in practices with ten or more practitioners.  Sub-analyses focused on specific subsets of practitioners (e.g., robust reporters, high-volume practitioners).
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis focused on calculating the share of procedures with any reported post-operative visits and the ratio of observed to expected post-operative visits.  Numerous sensitivity analyses were conducted to address potential biases and confounding factors, including variations in the definition of clean procedures, inclusion/exclusion of specific practitioner groups, and expansion of the definition of post-operative care to include E&M visits and other procedures.

sections.title: Chapter 2. Methods of data collection
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods approach combining qualitative and quantitative data.  Methods included a literature review, two ambulance staff surveys (Years 1 and 3), two site visits to ambulance trusts, analysis of the NHS Staff Survey, interviews and focus groups with members of the public, frontline staff, trust project managers, and trade union representatives, and analysis of data from Video Manager software.  Details on each method are provided in Annex B, with survey, interview, and focus group questions and protocols in Annexes C-I.

sections.title: Annex B. Data collection and research methods
sections.methods_summary: Details of data collection methods for each year of the study. Year 1: Theory of change development, ambulance staff survey (985 responses), frontline ambulance staff interviews (9 interviews), member of the public interview (2 participants), focus groups with project managers (19 participants) and trade union representatives (6 participants). Year 2: Analysis of NHS Staff Survey data, desk research on BWCs in other contexts, site visit and deep dive in an ambulance station. Year 3: Analysis of Video Manager data, ambulance staff survey (1260 responses), interviews with BWC project managers (10 interviews), focus groups with members of the public (8 participants), and frontline ambulance staff (two groups, one with women only and one mixed gender).  Specific details on sampling, data collection instruments, and analysis techniques are provided for each method.

primary_methods: Data analysis (Video Manager, NHS Staff Survey)
analysis.sample_description: The study involved ambulance staff across 11 trusts in England, members of the public, trust project managers, and trade union representatives. Sample sizes varied across data collection methods, with some smaller samples limiting generalizability of findings.  Surveys were not fully representative of the ambulance staff population in terms of demographics.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics were used for quantitative data. Qualitative data from interviews and focus groups were analyzed thematically.  Cross-analysis of survey data was conducted to explore relationships between variables.  Video Manager data was analyzed descriptively to track BWC deployments and reported incidents.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: A multimethod approach consisting of a literature review, analysis of databases on Chinese foreign investments, and in-depth interviews with stakeholders.  Case studies focused on coal-fired power plants, electricity transmission infrastructure (Global Energy Interconnection initiative), and seabed mining. Case study topics and regions were selected by the sponsor (U.S. Department of State’s Global Engagement Center).

sections.title: Interview Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Interviews were conducted with representatives from six stakeholder organization types (intergovernmental, U.S. government, other government, industry, expert, watchdog/press). Interviews were conducted on a not-for-attribution basis.  Attempts were made to include the Chinese perspective, but these were unsuccessful.

analysis.sample_description: The sample included representatives from six stakeholder organization types (intergovernmental, U.S. government, other government, industry, expert, watchdog/press) across multiple countries.  The case studies focused on specific countries and subsectors of investment.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data and quantitative analysis of investment data from databases (e.g., Global Coal Plant Tracker).

sections.title: Overview of the NCF Risk Assessment Framework
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the framework used to assess risk to National Critical Functions (NCFs) from COVID-19.  It details the assessment end point (disruption or degradation of NCFs), drivers of risk (core commodity supply shortage, worker shortage, increased demand, decreased demand, change in cyber posture), time horizon (60 days, rolling), probability levels (low, medium, high), risk rating development (expert assessment by a team of >50 analysts), indicator identification and data source selection, risk assessment template design, and the use of a risk assessment dashboard for presentation of results.  The methods involved three phases of implementation.

sections.title: Challenges and Opportunities Identified in Applying the NCF Risk Assessment Framework
sections.methods_summary: This section describes challenges and adjustments made during the implementation of the NCF risk assessment framework.  Methods included comparing risk ratings from HSOAC and NRMC analysts to identify discrepancies, addressing issues related to NCF aggregation and definition, indicator selection and refinement, handling of complex inputs, clarifying the focus on likelihood vs. consequences of disruption, addressing bias toward high risk ratings, and handling the national vs. regional impact of disruptions.  Two types of risk reports were generated: long-form assessments and weekly risk reports.

sections.title: Additional Opportunities to Expand and Improve the NCF Risk Assessment Framework
sections.methods_summary: This section details further analyses conducted to improve the framework.  Methods included examining indicators used in the COVID-19 assessment based on various factors (number per NCF and driver, utilization across phases, source type, update frequency, data quality, predictive value, robustness beyond COVID-19).  Analysis of risk mitigation strategies involved analyzing the changing risk landscape, identifying common adaptation responses, and reviewing CISA's activities in supporting risk mitigation.  Interviews with CISA's NIAC members and NRMC personnel were conducted.  Analysis of NCF interdependence involved visualizing economic linkages between NCFs and estimating value-added multipliers.  Analysis of vulnerability focused on workplace and worker vulnerabilities using Department of Labor data on job duties and social interaction, linked with demographic information.  Geographic analysis involved examining the geographic distribution and concentration of NCFs and identifying data gaps.

sections.title: Conclusions and Action Items for the NRMC
sections.methods_summary: This section summarizes the findings and provides action items for the NRMC.  The methods used to reach these conclusions are implicit in the previous sections and involve analysis of the data collected and the challenges and opportunities identified in applying the NCF risk assessment framework.

analysis.sample_description: The study involved the 55 National Critical Functions (NCFs) defined by CISA.  Data was collected from various sources, including government agencies, industry sources, and media.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved a multi-phased approach, starting with initial risk assessments and transitioning to weekly updates.  The analysis incorporated qualitative and quantitative methods, including expert judgment, data analysis, economic modeling, and geographic analysis.  Comparisons were made between HSOAC and NRMC risk ratings to identify discrepancies and areas for improvement.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A survey experiment was conducted using Qualtrics, randomizing 5000 respondents (a representative sample of the U.S. population) to either a human or an AI decision-maker in two scenarios: one on hiring and the other on unemployment benefits.  The scenarios were identical except for the decision-maker.  Respondents answered questions about fairness, accuracy, transparency, bias, and willingness to take legal action.  Demographic data and other relevant variables (computer literacy, political orientation, belief in meritocracy, confidence in the legal system, etc.) were also collected.  Attentiveness checks were included. Descriptive analyses and Fischer's exact test were used to analyze the data.

analysis.sample_description: 5000 respondents, a representative sample of the U.S. population, randomized into AI and human decision-maker groups for two scenarios.  Quotas were used to ensure representativeness across age, gender, region, race, income, and education.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive analyses and Fischer's exact test were used to explore relationships between categorical variables.

sections.title: Chapter 2. Methods
sections.methods_summary: Two general population surveys of California residents were conducted: a baseline survey before the campaign launch and a follow-up survey one year later.  Surveys were reviewed and approved by RAND’s Human Subjects Protection Committee.

sections.title: Data Collection and Measures
sections.methods_summary: Data was collected using online surveys administered by Ipsos KnowledgePanel, with a probability-based sample of California adults (N=1284 at baseline, N=1588 at follow-up).  Oversampling of Spanish-speaking and rural respondents was conducted. Sample weighting was used to ensure demographic representativeness. The survey included measures of demographics, campaign exposure, mental health knowledge and attitudes, experience with mental health challenges, use of mental health resources, stigmatizing attitudes, barriers to treatment, and suicide prevention.

sections.title: Analyses
sections.methods_summary: Descriptive analyses, chi-square tests, logistic regressions were used to analyze the data. Sample weights were applied to account for differential nonresponse.  A 0.01 significance level was used for statistical significance. SAS/STAT software was used for analysis.

analysis.sample_description: Two probability-based samples of California adults, with oversampling of Spanish-speaking and rural residents.  A subset of participants (n=538) participated in both surveys. Sample size of 1,284 at baseline and 1,583 at follow-up (after removing 5 incomplete responses). Sample weighted to be representative of the California adult population.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, chi-square tests to compare distributions of outcomes across demographic groups, logistic regressions to predict outcomes based on demographic variables and campaign exposure. Longitudinal analyses (N=538) were conducted to assess changes in outcomes over time, controlling for baseline values and demographics.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research involved a series of interviews with experts from government, academia, and private industry, a literature review, and a "Day After..." exercise with a small group of RAND subject-matter experts.

analysis.sample_description: Experts from government, academia, and private industry were interviewed.  A small group of RAND subject-matter experts participated in the "Day After..." exercise.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative assessment of potential risks from a disruption scenario.  Synthesis of participant suggestions from the "Day After..." exercise with prior research.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for two comparisons. Comparison 1 uses a triple difference-in-differences model to compare changes in proficiency rates for SEPs and MLs in Delaware with those in Connecticut and Washington, controlling for state-specific and group-specific factors. Comparison 2 uses regression analysis to compare proficiency rates between Delaware schools that did and did not expend Opportunity Funding and SSBG funds, controlling for student demographics, per-pupil expenditures, and prior achievement.  An auxiliary analysis using quantile regression examines achievement gaps across the test score distribution.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from Delaware, Connecticut, and Washington.  The Delaware sample includes student-level administrative data (demographics, enrollment, SBAC scores), school-level achievement data, and LEA-level expenditure data.  Connecticut and Washington data include school-level SBAC proficiency rates for SEPs and MLs.
analysis.analysis_approach: Two main comparisons are conducted. Comparison 1 uses a triple difference-in-differences model to estimate the impact of funding changes on student achievement, controlling for various factors. Comparison 2 uses regression analysis to examine the association between school expenditures and student achievement, controlling for student and school characteristics. An auxiliary analysis uses quantile regression to investigate achievement gaps across different points of the test score distribution.

sections.title: Study Aim and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study collected and synthesized existing research, data, and resources to develop a prototype road map for pension reform.  Discussions were held with 3 subject-matter experts to supplement existing research and data.  The analysis focused on identifying dimensions of pension crises, reviewing existing knowledge, and identifying available tools and resources to inform reform pathways.  The study did not conduct new analyses to fill gaps in existing knowledge.

sections.title: Chapter 2. Pension Finance and Funding History: Actuarial Terminology, Methods, and Assumptions; Accounting and Reporting Standards for State and Local Pensions; State and Local Pension Plan Funding 2002-2020
sections.methods_summary: This section describes actuarial methods for valuing pension liabilities (actuarial present value, actuarial cost method, normal cost, actuarial accrued liability, unfunded actuarial liability) and the assumptions underlying these methods (economic and demographic assumptions, discount rate).  It reviews accounting and reporting standards (GASB statements) for state and local pensions.  Aggregate statistics on pension plan funding from 2002-2020 are presented using the Public Plans Data database, including calculations of funded ratios, investment returns, contributions, and portfolio allocations.  Weighted averages by state and cross-state averages are calculated, giving equal weight to each state.  The analysis separates experiences before and after the Great Recession to isolate its impact.

sections.title: Chapter 2. Pension Finance and Funding History: Summary
sections.methods_summary: Summarizes findings from the previous sections of Chapter 2, highlighting the use of Public Plans Data and calculations of weighted and cross-state averages.

sections.title: Chapter 4. Pension Plan Reforms
sections.methods_summary: This chapter analyzes pension reforms from 2009-2021 using data from Brainard and Brown (2018b) and NASRA (2021), along with a review of statewide system Annual Comprehensive Financial Reports.  The analysis focuses on the prevalence of reforms (increasing employee contributions, reducing benefits, changing plan types) and whether they apply to current or new employees.  Statewide system reforms are treated as state reforms to standardize comparisons.  The chapter also compares findings with those of other researchers, including simulations of retention effects using parameters estimated from data on South Carolina teachers.

sections.title: Chapter 6. Major Themes from Discussions with Subject-Matter Experts: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Eight semi-structured interviews were conducted with pension plan administrators, political leaders, and other experts.  Participants were selected from 16 state and local pension systems meeting specific criteria (funding decline and recovery, major reforms, attempted reforms).  A semi-structured interview protocol was used to gather information on factors contributing to underfunding, motivations for reforms, other policies used to address underfunding, and consequences of reforms.  Specific systems and experts are not identified to protect anonymity.

analysis.sample_description: The quantitative analysis uses data from the Public Plans Data database covering 210 state and local pension plans (95% of state/local pension assets and members). The qualitative analysis involves interviews with 8 experts from a range of state and municipal pension systems selected based on criteria related to funding performance and reform efforts.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study uses a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative analysis of existing data with qualitative analysis of interviews.  Quantitative analysis involves descriptive statistics (averages, medians, distributions) and potentially regression analysis (implied from references to other studies). Qualitative analysis involves thematic analysis of interview transcripts.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Citation analysis of prior art in Chinese military patents (Derwent Innovation Index).

sections.title: Chapter 3: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of publication data from Scopus (2011-2020) to track researcher affiliation changes between US and Chinese universities.  Researchers categorized into affiliation-change categories (No Change, In-Country, Migrate, Travel, Return). Analysis includes quantitative assessment of affiliation changes, origin affiliation, and the role of multi-affiliations. Qualitative assessment involves analysis of average citations per author and keywords associated with researchers.

sections.title: Chapter 4: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of publication data from Web of Science (2001-2020) focusing on aerospace engineering.  International collaborations defined as publications with authors from different countries.  Analysis includes examination of collaborations with Seven Sons universities and PLA-affiliated organizations.  Content analysis of publications (target tracking) for dual-use and military-relevant terms. Assessment of research impact (citations) and interdisciplinarity (number of WOS topic categories).

analysis.sample_description: Chapter 2: 2,728 Chinese military patents (2016-2020). Chapter 3: Publication data for researchers affiliated with top 10 US and Chinese universities and Seven Sons universities (2011-2020). Chapter 4: Publication data for aerospace engineering (2001-2020).
analysis.analysis_approach: Chapter 2: Analysis of patent citations to identify sources of prior art. Chapter 3: Quantitative and qualitative analysis of researcher affiliation changes, including citation counts and keyword analysis. Chapter 4: Analysis of collaboration patterns, content analysis of publications, and assessment of research impact and interdisciplinarity.

sections.title: Research Approach (Preface)
sections.methods_summary: The research drew on a wide range of publications in French and English, as well as conversations with French defense experts (journalists, think tank staff, government officials, and uniformed French officers).

sections.title: Research Methods
sections.methods_summary: Examination of primary sources in French (official strategies, doctrinal documents, parliamentary hearing transcriptions, legislative documents) and secondary sources in French and English on France's strategic priorities, military capabilities, and defense issues.  More than a dozen conversations with French government officials, active-duty and retired military officers, and defense researchers were conducted between March and May 2019.

analysis.sample_description: French defense experts (journalists, think tank staff, government officials, active-duty and retired military officers, and researchers specializing in defense issues).
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of documents and interview data to address key research questions regarding France's military capabilities and burdensharing.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research relied on previous work to understand integrated deterrence, reviewed public statements from DAF leaders, reviewed existing RAND research on DAF operations, modernization, and force structure, and conducted over 30 informal interviews with RAND subject-matter experts and DAF personnel.

analysis.sample_description: Over 30 informal interviews with RAND subject-matter experts on DAF planning and DAF personnel in offices working on the implementation of the NDS.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis highlighted areas where DAF capabilities align with integrated deterrence demands and identified areas where increased emphasis on existing initiatives or new ideas could promote integrated deterrence goals.

sections.title: Literature Review and Proposition Identification
sections.methods_summary: The research methodology involved a review of public statements by U.S. military space leaders, U.S. policy documents, and supporting policy research published in the public domain.  This literature review identified six significant propositions that appear to undergird U.S. thinking about required capabilities and strategy and the utility of different policy tools for averting and managing escalation in space.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is a policy analysis report, not an empirical study with a defined sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: The authors evaluated the validity of the six identified propositions by examining available evidence, identifying areas of uncertainty or inaccuracy, and applying relevant insights from the scholarly and policy literature on competition and conflict in other strategic domains (e.g., cybersecurity and nuclear weapons).  They also offered select examples of Chinese and Russian strategic and operational concepts and responses to U.S. activities for illustration and context.

sections.title: Research Questions and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research involved reviewing doctrine and policy, conducting site visits, observing operations and exercises, gathering vignette data from discussions on information-sharing technical issues and their interaction with nontechnical issues, and holding targeted discussions with subject-matter experts.  A simulation of a cruise missile attack was used to illustrate the impact of recommended courses of action.

analysis.sample_description: The sample is not explicitly defined, but it includes data from various sources, including policy documents, observations of operations and exercises, and interviews with subject matter experts within USAFE, EUCOM, NATO, and allied nations.
analysis.analysis_approach: The collected data was synthesized to identify challenges and recommend courses of action.  A simulation was used to illustrate the potential impact of these recommendations.

sections.title: Methodology: Change Impact Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The study used a change impact analysis framework consisting of four steps: 1) Determine impacted elements (process mapping of conjunction assessment, stakeholder interviews, literature review); 2) Determine change activities (survey of AI/ML tools); 3) Determine performance metrics (identification of metrics and model development); 4) Determine change effort (identification of enablers and barriers).  The team conducted 23 interviews across nine organizations, including in-person interviews with operators from the 18th and 19th Space Defense Squadrons and a week-long embedded research period with the 18th SDS.

analysis.sample_description: 23 stakeholders across nine organizations, including uniformed and contractor personnel from the 18th and 19th Space Defense Squadrons, and representatives from the Kobayashi Maru software factory and Space Systems Command.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of stakeholder interviews and literature review, quantitative modeling of AI/ML impact on conjunction assessment processes using developed models.

sections.title: Elliptical Screening Process Tool Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for the first case study, which uses a Bayesian Neural Network (BNN) to replicate the conjunction screening process.  It describes the synthetic data generation process using Poliastro (Python library for astrodynamics), the BNN architecture (three hidden layers, Adam optimizer, modified NLL loss function), training procedures (minimum-maximum scaling, dropout regularization), and post-processing classification using a confidence metric.  Model performance is evaluated using MAPE, MSE, KL divergence, and Wasserstein distance.

sections.title: Orbital State Propagator Tool Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines the methodology for the second case study, which uses a BNN to predict future RSO states and covariances.  It details the synthetic data generation using CelesTrak data and Monte Carlo simulations with Cowell's method in Poliastro. The BNN architecture (five-layer feedforward network with separate heads for covariance and mean position calculations) and training procedures are described. Model performance is evaluated using MAPE, MSE, KL divergence, and the probability of the true mean in the predicted distribution.  The section also explores recursive propagation, flexible time-step models, and active learning as potential operational frameworks, providing pseudocode for the active learning approach and evaluating its performance.

analysis.sample_description: Synthetic datasets generated using publicly available general perturbation orbit data from CelesTrak, focusing primarily on Starlink satellites for the first case study and expanding to include other constellations in some analyses of the second case study.  The size of the datasets varied depending on the specific experiment.
analysis.analysis_approach: Model performance is evaluated using a combination of metrics including MAPE, MSE, KL divergence, and Wasserstein distance.  Uncertainty quantification is a key aspect of the analysis, particularly in the context of BNNs.  The analysis also includes comparisons between BNNs and standard neural networks (SNNs) to assess the relative strengths and weaknesses of each approach.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research involved a review of guidance documents from the DAF, DoD, and federal EMS management; semistructured interviews and discussions with spectrum managers and EMSO subject-matter experts; and data analysis using Python on data from Stepstone, a certification process management system.  Data from Spectrum XXI was unavailable for analysis.

analysis.sample_description: Spectrum managers and EMSO subject-matter experts at Air Combat Command, Pacific Air Forces, U.S. Air Forces in Europe, the Nevada Test and Training Range (NTTR), and other DAF organizations.  Data from Stepstone included over 3,000 certification request records from 2007-2023.
analysis.analysis_approach: Python was used to analyze quantitative data from Stepstone to quantify delays and identify potential root causes of delays in spectrum-dependent system certification.  Root cause analysis of data from Spectrum XXI was not possible due to data unavailability.

sections.title: Data and Methods: Conflict Projections
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for generating conflict projections using a machine learning framework.  It describes the CoPro forecasting framework, the data sources (Uppsala Conflict Data Program’s Georeferenced Event Dataset (GED), CMIP6 climate models, ISIMIP datasets, SSPs), data aggregation methods (by province, averaging climate indicators across grid cells), the random forest modeling process (including training and testing on historical data from 1995-2015), and the selection of climate and socioeconomic scenarios (RCPs 6.0 and 8.5, SSPs 2, 3, and 5).

sections.title: Modeling Excursion: Drought Impact on Conflict
sections.methods_summary: This section describes a modeling excursion to assess the impact of drought on conflict risk.  It uses RCP 6.0-SSP 3 as a baseline, penalizing projected GDP growth in drought years (defined as >2 standard deviation shortfall in precipitation) by 1.5 percentage points, proportionally to agricultural GDP share.  The impact on governance quality is also recalculated. The results are compared to the unadjusted projections to show the increased conflict risk.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the U.S. Central Command (CENTCOM) area of responsibility (AOR), aggregated at the provincial level.  Historical conflict data from 1995-2015 are used for model training and validation.  Projections are made for 2030-2070.
analysis.analysis_approach: A machine learning approach, specifically random forest models, is used to generate conflict projections.  The model incorporates climate variables (temperature and precipitation) from CMIP6 and ISIMIP datasets, along with socioeconomic factors (GDP, population, governance) from SSP scenarios.  The relative importance of different factors is assessed using permutation importance scores.  A separate modeling excursion analyzes the impact of drought on GDP and subsequently on conflict risk.

sections.title: Chapter 2. Research Approach and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This chapter details a mixed-methods approach combining qualitative and quantitative methods.  The quantitative component involved analysis of 2016-2019 administrative data from the DWC's WCIS to identify high-volume provider specialties.  Qualitative data was gathered through a scoping review and environmental scan of literature on APMs (using databases like PubMed, EconLit, CINAHL, and Business Select, as well as grey literature from organizational websites), interviews with WC staff in Ohio and Washington, a focus group with California healthcare providers (from six high-volume specialties identified in the WCIS analysis), a focus group with employer representatives, and individual semi-structured interviews with employee representatives.  Data analysis involved inductive and deductive content analysis of transcripts, with discrepancies resolved through coder consensus.  The PRISMA guidelines were followed for the literature review.

analysis.sample_description: The quantitative analysis used 2016-2019 data from the DWC's WCIS. Qualitative data was collected from WC staff in Ohio and Washington, California healthcare providers (10 participants across six specialties), California employer representatives (6 participants), and California employee representatives (3 participants).  Provider participants were selected based on WCIS data showing high patient volume.  The sample sizes for other stakeholder groups are not explicitly stated but described as 'small group interviews' and 'one-on-one semi-structured interviews'.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis involved rank-ordering provider specialties by patient percentage in WC. Qualitative data analysis used inductive and deductive content analysis to identify themes, with coder consensus used to resolve discrepancies. Thematic analysis summarized main themes across stakeholder groups, comparing the consistency of support for each theme.

sections.title: Data, Sample, and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used seven data sources: an early learning provider survey (online, ~20 minutes, ~2163 respondents), QSLA administrative data (iPinwheel database), interviews with key QSLA stakeholders (16 interviewees), focus groups with early learning providers (two waves, total 47 providers), focus groups with assessment TAs (four focus groups across two waves), focus groups and interviews with coaches (28 coaches across two waves), and observations of coaching sessions (12 sessions). Data collection occurred in two waves (February-June 2019 and February-March 2020).  Quantitative descriptive analysis was used for survey data, descriptive quantitative analyses (means, percentages) for administrative data, and qualitative analysis (coding and thematic analysis) for interviews and focus groups.  Observations were aggregated and analyzed for common themes.

analysis.sample_description: The study included a large online survey of early learning providers (approximately 66% of possible providers), interviews with key stakeholders, focus groups with providers (a small sample representing about 1% of all QSLA providers), TAs, and coaches, and observations of coaching sessions.  The sample for some data sources varied across waves and by provider type (centers vs. FCCs).
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative descriptive analysis was used for survey data, descriptive quantitative analyses (means and percentages) for administrative data, and qualitative thematic analysis for interviews and focus groups.  Observations were aggregated and analyzed for common themes.  Triangulation of findings across data sources was also employed.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods approach including open-source analysis of four data types (international and domestic Chinese sources, China's GEI activities and capabilities, Western literature), status mapping of GEI projects, RAND-developed open-source bibliometric methodology for assessing national S&T standings, cone-of-plausibility scenario-making, and a Day After-inspired gaming exercise.

sections.title: Methodology: Assessing China's Progress on GEI Ambitions
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods methodology combining status mapping of GEI projects, multiple targeted literature reviews, and bibliometrics analysis.  Bibliometric analysis used RAND-developed open-source methodology to assess national S&T standing based on research activity (publications and top publishing organizations) and innovation potential (patent filings and unique patent assignees).  Patent analysis used Derwent Innovation Index, focusing on patent families. Technical achievement assessed via number of UHV lines deployed and UHV miles built.

sections.title: Scenario-Making Method
sections.methods_summary: Cone-of-plausibility approach for scenario-making.  Steps included identifying key drivers (PESTLE framework), eliciting key assumptions for each driver, generating a baseline scenario ('patchwork GEI'), developing two alternative scenarios by altering assumptions, and designing a wild-card scenario ('weaponized GEI').  Global security implications assessed in a Day After-inspired workshop.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses various open-source data sources, including Chinese and Western publications, reports, and government documents related to the Global Energy Interconnection (GEI) initiative.  Patent data is drawn from the Derwent Innovation Index and publication data from the Web of Science.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis combines qualitative and quantitative methods. Qualitative analysis involves interpreting textual data from various sources to understand China's ambitions and the dynamics driving them. Quantitative analysis involves bibliometric analysis of publications and patents to assess China's technological capabilities and innovation potential. Scenario planning is used to explore potential future outcomes and their security implications.

sections.title: Chapter 2. Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the qualitative and quantitative methods used in the evaluation.  Qualitative data was collected through 41 semi-structured interviews with various stakeholders (program staff, treatment providers, law enforcement, etc.) using a standardized interview guide.  Thematic analysis was performed using Dedoose software. Quantitative analysis used program and administrative data from two sites (Lake County, Illinois, and Plymouth County, Massachusetts) to assess the impact of the deflection programs on overdose and crime rates.  The synthetic control method (SCM) was employed to estimate the impact of program adoption, using data from the Illinois Department of Public Health, Illinois State Police, Illinois Department of Health and Human Services, Massachusetts Emergency Medical Services, Massachusetts Department of Public Health, and Massachusetts crime statistics dashboard.  Covariate data from the 2014 American Community Survey was used to create synthetic control groups.  Analysis was conducted using the synth program in STATA version 17.0.

analysis.sample_description: Six sites were selected for Phase 1 (implementation and stakeholder perspectives), focusing on program models, partnerships, resources, police force size, and context.  Phase 2 (outcome analysis) included two sites (Lake County, Illinois, and Plymouth County, Massachusetts) selected based on data availability and program maturity.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data from interviews was analyzed using thematic analysis. Quantitative data was analyzed using the synthetic control method (SCM) in STATA to compare outcomes in treatment counties with synthetic control counties.  The analysis focused on overdose rates (fatal and non-fatal, opioid-related and all drugs) and crime rates (DUI, property crime, drug possession).

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research proceeded in three steps: 1. Review of policy debates and derivation of a framework for understanding U.S. leverage; 2. Testing the framework in 18 case studies (9 in Iraq and 9 in Afghanistan) using primary and secondary sources and interviews; 3. Statistical analysis of post-conflict countries (1975-2009) to assess generalizability.

analysis.sample_description: 18 specific episodes (influence events) in Iraq (since 2003) and Afghanistan (since 2001).  The statistical analysis included all post-conflict countries from 1975-2009.
analysis.analysis_approach: The case studies involved a review of primary and secondary sources (documents in English and Arabic) and interviews with practitioners. The statistical analysis used logistic regression to model binary outcomes (political inclusion and conflict recurrence), controlling for various contextual factors and including interaction terms to account for geopolitical context (Cold War vs. post-Cold War).

sections.title: Research Design and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The research involved a systematic review of 18 specific episodes in Iraq and Afghanistan (9 in each country). Data collection included analysis of hundreds of documents in English and Arabic, and interviews with senior White House officials, U.S. ambassadors, generals, and military officers, diplomats, and civil-society partners involved in implementing U.S. policies.  A framework was developed to analyze these events, considering interest alignment, influence strategy (persuasion/inducement, soft conditionality, hard conditionality), and conditions for leverage (clarity, observability, sanction strength).  The 18 events were categorized and analyzed based on this framework, assessing short-term and long-term outcomes (success, partial success, failure).

analysis.sample_description: 18 specific episodes of U.S. influence attempts in Iraq and Afghanistan (9 in each country) between 2001 and 2014.
analysis.analysis_approach: A framework was used to categorize and analyze the events based on interest alignment, influence strategy, and conditions for leverage. Short-term and long-term outcomes were assessed for each event.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research employed a mixed-methods approach.  Data collection involved 25 semi-structured interviews with industry SMEs (lasting approximately one hour each, conducted via Microsoft Teams) and 11 interviews with academics.  The interviews focused on existing COTS/GOTS PAI capabilities, Army needs, barriers to acquisition, and recommendations for improvement.  A PAI capability collection and categorization process involved identifying Army-relevant COTS/GOTS capabilities, collecting PAI tools and reports using existing inventories, open-web searches, and SME input (resulting in a refined list of 259 tools and technologies). Scenario-based workshops (using five scenarios: viral Army stories, force protection, early warning, stability operations, and regime change) were conducted with RAND SMEs to elicit PAI needs.  A framework for understanding how PAI analytics sync with military planning processes and operations was adapted from the 2020 PARDIE OIE Technology Development Roadmap, refined through multiple iterations and workshops, resulting in a categorized taxonomy of requirements (five main categories, 19 subcategories, 172 discrete tasks). A crosswalk analysis compared analytic requirements against the inventory of COTS/GOTS solutions.

sections.title: Data Acquisition and Evaluation
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for characterizing data supply and demand.  Data quality was assessed using the 5Vs (value, volume, velocity, variety, veracity). Source types were categorized as crowdsourced, commercial, public/administrative, and international. Data scope was categorized as nationally identified data (NID) and personally identified data (PID).  A taxonomy of PAI data types is presented in Appendix E.

analysis.sample_description: 35 subject matter experts (SMEs) were interviewed: 25 from industry and 11 from academia.  Additionally, various RAND SMEs participated in scenario-based workshops.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data and quantitative analysis of the COTS/GOTS tool inventory and crosswalk analysis to identify capability gaps and assess applicability across various information-related capabilities (IRCs).

sections.title: Study Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach.  A literature review using 24 search strings in Web of Science was conducted.  Semi-structured interviews were conducted with 16 subject matter experts from various organizations (listed in Table B.1).  A virtual workshop with participants from diverse organizations (listed in Table B.2) was held to validate the research agenda.  A Mural board was used to facilitate discussion and prioritization of research questions during the workshop.

analysis.sample_description: 16 subject matter experts from academia and practice across multiple countries and organizations; Workshop participants from various organizations in multiple countries.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data and workshop discussions;  Prioritization exercise in the workshop to rank research questions.

sections.title: Study Approach and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The research used a mixed-methods approach combining qualitative and quantitative analysis.  Qualitative methods included developing a detailed logic model of DHS trade enforcement efforts, reviewing laws, regulations, and policy documents, and conducting discussions with stakeholders from various sectors. Quantitative methods involved using data-driven trade and supply chain models to analyze changes in US imports and business relationships between December 2021 and mid-2023.

primary_methods: Data-driven Trade and Supply Chain Modeling
analysis.sample_description: Stakeholders from federal agencies, Congress, industry, and NGOs were interviewed.  The quantitative analysis used data on US imports and business relationships.
analysis.analysis_approach: A logic model was used to map DHS enforcement efforts and identify indicators of progress. Data-driven trade and supply chain models were used to evaluate the impact of trade enforcement on US imports and supply chains.  The findings were informed by qualitative data from document review and stakeholder interviews.

sections.title: B-CORE Methods and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a participatory approach drawing from community-partnered participatory research (CPPR) principles.  Purposive sampling (chain referral) was used to recruit 37 stakeholders.  Deliberative democracy methodology, specifically the citizens' panel format (stakeholder panels), was employed.  Stakeholders participated in eight monthly co-learning sessions followed by structured deliberative sessions in smaller groups.  Data collection involved written notes from deliberative sessions and visual scribing.  Virtual engagement was used for all project activities.

sections.title: Qualitative Analysis and Visual Scribing
sections.methods_summary: Written notes were analyzed using a constructivist grounded theory approach—thematic coding.  In-vivo coding was used initially, followed by refinement into a formal coding structure.  Visual scribing (graphic recording) was used as a complementary qualitative analysis approach, with real-time drawings summarizing discussions.  The visual scribing products were then compared for overarching themes and commonalities.

analysis.sample_description: 37 stakeholders were recruited using purposive sampling (chain referral).  This included Medi-Cal beneficiaries, perinatal care providers, health plan administrators, and maternal health advocates from Northern and Southern California, aiming to reflect the diversity of California’s Medi-Cal program.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data analysis using thematic coding and visual scribing.  Code co-occurrence was used to identify domains of understanding.  Visual scribing provided a complementary analysis and triangulation of findings.

sections.title: B-CORE Methods and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a participatory approach drawing from community-partnered participatory research (CPPR) principles.  Purposive sampling (chain referral) was used to recruit 37 stakeholders.  Deliberative democracy methodology, specifically the citizens' panel format (stakeholder panels), was employed.  Data collection involved eight monthly 90-minute interactive co-learning sessions followed by structured deliberative sessions.  Qualitative analysis used a constructivist grounded theory approach—thematic coding—with in-vivo coding and double-coding. Visual scribing was used as a complementary qualitative analysis approach.

analysis.sample_description: 37 stakeholders were recruited using purposive sampling (chain referral).  This included Medi-Cal beneficiaries, perinatal care providers, health plan administrators, and maternal health advocates from Northern and Southern California, aiming to represent the racial/ethnic makeup of Medi-Cal beneficiaries.
analysis.analysis_approach: A constructivist grounded theory approach with thematic coding was used to analyze written notes from deliberative sessions. In-vivo coding was used initially, followed by refinement into a formal coding structure. Double-coding was employed to analyze code co-occurrence. Visual scribing provided a complementary qualitative analysis, with aggregation and comparison of the resulting images.

sections.title: Approach and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research employed a mixed-methods approach.  It involved a mapping exercise using FMS-related legal, policy, and service-level documentation to understand organizational roles in different FMS phases.  This was followed by 99 semi-structured interviews with 105 government officials (over 1300 years of collective experience) from various organizations involved in the FMS process, including DSCA, IAs, CCMDs, OSD, Joint Staff, and DoS.  An attempt at quantitative analysis of FMS case timelines using DSCA data was unsuccessful due to data inconsistencies. The study acknowledges limitations, including focus on RRA barriers and skewed interview data towards a DSCA perspective.

analysis.sample_description: 105 government officials in the security assistance community with over 1,300 years of collective experience.  Interviewees represented DSCA (36), IAs (30), CCMDs (18), OUSD(P) (6), OUSD(A&S) (6), DoS (4), DTSA (3), and Joint Staff (2).
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data was the primary approach due to limitations in the quantitative data. The mapping exercise helped identify RRA pain points impeding FMS delivery.

sections.title: Empirical Analysis of Cyberstalking Offenses
sections.methods_summary: Data from the Federal Judicial Center's Integrated Database (IDB) and CourtListener/PACER were used to identify and analyze 412 federal cyberstalking cases filed between 2010 and 2020.  A codebook was developed to identify relevant variables. A hybrid NLP-human method was used for coding, with NLP used for some variables and human coders for others.

sections.title: Interviews with Subject-Matter Experts
sections.methods_summary: 23 subject-matter experts (prosecutors, investigators, law enforcement officials, and victims’ advocacy representatives) were interviewed using a semi-structured protocol.  A non-probabilistic convenience sample and chain sampling were used. Interviews were not recorded, but notes were taken. Thematic analysis was used to analyze the interview notes.

analysis.sample_description: 412 federal cyberstalking cases (2010-2020); 23 subject-matter experts (prosecutors, investigators, law enforcement, victim advocates, researchers).  Sampling for experts was non-probabilistic convenience and chain sampling.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis of case data (e.g., frequencies, durations, conviction rates, sentences); Qualitative thematic analysis of interview data.

sections.title: Survey Methods and How This Analysis Was Conducted
sections.methods_summary: The analyses are based on survey items administered online via The RAND Corporation’s American Teacher Panel (ATP) between October 25 and November 14, 2022.  2,500 K–12 teachers who are members of the ATP were randomly sampled to be invited to complete the survey.  Teachers received up to three reminder emails and a $10 incentive. 1,025 teachers completed enough of the survey to receive a weight and are included in the final data file (41% completion rate). 973 teachers completed the school safety module (39% completion rate). Teachers’ survey responses were weighted to be representative of the national population of public school teachers.  The ATP sampling frame was a list of U.S. public school teachers purchased from Market Data Retrieval (MDR). Probability-based sampling methods were used. The survey weights account for the multistep sampling process and teachers’ likelihood of completing the survey.  The final weights are the product of three weights: a calibrated sampling frame weight, sample selection weight, and survey response weight.  The weights were designed to make the panel match the national population of public school teachers, considering school-level and individual teacher-level characteristics. Survey response weights estimate teachers’ likelihood of responding conditional on school- and individual-level characteristics. Differences in teachers’ responses were examined by teacher characteristics (gender, race, experience) and school characteristics (grade level, enrollment size, locale, poverty status, student racial/ethnic composition). School demographic data were obtained by linking survey data files to the Common Core of Data (CCD).  Only statistically significant differences (at the 5% level) are described, unless otherwise noted. Multiple hypothesis test corrections were not applied.

analysis.sample_description: A nationally representative sample of 2,500 K-12 public school teachers from the RAND American Teacher Panel (ATP) was randomly selected.  973 teachers completed the school safety module of the survey.
analysis.analysis_approach: Teachers' responses were weighted to be nationally representative.  Differences in responses were examined by teacher and school characteristics.  Statistically significant differences (p<0.05) are reported, without multiple hypothesis test corrections.

sections.title: Appendix A. Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research used a mixed-methods approach combining interviews and a literature review. Interviews were conducted with experts from the XVIII Airborne Corps, other Army stakeholders, government and private sector experts, and soldiers in group and individual settings.  The literature review included policy documents, reports, news articles, doctrine and training manuals, technical manuals, Army and DoD documents, datasets on commercially available UAS, and relevant Army and Joint doctrine and strategies.  Classified literature and reports were also reviewed.

sections.title: Overview of Methods
sections.methods_summary: Two main research methods were used: interviews and a review of applicable literature. Interviews included experts from XVIII Airborne Corps divisions and other Army stakeholders. The literature review focused on current UAS experiences across the Army and other services, the conflict in Ukraine, the conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh, and other relevant technical and operational publications. For the materiel requirements analysis, input from interviews, examined literature, and knowledge of Army doctrine on how large-scale combat operations will be executed and tables of organization and equipment were used.

analysis.sample_description: The interviews included experts from the XVIII Airborne Corps, other Army stakeholders (including units, staff, UAS and robotics staffs in Army CoEs, acquisition officials, and DoD officials), government and private-sector experts, and soldiers (in group and individual settings).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved identifying operational requirements through a review of literature and discussions with Army stakeholders, and using this to inform the identification of commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) offerings that could quickly meet the XVIII Airborne Corps' needs.  The analysis also involved searching three databases (DIU Blue UAS, AUVSI Uncrewed Systems and Robotics Database, and Janes) and other sources to identify potential UAS for various use cases, and then screening these options to identify suitable choices for the XVIII Airborne Corps.

sections.title: Approach to Locating Potential SUAS and Surveying SUAS
sections.methods_summary: A four-step process was used to survey the SUAS marketplace.  This involved identifying initial search parameters based on use cases (Table 1), searching multiple databases (DIU's Blue UAS list, AUVSI Uncrewed Systems and Robotics Database, Janes), assessing promising systems in detail, and creating a final list considering factors like near-term acquisition.  The databases were chosen for their breadth of coverage and different market segments.  The initial search parameters focused on weight, range, endurance, EO/IR capabilities, and fuel type, excluding systems from China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea. Optional parameters included hand-launch or VTOL capabilities and ATAK compatibility.

sections.title: Individual Assessment of Potential UAS Candidates and Potential for Near-Term Acquisition
sections.methods_summary: A detailed assessment of 624 potential SUAS candidates was conducted by reviewing vendor websites for additional information, including cost, flight worthiness, manufacturing needs, and environmental conditions.  A further assessment was done to categorize each SUAS's potential for near-term acquisition (within a year) based on factors like existing DoD or federal government sales, presence on the Blue UAS list, and company location (Table 4).

analysis.sample_description: The study examined nearly 4,900 SUAS, initially filtering out systems from China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea.  Further filtering was applied based on use case parameters (Table 2). The final analysis focused on 176 SUAS that met or nearly met the key features of the use cases.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved comparing SUAS against six use cases (Table 1) based on key features and specifications (Table 2).  SUAS were categorized based on their potential for near-term acquisition (Table 4) and whether they met or nearly met the key features of each use case.  The results are presented in tables summarizing the number of SUAS meeting various criteria (Tables 5, A.1-A.7).

sections.title: Research Methods
sections.methods_summary: The research team used two main methods: interviews and review of applicable literature. Interviews focused on experts from XVIII Airborne Corps divisions and experts in the acquisition process and property accountability. The literature review focused on lessons from the Russo-Ukrainian War, recent changes to the acquisition process, and Army policy on property accountability.

analysis.sample_description: Experts from XVIII Airborne Corps divisions and experts in the acquisition process and property accountability.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis of interview data and relevant literature to identify barriers to expanding Army use of SUASs and options to overcome those barriers.

sections.title: Research Overview and Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: The research involved a review of Army EW and SM doctrine and policy, a summary of recent developments in SUAS and payload capabilities, and interviews with Joint Readiness Training Center military operations subject matter experts, Fort Bragg Network Enterprise Center subject matter experts, and other subject matter experts.  A fictional narrative approach was used to explore the implications of SUAS capabilities.

sections.title: Recommendations and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The recommendations are based on a review of relevant literature (Army doctrine, field reports from Ukraine, manufacturer documentation), discussions with Army operators and leaders, and input from senior subject matter experts.  The analysis involves identifying challenges and proposing solutions across the DOTMLPF-P spectrum (doctrine, organization, training, materiel, leadership and education, personnel, facilities, and policy).

analysis.sample_description: The study sample includes subject matter experts from various organizations (Joint Readiness Training Center, Fort Bragg Network Enterprise Center, etc.), Army operators and leaders.  The exact number of interviewees is not specified.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves reviewing existing literature and expert opinions to identify challenges and opportunities related to SUAS integration, EW, and SM. A fictional narrative is used to illustrate potential scenarios and outcomes.  Recommendations are developed based on the findings of the literature review and expert consultations, considering the DOTMLPF-P framework.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The RAND Arroyo Center research team examined the Army's ability to adapt its training for the 2020s.  Research involved analysis of historical training support data, interviews with commanders, staff, and SUAS operators from various Army divisions and corps units, battlefield assessments, and review of doctrinal and regulatory publications from the FAA and DoD.  Specific data sources included the Range Facility Management Support System (RFMSS) for Forts Bragg, Campbell, Stewart, and Drum (June 2022-May 2023) and JRTC data across six rotations (2022-2023).

analysis.sample_description: Personnel from the 3d Infantry Division, 10th Mountain Division, 82nd Airborne Division, 101st Airborne Division, 75th Ranger Regiment, XVIII Airborne Corps units and staff, experts from NTC and JRTC, experts from Maneuver, Fires, Intelligence, and Maneuver Support Centers of Excellence, US Marine Corps Warfighter Lab, and Security Assistance Group-Ukraine (SAG-U).
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data and quantitative analysis of historical training data from RFMSS and JRTC.

sections.title: Overview of Approach
sections.methods_summary: A simulation model was used to assess patient demand and provider supply for the delivery of AD DMTs.  The model included the capacity of primary care practitioners (PCPs) and utilized county-level data to account for geographic variations in patient populations and health system capacities.

sections.title: Conceptual Framework
sections.methods_summary: Describes the conceptual framework of the simulation model, outlining the clinical pathway (detection, diagnosis, treatment) and the types of units within the model (service, test, treatment, pool, wait, outflow).

sections.title: Model Parameters, Assumptions, and Projections
sections.methods_summary: Details the parameters and assumptions used in the simulation model, including patient uptake, clinical decisions, capacity, and test parameters.  Sources for these parameters are cited.

sections.title: Technical Details: Smoothing Capacities
sections.methods_summary: Explains the method used to smooth health resource capacity across counties, accounting for the fact that individuals may seek care outside their county of residence.  This involved calculating a Gini index and using a smoothing algorithm to redistribute resources while maintaining total capacity. A model of travel behavior was developed to estimate the travel matrix used in the smoothing algorithm.

sections.title: Steps in the Simulation
sections.methods_summary: Describes the simulation process, including how patients are represented as groups moving through the health system, the logic for flow through different units (service, test, treatment, pool, wait, outflow), and how health state changes are simulated using a transition matrix.  The model's output metrics (queue sizes, individuals treated, wait times) are also defined.

sections.title: Data and Simulation Details
sections.methods_summary: Details data sources (AHRF, Census Bureau, HRSA, OECD, etc.) and methods for estimating patient demand and health system capacity (PCPs, specialists, PET scanners, infusion workforce).  Explains the smoothing algorithm used to account for geographic variation in access to care.  Simulation scenarios (status quo, base case, alternative PCP capacity, alternative patient uptake, no constraints) are described.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses county-level data across the United States for the population aged 50 and older.  Expert consultation informed several key parameters and assumptions within the simulation model.
analysis.analysis_approach: A dynamic simulation model was developed to project patient demand and health system capacity for Alzheimer's disease-modifying therapies under various scenarios.  The model incorporates patient decisions, clinical decisions, and geographic variation in resource availability.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: A survey was fielded using the RAND American Life Panel (ALP), a population-representative sample of US adults aged 50-70.  Subjective probabilities (0-100 scale) were used to elicit responses regarding likelihood of undergoing testing and treatment under various hypothetical scenarios.  Several parameters (price, treatment availability, test location/mode) were randomized across respondents to allow for both cross-sectional and within-person variation.  The ALP's quarterly data were used to weight the survey for representativeness.

sections.title: Experimental Design
sections.methods_summary: Randomized design used for cognitive assessment and early-detection test questions to assess the impact of key features (price, treatment availability).  Follow-up questions modified one parameter at a time to control for anchoring effects.  Out-of-pocket price randomized ($0, $100, $300), treatment availability randomized (yes/no), and test location/mode randomized (doctor's office/computer-based in private setting).  A total of 12 scenarios were created for cognitive assessment and 12 for early detection testing. The order of scenarios was randomized across respondents.

sections.title: Analyses and Results
sections.methods_summary: Analysis begins with responses from the first question (cognitive assessment) to avoid anchoring bias.  Population averages are calculated, weighted by ALP data.  Subsequent analysis uses multivariate regression models to examine the relationship between outcomes and various factors.

analysis.sample_description: Population-representative sample of 1439 US adults aged 50-70 from the RAND American Life Panel (ALP).  Weighted to reflect the general population using ALP's quarterly data.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis includes descriptive statistics (weighted and unweighted) and multivariate regression models.  The study uses both cross-sectional and within-person variation in price and other attributes to estimate effects.

sections.title: Overview of Sample and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Web searches for ISA-offering institutions (Oct-Dec 2021), using various search terms. Inclusion criteria: served primarily US learners, provided public verification of ISA existence, offered ISAs directly to enrolled learners, offered education/training, used the term 'income share agreement' and described payments as income-contingent.  160 institutions met criteria. Downloaded all available ISA documents (Nov 2021-Apr 2022), created PDFs of webpages. Captured all documents for up to 3 ISA contracts per institution, sampling contracts at institutions offering >3 ISAs, prioritizing certain fields. Developed coding framework to abstract information about institution, contracts, and documents.  Two qualitative analysts coded institutions, with double-coding to ensure reliability.  Used RAND American Life Panel (ALP), a nationally representative sample of US adults (n=2463), surveyed in Feb 2022, to assess public perceptions of ISAs. Data weighted to ensure representativeness.  Analysis included logistic regression, linear probability models, t-tests, and ordered logistic regression.

analysis.sample_description: 262 ISA-offering institutions identified, 160 met inclusion criteria.  Up to three ISA contracts per institution sampled, with prioritization of certain fields when more than three contracts were offered.  RAND American Life Panel (ALP) survey of 2,463 nationally representative US adults.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative coding of documents to assess information accessibility and marketing practices. Quantitative analysis of survey data using logistic regression, linear probability models, t-tests, and ordered logistic regression.

sections.title: Patent–O*NET Matching Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for matching patents and O*NET tasks using NLP.  It describes the use of word embeddings (specifically BERT, fine-tuned for patent data), cosine similarity to measure semantic closeness, and the steps involved in the matching algorithm.  The algorithm involves generating embeddings for both patent titles and O*NET task descriptions, then comparing them using cosine similarity to score the pairwise matches.

sections.title: Measuring Occupation Exposure
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines the methods used to analyze patent-task matches.  It describes how the analysis considers different cosine similarity thresholds (0.75 and 0.80), examines patent matches by task frequency, aggregates patent-task matches to the occupation level, and analyzes exposure differences across occupations based on skills, education requirements, and routine task intensity.

sections.title: Aggregation of Patent-Task Matches to Occupation Level
sections.methods_summary: The patent-task matches are aggregated to the occupation level using task importance measures from O*NET.  The formula for calculating occupation-level exposure is provided, incorporating task importance scores and scaling to account for the growth in the number of patents over time.

sections.title: Exposure to Technology over Time
sections.methods_summary: Cumulative exposure is calculated by summing annual exposure from 1976 to a given year (e.g., 2000).  The top ten most exposed occupations are identified for 1980, 2000, and 2020.

sections.title: Skill Exposure
sections.methods_summary: Skill exposure is calculated as a weighted average of occupation exposure, weighted by the importance of the skill in each occupation.  The formula is provided.

sections.title: Task Inputs
sections.methods_summary: Task input indexes (nonroutine cognitive, nonroutine manual, routine cognitive, routine manual, and offshorable) are created using methods from Autor and Dorn (2013), updated with O*NET-26 data.  A regression model is estimated separately for 1980, 1990, 2000, 2010, and 2020, and for each technology group, to examine the relationship between cumulative exposure and task input indexes.

sections.title: Correlation Between Exposure, Wage, and Employment
sections.methods_summary: The relationship between exposure and wages is analyzed using data from the decennial census (1980, 1990) and the ACS (2000, 2019, 2020).  The sample is restricted to workers aged 18-65, and a labor-supply weight is calculated. Data is aggregated to the occupation level. LOESS regression is used to visualize the relationship between cumulative exposure and wages.

sections.title: Employment
sections.methods_summary: The share of full-time equivalent employees highly exposed to technology is calculated.  A worker is considered highly exposed if their occupation's cumulative exposure is at least one standard deviation above the average.  The share of total employment made up by highly exposed employees is calculated for 2019.

sections.title: Correlation Between Exposure and Employment Growth
sections.methods_summary: A regression model is estimated to examine the relationship between exposure and employment growth (1990-2019).  The model includes cumulative exposure in 2019, a routine-intensity index, and an interaction term between exposure and routine intensity.  Errors are clustered at the occupation level.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data on US occupations from O*NET, US patents from the USPTO and AIPD, and wage and employment data from the US Census and ACS.  The sample for wage and employment analysis is restricted to workers aged 18-65.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves matching patents to occupational tasks using NLP, aggregating data to the occupation level, and using regression analysis to examine the correlations between technology exposure and labor market outcomes (wages and employment growth).

sections.title: Research Approach and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A structured multi-method approach was used, encompassing three work packages (WPs). WP1 involved a literature review (using Google Scholar searches with Boolean and snowball searching, applying inclusion/exclusion criteria, and a structured data extraction matrix) and horizon scanning (reviewing RAND Europe's CFFS database). WP2 involved a literature review of social anthropology and Science and Technology Studies (STS), focusing on Actor-Network Theory (ANT), and identification of cultural aspects at macro, meso, and micro societal levels. WP3 involved deep dives into six technological systems using targeted desk research, ten semi-structured subject-matter-expert (SME) interviews (analyzed using an inductive thematic approach), and a final internal analysis to identify conclusions and implications for UK Defence.  The study acknowledges limitations related to future uncertainty, literature review and interview constraints, and a conceptual focus on cultural impact.

analysis.sample_description: Ten subject-matter experts (SMEs) were interviewed using purposive sampling based on their expertise.  The literature review included both academic and non-academic sources, with inclusion/exclusion criteria based on relevance, type, language, and publication date (excluding sources before 2012).
analysis.analysis_approach: Inductive thematic analysis was used for the SME interviews.  A structured data extraction matrix was used for the literature review.  The final internal analysis structured the study's conclusions and implications.

sections.title: Development and Parameterization of the Multistate Life Table (MSLT) Model
sections.methods_summary: The study used a three-state MSLT model to simulate transitions between 'no DS-AD', 'DS-AD', and 'death'.  The model's parameters (age-specific probabilities of DS-AD incidence and mortality) were iteratively developed using data from multiple sources: high-quality recent studies with large samples of adults, primary data analysis of administrative registry and surveillance data from CMS (Minimum Data Set (MDS) 3.0 and Master Beneficiary Summary File (MBSF)) and CDC (National Vital Statistics System), and consultation with key informants and stakeholders.  A novel extension of conventional MSLT methods was developed to adjust for changes in birth cohort size.

sections.title: Statistical Analysis of the MDS 3.0 Data
sections.methods_summary: The study used data from the CMS Minimum Data Set (MDS) 3.0, linked with the Master Beneficiary Summary File (MBSF), to estimate age-specific probabilities of DS-AD incidence and mortality.  A discrete-time survival analysis approach with logit models was employed to model incidence and mortality, controlling for gender and year of entry. Age splines were used to model the non-linear relationship between age and the probabilities.  Data cleaning steps were performed to address inconsistencies and implausible observations.

analysis.sample_description: The study used data from multiple sources including high-quality recent studies with large samples of adults, administrative registry and surveillance data from CMS (Minimum Data Set (MDS) 3.0 and Master Beneficiary Summary File (MBSF)) and CDC (National Vital Statistics System).  The MDS 3.0 data initially included 16,679 unique nursing home residents with DS, which was reduced to 13,150 after data cleaning. A subset of 4,236 residents and 16,897 person-year observations were used for the incidence analysis, and 13,150 residents and 40,913 person-year observations were used for the mortality analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: The MSLT model was used to simulate and project population trends in DS-AD and associated caregiving needs under different scenarios (varying assumptions about changes in DS survival probabilities and DS-AD incidence).  The model outputs included life expectancy, prevalence of DS-AD, and expected years of life with and without DS-AD.  These outputs were used to estimate caregiving needs in terms of full-time equivalent (FTE) hours.

sections.title: Research Approach and Scope
sections.methods_summary: This report uses extensive, original open-source Chinese-language primary sources to understand how China thinks about and plans for social media manipulation.  The research centers on one Chinese military-affiliated researcher, Li Bicheng, reviewing his publicly available works (over 220 Chinese-language articles and over 20 English-language articles).  Published research using grant funding Li received is also reviewed.  A broader survey of Chinese military writings on relevant topics supplements this focus on Li.  Authoritativeness of Chinese texts was assessed based on author affiliation, publication venue, government research funding, and publication content.

analysis.sample_description: The primary focus is on the research and publications of Li Bicheng, a Chinese military-affiliated researcher.  This is supplemented by a broader survey of Chinese military writings on relevant topics.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis of the authoritativeness of sources based on author affiliation, publication venue, funding, and content.  The analysis focuses on understanding how China conceptualizes and plans for social media manipulation.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Interviews with 65 experienced data scientists and engineers with at least five years of experience building AI/ML models in industry or academia. Participants were selected across a variety of company sizes and industries.

sections.title: Methods
