sections.methods_summary: Semistructured interviews with experienced AI practitioners in industry and academia.  Industry participants were identified using LinkedIn Recruiter and InMail, with a focus on individual contributors and managers in data science or ML engineering.  Academic participants were drawn from convenience samples. A consistent battery of questions was used for each group (Appendix A and B). Interviews were conducted between August and December 2023.  Common root causes were identified based on interview responses.

analysis.sample_description: 65 experienced data scientists and engineers (50 from industry, 15 from academia) with at least five years of experience building AI/ML models. Industry sample included participants from various company sizes and industries. Academic sample included researchers from different school types and degree levels.
analysis.analysis_approach: Common root causes of AI project failures were identified based on the interview responses. The analysis focused on identifying frequent and impactful reasons for failure, categorizing them into leadership-driven, bottom-up, data-driven, infrastructure-related, and technology-limitation categories.

sections.title: Data Collection and Study Selection
sections.methods_summary: A scoping review was conducted using seven electronic databases (Academic Search Complete, Business Source Complete, Embase, Policy File Index, PubMed, Scopus, and Web of Science) to identify peer-reviewed reports, government reports, and gray literature published between January 1, 2000, and February 27, 2023.  Inclusion criteria focused on studies of upcoding in healthcare provider settings that involved primary research.  A manual search of US government reports was also conducted. Data abstraction involved extracting information on the methodology used to measure upcoding, including the upcoding measure, calculation technique, and study characteristics.

sections.title: Data Analysis and Synthesis
sections.methods_summary: The 39 included studies were categorized based on their methods for measuring upcoding: variations in payments, variations in provider and patient attributes, prediction algorithms, self-reports, and validations.  The methods, strengths, and limitations of each category were summarized.

sections.title: Research Methods
sections.methods_summary: This report focuses on methodologies used to measure upcoding of hospital inpatient admissions, also considering outpatient and office-based visits where payment is determined by complexity or severity.  The search strategy involved seven electronic databases and a manual search of US government reports. Inclusion criteria focused on studies in English published from 2000-2023, measuring upcoding in healthcare provider settings and involving primary research.  Data abstraction followed PRISMA guidelines.  Studies were categorized by their methods for measuring upcoding and analyzed for strengths and limitations.

analysis.sample_description: 39 articles published between 2000 and 2023 that measured upcoding in provider settings.  The articles were drawn from seven electronic databases and supplemental searches of US government reports.  The majority of studies focused on inpatient hospital admissions, with fewer examining outpatient or office-based settings.
analysis.analysis_approach: The studies were categorized into five methodological approaches: variations in payments, variations in provider and patient attributes, prediction algorithms, self-reports, and validations.  Each category was analyzed for its strengths and limitations.  The analysis also considered whether studies measured upcoding at the aggregate level or for individual admissions/visits.

sections.title: Quantitative Methods
sections.methods_summary: Data was collected from municipal codes, law enforcement websites, legislative documents, city council meeting notes, local news, and California Public Records Act (CPRA) requests.  Analysis included calculating summary statistics (mean, standard deviation, mean differences with 95% confidence intervals using unpaired t-tests), difference-in-differences (DD) estimation with two-way fixed effects, Sun and Abraham (2021), and Callaway and Sant’Anna (2021) estimators, and spatial first differences (SFD) approach.  Parallel trends and local conditional independence assumptions were tested.

sections.title: Qualitative Methods
sections.methods_summary: Document review of municipal and sheriff department websites, news reports, training materials, lease addenda, emails, CPTED inspection reports, and other documents obtained through CPRA requests. Qualitative interviews were conducted with staff from reentry, eviction support, and legal aid organizations, and with one individual who experienced eviction or housing difficulties due to CFHPs.  Responses were coded for emergent themes.

primary_methods: Quantitative analysis (t-tests, difference-in-differences, spatial first differences)
analysis.sample_description: The study included data from all 482 California incorporated municipalities.  Qualitative interviews were conducted with 10 organizations and one individual.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis involved comparing municipalities with and without CFHPs, estimating the effects of CFHPs on crime and evictions using various statistical methods, and testing key assumptions. Qualitative analysis involved identifying themes from document review and interviews.

sections.title: References
sections.methods_summary: This section lists the sources consulted during the research, which included policy documents, data on embedded healthcare effectiveness, and interviews with subject matter experts.  It does not detail the methodology itself, but indicates the data sources used.

sections.title: Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study involved six tasks: (1) literature review and interviews on embedded healthcare; (2) identification of unit needs and risk levels; (3) development of personnel support packages; (4) development of alternative expansion options for TFTN; (5) comparative analysis of expansion options; and (6) documentation of findings and recommendations.  Data sources included policy documents, Air Force Research Laboratory (AFRL) data, Air Force Military Personnel Data System (MilPDS), and previous RAND research.

sections.title: RAND Framework and Assessment of Squadron Risk Factors
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for developing a framework to assess squadron risk. Data sources included AFRL/711th HPW data (profile data on mental health and musculoskeletal injuries, suicide risk scores), MilPDS data (on non-deployability, social detractor variables), and previous RAND research (on sexual assault prevalence).  Squadrons were ranked by risk level (high, medium, low) in each domain (physical, mental, social) based on percentile rankings of the variables.  The lack of data prevented the inclusion of a spiritual domain.

sections.title: Our Approach to a Monitoring Framework
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the methodology for creating a monitoring framework for the TFTN program.  The framework uses categories from the Air Force CAF (mental, physical, social, spiritual fitness).  It identifies issues to be monitored, measures for tracking progress, and methods for data collection (administrative data, surveys, focus groups, interviews).  Both quantitative and qualitative measures are suggested.

primary_methods: Data analysis (using AFRL, MilPDS, and RAND data)
Cost estimation (using OSD CAPE FCoM model)
analysis.sample_description: The study analyzed data from Air Force squadrons, using various data sources to assess risk levels and inform cost projections for different expansion scenarios. The exact number of squadrons included varied depending on data availability for specific variables.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved ranking squadrons by risk level based on percentile scores derived from multiple data sources.  Cost estimates were developed using the OSD CAPE FCoM model, incorporating assumptions about personnel types, pay grades, and inflation.

sections.title: Phase I-IV: Methodology for Building the China’s AI Exports Database (CAIED)
sections.methods_summary: This section details the multi-phase process of building the CAIED.  Phase I involved developing string lists for searching AI projects within the AidData GCDF 2.0 dataset.  Phase II adjusted these lists, conducted manual reviews, and merged data from AidData's military and Huawei projects. Phase III refined search keywords and conducted a recovery search. Phase IV involved generating an AI application indicator with defined rating scales and coding rules to categorize projects as AI application or AI infrastructure projects.  The methodology involved iterative searches, manual review and coding by multiple analysts, expert consultation, and refinement of search terms based on results.

sections.title: Phase V: Selecting Variables from the AidData GCDF 2.0 Dataset
sections.methods_summary: A subset of 15 key variables were selected from the AidData GCDF 2.0 dataset in collaboration with the AidData team.  These variables provide comprehensive project information, including financial details, implementation timeline, and agencies involved.

sections.title: Phase VI: Adding in Technology Categories and Country-Level Information
sections.methods_summary: Additional variables were created and added to the dataset.  A technology category variable was created based on project descriptions. An indicator for AI technology usage purpose (military or civilian) was also added.  Finally, country-level information on freedom, democracy, and data protection was incorporated from external sources.

analysis.sample_description: The study used AidData's Global Chinese Development Finance (GCDF) Dataset version 2.0, which includes data on 13,427 Chinese projects across 145 countries.  The sample was further refined through iterative searches and manual review, resulting in a final dataset of 155 AI-related projects.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved iterative refinement of search terms, manual coding of projects into AI application or AI infrastructure categories, and the addition of contextual information from external sources.  The final dataset was used to create an interactive world map and country selector tool.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Creation of the China’s AI Exports Database (CAIED) by combining data from AidData’s GCDF dataset, Electoral Democracy Index, Freedom House data, UN Conference on Trade and Development database, and DLA Piper database.  Quantitative analysis based on CAIED. Qualitative analysis through two country case studies (Kenya and Pakistan) involving in-depth interviews and social media analysis (Brandwatch sentiment analysis of Twitter data).

sections.title: Limitations
sections.methods_summary: Discusses limitations of the quantitative study, including data availability (2000-2017 data used), inconsistent definitions of AI, lack of exploration of gifting in China's export packages, and limitations of the indices used (V-Dem, Electoral Democracy Index, UN Data Protection Law Status, DLA Piper Index, and Technology Sector Index).  Also discusses limitations of the qualitative interviews (small sample size, potential bias due to RAND's US-based status), and social media analysis (selection bias inherent in social media data, inability to interpret user intentions).

sections.title: Methodology for Building China’s AI Exports Database (CAIED)
sections.methods_summary: Details the creation of CAIED using AidData's GCDF dataset version 2.0.  This involved screening for AI projects, generating AI application indicators (defining AI application and infrastructure projects), selecting project-level variables, and adding country governance and data policy variables (from V-Dem, Electoral Democracy Index, UN Conference on Trade and Development, and DLA Piper).  Describes the iterative process of refining search keywords, conducting manual reviews, and developing coding criteria and rules for the AI application indicator.  Explains the process of coding 'maybe' projects and salvaging originally excluded projects.  Finally, it details the selection of variables from the AidData GCDF 2.0 dataset and the addition of technology categories and country-level information (political regime, Electoral Democracy Index, Freedom House rating, Data Protection Law Status, and DLA Piper data protection level).

sections.title: Methodology for the Qualitative Interviews and Social Media Analysis
sections.methods_summary: In-depth stakeholder interviews (18 total: 8 in Pakistan, 10 in Kenya) conducted using a semi-structured interview protocol.  Data analysis involved axial coding. Social media analysis used Brandwatch to collect Twitter data using specific search terms (detailed in the appendix).

analysis.sample_description: The quantitative analysis uses data from 2000-2017 on 155 AI projects from China. The qualitative analysis includes in-depth interviews with 18 stakeholders in Kenya and Pakistan, and social media analysis of English-language Twitter data from 2021-2022.
analysis.analysis_approach: The quantitative analysis uses descriptive statistics and chi-square tests. The qualitative analysis uses axial coding to identify themes from interview transcripts and sentiment analysis of social media data.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Methodology - School Leaders' Awareness and Perceptions
sections.methods_summary: Survey of 664 high school principals from RAND's American School Leader Panel (ASLP) using probability-based sampling.  Responses weighted to be representative of the national population of public school principals. Analysis includes descriptive statistics and comparisons across school demographics (locale, enrollment size, poverty level, student racial/ethnic composition, region).

sections.title: Chapter 3: Methodology - JROTC Curriculum Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of 100- and 200-level JROTC textbooks from four service branches.  Two researchers independently coded 185 chapters across eight textbooks, focusing on military knowledge, civil-military relations, and civic development.  Coding framework based on state civics education standards. Inter-rater reliability established and discrepancies resolved through team consensus. Thematic analysis used to identify emergent themes.

sections.title: Chapter 4: Methodology - DoD Youth Programs, Military Presence, and Influence
sections.methods_summary: Quasi-experimental analysis using propensity score weighting to compare military applications and accessions in communities with and without DoD youth programs. Data combined from American Community Survey (ACS), Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC), and DoD youth program locations.  Military presence calculated using a spatial exposure index.  Treatment tracts defined based on distance to nearest program, varying by urbanicity (urban: 1.5 miles, suburban: 6 miles, rural: 17 miles). Negative binomial regression models used to estimate incidence rate ratios (IRRs), accounting for state-fixed effects and propensity score weights.  Analysis conducted separately for urban, suburban, and rural tracts, with a meta-analytic average for overall US estimate.

sections.title: Appendix A: American School Leader Panel Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: Details the survey methodology for the American School Leader Panel (ASLP) survey, including sampling, weighting, and analysis of responses across school demographics.  Mentions skip logic used in survey design.

sections.title: Appendix B: JROTC Textbook Analysis Technical Appendix
sections.methods_summary: Describes the data sources and methodological approach for analyzing JROTC textbooks.  Details the steps involved in identifying civics content and standards, establishing a coding framework, ensuring coding reliability, and conducting thematic analysis to identify emergent themes.

sections.title: Appendix C: Estimating the Association Between DoD Youth Programs and Military Accessions and Applications
sections.methods_summary: Details data sources (ACS, DMDC, DoD youth program locations, DISDI, recruitment station locations), geocoding procedures, and the creation of the analytic sample. Explains the calculation of military presence using a spatial exposure index and the definition of application starts, continuations, and accessions, including secondary outcomes (high-quality, technical eligible, historically marginalized populations). Describes the propensity score weighting approach using Generalized Boosted Models (GBMs) to create propensity score weights (PSWs).  Negative binomial regression models used to estimate IRRs, accounting for state-fixed effects and PSWs. Covariate balance assessed before estimating outcome models.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from multiple sources, including a nationally representative survey of high school principals, JROTC textbooks, and data from the American Community Survey (ACS) and the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC).  The sample for the quantitative analysis includes approximately 72,000 census tracts.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves descriptive statistics, thematic analysis of qualitative data, and regression modeling with propensity score weighting to account for non-random program placement.  Meta-analysis is used to combine estimates across different urbanicity categories.

sections.title: Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach.  This included focused legal and policy reviews of statutes, personnel and resource policies, and processes affecting Air Reserve Component (ARC) utilization.  Informational discussions were conducted with 37 senior U.S. Air Force leaders to identify challenges and potential solutions.  Finally, an analysis of U.S. Air Force personnel data from the Manpower Military Personnel Appropriations Man-Day Management System (M4S) was performed, focusing on demand for and supply of ARC members for operational missions.

analysis.sample_description: 37 senior military and civilian U.S. Air Force personnel participated in informational discussions.
analysis.analysis_approach: Findings from document reviews and interviews were synthesized to identify potential actions.  Data from the M4S (Beast table, Mobilization on Tour table, Active-Duty Operational Support table) were analyzed to characterize requests for ARC personnel by various factors (AFSC, support type, command level, mission area, requirement category, mission region) and to characterize individuals approaching the 1,095 man-day rule reporting requirement.

sections.title: Appendix A: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research involved two phases: an exploratory phase and an in-depth phase. The exploratory phase used desk research to gather and inventory relevant sources, employing various databases and search strings.  Inclusion criteria focused on location (case study countries), language (English, Dutch, German, French, Italian, Swedish), subject (safe country lists, Articles 36 and 37 of the Procedures Directive), date (post-2012), and document type (peer-reviewed publications, grey literature, PhD theses, policy documents, national legislation, editorials, opinion pieces, comments/letters, and blogs). The in-depth phase included additional literature research, jurisprudence research, and semi-structured interviews with experts and stakeholders in the case study countries and the Netherlands.  A total of 18 interviews were conducted (at least three per case study country), using a topic guide based on the research questions.  The interviews were analyzed using an extraction spreadsheet. The findings were used to supplement information from the literature and jurisprudence research and to draft the chapters on the various case study countries.  These draft chapters were then submitted to all interviewed experts for verification and to provide additional information.

analysis.sample_description: Five EU member states (Germany, France, Italy, Austria, and Sweden) were selected as case studies based on criteria including the number of excluded groups and regions, geographical location, volume of asylum applications, relevance to Dutch policy, information availability, and list length.  The Netherlands was also included for comparison.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data was extracted using a template organized around the research questions.  Interview notes were analyzed using an extraction spreadsheet.  Findings were triangulated across literature, jurisprudence, and interview data. Draft chapters were reviewed by interviewees for accuracy and additional information.

sections.title: Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a comparative approach, creating benchmark groups representing the spectrum of potential National Guard Youth ChalleNGe participants: high school dropouts without equivalent credentials, high school dropouts with GEDs, and high school graduates who did not attend college.  Data from three large public surveys (Current Population Survey, National Longitudinal Survey of Youth, and Education Longitudinal Study) were used to determine population averages for each benchmark group across a range of outcome measures.  These averages served as benchmarks for comparison with Youth ChalleNGe participants.

sections.title: Methodological Approach of This Research
sections.methods_summary: The study established population benchmarks to inform expectations of reasonable outcomes for program participants. Instead of an RCT, it devised population averages from three groups (high school dropouts without equivalent credentials, high school dropouts with GEDs, and high school graduates who did not attend college) to compare with Youth ChalleNGe participants.  These groups represented the scope of potential selection for the program.

sections.title: High School Dropouts, GED Holders, High School Graduates
sections.methods_summary: Definitions of the three benchmark groups are provided, clarifying how each group was identified within the datasets.  The rationale for including these specific groups is explained in terms of representing the range of potential Youth ChalleNGe participants.

sections.title: Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: The study used three publicly available datasets: the Current Population Survey (CPS) October Supplements (1996-2016), the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth 1997 Cohort (NLSY97), and the Education Longitudinal Study of 2002 (ELS2002).  Detailed descriptions of each dataset are provided, including how high school dropouts, GED holders, and high school graduates (without postsecondary enrollment) were identified within each.  The chapter also discusses the strengths and limitations of each dataset and how the samples were constructed for the analysis, acknowledging differences in sample characteristics and definitions across the datasets.

analysis.sample_description: Three benchmark groups were created: high school dropouts without equivalent credentials, high school dropouts with GEDs, and high school graduates who did not attend college. Data were drawn from the Current Population Survey (CPS), National Longitudinal Survey of Youth (NLSY), and Education Longitudinal Study (ELS).  The samples varied in size and specific characteristics across the datasets.
analysis.analysis_approach: Population averages for each benchmark group were calculated across a range of outcome measures using data from three large public surveys. These averages served as benchmarks for comparison with Youth ChalleNGe participants.  The analysis compared the benchmark groups at two time periods: around the time of dropping out and in the years following.

sections.title: Method
sections.methods_summary: This section details the three components of the research methodology: a literature review of school-based mental health services; a survey of all 39 ChalleNGe sites to gather data on counseling models, including questions on consideration of behavioral and mental health during the application process, number of licensed counselors, and number of cadets taking prescription drugs for mental health disorders; and case studies involving semi-structured interviews with counselors from six ChalleNGe sites, focusing on counselor background, observed cadet issues, counseling practices, site policies, handling of diagnosed and undiagnosed problems, data tracking, staff interactions, staffing needs, and advice for hiring counselors.

analysis.sample_description: The survey included data from all 39 ChalleNGe sites.  Interviews were conducted with counselors from six ChalleNGe sites; these sites were selected based on interview notes from prior site visits, prioritizing sites where staff mentioned behavioral or mental health issues as a challenge and had a trained counselor on staff. The selected sites were generally older and well-established, with a mix of sizes and locations.
analysis.analysis_approach: Survey data were tabulated and analyzed to understand the prevalence of mental health issues among cadets and staffing levels. Interview responses were coded for themes and unique practices.  The analysis focused on identifying common themes across sites and highlighting innovative practices.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research to answer the four questions was conducted in four steps: 1) extensive literature review on proxy warfare; 2) quantitative analysis to assess trends and drivers of proxy wars; 3) case studies of three major U.S. adversaries (Russia, China, Iran) to determine their motivations for engaging in proxy warfare; 4) case studies of four proxy wars (First and Second Indochina Wars, Houthi Rebellion, Donbas War) to assess military implications of sophisticated VNSAs.

analysis.sample_description: The case studies included three major U.S. adversaries (Russia, China, and Iran) and four proxy wars (First and Second Indochina Wars, Houthi Rebellion, and Donbas War).  Weaker states were intentionally excluded from the qualitative analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis of trends and drivers of proxy wars, and qualitative analysis through case studies to determine motivations and military implications.

sections.title: Ethical and Legal Considerations Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of ethical frameworks from the United States, UK, and Australia; analysis of UN discussions on Lethal Autonomous Weapons Systems (LAWS); review of government policies on military AI and autonomous weapons; interviews with U.S. State Department officials.

sections.title: Legal Review Processes Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Comparative analysis of Article 36 legal review processes in Australia, the UK, and the United States; identification of common steps in legal review processes based on existing literature; analysis of differences in approaches among the three countries.

sections.title: Expert Interviews and Literature Review
sections.methods_summary: Thirteen interviews with AI and defense policy experts from five U.S. allies and partners (anonymity guaranteed); open-source scan of government, scholarly, and grey literature using keywords such as 'autonomous weapon systems', 'military co-development', 'AUKUS', 'ITAR', 'export control', 'military artificial intelligence', and 'ethical challenges of LAWS'; data sources included RAND Knowledge Services database, Scopus, and Google Scholar.

sections.title: Case Study Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of two case studies: the Future Combat Air System (FCAS) and the Nulka Active Missile Decoy.  The analysis focuses on challenges and successes in multinational co-development, considering factors such as common conceptual approaches, domestic and industrial pressures, and regulatory and technical barriers.

analysis.sample_description: For the expert interviews, 13 experts in AI and defense policy from 5 different U.S. allies and partners were interviewed.  Anonymity was guaranteed.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report uses comparative analysis to examine the approaches of Australia, the UK, and the US to ethical considerations, legal review processes, and export controls.  Case studies are used to illustrate the challenges and opportunities of military technology collaboration.  Qualitative data from interviews and document analysis are presented.

sections.title: Survey Design and Content, Sampling, Field Dates, and Response, Weighting
sections.methods_summary: This section details the survey design, including the selection of research topics and questions, the estimated survey length, and conditional question branching.  It describes the sampling procedure (inviting 2,622 panel members from the RAND American Life Panel, a nationally representative internet panel recruited through random digit dialing), the survey fielding dates (May 1-6, 2020), the response rate (78%), and the weighting methodology used to match sample characteristics to the U.S. adult population using a raking algorithm and chained imputation for missing data.  A note addresses a technical error affecting three questions fielded later.

analysis.sample_description: The study used data from the RAND American Life Panel (ALP), a nationally representative internet panel recruited primarily through random digit dialing.  Those without internet access were provided with necessary equipment.  2,622 panel members were invited to participate in the May 1-6, 2020 survey; 2,052 participated (78% response rate).  The sample was weighted to match the distribution of characteristics in the U.S. adult population based on the March 2019 Current Population Survey.
analysis.analysis_approach: The document does not explicitly detail the analysis techniques used beyond mentioning the weighting methodology (raking algorithm and chained imputation for missing data).

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with 20 members of national or local organizations in California serving AAPI communities.  A two-pronged sampling strategy was used: referral-based snowball sampling and random selection from a database of AAPI organizations.  Data analysis used a rapid qualitative approach due to time and resource constraints, involving detailed note-taking, development of a preliminary conceptual framework, and iterative refinement of the framework through regular meetings and analysis of emerging constructs.

analysis.sample_description: 20 interviewees representing various national and local organizations in California serving diverse AAPI communities (from ethnic communities to specific populations like youth, women, and LGBTQ individuals).  Sampling involved referral-based snowball sampling and random selection stratified by specific subgroups (e.g., young people, older people, women, LGBTQ people, AAPI in general, Chinese, South Asian, other East and Southeast Asian communities).
analysis.analysis_approach: Rapid qualitative analysis: detailed note-taking for each interview using a template; development of a preliminary conceptual framework; regular meetings to identify emerging constructs and guide subsequent interviews; iterative addition of findings and new content to the framework; this process facilitated efficient organization of data and identification of knowledge gaps for future research.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A workshop was organized bringing together 24 experts and former officials from Europe and the United States for non-attribution discussions on four topics. This report summarizes the dialogue among participants and includes background on the geopolitical context provided by the organizers.

analysis.sample_description: 24 experts and former officials from Europe and the United States.
analysis.analysis_approach: Summary and synthesis of discussions from a workshop on Russia, NATO, and Black Sea Strategy.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the research methodology used in the report.  The authors investigated current U.S. tort doctrine by reviewing leading treatises and academic articles, judicial decisions, jury instructions, and Restatements of Torts. They accessed these materials through legal research databases (Westlaw, LexisNexis, Google Scholar) and conducted research on AI development and its potential harms by reviewing literature on databases like arXiv and Google Scholar.  The authors also drew upon their prior experience teaching and researching tort law, related legal doctrine, and AI governance.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable. This is a legal analysis, not an empirical study with a defined sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of legal doctrine and precedent. The authors identified specific tort doctrines for analysis based on an assessment of the likelihood that AI-caused harms might implicate those doctrines.

sections.title: Research Questions and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research involved a systematic approach with the following steps: reviewing existing research on ACFT, analyzing historical ACFT performance, developing defensible courses of action (COAs), recommending a sampling approach for a Practice Phase, evaluating Practice Phase results and developing a model to predict improvement, and conducting a workshop with soldiers to gather feedback on COAs.  Two types of standards (criterion-referenced and norm-referenced) were evaluated.

sections.title: Practice Phase Design and Results
sections.methods_summary: The Army conducted a Practice Phase to pilot higher ACFT standards.  The study used two primary approaches: increasing the overall point standard and increasing the MDL standard.  The Army ultimately chose a standard of 450 overall points and 150 pounds on the MDL.  Data from 47,744 Practice Phase test records were analyzed.  A comparison was made between Practice Phase performance and prior performance, and a model was developed to predict future improvement.

sections.title: Sample Construction for Practice Phase and Historical ACFT Results
sections.methods_summary: A set of inclusion criteria ('business rules') were applied to both historical and Practice Phase data.  These rules included restricting the data to October 2022 onward, soldiers aged 17-62, excluding soldiers on profile or with missing data, using only for-record ACFT results for historical data, restricting to close combat MOSs (excluding Special Forces), and considering only one test record per soldier (except for analyses of individual performance changes over time).  A statistical power analysis was conducted to determine sample sizes for the Practice Phase, considering subgroups by gender, age group, MOS, and component.  The final sample included 115,979 historical ACFT results and 44,293 Practice Phase ACFT results.

sections.title: ACFT Improvement Models
sections.methods_summary: Two mixed-effects models (one for raw MDL performance and one for total points) were fit to the historical ACFT longitudinal data.  Predictors included baseline ACFT performance, experience with the ACFT, gender, MOS, component, and interactions between these variables.  These models were used to generate predicted ACFT performance in September 2025 for Practice Phase participants.

sections.title: Additional Details on Workshop Methodology and Results
sections.methods_summary: A stakeholder workshop was conducted with 38 soldiers representing key subgroups.  The workshop aimed to identify challenges related to implementing higher standards and to identify potential policy mitigation strategies.  Participants rated the challenges associated with various standard options and brainstormed mitigation strategies.  The workshop included presentations, full-room discussions, and small-group discussions.

sections.title: Additional Background on Sources of ACFT Evidence
sections.methods_summary: The research reviewed five key sources of evidence: a meta-analysis of physical fitness tests and military task performance, data from the BSPRRS (Fort Riley and Fort Benning), RAND studies on ACFT and injury risk, and OPAT studies.  The appendix also details how ACFT events were linked to combat task performance and injury prevention, and provides an example of a method to establish specific cutoff scores.

analysis.sample_description: The study used historical Army Combat Fitness Test (ACFT) data and data from a large-scale Army Practice Phase.  The Practice Phase sample aimed to represent various subgroups (gender, age, MOS, component), though some subgroups were underrepresented due to operational constraints.  A workshop included 38 soldiers representing various subgroups.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis included descriptive statistics, regression analysis (linear and logistic), and the development of predictive models to estimate future ACFT performance.  Confidence intervals were calculated to quantify uncertainty in pass rate estimates.  Qualitative data from the soldier workshop were also analyzed.

sections.title: Landscape Review: Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach.  A landscape review involved targeted searches of key agency and organization websites in three geographic locations (Atlanta, Los Angeles County, New York City), supplemented by expansive online searches using Boolean operators.  Specific search terms are listed in Appendix A.  Data extracted included funding source, program name, application links, eligibility requirements, geographic scope, funding amount, time period, need categories, and target populations.  A secondary search focused on funding for specific youth populations.  Results from the first ten search results (or fewer, if relevance decreased) were reviewed, and links to other funding sources were followed.  An additional search focused on organizations administering the funds, particularly Chafee grants, in the three geographic areas.

sections.title: Landscape Review: Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Data from webpages and databases were abstracted into a spreadsheet, developed collaboratively by team members and based on the funding agency's aims.  The spreadsheet compiled information on funding opportunities, including source, amount, timeline, need category, method, and eligibility criteria.  Characteristics of the funding (permanency, spend-down period, application process, enrollment caps) were also recorded.  Opportunities were categorized by recipient type and funding type.  Two team members (JR and EB) conducted the abstraction process, with input from the full research team to resolve discrepancies.  A codebook was used to ensure consistency.  The spreadsheet was reviewed for accuracy, completeness, consistency, and clarity.  Three program exemplars per geographic location were identified to illustrate services and supports.

sections.title: Interviews: Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: Semi-structured interviews were conducted virtually (ZoomGov) with experts and stakeholders to identify barriers and facilitators to accessing funding and services for foster TAY.  Participants included representatives from organizations supporting foster youth, foster TAY (ages 18–25), and foster caregivers.  Organizations were identified through website reviews and in consultation with the Conrad N. Hilton Foundation.  Foster TAY and caregivers were recruited through the organizations.  Each interview was led by one researcher with a notetaker present.  Interview protocols are in Appendix B. Interviews were recorded and transcribed.  Foster TAY and caregivers received a $50 Amazon gift card.

sections.title: Interviews: Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Interview transcripts were uploaded into Dedoose for qualitative data analysis.  The interview lead developed an initial codebook, which was applied to three transcripts by the lead and a second team member.  After initial coding, the codebook was revised, and the remaining transcripts were coded independently by the lead and a second team member.  Subthemes were added as they emerged.  Coders met to discuss coding and resolve disagreements.

analysis.sample_description: The study focused on three geographic areas: metro Atlanta, Los Angeles County, and New York City.  The landscape review covered funding sources available from 2018–2023.  Interviews were conducted with nine organizations serving foster TAY, nine foster TAY, and five caregivers.  Interview participants were recruited using convenience sampling.
analysis.analysis_approach: The landscape review data were abstracted into a spreadsheet and analyzed descriptively.  Qualitative interview data were analyzed using thematic analysis with a codebook to ensure consistency.

sections.title: Quantitative Evaluation: Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the quantitative methods used in the evaluation.  It describes the data sources (MHSA FSP Data Collection and Reporting System (DCR) and EHRs), outcome metrics (stable housing, psychiatric admissions, justice system involvement, social connection), statistical models (pre-post comparison, regression models including linear, zero-inflated negative binomial, and logit models), and how service utilization was analyzed in relation to outcomes.

sections.title: Qualitative Evaluation: Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the qualitative methods.  It outlines the sampling and recruitment of participants (DBH leadership and FSP providers), the interview protocol, procedures (verbal consent, Zoom interviews, audio recording, detailed note-taking), and data analysis (abstraction form, rapid thematic analysis, inter-rater reliability).

analysis.sample_description: The quantitative analysis used data from 2,555 FSP participants enrolled from July 2019 through October 2022 across six counties.  The qualitative analysis involved 31 semi-structured interviews with DBH leadership and FSP providers from the participating counties.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis involved pre-post comparisons of outcomes using linear, zero-inflated negative binomial, and logit regression models to assess the impact of FSP participation and the FSP Innovation Project. Qualitative data analysis used a rapid thematic analysis approach to identify recurring themes and patterns in the interview data.

sections.title: Research Question and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research assessed the evolving capability and readiness of European air forces to contribute to high-intensity conflict.  It identified issues European air forces could address to be central contributors to NATO's deterrent posture.  The study examined Russian perspectives on evolving NATO combat airpower to understand mission areas of significance to Russian decisionmakers.  The analysis focused on high-intensity operations in a European theater, assuming an Article 5 declaration and full member contributions.  The study used documentary research, interviews, and roundtable discussions with experts from the US and European air forces and NATO commands.  The assessment framework used two factors: force structure and technology (fighter aircraft and munitions inventories, including subsystems and add-ons), and readiness (equipment availability, personnel, training, and exercises). The 13 European nations selected for the study each maintained at least two squadrons of fourth- and/or fifth-generation aircraft, advanced munitions, and associated training.

analysis.sample_description: 13 European nations maintaining at least two squadrons of fourth- and/or fifth-generation aircraft, advanced munitions, and associated training.
analysis.analysis_approach: Two-factor assessment framework: force structure and technology, and readiness.  Synthesis of insights from research methods into a framework.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative interviews with three groups of stakeholders: administrators of programs employing Peer Support Specialists (PSSs), PSSs themselves, and PSS service users.  A convenience sample was used, recruiting from six counties with established peer support services. Semistructured interview protocols were developed for each group. Interviews were conducted via Zoom (or phone), audio-recorded (where possible), and transcribed. Rapid qualitative data analysis was used, employing abstraction forms to record respondent comments and themes.  The analysis involved individual summaries, team review, and consensus building to identify major themes and variations in responses.

analysis.sample_description: Convenience sample of administrators, PSSs, and service users from six diverse California counties with established peer support programs.  Sample sizes aimed for similarity across the three groups.
analysis.analysis_approach: Rapid qualitative data analysis using abstraction forms to record and summarize respondent comments related to pre-identified issues.  Team review and consensus building were used to identify major themes and variations in responses across groups.

sections.title: Model Development and Validation
sections.methods_summary: A literature review was conducted to gather information on jamming calculations, GPS performance, and inertial navigation system performance.  Mathematical models were developed based on the literature review and implemented in spreadsheet prototypes.  A Python implementation was created for greater flexibility and efficiency.  The spreadsheet and software versions were compared for validation.  Jamming estimates were checked against published sources and hand calculations.

sections.title: MJEM Model Description and Calculations
sections.methods_summary: The MJEM model mathematically calculates position error and the probability of target acquisition within the missile seeker's field of regard.  It uses systems and electrical engineering estimation techniques, including link budget analysis, to evaluate model outputs from inputs.  Specific calculations are detailed for jamming ranges (GPS and IFTU), missile navigation system errors (GPS and INS), in-flight target update (IFTU) position and velocity errors, evasive maneuver position error, shooter position error, and final position error and probability of seeker acquisition. The model is implemented in Python using several defined classes.

analysis.sample_description: No specific sample is described; the model uses parameters representing various system characteristics and scenarios.
analysis.analysis_approach: The model uses mathematical equations and algorithms to estimate performance measures based on input parameters.  Results are presented graphically and numerically to illustrate model behavior and sensitivity to input variations.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods approach including literature review, three focus groups with ASCS students at the UK Defence Academy, and engagement with ten external experts.

analysis.sample_description: Three focus groups with Advanced Command and Staff Course (ASCS) students at the UK Defence Academy and ten external experts.
analysis.analysis_approach: Key insights from the study are summarized in the research brief.  No specific analytical techniques beyond qualitative synthesis are described.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: An online survey was developed and fielded to YourDMH stakeholder group members.  DMH provided a list of email addresses (3,106 with valid addresses) including voting members and attendees.  An email with a link to the confidential survey was sent, with up to four reminders. The survey was open from July 1 to 24, 2024.  Individual questions were not required, resulting in varying sample sizes due to nonresponse.  A subset of questions was administered to nonparticipants (72 of 222 respondents).

analysis.sample_description: The sample consisted of 3,106 individuals with valid email addresses provided by DMH, including voting members, attendees, and those who expressed interest in the groups.  222 responded (7% response rate).  The sample was racially diverse, with a high percentage of female respondents and family members of mental health consumers. 38% identified as mental health consumers.
analysis.analysis_approach: Chi-square tests were used to compare groups' satisfaction levels. Two-sample t-tests were used to compare group means for inclusive leadership and psychological safety scores.

sections.title: Overview of Methods
sections.methods_summary: Integrated five quantitative and qualitative data sources: (1) peer-reviewed publications (through October 31, 2020), (2) Program documentation (through February 2021), (3) transcripts of 12 structured focus groups (December 2019–February 2020), (4) transcripts of individual stakeholder interviews (October–November 2020), and (5) gray literature publications (through November 30, 2020). Mixed methods analysis.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Four research questions guided the analyses.  Integrated five quantitative and qualitative data sources: (1) peer-reviewed publications (through October 31, 2020), (2) Program documentation of research activities (through February 2021), (3) transcripts of 12 structured focus group discussions (December 2019–February 2020), (4) transcripts of individual stakeholder interviews (October–November 2020), and (5) gray literature publications (through November 30, 2020). Mixed methods analysis.  For RQ1, data collected from nearly 1,000 peer-reviewed publications using an electronic abstraction form, charted data into categories using PI/ECOTSS, study classifications (exposure characterization, exposure-outcome linkage, outcome modification), and the NIEHS Translational Framework. For RQ2, synthesized qualitative data from gray literature, Program documentation, focus groups, and interviews; applied a machine-learning algorithm. For RQ3, synthesized qualitative data; applied a priori codebooks. For RQ4, several analyses were run; a priori coding; three case studies using the NIEHS Translational Research Framework.

sections.title: Appendix C. Methods Overview
sections.methods_summary: Describes research question development and refinement, data collection and processing (peer-reviewed publications, program documentation, focus groups, interviews, gray literature), data integration and mixed methods analysis, and case studies of research translation using the NIEHS Translational Research Framework.  Details on systematic review methods for peer-reviewed publications, including search strategy, screening criteria, data abstraction, and analysis.  Details on thematic content analysis of program documentation, focus group methodology, interview methodology, gray literature search strategy and analysis using machine learning (bag of words, supervised classification, stratified K-fold cross-validation).

sections.title: Appendix D. Scoping Review: Search Strategy for Peer-Reviewed Publications
sections.methods_summary: Details the search strategy used for six databases (OVID MEDLINE, Psychinfo, Scopus, Web of Science, CINAHL, Embase) including search terms and limits applied.  Describes validation steps comparing search results with Program resources.

sections.title: Appendix E. Scoping Review: Data Abstraction Topics
sections.methods_summary: Lists the topics covered in the data abstraction form used for the scoping review.

analysis.sample_description: The study included peer-reviewed publications, program documentation, focus group discussions with various stakeholders (responders, survivors, program leaders, clinicians, researchers), individual stakeholder interviews, and gray literature publications.  Specific numbers of participants are provided for focus groups and interviews.
analysis.analysis_approach: Mixed methods analysis integrating quantitative and qualitative data.  Specific analysis techniques include thematic analysis,  machine learning algorithms (bag of words, supervised classification, stratified K-fold cross-validation), and application of the NIEHS Translational Research Framework for case studies.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Literature review to identify significant events in military behavioral health (2003-2013). Development of structured procedures for identifying and describing key events. Creation of two conceptual frameworks to organize background material and interview insights. Collection of 96 events (categorized by source type). Expert consultation to identify missed materials. Selection of 42 experts, interviews with 17 (approx. 90 minutes each).  Development of two databases: a timeline of key events and a collection of interviews/transcripts.

sections.title: Interview Procedures
sections.methods_summary: Lead author conducted all interviews.  Interviewees signed release forms for recording. Interviews lasted approximately 90 minutes and were conducted in person, by phone, or via Zoom.  Interviewee selection was based on experience with significant events, professional role, branch of service, period of service, and influence on policy. Snowball sampling was used.  A total of 42 potential interviewees were identified, with 17 interviewed.  Interview goals were defined, but content was open-ended.  Early interviews informed later interviews.

sections.title: Interview Protocol
sections.methods_summary: Provided a protocol to interviewees to guide discussion.  The protocol included primary questions about changes in the mental health delivery system, prompts for describing events and policy changes, and potential topic areas for practitioners and policymakers.  The protocol also included questions about hindsight and lessons learned.

analysis.sample_description: 17 experts (out of 42 potential candidates) were interviewed.  The sample included policymakers and clinicians from different service branches and leadership levels.  Social workers, behavioral health technicians, and congressional policymakers were not included.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis was largely descriptive and interpretive, drawing inferences from the interviews and timeline of events.  A structured qualitative analysis was not conducted due to time, budget, and regulatory constraints. The authors acknowledge the subjective nature of the analysis and the potential for bias in selecting events, interviewees, topics, and interview excerpts.

sections.title: Case Study Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research uses a qualitative case study approach, examining five U.S. allies (Australia, Japan, the Philippines, Republic of Korea, and Thailand) individually to assess their likelihood of hosting U.S. GBIRMs.  Data is collected from a variety of sources including government documents, public speeches and interviews, expert analysis, and media reports.  Analysis focuses on domestic political conditions, regional security trends, and bilateral relations between the U.S. and each ally.

sections.title: Analysis of Alternatives to Permanent Basing
sections.methods_summary: This section examines four alternative approaches to permanent basing of GBIRMs: co-development/foreign military sales, crisis deployment, peacetime rotational deployment, and deployment on Guam or Compact of Free Association states.  The analysis involves a comparative assessment of the political feasibility and operational advantages/disadvantages of each alternative, drawing on existing literature and expert knowledge.

analysis.sample_description: Five U.S. treaty allies in the Indo-Pacific region: Australia, Japan, the Philippines, Republic of Korea, and Thailand.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of various data sources to assess the political and operational feasibility of different deployment options for GBIRMs.  The analysis considers factors such as domestic political conditions, regional security dynamics, bilateral relations, and operational constraints.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Linear probability models were used to estimate differences between proportions of teachers in various groups (elementary vs. secondary, higher vs. lower poverty schools). Linearized standard errors and survey weights were used in all models.  The Affective Experiences Scale (AES) was used to measure teacher well-being.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Linear probability models were used to estimate differences between the proportion of teachers in elementary and secondary schools who at least agreed (agreed or strongly agreed). Linearized standard errors and survey weights are used in all models.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Linear probability models were used to estimate differences between the proportion of teachers in elementary and secondary schools who at least agreed (agreed or strongly agreed). Linearized standard errors and survey weights are used in all models.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Survey weights were used in all tabulations.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Linear probability models were used to estimate differences between the proportion of teachers in elementary and secondary schools who responded a few times per year or more (a few times per year or monthly or more often). Linearized standard errors and survey weights are used in all models.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Linear probability models were used to estimate whether all three responses (“yes,” “no,” and “I don’t know”) were equal. Linearized standard errors and survey weights are used in all models.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Linear probability models were used to estimate differences between the proportion of teachers in elementary and secondary schools who responded at least a moderate extent (a moderate extent or a great extent). Linearized standard errors and survey weights are used in all models.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Linear probability models were used to estimate differences in proportions of teachers in elementary and secondary schools who responded at least sometimes (sometimes or often). Linearized standard errors and survey weights are used in all models.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Linear probability models were used to estimate differences in proportions of teachers in elementary and secondary schools who responded at least to a moderate extent (a moderate extent or a great extent). Linearized standard errors and survey weights are used in all models.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Linear probability models were used to estimate whether all three responses (“yes,” “no,” or “I don’t know”) were equal. Linearized standard errors and survey weights are used in all models.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Regression analysis was used to examine relationships between teacher well-being and SEL practices, controlling for school and teacher characteristics. A composite measure of SEL-supporting pedagogy was created by averaging teachers' responses to relevant survey questions.

sections.title: Data Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Regression analysis was used to examine relationships between teacher well-being and SEL practices, controlling for school and teacher characteristics.  Two sets of regression analyses were conducted for each of the three well-being scales: one without and one with a measure of school supports for SEL.

sections.title: Study Design and Sampling
sections.methods_summary: Spring 2019 survey of a nationally representative sample of K–12 public school teachers.  The sample was weighted to ensure national representativeness in terms of teacher and school characteristics.  Subgroup analyses were conducted for elementary vs. secondary schools, urban vs. non-urban schools, higher vs. lower poverty schools.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative sample of K–12 public school teachers surveyed in Spring 2019.  Sample weighted to ensure representativeness based on teacher and school characteristics. Subgroup analyses conducted based on school type (elementary vs. secondary), location (urban vs. non-urban), poverty level (high vs. low).
analysis.analysis_approach: Linear probability models and regression analyses were used to examine relationships between teacher responses and various factors (e.g., school type, poverty level, teacher well-being, etc.).  Survey weights and linearized standard errors were used to account for sampling design.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Patient Population and Sampling
sections.methods_summary: Describes the target population (adult patients with ambulatory palliative care visits), sampling frame creation using data from the Center to Advance Palliative Care and NCHPC, program recruitment strategies (oversampling larger programs, stratification by administrative home type and geographic location), patient sampling procedures (data file submission from programs, data processing and cleaning at RAND, filtering for eligibility, selection of reference provider), and data collection procedures (mixed-mode survey administration: web, mail, and telephone follow-up; prenotification letter, email invitations, reminders, mailed surveys, CATI interviews).  Details the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on data collection, including a pause and subsequent modifications to the survey instrument.

sections.title: Chapter 3: Critical Data Element Testing: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Describes scale development (selection of data elements, modification and refinement, cognitive interviews, input from TECUPP and advisory group), data element reliability assessment (Cronbach's alpha for internal consistency, test-retest reliability using a subset of telephone respondents), and data element validity assessment (convergent validity using bivariate correlations with CAHPS communication measure and Receiving Desired Help for Pain measure).

sections.title: Chapter 4: Performance Measure Testing: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Describes performance measure characteristics (distribution of unadjusted scores), risk adjustment (identification of potential risk factors through literature review and stakeholder input, statistical testing for association with measure scores and differences across programs using Fisher's exact test and ANOVA), diagnosis analysis (exploratory descriptive analysis to assess potential variation in measure performance by diagnosis), performance measure exclusions (patients who did not complete at least one data element, did not return the survey within six months, disavowed the program, were deceased, or had proxy-only responses), performance measure scoring (comparison of different scoring approaches, selection of top-box scoring, use of hierarchical generalized linear models for risk-adjusted scores), statistically significant and meaningful differences in performance (testing using likelihood ratio statistic from generalized linear models, ranking approach to assess practical significance), performance measure score reliability (signal-to-noise analysis, hierarchical generalized linear regression models, adjusted intraclass correlation coefficient [ICC], Spearman-Brown prophecy formula for sample size estimation, program-specific reliability estimation), performance measure score validity (bivariate correlations with Receiving Desired Help for Pain, CAHPS communication, and overall rating of provider), and face validity (expert panel ratings).

sections.title: Appendix B: Methods and Analytic Procedures
sections.methods_summary: Provides detailed technical information on performance measure scoring (hierarchical generalized linear models with binomial outcomes and provider-level random effects), statistically significant and meaningful differences in performance (likelihood ratio statistic from generalized linear models), and performance measure score reliability (hierarchical generalized linear models, adjusted ICC, Spearman-Brown prophecy formula).

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consisted of adult patients (18 years and older) who received ambulatory palliative care visits.  The sample was drawn from 44 palliative care programs across the United States, with an oversampling of larger programs and stratification by administrative home type and geographic location. A mixed-mode survey was administered to approximately 7,595 patients, resulting in 2,804 completed surveys used for analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved multiple statistical techniques, including hierarchical generalized linear models to account for the hierarchical structure of the data (patients nested within programs), Bayesian methods for estimating reliability and ICC, bivariate correlations to assess validity, ANOVA and Fisher's exact tests for risk adjustment analyses, and a ranking approach to interpret the practical significance of program-level differences.

sections.title: Patient Population and Sampling
sections.methods_summary: Describes the target population (adult patients with ambulatory palliative care visits), sampling frame creation using data from the Center to Advance Palliative Care and NCHPC, program recruitment strategies (oversampling larger programs, stratification by administrative home type and geographic location), patient sampling procedures (data file submission from programs, data processing and cleaning at RAND, filtering and refinement of data to create sampling file, selection of reference provider), and data collection procedures (mixed-mode survey administration: web, mail, telephone follow-up; prenotification letter, email invitations, survey mailing, telephone interviews, survey instrument versions, impact of COVID-19 pandemic on data collection).

sections.title: Critical Data Element Testing: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Describes methods for evaluating the reliability and validity of the 'Receiving Desired Help for Pain' data element.  This includes examining response distribution, assessing reliability using test-retest reliability coefficient and percent agreement (with a subset of respondents at two time points), and assessing convergent validity by examining associations with CAHPS communication measure and the 'Feeling Heard and Understood' measure using bivariate correlations.

sections.title: Performance Measure Specifications: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Describes methods for constructing and testing the 'Receiving Desired Help for Pain' performance measure. This includes examining the distribution of unadjusted measure scores, risk adjustment (identifying potential risk factors through literature review and statistical testing, selecting risk adjusters, and assessing their association with the measure and differences across programs), diagnosis analysis (exploratory descriptive analysis to identify potential variation in measure performance by diagnosis), performance measure exclusions (considering the impact of proxy assistance and applying exclusions based on proxy assistance, nonresponse, program disavowal, and death), performance measure scoring (using hierarchical generalized linear models), assessing statistically significant and meaningful differences in performance (using techniques similar to ANOVA to compare full and reduced models, and a ranking approach to assess practical significance), assessing performance measure score reliability (using a signal-to-noise analysis, hierarchical generalized linear regression models, adjusted intraclass correlation coefficient [ICC], and Spearman-Brown prophecy formula), and evaluating performance measure score validity (examining associations with other measures using bivariate correlations) and face validity (expert panel review).

sections.title: Appendix B: Methods and Analytic Procedures
sections.methods_summary: Provides further detail on performance measure scoring using hierarchical generalized linear models, statistically significant and meaningful differences in performance using likelihood ratio statistics, and performance measure score reliability using hierarchical generalized linear models and the Spearman-Brown prophecy formula.

analysis.sample_description: A nationally representative sample of 44 ambulatory palliative care programs across the United States.  The final analytic sample consisted of 2,804 completed patient surveys.  The sample was predominantly female, White, non-Hispanic/Latino, and highly educated.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data element and measure-level reliability and validity were assessed.  Hierarchical generalized linear models were used to estimate risk-adjusted program-level measure scores and assess reliability.  Bivariate correlations were used to assess convergent validity.  Qualitative data from program and patient interviews were analyzed using thematic analysis.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Review of USAF and DoD policies, interviews with senior USAF leaders, and a survey of recent PME in-residence graduates.

sections.title: Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach.  It involved a review of USAF and DoD policies on PME, semi-structured interviews with senior USAF leaders responsible for PME, and a survey of 4036 Air Force officers who graduated from IDE or SDE in-residence programs between 2014 and 2018.  The survey had four versions based on program type (fellowship vs. schoolhouse) and education level (IDE vs. SDE).  The response rate was 30%.  Analysis included descriptive statistics, comparisons of responses across groups, and regression analysis. Qualitative data from open-ended survey questions were coded thematically.

analysis.sample_description: The survey population consisted of all Air Force officers who graduated from either IDE or SDE in-residence programs between 2014 and 2018 (N=4036).  The final sample included 1313 respondents (30% response rate).  The sample was compared to the population to assess representativeness on variables such as race/ethnicity, gender, and primary Air Force specialty code (PAFSC).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved descriptive statistics for survey responses.  For ranking questions, a binary outcome was created (ranked in top three or not).  Likert-type and fixed-choice items were aggregated into scales based on exploratory factor analysis.  Regression analysis was used to examine the relationships between variables.  Qualitative data from open-ended comments were coded thematically.

sections.title: Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: Review of 98 peer-reviewed articles and reports published from 2010-2019 from Web of Science, PubMed, and disaster-related databases.  Qualitative synthesis of findings due to diversity of studies, preventing formal meta-analysis.  Focus on mental health, economic, and community distress; exclusion of studies primarily focused on physical health impacts.  Initial results presented at a workshop in New Orleans for feedback.

sections.title: Appendix A. Report Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Scoping literature review combining topic searches in Web of Science and PubMed with reviews of 20 other online databases (research organizations, studies, funders, online libraries).  Multi-stage selection process: initial screening by title and document type, abstract review, and full-text review.  98 documents included in final review.  Coded on dimensions of DWH spill impacts, community resilience factors, knowledge gaps, and resilience improvement strategies.  Findings presented at a workshop with subject-matter experts for feedback through presentations and participatory exercises.  Draft report reviewed by CRGC team, workshop participants, and two independent peer reviewers.

analysis.sample_description: 98 peer-reviewed articles and reports on the Deepwater Horizon oil spill published between 2010 and 2019, sourced from various databases.  The included studies varied in research design, sampling strategy, sample type, and geographic area.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative synthesis of findings across diverse studies, due to the heterogeneity of the literature.  Workshop discussions with subject-matter experts to elicit feedback and identify recommendations.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: Four main steps: 1. Literature review (official and unofficial documents, articles, reports, papers from think tanks, military schools, journals, blogs); 2. Understanding ARSOF capabilities and limitations through review of doctrine, concepts, policies, histories, and interviews with personnel from various U.S. government agencies and organizations; 3. Review and extension of quantitative analyses of the effectiveness of operations in relevant fields (security sector assistance, deterrence, FID, covert regime overthrow, public communications campaigns); 4. Case studies of SOF use in competition with Russia (building UW capacity in the Baltics, Iraqi Counterterrorism Service, support to El Salvador, operations at Al-Tanf Garrison, Poland's Solidarity movement and covert U.S. OIE, U.S. OIE in the Balkans).

sections.title: Technical Discussion of Statistical Modeling of FID
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of 250 civil war episodes (1946-2014) from the UCDP/PRIO Armed Conflict Dataset (ACD).  Data on 57 military interventions on behalf of governments were synthesized from multiple datasets, focusing on interventions with at least 100 troops. Rebel support data (from the Non-State Actor dataset) were limited to support from the U.S., Russia/USSR, and China.  A two-stage logistic regression model was used. The first stage estimated the probability of intervention, generating propensity scores. The second stage estimated the effects of intervention (and control variables) on conflict outcomes (government victory, rebel victory, negotiated settlement).

analysis.sample_description: 250 episodes of violent conflict from 1946-2014; 57 instances of military interventions on behalf of governments; data on rebel support from the U.S., Russia/USSR, and China.
analysis.analysis_approach: Two-stage logistic regression to account for selection bias in interventions. Propensity score matching used to weight observations in the second stage.  Analysis of conflict outcomes controlled for rebel strength, rebel support, Cold War, population, peacekeeping operations, war type, and other factors.

sections.title: Appendix A: Methodology of Systematic Review
sections.methods_summary: A systematic review was conducted adapting the 3ie template guidelines.  Data was collected on title, author, publication, geographical coverage, region characteristics (democracy and media freedom measures), sector, review type, background, objectives, methodology, main findings, intervention details (platform, message type, novelty), sender characteristics, receiver characteristics, phases of change, competition, duration, and quality assessment.  Gray literature, non-English results, and studies outside the 2000-2019 date range were excluded.  Articles were pulled from top-tier journals, with search queries constructed to reflect diverse outcomes and interventions. Bibliographies were checked for relevant articles.  Quantitative studies were prioritized and evaluated for quality based on sample size, methods, sampling strategy, and pre-/post-test results.  Initially five categories (civic education, countering violent extremism, misinformation, electoral turnout, media literacy) were used, but these were consolidated into two (electoral campaigns and information dissemination) due to overlapping studies and a lack of studies in some areas.  A total of 137 articles were included in the final sample.

sections.title: Research Approach and Review Procedure
sections.methods_summary: A systematic review of academic literature on political or civic communication campaigns was conducted, adapting a framework based on 3ie guidelines.  Academic Search Complete, Scopus, and Web of Science databases were searched for relevant studies published between 2000 and 2019 (June-July 2019 search). Only peer-reviewed articles with quantitative measurement of communication campaign impact were included, drawn from a preset list of journals. Data collected included intervention type (delivery method, repetition), sender, message type, audience, number of participants, demographic specifics, substantive impact, effect size, and statistical significance.  Initially five areas of interest (civic education, countering violent extremism, misinformation, electoral turnout, media literacy) were examined, but these were consolidated into two (electoral campaigns and information dissemination).  729 articles were initially returned, with 158 selected and 137 quantitative evaluative articles remaining after excluding meta-analyses and non-quantitative work.  The review covered only English-language articles.

analysis.sample_description: 137 quantitative evaluative academic articles published in English between 2000 and 2019, primarily from top-tier journals, focusing on communication campaigns in the areas of civic education, countering violent extremism, misinformation, electoral turnout, and media literacy.  The sample was later consolidated into two categories: electoral campaigns and information dissemination.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved a systematic review of the literature, focusing on four key factors: face-to-face versus remote messaging, message content, targeting, and competition environment.  The findings were summarized and presented in tables and figures, with effect sizes and statistical significance considered.

sections.title: Methodology: Overview of Data and Regional Focus
sections.methods_summary: The study leverages geopolitical, socio-economic, and public opinion indicators (2010-2017) to analyze Russian global influence and hostile activities.  It assesses these activities across cognitive and physical realms in six regions: former Soviet states (excluding Baltics), Balkans, active conflict zones, NATO states, non-NATO European states, and the rest of the world. Data sources include news reports, investigative efforts, and research from academics and think tanks. Intensity levels (high, medium, low) are assigned to each country in each realm based on evidence of Russian activities.  The analysis focuses on post-2014 activity due to increased availability of data.

sections.title: Methodology: Assessing Russian Global Influence
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of UN General Assembly voting patterns (2010-2017) to determine which countries voted with Russia when U.S. and Russian positions differed.  Two groups of countries are compared: those considered more vulnerable to Russian influence and those in the West. Arms sales data (SIPRI) are also used as an indicator of international clout.

sections.title: Methodology: Assessing Western Policies Toward Russia
