sections.methods_summary: Examination of two key measures: military spending among NATO member states (SIPRI data, as percentage of GDP) and the intensity of economic sanctions (measured as change in European exports to Russia from Eurostat data).

sections.title: Methodology: Assessing Western Public Opinion
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of Eurobarometer polling data on European citizens' satisfaction with democracy (2010-2017).  Net public opinion data on favorability towards NATO and Russia in select countries are also analyzed.

sections.title: Methodology: Assessing Russian Costs and Ability to Sustain Confrontational Foreign Policy
sections.methods_summary: Examination of various economic metrics: GDP (World Bank), foreign direct investment (Central Bank of the Russian Federation), total state revenues (Ministry of Finance of the Russian Federation), and domestic net approval ratings of Putin (Yuri Levada Analytical Center).

sections.title: Methodology: Overview of Hostile Russian Activities and Threat Assessment
sections.methods_summary: The study distinguishes between two realms of Russian hostile activities: cognitive (affecting decision-making and perceptions) and physical (affecting material capabilities).  Within each realm, activities are categorized (overt/covert information efforts, covert political support; overt/covert state actions, actions by non-state actors). Threat intensity is assessed qualitatively as high/low (cognitive realm) and high/medium/low (physical realm), considering both Russian effort and target state vulnerabilities.

analysis.sample_description: The study examines six geographic regions, focusing on the areas of responsibility of EUCOM, CENTCOM, and AFRICOM. Specific countries are selected within each region based on the availability of evidence of Russian hostile activities.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative assessment of threat intensity based on evidence from various sources, categorized by geographic region and realm of activity (cognitive and physical).

sections.title: Appendix A: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used three data sources: (1) interviews with UPPI university-based leads and state partner leads (105 interviews total over seven site visits), (2) interviews with additional state-level stakeholders (47 interviews), and (3) secondary data (state plans, licensure requirements, legislation, reports from state departments of education, research literature).  Interviews were conducted in person or by phone and lasted 45-60 minutes.  A snowball sampling method was used to identify interviewees. Qualitative data analysis was performed using Dedoose software.  The analysis involved generating detailed notes or transcriptions, coding, and identifying themes. Multiple coding approaches were used, including a priori and emergent coding.  Reliability checks were conducted, and the coding scheme was revised as needed.  Data on state use of policy levers were analyzed using several methods, including tabulation and identification of areas of convergence and divergence. Secondary data were synthesized in state profiles. The study acknowledges limitations related to self-reported data, convenience sampling, and generalizability.

analysis.sample_description: Seven states participating in The Wallace Foundation’s University Principal Preparation Initiative (UPPI).  Additional state-level stakeholders were interviewed using a snowball sampling method. The sample of additional stakeholders was a convenience sample and may not represent all possible participants’ perspectives.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data analysis using Dedoose software.  The analysis involved generating detailed notes or transcriptions, coding, and identifying themes using both a priori and emergent coding.  Data reduction tables and summaries were created and shared with the project team. Multiple analyses were conducted on data related to state use of policy levers. Secondary data were synthesized in state profiles.

sections.title: Data Collection and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Semistructured interviews were conducted with representatives from 22 agencies (69% of those contacted) between April 20 and May 22, 2020.  Data analysis used Rapid Qualitative Analysis, incorporating both deductive (Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research) and inductive approaches.  Key findings were summarized weekly by the research team.

sections.title: Method
sections.methods_summary: Semistructured interviews were conducted with representatives from various social service organizations serving people experiencing or at risk of homelessness and involved in the criminal justice system.  The study focused on organizations with pre-existing relationships with RAND to expedite the research. A qualitative, interview-based approach was chosen to minimize burden on organizations while gathering detailed information on their decision-making processes and pandemic responses. The study was approved by the RAND Institutional Review Board. An interview guide covered topics such as information sources for pandemic response plans, changes made in response to COVID-19, barriers and facilitators of implementation, monitoring strategies, and disproportionate impacts on subgroups.

analysis.sample_description: Representatives from 22 social service agencies in Los Angeles County serving vulnerable populations (homeless or at-risk, involved with the criminal justice system).  The agencies included various types of providers (behavioral health, case management, housing, vocational services, legal services, and funders).
analysis.analysis_approach: Rapid Qualitative Analysis (Hamilton and Finley, 2019; Taylor et al., 2018), incorporating both deductive (using the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research (CFIR) (Damschroder et al., 2009) to organize findings on facilitators and barriers) and inductive approaches.  Weekly team meetings discussed findings to identify key themes and evolving responses over the five-week data collection period.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research employed a two-case study approach. The first case study involved an analogous comparison of the human immune response to pathogens to identify beneficial and challenging traits of a Mosaic warfare system.  The second case study compared Mosaic warfare to the Naval Integrated Fire Control—Counter Air (NIFC-CA) project, analyzing programmatic decisions and governance to inform Mosaic warfare acquisition strategies. Case study selection involved evaluating potential programs based on six principal features of Mosaic warfare (fractionation, heterogeneity, rapid composability, system architecture, scalability and multiagent collaboration, and AI/ML and autonomy).  For the immune response analysis, a literature review was conducted, focusing on the immune system's response to pathogens and drawing analogies to various warfighting scenarios. The NIFC-CA analysis involved a literature review of unclassified documents (including those from UARCs, federally funded R&D centers, and Naval Warfare Centers), discussions with Navy subject-matter experts, and leveraging firsthand experience from an author with relevant experience.

analysis.sample_description: The study did not involve a traditional sample in the sense of human participants.  Instead, the 'samples' were the human immune system and the NIFC-CA project.
analysis.analysis_approach: Comparative analysis of the immune system and NIFC-CA against the six principal features of Mosaic warfare. Analogies were drawn between the immune response and various warfighting scenarios to identify beneficial and challenging traits for Mosaic warfare.  Lessons learned from the NIFC-CA project's organizational construct, experimentation process, and documentation were applied to inform Mosaic warfare acquisition strategies.

sections.title: Appendix A. Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Two modified-Delphi expert panels were conducted using the ExpertLens platform.  The panels consisted of 10 experts each, focusing on NAS and NOWS respectively.  Data collection involved three rounds: Round 1 (initial ratings and comments), Round 2 (feedback, comparison of responses, and anonymous discussion), and Round 3 (revision of responses based on feedback).  Quantitative data (9-point Likert scales) were analyzed using the RAND/UCLA Appropriateness Method (RAM) to determine consensus. Qualitative data (open-ended comments) were analyzed using thematic analysis in Excel.  Stratified randomization was used to assign participants to panels, balancing characteristics such as professional background, geographic region, and federal employment.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Two modified-Delphi panels were convened using the RAND/UCLA Appropriateness Method (RAM) and the ExpertLens platform.  The platform facilitated data collection through three rounds involving quantitative ratings (9-point Likert scales), open-ended responses, and anonymous online discussions.  One panel focused on NAS, the other on NOWS.  The methods are detailed in Appendix A.

analysis.sample_description: 20 national experts on NAS and NOWS (neonatologists, internists, nurse practitioners, general pediatricians) were invited. 19 participated in at least one round, 18 completed all three rounds.  Participants were randomly assigned to two panels (NAS and NOWS) using stratified randomization to balance characteristics such as professional background, geographic region, and federal employment.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative data were analyzed using descriptive statistics (frequency distributions, medians, interquartile ranges) and the RAM approach to determine consensus. Qualitative data were analyzed using thematic analysis.  All qualitative data were coded in Microsoft Excel.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study involved improving the AI/ML model and modeling and simulation tools, developing and demonstrating a DCS decision support tool with a web-based user interface, and using the demonstration to identify issues and recommend solutions for USSF integration of AI/ML into operations.

primary_methods: Development of DCS decision support tool with web-based UI
Demonstration and analysis of tool integration issues
analysis.sample_description: Not explicitly described, but the study uses synthetic data generated by the modeling and simulation tools to train the AI/ML model.  The data represents various combinations of adversary (Red) and friendly (Blue) courses of action.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves evaluating the performance of the improved AI/ML model in generating effective defensive counterspace courses of action, assessing the impact of decision delays, and identifying challenges and recommendations for operationalizing the tool within the USSF.

sections.title: Chapter 1: Introduction - Basic Concepts
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the foundational methodology: representing task dependencies as a directed acyclic graph (DAG).  It outlines four key assumptions made in abstracting data into this graph representation:  clearly defined task beginnings and ends; dependencies applying to task ends and beginnings; all tasks belonging to a development path; and the absence of loops (or their reduction to single tasks). The process of creating a connected DAG from potentially disconnected data is also explained.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Prioritization
sections.methods_summary: This chapter details algorithms for task prioritization based on 'reach' (number of dependent tasks) and topological ordering.  The reach algorithm identifies unrooted and unfinished nodes. Topological ordering helps identify circular dependencies.  These algorithms serve as error checks for the data used to construct the task dependency graph.

sections.title: Chapter 3: Scheduling
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the application of probabilistic methods to the task dependency graphs.  It uses a four-parameter beta distribution to model task completion times (optimistic, most likely, pessimistic).  A Monte Carlo method is used to simulate the graph and estimate the average end-to-end completion time, standard deviation, and critical path.  The impact of graph topology (simple chains, random Erdős-Rényi graphs, scale-free graphs) on schedule risk is analyzed through simulations.  The criticality index (probability of a node being on the critical path) is estimated through repeated simulations.

sections.title: Chapter 4: Resource Constraints
sections.methods_summary: This chapter extends the scheduling analysis by incorporating resource constraints.  It examines scenarios with fixed and variable resource requirements.  The concept of slack (the flexibility to delay tasks without affecting the overall schedule) is introduced and analyzed. A heuristic approach is proposed for scheduling tasks under resource constraints, prioritizing nodes likely to be on the critical path.

sections.title: Chapter 5: Analytic Approach for Calculating the Criticality Index
sections.methods_summary: This section presents a novel analytical approach to calculate the criticality index, addressing the computational limitations of the Monte Carlo method for large graphs.  It involves a semi-analytical method using spectral methods, transforming the problem into a different space for efficient computation. Two numerical methods are described: trapezoidal integration and a Chebyshev spectral method.  The rate of convergence for each method is analyzed and compared to the Monte Carlo method.

sections.title: Chapter 6: Conclusions
sections.methods_summary: This chapter summarizes the findings and conclusions from the previous methodological sections.  It does not introduce new methods but synthesizes the results of the topological analysis and the novel numerical methods.

sections.title: Appendix A: Equivalence of Representations
sections.methods_summary: This appendix compares two graph representations used in PERT/CPM: activities on arcs (AoA) and activities on nodes (AoN). It demonstrates the equivalence of the two representations and explains why the AoN approach was chosen for this research.

sections.title: Appendix B: The PERT and CPM Algorithms
sections.methods_summary: This appendix reviews the expected-value PERT and CPM algorithms, providing a foundation for understanding the more advanced stochastic algorithms presented in the main body of the report. It describes how these algorithms calculate project duration, critical path, slack time, and the probability of meeting a target completion time.  It also discusses cost-time trade-offs and budget flexibility.

sections.title: Appendix C: Proof That Convolution of Independent, Identical Beta Distributions Converges to a Normal Distribution
sections.methods_summary: This appendix provides a mathematical proof demonstrating that the convolution of independent and identically distributed beta distributions converges to a normal distribution. This is relevant to the probabilistic modeling of task completion times.

sections.title: Appendix D: Derivation of Maximum Order Statistic Formula
sections.methods_summary: This appendix derives the mathematical formula for the probability density function (PDF) of the maximum order statistic (MOS), which is used in the calculation of the criticality index.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses various types of graphs: simple chain topologies, random Erdős-Rényi graphs, and scale-free graphs.  The size of the graphs varies, with some containing hundreds or thousands of nodes.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves developing and applying algorithms based on graph theory to model and analyze task dependencies.  Probabilistic methods are used to model task completion times and schedule risk.  The analysis compares different graph topologies and explores the impact of resource constraints.

sections.title: Assessing Resilience
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the adoption of metrics for operational resilience from existing literature (Burch, 2019) and previous RAND research (McLeod et al., 2016; Dreyer et al., 2016) focusing on non-materiel methods to improve space operational resilience.  It mentions the use of network diagrams and SME meetings to rate the effectiveness of investments in countering threats.

sections.title: Chapter 2. The Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used, which involves a two-stage process: 1) Semistructured interviews to elicit logic models (theories of change) from SMEs across various sectors (DoD, allied, commercial) and levels of warfare (strategic, operational, tactical).  The interviews aimed to capture a range of perspectives on how integrating partners impacts resilience. 2) A survey instrument to measure community attitudes regarding the factors identified in the interviews.  The survey uses factor analysis (a graphical approach) to determine the independence of factors related to community attitudes.  Two vignettes are incorporated to assess the impact of operational context on these attitudes.  The survey also includes questions to explore trust and beliefs as potential confounding factors, using both Likert scales and rank-order questions.  The analysis focuses on detecting a lack of correlation in response distributions to identify independent factors, rather than measuring consensus.

primary_methods: Survey with Likert scales and rank-order questions
analysis.sample_description: The interview sample emphasized diversity across DoD MILSATCOM community, allied nations (Australia and Canada), and the commercial sector.  The survey included 22 respondents from across strategic, operational, and tactical communities, allies, and commercial entities, aiming for diversity of experience rather than large sample size.
analysis.analysis_approach: Graphical factor analysis to assess the independence of factors influencing resilience.  Network analysis to model partnership impacts on resilience, using metrics like centrality, graph density, shortest path, modularity, and vulnerability scores.  Sensitivity studies were conducted by varying factors in the network models to assess their impact on resilience metrics.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research approach consisted of four steps: 1. Literature review on CAS, MDOs, and complex warfare; 2. Development of four vignettes to explore complexity; 3. Development of a complexity lens based on CAS research; 4. Development of a mathematical representation of the decisionmaking cycle.

analysis.sample_description: No specific sample is described.  The research focuses on analyzing existing literature, developing theoretical frameworks, and creating illustrative vignettes based on existing wargame data and military concepts.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves applying a complex adaptive systems (CAS) lens to understand and model the impact of complexity on adversary decision-making.  A mathematical model, represented as a Markov chain, is developed to quantify the effects of complexity imposition.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Complex Adaptive Systems - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A literature review of writings by leading thinkers in complexity sciences and field-specific texts and papers was conducted to identify a set of common characteristics that can be employed to recognize complex systems, analyze their behavior, and translate this to actions in warfare.  This involved identifying characteristics consistently related to CAS, trimming the list to reduce concept overlap, and organizing it into a CAS concept map for Air Force application.

sections.title: Chapter 3: Complexity Adaptive Systems Lens “User Manual” - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A rubric (Table 3.1) was developed to aid in identifying the extent to which aspects of CAS are represented in programs, initiatives, and fielded systems.  The rubric is used to review S&T efforts and considers structural organization, adaptation, and emergent properties.  For each property, the rubric assesses the extent to which the system has these properties and then examines certain actions that the properties imply or enable, considering their impact on defense and offense. A hypothetical software tool for planning Blue air operations is used as an example to illustrate the application of the rubric.

sections.title: Chapter 4: Markov Chain Formulation and Analysis of Decision Processes - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The adversary decision flow is modeled as a Markov chain. Properties of graphs and Markov chains are used to study the structure of decision processes.  Transition matrices are constructed from Markov chains, and their properties are analyzed.  Graph theory is used to analyze the structure of the state space of the Markov chain, even when transition probabilities are unknown.  Several graph statistics (average node degree, degree centrality, eigenvector centrality, betweenness centrality, clustering coefficient, diameter, average distance, cycles, girth, terminal nodes, number of paths to terminal nodes) are used to quantify the size and topology of the graph. The decision flow is presented as a transition matrix, and the impacts of complexity attacks are analyzed by observing changes in the transition matrix and using graph theory to analyze the topology of the decision network.

analysis.sample_description: Chapter 3 uses a hypothetical software tool for planning Blue air operations as an example. Chapter 4 uses decision flow diagrams from Volume I.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of literature and rubric application in Chapter 2 and 3. Quantitative analysis using Markov chains and graph theory in Chapter 4.

sections.title: Approach and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The RAND PAF team examined 9 AF’s efforts to optimize for JTF HQ formation and selection.  The team developed a baseline understanding of 9 AF’s efforts to organize, train, and equip a JTF HQ. They explored historical data, doctrine, and discussions with those familiar with 9 AF JTF HQ activities to identify key lessons learned.  They developed an understanding of 9 AF’s approach and identified potential opportunities for 9 AF to adjust course.  Discussions were held with 9 AF leaders, Headquarters Air Force (HAF), and ACC officials, and others familiar with the JTF HQ initiative. The study team attended multiple staff exercises (STAFFEXs) at 9 AF Headquarters (HQ) at Shaw AFB in South Carolina and at Robins AFB in Georgia.  A review of literature on joint operations and doctrine was conducted. Quantitative data on JTF HQ selection between 1990 and 2017 was examined. Three case studies of operations were conducted.

sections.title: An Approach to Analyzing Key Trends in Joint Task Force Selection
sections.methods_summary: Data on JTF HQs formed between 1990 and 2017 was collected using official reports, academic papers, and news articles.  For each JTF HQ, the number of years operational, primary mission set, commander’s rank and service branch, and core element of the JTF HQ staff were identified.  Analysis focused on frequency and duration of JTF HQ formation, frequency of JTF HQ mission types, frequency of JTF HQ leadership by service, and frequency of JTF HQ alignment with COCOMs.  An existing RAND database was used as a starting point, supplemented by Google searches and verification through additional sources.  The JTF HQ list and analysis were briefed to 9 AF leadership for feedback.

sections.title: An Approach to Case Study Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Three case studies of military operations (2011-2020) were selected based on JTF structure (preexisting core unit), recency, and alignment with 9 AF Joint Training Guidance.  The analysis explored implications for building USAF JTF HQ capability along two dimensions: "getting ready" and "answering the call."  No attempt was made to control for variables or isolate the impact of particular factors; the goal was to identify common themes.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Literature reviews, discussions with subject-matter experts, attendance at staff exercises at 9 AF headquarters at Shaw AFB and Robins AFB, generation of three case studies, and examination of a data set of 88 JTF HQs activated between 1990 and 2017.

primary_methods: Qualitative analysis (literature review, expert interviews, case studies)
Quantitative analysis (data analysis of JTF HQs)
analysis.sample_description: 88 JTF HQs activated between 1990 and 2017; three case studies of recent JTF operations.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis of trends in JTF HQ formation, mission types, leadership by service, and alignment with COCOMs; thematic analysis of case studies to identify lessons learned.

sections.title: Scenario Development: China Annexes Taiwan
sections.methods_summary: Development of a hypothetical war scenario focusing on a Chinese victory in a conflict over Taiwan.  The scenario considers various factors such as U.S. intervention, Chinese military strategy, and the role of nuclear weapons. The narrative is developed chronologically, detailing key events and their consequences.  Post-conflict analysis focuses on strategic outcomes and implications for the joint force.

sections.title: Scenario Development: US Degrades China's Military Power
sections.methods_summary: Development of a hypothetical war scenario where the US aims to degrade China's military power following a conflict in the East China Sea.  The scenario explores the expansion of US war aims, potential Russian intervention, and the role of nuclear escalation.  The narrative is chronological, analyzing key events and their impact on the postwar environment.  The analysis includes an examination of strategic outcomes and implications for the joint force.

sections.title: Scenario Development: Indecisive Taiwan Conflict
sections.methods_summary: Development of a hypothetical war scenario where a conflict over Taiwan ends indecisively.  The scenario explores China's unpreparedness for a full-scale invasion, the US military intervention, and the resulting stalemate. The narrative is chronological, focusing on key events and their consequences. Post-conflict analysis examines the resulting frozen conflict, the long-term US presence on Taiwan, and implications for the joint force.

sections.title: Scenario Development: War Caused by Russian Misperception
sections.methods_summary: Development of a hypothetical war scenario where a conflict between Russia and NATO arises from Russian misperception. The scenario explores the escalation to limited nuclear use, the resulting peace agreement, and its consequences. The narrative is chronological, detailing key events and their impact on the postwar environment.  The analysis includes an examination of strategic outcomes and implications for the joint force.

sections.title: Overall Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The report uses a qualitative methodology, generating four hypothetical high-intensity, largely conventional war scenarios.  The scenarios explore variations in key features of great power wars, such as the parties involved, the role of nuclear weapons, the length of the conflict, and the victor.  The scenarios are developed chronologically, and postwar consequences are analyzed based on research on contemporary decisionmaking, international relations literature, historical analogies, and expert judgment.  The analysis focuses on variables such as military, economic, and diplomatic strategies, changes in objectives, and the implications for the joint force.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is a qualitative study using hypothetical scenarios.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of hypothetical scenarios, focusing on the interaction of various factors and their impact on postwar outcomes.  Expert judgment and historical analogies are used to inform the analysis.

sections.title: Methodology: The Process of Estimating Casualties
sections.methods_summary: The study estimated casualties and fatalities from potential North Korean artillery strikes.  It involved identifying the number of DPRK artillery systems within range of South Korea, dividing them into groups, and identifying high-population-density targetable areas.  The study assessed the number of artillery rounds that could be fired, estimated maximum rates of fire, and identified populations at risk using South Korean population density data.  Direct casualties and fatalities were estimated using historical Soviet artillery norms and recent U.S. military data.  Estimates included casualties from panic and the 'worried well'.  Finally, the study accounted for mitigating factors like counterfires, inaccuracy, and dud ammunition, resulting in 'Modified Casualty Estimates'.

primary_methods: Data analysis of DPRK artillery systems and their range
Population density data analysis from US national laboratory and South Korean census
Casualty estimation using historical Soviet artillery norms and US military data
Inclusion of panic casualties and 'worried well' estimates
Adjustment for mitigating factors (counterfire, inaccuracy, dud ammunition)
analysis.sample_description: High-population-density areas in South Korea within range of DPRK artillery systems, categorized by five case studies representing different attack scenarios.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis using population density data and historical casualty rates to estimate the potential impact of North Korean artillery strikes under various scenarios.  The analysis included adjustments for mitigating factors to provide a range of potential casualty estimates.

sections.title: Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: A combination of qualitative and quantitative methods was used.

sections.title: Qualitative Methods
sections.methods_summary: Semi-structured interviews with 26 key informants (children's advocates, providers, Medicaid managed care plans, and state agencies) between November 2020 and January 2021. Data coded based on the goals of the interim evaluation.  Stakeholders selected from a list provided by NYS DOH to ensure representation of different affected populations and regions (NYC, upstate, rural).

sections.title: Quantitative Methods
sections.methods_summary: Analyses of baseline levels of access to and quality of care using population-level aggregate data from the 2017-2019 NYS Medicaid Data Warehouse.  Three subpopulations: children in Health Homes Serving Children (HHSC), Fee-for-Service (FFS), and Medicaid Managed Care (MMC). HHSC population considered most similar to the Children’s Design target population. Pairwise t-tests and linear regression to assess differences and trends between groups.  Data from the 2018 NYS Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (CAHPS) survey of children with chronic conditions (CCC) used to complement analysis for select research questions. CCC population used to approximate the target population due to data availability constraints.

sections.title: Quality Measures from the Medicaid Data Warehouse
sections.methods_summary: Aggregate data from the Medicaid Data Warehouse provided by NYS DOH. Eight quarterly data points for various Medicaid subgroups.  Three population subgroups: HHSC, FFS, and MMC.  Quality measures selected to address specific research questions (well-care visits, follow-up visits, immunization rates, metabolic monitoring, weight and nutrition counseling). Sample sizes vary by measure and population.

sections.title: Analytic Approach (Quantitative)
sections.methods_summary: Pairwise t-tests to compare rates between HHSC, FFS, and MMC at three time points (April 2017, January 2018, January 2019). Linear regression to test if trends between the first seven time points and the last time point differ across populations.  Comparison of Medicaid Data Warehouse measures for HHSC with overall NYS Medicaid population and comparable states. Chi-squared tests used for some comparisons.

sections.title: Quality Measures from the CAHPS Children with Chronic Conditions Survey
sections.methods_summary: Data from the 2018 NYS CAHPS survey of children with chronic conditions (CCC).  Questions related to satisfaction with PCPs, access to services, and care coordination.  Sample sizes vary by question and subgroup (CCC vs. all children).

sections.title: Analytic Approach (Qualitative)
sections.methods_summary: Bar charts showing the share of CCC and all children responding affirmatively to survey questions.

analysis.sample_description: Qualitative: 12 semi-structured interviews with 26 key informants representing four stakeholder groups. Quantitative: Population-level aggregate data from the Medicaid Data Warehouse for three subgroups (HHSC, FFS, MMC) and data from the 2018 CAHPS survey of children with chronic conditions.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data coded using Dedoose software. Quantitative data analyzed using pairwise t-tests, linear regression, and chi-squared tests to assess differences and trends in quality measures across subgroups.  Comparisons made between HHSC, FFS, and MMC populations, and between HHSC and overall NYS Medicaid and comparable states.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data source (IQVIA's MIDAS database), data cleaning and aggregation procedures (string matching, manual crosswalking), inclusion/exclusion criteria (animal insulin products), and the price index methodology used to compare US insulin prices to those in other OECD countries.  The methodology involves creating a market basket of insulins based on US volume shares and calculating price ratios between the US and other countries.  A sensitivity analysis using only prescription insulin data is also mentioned.

analysis.sample_description: Data covers the year 2018 and spans 33 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries, including the United States.  Animal insulin products were excluded.
analysis.analysis_approach: A price index approach was used, comparing US prices to those of other countries, holding a constant market basket at US volume shares by presentation.  Comparisons were made for all insulins and for specific type and timing categories.  Price ratios were reported. A sensitivity analysis was conducted using data aggregated at the active-ingredient level instead of the presentation level.

sections.title: Chapter 2. Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources (IQVIA MIDAS database), data cleaning and matching procedures (string matching and manual crosswalking), the creation of new variables (IU-based volume measure, estimated U.S. net sales), data aggregation methods (country presentation level, active ingredient level), the calculation of per capita utilization and sales, and the price index methodology (comparing manufacturer gross and net prices in the US with those of comparison countries, holding a U.S. insulin market basket constant).  The analysis focuses on insulins sold in the US and matches them to those sold in 33 other OECD countries.  It uses both standard units (SUs) and international units (IUs) for volume measurement and compares results from both approaches.  A 76% discount is applied to US gross sales to estimate net sales.  The price index methodology uses U.S. volume shares to create a market basket for comparison.

analysis.sample_description: Data from IQVIA MIDAS database covering 2017-2022 for the United States and 33 other OECD countries.  Animal insulins and inhaled insulins were excluded.  The analysis is limited to insulins sold in the United States, with comparisons made to matching products in other countries.
analysis.analysis_approach: Price index-based comparisons holding the mix of insulins constant between the United States and comparison countries.  Comparisons were made for all insulins combined and for different categories of insulins.  Analyses were conducted using both gross prices and estimated net prices (after applying a 76% discount to US gross prices).  Both standard units (SUs) and international units (IUs) were used for volume measurement, and results were compared.  Robustness checks were performed by aggregating data at the active ingredient level.

sections.title: Chapter 2. Price Index–Based Drug Price Comparisons Using 2022 Data
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources (IQVIA MIDAS data for 2022 from the US and 33 other OECD countries), data cleaning procedures (exclusion of over-the-counter drugs, records with non-positive volume or sales, inconsistent data, and presentations with low volume or sales), aggregation methods (aggregation by presentation, then by active ingredient for sensitivity analysis), and the main price index calculation method (using U.S. volume weights to calculate volume-weighted prices for the U.S. and other countries, then calculating the price index as the ratio of these weighted prices).  Additional analyses included subgroup comparisons (brand-name originator drugs, unbranded generic drugs, biologics, biosimilars, and non-biologic drugs) and sensitivity analyses (varying volume weights, using retail prices, applying different price ratio exclusion criteria, and analyzing trends over time using both varying and fixed market baskets).

sections.title: Appendix A. Price Index Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This appendix provides further detail on the price index methodology, including specific exclusion criteria (low volume and sales thresholds, extreme price ratios), and the number of presentations and active ingredients used in the analysis.  It also discusses the implications of using presentation-level versus active ingredient-level data and the impact of different exclusion criteria on the results.

analysis.sample_description: Data from IQVIA MIDAS for 2022, covering the United States and 33 other OECD countries.  Data were cleaned to exclude over-the-counter drugs, records with non-positive volume or sales, inconsistent data, and presentations with low volume or sales.  The final sample varied depending on the specific analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: Bilateral price index comparisons were conducted between the U.S. and each of the other 33 countries, as well as a comparison of U.S. prices with the average of all other countries.  U.S. volume weights were primarily used, with sensitivity analyses using other country weights and blended weights.  Subgroup analyses were performed for different drug categories, and sensitivity analyses explored the impact of various methodological choices (e.g., aggregation level, price ratio exclusion criteria).

sections.title: Chapter 2. Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources (IQVIA MIDAS data for the US and 26 OECD countries), data selection criteria (new drugs with sales > $1,000,000, exclusion of certain drug types), and analytical methods.  The study sample consisted of 287 new drugs.  Methods included defining the global first sales quarter, determining drug availability in each country, measuring the time from global first sales to country-specific sales, and calculating the cumulative probability of entry using the Kaplan-Meier estimator and average likelihood of launch using Cox proportional hazard models.

analysis.sample_description: 287 new prescription drugs first sold from 2018-2022 in the US and 26 other OECD countries.  Some analyses used a subset of 122 drugs first sold globally in 2018 or 2019.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive analysis of drug availability (share of drugs available in US only, other countries only, and both), spending on new drugs (share of total spending), and launch timing (difference in quarters between US and other country launches).  Kaplan-Meier estimator used to calculate cumulative probability of entry, and Cox proportional hazard models used to estimate average likelihood of new drug launch in each country relative to the US.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative case study analysis of Russian conflicts, quantitative statistical evaluation of correlates of Russian disputes, qualitative analysis of additional potential drivers of flashpoints (PMCs and OIE).

sections.title: Method and Research Design
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative analysis of four militarized conflicts and six disputes using a 16-factor framework. Quantitative analysis using dyadic MIDs data (1992-2010) with Firth logit models to identify correlates of MID onset. Predictive analysis (2011-2018) using baseline model estimates and country-specific data.

analysis.sample_description: Nine militarized conflicts and 54 militarized disputes involving Russia (1992-2019) for qualitative analysis. Dyadic MIDs data set (1992-2010) for quantitative analysis. Country-specific data (2011-2018) for predictive analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis using a 16-factor framework to identify drivers of escalation. Quantitative analysis using Firth logit models to identify correlates of MID onset and predictive analysis to estimate the probability of future MIDs.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Data on all exchange-listed firms in East and Southeast Asia with annual revenues exceeding $10 million USD were collected from the Osiris database (Bureau van Dijk) for 2006, 2018, and 2020.  Data included firm name, nationality, industry, size, and financial information, as well as board of director makeup (name, position, nationality).  A bipartite network was created using the igraph package in R, mapping relationships between firms and directors.  Network projections were used to construct networks of relationships between firms (shared directors) and directors (shared board memberships). Shareholder data (firm or owner identified by unique codes and share of ownership) were used to construct shareholder networks.  The analysis excluded ownership by non-Asian companies and individual investors. Firms were associated with their country of incorporation, regardless of exchange listing.

analysis.sample_description: All exchange-listed firms in East and Southeast Asia (China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Laos, Vietnam, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, and the Philippines) with annual revenues exceeding $10 million USD in 2006, 2018, and 2020.
analysis.analysis_approach: Bipartite network analysis using igraph in R to map firm-director and firm-firm relationships based on board interlocks and shareholding data.  Analysis focused on network structure and topology, including measures like betweenness centrality, mean path, average degree, and transitivity.  Statistical tests (Welch two-sample t-test) were used to compare network positions of firms with and without international ties.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research approach relied heavily on RAND's library and archival resources.  Snowball sampling was used to identify reports related to air base defense and attack (ABD/A). A spreadsheet template was created to qualitatively code reports based on various factors (threats, regions, solutions).  Data on authors and co-authorships were used for network analysis using Python packages networkx and nxviz.

analysis.sample_description: The sample consisted of 264 RAND reports on ABD/A, dating back to 1951.  A subset of 95 unclassified or declassified reports was used for the detailed historical analysis in Chapters 3-6.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics were generated on report content. Network analysis was performed on author co-authorship data using Python packages.  The historical narrative chapters focused on unclassified/declassified reports.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A combination of discussions with subject-matter experts from HQDA G-4, DLA, and the 21st Theater Sustainment Command, and analysis of distribution data provided by DLA’s Analytics Center of Excellence (ACE).

sections.title: Automatic Detection Algorithms Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Developed automatic detection algorithms using statistical process control (SPC) with Western Electric (WE) rules (WE1, WE2, WE3) to detect changes in key metrics (proportion of shipments, RWT, requisition-to-receipt segment durations).  Data was obtained from DLA's ACE, including DLA issues and receipts, Logistics Response Time (LRT), and GCSS-Army receipts.  Data was analyzed across multiple dimensions (customer region, AMI/NAMI, DC, shipment mode, IPG) and aggregated into weekly or monthly periods.  Ineligibility rules were implemented to filter out detections with small sample sizes (<5% of transactions).

analysis.sample_description: Distribution data from DLA's Analytics Center of Excellence (ACE), encompassing DLA issues and receipts, Logistics Response Time (LRT), and GCSS-Army receipts. Data included various dimensions such as customer location, shipment mode, distribution center, and issue priority group (IPG). Data was aggregated into weekly or monthly periods.
analysis.analysis_approach: Statistical Process Control (SPC) using Western Electric rules (WE1, WE2, WE3) to detect changes in metrics across different dimensions of the data.  Data visualization dashboards were used for root cause analysis.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used the COMPARE microsimulation model to estimate the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on insurance loss in New York state in 2020 and 2021.  The model uses a cost-benefit approach, allowing simulated individuals to choose among available health plans. Data sources included the U.S. Census Bureau's Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP), the Kaiser Family Foundation and Health Research and Educational Trust's annual Employer Health Benefits Survey, the Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS), and the 2018 U.S. Census Bureau American Community Survey (ACS).  The population was adjusted to reflect current New York demographics and projected using New York state population projections. Health expenditures were estimated using National Health Expenditures Account (NHEA) projected per capita growth rates.  Four policy scenarios were considered for 2020, varying by the availability of FFCRA-related Medicaid continuous enrollment and furlough coverage.  For 2021, scenarios accounted for provisions in the American Rescue Plan (ARP).

sections.title: Appendix. Additional Detail on Methods and Data
sections.methods_summary: This section provides detailed information on the COMPARE microsimulation model, including data sources (2010 SIPP, 2011-2012 MEPS, 2009 Employer Health Benefits Survey), model adjustments to reflect New York-specific policies (full community rating, Essential Plan), and the process of applying transition probabilities from the national model to New York-specific data from the 2018 ACS.  It describes how job loss was assigned to individuals in the model based on BLS data, accounting for industry-specific differences and racial/ethnic variation in unemployment rates.  The methods for accounting for continuous coverage under the FFCRA, furlough coverage, and the ARP's changes to APTCs are also detailed.

analysis.sample_description: The under-65-year-old population in New York State.  The model uses a synthetic population based on nationally representative data, adjusted to reflect New York demographics.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study used a microsimulation model to simulate health insurance enrollment under various policy scenarios.  Comparisons were made between scenarios with and without pandemic-related policies (Medicaid continuous enrollment, furlough coverage, ARP provisions) and a counterfactual scenario without the pandemic.

sections.title: Study Background and Design
sections.methods_summary: Participants read a document about classified information leaks, then completed two interviews (VTC and text-based chat) simulating a background investigation. Half the participants were instructed to be truthful, half to withhold details.

sections.title: Data Collection and Procedures
sections.methods_summary: 103 participants (University of New Haven) completed a demographic questionnaire, read a document (news story or sensitive memo), received instructions on truthfulness/deception, and underwent two interviews (VTC and chat). Interviews used modified cognitive interviewing (MCI).  VTC interviews were audio-recorded and transcribed using AWS Transcribe, with manual corrections. Chat logs were collected directly.

sections.title: Analysis of Interview Data
sections.methods_summary: Analysis focused on detectable differences in responses between VTC interviews and chat interviews, comparing truthful and deceptive responses.

sections.title: Analysis of Interview Data: Linguistic Models
sections.methods_summary: Three main models were developed using Scikit-learn (version 0.23.2): 1) Word Vectors (word counts of 500 most common words); 2) Stance Vectors (using RAND-Lex to categorize words into attitudinal dimensions); 3) Metadata (features like speaking cadence, word length, etc.).  A nested three-fold cross-validation was used to evaluate models.  Feature importance was assessed using a permutation algorithm.  Combined models using various combinations of the three main models were also tested.  Analysis was performed separately for VTC and chat data, and a combined model using both data sources was also created.

sections.title: Analysis of Interview Data: Gender Bias
sections.methods_summary: Models were re-run separately for male and female participants to assess gender bias in accuracy rates.  Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests were used to compare word usage distributions between genders.

primary_methods: Deep Learning (Transformer model for contradiction detection)
analysis.sample_description: 103 English-speaking U.S. citizens aged 18–60, associated with the University of New Haven.  The sample was not perfectly balanced between truthful and deceptive conditions.
analysis.analysis_approach: Multiple machine learning models were trained and tested using various linguistic features extracted from interview transcripts and chat logs.  Model performance was evaluated using accuracy rates and other metrics.  A nested three-fold cross-validation strategy was employed to mitigate overfitting.  Gender bias was assessed by analyzing model performance separately for male and female participants.

sections.title: Survey of Los Angeles County Residents: Method
sections.methods_summary: An online survey was conducted using Ipsos' KnowledgePanel platform from August 8, 2020, to August 25, 2020.  A probability-based sample of Los Angeles County residents aged 16-25 and 26+ was recruited.  The survey included measures of demographics, campaign exposure, targeted campaign outcomes (well-being), and COVID-19-related concerns and experiences.  Sample weighting was used to ensure demographic representativeness.  Analysis involved weighted percentages and odds ratios, with statistical significance set at p < 0.05. SAS/STAT software was used for data analysis.

sections.title: Data and Method: Twitter Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Data was collected from Twitter using Brandwatch for the period March 19, 2020 – August 25, 2020.  Specific query terms were used to identify relevant tweets.  Community lexical analysis (CLA) was employed to identify communities of accounts based on interactions and text analysis methods.  Keyness testing, collocate analysis, and in-context viewing were used to analyze the content of the conversations within these communities.

analysis.sample_description: The study included two samples: a sample of Los Angeles County youth aged 16-25 and a representative sample of Los Angeles County adults aged 26 and older.  The samples were weighted to be demographically representative of the Los Angeles County population.
analysis.analysis_approach: For the survey data, weighted percentages and odds ratios were calculated. Statistical significance was determined using p < 0.05.  For the Twitter data, CLA, keyness testing, collocate analysis, and in-context viewing were used to analyze the content of conversations within identified communities.

sections.title: Survey of 2021 WeRise Online Event Attendees: Method and Measures
sections.methods_summary: An online survey was sent to 790 estimated attendees of 16 online WeRise events (out of 24 total events) and to an email list of interested individuals.  Eligibility was limited to those 18 or older speaking Spanish or English. 197 surveys were completed, with 148 usable after removing incomplete and duplicate responses. A $5 online gift card was offered as an incentive.  Measures included WeRise awareness (logo recognition and goal identification), demographics (gender, age, race/ethnicity), perceptions of the WeRise event (five-point Likert scale), and mental health-related attitudes and beliefs (five-point and four-point Likert scales, including previously validated items from the Each Mind Matters campaign evaluation).

sections.title: Survey of Los Angeles County Residents: Method
sections.methods_summary: An online survey of Los Angeles County adults aged 18+ was fielded by Ipsos from March 12 to April 21, 2021, using the KnowledgePanel web platform with address-based sampling to ensure representativeness.  Web-enabled devices and internet service were provided as needed. Sample weighting was used to ensure demographic representativeness of the Los Angeles County population aged 18+. The survey was available in Spanish and English and took approximately 13 minutes to complete. Measures included demographics, campaign exposure (recognition of outdoor advertising images, recall of radio/TV ads, and recognition of ad content), perceptions of campaign effects (five-point Likert scale), knowledge, attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors targeted by the campaign (five-point Likert scale), stigma and mobilization against barriers to mental health (four-point and five-point Likert scales, including previously validated items), use of the LACDMH website and helpline, and well-being (loneliness, hope, social support).  Psychological distress was measured using the Kessler-6.

sections.title: Survey of Los Angeles County Residents: Analyses
sections.methods_summary: Analyses included descriptive statistics, comparisons of mental health-related attitudes, beliefs, behaviors, and well-being between those exposed and not exposed to the campaign. Sample weights were applied to account for differential nonresponse. Data were weighted to represent the Los Angeles County adult population based on age, gender, race/ethnicity, education, household income, and language proficiency. Weighted percentages and odds ratios were reported.  Statistical significance was set at p < 0.05. SAS/STAT software was used for data analysis.

analysis.sample_description: The study included two surveys: one of Los Angeles County residents aged 18+ (approximately 1000 participants, weighted to be representative of the county population), and one of attendees of the 2021 WeRise online events (148 usable responses after cleaning).
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, bivariate analyses, significance tests (p<0.05), odds ratios, sample weighting to ensure demographic representativeness.

sections.title: Research Design and Data Collection Overview
sections.methods_summary: Online survey of a representative sample of Los Angeles County adults ages 18 and older to compare those exposed to the WhyWeRise campaign with those who were not.

sections.title: Survey Methodology
sections.methods_summary: An online survey of Los Angeles County adults (ages 18+) was conducted by Ipsos using the KnowledgePanel platform from October 29 to November 29, 2021.  Address-based sampling ensured a representative sample, with weighting used to adjust for demographic differences. The survey (available in English and Spanish) measured demographics, campaign exposure (through various methods including self-reported exposure to ads, events, websites, and social media), perceptions of campaign materials, and targeted campaign outcomes (knowledge, attitudes, beliefs, behaviors related to mental health).  Analysis included weighted percentages and odds ratios to compare exposed and unexposed groups.  Statistical significance was set at p < 0.05. SAS/STAT software was used for data analysis.  The sample was weighted to be representative of the Los Angeles County adult population based on age, gender, race/ethnicity, education, income, and language proficiency.

analysis.sample_description: A probability-based sample of Los Angeles County adults ages 18 and older, weighted to be demographically representative of the county population.
analysis.analysis_approach: Weighted percentages and odds ratios were used to compare mental health-related attitudes, beliefs, behaviors, and well-being between those exposed and not exposed to the campaign. Statistical significance was determined at p < 0.05. SAS/STAT software was used for data analysis.

sections.title: Countywide Surveys of Los Angeles Residents: Method
sections.methods_summary: Two cross-sectional online surveys of representative samples of Los Angeles County adults (ages 18+) were conducted using Ipsos' KnowledgePanel.  Surveys were fielded in Spring 2021 (evaluating 2020 outreach) and Fall 2021 (evaluating 2021 outreach).  Address-based sampling ensured a comprehensive sample, with weighting used to achieve demographic representativeness.  Surveys were available in English and Spanish.  Measures included demographics, campaign exposure (assessed via multiple items targeting various media), perceptions of campaign materials, targeted knowledge, attitudes, beliefs, behaviors, stigma, mobilization, awareness and use of LACDMH resources, and well-being.  Analysis involved weighted percentages, odds ratios, and significance tests (p<0.05). SAS/STAT software was used for data analysis.

sections.title: Survey of 2021 Dodger Game Attendees: Method
sections.methods_summary: An online survey was sent to individuals on the Los Angeles Dodgers' mailing list on May 25, 2021, inviting those who had recently attended a game to participate.  Eligibility was limited to those 18+ who spoke English or Spanish. The survey closed May 26, 2021.  After removing incomplete or invalid responses, 635 surveys remained for analysis.  Measures included WeRise awareness (logo recognition and goal identification), demographics, perceptions of the Dodger game outreach (using a 5-point Likert scale), and mental health-related attitudes and beliefs (using a mix of 5-point and 4-point Likert scales, including some previously validated items).  Analysis included univariate and bivariate analyses and significance tests.

analysis.sample_description: Two countywide surveys of Los Angeles County adults aged 18 and older; a separate survey of attendees of Los Angeles Dodgers games during Mental Health Month in 2021.
analysis.analysis_approach: Weighted percentages, odds ratios, significance tests (p<0.05), univariate and bivariate analyses.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The methodology leverages key tenets of traditional U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) net assessments.  This includes a basic assessment (defining and characterizing key concepts, identifying important trends, key players, and the overall state of the balance), a trends and asymmetries analysis (highlighting strategic and technical asymmetries), and the development of implications and opportunities for DoD.  The analysis of Chinese approaches to DI primarily used research from U.S. scholars and subject-matter experts, relying on secondary sources and not directly consulting Chinese writings.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is not an empirical study with a defined sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis based on existing literature and expert knowledge to characterize the competition for digital infrastructure and its implications.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Semistructured interviews with 43 subject-matter experts from 35 organizations (automobile insurance companies, manufacturers, government, consumer advocacy groups, ride-sharing companies, AV and trucking start-ups, industry associations, academia, plaintiff's and defense lawyers) in the US, UK, Australia, Canada, and Japan.  A matrix was created to assess stakeholder perspectives on key issues.  A literature review was also conducted.

analysis.sample_description: 43 subject-matter experts from 35 organizations across five countries (US, UK, Australia, Canada, Japan), representing diverse stakeholders in the automotive and insurance industries.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data, creating a matrix to summarize stakeholder perspectives, and descriptive analysis of findings.

sections.title: Project Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach involving the collection and analysis of program data, interview data, and document/database review. Program data were collected from ChalleNGe sites in June and July 2020, covering program characteristics, budget, applicant/participant/graduate numbers, credentials awarded, physical fitness and community service metrics, staffing, class dates, and post-residential placements.  Cadet-level data included graduation, credentials, TABE scores, and post-residential placements.  Interviews were conducted (virtually in 2020) with Job ChalleNGe staff and training partners, covering program mission, resources, staffing, outreach, and data collection. Document and database review included program materials, notes from prior site visits, and data from the National Guard Bureau and other sources like the National Center for Education Statistics and the U.S. Census.

sections.title: Developing a Job ChalleNGe Logic Model and Examining Implementation and Outcomes
sections.methods_summary: A Job ChalleNGe logic model was developed to guide the study.  The implementation study used a mixed-methods approach combining quantitative and qualitative data to document similarities and differences among Job ChalleNGe sites. Data sources included document review, semistructured interviews with program and partner staff, structured observations (replaced by virtual discussions due to COVID-19), focus groups (not conducted due to COVID-19), and participant surveys (planned for future data collection). The outcomes study aimed to identify the relationship between Job ChalleNGe participation and participant outcomes.  While an RCT was not feasible, quasi-experimental techniques were planned to be used to generate causal estimates by comparing Job ChalleNGe participants with ChalleNGe-only participants, non-ChalleNGe youth, and ChalleNGe graduates in states without Job ChalleNGe.  This would require access to large samples and longitudinal data, potentially leveraging state-level longitudinal data systems.

analysis.sample_description: The study focused on ChalleNGe classes that began in 2019 (Classes 52 and 53) and Job ChalleNGe programs.  The sample size varied across data sources and analyses.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, trend analysis, and multivariate regression models (planned for future analyses) were used.  The study also planned to use quasi-experimental techniques for causal inference in the Job ChalleNGe outcomes study.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The research involved gathering inputs from various stakeholders (military services, USTRANSCOM, DoD policy organizations) through interviews with subject matter experts (SMEs).  Data analysis included examining TWCF operational data (revenues, expenses, net operating results, customer rates, Airlift Readiness Account) from sources like annual budget estimates and Billing Rate Computation and Proposed Adjustments (IF-12 exhibits).  The analysis also drew upon relevant DoD and USTRANSCOM documents outlining missions, Defense WCF objectives, and TWCF policies.

sections.title: Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: The analysis used selection criteria addressing whether the TWCF supported USTRANSCOM readiness, met DoD objectives for DWCFs, and met administrative objectives.  Potential courses of action (COAs) were developed, including Appropriations, Variable Cost Pricing, Commercial Benchmark, and Cost Plus.  These COAs were evaluated based on customer payments, other cost recovery methods, and other features. The analysis also considered regulatory and administrative changes such as increased customer engagement and oversight of USTRANSCOM overhead costs.

analysis.sample_description: The study included a wide range of stakeholders:  military services customers, USTRANSCOM headquarters and service component commands, and DoD policy organizations.  Specific SMEs are listed in chunk 31.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved assessing the current TWCF structure against established evaluation criteria and comparing it to alternative COAs.  The analysis also considered the implications of each COA for USTRANSCOM readiness, DoD objectives, and administrative efficiency.  A decision logic was applied to determine the most appropriate COA for each business line, considering factors such as workload predictability, customer decision influence, and contribution to readiness.

sections.title: Cost Estimation Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Variable costs for each business line were estimated using assessments from USTRANSCOM subject-matter experts on cost categories reported in IF-12 exhibits. Partially variable costs were allocated based on proportions of other costs designated as fully variable or fixed.  Direct Contracts were considered fully variable. Fixed costs included personnel and facilities costs, contract setup costs, travel, depreciation, and overhead.  Partially variable costs were allocated 40% to variable and 60% to fixed.

analysis.sample_description: Data from USTRANSCOM's IF-12 exhibits, covering fiscal years 2015-2021.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative assessment of cost categories by subject matter experts, followed by quantitative allocation of partially variable costs based on proportions of fully variable and fixed costs.

sections.title: Appendix A: Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used in the RAND study.  It involved a two-pronged approach: a top-down environmental scan of peer-reviewed and non-academic literature using PubMed, Google Search, and Google Scholar, and a bottom-up approach involving an advisory panel and key informant interviews. The top-down approach used concept mapping to guide literature searches, focusing on scope, scale, evidence strength, and case studies. The bottom-up approach involved an advisory panel of experts (mental health consumers, advocates, researchers, clinicians, health system representatives, policymakers, and payers) who provided feedback on the concept map and identified additional mechanisms and policies for investigation.  Fifteen interviews were conducted with 16 individuals (representing consumers, payers, providers, researchers, and policymakers at federal and state levels).  A semi-structured interview guide covered structural problems, access to care, workforce, person-centered care, and financing.  The advisory panel met twice to review the concept map, mechanisms for change, and potential policies and programs.

analysis.sample_description: Advisory panel of experts (mental health consumers, advocates, researchers, clinicians, health system representatives, policymakers, and payers); 15 interviews with 16 individuals (consumers, payers, providers, researchers, and policymakers at federal and state levels).
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of literature and interview data;  Advisory panel ratings of mechanisms for change across five dimensions (evidence-based, actionable, transformative, politically feasible, novel).

sections.title: Method (Task 1-3)
sections.methods_summary: Three tasks were conducted: 1) Review of relevant documents and data from DCSA on current collection efforts, supplemented by interviews with DCSA and SLTT experts. 2) Identification of data elements required for a DAF, data aggregation and cleaning, and quality assessment. 3) Development of an Excel-based DAF using information from previous tasks, considering DCSA goals and priorities to identify areas for resource investment.

sections.title: Assumptions and Limitations
sections.methods_summary: Data limitations at the local level and for tribes/territories; data are aggregated at the state level. Data are a snapshot in time (May 2020-December 2021), using pre-COVID-19 data when possible.  The DAF does not include detailed information on DCSA encounters with LEAs.

sections.title: Method
sections.methods_summary: Literature review of publicly available reports (SEARCH reports, IJIS Institute, DOJ) on CHRI practices, including legislation, regulations, policies, and practices related to CHRI across SLTTs.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Three tasks: 1) Survey of statutory and regulatory authorities governing the current process and identification of impediments to DCSA collaboration. 2) Analysis of DCSA-provided data to identify obstacles to efficient information-sharing and prioritize SLTT organizations. 3) Use of visualization tools and advanced analytic techniques to support data-driven decisions on resource allocation.

sections.title: Method (DAF Development)
sections.methods_summary: Multiparameter ranking method derived from multiattribute utility theory (MAUT).  Three-step process: 1) Data scoping, sorting, and organization. 2) Indicator scoring and normalization, locality organization by factor scores. 3) Priority assignment through weighting schema, indexing, and ranking.  Qualitative and quantitative data combined.  Missing data scores assigned where information was unavailable.  Data normalized to 0-1 scale.  DCSA data used to adjust index score based on investigation quantity and priority.

analysis.sample_description: The study focuses on all 50 US states and Washington, D.C., with data aggregated at the state level. Data for local, tribal, and territorial levels were limited.
analysis.analysis_approach: A multiparameter ranking method derived from MAUT was used to develop a decision aid framework (DAF).  The DAF combines qualitative and quantitative data to rank localities based on their ability to support CHRI collection.  Data were normalized and weighted according to DCSA priorities.  A DCSA adjustment factor was incorporated to account for investigation quantity and priority.

sections.title: Approach and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A modified systematic review of policy papers related to disinformation was conducted.  A search of the Policyfile database yielded 156 reports. Additional reports were added from the EUvsDisinfo website and other sources.  64 studies meeting the criteria (clearly demarcated recommendations section and focus on disinformation/propaganda) were included.  Qualitative coding using Dedoose software was used to categorize recommendations into major and subcategories.

analysis.sample_description: 64 policy papers published between January 2, 2016, and December 11, 2020, focusing on recommendations to address disinformation or propaganda.  The majority were from the US, with some from Europe. Most focused on propaganda and social media.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative coding using Dedoose software to categorize recommendations into major categories (social media platform policies, U.S. and allied government policies, coordination recommendations, awareness and education recommendations, recommendations for supporting various media and media content) and subcategories.  The analysis focused on categorizing and explaining recommendations.

sections.title: Prototype Tool Development and Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: The study leveraged existing computer code from a previous RAND report (Knapp et al., 2020) that applied Full Cost of Manpower (FCoM) cost factors to billet files. This code was integrated into a prototype tool.  The prototype tool allows users to upload billet files, apply FCoM cost factors, and visualize cost estimates through graphs and tables.  The study used data from the FCoM model, including compensation, healthcare, recruiting, and training costs. Expected years of service (for active duty) and step (for civilian billets) were computed using data from the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC) Active Duty and Civilian Master Files, averaging the 10th, 30th, 50th, 70th, and 90th percentile values for each pay grade-service combination from FY 2013 to FY 2018.  The study also used data from the Population Representation of the Military Services report and FedScope to estimate the proportion of the DoD force excluded from the prototype tool due to limitations in FCoM data.

sections.title: Prototype Tool Demonstration: Hypothetical Organization
sections.methods_summary: The prototype tool's functionality was demonstrated using a hypothetical organization designed to resemble a combatant command, including a mix of active duty and civilian billets across services, pay grades, and locations.  The demonstration showcased three key features: streamlining cost estimation for large organizations, summarizing cost estimates in tables and figures, and manipulating billet counts to observe the effect on cost.  A scenario involving reallocation of billets was presented to illustrate the tool's capabilities for running various manpower scenarios.

sections.title: Appendix A: Prototype Instructions
sections.methods_summary: This section provides a step-by-step guide on using the prototype tool, including uploading a billet file, cleaning the data, applying cost factors, summarizing the output, and manipulating billet counts to run scenarios.  It uses a hypothetical organization as an example.

sections.title: Appendix B: Description of Billet File Formats
sections.methods_summary: This appendix details the required and acceptable formats for billet files, specifically for pay grade and UIC columns.  It describes the cleaning process the prototype tool uses to handle variations in input formats, including how it derives service from UIC when not explicitly provided.  It explains how the tool converts various UIC formats to the DMDC UIC format used for location matching.

analysis.sample_description: A hypothetical organization designed to resemble a combatant command, with a mix of active duty and civilian billets across services, pay grades, and locations.  Data from the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC) Active Duty and Civilian Master Files were used to calculate expected years of service and step for billets.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study primarily involved developing and demonstrating a prototype tool.  Data analysis was performed to summarize cost estimates and illustrate the tool's capabilities in various scenarios.  The analysis relied on existing data from the Full Cost of Manpower (FCoM) model and the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC).

sections.title: Approach and Roadmap to This Report
sections.methods_summary: This report relied on an extensive literature review, a series of consultations with researchers at RAND with expertise in related topics, and expert perspective of the authors. The literature review included academic literature, policy research literature, government reports, and popular media. We also reviewed public data sources (such as about energy and trade). To develop our discussion of U.S. interests, we considered core interests that have stood the test of time through politically different administrations. We then considered regional characteristics that have caused notable problems for the United States and added them to interests that needed to be addressed. Then to develop the recommendations, we looked at changes in both the United States and the Middle East that create new circumstances or opportunities.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable. This is a policy analysis report, not an empirical study with a defined sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of existing data and expert opinions to develop a framework for understanding U.S. security interests in the Middle East and recommendations for policy changes.

sections.title: Roundtable Discussion and Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: The primary methodology was a one-day roundtable discussion with judges, lawyers, corporate officials, legal analysts, and scholars involved in or studying the Volkswagen 'clean diesel' litigation. Participants came from jurisdictions with well-developed mass litigation procedures.  The discussion focused on global mass civil litigation generally, not the specifics of the VW case.  The report was initially intended to summarize this discussion but was expanded to include updated descriptions of procedural mechanisms and outcomes of the VW litigation in the represented jurisdictions.

sections.title: Comparative Analysis of Legal Procedures
sections.methods_summary: The study involved a comparative analysis of legal procedures for resolving mass claims in seven jurisdictions (U.S., Canada, Australia, Germany, Netherlands, Brazil, Chile).  The analysis describes the key characteristics of collective resolution mechanisms, including representative procedures (class actions) and procedures aggregating individual claims.  The analysis also considers factors such as legal fee distribution, litigation funding, and lawyer payment rules, and their interaction with collective procedures. A table compares key features of each jurisdiction's procedure.

sections.title: Case Study Analysis of Volkswagen Litigation
sections.methods_summary: The study uses the Volkswagen 'clean diesel' litigation as a case study to examine global mass civil litigation.  It describes the progress and outcomes of the VW litigation in the seven jurisdictions, drawing on information from lawyers representing plaintiffs and defendants, and public records.  The analysis tracks the litigation's development, including settlements, regulatory actions, and criminal prosecutions, in each jurisdiction.

analysis.sample_description: The roundtable included judges, lawyers, corporate officials, legal analysts, and scholars from Australia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Germany, the Netherlands, and the United States, all with expertise in mass litigation and many with direct involvement in the VW case. The case study analysis focuses on the VW litigation in these same seven jurisdictions.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis is primarily descriptive, comparing and contrasting the legal procedures and outcomes of the VW litigation across different jurisdictions.  It identifies common themes and lessons learned from the litigation.

sections.title: Software Risk Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Data was collected from BitSight and Shodan for publicly accessible software applications.  NIST's NVD was used to identify known vulnerabilities. CVSS scores were used to assess vulnerability severity, and EPSS scores estimated the probability of exploitation.
