Analysis involved identifying prevalent applications, their vulnerabilities, severity, and exploitability, and visualizing these relationships.  A complementary analysis examined software libraries and dependencies, noting data limitations.

sections.title: Software Dependency Component Libraries Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of two reports (CII and Veracode/Cyentia) on commonly used open-source software libraries.  Examination of ownership and management of these libraries using publicly available information on GitHub, focusing on owner type and nationality.  Categorization of library owners as individual, community, or business, and by nationality (U.S., non-U.S., unknown).

sections.title: Business Risk Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Leveraged existing work (Welburn, Strong, Nekoul, et al., 2020) using a firm-level input/output model to estimate total economic loss and interconnectedness for IT and communication sector firms following a 1% revenue shock.  Identified firms with greatest total economic loss and most interconnected firms.  Analysis used data from the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission's Statement of Financial Accounting Standards 131.

sections.title: Mapping National Critical Functions to Businesses Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Developed a two-step process: 1) Mapping NCFs to a software taxonomy (modified version of International Data Corporation’s Worldwide Software Taxonomy) using expert panel review; 2) Mapping software categories to firms using industry analyst reports.  Selected NCFs with detailed descriptions and associated assets.  Enumerated firms without applying prioritization logic from analyst reports.

analysis.sample_description: The study used various data sources including publicly accessible software applications, vulnerability databases (NVD), and financial data on publicly traded companies.  The open-source software library analysis focused on the most commonly used libraries in various programming languages. The business risk analysis focused on the largest 1000 firms by revenue.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved identifying and visualizing relationships between vulnerability severity and exploitability, examining software dependencies and ownership structures, estimating economic loss and interconnectedness using a firm-level input/output model, and mapping NCFs to software companies through a software taxonomy.

sections.title: Research scope, objectives and methodology
sections.methods_summary: Scoping study involving review of key documentation (mainly from the MCCE) and key informant interviews with ten officials from across the MCCE and selected Member Nations (e.g., US Africa Command (AFRICOM)).

analysis.sample_description: Ten officials from across the MCCE and selected Member Nations.
analysis.analysis_approach: Findings from the document review and interviews are summarized in the report.

sections.title: Research Purpose and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research involved five tasks: 1) A literature review of RAS-AI; 2) Gathering information on relevant strategy, policy, missions, systems, programs, and threats; 3) Conducting interviews with key stakeholders using a mixture of structured and semi-structured questions; 4) Holding workshops with RAND subject matter experts (SMEs) to review lessons learned from past RAND RAS research and discuss potential areas for consideration in the RAS strategy; and 5) Developing recommendations to inform the Navy RAS-AI strategy.

sections.title: Literature Summary
sections.methods_summary: A literature review of over 200 documents was conducted, resulting in summaries of approximately 100 documents relevant to informing Navy's thinking about RAS-AI.  These documents included academic reviews, policy pronouncements, commentaries, and news reports.

sections.title: Stakeholder Interview Summaries
sections.methods_summary: Fifteen semi-structured interviews were conducted with senior Navy and other Defence staff.  The interviews focused on two main questions: understanding the evolving context for RAS-AI in the maritime domain and understanding the steps required for Navy to realize the benefits of RAS-AI.  A series of questions based on Plan Pelorus were used.

sections.title: Summary of Responses
sections.methods_summary: Key points from the interviews are summarized for each question.  These points, along with the literature review, were used to identify key initiatives or issues for Navy to address regarding RAS-AI.

sections.title: UK Perspectives
sections.methods_summary: Four interviews were conducted with senior UK defence and industry officials to gain insights into the UK's approach to maritime RAS-AI.

sections.title: U.S. Perspectives
sections.methods_summary: Three virtual stakeholder workshops were held with RAND U.S. Navy experts focusing on integration and interoperability, capability development and acquisition, and C2 and RAS-AI missions.

analysis.sample_description: The study included interviews with 15 Australian Defence Force personnel, 4 UK defence and industry officials, and 10 RAND U.S. Navy experts participating in workshops.  The literature review encompassed over 200 documents, with approximately 100 summarized.
analysis.analysis_approach: Thematic analysis of interview data and literature review findings.  Thematic analysis of workshop findings. Thematic synthesis of all data to inform recommendations for a strategic roadmap.

sections.title: Method for Assessing a Nation's DIB Manufacturing
sections.methods_summary: Sequential methodology to 1. establish total manufacturing output; 2. categorize and assess manufacturing DIB; 3. establish additional categories of convertible manufacturing; 4. qualitatively and quantitatively assess strengths and weaknesses using manufacturing indices.  Includes metrics for manufacturing capacity, dependency, trade balance, and supply chain analysis.

sections.title: Method for Assessing Raw Materials
sections.methods_summary: Examines domestic availability vs. import reliance for raw materials. Uses the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI) to quantify concentration risk.  Analyzes 40 concentrated minerals for defense applications, considering substitutability.  Classifies minerals by substitutability and defense application.

sections.title: Study Approach and Methodology Development
sections.methods_summary: 1. Scoping relevant areas for assessment based on the FY21 NDAA. 2. Literature review of English-language sources (academic journals, research organizations, government documents). 3. Development of a repeatable, structured methodology across six topics (economics, governance, R&D, workforce, manufacturing, raw materials). 4. Application of the methodology to China using both primary and secondary sources.  Includes details on literature search terms, databases used, and document prioritization.

sections.title: Assessment Methodology for a Foreign DIB
sections.methods_summary: Provides a framework and methods for assessing a foreign country's DIB across six topics: economics, governance and regulations, research, development, and innovation, workforce, labor, and skills, manufacturing, and raw materials.  Details are provided for each topic, including specific metrics, data sources, and analytical approaches (both quantitative and qualitative).

analysis.sample_description: The primary case study is the People's Republic of China's defense industrial base (DIB). The methodology is designed to be applicable to any country.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis combines qualitative and quantitative methods, using various metrics and data sources to assess strengths and vulnerabilities across six key areas.  The analysis compares China's progress against its own stated goals and identifies areas of reliance on the United States and its allies.

sections.title: Data Sources and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Interviews with Weinberg Center staff, analysis of medical records (MDS data) for Weinberg Center clients (2013-2019), construction of five vignettes to quantify cost savings and benefits, analysis of Weinberg Center financial data (2013-2019).

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Semi-structured interviews with 10 Weinberg Center and Hebrew Home staff (7 interviews with interdisciplinary team members analyzed for themes), analysis of Minimum Data Set (MDS) data for 100 Weinberg Center clients (2013-2019) focusing on depression, pain, cognition, and mobility; financial analysis of Weinberg Center data (2013-2019); cost-benefit analysis using a vignette framework with five illustrative hypothetical scenarios, applying a formula (Si = Ai × Ri × Pi – Ci) to calculate potential savings, drawing parameters from existing literature and Weinberg Center data.  Limitations of the vignette approach are discussed.

primary_methods: Analysis of Minimum Data Set (MDS) data
analysis.sample_description: 100 Weinberg Center clients admitted between 2013 and 2019.  A subset of these clients had complete data for all four assessments.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive analysis of MDS data to track changes in health indicators over time.  Cost-benefit analysis using a formula and parameters from existing literature applied to individual vignettes and then extrapolated to the study population.  Limitations of the analysis are acknowledged.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Data Collection and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This chapter details the methodology used for the study, including formative evaluation, evaluability assessment, and evaluation design options.  Data collection involved staff interviews (with two interview guides, one for Weinberg Center staff and one for others), a systematic literature review of 1565 unique sources (using specific databases and inclusion/exclusion criteria), and data from the Weinberg Center and SPRiNG Alliance members. Qualitative data analysis used manual coding and the Dedoose software. The evaluability assessment utilized a RAND-developed tool, the Program Implementation and Evaluation Readiness (PIER) report, with three researchers independently scoring the Weinberg Center's EAS and resolving disagreements through consensus.  The evaluation design options were informed by a comprehensive review of existing shelter evaluations, using an extraction form to collate information on designs, data, and measures.

sections.title: Chapter 4: Evaluability Assessment of the Weinberg Center
sections.methods_summary: An evaluability assessment was conducted using the RAND-developed PIER report, focusing on organizational readiness (culture, capacity, staff, partners), program readiness (design, implementation processes, procedures, case flow, training), and evaluation readiness (quasi-experimental design elements, client enrollment, data collection). Three researchers independently scored the Weinberg Center's EAS, resolving disagreements through consensus. Scores ranged from 0 to 3, with higher scores indicating greater readiness.  The analysis presented the overall scores for each category and discussed key factors contributing to those scores.

sections.title: Chapter 5: Evaluation Designs
sections.methods_summary: This chapter outlines three evaluation designs for assessing the impact of the Weinberg Center's EAS and other EASs.  A literature review of 35 sources (including systematic and nonsystematic reviews, quasi-experimental designs, and RCTs) informed the proposed designs.  Recommended outcome measures, compiled from the literature review, the Weinberg Center logic model, and expert consultations, were grouped into four areas: mental and physical health and well-being, legal and justice outcomes, abuse risk, and client-centered goals.  Three evaluation options were presented: 1) Randomization using the opt-in nature of treatment (comparing outcomes of Weinberg Center clients with those who were referred but did not become clients); 2) Propensity score matching (comparing Weinberg Center clients with similar individuals in a secondary data source, such as APS data); and 3) A pre- and post-evaluation design (tracking Weinberg Center clients over time to determine whether client outcomes improve).  Each option included a discussion of potential biases, sample size considerations (including power analysis for Option 1), data collection methods, cost estimates, and timelines.  The chapter also discussed important considerations for evaluators, including working with victims of elder abuse, equity, data security, client and family input, and cost-benefit analysis.

primary_methods: Quasi-experimental designs (including propensity score matching and pre-post design)
analysis.sample_description: The study focused on the Weinberg Center for Elder Justice in NYC and its Elder Abuse Shelter (EAS) model.  Data also included information from six SPRiNG Alliance member organizations and various stakeholders (APS, hospitals, law enforcement, etc.).  Sample sizes for proposed evaluation designs varied, with recommendations of at least 100 participants in each arm for some designs, and a total of 200 participants for others.  The actual number of Weinberg Center clients was relatively small (16-34 per year).
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data analysis involved manual coding and thematic analysis using Dedoose software.  Quantitative analysis for the proposed evaluation designs would involve various statistical methods depending on the chosen design (e.g., comparison of means, regression analysis, propensity score matching).

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Systematic examination of classical deterrence literature, recently published commentaries and academic papers on deterrence strategy in the space domain, and a broad set of primary source documents representing China’s objectives and strategy in space.  Analysis of Beijing’s goals and its approach to deterrence in the space domain and how these goals may challenge elements of an effective deterrence strategy in space. Assessment of potential implications for the United States, allies, and partners in the Indo-Pacific.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consists of classical deterrence literature, recent publications on space domain deterrence, and primary source documents on China's space strategy.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves identifying key tenets of deterrence strategies, comparing and contrasting them with the space domain context, examining China's specific goals and approaches, and assessing the implications for US strategy in the Indo-Pacific.

sections.title: Annex B. Methodology information
sections.methods_summary: This section details the mixed-methods approach used in the evaluation.  Data collection methods included: targeted documentation review (funding applications, routine data, management information, fidelity review documentation), case studies of Communities of Practice (CoPs) involving observations and interviews, semi-structured interviews and focus groups with various stakeholders, and two rounds of online surveys with IPS practitioners.  Qualitative data analysis (thematic analysis) and descriptive statistics were used.  Adaptations were made to data collection due to the COVID-19 pandemic, shifting to virtual methods.

primary_methods: Case studies of Communities of Practice
analysis.sample_description: A sample of 21 STPs was selected for baseline assessments, ensuring geographical coverage, diversity in access to IPS, provider types, and funding amounts.  For fidelity reviews, 7 services were selected, aiming for regional and service type spread but ultimately guided by practical considerations.  CoPs were purposively sampled based on geographical and thematic coverage and practical considerations. Interviewees were selected to represent a range of regions and service types from the baseline assessment sample, with the help of IPS Grow leads.  The online survey was disseminated to all IPS team leaders supported by IPS Grow.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data analysis (primarily thematic analysis) was used for interviews, focus groups, and open-ended survey questions. Descriptive statistics were used for closed-ended survey questions.  Fidelity reviews used a 25-item fidelity scale to assess the quality of IPS services.  A draft typology of IPS service organization models was created based on the review of funding applications.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section details the research approach, which involved a review of 31 publicly available RAND reports published between 2013 and mid-2020.  The reports were identified using search terms based on OPM's definition of talent management and RAND's internal research taxonomy.  Qualitative data analysis software was used to group findings and recommendations by workforce management topic. A framework was developed to organize findings around four pillars of talent management: build and organize, train and develop, manage and motivate performance, and promote and retain the right talent.

analysis.sample_description: 31 publicly available RAND reports on defense workforce management published between 2013 and mid-2020.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data analysis software was used to group findings and recommendations by workforce management topic.  Findings were organized using a framework based on four pillars of talent management.

sections.title: Study Design and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the overall study design, including research questions, study populations, data sources, and analytic approaches for each domain and component.  It describes descriptive statistics, quasi-experimental models (difference-in-differences for Domain 1, survival analysis for Domain 2), and multivariable regression models. Specific methods include logistic regression, Poisson regression, negative binomial models (where applicable), linear regression, and Huber-White standard errors.  Data sources include MLTC enrollment data, Medicaid Data Warehouse, Minimum Data Set (MDS 3.0), MLTC satisfaction data, Money Follows the Person (MFP) master data, Semi-Annual Assessment of Members (SAAM), Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS), and Uniform Assessment System for New York (UAS-NY) Community Health Assessment Data (CHA).  Sampling methods are described for specific analyses, including simple random sampling for some Domain 2 analyses.  The section also discusses limitations of the data and analysis, such as the lack of individual-level data and changes in outcome measure definitions over time.

sections.title: Appendix A: Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: This appendix provides a table listing and describing the various data sources used in the evaluation.

sections.title: Appendix B: Regression Methods
sections.methods_summary: This appendix details the specific regression models used for each domain and goal, including the variables and parameters used in each model.  It describes the use of region-level fixed effects, flexible functions of calendar time, and Huber-White standard errors.

sections.title: Appendix C: Criteria Used to Identify Individuals Excluded or Exempt from Medicaid Managed Care
sections.methods_summary: This appendix provides tables defining the populations excluded from and exempt from Medicaid Managed Care (MMC) enrollment.

sections.title: Appendix D: Additional Results
sections.methods_summary: This appendix presents additional tables and figures showing detailed results, including the number of MLTC plans by region, year, and plan type; percentages with continuous enrollment by demographics; and probabilities of disenrollment and continuous enrollment adjusted for demographics and health status.

primary_methods: Multivariable regression analysis (logistic regression, Poisson regression, negative binomial regression, linear regression)
analysis.sample_description: The study populations vary by domain and goal.  For Domain 1, data are aggregated at the plan level. For Domain 2, the study population includes individuals newly covered by the 12-month continuous eligibility policy (treatment group) and a comparison group of children.  A simple random sample of Medicaid enrollees was used for some Domain 2 analyses.  Specific sample sizes are provided throughout the report.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach varies by domain and goal but generally involves descriptive statistics, trend analysis, and multivariable regression modeling to assess the impact of the interventions.  Difference-in-differences and survival analysis techniques are used to estimate causal effects.  Huber-White standard errors are used to account for potential heteroskedasticity and intra-person correlation.

sections.title: Study Methodology: Interviews
sections.methods_summary: Semistructured interviews with 30+ senior leaders and SMEs from 25+ defense S&T organizations. Thematic analysis (Attride-Stirling, 2001; Braun and Clarke, 2006) was used to identify themes from 225 transcribed comments.

sections.title: Study Methodology: Data Science Methods
sections.methods_summary: Development of a prototype tool, Semantic Clustering Analysis and Thematic Exploration Tool (SCAnTExT), to extract information from free-text data sources.  The NLP path involved data extraction, preparation (stemming, stop word removal, TF-IDF), and semantic analysis (Latent Semantic Analysis).  The tool was applied to a collection of 20+ data sources comprising hundreds of thousands of records. Three semantic operations were demonstrated: locating, grouping, and matching records.

sections.title: Study Methodology: Foresight Methods
sections.methods_summary: Review of literature on foresight methods.  Application of Porter's framework (2010) to three TCO initiatives (Explore, WARTECH, Vanguard) to determine the suitability of different foresight methods.  Selection of foresight methods based on nine dimensions (motivation, drivers, scope, locus, time horizon, purpose, target users, participation, study duration). Three case studies used a combination of SCAnTExT and selected foresight methods.

sections.title: Study Methodology: Case Studies
sections.methods_summary: Three case studies (High-Speed Vertical Takeoff and Landing, Joint All-Domain Command and Control, Human Capital Management) were conducted, each following a four-step process: (1) using SCAnTExT to extract initial capability gaps; (2) iterating gap selection using foresight methods; (3) using SCAnTExT to extract initial technology solutions; and (4) iterating solution selection using foresight methods.  Specific foresight methods used varied by case study (e.g., brainstorming, relevance trees, scenario creation).

sections.title: Appendix C: Data Science Methods - Additional Analyses
sections.methods_summary: Manual coding of 800 JLLIS records to create a labeled dataset for supervised learning. Evaluation of two supervised learning algorithms (support vector machines, penalized general linear models) and one unsupervised learning algorithm (LSA) for classifying JLLIS records related to Air Force Task 5.1.  Leave-one-out cross-validation was used. Model performance was evaluated using precision, recall, and F1 score.  Exploration of using BERT for topic modeling, including embeddings generation, dimensionality reduction (UMAP), clustering (HDBSCAN), and topic determination (class-based TF-IDF).

primary_methods: foresight methods (Porter's framework, brainstorming, relevance trees, scenario creation, etc.)
supervised and unsupervised machine learning (SVM, GLM, LSA, BERT, UMAP, HDBSCAN)
analysis.sample_description: 30+ senior leaders and SMEs from 25+ defense S&T organizations; hundreds of thousands of records from 20+ data sources; 800 JLLIS records for supervised learning; 60,000 records for BERT topic modeling.
analysis.analysis_approach: Thematic analysis of interview transcripts; Latent Semantic Analysis and clustering of text data; application of Porter's framework to select foresight methods; evaluation of machine learning models using precision, recall, and F1 score; topic modeling using BERT and HDBSCAN.

sections.title: Technical Appendix: Survey Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used a weighted probability sample of K-12 public school districts and charter management organizations (CMOs) in the US.  Weights were created to reflect the national population of public school districts, accounting for selection and response probabilities.  The weights were calibrated to match the population distribution of public school districts and CMOs.  Open-ended responses were analyzed using Dedoose qualitative analysis software, with open coding to identify emergent themes and sub-themes.  These themes were then weighted to reflect their prominence in the sample.

analysis.sample_description: A weighted probability sample of K–12 public school districts and charter management organizations (CMOs) in the United States. Large urban districts were oversampled.  The sample included over 375 districts, with a response rate of 84%.
analysis.analysis_approach: Weighted analysis to account for sampling and nonresponse bias. Open-ended responses were coded using qualitative analysis software and then weighted to reflect their prevalence in the sample.  The analysis included comparisons between focus districts (at least 50% Black or Hispanic/Latino students or at least 50% eligible for free or reduced-price lunch) and nonfocus districts.

sections.title: Sample Design and Recruitment Strategy
sections.methods_summary: The study used a stratified sampling design with three strata: a nationally representative sample of traditional public school districts, Council of the Great City Schools (CGCS) members, and charter management organizations (CMOs) from the Charter School Growth Fund (CSGF).  Probability proportional to the square root of district size was used for sampling the national sample. Recruitment involved a multi-pronged approach using trusted partner organizations, mailed invitations, emails from the ASDP help desk, and follow-up phone calls (initially).  The study also describes the two-step enrollment process: an online enrollment form followed by a short survey.

sections.title: Weighting the ASDP Responses
sections.methods_summary: Weights were created to make the sample nationally representative.  This involved calculating sample selection weights (inverse probability of selection, proportional to the square root of enrollment size) and survey response weights (inverse of the modeled probability of response, conditional on district characteristics).  These weights were then calibrated to match national characteristics of US public school districts using district size, student demographics, free/reduced-price lunch eligibility, geographic region, and locale as calibration factors.  A trimming process was used to reduce outliers in the final weights.  The resulting design effect was 1.70.

analysis.sample_description: A stratified sample of approximately 750 school districts and charter management organizations (CMOs) was used.  The sample included a nationally representative sample of traditional public school districts, all members of the Council of the Great City Schools (CGCS), and a selection of CMOs from the Charter School Growth Fund (CSGF).  The national sample was drawn using probability proportional to the square root of district size.
analysis.analysis_approach: Survey data was weighted to ensure national representativeness, using calibration weighting to adjust for nonresponse and to match population characteristics.  Outliers in the weights were trimmed.

sections.title: Data Collection and Sample Description
sections.methods_summary: A survey was fielded to a randomly sampled set of 291 district and charter network leaders.  Responses were weighted to be nationally representative. The report focuses on a subset of 222 superintendents. The survey was administered between February 28, 2022, and April 10, 2022.

sections.title: Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Differences in responses by district characteristics were examined.  Data on district characteristics were obtained by linking survey data to the 2020–2021 Common Core of Data (CCD). Significance testing was conducted at the p < 0.05 level.  Multiple hypothesis test corrections were not applied.

sections.title: Study Design and Sampling
sections.methods_summary: Researchers randomly sampled districts and CMOs to invite them to enroll in the ASDP between fall 2020 and spring 2022. All enrolled districts were invited to complete the survey.  The report is based on survey responses from 222 superintendents.  District characteristics examined included locale, student racial and ethnic composition, district poverty level, and district size.  These yielded ten subgroups.  The analysis notes that each district belongs to four subgroups, and patterns observed might be driven by districts sharing multiple characteristics.

analysis.sample_description: A nationally representative sample of 222 superintendents, a subset of a larger survey of 291 district and charter network leaders.  Subgroup analysis was conducted based on district characteristics (locale, student demographics, poverty level, and size).
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics and significance testing (p<0.05) were used to analyze differences in responses across district subgroups.  Exploratory regression analyses were conducted but deemed underpowered to report.

sections.title: Survey Sample and Administration
sections.methods_summary: Describes the sixth ASDP survey, its development in consultation with stakeholders, administration timeline (October 13, 2022 – December 12, 2022), online administration,  participation limitations to ASDP member districts and CMOs, email survey requests to designated points of contact, potential for multiple staff members within a district to contribute to responses, invitation to non-enrolled districts to join the ASDP, and lack of monetary incentives.

sections.title: Survey Sample and Administration (continued)
sections.methods_summary: Provides survey completion rate (26.1%), respondent breakdown (94 newly enrolled, 206 previously enrolled), and reference to weighted descriptive statistics in Table 1.  Also includes footnotes explaining the calculation of completion rate and the reasons for not using monetary incentives.

sections.title: Method for Creating the Sample and Survey Weights
sections.methods_summary: Details the creation of weights to reflect the national population of public school districts and CMOs.  This includes accounting for probability of selection and response probability.  The process involved multiplying selection and participation probabilities, calibrating them to match population distribution, and adjusting for nonresponse bias.  The method uses two interim weights: sample selection weight (inverse probability of selection, with oversampling of large urban districts) and survey response weight (inverse of modeled probability of response, conditional on district characteristics).  Recalibration ensures alignment with population estimates.  The final weight is the product of these interim weights, with trimming of extreme values at the 95th percentile and reallocation to maintain population totals.  The sampling probability was proportional to the square root of district enrollment size.  The response weight was modeled using district characteristics from the National Center for Education Statistics' Common Core of Data.

analysis.sample_description: The sample consisted of 1,148 school districts and charter management organizations (CMOs) enrolled in the American School District Panel (ASDP) between fall 2020 and fall 2022.  Of these, 300 participated in the fall 2022 survey.  Large urban districts were oversampled.  Weights were used to adjust for sampling and nonresponse bias to ensure the sample reflected the national population of school districts and CMOs.
analysis.analysis_approach: Weighted proportions were calculated using survey weights calibrated to match national averages.  The report mentions an interactive Survey Results tool for disaggregated data, but doesn't detail specific analytical techniques beyond descriptive statistics.

sections.title: Survey Sample and Administration
sections.methods_summary: The seventh ASDP survey was developed in consultation with the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and project partners.  It was administered online from March 1, 2023, through April 25, 2023, to a sample of 1,107 school districts, with 222 participating (20.1% response rate).  The survey was emailed to designated points of contact (often superintendents), who could share it with other staff.  No monetary incentives were used.  Districts not yet enrolled in the ASDP were also invited to participate.

sections.title: Method for Creating the Sample and Survey Weights
sections.methods_summary: Weights were created to ensure the sample reflected the national population of public school districts.  This involved accounting for the probability of selection and response.  The weights were calculated as the product of the sample selection weight (inverse probability of selection, with oversampling of large urban districts) and the survey response weight (inverse of the modeled probability of response, conditional on district characteristics).  The resulting weights were recalibrated to match population estimates, and extreme weights were trimmed at the 95th percentile.

analysis.sample_description: The study used the American School District Panel (ASDP), a nationally representative sample of over 1,000 school districts.  For this survey, 222 districts participated out of 1,107 invited (20.1% response rate).  Large urban districts were oversampled.  The sample included traditional K-12 public school districts and charter management organizations (CMOs), excluding CMOs in this specific survey cycle.
analysis.analysis_approach: Weighted descriptive statistics were calculated to ensure the sample reflected the national population of school districts.  The weighting process accounted for both selection and participation probabilities, and weights were calibrated to match national averages.  A variable selection method was used to choose the model that best fit the data for response weights.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Compilation of tribal and local policing cases (since 1880), interviews with tribal and community leaders across rural Afghanistan, examination of anthropological work on tribal and community dynamics.

analysis.sample_description: Dozens of tribal and community leaders across rural Afghanistan (west, south, and east), nearly two dozen tribal and other local policing cases dating from 1880.
analysis.analysis_approach: Brief assessment of the effectiveness of local defense forces, informed by the collected data and anthropological literature.

sections.title: Analytic Approach and Baseline Estimates
sections.methods_summary: Review of existing literature on Chinese and Indian defense spending. Compilation of historical GDP and defense spending data in local currency units (LCUs). Estimation of real growth rates using implicit price deflators from the IMF. Creation of alternative forecasts of defense spending using different assumptions about growth rates and GDP shares. Conversion of spending estimates from LCUs to constant 2009 U.S. dollars using market exchange rates (MXR) and purchasing power parity (PPP).

sections.title: Comparative Forecasts of Defense and Defense Procurement Spending in 2025
sections.methods_summary: Two types of forecasts were conducted: "defense growth rate" forecasts, projecting real growth in defense spending at various constant average annual real growth rates; and "parametric" forecasts, assuming alternative annual real growth rates in GDP and alternative defense shares of GDP.  Varying assumptions were used to explore a range of plausible trajectories.

sections.title: Parametric Defense Spending Forecasts
sections.methods_summary: Forecasts generated using alternative assumptions about average real GDP growth rates (5.0, 7.5, 10.0, and 12.5 percent) and defense shares of GDP (2.0, 2.5, and 3.0 percent).  Analysis of 144 paired cases (12 for each country).

sections.title: Meta-Analysis of Economic Growth
sections.methods_summary: Collection of studies on economic growth in China and India. Selection of a subset of studies with sufficient data for comparison. Data extraction and calculation of growth rates for GDP, employment, capital, and total factor productivity. Grouping of studies into three clusters (academic, business, and international organizations).

sections.title: Science and Technology Forecast Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Development of a simulation model using GDP growth as an exogenous variable.  Estimation of parameters based on data from OECD and the governments of India and China.  Four alternative scenarios were considered: Scenario 1 (current parameters), Scenario 2 (convergence to South Korea's cost per FTR), Scenario 3 (convergence to South Korea's researcher productivity), and Scenario 4 (quality adjustment based on McKinsey Global Institute data).

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from various sources, including official government documents, international organizations, and academic research.  The meta-analysis includes 27 studies on macroeconomic growth.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a combination of quantitative and qualitative methods. Quantitative methods include data compilation, forecasting, meta-analysis, and simulation modeling. Qualitative methods include literature reviews and expert judgment.

sections.title: Defining Syntax, Semantics, and Contextual Validity
sections.methods_summary: Illustrative example using a first-year physics problem of a falling body to highlight syntactic, semantic, and validity problems in model composition.  Comparison of two models (A and B) to demonstrate these issues.

sections.title: Defining Validation
sections.methods_summary: Discussion of model validation, emphasizing the need to distinguish between the model's representation of the referent, the simulator's execution of the model, and the simulator's generation of behavior like that of the real system.  The importance of specifying context and criteria for evaluation is highlighted.

sections.title: Formalizing Composability Information
sections.methods_summary: Four activities are outlined for producing and utilizing formal composability information: 1. Define a formalism; 2. Define an ontology; 3. Describe candidate models; 4. Develop inference tools.  Discussion of existing efforts (XML, semantic web, ADLs, DEVS) and their limitations.

sections.title: Diagnosis of Composability Issues
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative analysis of factors limiting success in composability efforts, including system complexity, objective difficulty, science and technology, and human considerations.  Speculative parametric plot of risk versus attributes of the composite M&S.

sections.title: Testing and Analysis of a Toy Problem
sections.methods_summary: A toy problem of a duel between two shooters is used to illustrate the complexities of model composition.  A naive composite model is created and tested, revealing discrepancies.  A corrected model is developed and compared to an exact model, highlighting the importance of understanding component internals.  Discrete-time and discrete-event simulations are discussed.

sections.title: Analysis of RAND and Lockheed-Martin Composability Experiences
sections.methods_summary: Description and analysis of composability efforts at RAND (using JANUS and related models) and Lockheed-Martin (using Joint MEASURE).  Focus on the use of high-resolution models for analysis, the challenges of composing models from diverse sources, and the importance of rigorous model specification.

sections.title: Summary of SBA Conclusions
sections.methods_summary: Summary of conclusions from past studies on simulation-based acquisition (SBA), highlighting the importance of culture, acquisition process, and acquisition environment.  Discussion of the limitations of SBA in achieving its goals with complex models.

sections.title: Summary of Workshop Comments
sections.methods_summary: Paraphrased summary of comments from a workshop on composability, covering concerns about culture, organization, people, processes, interoperability, metamodels, data standards, incentives, and the need for a business case.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable.  The document uses illustrative examples and case studies rather than a formal sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis is primarily qualitative, drawing on illustrative examples, case studies, and a review of existing literature to identify factors affecting composability and to suggest recommendations for improvement.

sections.title: Methodology and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study was conducted in three stages. Stage 1 used FY2006 data (with informal checks in FY2007-2008) to assess TADLP's interactive multimedia instruction (IMI) courseware program against five measures of effectiveness: impact, efficiency, quality, cycle time, and responsiveness. Stage 2 developed options for improving the IMI program (as it existed through 2008) based on Stage 1 findings. Stage 3 developed options for broadening TADLP beyond its IMI focus to increase impact, quality, and responsiveness, and improve efficiency.  The study used various methods and sources, including document reviews, data analysis from Army databases, surveys of specific DL courses, interviews and focus groups with schools, contractors, and TRADOC staff, reviews of courseware development processes, and analysis of selected IMI courseware quality.

analysis.sample_description: A stratified sample of 10 IMI courses fielded under TADLP between 2005 and 2007 was used for the qualitative evaluation of courseware.  Interviews were conducted with officials from 20 Army DL programs.
analysis.analysis_approach: The five measures of effectiveness (impact, efficiency, quality, cycle time, and responsiveness) were used to assess TADLP's performance.  A qualitative content analysis was conducted on the selected IMI courseware.  Data from various Army databases and other sources were analyzed.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Used Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) injury and illness data from California (2003-2007). Compared injury frequency and severity for firefighters with those in other occupations.  Calculated average injury rates and median durations of time to return to work by occupation, injury type, and age. Used Occupational Employment Statistics (OES) and Current Population Survey (CPS) data to obtain workforce population sizes.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Methods (Age Analysis)
sections.methods_summary: Examined injury rates (MSD and otherwise) of firefighters in different age ranges to explore the relationship between age and injury risk. Compared injury rates and durations for firefighters and private-sector workers by age.

sections.title: Chapter 3: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Used matching methodology (similar to Peterson et al. 1998; Reville et al. 2001, 2002; Reville, Bhattacharya, and Weinstein 2001; Reville and Schoeni 2001; Reville, Seabury et al. 2005) to measure economic outcomes.  Linked California Disability Evaluation Unit (DEU) data with California Employment Development Department (EDD) earnings data.  Selected up to five workers at the same firm with similar pre-injury earnings and tenure as the injured worker. Calculated earnings loss and proportional earnings loss. Defined return-to-work (RTW) as the probability that injured workers report positive earnings compared to uninjured control workers.  Identified occupations using a search algorithm on text fields in the DEU data.

sections.title: Chapter 4: Analysis of Disability Rating Trends
sections.methods_summary: Used DEU data on permanent disability ratings (2000-2007), focusing on reports from qualified medical evaluator (QME) panels. Compared trends in average disability ratings by occupation, including and excluding zero ratings.  Restricted analysis to back injuries for comparison.

sections.title: Chapter 4: Apportionment and Disability Ratings
sections.methods_summary: Used DEU data to examine the impact of apportionment on disability ratings, focusing on back injuries and other injuries.  Measured frequency of apportionment and severity of its impact on disability ratings.

sections.title: Chapter 5: Study of Existing Work on the Use and Effectiveness of Chiropractic Care and Physical Therapy - Methods
sections.methods_summary: Performed a systematic literature review of eight high-quality journals in MEDLINE using specific search terms related to treatment, injury, and outcomes.  Analyzed Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS) data (2002-2007) to estimate average utilization rates for DC and PT services, comparing rates for individuals with MSD injuries and workers' compensation status. Reviewed literature on the effectiveness of DC and PT treatments, focusing on health outcomes, RTW, and cost-effectiveness.

sections.title: Chapter 5: MEPS Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Combined MEPS full-year consolidated and medical-condition files (2002-2007). Included individuals with injuries and identifiable ICD-9 codes who visited a chiropractor or PT.  Calculated utilization rates and the proportion exceeding 24 visits, segmented by injury type and workers' compensation status.

sections.title: Chapter 5: Chiropractic and Physical-Therapy Effectiveness Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Reviewed literature on the effectiveness of DC and PT treatments, focusing on study type, sample size, outcome measures, and incremental results.  Prioritized RCTs and observational studies with strong methodologies, particularly those evaluating long-term care.  Evaluated evidence on health outcomes, RTW, and cost-effectiveness.

sections.title: Chapter 5: Summary of Utilization and Effectiveness Analyses
sections.methods_summary: Summarized findings on utilization and effectiveness of DC and PT treatments.  Compared findings with ACOEM recommendations and discussed implications for the impact of the 24-visit cap on firefighters.

sections.title: Chapter 5: Empirical Analysis of the Impact of the Medical Reforms
sections.methods_summary: Used matched DEU and EDD data to analyze employment outcomes two years after injury.  Performed descriptive analysis comparing relative employment ratios and earnings losses over time by year of injury and injury type.  Estimated multivariate regression models to isolate the impact of reforms, controlling for age, injury severity (using quintiles of disability ratings), pre-injury wages, and control worker employment.  Used a difference-in-differences approach comparing back injuries to other injury types for firefighters.

sections.title: Appendix: Multivariate Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Estimated a linear probability model to predict the likelihood of working in quarter 8 after injury.  Included variables for worker characteristics, post-reform status, and quarter of injury.  Used quintiles of disability ratings to capture injury severity.  Used a difference-in-differences specification comparing back injuries to other less-affected injury types.  Estimated heteroskedasticity-consistent standard errors.

analysis.sample_description: The study used various datasets including BLS injury data (2003-2007), California DEU data (2000-2007), EDD earnings data, and MEPS data (2002-2007).  The samples included firefighters, police officers, corrections officers, teachers, construction workers, and laborers.  Specific sample sizes varied by dataset and analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved descriptive statistics, comparisons of means and medians, trend analysis, and multivariate regression modeling to assess the impact of workers' compensation reforms on firefighters' injury rates, employment outcomes, and disability ratings.

sections.title: Chapter 5: The Design of Measures That Link Performance to Incentives - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This chapter details the methodology used to analyze performance measures within Performance-Based Accountability Systems (PBAS).  The analysis explores the available options for designing measures (e.g., focusing on outputs, inputs, processes, or structures; using continuous scales or categories; focusing on current or change over time; using single, composite, or multiple measures; including incentivized and non-incentivized measures).  It then examines six factors influencing the choice of measures in the studied PBASs: feasibility, availability, cost, alignment with goals, resistance to manipulation, and understandability. The analysis is based on a qualitative review of nine PBAS cases across five sectors (child care, education, healthcare, public health emergency preparedness, and transportation).

sections.title: Chapter 6: Implementation and Monitoring - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This chapter examines the implementation process of PBASs, drawing on literature review and case studies of nine PBASs across five sectors.  It identifies common pitfalls (lack of experience, unrealistic timelines, complexity, communication failures, stakeholder resistance) and strategies for successful implementation (leveraging existing infrastructure, incremental implementation, pilot testing, effective communication, stakeholder engagement, formative evaluation). The methodology relies on qualitative analysis of case studies and a review of relevant literature.

sections.title: Chapter 8: Motivating and Improving System Evaluation - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This chapter explores the reasons for limited PBAS evaluation and proposes strategies for improvement.  The methodology involves a qualitative analysis of the reasons for limited evaluation (political climate, evaluation as a sign of failure, stakeholder comfort with status quo, evaluation challenges). It then suggests strategies to improve evaluation (reframing PBAS as one of several options, embedding evaluation in implementation, developmentally appropriate designs, realistic timelines, sufficient expertise, external funding, improved design elements).

sections.title: Chapter 9: Conclusions - Methodology Summary
sections.methods_summary: This chapter summarizes the findings from a cross-sectoral analysis of nine PBAS cases across five sectors. The methodology involved a literature review, development of an analytical framework, a workshop with stakeholders, and analysis of sector-specific empirical results to identify cross-sector principles.  The analysis is primarily qualitative, drawing on case studies and existing research to identify common themes and challenges in PBAS design, implementation, and evaluation.

analysis.sample_description: Nine PBAS cases across five sectors: child care, education, healthcare, public health emergency preparedness (PHEP), and transportation.
analysis.analysis_approach: Cross-sectoral comparison of case studies to identify common themes, challenges, and best practices in PBAS design, implementation, and evaluation. Qualitative analysis of existing research and data.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research approach included a broad review of literature related to performance measurement and accountability, the development of an analytic framework, a 1.5-day integrative workshop examining various features of PBASs, and analysis of sector-specific empirical results and identification of cross-sector principles.  The goal was to derive principles with general applicability.

analysis.sample_description: Nine PBASs were examined, drawn from five sectors: child care, education, health care, public health emergency preparedness (PHEP), and transportation.  The selection was guided by practical considerations (RAND's existing expertise) and theoretical considerations (inclusion of public and private sectors, and a case with measurement challenges).
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis of sector-specific empirical results and identification of cross-sector principles to derive generally applicable principles.

sections.title: Analysis of Prototyping Benefits
sections.methods_summary: The analysis combines a review of existing literature (case studies and a statistical analysis from the early 1990s) on the effects of prototyping on weapon system acquisition.  The analysis focuses on cost growth, schedule slip, and performance outcomes, comparing prototyping and non-prototyping programs.  The limitations of available data and the influence of factors other than prototyping are acknowledged.

sections.title: Analysis of Defense Acquisition Workforce
sections.methods_summary: This section analyzes data from the DoD Civilian Personnel Master File from the Defense Manpower Data Center.  The analysis focuses on the number of DoD civilians in occupational series related to acquisition activities, comparing trends from 1980 to 2007.  It contrasts these trends with the official DoD Acquisition Workforce count. The analysis addresses limitations in data availability, particularly regarding contractor workforce data and inconsistencies in the definition of the acquisition workforce over time.

sections.title: Analysis of Competition in Defense Procurement
sections.methods_summary: This section uses historical data from multiple studies (spanning 30 years) on the introduction of competition into ongoing sole-source production programs.  A RAND-developed Required Cost Reduction (RCR) methodology is applied to determine the likelihood of cost savings from competition, considering factors like non-recurring costs, cost improvement slopes, and production quantities.  A spreadsheet model is used to illustrate the RCR methodology with varying assumptions. The analysis compares RCR ratios to historical savings data to assess the reasonableness of competitive strategies in different scenarios.

analysis.sample_description: The studies analyzed include various weapon systems, subsystems, and components across different time periods.  The acquisition workforce analysis uses DoD-wide civilian personnel data, focusing on acquisition-related occupational series. The competition analysis uses data from multiple studies of weapon systems, subsystems, and components where competition was introduced into sole-source production.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves comparing prototyping and non-prototyping programs, contrasting trends in workforce data, and applying a quantitative model (RCR methodology) to assess the likelihood of cost savings from competition under different conditions.  The analysis also incorporates qualitative assessments from case studies and acknowledges limitations in data and methodological approaches.

sections.title: Survey Development, Implementation, and Deployment
sections.methods_summary: A web-based survey was developed using an established procedure at RAND Europe.  The survey was implemented using RAND Europe’s in-house survey tool, ClassApps.com SelectSurvey.NETv4.019.001. Internal testing was conducted, followed by discussion with industry representatives.  The survey was then deployed in a password-protected form. Data was collated and exported for analysis.

sections.title: Modelling Critical Competences
sections.methods_summary: A three-stage process was used to determine if a skill was critical to the military fixed wing programme and primarily or solely sustained by the sector.  Stage 1: Analysis of Section 3 (Skill Criticality) survey results to calculate mean and standard deviation of responses.  Stage 2: Two-round Delphi exercise with the project team to assess whether the skill was key to the military fixed wing programme. Stage 3: Another two-round Delphi exercise to determine if the skill could be transferred from outside the military.

sections.title: Research Methods Summary
sections.methods_summary: A range of research methods were employed to meet the study objectives.  Qualitative information was obtained through semi-structured interviews with MOD key suppliers, industry representative groups, stakeholders in the Department for Business, Innovation and Skills, and key personnel within the MOD. Quantitative and qualitative information was obtained from key suppliers through an extensive survey.  Four different demand scenarios provided by the MOD were used to assess future sustainment of key competences.

sections.title: Section Selection for Survey
sections.methods_summary: Participants selected which sections of the survey they wished to complete.

sections.title: Modelling Future Demand
sections.methods_summary: A model was developed to highlight potential mismatches between supply and demand of skills.  The model used MOD fixed wing demand scenarios, industrial survey results, and Delphi exercises to calculate coverage for key competences.  Continuity and coherence criteria were applied, and traffic light colour coding was used to indicate future sustainment.

analysis.sample_description: 12 of the MOD’s key suppliers in the military fixed wing and related sectors participated in the survey.  The survey covered approximately 29,000 technical staff who work exclusively or primarily on military fixed wing activities.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis included descriptive statistics from the survey. Qualitative analysis was used to identify skills sustained primarily by MOD programmes, skill transferability between domains, and links between design, production, and in-service skills.  A traffic light system was used to assess future skill sustainment based on coverage, continuity, and coherence criteria.

sections.title: Data Collection and Description of AQI Financial Records
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of two sets of captured AQI financial documents: 'Travelstar' documents (provincial administration, 2005-2006) and nine documents from Tuzliyah (western sector, September-December 2006).  The analysis describes the organization, bureaucracy, division of labor, financial flows, revenue-generating activities, expenditures, and administrative decision-making within AQI based on these documents.

sections.title: Economic Analysis of AQI Compensation and Risk
sections.methods_summary: Comparison of AQI members' salaries with reported income levels of Anbari households from available survey data (2004, 2005, 2007, 2008).  Comparison of the risk of death for AQI members with that of the broader Anbari population using data from AQI documents and the Iraq Body Count (IBC) project. Calculation of expected lifetime earnings for AQI members and Anbari civilians, considering different assumptions about income loss upon death and the impact of discount rates.

sections.title: Statistical Analysis of Expenditures and Attacks
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of the relationship between AQI spending (transfers from Anbar administrative emir to sectors) and attack levels using data from the U.S. Department of Defense's Significant Activities III (SIGACTS) database.  Regression analysis at both monthly and weekly levels, incorporating indicator variables for sectors, time trends, and five-week periods to account for unobserved variables that might influence attack levels.  Calculation of the cost per attack based on regression results.

analysis.sample_description: Two sets of captured AQI financial documents from Anbar province, Iraq, covering 2005-2006.  Data supplemented with information from U.S. military analysts, operators, and the SIGACTS III database.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive analysis of AQI's financial operations, economic comparison of AQI compensation and risk with civilian counterparts, and statistical analysis to determine the relationship between AQI spending and attack levels.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Thought experiment comparing pre- and post-reorganization scenarios in asbestos cases, assuming consistent jury verdicts and varying trust payments.  Analysis explores potential impact on total plaintiff compensation and payments by solvent defendants.

sections.title: Data Collection and Expert Interviews
sections.methods_summary: Interviews with 20 defense attorneys, 11 plaintiff attorneys, and 6 trust managers or counsel. Review of state statutes, court rules, and appellate opinions.

sections.title: Focus and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative analysis of state tort law and civil practice rules in six states (California, Illinois, New York, Pennsylvania, Texas, and West Virginia) selected for their history of asbestos filings or innovative approaches.  Focus on the interaction of state law with asbestos bankruptcy trusts, exploring potential effects on plaintiff compensation and payments by solvent defendants. Analysis is descriptive, not normative, due to unavailability of quantitative data on compensation trends.

analysis.sample_description: Six states (California, Illinois, New York, Pennsylvania, Texas, and West Virginia) selected for their high volume of asbestos filings or innovative legal approaches.  Interviews included plaintiff and defense attorneys and trust managers/counsel.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive analysis of legal rules and procedures, exploring potential impacts through hypothetical scenarios comparing pre- and post-reorganization outcomes.  Focus on the linkages between trust payments and tort awards, considering information sharing, setoffs, indirect claims, and trust payment limitations.

sections.title: Research Approach and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a multi-method research design including a literature review, review of documents and secondary data, on-site interviews, school visits and observations, a teacher survey, modeling, and geographic information system (GIS) mapping.

sections.title: Forecasting Model Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A causal forecasting model was built using spreadsheets to project future student enrollment.  The model incorporated historical enrollment data, assumptions about population growth, completion rates of basic education, and gender parity.  Transition probabilities between grades were derived from historical data.  The model allowed for the creation of different scenarios based on varying assumptions.

sections.title: Analysis of School Construction Alternatives
sections.methods_summary: The analysis involved reviewing challenges and benefits of prefabricated school construction.  Data on existing schools and construction methods were used.  Cost estimates were obtained from prefabricated school providers.  A survey of case studies, trade publications, and informal discussions with U.S. designers and construction management firms was conducted to estimate construction costs.

analysis.sample_description: The teacher survey included 2,904 teachers in 226 schools randomly selected in proportion to enrollment in 11 randomly selected districts.  The sample covered all three governorates, urban and rural schools, and primary, intermediate, and secondary levels of education.  Responses were weighted to reflect the teacher population by level and governorate.  The study also included 36 interviews with various stakeholders and visits to 16 schools.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data analysis involved examining student enrollment trends, school capacity, teacher characteristics, curriculum content, instructional time, and student performance.  The forecasting model projected future enrollment under different scenarios.  GIS mapping was used to visualize school distribution and assess feasibility of proposed actions.  Comparative cost analysis was used to evaluate different school construction methods.  Case studies were reviewed to inform recommendations.

sections.title: Study Organization and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study draws on primary and secondary sources and over two dozen author interviews in Israel, as well as in-person and telephone conversations with regional experts in Washington and abroad.  The Israel interviews included high-level officials in the military, the prime minister’s office, and the foreign ministry, as well as former defense and intelligence officials.  Also included were nongovernmental experts, including academics, journalists, and think tank analysts.

analysis.sample_description: Over two dozen interviews with high-level Israeli officials (military, prime minister's office, foreign ministry, former defense and intelligence officials), nongovernmental experts (academics, journalists, think tank analysts), and regional experts in Washington and abroad.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of primary and secondary sources and interview data to understand the evolution, nature, and implications of the Israeli-Iranian rivalry and to offer policy prescriptions for managing it.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach.  Qualitative data were gathered through semi-structured interviews with stakeholders (self-insured employers, payers, providers, attorneys, regulators, judges, and researchers).  A literature review of relevant reports and regulations was also conducted. Quantitative data analysis involved examining administrative data from California's Office of Statewide Health Planning and Development (OSHPD) on inpatient hospital services, ambulatory surgery, and emergency room services, as well as medical service data from the Workers' Compensation Information System (WCIS) for 2007.

sections.title: Organization of This Monograph
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines the structure of the monograph, not the research methods themselves.  It describes the content of each chapter, including the topics covered and the data used.

analysis.sample_description: Stakeholders involved in the California workers' compensation medical treatment system, including self-insured employers, payers, providers, applicants’ attorneys, state regulators, WC appeals judges, and researchers.  The quantitative data analysis used data from California's OSHPD and WCIS for the year 2007.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative data from interviews were analyzed thematically. Quantitative data from OSHPD and WCIS were analyzed descriptively and comparatively, with specific methods detailed in appendices.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach.  It involved reviewing existing reports and databases on the coal-based electricity-generation industry, conducting 25 structured interviews with industry stakeholders (utilities, AEC/EPC firms, OEMs, material suppliers, labor organizations, industry associations), and collecting and analyzing data to validate or verify concerns raised in the interviews.  The interviews focused on industry concerns, key suppliers, global market impact, project management issues, regulatory impacts, workforce concerns, and the uniqueness of coal-fired electricity generation technologies.

analysis.sample_description: 25 structured interviews with a cross-section of industry stakeholders: major utilities, leading AEC/EPC firms, OEMs, critical-material firms, labor associations, industry trade and research organizations, and engineering and workforce associations.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative data from government, industry, and stakeholder organizations were used to describe the existing coal EGU fleet and identify key domestic and international companies in the industrial base.  The analysis examined historical patterns of mergers, acquisitions, and new starts, and assessed workforce trends at an aggregate level. The study aimed to verify or validate issues and concerns raised in the interviews using objective empirical evidence.  The availability of data constrained the ability to definitively support some concerns, but common themes among stakeholders, existing reports, and databases provided confidence in the findings.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Literature review, interviews with policy leaders, health practitioners, patients, and government officials, data collection and analysis of health resources, services, and conditions, projection of future demand using traditional methods and population growth estimates, GIS mapping of PHCs, policy analysis using a modified Delphi technique to rate policy options by importance and feasibility.

analysis.sample_description: Not explicitly described, but data was collected from various sources including policy leaders, health practitioners, patients, and government officials across the Kurdistan Region.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data analysis to project future health care utilization, including a base model and three scenarios.  Policy analysis used a modified Delphi technique to rank policy options by importance and feasibility.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The report drew on available literature and extensive interviews with Koreans and Americans involved in or knowledgeable about the U.S.-ROK security relationship.  Interviews included Korean government officials, military personnel, security and foreign policy specialists, retired officers, and former high-level officials.  U.S. interviews included key foreign policy and defense officials in Washington, as well as U.S. officers, officials, and analysts serving in South Korea. Seminars were also conducted at the New Asia Research Institute (NARI) and the Korean National Defense University (KNDU) in Seoul.

analysis.sample_description: The interviews included a range of Korean and American individuals with expertise in the U.S.-ROK security relationship, encompassing government officials, military personnel, academics, and other experts.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report adopts an "inside-out" orientation, focusing on the nature of the U.S.-ROK relationship itself and assessing its strengths and vulnerabilities.  It gives greater attention to the situation inside South Korea and focuses recommendations primarily on U.S. policy, while also addressing centrifugal forces within the U.S. and offering suggestions for South Korea.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Uses datasets of simulated behavior to tabulate AC retention and RC participation and compute policy cost.  Outputs include graphs of AC retention by year of service, RC participation by year of active-plus-reserve service, and various cost measures.  Model fit is assessed using figures comparing actual and simulated AC retention and RC participation.

sections.title: Data and Methods Summary
sections.methods_summary: Uses WEX data for AC entrants in FY 1990 and FY 1991, augmented with data on AC, RC, and civilian pay.  Employs a stochastic dynamic programming model (DPM) of AC retention and RC participation, estimating parameters using WEX data.  The estimated model is applied to simulate AC retention and RC participation under current and alternative compensation policies.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The primary dataset is the Work Experience File (WEX), augmented with data on AC, RC, and civilian pay.  A dynamic retention model (DRM), a stochastic dynamic programming model, is used to model AC retention and RC participation decisions.  The model incorporates AC, RC, and civilian pay, retirement benefits, individual preferences, random shocks, and switching costs.  Parameters are estimated using maximum likelihood estimation with a BHHH algorithm.  A Halton sequence is used for Monte Carlo integration to handle unobserved heterogeneity in tastes.  Simulations are conducted using a synthetic population of 10,000 individuals to project AC participation, RC affiliation, RC participation, and personnel costs under alternative compensation policies.

analysis.sample_description: Samples of 25,000 individuals who entered active duty in FY 1990-1991, tracked through FY 2009.  Analysis focuses on prior-service reservists (those with prior active duty service).
analysis.analysis_approach: A dynamic stochastic programming model is used to simulate the effects of different compensation policies on active component retention, reserve component participation, and costs.  The model accounts for individual preferences, uncertainty, and the dynamic nature of career choices.  Results are compared to a baseline scenario representing the current compensation system.

sections.title: Study Purpose, Scope, and Approaches
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the study's purpose, scope, and data sources.  It states that the study reviewed relevant literature and conducted analyses using the Mexican Health and Aging Study (MHAS) 2001 data, supplemented with other sources as needed. The MHAS is described as a nationally representative panel survey of Mexicans born before 1951.

analysis.sample_description: The Mexican Health and Aging Study (MHAS) 2001 data, a nationally representative panel survey of Mexicans born before 1951.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study used the MHAS data to analyze various dimensions of the state of older people in Mexico, including social vulnerability, socioeconomic status, social security programs, private savings instruments, health care provision, income sources, and the role of remittances and family transfers.  The analysis also involved comparisons with other countries and projections of future trends.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Literature review and analysis of data from the Estudio Nacional sobre Salud y Envejecimiento en México (ENASEM), a nationally representative longitudinal study of Mexicans born before 1951, with data collected in 2001 and 2003.  The 2001 data was primarily used.  The study also supplemented ENASEM data with other sources where relevant.

analysis.sample_description: The primary data source was the Estudio Nacional sobre Salud y Envejecimiento en México (ENASEM), a nationally representative longitudinal study of Mexicans born before 1951. Data from 2001 was primarily used.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data analysis of the ENASEM dataset, supplemented by other sources where appropriate.  The report does not detail specific statistical techniques.

sections.title: ASAP Architecture Control and Learning
sections.methods_summary: The control system uses principles of cybernetics, augmented process maps with quantitative and qualitative performance metrics, and three types of electronic agents (processing agents, automated control agents, and control assistance agents).  Learning and adaptation strategies include automated learning (statistical training using linked data sets and significance statements), manual adaptation processes (modifying data collection and analysis tests), and periodic environmental reviews.

sections.title: Roles of Human Analysts and Automated Agents
sections.methods_summary: Describes the complementary roles of human analysts (providing meaning and context) and automated agents (detecting out-of-the-ordinary signals, linking data, detecting trends, and facilitating follow-up).  Emphasizes the importance of human judgment and the need for organizational support of risk-taking and learning from both successes and failures.

sections.title: Finding Dots with Rules
sections.methods_summary: Describes the use of rules for identifying out-of-the-ordinary activities (dots), including single-point analysis, trend analysis, and multipoint analysis.  Introduces the concept of contextual rules, which dynamically adjust the significance of observations based on context.

sections.title: Systems Related to the ASAP Architecture
sections.methods_summary: This section discusses existing and emerging systems that could be used to implement parts of an ASAP system.  It mentions several systems and their potential roles in data interception, relationship identification, hypothesis generation, and analyst support.  The systems mentioned include COUGAAR, Intelliseek, IBM's federated information systems, NORA, Attensity's EWR, Stratify's Discovery System, Mohomine's MohoClassifier, Tacit Knowledge System's Activenet, AHEAD, Analyst's Notebook, MetaCarta's Geographic Text Search Appliance, and SRI International's SEAS.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample is not explicitly defined, but the methods focus on analyzing existing data streams from various intelligence and security sources, including intelligence networks, reports of out-of-the-ordinary behavior, data from critical industries, open-source information, and (with probable cause) commercial databases.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach is a hybrid of automated and human analysis. Automated agents identify out-of-the-ordinary signals (dots), link them, generate hypotheses, and prioritize results. Human analysts provide context, interpret results, and make decisions based on the automated analysis.

sections.title: Health Care Guideline Development Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Four basic steps: (1) topic selection (based on cost, numbers, and practice variation); (2) selection of the decisionmaking group (balanced representation among professions, generalists and specialists, etc.); (3) evidence collection (literature review, evaluation of study quality, synthesis of findings, expert opinion); (4) decisionmaking process (consensus development method, potentially modified Delphi method).

sections.title: Risk Adjustment Methodology in Health Care
sections.methods_summary: Five steps: (1) agree on the outcome of interest; (2) identify predictors of the outcome; (3) select risk factors to adjust for; (4) operationalize these risk factors (considering data accuracy, completeness, and availability, and medical meaningfulness); (5) combine risk factors into a statistical regression model (logistic regression for dichotomous outcomes).  The model's beta coefficients are used as weights to predict expected outcomes, which are then compared to actual outcomes at the provider level.

sections.title: Methodology for Analyzing Health Care Report Cards
sections.methods_summary: The chapter analyzes existing literature and reports on the effects of health care report cards and public data release on health care organizations, physicians, and consumers.  The analysis draws on various sources, including studies examining changes in provider behavior, market share, and consumer choices in response to publicly available performance data.

sections.title: Study Design and Selection of Accountability Models
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach.  Recommendations were solicited from educational researchers and colleagues studying organizations in other fields.  A review of the education literature surrounding the No Child Left Behind Act was also conducted. The final selection of accountability models aimed for relevance, interest, and diversity, including cases from manufacturing and service sectors.
