analysis.sample_description: The study examined five accountability models: Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award Program, Toyota Production System/Lean Manufacturing, Job Training Partnership Act/Workforce Investment Act, the legal profession, and aspects of the US health care system.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved describing each model, summarizing research on effectiveness, and drawing lessons for educators.  The analysis also involved comparing and contrasting the models to identify common themes and implications for educational accountability.

sections.title: Methodology: Employment and Wages Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Linear probability models and multinomial logit models were used to analyze employment transitions and their correlates.  Data from IFLS2 and IFLS3 were used. Individual sampling weights were applied, and standard errors were robust to clustering at the community level and heteroscedasticity.

sections.title: Methodology: Health Input Utilization
sections.methods_summary: Linear probability models were used to analyze healthcare facility usage. Data from IFLS2 and IFLS3 were used, with individual sampling weights and standard errors robust to clustering at the community level.

sections.title: Methodology: Health Service Delivery Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of health service provision and quality using data from IFLS2 and IFLS3.  Median prices and interquartile ranges were used to analyze service charges due to potential outliers.  Standard errors were robust to clustering at the community level.

sections.title: Methodology: Family Planning Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of contraceptive use trends using data from IFLS2 and IFLS3. Linear probability models were used to analyze correlates of contraceptive use. Individual sampling weights were used, and standard errors were robust to clustering at the community level.

sections.title: Methodology: Family Planning Services Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of family planning service provision and charges using data from IFLS2 and IFLS3. Standard errors were robust to clustering at the community level.

sections.title: Methodology: Social Safety Net Programme Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of social safety net programs using individual, household, and community-level data from IFLS3. Linear probability models were used to analyze program participation.  Household sampling weights were used, and standard errors were robust to clustering at the community level.

sections.title: Methodology: IFLS Data Weighting
sections.methods_summary: Weights were calculated for IFLS2 and IFLS3 to match household and individual sample proportions to those in the SUSENAS Core Surveys for 1997 and 2000.  Matching was done by province and urban/rural area for households, and by detailed age groups by gender for individuals.

sections.title: Methodology: Poverty and Per Capita Expenditure Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Household data weighted by household size were used to calculate poverty rates.  Poverty lines were deflated to December 2000 Jakarta rupiah values. Linear probability models were used to analyze correlates of poverty, with standard errors adjusted for clustering at the enumeration area.  Tests for stochastic dominance were conducted using the Davidson and Duclos (2000) method.

sections.title: Methodology: Subjective Welfare Measures
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of subjective welfare measures using data from IFLS3.  Regression analysis was used to compare subjective scores with correlates of poverty and pce. Individual sampling weights were used, and standard errors were robust to clustering at the community level.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the Indonesia Family Life Surveys (IFLS), specifically IFLS2 (1997) and IFLS3 (2000), and a smaller IFLS2+ (1998) subsample.  The IFLS samples were weighted to match the SUSENAS Core Surveys for 1997 and 2000.  The sample includes households and individuals, with various demographic breakdowns (age, gender, location).  Facility data from IFLS2 and IFLS3 are also used.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a variety of statistical techniques, including linear probability models, multinomial logit models, OLS regressions, and tests for stochastic dominance.  The analysis focuses on changes in welfare indicators between 1997 and 2000, examining both objective (pce, poverty rates) and subjective measures of well-being.  The analysis also explores the correlates of various outcomes and the impact of the 1997-98 financial crisis.

sections.title: Demand: Assessing Attackers' Information Requirements - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of postulated attacks on critical infrastructure, military, and cultural targets.  Attacks evaluated based on plausible attacker motivations, historical attack methods, weapon capabilities, and modern targeting techniques (remote sensing, GIS, GPS). Quantitative evaluation of likely damage.

sections.title: Supply: Assessing the Significance of Publicly Available Geospatial Information - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Three-part methodology: 1. Structured survey of federal geospatial data sources (examining >5000 websites). 2. Sampling of geospatial datasets from federal sources (629 datasets selected based on likelihood of containing sensitive information). 3. Sampling of alternative non-federal geospatial information sources (>2000 websites examined, >300 sources sampled).  Analysis involved ranking usefulness, availability of alternatives, and significance (combining usefulness and uniqueness).

sections.title: Chapter 2: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Postulated attacks on various targets (critical infrastructure, military, cultural) to assess information needs.  Rationales based on plausible motivations, historical attack methods, weapon proliferation, and modern targeting techniques. Quantitative damage assessment using conventional weapon effects techniques (Joint Munitions Effectiveness Manual).

sections.title: Chapter 3: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Three-part methodology: 1. Structured survey of federal geospatial data sources (>5000 federal websites examined, 69 federal agencies). 2. Interviews and group discussions with federal, state, and local experts. 3. Sampling of non-federal geospatial data sources (>2000 non-federal websites examined, >300 sources sampled).

analysis.sample_description: The study examined a sample of 629 federal geospatial datasets and more than 300 non-federal sources.  The federal datasets were selected based on their likelihood of containing sensitive information about U.S. critical sites. The non-federal sample was selected to represent the range of alternative sources.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved ranking the usefulness and uniqueness of geospatial datasets.  Usefulness was assessed based on the potential attacker's needs. Uniqueness was determined by examining the availability of similar information from alternative sources. Significance was a combined measure of usefulness and uniqueness.

sections.title: Overall Assessment and Policy Recommendations
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines the overall approach to analyzing the U.S.-China military relationship.  It mentions examining the goals of U.S. policy, assessing the benefits of the current relationship, and proposing a revised policy.  The analysis involves reviewing the history of the relationship and considering constraints and limitations imposed by both sides.  The primary methods appear to be qualitative analysis of existing data (historical documents, reports, interviews) and a case study approach to examine specific issues (intellectual property rights, arms control).

sections.title: The U.S. Debate over U.S.-China Military Relations
sections.methods_summary: This section analyzes the U.S. debate on military relations with China. The methodology involves examining four key issues: potential risks to U.S. national security, potential benefits to the U.S., the ability of the U.S. to influence China, and reciprocity/transparency. The analysis relies on qualitative data (interviews, reports, policy documents) and quantitative data (tables showing the number of visits to U.S. and Chinese facilities).  The analysis approach is primarily qualitative, interpreting existing data and assessing the validity of arguments presented in the debate.

sections.title: Chinese Views of Military Relationships
sections.methods_summary: This section explores Chinese perspectives on military relations. The methodology involves analyzing a study by the Center for Naval Analyses (CNA) to understand China's objectives in conducting military relations.  The analysis relies heavily on interpreting the CNA report and other secondary sources to understand Chinese motivations and goals. The approach is primarily qualitative, focusing on interpreting existing research and policy statements.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample is not explicitly defined, but it draws on a wide range of sources, including interviews with experts, government reports, and published research. The interviews are anonymous.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach is primarily qualitative, interpreting existing data and assessing the validity of arguments.  Quantitative data is used in a supplementary role, such as in the tables showing the number of visits to U.S. and Chinese military facilities.

sections.title: Study Design and Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: The study uses data from the Los Angeles Family and Neighborhood Survey (L.A.FANS), a random sample of 3,010 households in 65 Los Angeles neighborhoods interviewed in 2000 and 2001.  Standardized tests were administered to children and mothers.  The study focuses on two dimensions of children's home environment: literacy environment and parenting practices, and their relationship to school readiness measures.  Statistical techniques are used to disentangle the effects of social characteristics on school readiness.

sections.title: Data Collection: Chapter 2 (Home Literacy Environment)
sections.methods_summary: Mothers were interviewed about their children's literacy environment (number of children's books, frequency of reading to the child, TV watching time, library visits, and discussions about TV programs).

sections.title: Data Collection: Chapter 3 (Reading and Math Skills)
sections.methods_summary: Preschoolers (ages 3-5) took standardized reading and math tests (picture-word identification and problem-solving). Mothers also took a standardized reading test. Scores were normed and categorized as high, middle, or low.

sections.title: Analysis Methods: Chapter 3 (Reading and Math Skills)
sections.methods_summary: Statistical techniques were used to examine the effects of socioeconomic characteristics (mother's education, neighborhood poverty, immigrant status, ethnicity) and home literacy activities on reading and math scores, holding other factors constant.  The analysis included mothers' reading comprehension test scores.

sections.title: Data Collection: Chapter 4 (Parenting Practices)
sections.methods_summary: Data on parental warmth and discipline were collected using questions from standard parenting measures.  The focus was on children aged 1-5 years.

sections.title: Analysis Methods: Chapter 5 (Well-being and Behavior)
sections.methods_summary: Statistical techniques were used to examine the effects of socioeconomic characteristics and parenting behavior (warmth and discipline) on children's behavior problems (sad/anxious and aggressive), holding other factors constant.  Indexes of warmth and discipline were created using principal components analysis.

sections.title: Study Sample Description
sections.methods_summary: The study uses data from the Los Angeles Family and Neighborhood Survey (LAFANS), which included 3,010 households.  The analysis focuses on households with children from birth to age five (1,720 households, 1,086 children).  Sampling weights were used to make the sample representative of Los Angeles County.

sections.title: Measures Used
sections.methods_summary: The study used the Home Observation for Measurement of the Environment (HOME) to assess home literacy environment and parenting practices, the Behavior Problem Index (BPI) to measure social and emotional development, and the Woodcock-Johnson-Revised Test of Achievement (WJ-R ACH) to measure language, reading, and math skills.  The WJ-R ACH scores were norm-referenced.

analysis.sample_description: A random sample of 3,010 households in 65 Los Angeles neighborhoods, with an oversample of households with children and poor neighborhoods. The analysis focuses on 1,086 children aged birth to five years.
analysis.analysis_approach: Statistical techniques were used to analyze the relationships between socioeconomic characteristics, home environment, parenting practices, and children's school readiness (basic skills and behavior).  These techniques included controlling for confounding variables and creating composite indexes using principal components analysis.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Review of published and unpublished analyses by government organizations, international organizations, NGOs, scientific literature, and data from the Health Inforum website. Interviews with Palestinian, Israeli, and international stakeholders knowledgeable about the Palestinian health system were conducted in person and by phone.  No new quantitative data were collected.

sections.title: Appendix 7.B: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Review of published and unpublished literature on Palestinian health. Interviews with stakeholders conducted in person and by phone in Palestine and Israel (except Gaza, which was closed to foreigners during the study period).  A two-day meeting was held at RAND's Washington, D.C. office. Interview questions were open-ended.  Draft chapter provided to participants for comment.

sections.title: Appendix 8.A: Methods for Estimating Education Costs
sections.methods_summary: Used UNESCO data on education spending per student as a percentage of GNI per capita for selected countries.  Adjusted these figures to account for Palestine's high population growth, depleted capital stock, and differences in the transition paths of salary levels and GNI per capita.  Used PA estimates of projected enrollments through 2010, supplemented by a youth population growth figure of 4.5 percent per year for 2010–2014.

sections.title: Appendix 7.B: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Data from published and unpublished sources (government organizations, international organizations, NGOs, scientific literature). Interviews with stakeholders (in-person and phone).  Coordination with EU health sector review.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Data from published and unpublished sources (government organizations, international organizations, NGOs, scientific literature). Interviews with stakeholders (in-person and phone).  Coordination with EU health sector review.

analysis.sample_description: The health section involved interviews with a large number of stakeholders in Palestine and Israel, but the sample was not representative or exhaustive.  The education section does not describe a sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative analysis.  The health section used a macro-level approach focusing on key institutions and programs. The education section used a framework of access, quality, and delivery to assess the system. The economics section used a growth accounting model. The water section used a modified version of the West Bank Water Management Analysis Tool developed by CH2M HILL.  The internal security section used analogies based on recent experience in Iraq.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Analysis considered essentials of a successful state (institutions, security structures), demographic, economic, and environmental resources, and factors limiting resource use.  Drew on empirical data to describe success requirements, identify alternative policies, and analyze consequences. Estimated financial costs for the first decade of independence (in constant 2003 U.S. dollars), noting that costing methodology varied by question and data availability.  Estimates were not based on detailed cost analyses but intended to suggest the scale of required financial assistance.

sections.title: Economic Development Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Examined economic development trajectories (2005-2019), focusing on sustaining per-capita income growth. Considered prerequisites (security, governance, territory, resources, infrastructure) and critical issues (transaction costs, resources, trade regime, labor access to Israel).  Developed four scenarios based on geographic contiguity and economic integration with Israel, estimating growth levels under each scenario with specific international investment levels. Identified best-practice policies to encourage economic development.

sections.title: Costs and Direct Economic Benefits Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Focused on construction costs for transportation (rail, highway, boulevard roads, stations) and housing for immigrants.  Excluded land acquisition costs. Costs reported in nominal U.S. dollars.  Estimated potential construction jobs by dividing projected construction spending by gross construction output per worker from neighboring Arab states (Jordan and Egypt).

analysis.sample_description: Not explicitly defined; analysis focuses on a future Palestinian state and draws on existing data and projections.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative analysis combining empirical data, cost estimations, scenario modeling, and policy recommendations.

sections.title: Cost Estimation Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Cost of a peace-enabling force in Palestinian territory is estimated using a top-down approach, based on the costs of the U.S. and NATO operation in Kosovo.  The average per-soldier costs for military and civilian personnel, personnel support, operating support, and transportation are calculated from U.S. Department of Defense data and used as a baseline for estimating the cost of peace-enabling forces in Palestinian territory.  Two force sizes (2,500 and 7,000 soldiers) are considered.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable.  The analysis uses existing data from the Kosovo operation as a basis for cost estimation.
analysis.analysis_approach: Top-down approach using existing data from a comparable operation (Kosovo Force) to estimate costs for different force sizes.

sections.title: Methodology: Simulation Modeling
sections.methods_summary: Simulation modeling using the EnMasse model to explore the impact of varying operational and performance parameters (transportation time, removal rates, initial spares deployments) on CIRF performance for F100-100 engines and ALQ-131 ECM pods.  The model simulates daily spares performance over a 90-day deployment, with the primary measure of effectiveness being spares availability.

sections.title: Simulation Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Modified EnMasse model to include allocation decisions under centralized ownership, inventory storage at the CIRF, and differentiation between F-15 and F-16 engines.  MRC scenarios for F100-229 and F100-220, and a steady-state scenario for F100-220, were simulated under both unit and centralized ownership policies. Spares availability was the primary measure of effectiveness.  METRIC algorithm used for spares allocation in the centralized ownership scenario.

analysis.sample_description: The simulations used data from the CIRF test to parameterize models of F100-100 engines and ALQ-131 ECM pods, representing scenarios involving F-15 and F-16 aircraft deployments.  Specific numbers of aircraft and spares were defined for each scenario.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved varying key parameters (transportation time, removal rates, initial spares deployment) in the simulation model to determine their impact on daily spares levels and overall system performance.  The goal was to identify a tradespace of support options that would maintain acceptable spares levels.

sections.title: Appendix B: Base Realignment and Closure History and Decisionmaking
sections.methods_summary: This section details the historical context of Base Realignment and Closure (BRAC) processes, including the legislative framework, decision-making structures, and selection criteria used in previous rounds.  It serves as background information for understanding the context of the case studies, rather than a methodology section in the traditional sense.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research employed a multiple case study design.  Four case studies were conducted, involving site visits, interviews with various stakeholders (faculty, administrators, sponsors, community leaders, etc.), and review of relevant documentation. Interview protocols were standardized across cases.  Data triangulation was attempted by verifying interview responses against available documents.  Findings generally reflect consensus responses from multiple interviewees; discrepancies were investigated further.

analysis.sample_description: Four DoD education and training (ET&D) institutions were selected as case studies based on discussions with the DoD Chancellor and his staff.  The selection aimed to represent different variables (student mix, size, infrastructure change scenarios), but the sample is not necessarily representative of all DoD ET&D institutions.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data and documents.  Findings are presented based on consensus responses from multiple interviewees, with efforts to address and resolve discrepancies.

sections.title: Data Sources and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources (Ingenix Inc. data from 25 Fortune 500 employers for 1999 and 2000, including detailed information on insurance eligibility, medical and pharmacy claims), study sample (56,840 primary beneficiaries age 45 to 64 continuously enrolled in an employer-provided plan with drug coverage for two years), data cleaning procedures, and the dependent and explanatory variables used in the analysis.  The primary statistical techniques employed include difference-in-differences analysis, ordinary least squares (OLS) regression (with logarithmic transformation of expenditures), negative binomial regression, and probit regression.  Both weighted and unweighted models were estimated, with standard errors adjusted for clustering within plans.  The analysis also included class-level analyses focusing on six high-cost therapeutic drug classes and drug-level analyses examining changes in market share when specific medications were moved between tiers.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consisted of 56,840 primary beneficiaries age 45 to 64 who were continuously enrolled in an employer-provided plan with drug coverage for two years.  The analysis compared seven plans that added a third tier in 2000 to 13 plans that did not change drug benefits during 1999-2000 (six two-tier and seven three-tier plans). Elderly beneficiaries (age 65+) were excluded due to data limitations.
analysis.analysis_approach: A difference-in-differences approach was used to compare changes in pharmacy costs and utilization between plans that added a third tier and those that did not.  Multivariate regression models were employed, with different model specifications (OLS, negative binomial, probit) depending on the dependent variable.  The models controlled for various patient, plan, and area characteristics.  Additional class-level and drug-level analyses were conducted to examine the effects across therapeutic classes and individual medications.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach combining literature reviews of public and government documents, interviews with government contractors and Army personnel, and data analysis of communication technologies' performance.  Due to the fluidity of future force concepts, the research also incorporated data from past Army digitization exercises, commercial device data, modeling and simulation estimates, and near-term Army plans and requirements.  The focus was on analyzing the operational architectures of the Stryker Brigade Combat Team and Future Combat System to identify key bandwidth consumers based on information type and transmission frequency.

analysis.sample_description: The study did not involve a human sample in the traditional sense.  Data was drawn from existing documents, simulations, and past military exercises related to the Stryker Brigade Combat Team and Future Combat System.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved identifying key bandwidth consumers within the studied systems, comparing current and near-term capabilities to projected needs, and evaluating potential methods for increasing bandwidth capacity.  This included analyzing the impact of various factors on network performance, such as routing efficiency, antenna technology, and node mobility.

sections.title: Technical Evaluations of the Methods of Sanders and Rivers (1996) and Wright, Horn, and Sanders (1997)
sections.methods_summary: Analytical evaluations in tractable cases and simulations to explore properties of methods in more complex cases resembling empirical structures.  Focus on bias in Sanders and Rivers' two-phase method (analytically for two years, via simulation for multiple years), and the Wright, Horn, and Sanders effect-size metric (simulation). Data generation models varied parameters for teacher effects, persistence of effects, mixing of students, and correlation between teacher effects and omitted student characteristics.  SAS and R were used for data generation and analysis.

sections.title: Modeling Longitudinal Data to Estimate Teacher Effects
sections.methods_summary: Discussion of three approaches to analyzing longitudinal data: covariate adjustment models, gain score models, and multivariate models.  Details on cross-classified, layered, and persistence models.  Comparison of fixed vs. random effects models, including discussion of shrinkage.  Analysis of omitted variables, confounders, and missing data, including discussion of missing completely at random (MCAR), missing at random (MAR), and missing not at random (MNAR) data.  Discussion of the effects of incomplete records and linking students to teachers.  Analysis of issues arising from the use of achievement tests as outcomes, including timing of tests, test construction and scaling, score inflation, and measurement error.  Discussion of uncertainty in estimated effects, including sampling error and other sources of uncertainty.

analysis.sample_description: The methodology sections describe various datasets used in the analysis, including those from Tennessee, Texas, and Dallas school districts.  Specific details on sample sizes and characteristics vary across the studies discussed.
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analytical approaches include analytical evaluations of tractable cases and extensive simulation studies to assess the properties of different value-added modeling (VAM) methods under various conditions.  Statistical techniques employed include regression analysis, mixed-effects modeling, maximum likelihood estimation, and Bayesian methods.  The analysis focuses on bias, efficiency, and sensitivity of estimates to various factors such as omitted variables, missing data, and measurement error.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: Comparative case study of the Green Revolution and the Gene Revolution, focusing on science and technology, funding sources, geographic location, and political environment.

analysis.sample_description: The study compares two historical agricultural movements: the Green Revolution and the Gene Revolution.  No specific sample of individuals or farms is described.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis compares the two movements across four key areas: science and technology, funding, geographic location, and political environment.  The authors draw lessons from the Green Revolution to inform the Gene Revolution.

sections.title: Approach to Estimating Total Number of Asbestos Claimants
sections.methods_summary: Obtained confidential data from multiple participants in the litigation (defendants and personal injury trusts). Compared lists of claimants, deleted redundant entries to identify unique individuals.  Addressed missing data by estimating the probability a claimant with missing information on one list was also on another list.

sections.title: Approach to Estimating Total Number of Asbestos Defendants
sections.methods_summary: Merged lists of defendants from various sources. Verified existence of defendants using InfoUSA and Hoover's Online. Due to the large number of defendants, a random sample of 500 defendants was drawn from the merged list for analysis.  Used LaPlace estimator of proportion to analyze distribution of defendants across industries, and adjusted confidence intervals to account for information from an initial, non-random sample of defendants.

sections.title: Approach to Estimating Total Spending on Asbestos Litigation
sections.methods_summary: Estimated number of claims closed each year by claim type using methods from Chapter Four. Calculated distribution of time-to-disposition for all defendants combined for each claim type. Obtained three independent estimates of total spending per claim type in a given year (2000 or 1998-1999) from defense attorneys, Tillinghast-Towers Perrin, and an unnamed research corporation.  Used these estimates to compute average annual rate of increase in total spending per claim for each claim type. Extrapolated trends to 2001 and 2002. Multiplied estimated number of claims by time-to-disposition and average spending per claim to estimate total amount paid out by defendants and insurers.

sections.title: Approach to Estimating Defense Transaction Costs
sections.methods_summary: Obtained aggregate annual data on indemnity payments and defense costs for a large number of defendants. Computed weighted average ratio of defense transaction costs to total spending for each year. Multiplied this ratio by estimates of total spending to estimate defense transaction costs.

sections.title: Approach to Estimating Gross Compensation
sections.methods_summary: Multiplied estimates of total spending on each claim type by one minus the fraction of total spending that went to defense transaction costs.

sections.title: Approach to Estimating Claimants’ Transaction Costs
sections.methods_summary: Used Kakalik et al. (1984) findings that claimants’ total legal expenses averaged 39 percent of gross compensation. Multiplied annual estimates of claimants’ gross compensation by 39 percent to estimate claimants’ transaction costs.  Performed a sensitivity analysis assuming claimants’ other legal costs declined at a constant annual rate from 5 percent in 1982 to 0 percent in 2000.

sections.title: Approach to Estimating Claimants’ Net Compensation
sections.methods_summary: Subtracted estimates of claimants’ transaction costs from estimates of claimants’ gross compensation.

sections.title: Approach to Identifying Asbestos-Related Bankruptcies
sections.methods_summary: Compiled a list from various sources (Mealey's Litigation Report, Mealey's Asbestos Bankruptcy Report, Asbestos Litigation Reporter, COLUMMS—Asbestos, American Academy of Actuaries list, American Insurance Association list, Porter Novelli Issue Advocacy list, Plevin and Kalish (2001), Lexis-Nexis, Westlaw, newspapers, magazines).  Verified information using bankruptcy filings, 10-K forms, and business entity references. Treated bankruptcies of parent companies and subsidiaries as single events.

sections.title: Constructing the Jury Verdict Database
sections.methods_summary: Searched electronic version of Mealey's Litigation Report for articles containing "jury" and "verdict." Manually screened results to remove irrelevant articles. Created separate entries for each trial.  Developed rules to ensure each plaintiff's claim was counted only once and only complete jury verdicts were included.

primary_methods: data collection from multiple sources (public and confidential)
analysis.sample_description: The study used various samples, including a random sample of 500 defendants from a merged list of over 10,000, and samples of claims from defendants' files for analysis of impairment.  The main data sources were confidential data from multiple participants in the litigation.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved comparing data from multiple sources, calculating proportions and confidence intervals, and using statistical techniques to analyze trends and patterns in the data.  Regression analysis was used in some parts of the analysis.

sections.title: Data Sources and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used a variety of quantitative analytic techniques to measure the impact of patient and facility characteristics on the costs of providing care to veterans.  A multivariate regression equation was estimated to explain variation in veterans' annual costs of care.  Three models were constructed: a base regression model (BRM), an all variables model (AVM), and a selected variables model (SVM).  The SVM was the primary focus of the analysis.  The study used patient-level data from the VA's Decision Support System (DSS), Medicare expenditure data from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, and county-level health care resource data from the Area Resource File (ARF).  A single-equation approach was used, combining patient- and facility-level characteristics into one regression equation.  Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression was employed.  The regression estimates were used to simulate VERA allocations under various scenarios, and the results were disaggregated to show the influence of each variable on VISN allocations.  The study also compared the effects of using different case-mix measures (VERA-10 and VA DCGs).

analysis.sample_description: The primary analysis sample included veterans who are included in the workload count in the current VERA allocation methodology; Priority 7 veterans and non-veteran employees were excluded. The final sample for FY 2001 included 3,186,221 veterans.
analysis.analysis_approach: Multivariate regression analysis was used to explain variation in veterans' annual costs of care.  Three models were created: a base regression model (BRM), an all variables model (AVM), and a selected variables model (SVM).  The SVM included variables that were statistically significant, consistent with the VA's mission, measured without significant error, and met current VA policy objectives.  OLS regression was used.  Regression results were used to simulate VISN allocations under different scenarios, and the simulations were disaggregated to analyze the impact of individual variables.  Comparisons were made between actual FY 2003 allocations, BRM simulations, VERA-10 SVM allocations, and VA DCG SVM allocations.

sections.title: Projecting Workforce Size
sections.methods_summary: The BLS projects workforce size by generating separate population projections for 136 age, sex, and race/Hispanic origin groups, projecting labor force participation rates for each group (calculating the rate of change over the past eight years and applying it to the most recent rate, then manually adjusting implausible projections), and multiplying the participation rates by the population projections.

sections.title: Analysis of Firm Organization and Workplace Practices
sections.methods_summary: The analysis draws on case studies and firm-level data to examine the correlation between changes in business organization and investment in IT.  It also examines the adoption of high-performance workplace practices and their correlation with IT investment.

sections.title: Analysis of Nonstandard Work Arrangements
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of BLS data on alternative work arrangements, including independent contractors, on-call workers, temporary help agency workers, and workers provided by contract firms.  Also includes analysis of data on contingent workers and their preferences for full-time employment.

sections.title: Analysis of Workplace Safety, Security, and Privacy
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of data on workplace safety trends, including injury and fatality rates for older workers.  Analysis of a survey on corporate security spending after 9/11.  Discussion of privacy concerns related to employee monitoring and data use.

sections.title: Analysis of Skill Requirements and Training
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of trends in skill requirements across sectors, drawing on data on computer use in the workplace and studies on skill-biased technical change.  Examination of data on employer-provided training and technology-mediated learning.

sections.title: Analysis of Wages and Benefits
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of trends in wages by education level, examining the college wage premium.  Discussion of the effects of technology and globalization on wage inequality.  Analysis of employer-provided benefits, including health insurance and pension plans.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses various data sources, including BLS data, CPS data, INS data, and data from various academic studies and surveys. Specific samples are described within the relevant sections.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach is primarily qualitative, drawing on existing data and research to identify trends and their implications.  Quantitative data are used to illustrate trends and support arguments, but the analysis does not involve original statistical modeling or testing of hypotheses.

sections.title: Modeling the Decision to Repair or Replace an Aging Aircraft
sections.methods_summary: This section details a model that considers discounted expenditure and availability flows from repairing versus replacing an aging system.  It uses a cost per available year metric to determine the optimal time to replace an aircraft. The model accommodates one-time expenditure spikes (modifications) by comparing costs per available year before and after the modification.

sections.title: Consideration of C-5A Depot-Level Capacity
sections.methods_summary: This section extends the methodology to assess the desirability of additional investment in depot-level capacity. It uses a queuing model of the programmed depot maintenance process as a multinode closed network to analyze the effects of increased capacity on aircraft availability.  The model uses mean value analysis and considers the impact of increased capacity on queuing times and the operating command's possession rate.

analysis.sample_description: The primary data used is from the Air Force's Total Ownership Cost (AFTOC) system and Reliability and Maintainability Information System (REMIS) for the C-5A and C-17 aircraft.  The analysis focuses on these two aircraft types as illustrative examples.
analysis.analysis_approach: The core analysis uses a cost-benefit approach, comparing the discounted costs and availability of repairing/modifying an existing aircraft versus replacing it with a newer model.  A queuing model is used to assess the impact of changes in depot-level capacity on aircraft availability.  Robustness checks are performed to assess the sensitivity of results to key parameter assumptions.

sections.title: Approaches to Cost Estimation
sections.methods_summary: Description of various cost estimation methods: Expert Judgment, Analogy, Parametric/Algorithmic, Bottom-Up/Work Breakdown Structure, and Top-Down.  Each method is described in terms of how it works, advantages, disadvantages, and usage.

sections.title: Study Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used a four-task approach: (1) defining key terms (uncertainty, error, risk, accuracy); (2) identifying sources of risk in software estimates by decomposing the estimation process into three components (select method, collect data, apply method); (3) describing major approaches to sizing and cost estimation; and (4) developing risk mitigation strategies and checklists.  The research relied on literature review and analysis, incorporating lessons from sample programs.

sections.title: Report Organization
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines the structure of the report, detailing the content of each chapter and how it contributes to the overall analysis of risks in software cost estimation.

sections.title: Survey of Sizing Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section describes seven sizing methods: Lines of Code, Function Points and Feature Points, Object Points, Application Points, Predictive Object Points, Analogies, and Estimating from UML Constructs. Each method is described in terms of its source, references, how it works, when to use it, and when not to use it.

sections.title: Risk Checklist for Sizing Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section analyzes risks in software size estimation, categorizing them by source (specification/design, development method, estimation process).  For each risk category, symptoms, warning signs, and mitigation strategies are provided.  A checklist is presented to guide analysts in identifying and managing these risks.

sections.title: Checklist for Reviewing Size-Estimation Risk
sections.methods_summary: This section provides a checklist for evaluating size estimates.  The checklist is organized into three sections: sizing-method selection, project/system assessment, and sizing-method application.  Each section contains actions and questions to guide the analyst in assessing the risks associated with the estimate.

sections.title: Approaches to Cost Estimation
sections.methods_summary: This section describes various cost estimation approaches: Expert Judgment, Analogy, Parametric/Algorithmic.  Each method is detailed with explanations of how it works, advantages, disadvantages, and appropriate usage scenarios.  The role of historical databases in enhancing estimation accuracy is also discussed.

analysis.sample_description: The study incorporates lessons from sample programs to develop pragmatic risk-mitigation strategies. Specific programs are mentioned but not detailed as a sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves defining a taxonomy of terms, decomposing the software estimation process, characterizing estimation methods, and developing risk mitigation strategies and checklists.  Regression analysis is mentioned as a technique used within some of the cost estimation methods.

sections.title: Methodology:  Policy Measures Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative analysis of policy documents and initiatives to identify aims, target groups, and implementation methods.  Categorization of measures by country, target group, and type of intervention (financial, facilitative, regulatory).  Analysis of longevity of initiatives.

sections.title: Methodology: International Comparison
sections.methods_summary: Structured analysis of factors influencing study choice and S&T outcomes in six European countries.  Collection of detailed statistical data on S&T uptake in secondary and higher education, and the labor market over 20-25 years. Qualitative data collection on policy measures and effects.  Analysis of relationships between implemented measures and effects over time and across countries. Consideration of contextual factors (education system organization, financing, labor market structure).

analysis.sample_description: Six European countries (Finland, Sweden, Germany, Italy, Ireland, UK) selected based on their performance in S&T uptake, representing different categories ('Forging further ahead', 'Losing momentum', 'Catching up', 'Falling further behind').  The Netherlands is excluded as a case study but used for comparison.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis interprets the data in light of international cultural differences.  A conceptual framework (Figure 2-1) guides the analysis of inflow and outflow of S&T students, considering demographic trends, study choice factors (formal and informal), quality of education, student retention, and labor market dynamics.  The synthesis identifies drivers of S&T uptake and evaluates the effectiveness of policy measures.

sections.title: Using Expert Judgment to Estimate the EV Components
sections.methods_summary: Used RAND's E-DEL+ITM collaborative consensus building method with an expert panel of Naval officers and senior civilian executives. This method involves independent assessments, followed by anonymous feedback and teleconferences for verbal feedback.  The process involved four rounds of evaluation.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Describes the RAND PortMan R&D decision framework (calculating Expected Value as the product of capability, performance potential, and transition probability) and the RAND E-DEL+I consensus building method.  Details the anchored scales used for evaluating capability, performance potential, and transition probability. Explains data requirements, including the use of project summaries compiled from proposal information and scenario descriptions.  Discusses the four-round E-DEL+I process, including real-time and non-real-time components.

sections.title: Case Study Description
sections.methods_summary: Details the case study evaluation of 20 ONR Code 31 6.2 applied research projects. Describes the composition of the expert panel, selection of projects, assessment dimensions (relevance, applicability, achievement, conditions, status, implementability), and the assessment questionnaire (Excel workbook). Explains the dynamics of the evaluation across four rounds, including the use of email and teleconferences, and the consensus-building process.  Reports on expert panel concerns and final assessments.

analysis.sample_description: 20 sample ONR Code 31 6.2 applied research projects in Command, Control, and Combat Systems (C2CS) or Communications subunits. Projects were selected based on data availability in proposals.
analysis.analysis_approach: Portfolio analysis using Expected Value (EV) calculations, plotting EV components (capability, performance potential, transition probability) and their uncertainties.  Projects were grouped based on similar characteristics and investment leverage.  Uncertainty was displayed using the range of expert valuations.

sections.title: Brief Overview of Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of industry data, comparison with other studies, surveys and interviews at 16 healthcare facilities (purposive sample), telephone interviews with HIT professionals, extensive literature review.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Surveys and interviews at healthcare facilities, telephone interviews with HIT professionals, extensive literature review.

sections.title: Chapter Two: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of data from Sheldon Dorenfest and Associates, literature review of EHR diffusion, interviews with HIT experts and providers (semi-structured interviews).

sections.title: Chapter Three: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Identification of historical diffusion curves from literature (Teng, Grover, and Guttler, 2002; Hall and Khan, 2003), literature review to identify key diffusion drivers, generation of predicted EHR diffusion curve based on historical data and diffusion theory, assessment of causal diffusion variables using surveys and interviews at healthcare facilities (purposive sample of thought leaders, early adopters, new adopters, non-adopters, and community health networks), telephone interviews with thought leaders, extensive literature review.

sections.title: Chapter Four: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Top-down approach: analysis of IT value in other industries (case studies of telecommunications, securities trading, retail, wholesale, retail banking, and hotels), literature review, site interviews. Bottom-up approach mentioned but details deferred to future research.

sections.title: Chapter Five: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Theoretical analysis based on economic welfare principles and market failure concepts (imperfect information, market power, externalities), literature review of policy interventions and their effects on technology diffusion.

analysis.sample_description: Chapter 2: Dorenfest database (mostly large hospitals), interviews with HIT experts and providers. Chapter 3: Purposive sample of 16 healthcare facilities (thought leaders, early adopters, new adopters, non-adopters, community health networks). Chapter 4: Case studies of six industries (telecommunications, securities trading, retail, wholesale, retail banking, hotels).
analysis.analysis_approach: Comparative analysis, diffusion modeling (logistic curve), qualitative analysis of case studies, economic welfare analysis.

sections.title: Definitions and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The primary methodological challenge was reconciling findings from the literature, given the rapid changes in virtual collaboration and mediated communication technology.  A two-pronged strategy was adopted: (1) establishing a convention for defining the effective communication medium of a hybrid system (characterizing the medium by the dominant type of interpersonal feedback), and (2) evaluating research results case by case to assess their relevance to the modern world.  Literature searches used multiple databases (PsychInfo, ECO, Web of Science, etc.) with keyword searches and Boolean operators.  Reference list tree expansions and follow-up emails to researchers were also employed.  The Pinsonneault and Kraemer (1989) framework was adapted to organize the results.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consisted of existing research papers, books, and dissertations on mediated communication, spanning several decades and disciplines.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved a case-by-case assessment of older research to determine its relevance to modern technology.  A framework was adapted to organize the findings, focusing on common effects across different communication media and identifying interaction effects.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: A sample of 306 Air Force contract actions from FY02 was selected, weighted toward larger-dollar-value actions.  Contracting officers responsible for these actions were interviewed to gather supplemental information. Statistical methods were used to extrapolate findings to the entire Air Force FY02 DD350 database.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Description of the DD350 database, a two-stage sampling process (initial random selection with weights proportional to contract action dollar value, followed by selection based on the number of actions per contracting officer), telephone interviews with contracting officers, high response rate (79%), challenges in assigning PSCs due to limitations in available codes and complexity of activities, creation of new codes for studies and warranties, handling of multiple activities within contract actions, and reweighting of survey results to reflect the entire Air Force FY02 DD350 population.

sections.title: Statistical Methods for Extrapolation
sections.methods_summary: Equations and variance formulas from Kish (1995) and Cochran (1977) were used to estimate proportions of contract actions with particular characteristics and to extrapolate sample dollar amounts to the entire DD350 population using combined-ratio estimates. Confidence intervals were calculated using Cochran's variance formula.

analysis.sample_description: A sample of 306 Air Force FY02 DD350 contract actions, weighted toward larger-dollar-value actions to ensure representation of a disproportionately large share of overall contract expenditures and potentially more complex actions.  Approximately 225 service contract actions and 75 goods contract actions were selected.
analysis.analysis_approach: Statistical methods were used to reweight survey results to accurately reflect the characteristics of the entire Air Force FY02 DD350 population.  Accuracy was defined as a match between the first character of the PSC in the DD350 record and the first character of the primary RAND-assigned PSC. Adequacy was defined broadly, considering a single PSC adequate if multiple goods or services within an action could be described with codes sharing the same first character.  Analysis involved examining the accuracy and adequacy of the data, exploring the nature of coding errors, and assessing the implications for tracking service expenditures.

sections.title: Data Sources and Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: The analysis is based on various cost and schedule reports available to PAF as well as data and information available in open sources.  Sources include Selected Acquisition Reports (SARs), Contract Cost Data Reports (CCDRs), Cost Performance Reports (CPRs), Cost Analysis Requirements Description (CARD), contractor’s weight reports, General Accounting Office (GAO) reports, and published articles and reports.

sections.title: Data Sources and Analysis Methods
sections.methods_summary: Cost information is from SARs (ending December 31, 2001), Contract Cost Data Reports (CCDRs), and Cost Performance Reports (CPRs). Top-level costs from monthly CPRs on main air vehicle contracts were collected for the EMD effort.  CCDR data for F/A-18E/F EMD was collected, but only F/A-22 EMD CCDRs from September 1995 to September 2002 were available.  Analysis includes comparison of EMD program costs, assessment of cost growth of major subsystems (airframe, avionics, propulsion), and examination of reasons for cost growth in the F/A-22 program.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from two multirole fighter aircraft programs: the Air Force's F/A-22 and the Navy's F/A-18E/F.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report compares the acquisition strategies, technical challenges, and management approaches of the two programs to identify factors contributing to cost and schedule outcomes.  Cost and schedule data are analyzed to identify trends and key cost drivers.  The analysis focuses on the Engineering and Manufacturing Development (EMD) phase of both programs.

sections.title: Evaluation Methodology: Process Evaluation
sections.methods_summary: Participant-observer approach; site visits at baseline and two follow-up times; interviews and focus groups with implementation team, providers, clinic staff, and quality management staff; semi-structured interviews; surveys at baseline and final site visit; document review.

sections.title: Evaluation Methodology: Evaluation of Effects (Outcomes)
sections.methods_summary: Analysis using administrative data (SIDR, SADR, MTF pharmacy data, HCSR, NMOP data); data extraction in two rounds; creation of RAND ID; creation of analysis master files; definition of key outcome variables (primary care visits, use of oral hypoglycemic agents, eye exams, ER visits, hospitalizations); cost estimation using MEPRS financial data, calculating inpatient and outpatient costs, updating unit costs to FY 1999 estimates using a 1.4% inflation factor.

sections.title: Appendix B: Analyses of Diabetes Metrics
sections.methods_summary: Ordered logistic regression models for primary care visits and hospitalizations; logistic regression models for ER visits, eye examinations, and use of oral hypoglycemic agents; predictor variables included dummy variables for each quarter, a dummy variable for demonstration site, and control variables for patient characteristics (insulin user, gender, age categories).

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consisted of TRICARE Prime enrollees at demonstration and control MTFs during the study period.  The larger study population included all individuals who used an Army MTF for diabetes care or resided in the catchment area of an Army MTF during the study period.
analysis.analysis_approach: Time series, control comparison design;  regression models (ordered logistic and standard logistic) were used to test for significant differences in outcome measures between demonstration and control sites, controlling for temporal trends and patient characteristics. Cost analysis involved applying unit costs derived from MEPRS data to encounter records.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: A stratified random sample of 209 local law enforcement agencies and a census of all 50 state law enforcement agencies were surveyed.  Survey weights were calculated for local agencies to account for sampling differences and nonresponses.  A finite population correction was used for state-level data.  The chapter acknowledges limitations related to respondent knowledge, nonresponse bias, and variations in state agency responsibilities.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Eight police organizations were selected for case studies based on their development or possession of intelligence capabilities.  Interviews were conducted with command staff knowledgeable about intelligence operations. The sample is not representative and generalizations are limited.

analysis.sample_description: For the survey, a stratified random sample of 209 local law enforcement agencies and a census of 50 state agencies were used.  For the case studies, eight agencies were purposively selected based on their existing or developing intelligence capabilities.  The case study sample is not representative.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive analyses were conducted for the survey data, with weights applied to the local agency data to ensure national representativeness.  The case study analysis was organized around six thematic areas, allowing for in-depth exploration of specific organizational experiences.

sections.title: Overview of Methods and Findings
sections.methods_summary: Identified 72 guidelines addressing work-related injuries. Selected a subset based on quality and cost criteria (<$500). Compared guidelines on technical quality and clinical content using a multidisciplinary panel of expert clinicians.

sections.title: Analysis and Recommendations
sections.methods_summary: Clinical panel evaluation of comprehensiveness and validity of guideline content.  Prioritization of guideline topics based on cost and risk.

sections.title: Appendix B: Publicly Posted Screening Criteria
sections.methods_summary: Details the criteria used for screening guidelines: nationally recognized, current, comprehensive, evidence-based, peer-reviewed, developed by a multidisciplinary team, kept up-to-date, and potentially open source.

sections.title: Appendix C: Selecting Clinical Panelists
sections.methods_summary: Description of the process for selecting the clinical panel: contacted relevant national specialty societies for nominations, reviewed curricula vitae, selected panelists based on attributes such as national balance, diversity of practice setting, experience, and lack of conflict of interest.  Telephone interviews were conducted to assess experience, attitude, potential conflicts of interest, and ability to work in a team.

sections.title: Appendix D & E: Sample Rating Forms and Clinical Panel Ratings
sections.methods_summary: Details the two-round rating process used by the clinical panel.  Round one involved individual ratings, and round two involved a face-to-face meeting to discuss ratings and re-rate.  Rating scales (1-9) were used to assess comprehensiveness and validity of guideline content.  Guidelines were also ranked.  Analysis involved assessing median rankings and defining agreement/disagreement among panelists.

sections.title: Guideline Evaluation
sections.methods_summary: Multiple search strategies to identify guidelines.  Screening based on quality and cost criteria.  Technical quality evaluation using the AGREE instrument. Clinical content evaluation by a multidisciplinary panel of clinicians, assessing comprehensiveness and validity of guideline content for selected therapies and overall.

sections.title: Stakeholder Experiences with Interim Use of the ACOEM Guidelines
sections.methods_summary: Semistructured interviews with stakeholders (physicians, practitioners, attorneys, payors, government officials) to gather information on their perceptions of the California workers' compensation program, the impact of legislative changes, and suggestions for improvement.  18 individual and group interviews conducted.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample included 72 guidelines initially, narrowed down to 5 guideline sets based on pre-defined criteria.  A multidisciplinary panel of 11 clinicians and 20+ stakeholders participated in the study.
analysis.analysis_approach: The AGREE instrument was used for technical quality assessment.  A modified RAND/UCLA Appropriateness Method was adapted for clinical content evaluation, using a 1-9 rating scale for comprehensiveness and validity.  Qualitative analysis of stakeholder interviews and meeting discussions was also conducted.

sections.title: Study Approach and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Literature review of program evaluation issues and evaluations of interventions for HIV/AIDS and TB in resource-poor countries.  A multidisciplinary team of RAND experts discussed methodological issues related to measuring the effects of complex health interventions and brainstormed on whether methodological approaches used in other disciplines might be used to address some of the methodological issues related to attributing measured effects to a health intervention.

sections.title: Methodological Challenges in Evaluating the Impact of Health Projects
sections.methods_summary: This section discusses attribution issues (internal and external validity, unobserved heterogeneity) and measurement issues (what to measure, how to measure, data limitations, use of surrogate markers, multidisciplinary measures).  Specific methods mentioned include randomized control trials, randomized cluster trials, quasi-experimental designs, pre-post regression analyses, propensity score matching, and two-stage regression analysis.

analysis.sample_description: The study reviewed existing evaluations of HIV/AIDS and TB interventions in resource-poor countries, focusing on more recent evaluations.  Specific studies are mentioned and summarized in tables within the document.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved reviewing the methodologies and findings of existing studies, identifying common challenges, and proposing improvements to evaluation practices.  Statistical techniques such as regression analysis and propensity score matching are discussed as methods for addressing selection bias.

sections.title: Methodology: Prospects and Implications of U.S. First Strikes
sections.methods_summary: The analysis draws on the analyses in the preceding chapters and on the results of 12 historical case studies.  These case studies include instances where anticipatory attacks were carried out and instances where such options were considered but rejected.  Each case falls into one of three categories: attacks to eliminate threats of interstate aggression, attacks against non-state actors, and attacks to limit the development of dangerous military capabilities.

analysis.sample_description: Twelve historical case studies of preemptive and preventive attacks, including both successful and unsuccessful attempts.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of case studies, categorized by type of attack and threat.

sections.title: Study Scope and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This monograph focuses on how the Army and Air Force have viewed five “war” cases during the post–Cold War era and what lessons they have drawn from them.  The analysis focuses on providing answers to the following questions: What are the causes of interservice tension at the war end of the range of military operations? Are Army and Air Force lessons learned being shaped by service influences that are inhibiting true learning and improvements in joint warfighting capabilities? Are single-service doctrinal paradigms sufficient to capture these lessons, or do they call for a fundamental rethinking and shift of the roles of air and ground power in warfighting? What would be the implications of such a shift in the realms of joint doctrine, service roles and missions, service programs, and service cultures?

primary_methods: Qualitative analysis of existing documents and reports
analysis.sample_description: Five post-Cold War conflicts: Iraq (1991), Bosnia (1995), Kosovo (1999), Afghanistan (2001), and Iraq (2003).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis identifies the responses of the ground-centric and air-centric communities to these wars, examines lessons learned, and provides an integrated assessment.  The study characterizes the views of credible advocates within each service, using academic and public sources to assess what actually happened in each conflict.

sections.title: Study Scope and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study analyzes five post-Cold War conflicts (Iraq 1991, Bosnia 1995, Kosovo 1999, Afghanistan 2001, Iraq 2003) to examine how the Army and Air Force viewed these conflicts and the lessons they drew.  It focuses on the 'war' category of military operations, as this largely influences service behavior. The analysis characterizes the views of credible advocates within each service, using academic and public sources to assess what actually happened.  The study aims to identify causes of interservice tension, determine if service influences inhibit learning, assess if single-service doctrines are sufficient, and explore the implications of a potential shift in the roles of air and ground power.

analysis.sample_description: Five post-Cold War conflicts involving large-scale combat operations for the Army, Air Force, or both.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis focuses on identifying the responses of ground-centric and air-centric communities to the conflicts, the lessons learned, and an integrated assessment of the wars.  It examines the views of credible advocates within each service and uses academic and public sources to assess what actually happened.

sections.title: Estimating Costs and Benefits of Disease Management Programs
sections.methods_summary: Cost estimation based on labor resources spent on program components (assessment, education, monitoring, reminders, evaluation). Two HIT scenarios (basic and advanced) considered.  Benefits estimated by combining trajectory data from MEPS with factors from literature, adjusting selected elements (ER visits, hospital stays, office visits) to reflect program effects.  Analysis conducted using Excel spreadsheets.

sections.title: Estimating Long-Term Effects of Healthy Behavior
sections.methods_summary: Estimation of maximum effects of a four-step lifestyle change program.  Algorithm adjusts prevalence of conditions based on changes in incidence, using a scaling factor (0.4 in examples) to reduce odds of each condition.  Algorithm controls for age, sex, and ethnicity.  Analysis considers interaction effects of multiple conditions.  Excel file I0D14mlt40.xls used for detailed results.  Comparison with literature estimates (CDC, etc.) to assess plausibility of results.

sections.title: Assessing Patient Adherence to Disease Management and Lifestyle Changes
sections.methods_summary: Review of literature on patient adherence to medication and lifestyle recommendations.  Discussion of potential benefits of improved adherence.  Analysis of factors affecting adherence (beliefs, incentives, barriers).  Exploration of the role of HIT in improving adherence (reminders, education, support).  Speculation on achievable success rates (50% considered possible).

sections.title: Estimating Potential Effects of Interventions
sections.methods_summary: Baseline values for utilization, expenditures, and health outcomes established using MEPS data.  MEPS data compared with other authoritative sources (NHE, NIS, NAMCS, NHAMCS) to devise adjustments.  Effects of interventions estimated by modifying baseline data based on literature review.  Systematic review of peer-reviewed and gray literature.  Analysis considers effects in year 2000 and projections to future years, adjusting for demographic changes and inflation.  Excel spreadsheets used for analysis.

sections.title: Building the Trajectory Database from the MEPS
sections.methods_summary: Combined data from MEPS panels 1-4 to create analysis files (approx. 56,000 respondents).  Person-level weights developed by adjusting baseline weights to reflect 2000 population, including adjustments for institutionalized populations (nursing home residents, prisoners).  Expenditures inflated to 2000 levels.  MEPS diagnoses mapped into defined medical conditions.  Health outcome variables calculated using data from Full Year Consolidated Data File, considering factors like activity limitations, perceived health status, and days missed from work/school.

sections.title: Interpreting MEPS-Based Estimates
sections.methods_summary: Discussion of precision of MEPS estimates (standard errors calculated using SAS SURVEYMEANS procedure).  Analysis of errors and omissions in MEPS data, comparing with other sources (NIS, NAMCS, NHAMCS, NHE, 1997 Economic Census).  Development of adjustments to align MEPS estimates with authoritative sources.  Projection of estimates to future years (2005-2020), adjusting for demographic changes and inflation (using NHE projections).  Discussion of factors not included in adjustments (technology, cultural attitudes, indirect effects), considering potential responses of the healthcare system to interventions (blunting or embracing savings).

analysis.sample_description: The primary data source is the Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS), covering several years and including approximately 56,000 respondents.  Adjustments are made to include institutionalized populations and project to future years.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis combines data from the MEPS with information from the published literature to estimate the effects of various interventions.  Cost-benefit analyses are performed, and results are compared with data from other authoritative sources to assess plausibility and make adjustments.  The analysis uses Excel spreadsheets and statistical software (SAS).

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The RAND team used a three-pronged approach: 1) thorough document review and analysis of policies, procedures, directives, concepts of operations, implementation plans, agreements, protocols, and communication records; 2) interviews with over 100 individuals from more than 20 organizations; and 3) site visits to DoD facilities to inspect layout, processes, standards, and protocols related to the incidents.  The adequacy of DoD plans and actions were judged against the NIMS/NRP and HHS/CDC guidelines.

analysis.sample_description: Data was collected from documents and interviews conducted with over 100 individuals from more than 20 organizations.  The study included three DoD mail facilities in northern Virginia and Washington, D.C.
analysis.analysis_approach: The adequacy of DoD plans and actions were assessed by comparing them to the National Incident Management System (NIMS), National Response Plan (NRP), and HHS/CDC guidelines.  A three-pronged approach of document review, interviews, and site visits was used to gather data.

sections.title: Assumption-Based Planning
sections.methods_summary: The study uses Assumption-Based Planning (ABP) to assess Army acquisition plans by identifying key assumptions, signposts indicating vulnerability, shaping actions to maintain assumptions, and hedging actions to prepare for unwelcome developments.  The five main steps in the ABP process are applied to Army acquisition policy.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research involved two main parts: 1) adapting the ABP process to create a robust and adaptive acquisition investment strategy; 2) applying this process to create a 'strawman' strategy for the Army.  The study also examined analogous circumstances from the interwar years.  Steps included identifying key assumptions and vulnerabilities, identifying alternative threat environments (using DoD Strategic Planning Guidance), using signposts, shaping actions, and hedging actions to identify appropriate investments, and specifying an Army investment strategy.  A threat and likelihood plot was created to prioritize investments.

sections.title: Developing a Tool for Investment Strategy Planning
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used, which adapts an ABP process to create an Army acquisition investment portfolio responsive to the national security landscape.  It involves identifying fundamental assumptions (operational and technological dominance, rapid global deployment, managing complexity, budget sustainability, reliance on Reserve Component and sister services), developing signposts of vulnerability for each assumption, and developing shaping and hedging actions (investments in procurement, R&D, and recapitalization).  Alternative circumstances requiring Army capabilities are identified and plotted on a threat and likelihood chart. A Cobb-Douglas utility function is used to prioritize these circumstances for budgeting.  Investment emphasis is weighted according to likelihood and threat, and then normalized against the FY 2004 acquisition budget to produce final budget recommendations.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is not an empirical study with a defined sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a mixed-methods approach combining qualitative analysis of Army documents and strategic planning materials with quantitative analysis using a utility function to prioritize investments based on threat and likelihood.  Scenario planning is used to explore alternative futures and their impact on Army acquisition needs.

sections.title: Method for Identifying and Assessing Planned Training System Enhancements
sections.methods_summary: This section details the approach for identifying and assessing training enhancements for FCS-equipped BCTs.  It involved multiple iterations of identifying enhancements, circulating a list among subject matter experts (SMEs) for feedback, and using an approach (illustrated in Figure 4.1) to evaluate each enhancement individually.  The approach involved considering available information on the enhancement's design and goals, comparing it to current and future training requirements and CTC training performance, and identifying factors limiting the enhancement's potential (unit time constraints, technology risk, funding risk).  The evaluation also considered the aggregate value of enhancements and the Army's process for making tradeoffs among training investments.

sections.title: Method Used to Score Unit Performance at the National Training Center (NTC)
sections.methods_summary: Unit performance at the NTC was scored using a six-point rating scale (Table A.1) based on whether a skill, task, or function was accomplished well enough to allow mission accomplishment, independent of other performance or actual mission accomplishment.  The percentage of units showing improvement between first and best scores was also recorded.

sections.title: Approaches for Developing Effective Simulations and Automated Support Training Tools
sections.methods_summary: This section discusses approaches for improving constructive simulations, focusing on determining the necessary level of realism, exploring methods to speed simulation development (Tiger Teams, rapid prototyping), and developing support tools for scenario development (user-friendly authoring tools, modification toolkits), execution management, and AAR material generation (automated data logging, analysis, and briefing slide generation).

sections.title: Activities That Could Support an Improved Spiral Development Process for Simulation-Based Training
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines activities to support a spiral development process for simulation-based training, including demonstrating positive transfer from simulation to live actions, understanding how to speed simulation development and improve quality, exploring methods for providing high-quality OPFOR, increasing the value of automated instruction, and supporting small-scale simulation development at the institutional and PEO STRI levels.

primary_methods: Literature review of Army training documents and programs
Comparative analysis of enhancements across metrics (quality, quantity, adaptability)
analysis.sample_description: The study examined training programs of heavy and light units in 2001-2002, and more recent data from the 3rd and 4th Infantry Divisions.  Data from the National Training Center (NTC) were also analyzed.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study used a mixed-methods approach, combining qualitative assessments of training enhancements with quantitative analysis of unit training data and NTC performance.  Enhancements were evaluated against three metrics: training quality, quantity of training events, and adaptability of training events.  Factors limiting the potential of each enhancement were also considered.

sections.title: Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: Evaluates transformational options for meeting combat support mission needs for the air and space expeditionary force (AEF).  Analyzes the Air National Guard's role in these options in terms of effectiveness and efficiency. Four Air Force mission areas are evaluated: CONUS centralized intermediate repair facilities, civil engineering deployment and sustainment capabilities, GUARDIAN capabilities, and air and space operations center reachback missions.  Uses a strategies-to-tasks framework to identify shortfalls and suggest, describe, and evaluate options for implementing improvements in current processes, doctrine, organizations, training, and systems.

sections.title: Portfolio of Candidate Mission Options: COMAFFOR Warfighting Operations Support
sections.methods_summary: Evaluates options for using the ANG to augment the WFHQ AFFOR staff during wartime operations.  Considers a base case (individual augmentation) and two options: unit-based augmentation and unit-based, AOR-specific augmentation, both using a force-provider construct.  Analyzes effectiveness and efficiency of each option, considering factors like 24/7 support requirements, existing precedents (e.g., NORAD and NORTHCOM support), and ANG strengths and limitations.  Provides manpower estimates for each option.

sections.title: Portfolio of Candidate Mission Options: Intermediate-Level Maintenance
sections.methods_summary: Analyzes the impact of BRAC and FTF initiatives on ILM and ANG support of active flying units, using the F-16 as a case study.  Compares notional ILM manpower requirements at an ACC F-16 wing with those at three ANG F-16 units.  Evaluates two options for employing the ANG in the ILM mission, each with variations in staﬃng mix (full-time/part-time) and UTE rates.
