Considers a base case where the active component retains all responsibility for ILM.  Estimates active authorizations made available and funding requirements for each option.  Discusses implementation issues, including relocation and colocation of ANG ILM units.

sections.title: Overarching Concepts and Conclusions Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Presents a methodology for investigating the ANG's role in assuming some missions currently staffed by the active component.  Evaluates four mission areas (Predator support, air mobility command and control, COMAFFOR warfighting support, and base-level intermediate maintenance) to illustrate the methodology's application.  Identifies overarching principles and concepts from the evaluation of these mission areas, focusing on the benefits of ANG participation and the need for a continual review of roles and missions.

primary_methods: Qualitative analysis of existing data and reports
analysis.sample_description: The study does not have a specific sample in the traditional sense.  Instead, it analyzes existing data and operational requirements for various Air Force missions and assesses the potential for ANG involvement.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a mixed-methods approach, combining qualitative analysis of existing data and reports with quantitative analysis of manpower requirements and costs. A decision tree is used as a structured framework for evaluating the suitability of different missions for ANG participation.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research documents salient features of three Air Force systems (manpower, strength management, and enlisted promotion) and discusses their detrimental interactions.  It lays the foundation for a discussion of policy changes to better synchronize these systems.

sections.title: Synchronization Strategies and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Four strategies are presented to improve synchronization of the Air Force's strength management, promotion, and manpower systems.  These strategies involve modifying grade authorizations within skill levels to create executable manning targets. The analysis uses data from the Air Force Personnel Center (AFPC) to illustrate the strategies and their potential impact on manning levels.  The analysis also involves developing equations to determine optimal E5/E4 ratios based on existing 7-level/5-level ratios and Air Force averages for E7/E6 and E6/E5 ratios.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the Air Force Personnel Center (AFPC) on enlisted personnel, including authorizations, manning levels, promotions, and retraining data.  The analysis focuses on Air Force Specialty Codes (AFSCs) and their grade structures.
analysis.analysis_approach: The research analyzes the interactions between the Air Force's manpower, strength management, and enlisted promotion systems.  It develops and evaluates four strategies for improving synchronization, using mathematical models and data analysis to assess the potential impact of each strategy on manning levels and resource allocation.

sections.title: Data Sources and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The analysis relies on interviews with former senior Iraqi military and civilian officials, and high-value detainees.  The author acknowledges potential biases in the data due to self-serving accounts and the influence of potential prosecution.

analysis.sample_description: Interviews with former senior Iraqi civilian and military officials, including high-value detainees (e.g., Saddam Hussein and key political/military figures).  The author notes potential biases in the data due to self-serving accounts and the influence of potential prosecution.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview transcripts and existing documents, focusing on identifying patterns and explanations for the weak Iraqi resistance.

sections.title: Methodology for Developing Inflow Goals for Colonels
sections.methods_summary: This section details a three-step approach: 1) Identifying skills needed for colonel positions using expert panels (2002 data on ~2800 positions, excluding medical, legal, and chaplain fields).  2) Developing a flow-analysis model to translate job requirements into inflow goals for new colonels.  This model considers factors like job sequencing, occupational pyramids, preparatory roles, selectivity, progression, and outflows. 3) Using analytic results (from the flow model) to target skill pairings.  A later attempt to survey colonels (June 2005) about needed backgrounds yielded only a 40% response rate, highlighting the limitations of this approach. The authors advocate for expert panels over surveys for identifying skill requirements.

sections.title: Four-Step Approach for Setting Force-Development Goals for Individual Career Fields
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines a four-step approach demonstrated for the 13S career field (space and missile operations officers): 1) Identify the demand: Expert panels rate the importance of various background elements (experience, education, training) for different jobs within the career field (critical, important, useful, not relevant). 2) Assess the supply: Review officers' personnel records to determine acquired background elements. 3) Compare supply with demand (gap analysis): Determine if enough officers at each grade have the needed background elements and combinations. 4) Plan ways to improve the match: Model officers' assignment sequences to identify efficient career paths that meet job demands and policy objectives (maximizing experience depth/breadth, establishing career tracks, ensuring equal opportunity).  The analysis uses a model with up to 13 career stages and one to three jobs per grade, awarding points for meeting job requirements.  The results are compared to 'actual' assignments to highlight potential improvements.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data on Air Force officers, specifically focusing on general officers, colonels, and officers in the 13S (space and missile operations) career field.  A 2005 survey of colonels had a low response rate (40%).  The main data for colonel positions comes from 2002 data on approximately 2800 positions.
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis methods involve flow analysis modeling to translate job requirements into personnel inflow goals.  This model accounts for various factors influencing officer career progression.  Gap analysis compares the supply of officers with the required skills to the demand for those skills in different job positions.  The analysis also involves comparing 'optimized' career paths (from the model) to 'actual' career paths to assess potential improvements.

sections.title: Methodological Note (Chapter 5)
sections.methods_summary: Data from Chapter 3 used; implementation scores computed for each category of school; paired t-tests used to determine significance of differences between model and non-model schools; highest possible score is 2.

sections.title: Methodological Note (Chapter 6)
sections.methods_summary: Focus on four of six core components; investigated relationship of average implementation scores with model support mechanisms and school characteristics using correlation and simple linear and multivariate regression models; simple regression models examined statistically significant correlations; differences in sample size among models considered.

analysis.sample_description: A cross-sectional sample of 250 model schools (36 AS, 42 CK, 93 DI, 79 SFA) and 190 matched comparison schools in Florida and Texas.  Data collected from principals and teachers via surveys, supplemented by case studies in 12 schools.  Initial longitudinal design was abandoned due to high attrition.
analysis.analysis_approach: Implementation scores were computed for each school, indicator, model, and survey year, standardized to allow comparison and aggregation.  Paired t-tests were used to compare model and non-model schools. Correlation and regression analyses examined relationships between implementation levels and support mechanisms/school characteristics.  Multiple imputation addressed missing data in multivariate analyses.

sections.title: Research Methodology: Analysis of Qatar’s Education System
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach involving school observations, interviews, and document analysis.  Data collection included site visits to approximately 15 schools (both public and private), interviews with over 200 stakeholders (teachers, students, parents, Ministry officials, university staff, and employers), and analysis of Ministry documents such as student test scores and curriculum materials.  The data analysis involved identifying strengths and weaknesses in the system, focusing on system integration, incentives and accountability, resource allocation, and curriculum and pedagogy.  The study concluded that a system-changing reform was necessary.

sections.title: Methodology: Examining the Existing System
sections.methods_summary: The initial study (2001-2002) involved on-site investigations in Doha, with the interdisciplinary team conducting observations at approximately 15 schools, interviews with over 200 individuals, and analysis of relevant documents.  The team collaborated with a Coordinating Committee to gather information and understand the social and cultural context.  The analysis identified strengths and weaknesses in the existing system, leading to the recommendation of system-changing solutions.

sections.title: Methodology:  Description of Qatar's Education System
sections.methods_summary: This section uses descriptive statistics and information from various sources, including the Ministry of Education, to describe the historical and political background, economy, population, and education system of Qatar.  The description includes data on school enrollment, teacher demographics, curriculum, and previous reform efforts. The methods are primarily descriptive and rely on secondary data analysis.

analysis.sample_description: The sample for the initial analysis included approximately 15 schools (public and private), over 200 interviewees from various stakeholder groups, and relevant Ministry documents.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of observations and interviews, quantitative analysis of existing data (e.g., test scores), and identification of themes and patterns to assess the strengths and weaknesses of the education system.

sections.title: Developing Curriculum Standards and Supporting Their Implementation; Developing the Assessment System; Establishing the Independent Schools
sections.methods_summary: This section details the process of developing curriculum standards, involving the selection of CfBT to develop drafts, review by independent experts, and finalization of standards for Arabic, English, mathematics, and science.  The development of the Qatar Student Assessment System (QSAS) is described, including standardized testing (Qatar Comprehensive Educational Assessment - QCEA) developed with Educational Testing Service and CTB, and surveys developed with the National Opinion Research Center.  The establishment of Independent schools involved developing guidelines and policies, selecting schools and operators, and supervising renovations.  The methods are largely descriptive, detailing the steps taken in the implementation process.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample includes all students in grades 1-12 in Qatar's publicly funded schools, some private schools, school administrators, principals, teachers, social workers, and students and their parents.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis is primarily descriptive, detailing the process of implementing the education reform.  Quantitative data from assessments and surveys are presented, but specific analytical techniques are not explicitly detailed.

sections.title: Methodology: Identifying, Evaluating, and Comparing Global Strike Options
sections.methods_summary: The study began with a set of building blocks (described below), experimented using an option-generation-and-screening tool, BCOT, and iterated.  The result was a shorter set of options.  Building blocks were added to a baseline program.  The building blocks were motivated by concerns about penetrating advanced air defenses, detecting mobile targets, timeliness, payload delivery, and SOF penetration.

sections.title: Methodology: Iterative Option Selection and Screening
sections.methods_summary: Using the BCOT tool, thousands of composite options were considered.  The analysis iteratively refined the building blocks, leading to conclusions about which options should be included in further analysis.  The analysis considered the sensitivity of dominant points to scenario classes and parameter assumptions.  The methodology involved computer-assisted analysis, but also incorporated analyst judgment.

sections.title: Methodology: Portfolio Analysis and Zooming
sections.methods_summary: The study used a portfolio-analysis tool (PAT) to organize information and generate displays.  The analysis included a summary scorecard, and allowed for zooming (drilling down) to understand the basis of top-level assessments.  Aggregation rules depended on the problem, ranging from simple averages to more complex rules for combining probabilities.  Zooming allowed for examination of systems analysis level details, such as parametric plots of search rate, false-alarm rate, and probability of finding a target.

sections.title: Methodology: Cost-Effectiveness Comparisons
sections.methods_summary: Cost-effectiveness was assessed by plotting effectiveness versus cost for various options.  The analysis acknowledged the sensitivity of results to assumptions.

sections.title: Methodology: Treatment of Risk
sections.methods_summary: The study considered various types of risk, including political and strategic risk during development, technical and programmatic risks, strategic risks at the time of execution, availability risk, operational-employment risks, and risks associated with operational and strategic effects.  Risks were aggregated using a worst-case approach.

sections.title: Methodology: Tools for Capabilities Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The study utilized systems engineering models, capability models (parametric models for systems analysis under uncertainty), an option generator and screener (BCOT), and a portfolio-analysis tool (PAT).

analysis.sample_description: No explicit sample description provided; the analysis is based on notional data and illustrative scenarios.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a multi-stage approach involving iterative option generation and screening, portfolio analysis with multiple levels of detail (zooming), and cost-effectiveness comparisons.  The analysis explicitly incorporates risk assessment and acknowledges the sensitivity of results to assumptions.

sections.title: Methodology: Assessing Current DLR Planning and Execution
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of existing DLR planning and execution decision rights and information flows.  Examination of current data collection and decision-making processes.  Qualitative analysis of existing systems and procedures. Table analysis to illustrate information availability and decision rights.

sections.title: Methodology: Designing a Common Operating Picture (COP) for DLR Sustainment
sections.methods_summary: Development of a conceptual framework for a closed-loop planning and execution system using MOEs and MOEIs.  Proposal of an organizational structure with a neutral integrator (AFMC CAM and GLSC) to facilitate planning and execution.  Description of a system for monitoring MOEIs and setting alarm thresholds using the Adams, Abell, and Isaacson forecasting approach.

sections.title: Methodology: Modeling DLR Sustainment
sections.methods_summary: Utilizing the Hillestad et al. (2006) capacity-sensitive computer model to examine the effects of different optempos and investments on NFMCD levels.  This model allows for rapid examination of various funding allocation scenarios and their impact on MOEs.

sections.title: Methodology: Identifying MOEIs and Setting Alarm Thresholds
sections.methods_summary: Identification of nine factors affecting NFMCD: optempo, component reliability, repair flow times, inventories, repair locations, transportation flow times, transportation capacity, repair capacity, and requisition priorities.  Use of the Adams, Abell, and Isaacson forecasting approach to estimate probability distributions of demands and set alarm thresholds.  Monitoring of pipeline quantities, hands-on repair time, capacity, and spare-part inventory changes to detect potential problems.

primary_methods: Adams, Abell, and Isaacson forecasting approach
analysis.sample_description: The study focuses on the Air Force's materiel sustainment system, specifically depot-level reparable (DLR) components for aircraft.  No specific sample size is mentioned, as the analysis is based on existing data and systems.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach is primarily qualitative, involving the examination of existing data, processes, and decision-making structures.  Quantitative methods are used in the context of applying existing models (Hillestad et al. 2006; Adams, Abell, and Isaacson) and in the proposal of statistical thresholds for monitoring MOEIs.

sections.title: Study Design and Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: The study used a three-pronged approach: 1) Review of existing Army and US military doctrine on IW intelligence and analytic requirements. 2) Identification of common logical lines of operation (LLOs) for IW missions, followed by brainstorming sessions to identify associated intelligence and analytic requirements. 3) Examination of the IW environment through various methodological lenses (expected utility modeling, social network analysis, media content analysis, public opinion analysis, and major theories related to IW, mobilization, etc.).  The resulting lists of requirements were cross-checked with area study outlines, curricula, and syllabi related to IW.

sections.title: Analytic Framework and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The core of the methodology is an eight-step analytic framework for assessing irregular warfare (IW) situations, divided into three main activities: 1) Initial assessment and data gathering (preliminary assessment, core issue/grievance identification, stakeholder identification, basic data collection). 2) Detailed stakeholder analyses (stakeholder characteristics, stakeholder network and relationship/link assessment, stakeholder leadership assessment). 3) Dynamic analyses (integration of intelligence information to understand a threat's likely course of action).  The framework incorporates various analytic techniques including agent-based rational choice models, link analysis/social network analysis, pattern analysis, cultural comparison matrices, historical timelines, perception assessment matrices, spatial analysis/map overlays, psychological profiles, and trend analyses.  The framework's compatibility with the standard Intelligence Preparation of the Battlefield (IPB) process is also discussed and assessed.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is a framework study, not an empirical study with a specific sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach involves a systematic, multi-faceted examination of irregular warfare, drawing on existing doctrine, theoretical frameworks, and various analytical techniques to develop a comprehensive framework for intelligence analysis.

sections.title: Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study selected 35 acquisition programs from a list of 125, using criteria such as at least 35% of planned procurement funded through FY 2004, MS B occurring after 1980, a solid baseline estimate at MS B, program not canceled after early production, and similarity in technical complexity to Air Force programs.  Data were collected from Selected Acquisition Reports (SARs), including development and procurement cost estimates, cost variances by category, unit-cost calculations, contract and procurement quantity information, and narrative discussions.  Two files were created for each program: a narrative document summarizing program history and issues, and a spreadsheet documenting milestones, cost estimates, variances, unit costs, procurement quantities, and trigger events.  Cost variances were categorized using a four-category system (errors, decisions, financial matters, miscellaneous) with subcategories.  The study acknowledges limitations of SAR data, such as aggregation, changing baselines, inconsistent reporting, and ambiguous variance explanations.

analysis.sample_description: 35 mature major defense acquisition programs (MDAPs), including 16 Air Force programs and 19 non-Air Force programs.  Programs were selected based on maturity, MS B date, baseline estimate quality, completion status, and technical complexity.
analysis.analysis_approach: Cost growth was analyzed using both simple and weighted averages, medians, and percentiles.  Cost variances from SARs were reclassified into a causally oriented category system.  The analysis compared cost growth across all programs, Air Force vs. non-Air Force programs, and program types (aircraft, missiles, electronics).

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research involved three lines of inquiry: gathering statistical information on trade and FDI flows from Ukrainian sources; reviewing past recommendations from the European Business Association and the Blue Ribbon Commission; and conducting interviews with US and other foreign investors and business groups in the US and Ukraine to determine what contributes to and detracts from trading with and investing in Ukraine.  More than two dozen interviews were conducted with foreign and Ukrainian business leaders, business groups, members of the financial and research communities, employees of international lending institutions, and Ukrainian government officials and leaders.

analysis.sample_description: Interviews were conducted with more than two dozen individuals in the US and Ukraine, including foreign and Ukrainian business leaders, business groups, members of the financial and research communities, employees of international lending institutions, and Ukrainian government officials and leaders.
analysis.analysis_approach: The statistical data was used to assess trends in Ukrainian trade and FDI. The literature review informed the evaluation of past recommendations and provided a basis for the researchers' own recommendations. The interviews formed the core of the report, providing insights into the barriers to trade and investment.

sections.title: Methodology: Analysis of S&E Workforce
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of Current Population Survey (CPS) data on wages of the science and engineering workforce.  The sample consisted of full-year, full-time workers (S&E and non-S&E) with annual earnings of $10,000 or more and at least a bachelor's degree.  Analysis included comparisons of median salaries across S&E occupations and education levels, and comparisons of salaries for U.S. citizens versus non-citizens.  Three-year moving averages were used for salary data.  Analysis also included unemployment rate comparisons between S&E and non-S&E occupations.

sections.title: Appendix: Current Population Survey Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Details on the analysis of Current Population Survey (CPS) data.  The sample included full-year, full-time workers with annual earnings of $10,000 or more and at least a bachelor's degree from 1989-2006 ASEC Supplements.  Person weights were used in CPS tabulations.

primary_methods: Data analysis of Current Population Survey (CPS) data
analysis.sample_description: Full-year, full-time workers (S&E and non-S&E) with annual earnings of $10,000 or more and at least a bachelor's degree.  Data from 1989-2006 Annual Social and Economic (ASEC) Supplements of the Current Population Survey (CPS).
analysis.analysis_approach: Comparisons of median salaries across S&E occupations and education levels, comparisons of salaries for U.S. citizens versus non-citizens, three-year moving averages for salary data, unemployment rate comparisons between S&E and non-S&E occupations, time-series analysis of R&D expenditures and other S&T indicators, and comparative analysis of quantitative indicators across nations/regions.

sections.title: Purpose and Approach
sections.methods_summary: Researchers reviewed the history of U.S. Army JTFs, analyzing missions and problems encountered. They analyzed alternative future national security environments to identify potential missions for Army-led JTFs.  Different approaches to providing JTF HQ and their preparation were considered.

analysis.sample_description: The study examined U.S. Army JTFs from 1970-2005, focusing on a subset of operations from 1999-2005 for detailed analysis.  Specific JTFs are highlighted in Chapters Two and Four, with a complete list in Appendix A.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved reviewing historical data on JTF deployments, missions, and staffing.  Alternative approaches to structuring Army-led JTFs were compared and evaluated based on their potential effectiveness in various scenarios.

sections.title: Four Approaches to Measuring the Impacts of WAPS Factors
sections.methods_summary: This section details four approaches to measuring the impact of WAPS factors.  Approach One uses standard deviations of WAPS factors for each AFSC. Approach Two divides the standard deviation of each AFSC's WAPS factors by the standard deviation of its total score. Approach Three measures the degree to which each individual's rank-ordered percentile changes as a WAPS component is removed. Approach Four calculates for each tester the absolute difference in standard deviations from the mean with and without each WAPS component score. The authors ultimately adopted Approach Four.

sections.title: Multivariate Models to Predict Selection Rates to E5
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the development of multivariate linear regression models to predict selection rates to E5 as a function of time in service.  The models included several predictor variables (EPR impact, decoration impact, testing impact, longevity impact, indicator variables for different selection cycles, and a CCS indicator variable).  Data from 87 AFSCs across eight selection cycles were used, focusing on those with four years TIS.  Four different models were developed based on seniority (TIS = 4, 5, 6, and 7).

sections.title: Multivariate Models to Predict Selection Rates to E6
sections.methods_summary: This section details the creation of multivariate linear regression models to predict selection rates to E6.  The models considered time in service, categorized into fast burner groups (FB, FB+1+2, FB+3+4, FB+5+6, FB+7+8) based on seniority. Data from 103 AFSCs across eight selection cycles were used, focusing on those with at least 25 E5 eligibles in a cycle. The models included similar predictor variables as the E5 models.

sections.title: Multivariate Models to Predict Selection Rates to E7
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the development of multivariate linear regression models to predict selection rates to E7.  Similar to the E5 and E6 analyses, models were created based on time in service (TIS ≤ 14 and TIS ≥ 19). Data from 84 AFSCs across eight selection cycles were used, with a minimum of 10 E6 eligibles per AFSC/cycle for the models.  Predictor variables were similar to those used in the E5 and E6 models.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the Air Force Personnel Center (AFPC) WAPS history file, focusing on various Air Force Specialty Codes (AFSCs) across multiple selection cycles (E5-E9).  Specific exclusions were made for tax AFSCs and AFSCs with insufficient eligibles or inconsistent testing impacts.  The sample size varied depending on the grade and seniority group being analyzed.
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis method is multivariate linear regression, used to predict selection rates based on various WAPS factors and seniority.  A simulation was also used to model the long-term effects of test score variance on senior NCO manning.

sections.title: Appendix A: RMS's Probabilistic Terrorism Model
sections.methods_summary: Description of the Risk Management Solutions (RMS) Probabilistic Terrorism Model used to estimate losses from terrorist attacks.  The model incorporates weapon effects, target characteristics, exposure characteristics, and expert judgment to estimate attack consequences and probabilities.

sections.title: Appendix B: Policyholder Take-Up of Terrorism Insurance
sections.methods_summary: Development of an insurer cost model to predict changes in terrorism insurance take-up rates. The model uses the RMS model's loss distribution, assumptions about insurer behavior (including capital requirements and pessimistic claim expectations), and an elasticity of demand to project changes in take-up rates based on changes in policy regimes (e.g., TRIA expiration, TRIA enhancements).

sections.title: Appendix B (continued): Parameterization and Calibration
sections.methods_summary: Description of parameter ranges used in the take-up rate model (take-up rates under TRIA, exceedance probability, demand elasticity, expense factor, cost of capital, insurer copayment). Calibration of the model using existing empirical studies on take-up rates with and without TRIA to constrain the range of plausible futures.

sections.title: Appendix C: Loss-Distribution Model
sections.methods_summary: Description of the loss-distribution model that allocates losses among stakeholders (insurance industry, uninsured, future policyholders, unpaid insured, taxpayers) under different government interventions.  The model uses total losses from the RMS model, take-up rates from the take-up model, and assumptions about government compensation and industry surplus.

sections.title: Appendix D: Identifying Key Factors Driving Trade-Offs
sections.methods_summary: Application of the Patient Rule Induction Method (PRIM) to identify key uncertain input factors driving trade-offs among government interventions. PRIM is used to generate clusters of scenarios with similar outcomes, highlighting the most influential factors.

sections.title: Appendix E: Calculating Expected Losses with Multiple Probability Distributions
sections.methods_summary: Calculation of expected values for outcome measures using multiple plausible probability distributions for terrorist attack sizes.  The RMS distributions are used as a base, and the tails are reweighted to create a range of plausible distributions.

sections.title: Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: A simulation model is used to compare outcomes of different government interventions across a wide range of plausible scenarios.  The model includes a terrorist-attack model (RMS), a take-up rate model, a postattack government compensation model, and an insurance-compensation and loss-distribution model. A robust decisionmaking (RDM) approach is used to handle deep uncertainties.

sections.title: Analytic Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study uses a robust decisionmaking (RDM) approach, employing a simulation model to project outcomes under different government interventions across a wide range of plausible futures.  The simulation model incorporates a terrorist-attack model (RMS), a take-up rate model, a postattack government compensation model, and a loss-distribution model.  The RDM approach involves running the model over a large number of scenarios generated by varying uncertain input parameters (described in Table 2.3) and analyzing the results to identify robust interventions.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses a large ensemble of plausible futures (scenarios) generated by varying numerous uncertain input parameters, including attack type and size, take-up rates, government compensation levels, and insurer beliefs about the TRIA cap.  The number of scenarios varies depending on the specific analysis (e.g., 2,838 for conventional attacks with uncertain cap, 5,676 for NBCR attacks with uncertain cap).
analysis.analysis_approach: The simulation model projects outcomes (e.g., taxpayer cost, uncompensated losses) under different government interventions (TRIA, no program, modified TRIA with NBCR coverage).  The RDM approach helps identify robust interventions—those that perform well across a wide range of plausible futures.  Statistical methods (PRIM) are used to identify key factors driving trade-offs among interventions.  Expected values are calculated using multiple plausible probability distributions for attack sizes.

sections.title: MHS Senior Leaders' Views on the Value of AHLTA: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A series of 14 semi-structured interviews were conducted with senior MHS leadership.  The interviews, lasting 45 minutes to one hour, followed a protocol approved by RAND’s Human Subjects Protection Committee.  Interviewees discussed their roles and responsibilities related to AHLTA, anticipated effects of AHLTA on strategic performance, AHLTA's role in performance measurement, and their general perceptions of AHLTA. Thematic analysis was used to identify emerging themes.

sections.title: Analyzing the Effect of AHLTA on the Strategic Performance of the Military Health System: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a treatment-outcomes methodology with four key elements: (1) outcome measures (MHS strategic objectives); (2) treatments (specific uses of AHLTA); (3) logic models (qualitative descriptions of cause-and-effect relationships); and (4) evaluation design (pre-post comparison, pre-post comparison with control, pre-post comparison with randomization). Regression models were used to compute quantitative measures of AHLTA's effects.  The study also utilized logic models as a framework for gathering indirect evidence and substantiating cause-and-effect relationships where quantitative data were insufficient.  Event chains were used to combine qualitative and quantitative evidence.

sections.title: Potential Benefits of EMR Systems: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A review of the published literature on EMR systems was conducted to identify specific uses of EMRs that produce benefits and the mechanisms by which those benefits arise.  This literature review informed the selection of AHLTA-related treatments and the construction of logic models.

sections.title: Measures for the MHS Strategic Objectives: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study identified concrete, detailed measures and associated them with strategic objectives.  It prioritized measures from well-accepted measure sets (HEDIS, Joint Commission) and suggested new measures where existing sets were lacking.  The study used the National Quality Measures Clearinghouse (NQMC) database, which contained 1,153 measures.  A catalog of these measures was created.  Each NQMC measure was associated with strategic objectives.  The study also explored the use of 'episodes of care' as units of analysis and discussed challenges in identifying all healthcare events within an episode.

sections.title: Strategic Management: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study described approaches for constructing strategic measures from detailed measures, focusing on the structure of detailed measures (eligibility and score for each individual).  It discussed the creation of composite measures by combining multiple detailed measures.  Logic models and event chains were used to reduce the number of measures considered.  The study emphasized the importance of establishing an analytical support group to select information for senior leaders, design composite measures, and drill down to component measures when necessary.  The study also discussed using standard subsets of beneficiaries (e.g., by age and treating MTF) and building models to estimate measure value as a function of various data elements.

analysis.sample_description: For the interview section, the sample consisted of 14 senior MHS leaders.  The database analysis section utilized the NQMC database of 1,153 measures.
analysis.analysis_approach: Thematic analysis was used for the interviews.  Regression models were used for quantitative analysis of AHLTA's effects.  Logic models and event chains were used to analyze cause-and-effect relationships and to support qualitative analysis.  Composite measures were created to summarize detailed measures.

sections.title: Methodology: Categorizing US Security Cooperation
sections.methods_summary: Review of classified and unclassified State Department and DoD security cooperation strategies to identify major categories of US government security cooperation efforts.  These categories are used as a framework for analyzing security cooperation in Iraq and Afghanistan.

sections.title: Methodology: Assessing Security Cooperation Activities
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of the appropriateness of 14 categories of security cooperation and operational assistance for four different political and security environments in Iraq and Afghanistan (compatible-secure, compatible-insecure, incompatible-secure, incompatible-insecure).  This is presented graphically in Figure 3.1.

analysis.sample_description: The study analyzes US security cooperation strategies and their application to Iraq and Afghanistan, considering various political and security scenarios.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a framework of security cooperation categories to assess the appropriateness of different activities under various political and security conditions in Iraq and Afghanistan.  The analysis is largely qualitative, using existing data and reports to support its conclusions.

sections.title: Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The study uses a mix of existing and new analytical techniques, informed by experience in Iraq and Afghanistan.  Data sources include significant activities (SIGACTS) reports, which are analyzed for patterns and to develop indicators.  Methods include pattern classification methods, hierarchical decision trees, linear discriminant analysis, predictive analyses (statistical analysis of past insurgent behavior), social network analysis (SNA), game theory, and change detection (using Blue Force Tracker data).

sections.title: Intelligence Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Data collection focuses on significant activities (SIGACTS) reports, noting issues like uneven reporting and lack of standardized lexicon.  Methods used include: discerning patterns (pattern classification, hierarchical decision trees, linear discriminant analysis, Bayesian classification), predictive analyses (statistical analysis of past insurgent behavior, K-Means Clustering), analyzing insurgent networks (creating a 'Counterinsurgency Common Operational Picture' or COINCOP), and analyzing friendly-enemy interactions (game theory and change detection using Blue Force Tracker data).

sections.title: Enemy-Friendly Interaction Analyses
sections.methods_summary: This section focuses on analyzing friendly-enemy interactions using two methods: game theory (modeling Red-Blue interactions as a non-cooperative, two-player, zero-sum game) and response detection (analyzing Blue Force Tracker data to identify changes in friendly force activity and corresponding enemy responses, using statistical tests and a nonlinear equation to model Red response to Blue activity).

analysis.sample_description: Data from Iraq and Afghanistan, specifically significant activities (SIGACTS) reports and Blue Force Tracker (BFT) data.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis focuses on developing indicators of insurgent activity, predicting future attacks, understanding insurgent networks, and analyzing the interaction between friendly and enemy forces.  Both quantitative and qualitative methods are employed, with a focus on adapting methods to the dynamic and localized nature of insurgency.

sections.title: Research Design and Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the capabilities-based assessment (CBA) methodology, which involves a functional area analysis (FAA), functional needs analysis (FNA), and functional solution analysis (FSA).  The FAA, the focus of this document, identifies operational tasks, conditions, and standards for intratheater airlift. Data sources include guidance documents (National Security Strategy, National Defense Strategy, Joint Operations Concepts, etc.),  meetings with Air Force personnel, and analysis of recent operations in Afghanistan and Iraq.

sections.title: Literature Review and Guidance Document Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This section details the various guidance documents used to inform the FAA, including the JCIDS process guidance, National Security Strategy, National Defense Strategy, Joint Operations Concepts family of documents (CCJO, JOCs, JFCs, JICs), the U.S. Air Force Transformation Flight Plan 2004, Global Mobility CONOPS, the Air Mobility Master Plan, and the Army's vision for fixed-wing aviation. The analysis involved reviewing these documents to identify relevant tasks, conditions, and standards for intratheater airlift.

sections.title: Scenario Development and Variable Identification
sections.methods_summary: The methodology involved using Defense Planning Scenarios and historical experience from Afghanistan and Iraq to understand the operational environment and potential shortfalls in intratheater airlift.  Critical variables influencing the analysis were identified (e.g., number of delivery points, terrain, threat level, supply characteristics, team characteristics).  The analysis considered a range of operational environments and scenarios to ensure robustness.

sections.title: Task Identification and Categorization
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the process of identifying relevant tasks from the Universal Joint Task List (UJTL) and the Air Force Master Capabilities Library (MCL) for each of the three operational mission areas (routine sustainment, time-sensitive/mission-critical resupply, and maneuver).

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is a policy analysis, not an empirical study with a defined sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of existing documents and scenarios to identify tasks, conditions, and standards for intratheater airlift.  The analysis is structured around three operational mission areas.

sections.title: Data and Sources
sections.methods_summary: Data from the Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP), Survey of Inmates in State and Federal Correctional Facilities, Survey of Inmates of Local Jails, Current Population Survey, Medicare and Medicaid Statistical Supplement, and Digest of Education Statistics were used.  The unit of analysis is the individual. Data mapping and aggregation were performed for educational attainment and population identifiers.  Assumptions were made regarding income distribution within households and cost per inmate/participant.

sections.title: Estimating Tax Payments
sections.methods_summary: Two-part models were used for payroll taxes (probit for participation, OLS for tax amount). OLS regression was used for federal and state income taxes. Independent variables included educational attainment, age (and age squared), interactions between education and age, race/ethnicity dummies, and a dummy for immigrant status. Separate models were run for men and women.

sections.title: Social Program Participation and Costs
sections.methods_summary: Two-part models (probit for utilization, OLS for benefit amount) were used for most social programs (welfare, food stamps, SSI, Social Security, Unemployment Insurance).  A single-part probit model was used for subsidized housing. Two-part models were also used for Medicare and Medicaid, with separate models for inpatient and outpatient utilization.  Administrative data were used to supplement SIPP data for benefit amounts in some cases.  Separate models were run for elderly and non-elderly populations where appropriate.  The response variables were transformed (logarithmic or square root) for normality.

sections.title: Incarceration Cost Estimations
sections.methods_summary: Probability of incarceration was estimated using data from the Survey of Inmates in State and Federal Correctional Facilities and the Current Population Survey.  Per-person incarceration costs were obtained from the Sourcebook of Criminal Justice Statistics.  A two-part model approach was used, but no regression was performed for the probability of incarceration.

sections.title: Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study estimated the effects of increased educational attainment on tax revenues, social program expenditures, and incarceration costs.  A nationally representative sample of approximately 40,000 individuals from the 2002 SIPP was used.  Separate analyses were conducted for different demographic groups (gender and race/ethnicity).  National average costs for public education were used to estimate the costs of providing additional education.  All dollar amounts were discounted to 2002 dollars using a 3 percent annual discount rate.  The study focused on U.S.-born individuals due to data limitations for immigrants.

sections.title: Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a nationally representative sample of approximately 40,000 individuals from the 2002 SIPP to estimate the relationships between education level and various government revenues and costs.  Independent variables included educational attainment, age (and age squared), interactions between education and age, race/ethnicity dummies, and a dummy for immigrant status. Separate models were run for men and women.  Two-part models (probit and OLS) were used for payroll taxes and many social programs. OLS regression was used for federal and state income taxes.  Data were transformed (logarithmic or square root) to address right-skewness.  Survival rates were used to project lifetime effects.  A sensitivity analysis was conducted by reducing the estimated effects of education by 25 percent.  The study assumed that observed relationships reflected causal effects of education, but acknowledged potential confounding factors.  Future trends were assumed to be similar to those observed in 2002.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative sample of roughly 40,000 individuals from the 2002 Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP), focusing primarily on U.S.-born individuals due to data limitations for immigrants.  The sample was further divided into subgroups based on gender and race/ethnicity.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study employed a combination of statistical modeling techniques, including two-part models (probit and OLS regression), and single-part OLS regression.  Data transformations (logarithmic and square root) were used to address right-skewness in financial variables.  Survival rates were incorporated to project lifetime effects of educational attainment on government revenues and costs.  All dollar amounts were discounted to 2002 values using a 3% annual discount rate.  A sensitivity analysis was conducted to assess the robustness of the findings to variations in the estimated effects of education.

sections.title: Approach and Analytical Techniques
sections.methods_summary: This study used a mixed-methods approach combining content analysis of newspaper articles from the Columbus Dispatch and Toledo Blade (January 1, 2003 – June 30, 2006) and key respondent interviews with criminal justice officials and social service providers (February – July 2007).  The content analysis used 14 search terms related to human trafficking. Key respondent interviews were conducted using a snowball sampling technique, targeting 44 respondents from 30 agencies; 26 ultimately participated. The study focused on 'concrete cases'—those with evidence supporting a trafficking offense under the TVPA definition.

sections.title: Analytical Techniques: Content Analysis and Key Respondent Interviews
sections.methods_summary: Content analysis of newspaper articles (Columbus Dispatch and Toledo Blade) from January 1, 2003 to June 30, 2006, using 14 search terms related to human trafficking. Key respondent interviews (February-July 2007) with 26 individuals from 19 agencies (11 criminal justice, 8 social services) using snowball sampling. Interview instrument covered existence of human trafficking, case characteristics, organizational responses, collaboration, and policy recommendations.

analysis.sample_description: Two urban Ohio communities, Columbus and Toledo, were selected as case study sites due to factors suggesting susceptibility to human trafficking (e.g., proximity to transportation routes, immigrant populations, economic conditions).  A snowball sampling technique was used for the key respondent interviews.
analysis.analysis_approach: A mixed-methods approach was used. Content analysis identified articles relevant to human trafficking, focusing on 'concrete cases' meeting the TVPA definition.  Interview data provided additional context and perspectives on the identified cases and the responses of the criminal justice and social service communities.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research combined qualitative and quantitative methods.  Data sources included analysis of Selected Acquisition Reports (SARs), interviews (111 participants across three categories), a model of cost analysis personnel demand, and a survey of program offices for personnel and workload data.  Qualitative methods involved semi-structured and unstructured interviews. Quantitative methods included a RAND cost-variance categorization methodology applied to SAR data and a model to analyze cost analysis personnel requirements.

analysis.sample_description: 111 interviewees: 55 involved in case studies (SBIRS-High and GPS), 42 from SMC program offices, and 14 from other cost analysis organizations.  Data also collected from surveys of SMC program offices.
analysis.analysis_approach: RAND cost-variance categorization methodology used to analyze SAR data.  A dynamic monthly forecasting model estimated personnel requirements.  Qualitative data from interviews analyzed to identify systemic problems and best practices.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research drew on a large body of ethnographic, political, and economic literature.  For the political section, official statements, published studies, and Iranian weblogs were assessed. For the demographic section, Iranian and Western studies and population projections from the U.S. Census Bureau were used. For the economic section, primary data from the Central Bank of Iran and data from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) were used.  Vulnerabilities were identified and the effectiveness of Iranian government measures to mitigate them were evaluated.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is not an empirical study with a defined sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of existing data and evaluation of government policies.

sections.title: Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods approach.  It involved a literature review of longitudinal SUR systems and state experiences, interviews with SUR administrators in four states (Florida, Kentucky, Oregon, and Texas), a review and documentation of California's SUR data systems (including web data and file dictionaries), interviews with California stakeholders (state-level, education segment leaders, and researchers), and a review of relevant California state law and Memorandums of Understanding.

analysis.sample_description: Four states (Florida, Kentucky, Oregon, and Texas) were selected for interviews based on literature review, conversations with NCHEMS staff, data matching capacity, system size, SUR content breadth, and number of higher education governance systems.  In California, interviews were conducted with stakeholders from various institutions (Cal-PASS, CDE, CCCCO, etc.).
analysis.analysis_approach: The information collected from various respondents was systematically grouped by topic and compared within and across respondent types to identify key issues.  This synthesized information was used to develop recommendations.

sections.title: Industry Survey Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Semi-structured interviews with aircraft industry leaders using a list of seed questions to explore sources of cost escalation, evolution of aircraft complexity, impact of regulatory changes, overhead cost growth, changes in the industrial base, government reporting requirements, and potential cost-reduction initiatives.

sections.title: Data Collection and Preparation
sections.methods_summary: Data were collected from three primary sources: the Historical Aircraft Procurement Cost Archive (HAPCA), a Congressional Budget Office (CBO) study, and P-1 budget documents.  The data included procurement costs and quantities, and technical characteristics.  Data limitations are discussed, including incomplete technical information and the aggregation of certain cost elements. Costs were adjusted for inflation using the standard Navy aircraft procurement (APN) deﬂator.  The analysis used varying subsets of aircraft data depending on the specific analysis being conducted.

sections.title: Cost Escalation Measurement and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Cost escalation was quantified using annual growth rates calculated using a compound function (Equation 2.1) and optimized least squares regression for multiple observations.  The analysis compared aircraft cost escalation rates to common inflation indices (CPI, DoD procurement deﬂator, GDP deﬂator).  Trends in unit procurement costs and flyaway costs were examined and compared.  The analysis also considered the impact of upgrades and improvements within aircraft programs.

sections.title: Analysis of Economy-Driven Factors
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of economy-driven factors (labor, material, equipment, fees, and profits) used data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) and Contractor Cost Data Reports (CCDRs).  The relative importance of these factors was determined using CCDR data.  Trends in labor rates, material and equipment costs, G&A costs, material overhead, and operating margins were analyzed using regression analysis and other statistical methods. A notional aircraft comparison was used to illustrate the combined contribution of these factors to cost escalation.

sections.title: Analysis of Customer-Driven Factors
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of customer-driven factors (quantity effects, cost improvement, procurement rate, configuration changes, technical characteristics, airframe materials) used regression analysis.  Cost improvement and procurement rate effects were modeled using Equations 4.1 and 4.2. Configuration change effects were incorporated into the regression analysis (Equation 4.3).  The relationship between technical characteristics (empty weight, maximum speed, carrier-based, electronic, bomber) and unit cost was analyzed using Equation 4.4.  The effect of airframe materials complexity was analyzed using Equation 4.5. Pairwise comparisons of aircraft were conducted to assess the relative contributions of economy-driven and customer-driven factors to cost escalation.  A regulatory factor was included in the pairwise comparisons based on a separate analysis of submarine construction.

analysis.sample_description: The study analyzed data on a wide range of Air Force and Navy fixed-wing aircraft, including various mission types (patrol, cargo, trainer, bomber, attack, fighter, electronic warfare).  The specific aircraft included in each analysis varied depending on data availability and the requirements of the statistical models. Appendix A provides a detailed list of the aircraft used in each part of the analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis disaggregated cost escalation into economy-driven and customer-driven factors.  Regression analysis was used extensively to model the relationships between various factors and aircraft costs.  Pairwise comparisons were used to assess the relative importance of these factors in explaining cost escalation between different aircraft types and generations.  The study also incorporated inflation adjustments to account for changes in the overall economic environment.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: This monograph relies heavily on interviews with maritime experts and intelligence and security analysts.  The interviews were conducted on a not-for-attribution basis due to the sensitivity of the subject matter.  The monograph also draws on data from the International Maritime Bureau (IMB), other published reports, and publicly available information.

analysis.sample_description: The interviews included maritime experts and intelligence and security analysts.  The number of interviewees is not specified, but the text indicates numerous interviews were conducted.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis assesses the nature, scope, and dimensions of piracy and maritime terrorism, examining their interrelationship and relevance to U.S. national and international security interests.  The analysis draws on data from various sources to identify trends and contributing factors.

sections.title: Strategies-to-Tasks Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This methodology identifies tasks needed to achieve specific military objectives, starting with the National Military Strategy and cascading down through national military objectives, campaign objectives, operational objectives, operational tasks, functions, and finally, operational systems.  This assessment of ship characteristics stops short of defining ship systems.

sections.title: Methodology: Linking Missions and Tasks
sections.methods_summary: A strategies-to-tasks approach was used to develop required characteristics of a small vessel conducting TSC operations.  This involved reconciling two task lists (one from OPNAV N816 and one generated by RAND) using the strategies-to-tasks methodology.  The study also adopted a "Use of the Sea" framework to describe maritime needs of nations, comparing the needs of the U.S. Navy with those of potential partner nations.  The constabulary role was examined in detail, considering maritime presence and police operations.

sections.title: Vessel Survey and Assessment
sections.methods_summary: A world survey of over 1000 vessels from over 60 nations was conducted, using data from Haze Gray website and Jane’s Intelligence Service.  The survey results were cross-checked against material provided by OPNAV N81.  A qualitative assessment using a stoplight system (red, yellow, green) was used to judge the performance of each vessel class against identified capabilities in two task lists.  Cost estimates were also provided for each vessel class.

analysis.sample_description: The study focused on 21 countries of interest to the U.S. Navy in sub-Saharan Africa, and also considered vessels from other regions (Central America, Caribbean, Northern South America, Western Pacific).  The vessel survey included over 1000 vessels from over 60 nations.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study used a cascading methodology to link high-level strategic objectives to specific vessel characteristics.  Qualitative assessments were made to evaluate the capabilities of different vessel classes against identified tasks and capabilities.  Cost estimates were used to compare the economic feasibility of different options.

sections.title: Methodology for UAE Case Study
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of reports, public websites, and interviews with government officials in the education and labor market sectors.  Documentation of initiatives to expand human capital and increase participation in the private sector, focusing on education (K-12, post-secondary, and training) and labor market (economic diversification, privatization, and employment policy levers) reforms. Measurement of changes against policy goals (where data available). Examination of resources for policy evaluation and development. Discussion of opportunities for improving data collection and analysis systems.

sections.title: Methodology for Oman Case Study
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of information from reports, public websites, and interviews with government officials and private sector leaders.  Focus on education and labor market initiatives, measuring changes against policy goals where possible. Discussion of data resources for policy evaluation and development.

sections.title: Methodology for Lebanon Case Study
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of secondary data and interviews with government officials and private sector leaders (conducted January-June 2006, prior to the 2006 Hezbollah-Israel conflict). Description of policy approaches to addressing human resource problems. Discussion of data resources for assessing progress in human capital development and other economic outcomes.

sections.title: Overall Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Review of relevant literature, collection of population and labor force data from international and in-country sources, and a series of elite interviews with government officials and individuals in private organizations in the study countries (January-August 2006 in Lebanon, Oman, and the UAE; 2001-2006 in Qatar).

analysis.sample_description: Four Middle Eastern countries: Lebanon, Oman, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates.  Selection based on reliance on natural resources, sociopolitical system, economic diversity, and labor pool composition.
analysis.analysis_approach: Three-part framework: 1) Identification of human resource challenges; 2) Cataloguing policy approaches; 3) Examining resources for policy evaluation.  Analysis of data and information to understand human resource issues, reform policies, and policy evaluation mechanisms.  Comparison of reform strategies across countries.

sections.title: Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: A three-part analytic framework was used.  First, the most pressing human resource issues were identified for each country. Second, policy approaches to address these issues were cataloged. Third, the availability of resources for evaluating the policies was examined.  This involved analysis of data from in-country and international sources, reports, and interviews with key decisionmakers.

sections.title: Approach to Data Collection and Interviews
sections.methods_summary: Two data sources were used: analysis of secondary data from government organizations and international databases (UNDP, UNESCO, World Bank, IMF); and semi-structured interviews with officials in the government and private sectors of each country (except Qatar, where existing RAND studies were used).

sections.title: Rationale for Country Selection
sections.methods_summary: The study included three Gulf countries (Oman, Qatar, UAE) and one non-Gulf country (Lebanon) to compare reform strategies.  The selection also considered logistical constraints, including proximity to the RAND office in Doha and existing relationships.

sections.title: Limitations of the Study
sections.methods_summary: The study did not formally evaluate whether reforms met their goals due to the nascent stage of many policies and data limitations.  Generalization to other Arab countries is not recommended due to the diversity of the region.

sections.title: Data Collection and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The study relied on secondary data sources and interviews.  The interviews aimed to understand human resource challenges, reform efforts, and policy evaluation mechanisms.  The secondary data included population, economic, education, and labor market data from country-level and international sources.

analysis.sample_description: Four countries were selected: Lebanon, Oman, Qatar, and the UAE.  The selection was based on a combination of factors including resource richness, political systems, economic diversity, and labor pool composition, as well as logistical considerations.
analysis.analysis_approach: A three-part framework was used to analyze data: diagnosis and articulation of the problem, approaches to addressing the problem, and availability of resources for policy evaluation.  The analysis drew on both quantitative and qualitative data sources.

sections.title: First Survey: Data Collection and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: A paper questionnaire was administered in person to a purposive sample of Army officers at Fort Benning, Fort Sill, Fort Leavenworth, and the Army War College between January and April 2007. Data entry was performed in Microsoft Access, and quality assurance was conducted by a separate team member.  Analysis was performed using Stata software, including descriptive statistics, correlations, and hypothesis tests. Written responses were analyzed separately for patterns.

sections.title: Second Survey: Sampling Design, Data Collection, and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: A stratified random sample of 6,996 officers (O-2 through O-6) from selected combat and combat support branches was drawn from the Officer Master File (OMF) database.  An online survey was administered, with eligibility determined by deployment history to Iraq or Afghanistan between 2001 and the survey date.  Sampling weights were calculated to account for stratification and nonresponse.  Poststratification was used for formal system responses. Data cleaning involved handling ineligible respondents, imputing missing data, and adjusting for discrepancies between self-reported and OMF data. Analysis was performed using Stata and SAS software, including weighted means, confidence intervals, correlations, and hypothesis tests.

sections.title: National Training Center Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Data from NTC rotations (March 2005–March 2006) were analyzed.  Company and platoon use of digital C4ISR systems was assessed based on observer/controller ratings.  Unit performance was evaluated across multiple dimensions.  A 2x2 table analysis and phi coefficient were used to assess correlations between digital system use and performance measures.  Caveats regarding non-independence of observations and heterogeneity of missions/units are noted.

analysis.sample_description: The study used multiple samples: a purposive sample of Army officers for the first survey, a stratified random sample of Army officers for the second survey, and data from NTC rotations for the quantitative analysis.  Specific details on sample sizes and characteristics are provided within each methodology section.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved both qualitative and quantitative methods. Qualitative analysis included case studies and thematic analysis of open-ended survey responses. Quantitative analysis involved descriptive statistics, correlation analysis (including the phi coefficient), and hypothesis testing.  Weighting was used to adjust for sampling design and nonresponse in the second survey.

sections.title: Study Objective and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used literature reviews, analysis of historical data from defense and commercial industries, and interviews with experts from the titanium manufacturing and processing industries, the aircraft manufacturing industry, and government agencies (USGS and BLS).

analysis.sample_description: Experts from titanium manufacturing and processing industries, aircraft manufacturing industry, and government agencies (USGS and BLS).
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis of historical data and trends, comparison of supply and demand scenarios.

sections.title: Elements of an Enhanced Approach to Security Cooperation
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines an approach for enhancing Air Force security cooperation by considering five key elements.  These elements include determining U.S. strategic interests, assessing a partner’s security needs, determining comparative advantage, selecting capabilities, and managing U.S.-partner relationships. Decision trees are used to illustrate the approach to assessing partner needs and selecting capabilities.  A comparative advantage technique is described for choosing among potential partners based on cost and probability of favorable behavior in a crisis.

sections.title: Building Partner Capacity Based on Comparative Advantage Considerations
sections.methods_summary: A comparative advantage technique is described for determining whether to build a capability with a partner. This involves estimating the cost of producing the capability within the partner's military and estimating the likelihood that the partner would behave in a way consistent with U.S. interests in a crisis.  These factors are multiplied to determine a net value for each potential partner, allowing for direct comparisons.

sections.title: Selecting Capabilities to Build with Partners
sections.methods_summary: Inductive and deductive approaches are described for selecting capabilities. The inductive approach starts with a partner's security needs and considers how key operational functions of airpower contribute to addressing those needs. The deductive approach starts with the partner's security strategy and disaggregates it into constituent tasks to identify needed capabilities. A decision tree is used to illustrate the final vetting and selection process, considering factors such as appropriateness given global/theater circumstances, attractiveness to the partner, and cost.

sections.title: Managing Building Partner Capacity Relationships and Programs
sections.methods_summary: A decision tree is presented to outline an approach for managing U.S.-partner relationships.  This involves assessing whether objectives are still appropriate, whether the program is progressing satisfactorily, and whether additional capabilities are likely to improve outcomes.  The decision tree guides decisions about continuing, expanding, or cutting existing programs.

sections.title: Overall Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study team conducted a literature review of national, DoD, and Air Force strategic guidance on security cooperation and building partner capacity.  They reviewed background reports and after-action reviews from several efforts and data in the Air Force Knowledgebase.  They conducted extensive interviews with key policy planners and implementers in the Air Force, COCOMs, component commands, and other entities.  Finally, they conducted focused discussions with selected allies on their bilateral security cooperation programs.

analysis.sample_description: Six ongoing case studies of Air Force security cooperation activities were selected to illustrate the breadth and variation of approaches.  The cases include efforts from each COCOM, bilateral and multilateral training, conventional and unconventional training methods, and activities beyond security assistance.
analysis.analysis_approach: Macro-level analysis of security assistance data (FMS, FMF, IMET) was conducted to assess responsiveness to strategic shifts.  Micro-level analysis of the six case studies examined planning, evaluation, and resourcing criteria.  Decision trees were used to guide the analysis of partner needs, capability selection, and relationship management.  The analysis focused on identifying issues, problems, lessons, and best practices.

sections.title: Chapter 5: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of data from the Current Population Survey (CPS) and the National Health Interview Survey (NHIS).  The CPS data included information on disability, health status, and income. The NHIS data provided more detailed information on health conditions and behaviors.  Logistic regression models were used to estimate the likelihood of experiencing various health conditions as a function of occupation, controlling for demographic characteristics.  The analysis accounted for the survey design weights, stratification, and clustering.

sections.title: Chapter 6: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Data from 29 California public employers were linked to California Public Employees' Retirement System (CalPERS) data.  The analysis compared rates of permanent partial disability (PPD) benefits receipt among public safety and non-safety employees.  The analysis controlled for age and accounted for potential biases in the matching process and differences in claiming behavior.  The analysis made three critical assumptions: differences in workers' compensation claiming rates correlate strongly with differences in injury rates; receipt of PPD benefits is a reliable indicator of a work-limiting disability; and PPD claims are evaluated the same across public safety and non-safety occupations.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Literature review, roundtable discussions with public safety personnel in California, analysis of national survey data (CPS and NHIS), and analysis of administrative data from California on workers' compensation claims and disability retirement.

primary_methods: Administrative data analysis (workers' compensation, retirement data)
analysis.sample_description: The study used multiple samples:  men aged 18-50 from the CPS, men aged 18-65 from the NHIS, and California public employees from workers' compensation and retirement data.  The California sample focused on retirees from 1991-2006.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, logistic regression modeling to control for demographic factors and compare health outcomes across occupations.  Odds ratios were calculated to compare the likelihood of various health conditions across occupational groups.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A mathematical model was developed to simulate counterland air-ground interactions in a scenario focused on disrupting enemy ground force maneuver.  The model uses differential equations (including a modified Lanchester square law for close combat) to calculate the drawdown of Red and Blue force strengths based on input values representing various factors such as battlespace characteristics, weapon effectiveness, ISR capabilities, C2 throughput, and communications limitations.  A sensitivity analysis was conducted to assess the impact of variations in these input values on the effectiveness of different air-ground integration options.

analysis.sample_description: The model simulates a scenario involving Blue (friendly) and Red (enemy) ground forces, with initial force sizes of 15 and 75 battalions respectively, operating in a 100 nm wide x 150 nm deep area of operations.  Variations in enemy tactics and battlespace conditions are explored through sensitivity analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: The effectiveness of different air-ground integration options is compared by measuring the number of aircraft needed to reduce Red force strength by 50% while ensuring that at least 90% of Blue forces remain.  The model calculates force drawdown over time based on engagement potential (EP) rates, which are influenced by weapon potential, ISR effectiveness, C2 constraints, and communications limitations.  Sensitivity analysis examines the impact of varying input values on the results.

sections.title: A Note on Sources
sections.methods_summary: The research utilized abundant resources, including assistance from French officials, online information from French military institutions (Doctrine journal and C2SD research), and legislative reports.

sections.title: Methodology: Joint Training Norms
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of French joint-training norms from a legislative document (Table 3.1) and analysis of major French joint exercises from the État-Major des Armées website (Table 3.2).

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used a comparative case study approach, examining the military establishments of China, France, the UK, India, and Israel.  The methodology involved identifying defense establishments, strategic demands, priorities, mission sets, training programs for adapting forces, and unique training regimes for specific missions.  Open-source materials and unclassified interviews were used.

analysis.sample_description: The study examined the militaries of China, France, the United Kingdom, India, and Israel.
analysis.analysis_approach: Comparative analysis of training models and practices across the five countries, focusing on similarities and differences with the U.S. military system.  The analysis also considered adaptability and the Train, Advise, and Assist mission.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The research draws from a range of primary and secondary sources, including over 50 interviews with diplomatic, military, and security officials, local think tanks, scholars, journalists, Islamists, oppositionists, and other political actors in Egypt, Jordan, Israel, Lebanon, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, and the UAE in 2007 and 2008.  Arabic and Persian-language strategy pieces, opinion polls, indigenous news outlets, and internet chat rooms were also consulted.

analysis.sample_description: Over 50 interviews conducted in 2007 and 2008 with a range of individuals in eight Middle Eastern countries.  Also included analysis of Arabic and Persian-language documents, opinion polls, and internet forums.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data and documents, descriptive analysis of secondary data.

sections.title: Chapter Eight: Analytic Methods
sections.methods_summary: Propensity score weighting and doubly robust regression; Generalized Additive Mixed Models (GAMM).

sections.title: Chapter Nine: Analytic Methods
sections.methods_summary: Propensity score weighting and doubly robust regression; Regression Discontinuity Design (RDD) models.

sections.title: Chapter Ten: Analytic Methods
sections.methods_summary: Survey weighting; Imputation (polytomous item response theory); Estimation of survey scale scores; Multiple statistical tests (adjusting for false discovery rate); Regression models (weighted least squares, logistic regression).

sections.title: Appendix A: Technical Appendix for Achievement Models
sections.methods_summary: Detailed explanation of propensity score weighting and doubly robust regression, RDD methods, hierarchical and GAMM models used in Chapters Eight and Nine.

sections.title: Chapter Four: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Data collection included interviews with RDISs and SSO leaders, case studies of schools, SPAs, and SSAs, administrator surveys, student surveys, data on school characteristics, and longitudinally linked data on 5th- and 3rd-grade cohorts.  Analysis methods included qualitative research methods (coding), document review, cross-tabulations, statistical tests for differences in means and proportions, logistic regression, OLS regression, propensity score weighting, doubly robust regression models, GAMM, and RDD models.

primary_methods: Qualitative research methods (interviews, focus groups, observations, document review)
Surveys (principals, AIS team leaders, SPA and SSA administrators, students)
