Quantitative analysis (descriptive statistics, regression analysis, propensity score matching, RDD, GAMM)
analysis.sample_description: Four cohorts of 5th graders (one comparison, three policy cohorts) and three cohorts of 3rd graders; case studies of schools, SPAs, and SSAs; surveys of administrators and students.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview and case study data; quantitative analysis using descriptive statistics, regression models (logistic, OLS, doubly robust), GAMM, and RDD to estimate treatment effects and explore relationships between variables.  Propensity score weighting used to create comparable groups for regression analysis.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: A top-down and bottom-up approach was used. The bottom-up approach involved collecting information on each network and application and gathering views from stakeholders to establish a baseline. The top-down approach involved reviewing research literature and case studies to discern potential manpower, personnel, and training implications.  Significant inputs and intermediate outputs affecting final outcomes were assessed.

sections.title: Mathematical Approximation of Manpower Requirements
sections.methods_summary: A mathematical model was developed to approximate the Navy's manpower requirements system.  The model used 15 variables (CI watches, CIII watches, ship standard workweek, training allowance, service diversion, etc.) to calculate hours available for work and workload hours needed.  Manpower requirements were then determined based on the relationship between these two values. The model's logic was validated against historical ship manpower documents (SMDs).

sections.title: Research Methods
sections.methods_summary: The research relied on a review of literature, data from ship and activity manpower documents, Navy Training Systems Plans, Enlisted Distribution Verification Reports, watch bills, Navy and Defense Manpower Data Center personnel inventories and authorizations; interviews with personnel from various Navy organizations and subject-matter experts; and ship visits. Data analysis and system dynamics modeling were also used.

sections.title: Training Model Description
sections.methods_summary: A system dynamics model, programmed in iThink, was used to simulate the movement of ITs through the Navy training and assignment system.  The model included stocks (representing ITs at different stages), flows (controlling movement between stocks), and auxiliaries (used for counting ITs). Three model versions were used: a status quo model, a base case model (reflecting planned changes), and an excursion model with early C school.  The models used retention rates at key decision points (4 years and 6 years of service) and simulated the system until steady state was reached.

analysis.sample_description: The study focused on selected systems (ISNS, SCI Network, CENTRIXS-M, GCCS-M, NTCSS), ship classes (carriers and destroyers), and Navy Enlisted Classifications (NECs).  Data for one exemplar ship of each class was analyzed.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved approximating the Navy's manpower requirements system mathematically, validating the model against historical data, and then using the model to analyze current manpower and the implications of CANES.  System dynamics modeling was used to analyze training alternatives, considering costs and the number of trained ITs assigned to billets.  Sensitivity analysis was conducted by varying retention rates.

sections.title: Approach and Methods for Cost-Effectiveness Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The study used a cost-effectiveness analysis to determine whether potential avionics modernization options are worthwhile.  This involved calculating percentage changes in fuel consumption and flying hours for compliant and non-compliant aircraft using two years of flight operational data validated by AMC experts.  These percentages were applied to 11 years of data from the Air Force Total Ownership Cost (AFTOC) database.  Flight data (nearly 20,000 flights) was analyzed to determine distance traveled in each ICAO region, modeling fuel use and flight time under compliant and non-compliant conditions using the KC-10 performance manual and operational practices.  A 14-minute flight delay was applied for non-compliant aircraft transiting regions with projected delays.  Regression analysis was used to model the relationship between nonfuel costs and flying hours.  Cost avoidance was calculated using net present value (NPV) with a 2.8% discount rate.  Cost estimates for modernization were drawn from contractor-based concept refinement studies (CRSs).

sections.title: Methods for Assessing Wartime Effectiveness
sections.methods_summary: The study assessed the impact of non-modernization on seven broad tanker missions. Three missions (homeland defense, OPLAN 8010, and employment) were deemed unaffected by CNS/ATM mandates based on judgment and expert consultation.  For the four affected missions (deployment, air bridge, national reserve, and global strike), the number of tankers required under compliant and non-compliant conditions was calculated using mission descriptions from the KC-X AoA, the Mobility Capabilities Study, and tanker doctrine.  Deployment effectiveness was calculated as the ratio of required compliant tankers to required non-compliant tankers.  The analysis considered the impact of non-compliance in different ICAO regions and the allocation of tankers to different mission types.  Airport access analysis involved examining runways worldwide to identify those newly accessible with RNP 0.15-0.3 capability.  The impact of exclusion from established air refueling tracks and European airspace was also assessed.

analysis.sample_description: The study used two years of KC-10 flight operational data (approximately 20,000 sorties) and 11 years of data from the Air Force Total Ownership Cost (AFTOC) database (1996-2006).  Data from contractor-based concept refinement studies (CRSs) were also used for cost estimation.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved calculating the cost avoidance from modernization by comparing the operational costs of compliant and non-compliant aircraft, considering fuel consumption, flying hours, and nonfuel costs.  Wartime effectiveness was assessed by comparing the number of tankers required to accomplish missions under different compliance scenarios.  Net present value (NPV) was used to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of modernization.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the methodology used to analyze Air Force prepositioning strategies. It discusses the implications of the current security environment for DoD planning and programming, and presents optimization models that identify minimum-cost prepositioning postures.  The models address either meeting time-phased deployment requirements across multiple potential futures or satisfying deployment requirements even with loss of access to any forward support location (FSL).

sections.title: Mathematical Model Details
sections.methods_summary: This section details the mixed integer programming (MIP) model used, developed using the General Algebraic Modeling System (GAMS).  It describes indices, sets, data elements (cost coefficients and other parameters), variables (binary, integer, and continuous), and equations (objective function and constraints).  Modifications for robustness and reliability analyses are also explained.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from various sources, including DoD Strategic Planning Guidance (SPG) scenarios, RAND-developed START model outputs, Air Force databases (OLVIMS, Equipment Management System), CENTAF and PACAF data on BEAR and WRMV assets, and commercial standards for transportation costs.  Specific details on data sources are provided within Chapters 3 and 4.
analysis.analysis_approach: The core method is optimization modeling, specifically mixed integer programming, to determine minimum-cost prepositioning postures.  The model considers various factors such as facility construction costs, operations and maintenance, asset procurement, transportation costs (air, sea, land), packaging configurations (palletized, containerized, wrapped), maintenance concepts (on-site, traveling teams, asset swap), and throughput constraints.  Sensitivity analyses are conducted to assess the impact of varying demand levels, risk tolerance, AOR-specific management, and political considerations.  The model is also extended to incorporate robustness (multiple potential futures) and reliability (potential FSL disruptions) analyses.

sections.title: Research Approach and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The research involved examining Air Force cyberspace strategy and doctrine, conducting a strategies-to-tasks analysis, developing example scenarios based on understanding of cyberspace and Air Force roles, and raising key questions regarding cyberspace boundaries, national strategy, Air Force goals, organizational responsibilities, and the nature of cyberwarfare.  The analysis focused on understanding the roles of computer network attack (CNA), computer network defense (CND), and computer network exploitation (CNE) operations and the interactions between the Air Force and other organizations like the NSA.

analysis.sample_description: The study did not involve a specific sample of individuals or organizations in the traditional sense.  The analysis focused on existing Air Force documents, strategies, and organizational structures, as well as the broader national security context of cyberspace operations.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis was primarily qualitative, involving the examination of existing documents, the development of illustrative scenarios, and the identification of key questions and challenges related to the Air Force's role in cyberspace.  A strategies-to-tasks framework was used to analyze the Air Force's potential missions and capabilities.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: This technical report is the first in a four-volume series examining U.S. Air Force roles in promoting international energy security.  The report examines the world oil market, energy security issues associated with petroleum, and how energy market and security considerations relate to Air Force operational planning. The other three volumes present exploratory studies that examine potential opportunities where the Air Force can promote energy security through bilateral and multilateral partnerships.

analysis.sample_description: Not explicitly defined; analysis focuses on the global oil market, the U.S. Air Force, and specific regions (Turkey, Caspian Basin, Asia's sea-lanes, Gulf of Guinea).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves reviewing existing data on the world oil market, assessing energy security issues, and exploring potential Air Force roles in promoting energy security through case studies of specific regions.  The approach is largely qualitative, drawing on existing literature and expert knowledge to develop policy recommendations.

sections.title: Research Design and Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the overall research design as exploratory research conducted as part of a broader study on energy security and its effects on USAF planning.  It involved three exploratory studies, one focusing on the Caspian and Turkey (this document), another on sea-lanes from Hormuz to Asia, and a third on the Gulf of Guinea. The methodology is described as exploratory, focusing on identifying potential USAF roles in promoting international energy security in regions outside the Middle East where energy security issues have not been as extensively studied.

analysis.sample_description: The sample is not explicitly defined, but the research involved consultations with government and energy experts in Washington, Turkey, and the Caspian region, as well as energy industry representatives (on a not-for-attribution basis).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach is qualitative and descriptive, examining major energy security challenges, assessing threats, and identifying potential USAF roles.  The report synthesizes information from various sources to draw conclusions about the energy security situation and potential areas for USAF engagement.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A broad survey of secondary and primary sources and interviews with country, regional, and operational experts. Sources included professional journals, academic studies, official strategy and doctrine documents, international and interdepartmental agreements, and news reports.  Participation in several conferences related to maritime security and piracy.

analysis.sample_description: The study did not involve a specific sample of individuals in the traditional sense.  Instead, it drew upon a broad range of secondary sources and interviews with experts.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved examining the importance of sea-lanes, current and foreseeable threats, existing security mechanisms, potential benefits of alternative arrangements, and challenges associated with new approaches.  The findings were presented as an exploratory assessment, not a definitive conclusion.

sections.title: Appendix A: Analysis of Potential Aerial Operations
sections.methods_summary: This appendix details a parametric analysis modeling the operational challenges for the Nigerian Air Force to deter attacks on offshore energy infrastructure.  The analysis uses an Excel-based model of an alert-response-search algorithm, typical of maritime search and rescue operations, to determine the number of bases and aircraft needed for timely response to attacks on 24 major offshore facilities.  Assumptions include aircraft capabilities (ATR-42 and AS332 Super Puma), detection methods (visual at 3000 feet), boat speed (25 knots), and bearing. The analysis examines two scenarios: immediate launch order and a 10-minute delay.  The results assess the percentage of facilities covered under different scenarios (single base, two bases, etc.). A similar analysis is performed for rapid tactical transport (RTT) operations, focusing on helicopter interception of attackers at landfall.  The analysis also outlines the command, control, and communications (C3) requirements for effective incident response.

analysis.sample_description: 24 major Nigerian offshore oil and gas facilities.
analysis.analysis_approach: An Excel-based model simulating alert-response-search algorithms for airborne surveillance and rapid tactical transport, considering various factors like response time, aircraft speed, and distance to facilities. The analysis calculates the percentage of facilities covered under different scenarios.

sections.title: Methods and Limitations
sections.methods_summary: Surveys were sent to principals, teachers, and parents in both charter and traditional schools.  Data analysis included cross-tabulations and regression models.

sections.title: Appendix A: Statistical Models Used in the Analyses
sections.methods_summary: Details of statistical models used, including simple cross-tabulations, between-school effects regression models, and random-effects regression models.  Equations are provided for each model type.

sections.title: Research Design
sections.methods_summary: Three separate surveys were developed for principals, teachers, and parents.  Surveys were mailed in spring 2009 with follow-up communications.  Response rates are reported.  Data analysis used Stata 10.0, including multilevel models to account for nesting of individuals within schools and ordinary least squares and multilevel regression analyses to examine relationships between school performance and characteristics.  Limitations of the study, including nonresponse bias and the descriptive nature of the findings, are discussed.

analysis.sample_description: Surveys were sent to principals of 75 schools (42 charter, 33 traditional), a random sample of 436 teachers (stratified by grade level and subject), and 411 parents (stratified by school and grade level). Response rates were approximately 32% for principals, 52% for teachers, and 36% for parents.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data analysis used Stata 10.0.  Multilevel models accounted for nesting of individuals within schools.  Ordinary least squares and multilevel regression analyses examined relationships between school performance and characteristics.  Cross-tabulations were used for principal survey data.

sections.title: Methods for Conducting Interviews and Developing Case Studies
sections.methods_summary: The study employed interviews with 65 key informants across four large LHDs (Alameda, Los Angeles, Palm Beach, and Duval counties).  Interview questions focused on GIS infrastructure, planning methods with geographic components, availability of geocoded data, and the use of data in program planning and resource allocation.  Relevant documentation from the LHDs was also reviewed. Case studies were then conducted in Alameda, Los Angeles, and Palm Beach counties, focusing on methods used to overcome barriers to 'mapping the gaps'.  Case study topics were chosen by each LHD in consultation with the RAND team, considering feasibility and data availability.  The RAND team worked with each LHD to refine analysis questions and create maps to depict data and questions of interest. Findings were reviewed with each LHD to understand how maps could enhance planning.

analysis.sample_description: Four large LHDs were selected due to their diverse populations and data infrastructures.  12-24 key informants were interviewed at each LHD, including staff at all levels (directors, program directors, program staff, epidemiologists, GIS experts).
analysis.analysis_approach: The interview findings were used to develop a conceptual model of factors influencing LHD use of GIS. Case studies involved developing new planning questions or reframing existing ones, identifying and preparing GIS data, and implementing GIS techniques to answer the questions.  Maps were created to highlight geographic areas where population health needs and service delivery were mismatched or aligned.  The analysis involved creating various types of maps (population health needs, LHD points of dispensing, and combined services and needs maps).

sections.title: Methodology and Data for the Roadmap
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed integer linear program (MILP) formulated using the General Algebraic Modeling System (GAMS) to optimize rehosting decisions.  Data collection involved assembling information on projected UUT workload from multiple sources (D200, ACPINS, technical orders, local repair shops), including UUT demands, failure rates, repair times, and ATS-UUT matches.  Data inconsistencies and fragmentation across sources are discussed.

sections.title: Case Study: Selected B-1B Avionics
sections.methods_summary: This section details the application of the MILP methodology to a subset of B-1B avionics UUTs and testers.  It describes the selection of ATSs and UUTs, workload projections based on a level flying-hour program, data on ATS availability from Ellsworth AFB and Warner Robins ALC, and the estimation of operating and sustainment costs.  Rehosting costs, including hardware acquisition and TPS translation costs, are estimated and varied in sensitivity analyses.  The analysis explores the roadmap decision space by varying support costs and translation costs, and by changing the time horizon.

analysis.sample_description: A subset of 470 UUTs from the B-1B avionics suite, focusing on a single weapon system with a small number of operating locations to facilitate data collection.
analysis.analysis_approach: A mixed integer linear program (MILP) was used to find the cost-optimal solution for rehosting UUTs from legacy automatic test systems (ATSs) to a new common ATS. Sensitivity analyses were conducted to assess the impact of varying parameters such as support costs and translation costs. The analysis also explored the impact of different time horizons.

sections.title: Study Questions and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach, combining key informant interviews (n=30) with a review of publicly available documents and website materials (n=70).  A purposive sample of organizations from 11 categories was selected.  The study focused on primary end-users of performance measures and classified measure use into four broad categories: QI, public reporting, accreditation/certification/credentialing/licensure, and payment applications.

sections.title: Study Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a mixed-methods design.  Data collection involved semi-structured phone interviews (n=30) with key informants and a review of publicly available documents and website materials (n=70).  A purposive sample of organizations was selected to ensure representation across 11 end-user categories and four measure uses.  Data were coded to capture various aspects of measure use, including setting, data sources, measure domains, and NQF endorsement status.  The study focused on primary end-users and excluded secondary users.

analysis.sample_description: A purposive sample of 70 primary end-user organizations was selected from a list of approximately 580 organizations.  The sample aimed for broad representation across 11 end-user categories and four measure uses, but was not designed to be statistically representative.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data from interviews and document reviews were coded and analyzed to identify key themes and patterns related to performance measure use, influencing factors, system changes, and opportunities for improvement.  Frequencies and percentages were calculated to summarize findings.

sections.title: Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach. Data were primarily collected from DLIELC through a question-and-answer process (150 data requests), supplemented by interviews with DLIELC officials, AETC personnel, and policy officials in Washington D.C.  Relevant regulations, directives, instructions, and policy documents were reviewed. A comparative analysis was conducted with 12 similar organizations (10 DoD and 2 foreign).

analysis.sample_description: Student data from DLIELC from 2001 to 2010 were used.  The comparative analysis included 10 DoD organizations and 2 foreign English/French-language training organizations.
analysis.analysis_approach: Regression analysis was used to predict student load based on Foreign Military Sales (FMS) data and to predict average English language training time for new countries based on world modernity data.  Other analyses included descriptive statistics and correlations.

sections.title: Methodology and Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: The study reviewed existing police performance measurement systems from around the world.  Data was collected through a review of documents (policies, reports, annual accounts, etc.) from various police forces in England and Wales, Northern Ireland, New Zealand, and South Africa.  The researchers also conducted interviews with over 130 police executives and experts globally to gather information on best practices.  The methodology involved comparing and contrasting different approaches to performance measurement, identifying common elements, and analyzing the strengths and weaknesses of each system.  Specific data sources included the British Crime Survey, the New Zealand Crime and Safety Survey, the Northern Ireland Policing Board's annual reports and policing plans, and data from the South African Police Service (SAPS).  The report also draws upon existing literature on police performance measurement.

analysis.sample_description: The study examined performance measurement systems in England and Wales, Northern Ireland, New Zealand, and South Africa, as well as drawing on broader international best practices from over 130 interviews with police executives and experts.
analysis.analysis_approach: Comparative analysis of different performance measurement systems, identifying common elements and best practices.  The analysis focuses on the strengths and weaknesses of various approaches, considering factors such as outcomes vs. outputs, interpretability of measures, and adjustments for context.

sections.title: Understanding the Inputs: Where Does the Money Go?
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the methodology for tracking funding flows for PEPFAR and GFATM.  It involves a vertical perspective (tracking funds from headquarters to implementing partners) and a horizontal perspective (examining allocation across spending categories). The authors acknowledge challenges in comparing costs across funders and over time due to varying definitions and changing reporting practices.  They establish their own consistent cost classification framework encompassing direct services, indirect services, and overhead/administration costs.  For PEPFAR, the analysis relies on budget data due to the unavailability of expenditure data. For GFATM, the analysis uses expenditure data from annual reports, but these data are aggregated and lack detail on HIV-specific spending.  The authors combine information from various sources to estimate spending on different HIV services for GFATM.

sections.title: Understanding Outputs and Outcomes: What Does the Money Buy?
sections.methods_summary: This section discusses the challenges in defining and measuring health outcomes for HIV funding.  It reviews existing outcome measures from the literature and those used by funders, highlighting the difficulties in attributing changes in health outcomes to specific interventions and the use of process or output measures as proxies. The authors discuss the care delivery value chain (CDVC) as a potential framework for evaluating efficiency but note the lack of data for comprehensive CDVC analysis.  For their analysis, they use the number of people on ART as a readily accessible output measure, acknowledging its limitations. The section also examines the missions, objectives, and principles of PEPFAR and GFATM and compares their funding allocations to their stated objectives.  It analyzes PEPFAR's five-year strategy and its measurable goals, noting the shift towards sustainability and country ownership.  For GFATM, the analysis focuses on its guiding principles emphasizing a balanced approach to funding.

sections.title: Appendix: Technical Notes
sections.methods_summary: This appendix provides detailed technical information on the data and methods used in the study. It includes a breakdown of PEPFAR and GFATM funding flows at different hierarchical levels, explaining the data sources and classifications used.  For PEPFAR, it details the use of budget data instead of expenditure data and the methods for apportioning overhead and capacity-building costs.  For GFATM, it explains the use of annual reports and other documents to estimate spending on HIV services and the challenges in linking spending to services delivered.  It also describes the methods used to calculate cost-efficiency ratios for both funders, including the treatment of double-counting and the limitations of available data.  A literature review of clinical-level cost studies is included to provide context for the top-down cost estimates.

sections.title: How Can Efficiency Be Measured and Improvements Tracked?
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines a methodology for measuring the efficiency of HIV funding. It emphasizes the need to link input and output measures to arrive at cost estimates for different services and compare costs over time and across funders.  The authors present an illustrative example of how efficiency can be measured for ART provision, including costs for indirect services, overhead, and administration.  They acknowledge challenges in obtaining reliable data and inconsistencies in data reporting between PEPFAR and GFATM.  The section presents calculations of cost ratios for PEPFAR and GFATM contributions to ART per person-year, highlighting the limitations of existing monitoring and evaluation systems.  It discusses the underestimation of costs due to potential double-counting of patients and the difficulty in attributing costs to specific funders when multiple sources contribute to service provision.  The section concludes by summarizing challenges in evaluating HIV funding efficiency, including issues related to overhead costs, indirect costs, and donor-specific contributions.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from PEPFAR and GFATM, focusing on their funding for antiretroviral therapy (ART) in developing countries.  A case study of Uganda is also included for a more detailed comparison.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves tracking funding flows, classifying costs, and calculating cost-efficiency ratios to compare the efficiency of PEPFAR and GFATM in delivering ART services.  The authors acknowledge limitations in data availability and consistency, which affect the reliability of their comparisons.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Uses Proxy-PERSTEMPO data from the Defense Manpower Data Center.  Estimates differences in retention and promotion between white males (reference group) and other groups defined by race, ethnicity, and sex. Controls for several variables (service, source of commission, prior enlisted status, occupation group, deployment experience, marital status, and education) in analyses.  Analysis is purely descriptive and does not attempt to explain *why* differences occur.

sections.title: Overview of Data and Approach
sections.methods_summary: Data source: Proxy-PERSTEMPO data file from the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC).  Career progression measured as a series of retention and promotion milestones, each conditional on its predecessor.  Promotion eligibility windows defined based on observed promotions in the data. Retention defined as staying until at least the first month of the promotion eligibility window.  Analysis uses probit regressions to estimate differences in likelihood of reaching milestones, controlling for various factors (service, source of commission, prior enlisted service, occupation group, deployment experience, marital status, and education).  A difference-in-difference approach is used to analyze differences in career progression for women in partially closed vs. open occupations, netting out differences for men in those same occupations.  Race and ethnicity defined using pre-2003 definitions. Occupations partially closed to women identified based on a list obtained from each service.  The analysis is descriptive, not causal.

sections.title: Summary and Conclusions
sections.methods_summary: Compares results with an earlier RAND study, noting limitations of direct comparison due to differences in data, sample sizes, and control variables.  Discusses potential explanations for findings regarding women in partially closed occupations, including the possibility of early-career differences, higher qualifications/performance of women in these occupations, behavioral responses to restrictions, and non-binding restrictions.  Highlights unanswered questions, such as the generalizability to recent cohorts and the causal effect of lifting restrictions, suggesting potential future research approaches (structural modeling of occupational and retention decisions, simulation of alternative policies).

sections.title: Detailed Description of Data and Methods, and Regression Results
sections.methods_summary: Provides detailed information on data construction, variable definitions (static vs. dynamic), and the imputation of promotion windows.  Describes how control variables were measured (at entry or at the time of the most recent promotion). Presents regression results (Tables A.5-A.8) from probit models, including marginal effects, standard errors, and statistical significance levels.  Notes the inclusion of year-of-entry fixed effects in all models.

analysis.sample_description: Active-duty officers (excluding those in medical and professional fields) from 1971-2002 cohorts.  Sample sizes vary across analyses due to data availability and the conditional nature of the milestones.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis primarily focuses on describing differences in career progression by race, ethnicity, gender, and occupational closure status, controlling for several factors.  Probit regression models are used to estimate the likelihood of reaching various career milestones, conditional on reaching previous milestones.  A difference-in-differences approach is employed to analyze the impact of occupational restrictions on women's career progression.

sections.title: Los Angeles Family and Neighborhood Survey (L.A.FANS) Data and Measures
sections.methods_summary: The study used data from the L.A.FANS survey, a multilevel study of neighborhood social conditions and family life on child development.  A stratified sampling design oversampled poor neighborhoods and households with children.  The survey collected data on child care use, including whether the child received non-parental care, the type of care, hours of care, number of arrangements, cost of care, and child-to-adult ratios. Data were reported by the child's primary caregiver (usually the mother).

sections.title: Analysis of Regular Use of Non-Parental Child Care
sections.methods_summary: Bivariate tabulations and binomial logistic regression were used to examine the association between child care use and various geographic, socioeconomic, and demographic characteristics.  Bivariate logit analysis was used to test the significance of individual variables.  A multivariate binomial logistic regression model was used to assess the relative importance of each characteristic while controlling for others.

sections.title: Analysis of Number of Arrangements and Primary Type of Child Care
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of the number of child care arrangements used bivariate analysis.  A multinomial logistic regression was used to examine the relationship between the primary type of child care (relative, non-relative, center-based) and various characteristics, contrasting relative and non-relative care with center-based care (reference category).

sections.title: Analysis of Amount of Child Care Used Per Week
sections.methods_summary: Multivariate logit models were used to examine the association between the amount of child care (full-time vs. part-time) and various characteristics.

sections.title: Analysis of Child Care Costs
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of child care costs used figures and graphs to show monthly and hourly costs by type of care and income level. Logit regression was used to examine the relationship between whether families paid for care and various characteristics.  Ordinary least squares (OLS) regression was used to analyze hourly costs for families who paid for care.

sections.title: Analysis of Child-Adult Ratios
sections.methods_summary: Child care quality was assessed using child-to-adult caretaker ratios.  Analysis of these ratios used bivariate tabulations and graphs to show ratios by type of care, age, and family income. Multivariate OLS regression was used to examine the association between child-adult ratios and various characteristics, including cost of care.

analysis.sample_description: The study used data from the Los Angeles Family and Neighborhood Survey (L.A.FANS), a multilevel study with a stratified sampling design that oversampled poor neighborhoods and households with children. The sample for this report consisted of 887 children ages 0 to 5 who were not yet enrolled in school and for whom complete data were available.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis included bivariate tabulations, binomial logistic regression, multinomial logistic regression, and OLS regression to examine the relationships between child care patterns and various geographic, socioeconomic, and demographic characteristics.  Multivariate models controlled for the effects of other variables.

sections.title: Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: Financial data from the California Department of Education's Standardized Account Code Structure (SACS) files, combined with district characteristics (district type, fiscal health, Basic Aid status, urban category, size, student performance, percentage of students in poverty, percentage of English learners).

sections.title: Data Description and Limitations
sections.methods_summary: Detailed explanation of the SACS data, including resource, function, object, and goal codes.  Discussion of limitations, such as data lag (analysis limited to 2009-10), inability to identify Tier 3 funds after 2008-09, and challenges in separating the effects of flexibility from budget cuts.  Description of district characteristics used in the analysis (district type, fiscal health, Basic Aid status, urban category, size, student performance (API), poverty rate, English learner percentage).  Explanation of student-weighted means and the impact of Los Angeles Unified School District's size on the analysis.

analysis.sample_description: 921 California K-12 school districts with complete data for 2007-08, 2008-09, and 2009-10.  A smaller subset of 10 districts were studied in-depth in a companion report.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, analysis of revenue and expenditure patterns across districts, comparison of changes in revenue and expenditure across different district characteristics (district type, fiscal health, Basic Aid status, urban category, size, student performance, poverty rate, English learner percentage).  Student-weighted averages were used to account for district size variations, with results presented both with and without the Los Angeles Unified School District to assess its influence.

sections.title: Methodology for Examining Career Transitions
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodological approach used to analyze career transitions.  It focuses on two types of transitions: the transition from teaching to school administration, and the transition from the principalship. A multinomial logit model, a longitudinal event history model, is employed.  The model accounts for censoring and time-varying covariates.  Two specifications are estimated to address potential endogeneity of school-level variables. The analysis is clustered at the school level to account for potential correlation in error terms.  Explanatory variables include individual characteristics (age, gender, race/ethnicity, education, experience, undergraduate institution quality), and school/district characteristics (size, student demographics, school level). The IIA assumption is tested and found to be valid. Predicted probabilities are calculated to interpret the results.

analysis.sample_description: The analysis sample included all people who began as teachers in the Illinois public school system, were not currently in a principal or superintendent position, and worked in the system between school years 1987–1988 and 1999–2000.  For the two-stage model, a subsample of assistant principals was used.  For the principal turnover model, the sample included all principals working between 1987-1988 and 1999-2000.
analysis.analysis_approach: A multinomial logit model was used to analyze the probability of different career transitions.  The model included both individual and school/district characteristics as explanatory variables.  Predicted probabilities were calculated to interpret the magnitude of effects.  The analysis was clustered at the school level to account for potential correlation in error terms.

sections.title: Appendix A: Model Assumptions and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A simple model comparing costs of reusable and expendable weapon systems.  The model equates the cost of a penetrating aircraft system with the cost of a standoff missile system, considering system development (SDD) costs, infrastructure costs, and expendable costs (weapons and fuel).  The indifference curve is derived through algebraic manipulation of these cost components.  Specific cost assumptions are detailed in Table A.1.

sections.title: Appendix B: Data Sources
sections.methods_summary: Data on historical air-to-ground attacks were collected from readily available unclassified sources.  In cases where the exact number of weapons dropped was unavailable, the total weight delivered was used to estimate the number of weapons, assuming an average weight of 1,000 lbs per weapon.  Specific sources are listed for each conflict.

analysis.sample_description: Historical data on air-to-ground attacks from various conflicts (Vietnam War, Desert Storm, etc.) are used.  The data includes intensity (weapons delivered per day) and duration of conflicts.
analysis.analysis_approach: A simple mathematical model is developed to compare the costs of using reusable aircraft versus expendable missiles.  The model considers development costs, infrastructure costs, and operational costs.  The results are presented graphically as indifference curves, showing the conditions under which each approach is cost-effective. Sensitivity analysis is performed by varying cost assumptions to assess the robustness of the findings.

sections.title: Approach of This Study
sections.methods_summary: Literature review, data collection from 11 US jurisdictions on inclusionary zoning (IZ) programs, geocoding of IZ addresses, analysis of neighborhood and school characteristics using Census data (ACS 5-Year Estimates), school district data, and state education agency data.  Analysis involved comparing characteristics of neighborhoods and schools with and without IZ homes.

sections.title: Additional Information on Methods
sections.methods_summary: Data collection from 11 localities, geocoding of addresses (15,528 successful geocodes out of 15,659), matching geographic coordinates to Census data (2000 and 2005-2009 ACS 5-Year Estimates) at the census block group level, obtaining GIS school attendance zone boundary files (with limitations noted for districts with school choice systems), linking school data to student characteristics (NCES Common Core of Data), ranking schools based on state standardized test data (math and ELA), and noting limitations of the data (e.g., lack of information on school attendance for IZ children, assumption of constant school attendance zones).

analysis.sample_description: 11 geographically diverse US jurisdictions with inclusionary zoning programs; 15,659 unique IZ addresses (15,528 successfully geocoded).
analysis.analysis_approach: Comparative analysis of neighborhood and school characteristics (poverty rates, school performance) for areas with and without IZ homes. Statistical tests were used to determine significant differences between IZ and non-IZ neighborhoods and schools.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources (2000 decennial Census, 2009 Army Stationing and Installation Plan, 2010 USAF Almanac, Total Army Personnel Database, 2003 Air Force Community Assessment Survey), sample selection criteria (Army and Air Force installations with at least 1000 full-time military personnel), neighborhood definition (ZIP Codes including the installation and contiguous ZIP Codes), data aggregation (population-weighted averages), and the creation of the Military Neighborhood Ranking Index (MNRI) using a relative ranking method.  Multilevel modeling is described as the analytical technique used to link MNRI scores to Soldier and Airman outcomes.

sections.title: Case Study 1: U.S. Army Installations - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the multilevel modeling approach used to analyze the association between the MNRI (and its six domains) and three Soldier outcomes: attrition, separation from active duty, and BMI.  It details the basic and full models (with and without covariates), the handling of anomalous results (exclusion of Fort Rucker from separation models and Fort Story from attrition models), and the interpretation of odds ratios and coefficients.

sections.title: Case Study 2: U.S. Air Force Bases - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines the methodology for the Air Force case study, emphasizing the use of the 2003 Air Force Community Assessment Survey. It explains the use of on-base/off-base status as a proxy for exposure to neighborhood characteristics and the inclusion of an interaction term in the models to test the exposure hypothesis.  The analysis plan describes the multilevel regression models (continuous, binary, and count outcomes), the inclusion of covariates, and the separate analyses for officers and enlisted personnel.  The section also describes the outcome variables (satisfaction with housing, community satisfaction, neighborhood cohesion, perceived safety, financial difficulties, depressive symptoms, self-rated health, life satisfaction, and career intentions).

analysis.sample_description: The study included 36 Army installations and 62 Air Force bases in the continental United States, selected based on having at least 1000 full-time military personnel.  The Army data came from the Total Army Personnel Database, while the Air Force data came from the 2003 Air Force Community Assessment Survey.  For the Air Force analysis, individuals who had not been assigned to their current location for at least one year were excluded.
analysis.analysis_approach: Multilevel regression models were used to analyze the relationship between the Military Neighborhood Ranking Index (MNRI) and various outcomes for Soldiers and Airmen.  Basic models were estimated without covariates, and full models included individual-level covariates.  Interaction terms were included to test the exposure hypothesis (that the association between neighborhood quality and outcomes would be stronger for Airmen living off base).

sections.title: Approach (TSS Study)
sections.methods_summary: Research-based qualitative analysis; examination of TSS objectives, goals, and processes; assessment of processes and identification of areas needing improvement; identification and description of directions for process improvement.  Extensive dialogue with key members of the TSS community.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Examination of ATLD processes in four key areas; assessment using questions related to support of operational readiness and ARFORGEN processes, adoption of an enterprise approach, and stewardship of resources; development of conclusions about ATLD management processes, identification of areas for improvement, and development of directions for improvement.  Use of a new case study and three previous ATLD-related research efforts.

sections.title: Improve Analytical and Data-Collection Processes
sections.methods_summary: Six-step improved analytical approach focusing on ATLD output improvement: 1. Document ATLD activity outputs and costs; 2. Quantify leader and unit performance needs; 3. Identify and prioritize areas for unit and leader performance improvement; 4. Develop and analyze options for improvement; 5. Revise ATLD strategies; 6. Revise ATLD programs and activities.  Data collection methods include improved end-of-course tests, surveys and structured interviews of graduates and participants, case studies, and structured training assessments of unit performance improvement.  Analysis will rely heavily on qualitative analysis supported by some quantitative analysis. Cost-benefit analysis will be used to evaluate and select improvement options.

sections.title: Improve Systems for Collecting Data on Training and Leader Development Programs’ Achievements, Nature, and Needs During the ARFORGEN Cycle
sections.methods_summary: Data collection during the ARFORGEN cycle (Reset, Train-Ready, Available phases) using various sources: Unit activity reports, training event data, PME requirements and completion data, manning and equipment levels, assessment efforts, After Action Reports, ATRRS/TAPDB data, surveys, focus groups, and USRs.  Data collection on achieved training proficiency levels, especially in areas identified as needing improvement, will be collected at externally conducted training events (Maneuver CTC rotations and MCTP exercises).  Data collection will leverage existing capabilities and initiatives, such as CALL embedded in deployed units and TRADOC visits to returning BCTs.

sections.title: Unify Responsibility for Data Collection and Analysis and for Supporting ATLD Strategy and Program Management
sections.methods_summary: Centralized effort to implement and evolve data collection and analysis process; development of collection plans, implementation, and modification of plans; high-level assessment and analysis; development of improvement options; cost-benefit analysis; development of a supporting IT system.

sections.title: Approach Used in This Study (BCT Training)
sections.methods_summary: Examination of BCT training programs in the baseline period (FY 2001–2002), identification of changes in post-2002 training requirements, identification of gaps between training requirements and likely unit training program achievements, assessment of enhancements to BCT training strategies, and identification of ways to address gaps and improve Army processes for making decisions about training enabler prioritization.

analysis.sample_description: The main sample included data from 13 Brigade Combat Teams (BCTs) in the 2001-2002 timeframe, and the Advanced Leader Course (ALC).  Other data sources included the Army Distributed Learning Program (TADLP) and the Training Support System (TSS).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved examining ATLD processes to understand their function and identify participating organizations.  The researchers assessed the processes against Institutional Adaptation goals, using questions related to operational readiness, enterprise approach, and resource stewardship.  Findings were used to identify areas for improvement and develop directions for improvement.

sections.title: Cost Analysis Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for the cost analysis.  It describes the cost components included (program administration, probation costs, arrests, court appearances, and school attendance savings), the units of cost, and how cost differences between baseline and follow-up periods were calculated.  It also notes limitations, such as missing data for some cost components and the short (six-month) time frame for assessing long-term cost savings.

sections.title: Background and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the overall study design, including the use of quasi-experimental designs to evaluate the JJCPA programs. It discusses the challenges of creating comparable comparison groups and the use of propensity score matching and difference-in-differences analysis to address potential biases.  It explains the use of statistical significance testing (p<0.05) and the limitations of pre-post designs and small sample sizes.  The section also outlines the six mandated outcome measures ('big six') and the supplemental outcomes, and it explains the rationale behind Los Angeles County's ranking of the 'big six' outcomes.

sections.title: Probation’s Ranking of the Big Six Outcome Measures
sections.methods_summary: This section describes how the Los Angeles County Probation Department ranked the six CSA outcome measures (the 'big six') for its internal planning purposes.  It doesn't describe data collection or analysis methods, but it provides context for interpreting the results.

sections.title: Corrections Standards Authority–Mandated and Supplemental Outcomes for Individual JJCPA Programs, FY 2010–2011
sections.methods_summary: This appendix presents detailed statistics on the outcomes for each JJCPA program, including both CSA-mandated and supplemental outcomes.  It provides information on sample sizes, percentages, means, and confidence intervals for each outcome measure.  While it doesn't explicitly detail the methods used to collect or analyze the data, it presents the results of those analyses.

analysis.sample_description: The study included 36,749 youth who received JJCPA services in Los Angeles County during FY 2010-2011.  These youth were categorized as either at-risk (41.1%) or on probation (58.9%).  Comparison groups varied by program, using either contemporaneous groups (matched on various characteristics), historical comparison groups (previous year's participants), or pre-post designs.
analysis.analysis_approach: Statistical significance testing (p<0.05) was used to determine whether differences in outcomes between JJCPA youth and comparison groups were statistically significant.  Difference-in-differences analyses were conducted for programs using historical comparison groups to control for differences in baseline risk profiles between cohorts.  Cost analyses compared total juvenile justice costs (program costs, supervision, juvenile hall/camp, arrests, court appearances, and school attendance savings) during the six months before and after program entry.

sections.title: Study Purpose and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study involved four tasks: 1) Literature review and interviews with policymakers to characterize the policy debate on security cooperation and force posture in Europe; 2) Development of a framework to describe USAFE's BP approach using data from USAFE's Building Partnerships Scorecard, wing/squadron interviews, and a RAND-designed survey; 3) Definition of alternative postures for conducting BP activities using a building-block cost analysis; and 4) Recommendations for improving Air Force BP activities in Europe.  The survey collected information on routine BP activities of airmen based in Europe.

sections.title: Analytical Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section details the cost analysis methodology.  It used a building-block approach, breaking down BP activities into component parts (deployment, flying hours, TDY). Data sources included the USAFE scorecard database, AARs, EUCOM CFR, and TSCMIS.  The analysis categorized events by objective and force element required.  Building blocks were refined and verified with wing representatives.  Costs were calculated for different force postures (USAFE and CONUS) using data from AFTOC, MEFPAK, USTRANSCOM, and DTMO.  Excursions were run to account for activities eliminated in CONUS-based scenarios.

analysis.sample_description: Six wings and other organizations under USAFE in the AOR;  742 survey respondents.
analysis.analysis_approach: Building-block cost analysis comparing USAFE and CONUS force postures for conducting BP activities.  The analysis considered different organizing principles (status quo, reduced forward presence, modified reduced forward presence, alternative BP concepts).  Costs were broken down into deployment, event flying hours, and TDY.

sections.title: Appendix C: Analytic Sample Characteristics
sections.methods_summary: This section presents tables comparing baseline, wave 2, and wave 3 youth and parent respondents on demographic characteristics and survey items.  It does not describe methods, but presents the characteristics of the data used in the methods described elsewhere.

sections.title: Appendix D: Outcome Tables: Communication About Feelings Theme
sections.methods_summary: This section presents tables of results from analyses of the communication about feelings theme.  It shows weighted means and explores improvement (dichotomous outcomes) as reported by youth and parents.  It does not describe methods, but presents the results of analyses described elsewhere.

sections.title: Appendix E: Outcome Tables: Military Culture Theme
sections.methods_summary: This section presents tables of results from analyses of the military culture theme.  It shows weighted means and explores improvement (dichotomous outcomes) as reported by youth and parents.  It does not describe methods, but presents the results of analyses described elsewhere.

sections.title: Appendix F: Outcome Tables: Sense of Service/Stewardship Theme
sections.methods_summary: This section presents tables of results from analyses of the sense of service/stewardship theme.  It shows weighted means and explores improvement (dichotomous outcomes) as reported by youth and parents.  It does not describe methods, but presents the results of analyses described elsewhere.

sections.title: Appendix G: Outcome Tables: Outdoor Education Theme
sections.methods_summary: This section presents tables of results from analyses of the outdoor education theme.  It shows weighted means and explores improvement (dichotomous outcomes) as reported by youth and parents.  It does not describe methods, but presents the results of analyses described elsewhere.

sections.title: Appendix C: Analytic Sample Characteristics
sections.methods_summary: This section provides an overview of the characteristics of the final analytic sample.  It does not describe methods, but presents the characteristics of the data used in the methods described elsewhere.

sections.title: Chapter Two: Methods
sections.methods_summary: This chapter details the study's methodology, including objectives, hypotheses, survey content and key outcome measures, data collection procedures (web-based surveys at three time points, after-action reports, visitor logs), study design (quasi-experimental), sampling (propensity score weighting), and analysis methods (weighted t-tests, generalized boosted models, Bonferroni correction, sensitivity analyses).

analysis.sample_description: The study population consisted of all applicants to Operation Purple camps in 2011.  The final analytic sample included those who attended camp, those who were accepted but didn't attend, and those not accepted. Propensity score weighting was used to adjust for differences between the camp and no-camp groups.
analysis.analysis_approach: Propensity score weights were used to balance the camp and no-camp groups on baseline characteristics.  Weighted t-tests were used to compare means between groups.  Dichotomous outcomes (improvement from baseline) were also analyzed.  Generalized boosted models (GBMs) were used to estimate propensity scores.  A Bonferroni correction was applied to adjust p-values for multiple comparisons. Sensitivity analyses were conducted to assess the robustness of findings.

sections.title: Overview of Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section provides a high-level overview of the study's goals and the data used to achieve them.  It mentions the use of a web-based survey administered by Westat in 2010 and 2011, and that RAND conducted further analysis of the data.

sections.title: Survey Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Details the web-based survey administration by Westat to WWP alumni in 2010 and 2011.  Describes the timeline, communication methods (email and mail), response rates (32.4% in 2010 and 39.4% in 2011), and the lack of representativeness of the sample due to self-selection and the absence of population data to create weights.  It notes that statistical significance tests are limited to the sample of respondents.

sections.title: Analysis and Results Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Describes the demographic and service characteristics of respondents.  Explains the analysis approach, including the use of z-tests to assess statistically significant differences (p<0.05) in outcomes across subgroups (marital status, gender, pay grade, employment status).  Mentions the use of additional metrics from the literature (e.g., PTSD screening, depression scales) to enhance analysis of WWP's goals.

analysis.sample_description: WWP alumni database; 1,121 responses in 2010 (32.4% response rate), 2,312 responses in 2011 (39.4% response rate); 499 repeat respondents in both years.  Sample not necessarily representative of all WWP alumni.
analysis.analysis_approach: Z-tests to compare proportions across subgroups defined by demographic and service characteristics.  Additional analysis using metrics from existing literature (e.g., PTSD screening, depression scales, resilience scales) to provide broader context and comparison.

sections.title: Part I: Methods for Review of Reviews
sections.methods_summary: A comprehensive review of reviews was conducted using electronic searches of bibliographic databases (Cochrane Library, CRD, PubMed, Embase) and targeted websites (Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, European Medicines Agency).  Search terms included 'postmenopausal', 'osteoporosis', 'prevention', 'treatment', 'systematic review', and 'meta-analysis'.  Inclusion criteria specified systematic reviews and meta-analyses of studies on postmenopausal osteoporosis prevention and treatment, excluding primary studies, editorials, and commentaries.  Two reviewers screened titles and abstracts, resolving disagreements through consensus. Data extraction used a standardized evidence table.  Reviews were assessed for quality using five hierarchical criteria (explicit inclusion/exclusion criteria, adequate search methodology, synthesis of findings, quality assessment of reviewed studies, and sufficient detail on individual studies). Inter-rater reliability was assessed using Kappa scores.

sections.title: Part II: Methods for Country Case Studies
sections.methods_summary: A review of published and grey literature was conducted using PubMed searches with broad search terms related to osteoporosis management in England, France, Germany, and Spain.  The search was limited to studies published from 2000 onwards and included English, French, German, and Spanish language studies.  Titles and abstracts were screened for eligibility, with references from eligible studies followed up.  Excluded studies included general reviews of osteoporosis management, intervention studies, and aetiological studies.  The search was complemented by targeted searches of governmental and non-governmental agency websites and international organizations (IOF). National guidelines were analyzed using a structured template. Key informant interviews (telephone or written responses) were conducted with experts in osteoporosis prevention and treatment, using a structured questionnaire covering national strategies, guidelines, intervention uptake, and quality of care.  Country selection was based on healthcare funding and organization approaches and osteoporosis medication usage.

analysis.sample_description: The review of reviews included 128 eligible studies, with 29 rated as high or very high quality.  The country case studies focused on England, France, Germany, and Spain. Key informant interviews had a low response rate (3 out of 4 countries).
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of guidelines and literature, quantitative analysis of review quality using Kappa scores, and descriptive analysis of country case study findings.

sections.title: Root Cause Analysis Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used for root cause analyses (RCAs) of six defense acquisition programs.  The methodology is iterative and involves several key activities: 1. Analyzing breach notification and developing a hypothesis; 2. Setting up long-lead-time activities (interviews); 3. Documenting the unit cost threshold breach (creating a 'speeding ticket'); 4. Constructing a timeline of relevant cost growth events; 5. Verifying cost data and quantifying cost growth; 6. Creating and analyzing program cost profiles (RDT&E, procurement, unit cost); 7. Matching timeline events with cost profile changes to derive root causes; 8. Reconciling remaining issues; 9. Attributing unit cost growth to root causes; 10. Creating deliverables (narrative, briefing, full report) and refining the hypothesis.

sections.title: Data Sources for Root Cause Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the various data sources used in the RCAs, categorized by type (Acquisition Program Baseline, Acquisition Decision Memorandum, etc.).  It details the information contained in each source and its primary use in the analysis.  Sources include official program documentation (SARs, DAES, APBs, ADMs), congressional documents (testimony, CBO reports, CRS reports), GAO reports, DCMA reports, and industry data.  The section also describes the archiving process for preserving and accessing data for future analyses.

analysis.sample_description: Six major defense acquisition programs: Zumwalt-class Destroyer, Joint Strike Fighter, Longbow Apache, Wideband Global Satellite, Excalibur, and Navy Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved a multi-step iterative process combining qualitative and quantitative methods.  Qualitative data from interviews and document reviews were used to construct timelines and understand the context of cost growth.  Quantitative data from cost reports and budgets were used to create cost profiles and quantify cost growth.  The timeline and cost profiles were then compared to identify root causes of cost overruns.  The analysis also involved verifying data consistency across multiple sources and attributing cost growth to specific root causes.

sections.title: Exploratory Analysis Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology of exploratory analysis, including steps like defining the possibility space, narrowing the analysis, using multiresolution modeling, identifying a spanning set of scenarios, and employing computational experiments for scenario discovery.  Specific software tools like Analytica™ and CAR™ are mentioned.

sections.title: Strategic Planning Methodologies
sections.methods_summary: This section describes several strategic planning methods, including uncertainty-sensitive strategic planning, assumptions-based planning, planning specific adaptations, capabilities-based planning, and portfolio analysis.  It mentions the use of scenario-based methods, Day-After Exercises, and the development of scorecards and cost-effectiveness landscapes for comparing options.

sections.title: Acquisition Management Methodologies
sections.methods_summary: This section discusses methodologies used in acquisition management, including economic modeling to assess the break-even point for competition, brainstorming with experts to anticipate possibilities, and empirical research to quantify the effects of statutes and regulations.  It also mentions methods for scientific cost estimation, including eliciting probability distributions from multiple independent experts.

sections.title: Logistics Methodologies
sections.methods_summary: This section details methodologies used in logistics research, including dynamic stochastic programming, the Dyna-METRIC model, and the DRIVE algorithm. It highlights the use of complex simulation models, data analysis to forecast demand, and coping mechanisms for highly variable demand.  Recent work emphasizes the use of massive amounts of raw data and fast-turnaround empirical modeling.

sections.title: Manpower Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the use of stochastic dynamic programming at the individual level to model personnel retention, incorporating individual preferences and changing circumstances.  The methodology involves representing individual choices as a decision tree and using empirical data to establish model parameters.

sections.title: Crisis Decisionmaking Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines recommendations for crisis decision support, emphasizing the use of multiple models and stories, diverse communication modes, best-estimate, best-case, and worst-case assessments, and explicitly adaptive strategies to hedge against errors.

analysis.sample_description: The document mentions various samples throughout, including samples of acquisition programs, military personnel, and logistics data.  Specific sample sizes are provided in some cases (e.g., 316 participants in one acquisition study).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach varies across sections, but generally involves a combination of quantitative and qualitative methods.  Quantitative methods include economic modeling, statistical analysis, simulation modeling, and dynamic programming.  Qualitative methods include expert elicitation, brainstorming, and scenario development.

sections.title: Evaluation Approach
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods approach combining quantitative and qualitative data. Quantitative data included analysis of OES/EGC funding compared to total USG expenditures, and data from EPA's GMI database on activities and outcomes. Qualitative data included review of program documentation, interviews with program officers in DoS and EPA, and three country site visits.  Five core evaluation metrics were used: emissions reductions, leveraged funding, training, institutional outcomes, and policy outcomes. Gender dimensions were also assessed where applicable.

sections.title: Quantitative Analysis Approach
sections.methods_summary: Primary data source was EPA's GMI database.  Data on funding and activities were used to describe GMI's scope and characteristics related to DoS contributions.  Evaluation metrics included training (number of people attending training), leveraged funding (dollars), and emissions reductions (metric tons of CO2 equivalent).  Data on activities completed were also analyzed as a measure of program output. The GMI database, while useful, had limitations in terms of completeness and consistency of data entry.  Data were downloaded from six tables and merged to create a comprehensive dataset.

sections.title: Qualitative Observations of DoS Contributions
sections.methods_summary: Three country site visits were conducted in India, Mexico, and the Philippines.  Semistructured interviews were conducted with key stakeholders (32 individuals involved in approximately 30 distinct activities) and field visits were made to six sites.  Data analysis involved identifying common themes and outlier cases across the site visits, comparing across sectors and countries.  Additional qualitative data were collected from program documents and interviews with program officers.  A small number of NGOs were also contacted, but the response rate was low.

analysis.sample_description: Three countries (India, Mexico, Philippines) were selected for site visits based on methane emissions, GMI activity levels, and geographic diversity.  Site visits included interviews with 32 stakeholders and visits to six field sites.  A small number of NGOs were also contacted.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative data were analyzed using descriptive statistics. Qualitative data were analyzed thematically, identifying common themes and outlier cases across the three site visits and comparing across sectors and countries.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a computer-based system (Stabilization and Reconstruction Force Allocator, SRFA) to allocate Marine Corps units to tasks, considering situational factors.  The research involved three phases: 1) mission deconstruction (focusing on humanitarian assistance), 2) identifying equipment needed, and 3) defining measures and metrics (planning factors) to assess equipment capability. Software development ran concurrently.

sections.title: Equipment, Personnel, Metrics, and Planning Factors
sections.methods_summary: Mission deconstruction using Marine Corps documents and joint publications.  Identification of appropriate metrics for equipment based on capabilities (e.g., payload, speed).  Matching equipment to tasks based on capabilities.  Development of planning factors using task metrics and equipment capabilities.  A workshop with Marine Corps officers to validate tasks, equipment assignments, and metrics.  Prioritization of equipment based on officer input and a computer algorithm.  Use of the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to determine relative task importance.

sections.title: The MAGTF Equipment Structural Assessment (MESA) Application
sections.methods_summary: Development of the MESA software application to allocate equipment based on user-defined inputs: missions, tasks, prioritization of tasks, timelines, available equipment, equipment inventories, and hierarchies of preferred equipment.  The Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) is used for task prioritization.  The application outputs a list of allocated equipment and a percentage of task completion.  The application is data-driven and configurable via an Excel spreadsheet.

analysis.sample_description: The study used a sample MEU equipment inventory and focused primarily on the humanitarian assistance mission, with additional data for 14 other missions.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved deconstructing missions into tasks and subtasks, linking these to equipment based on capabilities and metrics, developing planning factors, prioritizing equipment, and using the AHP for task prioritization.  The MESA application then allocates equipment based on these factors and user inputs.

sections.title: Objective and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This document uses a literature review focused on information sharing at the individual level to examine potential psychological and motivational factors that may influence decisionmakers to create certain policies on information sharing.  The review focuses predominantly on empirical psychological and organizational behavior literature, acknowledging that other disciplines may offer additional perspectives.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is a literature review, not an empirical study with a specific sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach is qualitative, synthesizing findings from existing research on information sharing to identify key psychological and motivational barriers and suggest recommendations.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study employed two methodologies: a review of existing suicide epidemiological or surveillance data in California and an examination of peer-reviewed literature.  The epidemiological review examined data from the National Vital Statistics System and the California Health Interview Survey (CHIS), as well as non-fatal self-inflicted injury data from the California Department of Public Health. The literature search involved searching five databases (PsychINFO, PubMed, DTIC, NY Academy of Medicine Grey Literature Collection, and Social Science Abstracts) for evaluation studies and clinical trials of suicide prevention programs (SPP).  Data abstraction forms were used to ensure consistent coding across articles.  The abstracted data were then reviewed and organized into a conceptual model.

analysis.sample_description: The epidemiological review used data from the National Vital Statistics System, California Health Interview Survey (CHIS), and California Department of Public Health data on non-fatal self-inflicted injuries. The literature review included 166 evaluation studies and 34 relevant articles from five databases.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data from the literature review were abstracted using standardized data abstraction forms and reviewed for consistency.  The abstracted data were organized into a conceptual model to describe how suicide prevention programs, if they achieve their proximal goals, may ultimately help reduce suicides.

sections.title: Appendix A: Opportunities for Other Improvements in the Total Force Assessment
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of TFA-I methodology and process, based on TFA documents, BIM software, input and output files.  Quantitative review of TFA data for Reserve, Guard, and active components to identify problems. Comparison of results using proposed methodology and TFA-I methodology.

sections.title: Appendix D: MDS Authorizations Whose Requirements Need to Be Estimated Elsewhere
sections.methods_summary: Discussion of manpower categories (contractor manpower-equivalents, individual mobilization augmentees, reserve and guard civilian technicians, etc.) excluded from the main models due to requiring separate estimation methods or being inappropriate for inclusion.

sections.title: References
sections.methods_summary: List of data sources used in the research.

sections.title: Section 3: A More Broadly Applicable Methodology for Manpower Requirements
sections.methods_summary: Describes a proposed methodology for estimating manpower requirements.  This includes a BIM-like classification of MDS authorizations and TPFDD positions into four categories (deployable forces, in-place combat forces, continuing mission, support).  The methodology uses RAND's modified BIM (BIM-R) to estimate in-place support, adjusting for wartime workweek and workload changes.  It also addresses how to handle untasked forces under different requirements policies (e.g., overseas forward presence).

sections.title: Section 4: Manpower Requirements for Sample Alternative Scenarios
sections.methods_summary: Applies the proposed methodology to various scenarios (two-MTW, one-MTW SWA, one-MTW NEA, and small-scale contingency vignettes).  Compares resulting requirements with MDS authorizations and TFA-I results.  Analyzes differences and assesses the implications of different requirements policies.

sections.title: Section 5: Adequacy of the Estimated Requirements for Peacetime Engagements
sections.methods_summary: Assesses the adequacy of existing manpower authorizations for meeting peacetime EAF demands without reserve call-ups.  Compares manpower authorizations with actual personnel demand data to determine sufficiency within deployment tour length limits.  Analyzes data from AEF libraries and DRMDs.  Examines the potential contribution of Reserve and Guard manpower.

sections.title: Section 6: Concluding Observations
sections.methods_summary: Summarizes the contributions of the proposed methodology, highlighting improvements over TFA-I.  Offers suggestions for future TFA-like exercises, including improvements to the merge methodology, continual reexamination of requirements policy, establishment of a quality control organization, and greater feedback and control for the process.  Also discusses the need for more model automation and clarification of logic.

primary_methods: Data analysis (of TFA data, MDS, TPFDD)
analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the Total Force Assessment (TFA) Phase I, including the Manpower Data System (MDS), Time-Phased Force and Deployment Data (TPFDD), and Base Infrastructure Model (BIM) output.  The analysis also includes data from the Aerospace Expeditionary Force (AEF) libraries and Deployment Requirements Manning Documents (DRMDs).
analysis.analysis_approach: The research uses a comparative analysis approach, comparing the results of the proposed methodology with the TFA-I methodology and existing manpower authorizations.  The analysis involves quantitative review of data, model development and application (BIM-R), and scenario analysis to assess the implications of different requirements policies.

sections.title: Survey Design and Sampling
sections.methods_summary: Two surveys were conducted: a General Population Survey (GPS) and a Decision Maker Survey (DMS).
