The GPS involved 11,832 respondents in 15 EU Member States, Switzerland, and the US in 2002, and 10,407 respondents in 10 Accession Countries in 2003.  The DMS covered 3,139 establishments in 7 EU Member States.  Details of samples and methodological aspects are in Annex 1.

sections.title: Methodology of the GPS and DMS Surveys
sections.methods_summary: GPS 2002: Computer-aided telephone interviews (CATI) in 15 EU Member States, Switzerland, and the US.  Sampling involved random selection of households, with adjustments for household size and alignment with official statistics. GPS-NAS 2003: Personal aided personal interviews (PAPI) in 10 Accession Countries. Sampling used multistage stratified random-route sampling or random samples from official sources, with adjustments for household size and alignment with official statistics. DMS 2002: CATI in 7 EU Member States. Sampling used stratified random sampling based on industry and size class quotas, with weighting to reflect employment distribution.

sections.title: Methodology of the R&D Survey
sections.methods_summary: Postal survey of 1578 researchers in 6 EU Member States and Switzerland.  Sampling aimed for at least 30 scientists per discipline in smaller countries and 40 in larger countries, with a target response rate of 20%. Addresses were collected from scholarly associations and internet searches.  Weighting was used to account for differing sample structures across disciplines.

analysis.sample_description: The study used data from two main surveys: a General Population Survey (GPS) and a Decision Maker Survey (DMS). The GPS surveyed a large sample of individuals across EU member states, accession countries, Switzerland, and the US. The DMS focused on businesses in selected EU member states.  A separate R&D survey targeted researchers in specific scientific disciplines and countries.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report does not explicitly detail the statistical analysis techniques used beyond mentioning weighting adjustments to account for sample biases and the use of indices to combine multiple indicators.  More detailed analysis is likely presented in the individual topic reports referenced in the document.

sections.title: Methodology: Initial Phase of Evaluation
sections.methods_summary: The methodology for the initial phase involved developing baseline institutional profiles, analyzing design proposals, conducting site visits with interviews of key personnel, reviewing state policies, and conducting interviews with Carnegie Corporation representatives and AED representatives.  Data collected included work plans, progress reports, and work products.

sections.title: Methodology: Theory of Change
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines the theory of change underlying the TNE initiative, based on an analysis of the TNE prospectus and selection criteria.  It describes the design principles, enabling factors (external resources, universitywide commitment, strong leadership, supportive policy environment, high-quality program entrants, high-quality faculty, strong faculty commitment to reform, and strong partnerships with K-12 schools), and the transition from 'excellent' to 'exemplary' teacher education programs.  The methodology is primarily qualitative, drawing on document analysis and expert judgment.

analysis.sample_description: Four institutions (Bank Street College of Education, California State University, Northridge, Michigan State University, and the University of Virginia) were selected for the study.  The sample was not randomly selected but chosen based on Carnegie's selection criteria.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of data collected through document review, interviews, and site visits.  The analysis focuses on identifying cross-site themes and lessons learned.

sections.title: Identifying Stresses and Developing the Mission-Day Metric
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used to identify stresses on the MAF aircrews and to develop the mission-day metric.  It involved examining aircrew retention statistics (cumulative continuation rates and aircrew continuation pay acceptances), analyzing data from the Report on Career Decisions in the Air Force to understand reasons for separation, and developing the mission-day metric to quantify workload and OPTEMPO stresses.  Data sources included Air Force Operational Readiness Management System (AFORMS), Air Force Personnel Data System (AFPD), and the Global Decision Support System (GDSS).

sections.title: Evaluation of Existing Metrics
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the assessment of existing metrics used by the Air Mobility Command (AMC) to measure MAF readiness.  The metrics examined include million ton-miles/day, flying-hour program execution, currency and upgrade training accomplishment, and TDY days per crewmember per year.  The analysis involved evaluating the strengths and limitations of each metric in capturing stresses on the system and their impact on readiness.

sections.title: Application of the Mission-Day Metric
sections.methods_summary: This section details the application of the newly developed mission-day metric to the 437th Airlift Wing.  The methodology involved calculating peacetime availability to fly operational missions by subtracting various activities (weekends, holidays, leave, additional duties, training, TDYs, PCS, etc.) from the total available crewmember days.  Peacetime engagement mission requirements were then calculated based on mission length, crew complement, and additional requirements for specific mission types (BANNER, aerial refueling).  The supply and demand of mission-days were compared for all pilots and for senior pilots (aircraft commanders and above) to assess OPTEMPO stresses.

analysis.sample_description: The primary sample is the 437th Airlift Wing, with data also used from broader Air Force datasets on retention, career decisions, and operational data.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved quantitative analysis of existing data sources and the development and application of a new metric (mission-day) to assess the operational tempo and its impact on readiness.  Time series analysis was used to track changes in supply and demand over time.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the key assumptions and limitations of the study, including focusing on high-data-rate networks, nonlethal threats, and the limitations of complete system immunity.  It describes the threats (mobile ground jammers and ground-based SIGINT receivers), requirements, and baselines used in the analysis.  The systems and programs under review are listed, including JTIDS, JTRS, and the CDL family.  The data-rate requirement is discussed, along with the use of a parametric approach and considerations of data compression.  The analysis of threats from jamming and SIGINT receivers is explained, including formulas used and the impact of spread spectrum and time-hopping.  Signal detection analysis is detailed, focusing on a standard radiometer as an example and providing formulas for probability of detection and false-alarm probability.  The analysis includes consideration of trade-offs between received signal level, predetection resolution bandwidth, and detector integration time.

primary_methods: Analysis of existing systems and programs (JTIDS, JTRS, CDL family)
Mathematical modeling of jamming and signal detection
Parametric analysis of data rate requirements
Examination of trade-offs between different communication options
analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is not an empirical study with a human or physical sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses mathematical models and formulas to assess the effects of jamming and interception on communication links.  It considers various parameters such as data rate, antenna size, range, frequency, and signal processing techniques.  The analysis also involves comparing the performance of different communication systems and options under various threat scenarios.

sections.title: Methodology: Development of Supplemental QI Items
sections.methods_summary: This section details a four-step process: 1) Diagnosing the problem through semi-structured interviews with 27 health plan representatives; 2) Identifying priority topic areas using a two-round Delphi process with 18 participants from 13 health plans; 3) Developing specific items within priority topic areas through three review panel meetings with health plan representatives; and 4) Field-testing candidate supplemental QI items with three health plans using CAHPS 3.0 survey data.

sections.title: Methodology: Diagnosing the Problem
sections.methods_summary: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with a purposive sample of 27 health plans categorized by their CAHPS usage and performance.  The interviews aimed to gather in-depth information on quality improvement activities and perspectives on CAHPS's role.  Findings are not generalizable but provided a strong consensus to guide item development.

sections.title: Methodology: Identifying Priority Topic Areas
sections.methods_summary: A two-step consensus process was used: 1) A Delphi process with two rounds, involving 18 individuals from 13 health plans, to identify priority topic areas based on ratings and relative rankings; and 2) Analysis of reliability and consistency of ratings and rankings across the two rounds of the Delphi process to determine the stability of answers given by the experts.

sections.title: Methodology: Developing Specific Items
sections.methods_summary: Three review panel meetings were held with different types of health plans (sophisticated users, moderate users, and exclusive CAHPS users) to gather feedback on survey items within the priority topic areas identified in the Delphi process.  The panels provided feedback on wording and content of specific survey items.

sections.title: Methodology: Field-Testing Candidate Supplemental QI Items
sections.methods_summary: Twenty-three supplemental QI items were developed and field-tested with three health plans using CAHPS 3.0.  Data analysis addressed four questions: 1) Psychometric performance of items (tabulations, frequencies, univariate statistics); 2) Discrimination of performance across health plans (regression models with dummy variables for plans and products); 3) Uniqueness of QI items compared to CAHPS composites (correlation matrix); and 4) Redundancy among QI items (correlations and multivariate regressions).

sections.title: Methodology: Health Plan Interviews
sections.methods_summary: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with representatives from a purposive sample of 27 health plans, categorized by CAHPS usage and performance. A standardized interview protocol was used, focusing on the importance of consumer measures, CAHPS usage for quality improvement, feedback on CAHPS limitations, and identification of action-oriented data needs.

sections.title: Methodology: Health Plan Sample Selection
sections.methods_summary: Health plans were selected in collaboration with BCBSA and NCQA, categorized into three groups: plans not using CAHPS, plans using CAHPS without public reporting, and plans publicly reporting CAHPS results (further stratified by performance levels).  Recruitment involved a BCBSA web-based survey and collaboration with NCQA for selecting plans based on Quality Compass data.

sections.title: Methodology: Interview Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Interview data were analyzed using a two-step process:  Initial notes and transcriptions were reviewed and finalized, then a spreadsheet was created to quantify concepts and facilitate frequency counts and qualitative analysis.  Data were disaggregated by sample selection criteria to identify patterns.

sections.title: Methodology: Delphi Process Reliability Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Reliability of importance ratings was estimated using a one-way model, partitioning variance between and within topic areas. Correlations between ranks and ratings, and correlations across time points (Time 1 and Time 2), were computed using Spearman rank-order correlations.

analysis.sample_description: The study involved a purposive sample of 27 health plans, categorized by their CAHPS usage and performance levels.  The Delphi process involved 18 participants from 13 health plans.  The review panels included representatives from various health plans with differing levels of CAHPS usage and data sophistication.  Field testing involved data from three health plans.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data analysis included descriptive statistics, reliability analysis (intraclass correlation, Spearman correlations), regression analysis (with dummy variables), and correlation analysis to assess psychometric properties, discrimination across health plans, uniqueness of QI items, and redundancy among items.

sections.title: Supporting Tables
sections.methods_summary: This section presents tables of baseline covariate differences between program and comparison groups before and after weighting for several sites (A-G).  It shows effect sizes and p-values for various variables, indicating the success of weighting in balancing covariates.

sections.title: Supporting Tables (continued)
sections.methods_summary: Continuation of the previous section, providing similar tables for sites H-J.  Again, effect sizes and p-values for various variables are presented to assess covariate balance before and after weighting.

sections.title: Supporting Tables (continued)
sections.methods_summary: Further continuation of the tables showing baseline covariate differences before and after weighting, this time for site I and J.  The tables detail effect sizes and p-values for numerous variables.

sections.title: Supporting Tables (continued)
sections.methods_summary: Final supporting tables summarizing treatment effects for all facilities and all outcomes, along with post-hoc power calculations.  This section provides a summary of the results across all sites.

sections.title: Case-Mix Adjustment Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section details the case-mix adjustment approach using propensity score weights estimated with a generalized boosting model (GBM).  It describes the 86 control variables from the GAIN survey used for adjustment and the process of weighting to maximize similarity between treatment and comparison groups.  It also mentions the use of weighted analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) to account for remaining imbalances.

sections.title: Case-Mix Adjustment Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section defines the causal effect of interest (average treatment effect on the treated, ATT) and describes the statistical methods used to estimate it.  It explains the use of propensity score weighting with GBM to create a synthetic comparison group and the use of weighted ANCOVA to adjust for remaining covariate imbalances.  The Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) test is used to assess covariate balance.

sections.title: Study Procedures
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the study sample, including the inclusion and exclusion criteria.  It details the data collection procedures using the GAIN survey and its follow-up versions.  The six outcome measures are defined, along with the 86 baseline control variables selected from the GAIN survey based on ASAM criteria.  Missing data imputation using regression model hot-deck imputation is explained.

sections.title: Case-Mix Adjusted Comparison Samples
sections.methods_summary: This section assesses the success of the propensity score weighting in creating comparable comparison groups.  It uses the Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) test statistic to evaluate the similarity of covariate distributions before and after weighting.  It discusses the use of weighted ANCOVA for programs where weighting was insufficient to balance covariates.  Effective sample sizes after weighting are presented, along with minimum detectable effect sizes.

analysis.sample_description: The sample included all available cases from the ATM study as of March 2002 with completed 12-month assessments (over 90% of the original sample).  Cases admitted less than 12 months prior or lost to follow-up were excluded.  The sample comprised adolescents from 10 different treatment programs (one program excluded due to small sample size).
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis approach was to estimate the average treatment effect on the treated (ATT) for each program compared to other programs within the same level of care (LTR, STR, OP).  Propensity score weighting was used to adjust for differences in pretreatment characteristics, with weighted ANCOVA used to further adjust for remaining imbalances.  The Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) test was used to assess covariate balance, and randomization tests were used to evaluate the significance of remaining imbalances.

sections.title: Survey Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A web-based Joint Officer Management (JOM) Census survey was conducted in summer 2005.  The survey targeted three types of billets: those on the Joint Duty Assignment List (JDAL), non-JDAL billets in external organizations with some JDAL billets, and internal service billets nominated by the services as providing or requiring joint experience or education.  Due to an outdated sampling frame, the survey covered a subset of the intended billets (30,043 surveyed, 21,214 responses). Billets were categorized by JDAL status and major billet organization.

sections.title: Survey Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Web-based survey of individuals in billets requiring or providing joint experience.  Three types of billets were included: those on the JDAL, non-JDAL billets in external organizations with some JDAL billets, and internal service billets nominated by the services.  Due to an outdated sampling frame, the survey did not include all intended billets.  The survey included questions on billet characteristics, tasks performed, time allocation, task importance, responsibility levels, interactions with organizations and personnel, knowledge required and gained, and experience.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample included approximately 30,000 billets, encompassing JDAL billets, non-JDAL billets in external organizations with some JDAL billets, and internal service billets nominated by the services. Due to an outdated sampling frame, the final sample included a subset of these billets (30,043 surveyed, 21,214 responses).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved categorizing billets by JDAL status and major billet organization.  Descriptive statistics (percentages, means, medians) were used to summarize responses.  Rank ordering of billets based on various indicators of 'jointness' was also performed.  The study notes that more complex analysis (e.g., to estimate demand for and supply of joint officers) would be conducted in a later phase.

sections.title: Prototype Database: Structure, Data Entry, Retrieval, and Manipulation
sections.methods_summary: Describes the existing database architecture implemented in Lotus Notes/Domino. Details data entry (manual), retrieval (hierarchical system, user familiarity), and manipulation (formula and scripting languages, data copying to Excel for advanced analysis).  Assesses strengths and limitations of the prototype, highlighting manual data entry, hierarchical organization challenges, and difficulties in performing computations within the system.

sections.title: Recommendations for Social Indicators Database System Architecture
sections.methods_summary: Proposes improvements to the database architecture, including establishing electronic data exchange standards (XML), using a dedicated DBMS (RDBMS or data warehouse), adopting a three-tiered client/server architecture, implementing a web browser interface, and adding ad hoc query capabilities.  Also discusses the use of international coding and classification standards.

sections.title: Strategic Actions for Future Database Implementation
sections.methods_summary: Outlines strategic actions for implementing the recommendations, including understanding data sources, reviewing data gaps, in-depth indicator review, recomputing indicators for consistency, determining new data collection needs, and establishing cooperation with the Planning Council.  Also discusses pursuing longer-term objectives involving microdata analysis and new multipurpose surveys.

sections.title: Appendix A: Proposed Database Architecture
sections.methods_summary: Expands on the technical details of the recommended database architecture.  Discusses data exchange standards (XML and schema languages), the use of a DBMS (RDBMS and data warehouses), a three-tiered client/server architecture, web-based implementation, and ad hoc query provisions. Provides examples of XML coding and SQL queries.

sections.title: Appendix B: Organization, Resource, and Timeline Considerations
sections.methods_summary: Discusses organizational structure for the project (placing it within the Statistics and Analysis Department with an Advisory Committee), resource requirements (personnel, outsourcing, hardware/software, training), and a proposed timeline (three-year horizon, two-stage approach: proof-of-concept and production system).  Estimates resource needs and provides a detailed schedule.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is a report on database design and not a study with a sample.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach is primarily descriptive and prescriptive, focusing on evaluating the existing database, proposing improvements, and outlining a plan for implementation.  It uses a combination of qualitative assessment (strengths and weaknesses of the prototype) and quantitative considerations (resource estimation, timeline).

sections.title: Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a comparative case study design, observing combat support execution planning and control (CSC2) processes during two Air Force exercises: Terminal Fury 2004 (TF04) and Austere Challenge 2004 (AC04).  A RAND team, along with Air Force personnel, participated in both exercises. Data were collected through observation of CSC2 processes under stress, supplemented by daily teleconferences with strategic partners representing the broader Air Force combat support community. The focus was on evaluating the Air Force's transition to a new CSC2 architecture and identifying areas for improvement.  The closed-loop aspect of the CSC2 process could not be fully assessed due to exercise time constraints.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample consisted of CSC2 processes observed during two Air Force exercises (TF04 and AC04).  The exercises involved various Air Force organizations and personnel, including those in theater and CONUS.
analysis.analysis_approach: The assessment team reviewed CSC2 processes across and within nodes, examining communication methods, systems used, and training and education efforts.  The analysis compared observed processes with the goals of a new TO-BE CSC2 operational architecture.  Findings were discussed with strategic partners to gain broader insights.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: Four-step approach: 1) Identified six plausible attack scenarios. 2) Developed the modified intelligence preparation of the battlefield (ModIPB) framework. 3) Designated a "red team" to gather information using only public sources. 4) Undertook three validation exercises to assess the relevance and completeness of the information collected.

sections.title: Deﬁning Terrorists’ Information Requirements: The ModIPB Framework
sections.methods_summary: Developed a modified IPB (ModIPB) framework based on U.S. Army doctrine and the al Qaeda manual.  This framework categorized information needs into four areas: avenues of approach, target features, security, and threats to the operation.  A red team of RAND research assistants, serving as proxies for terrorist researchers, used the ModIPB framework to gather information from public sources.  Three validation exercises were conducted: review by SMEs, interviews with infrastructure insiders, and a comparison with an expert information gatherer.

sections.title: Summary of Red-Team Findings and Validation
sections.methods_summary: Describes the red team's information gathering for each of six scenarios.  Validation involved review by subject matter experts (SMEs), interviews with infrastructure insiders, and comparison with an expert red team member's findings.

analysis.sample_description: Six hypothetical terrorist attack scenarios involving air, rail, and maritime transportation infrastructures.  The red team consisted of RAND research assistants.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of information gathered by the red team, categorized using the ModIPB framework.  Validation exercises assessed the completeness and accuracy of the findings.  A stoplight system was used to summarize the sufficiency of information found for each scenario.

sections.title: Data Collection and Survey Design
sections.methods_summary: Combined stated preference (SP) and revealed preference (RP) surveys were conducted with non-resident visitors and residents of the Isles of Scilly.  The SP survey involved three experiments: a within-mode experiment comparing ferry alternatives, a between-mode experiment comparing ferry, airplane, and helicopter alternatives, and a between-mode experiment with no ferry option.  The RP survey collected data on actual travel choices.  Specific attributes like fares, journey times, and comfort were considered.  The surveys also included stated intention questions about how travel frequency might change under different scenarios.

sections.title: Fieldwork and Data Collection Details
sections.methods_summary: Accent Marketing and Research conducted the fieldwork.  Details on the number of shifts, interviewer hours, and achieved quotas for each mode (fixed-wing, helicopter, ferry) and trip length (day trip, long stay) are provided.  Response rates and productivity are discussed.  The process of obtaining stated preference (SP) opt-ins from revealed preference (RP) respondents is described.  The SP survey involved mailing materials and scheduling telephone interviews.  The number of completed SP interviews is reported, along with conversion rates.

sections.title: Sample Sizes and Model Structure
sections.methods_summary: Sample size targets and final numbers of respondents for both RP and SP surveys are presented for different traveller segments (day-trip visitors, staying visitors, residents/business/VFR).  The model needed to represent changes in modal shift and total travel demand, focusing on trip frequency.  The analysis was restricted to existing travellers and residents due to cost constraints.  Total annual trips were estimated separately using trend analysis.

sections.title: Mode Choice Model Estimation and Results
sections.methods_summary: Disaggregate discrete mode choice and trip frequency models were developed for different traveller segments.  RP and SP data were used jointly to estimate coefficients, accounting for error variation between datasets.  Nested model structures were tested to account for correlation between alternatives and inertia.  A secondary estimation procedure re-estimated mode-specific constants using RP data only.  The best models incorporated income-specific cost sensitivity, resulting in income-specific values of time.  Values of time for ferry time and quality improvements are presented.  Ferry fare elasticities are calculated and compared to other studies.

sections.title: Scenario Analysis and Model Limitations
sections.methods_summary: Several scenarios were evaluated using a sample enumeration procedure: 'Do Minimum' (no ferry after 2014), 'Do Something 1/2' (new ferry, minor harbour improvements), and 'Do Something 3/4' (faster new ferry, harbour improvements).  Results are presented graphically, showing demand by mode.  A sensitivity analysis is performed by reducing the effects of the new boat and harbour improvements by 50% to account for potential overestimation.

sections.title: Study Scope and Traveller Segmentation
sections.methods_summary: The study aimed to predict traveller responses to changes in transport services, focusing on trip frequency rather than overall travel choice.  Analysis was limited to existing travellers and residents.  Freight demand was excluded.  Annual trips by traveller segment were estimated separately using trend analysis.  Three traveller segments were defined: business and residents, non-resident day-trip travellers, and non-resident staying travellers.  Quotas were set for residents/business travellers together.

sections.title: Survey Methodology and Data Quality Checks
sections.methods_summary: Detailed descriptions of the RP and SP surveys are provided, including the variables and levels used in each experiment.  Data quality checks were performed on both RP and SP datasets for non-residents and residents.  Exclusions were made based on inconsistencies, incomplete answers, and non-intuitive responses to dominant questions.  Analysis of trading between choice alternatives is presented using Venn diagrams.

sections.title: Mode Choice Model: Joint SP/RP Estimation
sections.methods_summary: Joint SP/RP modelling was used to estimate model coefficients.  Utility equations were set up for RP and SP choice alternatives.  Parameters for variables common to both datasets were jointly estimated, while separate coefficients were estimated for terms specific to each dataset.  Assumptions about the distribution of unmeasured utility components were made.  A scale parameter was estimated to account for differences in variance between datasets.  Model specification tests were conducted, including tests for cost specification, linearity of ferry travel time valuation, and inertia.  Model summary statistics and coefficient values with t-ratios are presented.  Model fit was assessed using log-likelihood values and likelihood ratio tests.

sections.title: Mode Choice Model Results, Validation, and Calibration
sections.methods_summary: Mode choice model results are presented for day-trip visitors, long-stay visitors, and residents.  Model validation involved examining values of time and values of quality improvements.  Model calibration was performed to ensure that the model replicated observed mode shares using weighting procedures to account for different traveller segments.  Eight model segments were defined to account for the different traveller types and purposes.

sections.title: Trip Frequency Model Estimation and Results
sections.methods_summary: Stated intentions data were used to estimate disaggregate models of changes in trip frequency.  A logit model was used to relate trip rate to accessibility (logsum from the mode choice model) and socioeconomic variables.  Model results are presented for non-resident travellers (day-trip and staying visitors) and residents (leisure and business travel).  Predicted changes in aggregate trip numbers are compared to reported figures from the SI survey.

sections.title: Forecasting Tool: Sample Enumeration, Inputs, Outputs, and Consumer Surplus Calculation
sections.methods_summary: A forecasting tool using sample enumeration was developed in Excel.  User inputs include ferry type, journey time, timetable, harbour improvements, and fare increases.  Outputs include demand, revenue, and consumer surplus for each mode and segment.  Consumer surplus is calculated using the analytic integral of the demand function and converted to monetary units using the model cost coefficient.  The calculation is adjusted for shadow pricing when ferry capacity is exceeded.  Adjustment factors are applied to correct for differences between model-implied and DfT-recommended values of time.  The tool also incorporates trip frequency responses.

analysis.sample_description: The study involved both non-resident visitors and residents of the Isles of Scilly, segmented into day-trip visitors, staying visitors, and residents/business/VFR travellers.  Sample sizes exceeded initial targets in many cases.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis combined stated preference and revealed preference data in a joint estimation procedure to develop mode choice and trip frequency models.  Model fit was assessed using log-likelihood values and likelihood ratio tests.  Scenario analysis was conducted to evaluate the impact of different transport service options.  Consumer surplus was calculated using the analytic integral of the demand function, accounting for capacity constraints and differences between model-implied and DfT-recommended values of time.

sections.title: Cost Analysis Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Comparison of baseline and follow-up costs for each program. Baseline and follow-up periods were based on program start date, except for Inside-Out Writers (IOW), which used a six-month period before and after release from juvenile hall. School attendance was included as a cost component for school-based programs.  Estimated costs included program administration, probation costs (supervision, camp stays, juvenile hall days), arrests, and court appearances.  A benefit (negative cost) was included for improved attendance in school-based programs.  Limitations acknowledged:  costs for non-JJCPA programs during the baseline period were unavailable; six months may be insufficient to assess long-term cost savings.

sections.title: Evaluation Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Quasi-experimental designs were used, employing comparison groups (matched on demographic, criminal history, and offense severity factors) where possible.  Propensity score matching was used for some programs.  Pre/post designs were used when appropriate comparison groups were unavailable.  Six-month follow-up periods were used (after release from juvenile hall for hall-based programs).  Statistical significance testing (chi-square tests and difference of means tests) was used with p < .05 as the significance level.  Limitations acknowledged:  comparability of comparison groups could not be verified for all programs; historical comparison groups were used for some programs; data quality varied across programs and outcome measures.

analysis.sample_description: The study included various JJCPA programs in Los Angeles County during FY04-05.  Sample sizes varied across programs and outcome measures.  Comparison groups were constructed using various methods, including matching on relevant characteristics and historical comparison groups.  A total of 30,933 youths received services.
analysis.analysis_approach: Statistical significance testing (p < .05) was used to compare outcomes between program and comparison groups.  Cost comparisons were made between baseline and follow-up periods for each program, considering program administration, probation costs, arrests, court appearances, and school attendance savings.

sections.title: Approach and Overview of Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used a conceptual framework based on the costs and benefits of migration and the role of social networks.  Housing habitability was identified as the key driver of repopulation. A qualitative approach was used to estimate repopulation rates due to limited data availability.  This involved a consensus process among the authors, drawing on various primary and secondary sources including media reports, government data, reports from organizations like the Brookings Institution, and interviews with experts.

sections.title: Methodology: Estimating Future Population
sections.methods_summary: The study used a model (Equation 1:  it i it RPP × =0) to estimate future population based on pre-Katrina population by housing condition and estimated repopulation rates for four damage categories at four time points.  Due to limited data, a qualitative approach based on consensus among the authors was used to determine repopulation rates.  The four damage categories were based on floodwater depth: no flooding, <2 feet, 2-4 feet, and >4 feet. Data on dwellings and population by census block were obtained from the 2000 Census.

sections.title: Methodology: Pre-Katrina Population Estimates
sections.methods_summary: New Orleans dwellings were categorized into four damage levels based on floodwater depth (no damage, minor, serious, severe).  Data on housing units and population by block were obtained from the 2000 Census and combined with remote sensing data on floodwater depth (September 10, 2005) using a geographic information system (GIS) to determine the population within each damage category.

sections.title: Methodology: Estimates of Repopulation Rates
sections.methods_summary: A qualitative consensus approach was used to estimate repopulation rates for each damage category at four time points (3 months, 6 months, 1 year, 3 years post-flood).  The consensus was informed by a wide array of data sources: media reports, government data, reports from various organizations, interviews with professionals, and data from GCR and Associates, Inc. Key considerations included insurance and financing, construction and rebuilding timelines, and the willingness and ability of residents to return.  Assumptions about these factors were documented.

sections.title: Methodology: Estimates of Future Population and Sensitivity Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Future population estimates were calculated by applying the repopulation rates (from Table 3.2) to the pre-Katrina population estimates by damage category (from Table 3.1) using Equation 1. A sensitivity analysis was conducted by varying assumptions about damage severity and repopulation rates to assess the impact on the population estimates.  Spatial patterns of repopulation were mapped based on the results.

analysis.sample_description: The study used block-level data from the 2000 US Census for the entire city of New Orleans.  The analysis focused on the pre-Katrina population and its distribution across four flood damage categories.
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis involved applying a model to estimate future population based on pre-Katrina population distribution and qualitatively derived repopulation rates. A sensitivity analysis was conducted to assess the robustness of the estimates to changes in key assumptions.

sections.title: Methodological Underpinnings and Research and Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the use of logic models as a framework for strategic planning and evaluation.  The methodology involved developing NCIPC-tailored logic models by gathering information through reviewing existing planning documents and meeting with NCIPC staff.  A series of discussion points guided the meetings to elicit information about NCIPC's operations and strategy.  Existing strategic planning documents and management efforts were also reviewed. Draft models were presented to NCIPC staff for feedback and adjustments were made based on ongoing discussions and meetings.  To assist NCIPC in identifying, selecting, and effectively using evidence for the PART process, the researchers reviewed PART submissions from ten relevant federal programs, categorized the sources of evidence by PART sections, and provided recommendations on how NCIPC could apply its logic models to facilitate evidence selection and use.

sections.title: Gleaning Information for NCIPC-Tailored Logic Models
sections.methods_summary: Data collection involved reviewing existing planning documents and conducting meetings with NCIPC senior staff from various divisions and offices.  A series of discussion points guided these meetings, focusing on the program's goals, operations, inputs, activities, outputs, customers, partners, and external factors.  The information gathered was categorized according to the basic elements of the logic model to develop NCIPC-tailored logic models. Draft models were presented to NCIPC staff for feedback and iterative refinement.

sections.title: Identifying, Selecting, and Effectively Using Evidence
sections.methods_summary: The researchers reviewed PART submissions from ten federal programs relevant to NCIPC to identify potential sources of evidence.  The information was organized in Microsoft Excel worksheets categorized by the four PART sections.  This allowed for analysis of similarities and differences in evidence sources and explanations used to support evidence selection.

sections.title: Developing NCIPC-Tailored Logic Models
sections.methods_summary: A replicable process for developing logic models was used, starting with the logic model template and involving four steps: gathering information, modifying the template, filling in program-specific details, and validating the model.  Two significant deviations from the template emerged: the depiction of NCIPC's partners and the interdependencies among its activities and outputs.  The resulting modified model depicted the fully articulated path of NCIPC operations, highlighting partnerships, interdependencies, and overarching themes of coordination and changes in knowledge, attitudes, and behavior.

sections.title: Formulating Strategy and Generating Goals and Measures
sections.methods_summary: Three general approaches to conceptualizing strategic goals were described: activity-based, divisionally based, and priority area–based.  A mixed approach was suggested for NCIPC.  A hypothetical priority area, "sexual violence," was used to illustrate the process of generating goals and measures from the operational path and template.  The process involved developing strategic goals that addressed outcomes, target groups, and approach, with corresponding measures.  Intermediate and annual goals and measures were also generated, ensuring vertical alignment with the operational path and strategic goals.

sections.title: Using Evidence for Program Evaluation
sections.methods_summary: The logic model was used to facilitate the selection and effective use of evidence for the PART review.  The researchers reviewed PART submissions from ten programs to identify potential sources of evidence. The logic model provided a framework to ensure that the selected evidence was consistent with the program's operations and strategic goals.  The importance of demonstrating causal linkages between elements of the logic model was emphasized.  The use of the logic model for different sections of PART was discussed, highlighting the generation of evidence for Section II and the selection and use of evidence for Sections I, III, and IV.  The use of intermediate outcomes as evidence to support progress toward long-term goals was illustrated.  The use of program activities and outputs as evidence to demonstrate achievement of annual performance goals was also described.

sections.title: Gathering Evidence for Program Improvement
sections.methods_summary: The focus shifted to gathering evidence for program improvement, emphasizing understanding the reasons behind achieved (or unachieved) outcomes.  The importance of considering external factors and their impact on program outcomes was highlighted.  The logic model's incorporation of external factors was used as a framework for identifying areas for program improvement.  Examples were provided to illustrate how awareness of external factors could lead to changes in program design and service delivery.

analysis.sample_description: The study focused on the National Center for Injury Prevention and Control (NCIPC) and reviewed PART submissions from ten other relevant federal programs.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of documents and interview data, using a logic model framework to organize and interpret findings.  The analysis focused on identifying potential sources of evidence for PART review and program improvement, and on illustrating how the logic model could facilitate the selection and effective use of evidence.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study examined the relationship between fatality rate and business size using data from OSHA accident investigation reports, employment data from County Business Patterns (CBP), and a table from the U.S. Census on employment.  Poisson regression analysis was used to control for other variables.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used fatality data from OSHA's Integrated Management Information System (IMIS) for the years 1992-2001, excluding construction and certain event types (highway crashes, assaults). Employment data came from County Business Patterns (CBP) and the U.S. Census Bureau.  Poisson regression analysis was used to control for confounding variables such as unionization and metropolitan location.  The analysis also examined the types of accidents and OSHA violations associated with fatalities in different establishment sizes.

sections.title: Discussion of the Poisson Regression Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Poisson regression analysis was used to examine the relationship between fatality rate and establishment/firm size, controlling for metropolitan location, unionization, and year.  The analysis used data from OSHA's IMIS database, specifically programmed inspections and accident investigations.  The model assumed a Poisson distribution of fatal accidents and used the number of employees as an offset variable.

analysis.sample_description: The main analysis used OSHA fatality investigation data from 1992-2001 (all states), excluding construction and certain event types. A secondary analysis using Poisson regression used data from federal OSHA states, including randomly conducted planned inspections in manufacturing from 1984-1995 and fatality investigations in the same industries during that period.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics were used to examine the relationship between fatality rates and establishment/firm size.  Poisson regression analysis was used to control for confounding variables and to examine the independent effects of establishment and firm size on fatality risk.

sections.title: Appendix B: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used a benchmarking approach with three case studies.  Data collection involved desk-based research (annual reports, internal documents, articles, academic papers, external reviews) and semi-structured interviews using a standardized protocol.  Interviews were conducted with senior executives, HR managers, operations managers, training and development managers, and personal advisors.  A cluster analysis technique was used to summarize findings and identify themes and lessons for Jobcentre Plus.

analysis.sample_description: Three case study organizations were selected based on criteria including organizational function, customer groups, organizational type, operational characteristics, examples of good practice, and transferability of lessons to Jobcentre Plus. Pragmatic considerations such as NAO audit burden, availability of information, and willingness to participate also influenced selection.
analysis.analysis_approach: A cluster analysis technique was used to identify common themes and differences across the case studies, to explore lessons for Jobcentre Plus, and to consider potential process improvements.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: The study uses a revealed preference approach.  It infers the value of expedited PDM from the Air Force's decisions to undertake PDM visits, assuming these decisions were rational.  The analysis focuses on the minimum net benefits required to justify the cost of each PDM visit, working backward from the final visit to the initial acquisition.

sections.title: Simple Valuation of Expedited PDM
sections.methods_summary: This section presents a simplified model. It assumes a constant net benefit (total benefit minus incremental cost) after each PDM visit.  Using Air Force Total Ownership Cost (AFTOC) data, the cost of a PDM visit is estimated. Two scenarios are explored: a triangular valuation (linearly decreasing net surplus) and a constant valuation. The minimum net surplus required to justify the fourth (final) PDM visit is calculated, and this is used to estimate the value of expediting the visit by one month.

sections.title: Valuing F-15 PDM Speed with Declining Aircraft Valuation
sections.methods_summary: This section enhances the model by incorporating declining aircraft valuation over time.  Data on F-15 mission capability (MC) and full mission capability (FMC) rates from the Reliability and Maintainability Information System (REMIS) are used to estimate the annual valuation decline rate. Regression analysis is performed on the natural logarithm of MC and FMC rates against aircraft age.  The resulting decline rates (1.35% for FMC and 1.7% for MC) are incorporated into the PDM acceleration valuation calculation.  AFTOC data are used to estimate ordinary operations costs and the cost of PDM visits.  The value of expediting each PDM visit is then recalculated using the declining valuation curves.

sections.title: Robustness Explorations
sections.methods_summary: This section assesses the robustness of the findings by considering three extensions: (1) aging aircraft effects (variable operating and PDM costs over the aircraft's lifetime, using data from Pyles [2003]); (2) a constraint that life-cycle benefits equal or exceed life-cycle costs (including acquisition costs); and (3) possible post-PDM valuation jumps (analyzing the impact of a potential increase in aircraft valuation after a PDM visit).  The analysis involves repeating the PDM acceleration valuation calculations with these extensions incorporated.  Statistical tests (analysis of variance) are used to assess the significance of post-PDM changes in mission capability rates.

sections.title: Calculating PDM Acceleration Valuations
sections.methods_summary: This appendix details the calculations performed in Microsoft Excel to determine the value of expediting PDM visits. It describes the use of goal-seek functionality to find the value of month 360 benefit that sets the discounted benefit sum equal to the total expenditure.  The method for calculating benefits in earlier months is also explained.

sections.title: PDM Speed for New Military Aircraft
sections.methods_summary: This appendix explores how PDM speed might influence the size of a new military aircraft fleet.  A mathematical model is developed to relate the number of aircraft needed to the PDM duration and the desired number of aircraft available to operating commands.  The cost-minimizing levels of fleet size and PDM speed are discussed, assuming a functional form for the cost of changing PDM speed.

analysis.sample_description: The primary data are from the F-15 fighter aircraft fleet.  Specific samples are used in the analysis of mission capability rates and post-PDM valuation jumps, with sample sizes and selection criteria described in the text.
analysis.analysis_approach: The core analysis involves calculating the minimum net benefits required to justify the cost of each PDM visit, given different assumptions about aircraft valuation (constant, declining, with jumps).  Regression analysis is used to estimate the rate of decline in aircraft valuation.  Statistical tests are used to assess the significance of differences in mission capability rates before and after PDM.  A mathematical model is developed to explore the relationship between PDM speed and fleet size.

sections.title: Methodology for the Simulation Model
sections.methods_summary: The methodology for the simulation model is straightforward. The model simulates the flow of flights (groups of students) through the course plan of instruction (POI), including the requisite amount of resources (instructors, facilities, training devices, and time) according to the course POI. The model produces an event history from which we can calculate facility, instructor, and device usage rates. We can compute such aggregate statistics as the graduate production and investigate details such as bottlenecks in the POI.

sections.title: Data Collection and Analysis Approach
sections.methods_summary: The schoolhouse model requires data describing the resources, syllabi, and operations of the training courses and organizations. These data are gathered from a variety of sources. The Excel data input sheets are designed to replicate similar Air Force forms already used to record the specific data items, when applicable.  The data requirements are divided into six areas: group-level, facility, instructor, squadron-level, course plans, and training devices.  Analysis questions are posed for each data category to illustrate the types of policy questions or analyses that can result from changes in the input data.

sections.title: Simulation Methodology and Model Structure
sections.methods_summary: The study uses a simulation model built in Extend to analyze the technical training pipeline.  The reasons for choosing simulation over other methods are discussed, highlighting its ability to capture complex interactions and secondary constraints within the training system.  The key performance measures are defined (throughput, cost, resource utilization, washout/washback rates, training delays/deficiencies). The structure of the simulation model is described, focusing on the four main entities: classes of students, instructors, classrooms, and training devices. The model generates a detailed event history file for post-processing analysis.

sections.title: Data Analysis: Sample SAS Code
sections.methods_summary: Provides sample SAS code for parsing and summarizing the 'History.txt' file generated by the simulation. The code separates the data into four datasets (flight, instructor, devices, classrooms) based on event codes, calculates instructor man-hours, device usage hours, and classroom usage hours, and then summarizes these data to provide key utilization measures.

analysis.sample_description: Data are gathered from various Air Force databases, manuals, and forms.  The model uses data from the 37th Training Group at Lackland Air Force Base for demonstration purposes, but these data are not intended for analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: Comparative simulations are performed to determine resource requirements and policy impacts.  Post-processing of the simulation's event history file is used to generate various performance metrics and cost estimates.

sections.title: Appendix: Methodology, Data, and Estimation Results
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology, data sources, and estimation techniques used in the study.  It describes the use of random- and fixed-effects models with panel data from 48 states (excluding Alaska and Hawaii) and 17 NAEP tests (1990-2003).  Two methods are used to account for score gains over time: introducing dummy variables and using an annualized trend variable.  The analysis includes raw scores and full population-adjusted scores (using McLaughlin's [2000, 2001] methodology to impute scores for excluded students). Three versions of each model are estimated: without controls, with family and demographic controls, and with family, demographic, and resource controls.  The sensitivity of results to the 2003 4th grade math score is also tested.

sections.title: Regression Results and Model Specifications
sections.methods_summary: This section presents the regression results using both gain dummies and trend variables to account for score gains.  Random- and fixed-effects models are presented, along with a discussion of the assumptions underlying each.  The data used includes 696 observations.  The models include variables for family characteristics (derived from NELS:88 and US Census data), resource variables (pupil-teacher ratio, teacher salaries, teacher resources, pre-kindergarten participation), and control variables (participation rate, mobility).  Additional models explore non-linearity of pupil-teacher ratio and pre-kindergarten effects and their interaction with family SES.

sections.title: Data Description
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the NAEP data used in the analysis, including the number of states participating in each test (Table A.1), the test design (multiple-choice and constructed-response items, matrix sampling, balanced incomplete block spiraling), and the types of exclusions allowed (LEP and IEP/DS).  It also discusses the potential biases due to increasing exclusion rates and nonparticipation.

sections.title: Strengths and Weaknesses of NAEP Score Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This section discusses the strengths and limitations of using NAEP data for cross-state comparisons.  Strengths include multiple measures, large between-state variance, consistent results across model specifications, and consistency with experimental and non-experimental literature. Weaknesses include potential bias from omitted variables, the ecological fallacy, limitations of family variable measures, and inconsistent state participation.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from 17 NAEP tests administered between 1990 and 2003 to 4th and 8th graders in math and reading across 48 contiguous states (excluding Alaska and Hawaii). State participation varied before 2003, when the No Child Left Behind Act mandated participation from all states.  Samples included approximately 2,000-3,000 students from 100-150 schools per state, with oversampling of Black and Hispanic students.  Data on family characteristics were drawn from the National Education Longitudinal Study of 1988 (NELS:88) and the U.S. Census.
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis uses regression models to examine the relationship between state-level NAEP scores and family characteristics and educational resources.  Both random-effects and fixed-effects models are employed, and the analysis accounts for score gains over time using both dummy variables and trend variables.  The impact of various resource allocation strategies is assessed, and the sensitivity of results to different model specifications and assumptions is explored.  Data imputation is used to adjust for changing exclusion rates in the NAEP data.

sections.title: RAND Survey of State Agencies
sections.methods_summary: Phone surveys of agencies responsible for hospital licensing and regulation in all 50 states between October and December 2004.  Data collected included system purpose, implementation date, information collected, submission methods, and definition of reportable adverse events.  Analysis involved examining system documentation for key words related to patient safety and creating profiles of each state system using IOM-recommended domains as a template.  Analytic files were created based on these profiles to determine the types of information states are collecting.

sections.title: Research Aims
sections.methods_summary: The research aimed to describe state and accreditation body adverse medical event reporting systems, compile data elements used, identify similarities and differences, determine the usability of existing health information coding methods, and generate ideas for a nationwide standardized system.

sections.title: Appendix A: Creating Analytic Files or Worksheets
sections.methods_summary: Worksheets were created for each of the 19 IOM-recommended elements, plus a catch-all sheet.  Unique levels or categories were entered as rows, retaining the precise wording used by each state. Columns represented states with reporting systems.  A team member entered the information, and a second member verified it. Entries were organized into categories and subcategories to draw summary conclusions.

sections.title: Data Element Details
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of data from 23 state reporting systems (excluding Oregon due to incompleteness) to categorize information requested on forms in terms of 18 IOM data elements.  Elements not fitting IOM categories were classified as 'Other Elements'.

analysis.sample_description: All 50 US states' agencies responsible for hospital licensing and regulation.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative analysis of survey data and state reporting system documentation.  Categorization and comparison of data elements across states using IOM recommendations and existing classification systems (NQF, JCAHO, NYPORTS).

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Uses basic supply-and-demand models for electricity and motor fuels, incorporating a separate biomass feedstock supply model.  Employs a statistical sampling method (Latin Hypercube Sampling is implied) to generate 3000 scenarios based on ranges of key parameters.  Analysis focuses on identifying key factors influencing expenditure impacts rather than predicting a single most likely outcome.

sections.title: How We Did the Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Describes the electricity and fuel market models in detail, outlining five basic steps: 1. Construct cost curves for renewable energy technologies; 2. Calculate expenditure impacts of meeting requirements; 3. Substitute renewable fuels for fossil fuels; 4. Calculate new prices for energy consumers; 5. Calculate energy demand based on new prices.  The models iterate until demand converges.  Specific details are provided for the motor fuel model (including considerations of different biofuel types and pricing mechanisms) and the electricity model (accounting for different technology types and their capacity).  The analysis also incorporates a biomass feedstock supply model, considering low-cost and high-cost sources.  The study uses a range of price elasticities of supply and demand, varying these parameters in a sensitivity analysis.  The analysis of impacts on energy expenditures includes changes in expenditures on electricity and motor fuels, government expenditures/revenues from subsidies/taxes, and changes in expenditures on fossil fuels.  The analysis of impacts on CO2 emissions uses life-cycle emission estimates for renewable and nonrenewable technologies.  An uncertainty analysis is conducted using a statistical sampling method to explore the impact of varying key parameters.

analysis.sample_description: The study does not describe a sample of individuals or entities in the traditional sense. Instead, it uses a large number of scenarios (almost 2600) generated by varying input parameters across defined ranges. These parameters represent uncertainties in technology costs, biomass availability, energy demand elasticities, and other factors.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a combination of quantitative modeling and qualitative analysis. The models are used to generate a large number of scenarios, and these results are then analyzed to identify key factors influencing the outcomes (expenditure changes and CO2 emission reductions).  A scenario discovery method is used to identify combinations of input parameters associated with high and low expenditure changes.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Terrorism risk estimates were calculated for each of the UASI-defined urban areas for fiscal year 2005 using the RMS Probabilistic Terrorism Model.  The analysis assessed 45 urban areas, combining some areas due to data limitations or model design. Risk estimates were calculated using average annual fatalities and average annual loss (AAL) of property.  Property loss included damage to buildings and contents, excluding business interruption losses.  Average annual consequences were calculated as probability-weighted sums of losses for modeled events.  Risk estimates relied on assumptions from RMS's 2005 expert elicitation process. Results are presented as risk shares (risk for a specific urban area divided by the sum of risk across all urban areas).  Several sets of attack modes were modeled: all modes, conventional modes only, CBRN modes only, and sabotage modes only.  The Homeland Security Council (HSC) national planning scenarios were compared to the RMS scenarios to ensure overlap.

analysis.sample_description: 45 UASI-eligible urban areas in fiscal year 2005 (some combined due to data limitations).
analysis.analysis_approach: Risk estimates were calculated using the RMS Probabilistic Terrorism Model, considering average annual fatalities and property loss.  Risk shares were calculated to compare risk across urban areas.  Analyses were conducted using different sets of attack modes (all modes, conventional, CBRN, sabotage) to assess the impact of attack mode on risk distribution.  Results were compared to population and UASI funding allocations.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Methodologies
sections.methods_summary: This chapter details the methodology used to create an evaluation framework for the Foundations for Living (FfL) project.  The primary approach was logic modeling, supplemented by document review, interviews (with clients, management, and partner organizations), a focus group (with staff), and a workshop (with senior management).  Data from these sources were triangulated to inform the logic models and the development of performance indicators.

analysis.sample_description: The sample included 17 Papworth Trust clients (9 already in Huntingdon, 4 not moving, 4 planning to move), 5 members of Papworth Trust management, 5 partner organizations, and 14 staff members in a focus group.  The selection of clients and staff was done in collaboration with the Papworth Trust.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data from document reviews, interviews, focus groups, and workshops were integrated into the logic modeling process.  This process, in partnership with the Papworth Trust, led to the identification and agreement on performance indicators during a management workshop.

sections.title: Method: Arbitrariness
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the use of propensity scoring, a method for causal inference in observational studies.  It aims to reweight the data to make cases with nonwhite victims and cases with white victims look as similar as possible on all covariates, effectively mimicking a randomized experiment.  The method involves estimating propensity scores (the probability of having a white victim given other factors) using logistic regression and then using these scores to reweight the data or create strata.  The advantages, limitations, and potential objections to propensity scoring are discussed.

sections.title: Method: Capriciousness
sections.methods_summary: Boosted regression (a nonparametric method allowing for high-order interactions) is used to predict the USAO recommendation and AG decision.  The data is split into training and testing sets to assess predictive accuracy.  No formal hypothesis test is conducted, but the accuracy is compared to a baseline (always predicting the modal value).

sections.title: Method: Regional Variation
sections.methods_summary: Logistic regression is used to test whether the death penalty is sought more often in certain U.S. Census regions.  Indicator variables for regions and influential covariates from the capriciousness analysis are used.  An interaction term between white victim and Southern region is added to test for differential regional effects by race.

sections.title: Advantages, Limitations, and Potential Objections to Propensity Scoring
sections.methods_summary: This subsection discusses the advantages and limitations of propensity score matching.  One advantage is that there is less risk of overfitting. A potential objection is that one cannot adjust for unobserved covariates.  The authors argue that ensuring balance on observed covariates is a worthwhile goal even if the counterfactual is hard to imagine.

sections.title: Data Preparation
sections.methods_summary: The defendant is used as the unit of analysis. Variables related to individual victims are aggregated in multiple-victim cases using indicator variables. Missing values are handled by coding missing values as 'absent' for indicator variables and imputing missing values for defendant age using a hot-deck procedure. Variables with too few nonzero values or too many missing values are excluded. Several derived variables (mostly count variables) are computed.

sections.title: Model Building
sections.methods_summary: Logistic regression is used to examine the relationship between charging decisions, race, and other case characteristics.  Aggravating and mitigating factors are summed to create aggregate scores ('aggr' and 'mitg').  Models are constructed with and without victim race, defendant race, their interaction, and district dummy variables.  The authors discuss the challenges of variable selection and the limitations of logistic regression in this context.

sections.title: Creating the Database
sections.methods_summary: The study began by reviewing previous research and examining a sample of Department of Justice Capital Case Unit (CCU) case files. A case abstraction form and coding rules were developed. Five specially trained coders used these forms to record information from the CCU hard-copy files.

analysis.sample_description: The study included all potential capital cases submitted by USAOs for AG review between January 1, 1995, and July 31, 2000, and decided by the AG by December 31, 2000.  The sample consisted of 312 cases involving 652 defendants with a USAO seek/not-seek recommendation and 600 defendants with an AG seek/not-seek decision. Espionage cases were excluded.
analysis.analysis_approach: Three independent teams analyzed the data using different methods.  The main analyses focused on whether the USAO recommendations and AG decisions were related to defendant or victim race, controlling for case characteristics and geographic location.  The teams also assessed the predictability and capriciousness of the decisions.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a novel approach combining scenario analysis and strategic gaming. Scenario analysis examined the interactions of various factors in a sequence of events using a 'what if' framework. Strategic gaming immersed participants in a simulated catastrophic event to explore decision-making challenges for various stakeholders.  The two methods were combined to link the immediate effects of a hypothetical attack with its longer-term consequences.

sections.title: Nuclear Attack Scenario
sections.methods_summary: The study used existing literature on nuclear explosion effects (Glasstone and Dolan, 1977), public domain software for analyzing radioactive fallout, and publicly available data on population, infrastructure, and winds in the Los Angeles region to model the consequences of a terrorist nuclear attack.  The analysis calculated direct blast effects, assessed affected infrastructure, modeled fallout patterns, analyzed health implications, and considered evacuation logistics.

sections.title: Strategic Gaming
sections.methods_summary: A series of strategic games were conducted with representatives from the insurance, real estate, business, and policy communities. Participants were briefed on the scenario analysis results and asked for their perspectives on effects and response strategies. Notional estimates of direct costs were prepared as background for the gaming effort.

analysis.sample_description: The strategic gaming involved representatives from the insurance, real estate, business, and policy communities.  The exact number of participants is not explicitly stated but is mentioned as 'over 200' in one section.
analysis.analysis_approach: The scenario analysis used existing data and models to project the immediate effects of a nuclear attack. The strategic gaming explored longer-term economic and policy implications through simulated decision-making exercises. The results from both methods were combined to provide a comprehensive understanding of the potential consequences.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: Two MSG experiments were conducted using contrasting cases. The first used an epidemiological model of Islamist extremism, while the second started without a pre-existing model, using a list of conditions characterizing the next nuclear use (NNU).  Four primary methods were used for interpreting results: linear sensitivity analysis, analyst-inspired aggregation fragments, advanced filtering methods (data mining and machine learning), and motivated metamodeling.  Analytica and CARs software were used for scenario generation and analysis.

sections.title: Methods for Massive Scenario Generation (MSG) and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: This section details the approaches to model building for MSG, distinguishing between causal and noncausal models.  It discusses determining the appropriate scale of MSG ('How much is enough?'), focusing on dimensionality and resolution.  Four methods for interpreting the complexity of results are described: 1) Linear sensitivity analysis; 2) Extended linear sensitivity analysis using aggregation fragments; 3) Advanced data analysis with filters (data mining and cluster analysis); and 4) Motivated metamodeling.  The section also describes a dual-track experimentation approach using both a pre-existing model and a model built from a list of conditions.

sections.title: Experiment One: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: An epidemiological model of Islamist extremism was used.  The model was enhanced to reflect deep uncertainty about parameters and included exogenous events.  Analytica and CARs were used for scenario generation and analysis.  Methods used for analysis included: linear sensitivity analysis, aggregation fragments to improve prediction, advanced filters (PRIM algorithm from data mining and cluster analysis), and motivated metamodeling to find a simple explanatory theory (metamodel).

sections.title: Experiment Two: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This experiment started without a pre-existing model, using a report on the conditions of the next nuclear use (NNU).  The initial static attributes were expanded to create a dynamic model in Analytica.  Stochastic methods were used to reflect structural uncertainty, allowing for reversed directionality and diverse effects in influence diagrams.  CARs was used for scenario generation and analysis.  Linear sensitivity analysis was used to identify important variables for visualization.  The analysis focused on how revenge-motivated attacks by the DPRK might affect the nuclear taboo.

analysis.sample_description: Not explicitly defined, but the studies involved scenarios related to Islamist extremism and the next nuclear use, drawing on existing models and expert knowledge in those domains.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved generating a large number of scenarios and then using various statistical and analytical techniques to identify patterns and insights, focusing on both mean outcomes and the variance across scenarios.

sections.title: Outcome Evaluation Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources and analytical framework used for the outcome evaluation.  Data sources include the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS), Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance System (YRBSS), Natality Data Public Use File, cigarette excise tax revenue, and Synar inspection data.  The analytical framework involves calculating prevalence rates, adjusting for demographic changes using multivariate analysis (logit and least squares regression), estimating baseline trends, and comparing observed outcomes to expected outcomes based on these trends.  Comparative analyses are also conducted using both longitudinal and cross-sectional data, comparing Arkansas to other states and regions with varying levels of program activity.

sections.title: RAND Evaluation of the Arkansas Tobacco Settlement Program Evaluation Methods
sections.methods_summary: The evaluation uses a mixed-methods approach combining policy analysis, process evaluation, and outcome evaluation. Policy evaluation involved document review and stakeholder interviews. Process evaluation used the FORmative Evaluation, Consultation, and Systems Technique (FORECAST) model, incorporating annual site visits, quarterly conference calls, and the development of process indicators for each program. Outcome evaluation used various data sources (BRFSS, YRBSS, birth certificates, hospital discharge data, census data) to measure program effects on smoking and other health outcomes.  Analyses included prevalence calculations, adjustments for demographic changes using multivariate analysis (logit and least squares regression), baseline trend extrapolation, and comparative analyses (longitudinal and cross-sectional) to compare Arkansas to other states and regions.

primary_methods: Outcome evaluation (multivariate analysis, regression, trend analysis, comparative analysis)
analysis.sample_description: The outcome evaluation focuses on population-level measures rather than program participants alone, using data from statewide surveys and administrative records.  Specific subpopulations (e.g., youth, pregnant women, Delta region residents) are analyzed where relevant.
analysis.analysis_approach: Multivariate analysis (logit and least squares regression) is used to adjust for demographic changes and estimate baseline trends.  Comparisons are made between observed outcomes and expected outcomes based on these trends.  Comparative analyses are also used to compare Arkansas to other states and regions.

sections.title: Elicitation Procedure
sections.methods_summary: Synthesized procedure from multiple sources involving using multiple independent experts, eliciting upper, lower, and most-likely values for cost elements, fitting a triangle distribution, eliciting additional percentiles, providing feedback to experts, and documenting the process.

sections.title: Psychological Research on Elicitation Biases
sections.methods_summary: Review of psychological experiments where subjects were asked questions with unknown answers and asked to quantify their uncertainty.  Analysis focused on identifying biases like availability, representativeness, anchoring and adjustment, and overconfidence.

sections.title: Elicitation Methods in Cost Risk Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Review of tutorials and literature on elicitation in cost risk analysis.  Common methods included asking for maximum, minimum, and most-likely values and fitting a triangle distribution.  Some tutorials also suggested eliciting percentiles and fitting other distributions.

sections.title: Current Best Practices in Elicitation
sections.methods_summary: Proposed procedure combining insights from literature and current practice: using multiple experts, eliciting upper, lower, and most-likely values (with prompting to consider wider ranges), fitting an expanded triangle distribution, eliciting additional percentiles, providing feedback to experts, and thorough documentation.

sections.title: Analysis of Current Elicitation Practices
sections.methods_summary: Interviews with cost-estimation professionals in various organizations to assess current practices.  Analysis focused on identifying common issues such as convenient expert selection, rushed elicitation, lack of feedback, ad-hoc methodologies, and poor documentation.

sections.title: Recommendations for Improving Elicitation
