sections.methods_summary: Recommendations for improving elicitation practices include creating a comprehensive list of current methods, critically examining their theoretical and empirical basis, tracking performance with empirical case studies and a database, setting documentation standards, and conducting long-term studies comparing elicited distributions with actual costs.

analysis.sample_description: Cost-estimation professionals from the U.S. Air Force, NASA, and private aerospace and consulting firms.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of existing literature and interview data, comparative analysis of different elicitation methods, and recommendations for future research.

sections.title: Methods: Chapter Six - Citizen and Officer Satisfaction with the Complaint Process
sections.methods_summary: Survey of officers and citizens involved in official complaints.  Changes to the survey from year one included: changing survey distribution to one officer and one citizen per complaint; making surveys anonymous; replacing cover letter with one from Chief Streicher and FOP President Kathy Harrell; reducing the number of questions.  Analysis of demographic characteristics, nature of complaints, investigation of complaints, and satisfaction with the process and outcomes.

sections.title: Methods: Chapter Five - Satisfaction of Police Officers Working in Cincinnati
sections.methods_summary: Survey of CPD officers. Changes from year one included: changing survey distribution to officers attending academy training; removing identifying questions; replacing cover letter with one from Chief Streicher and FOP President Kathy Harrell; reducing the number of questions. Analysis of demographic characteristics, citizen cooperation and complaints, work environment, community policing knowledge, and overall conclusions.

sections.title: Methods: Chapter Three - Analysis of Vehicle Stops
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of 2005 traffic stop data. Three phases: (1) assessment of department-wide bias using veil-of-darkness method (comparing stops during daylight and darkness around DST changes); (2) assessment of individual officer bias using internal benchmarking (comparing each officer's stop rate to similar officers); (3) assessment of racial disparities in post-stop outcomes (citation rates, stop duration, search rates) using propensity score weighting. Data from contact cards and CAD logs were used.  Analysis included logistic regression and ANOVA/ANCOVA.

sections.title: Methods: Chapter Four - Analysis of Videotaped Police-Motorist Interactions
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of 325 randomly sampled video recordings of traffic stops from 2005.  Stratified random sampling based on officer and driver race.  Coding of interactions using a codebook (detailed in Appendix B).  Analysis included Chi-square tests, logistic regression, ANOVA, and ANCOVA.  Multivariate models used to control for reciprocal effects of communication.

analysis.sample_description: Descriptions of samples vary by chapter and data source (e.g., police officers, citizens involved in complaints, traffic stops, video recordings).  Specific sample sizes and selection methods are detailed within each chapter's methodology section.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis methods vary by chapter and data type, but generally involve statistical tests to assess for racial disparities and other relationships between variables.  Specific techniques include Chi-square tests, logistic regression, ANOVA, ANCOVA, and multivariate modeling.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: Desk-based research in English, French, German, Spanish, and Dutch.  Details in Appendix A.

sections.title: Appendix A: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Selective review of effectiveness and cost-benefits of interventions. Researchers selected based on familiarity with the area and experience in analysis/synthesis. Focus defined in cooperation with NAO. Desk-based research using databases like JSTOR and relevant journals.  Snowballing technique used to identify additional literature.  Consulted literature in English, French, German, Dutch, and Spanish. Key findings summarized and presented to NAO before final report.

analysis.sample_description: Not explicitly defined, but the research draws on a wide range of studies and reports, both from the UK and US, and other countries where relevant.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative synthesis of findings from existing studies and reports.  Cost-benefit analysis is used where data allows.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: Applies a modified Levitt and Porter (2001) statistical procedure to estimate the probability of older drivers causing car accidents relative to younger drivers, using high-quality data on two-car fatal accidents from the FARS database.  This approach avoids issues with inconsistent national accident reporting and unreliable vehicle miles traveled data.

sections.title: Derivation of an Alternative Estimate of Relative Riskiness and Exposure
sections.methods_summary: A modified Levitt and Porter (2001) model is used.  This model uses data on fatal two-car crashes to estimate relative riskiness (likelihood of causing an accident), relative exposure (prevalence on the road), and relative crash fatality rates (likelihood of death in an accident) for older drivers compared to younger and middle-aged drivers.  The model assumes equal mixing of driver types, that a single driver is at fault in two-car accidents, and that older drivers are at least as risky as younger drivers.  Relative crash fatality rates are estimated separately. Standard errors are estimated using a bootstrapping procedure.

sections.title: Data and Sample Description
sections.methods_summary: Data from the Fatal Accident Reporting System (FARS) from 1975-2003 are used. The sample is restricted to two-car crashes with no pedestrians, buses, or motorcycles involved, and drivers aged 15 or older. Drivers are categorized into three age groups: 15-24 (younger), 25-64 (middle-aged), and 65+ (older). To address the equal mixing assumption, data are disaggregated by time of day, day of week, time of year, speed limit, state, and year, creating 6120 potential groups.  Analysis is performed on the subset of these groups with sufficient data.

analysis.sample_description: Data from the Fatal Accident Reporting System (FARS) from 1975-2003, restricted to two-car crashes involving drivers aged 15 or older, excluding crashes involving pedestrians, buses, or motorcycles. Drivers are categorized into three age groups: 15-24, 25-64, and 65+. Data are disaggregated to address the equal mixing assumption.
analysis.analysis_approach: A modified Levitt-Porter (2001) statistical model is used to estimate relative riskiness, relative exposure, and relative crash fatality rates for older drivers compared to younger and middle-aged drivers.  The model uses data on fatal two-car crashes and accounts for differences in crash fatality rates. Standard errors are estimated using bootstrapping.

sections.title: Chapter 2 Methodology used
sections.methods_summary: This chapter details the methodology employed to assess the effectiveness of the Healthy Life Years (HLY) indicator's uptake since its 2005 introduction.  The methodology involved three main data collection activities:  1) Desk research: reviewing peer-reviewed literature, ministerial websites, EU and international organization websites, Member State submissions to the Commission, and online news sources.  2) Survey: an online survey distributed to Commission officials, representatives of national/regional health ministries, and representatives of other ministries.  3) Interviews: telephone interviews with stakeholders selected based on survey responses, focusing on awareness, use, barriers, and facilitators of HLY indicator uptake.  The chapter also addresses difficulties encountered during data collection (e.g., low response rates, challenges with survey content, limited interview participation) and the solutions implemented.

analysis.sample_description: The survey targeted 422 stakeholders (initially), comprising Commission Officials (52%), representatives of National or Regional Health Ministries (23%), and representatives of other ministries (25%). Due to various reasons (e.g., respondents no longer working in the relevant area, leave of absence), the final survey sample consisted of 378 stakeholders (Commission Officials 53%, representatives of National or Regional Health Ministries 23%, and representatives of other ministries 24%).  The interviews aimed to include 25 participants (5 Commission officials, 12 representatives of National or Regional Health Ministries, and 8 representatives of Non-Health Ministries), but ultimately involved 16 interviews (4 Commission Officials and 12 representatives of National or Regional Health Ministries).
analysis.analysis_approach: The desk research assessed awareness of the HLY indicator. Survey data was quantitatively analyzed using SPSS (results presented in Appendix 1). Interview notes were analyzed qualitatively and quantitatively by stakeholder group and question.  The chapter synthesizes findings from all three data collection methods to address the evaluation questions.

sections.title: Approach to the Analysis
sections.methods_summary: The RAND research team used five research questions to guide the analysis.  A terrorist activity chain was developed as a logic model.  The team examined terrorist use of network technologies for each element of the chain.  They identified which network technologies were most attractive to terrorists based on whether they improved the organization's ability to carry out activities or improved attack outcomes.  A framework was developed to consider how terrorists acquire technologies, the role of specific network technologies within groups' technology strategies, and options for security forces to counter terrorist use of network technologies.  This framework allowed comparison of the payoff for each combination of network technology and countermeasure.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research team used five guiding questions: 1. What could terrorists do with network technology? 2. Which network technologies are most attractive to terrorists? 3. How would specific network technologies fit within terrorist groups' broader approaches to acquiring and using technologies? 4. What should security forces do to counter this? 5. What conclusions and recommendations can be drawn from this analysis?  A terrorist activity chain (logic model) was developed to describe terrorist operations.  A model of terrorist decisionmaking was used to assess technology adoption based on benefits and risks.  A framework was developed to analyze how terrorists acquire and use technologies, considering four technology strategies: specialization, adoption of many technologies, focus on versatile technologies, and opportunistic use.  A framework was also developed to evaluate countermeasures based on technology strategy, benefit/risk balance, and countermeasure options.

sections.title: Conclusions and Recommendations
sections.methods_summary: This section summarizes the findings and offers recommendations based on the analysis.  It does not explicitly detail methodology, but rather interprets the results of the methods described in previous sections.

analysis.sample_description: The study does not explicitly define a sample in the traditional sense.  The analysis is based on existing literature, publicly available information, and expert knowledge regarding terrorist organizations and their use of technology.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a qualitative approach, developing logic models and frameworks to structure the examination of terrorist activities and security force responses.  Comparative analysis is used to evaluate the benefits and risks of different technologies and countermeasures.

sections.title: Appendix C: Methodology and Selected Results
sections.methods_summary: This section details the statistical models used to analyze the relationships between Carrera Magisterial (CM) program factors and educational quality.  It describes multivariate regression models for student test scores, teacher test scores, and peer reviews, including the use of Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) and fixed-effects models to account for unobserved confounding factors.  It also addresses issues of missing data and teacher participation patterns.  A regression-discontinuity approach is described for analyzing incentive effects, both during and after incorporation or promotion.  Finally, an attrition analysis is presented to assess potential bias due to sample composition.

sections.title: Analysis of Incentive Effects on the Year of Incorporation
sections.methods_summary: Regression discontinuity approach, utilizing a well-publicized minimum-point cutoff for program incorporation (70 points).  Compares teachers with weaker incentives (below cutoff) to those with stronger incentives (near cutoff).

sections.title: Analysis of Salary Bonus Impact After an Incorporation or Promotion
sections.methods_summary: Longitudinal regression with individual teacher effects, followed by a regression discontinuity design using state-specific cutoffs for incorporation and promotion to address mean reversion.  Descriptive analysis of teacher characteristics for returning and nonreturning teachers to assess sample attrition bias.

sections.title: Missing Data and Patterns of Teacher Participation
sections.methods_summary: Description of missing data patterns in the CM dataset, focusing on reasons for missing data (e.g., program design, teacher non-participation) and potential biases introduced by missing data.  Analysis of teacher participation rates across different years (Etapas).

sections.title: Descriptive Statistics and Regression Results
sections.methods_summary: Presentation of descriptive statistics for primary and secondary teachers, including student and teacher test scores, peer review ratings, seniority, education levels, and other relevant variables.  Results from fixed-effects regression models examining the relationships between CM factors and student test scores, teacher test scores, and peer review ratings are presented.

sections.title: Methodology and Selected Results on the Analysis Impact of the Salary Bonus During the Year of Incorporation
sections.methods_summary: Regression discontinuity design to analyze the impact of incentives on student test scores during the year of promotion.  Models examine the relationship between initial point scores (excluding student test scores) and student test scores, looking for a discontinuity around the 50-point threshold.

sections.title: Mean Reversion Analysis Results
sections.methods_summary: Fixed-effects regressions excluding observations from the year of promotion to assess the impact of mean reversion on the results from the analysis of salary bonus impact.

sections.title: Attrition Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Descriptive analysis comparing observable characteristics (CM point scores, raw student and teacher test scores) of returning and nonreturning teachers to assess potential bias due to sample attrition.

sections.title: Teacher and Student Test Analysis: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of teacher and student tests using data from the tests themselves, test specifications, curriculum standards, item-level data, and expert ratings.  Methods included psychometric indicators (internal consistency, item reliability, item discrimination, difficulty index), analysis of cognitive demand using adapted frameworks, and comparison to international standards.

sections.title: Analysis of CM’s Testing Program: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Review of CM's testing program using program guidelines, documents from the Ministry of Education's Directorate of Evaluation (DGE), interviews with DGE personnel, and international standards (AERA, APA, NCME; NRC; ECIEE).  Standards were categorized by phase and component of the testing program (test content, construction, reliability, administration, security, information, communication, organizational structure).

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Data from four sources (Carrera Magisterial, Ministry of Education's Directorate of Evaluation, National Program for Teacher Professional Development, National Statistical Institute).  Methods included quantitative analysis (psychometric indicators, regression discontinuity), qualitative analysis (expert consultations), and literature reviews.

analysis.sample_description: Data from Carrera Magisterial program (1998-2003), including primary and secondary teachers.  Sample sizes vary across analyses due to missing data and eligibility criteria.  Teacher positions are the primary unit of analysis, but some analyses use individual teachers.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis using various statistical methods, complemented by qualitative analysis of test content and curriculum alignment, and literature reviews to inform interpretation of findings.

sections.title: Methodology for Allocating ISR Resources
sections.methods_summary: This section details a strategies-to-tasks framework for allocating ISR resources.  It involves assigning utility values to campaign objectives, operational objectives, and operational tasks to create a weighted prioritization scheme.  The probability of successful collection is also incorporated into the calculation of expected utility for each task.  This framework guides both deliberate planning and dynamic retasking of assets.

sections.title: Collection Requirements Tool (CRT) Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the CRT, a tool for deliberate planning and scheduling of ISR assets.  It involves four steps: establishing collection requirements (operational and intelligence), selecting a collection strategy, applying operational checks (range, LOS, grazing angle, squint angle, NIIRS), and building collection decks by platform.  The CRT uses pre-filtering based on sensor capabilities and geometrical considerations (earth curvature, terrain masking) to select candidate targets.  Two collection strategies are considered: prioritized information requirements (PIRs) and utility prioritization.  The National Imagery Interpretability Rating Scale (NIIRS) is used to assess image quality.

sections.title: Collection Operations Model (COM) Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the COM, a simulation model for assessing the employment of ISR assets.  It uses the collection decks from the CRT as input, along with asset characteristics and scripted red forces behaviors.  The model simulates the ISR process, including operational checks (range, LOS, grazing angle, squint angle), sensor capabilities (NIIRS for imagery, probability of detection for ELINT), and communication delays.  The model outputs measures of performance (sensor success, delays) and effectiveness (meeting commander's objectives).  The NIIRS system is used for imagery, and a probability of detection model is used for ELINT, considering factors like emitter characteristics, antenna gain, and receiver sensitivity.  MTI is modeled using pre-existing tracking analysis to determine resource requirements for various tasks.

sections.title: ISR Assessment Methodology from the Model
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the methods for evaluating the performance and effectiveness of collection strategies using the COM's output.  Performance measures focus on sensor-level data (success, delays, accuracy), while effectiveness measures assess the strategy's impact on meeting commander's objectives.  The analysis compares the PIR-based and utility-based strategies, considering factors like target distribution and alignment with commander's goals.  The impact of altitude, orbit location, and sensor capabilities on performance is also analyzed.

sections.title: Research Methodology: Lessons Learned and Framework Development
sections.methods_summary: This section details the research methodology used to develop recommendations for improving ISR planning, tasking, and assessment.  The methodology involved a review of classified and unclassified literature, personal interviews with Air Force intelligence personnel from OEF and OIF, and participation in ACC-sponsored conferences and exercises.  The key findings led to the development of a three-step framework for ISR assessment (is the system working, can it be improved, what changes are needed) and a utility-based strategies-to-tasks framework for resource allocation.  The utility framework assigns weights to campaign objectives, operational objectives, and ISR tasks to create a prioritized list of collection targets, incorporating the probability of successful collection.

analysis.sample_description: The study draws on data from Operations Enduring Freedom (OEF) and Operation Iraqi Freedom (OIF), including interviews with Air Force intelligence personnel and data from the Terminal Fury exercises.  The models use existing ISR forces as a baseline.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a quantitative approach to assess the costs and benefits of alternative collection strategies.  The models simulate the deliberate planning and dynamic retasking of ISR assets, and the analysis compares the performance and effectiveness of different strategies in meeting commander's objectives.  The analysis also examines the impact of various factors, such as altitude, orbit location, and sensor capabilities.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: The main data collection methods used are desk research, a survey of project leaders, interviews with a variety of stakeholders, analysis of data archives and analysis of the project database (i.e. portfolio analysis).

sections.title: Methodology: Desk Research
sections.methods_summary: Review of annual work programs, calls for proposals and tenders, proposal documentation, Programme Decision, literature on dissemination, Commission guidelines on dissemination, public health policy documents from international organizations (OECD and WHO), project database, analysis of references to the PHP on other portals, identification of projects with websites, Programme statements on stakeholder and citizen needs, EC and national public health policies, literature on sustainability, and guidelines on monitoring.

sections.title: Methodology: Survey of Project Leaders
sections.methods_summary: Electronic survey deployed on the web (www.phpsurvey.org) to project leaders of activities funded in 2003-2005.  The survey covered general information about projects, satisfaction with the PHP, programme management, project follow-up, importance of the PHP, contribution to objectives, dissemination of findings, capacity building, sustainability, use of research findings in policy and practice, and broader impact on public health. Quantitative and qualitative analysis of 59 valid responses (37% response rate).

sections.title: Methodology: Interviews
sections.methods_summary: Interviews with a representative sample of project leaders, proposal leaders, DG SANCO officials and committee members, officials from other DGs, national health authorities, representatives from international organizations (WHO), and interest groups.  Tailor-made interview protocol tested by potential stakeholders.  27 interviews performed (out of 84 planned).

sections.title: Methodology: Analysis of Data Archives and Databases
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of the project database (CIRCA) for 53 selected projects to determine budget per project, cost types, variance in project budgets, ratio of administrative to public health work hours, co-funding sources, project outputs, and Member State engagement through network analysis of institutions and geographic networks within projects.  Network analysis using UCINET software.

sections.title: Appendix 4: Network Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Network analysis performed to understand the capacity of Member States to participate in the PHP at two levels: country level and organizational level.  Analysis of geographical patterns, Freeman's degree centrality (in-degree and out-degree), geodesic distance, clique analysis, and co-membership matrix. UCINET software used for analysis.

sections.title: Appendix 6: Efficiency of Processes
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of success rates, reasons for rejection, and outputs and outcomes of selected projects (2003-2005).  Analysis of reasons for rejection categorized into budget, cost-effectiveness, co-funding, geographical coverage, overlap with prior research, scope of topic, previous experience, added value, planning, dissemination, and general quality. Cluster analysis performed.

sections.title: Appendix 7: Use of Financial Resources
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of financial resources in a selected sample of projects (2003-2005) to examine budget per project and variance, cost types (personnel, travel, miscellaneous services, administration), percentage of EC funding per strand, and source and amount of co-funding.  Descriptive statistics and graphical representations used.

analysis.sample_description: A representative sample of 53 projects from 2003-2005 was selected for in-depth analysis.  The survey included all project leaders (159) funded in 2003-2005, with 59 valid responses.  84 interviews were planned, with 27 completed.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative and qualitative analysis methods were used, including SPSS for quantitative survey data, and thematic analysis for interview data.  Network analysis used UCINET software.  Descriptive statistics, t-tests, and cluster analysis were employed.

sections.title: Analytical Framework and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The report presents an analytical framework and a spreadsheet-based tool (BEAM) to help commercial building owners make reasoned judgments about water-efficiency investment options.  The framework considers costs and financial benefits (avoided water, wastewater, and energy costs).  It uses scenario analysis to address uncertainty in future utility prices, and a Monte Carlo simulation to evaluate expected performance under various price trends.  The report also discusses standard quantitative decision analysis and robust decisionmaking (RDM) as alternative approaches to handling uncertainty.

sections.title: Building Water Efficiency Analysis Model (BEAM) Methodology
sections.methods_summary: BEAM is a spreadsheet-based model that analyzes the financial performance of water-use efficiency packages.  It prompts the user for building information, efficiency packages, and resource price scenarios.  It estimates water and energy use for base and efficient conditions.  It performs a scenario analysis to illustrate financial performance under different water price scenarios, using a Monte Carlo simulation for each scenario to evaluate expected performance under ranges of water and energy price trends.  The model uses deterministic point estimates for water use, savings, and technology costs, and does not fully capture uncertainty in benefit and cost calculations.

sections.title: BEAM User's Guide and Data Entry Procedures
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data entry process for BEAM, including inputting basic building information, restroom fixture data, building cooling information, resource prices, and model parameter assumptions.  It describes how to customize price scenarios and efficiency packages.  The section also outlines the results provided by BEAM, including water and energy usage and savings, and investment results (capital investment, net present benefits, NPV, EANB, IRR, and payback time) from a Monte Carlo simulation.

analysis.sample_description: The primary case study uses data from the RAND Corporation headquarters building in Santa Monica, California, analyzing two baseline efficiency conditions: one hypothetical (pre-1992 fixtures) and one reflecting the building's current (post-1992) fixtures.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses cost-benefit analysis to evaluate the financial performance of various water efficiency packages under different scenarios of future utility prices.  Uncertainty in future utility prices is addressed through scenario analysis and Monte Carlo simulation.  Financial metrics used include net present value (NPV), equivalent annual net benefits (EANB), internal rate of return (IRR), and payback period.

sections.title: Measure Identification and Rating on Relationship to Teamwork
sections.methods_summary: A multi-step process was used to select candidate teamwork-related measures. This involved a modified-Delphi method with two rounds of ratings by a clinical advisory panel on technical soundness and relationship to teamwork.  Measures were ranked by median scores, and those consistently rated poorly were eliminated.  The panel met to discuss ratings and suggest new measures.  A final list of measures was developed based on the second round of ratings and feedback.

sections.title: Empirical Testing of Selected Measures: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Highly rated measures were tested using DoD administrative healthcare data (M2 data mart) from 2002-2004.  Data included inpatient, outpatient, and pharmacy files.  For each measure, rates were estimated, and correlations between measures and sample size calculations were performed to detect a 30% decrease from the 2002 rate. The clinical advisory panel reviewed the results.

sections.title: Review of the Literature on Teamwork and Patient Safety: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Studies on teamwork, patient safety, and outcomes were identified through electronic searches (MEDLINE, PubMed, ABI/INFORM) from 1965-2006 and hand searches.  Search terms included combinations of keywords related to teamwork, patient safety, and specific training programs.  Titles and abstracts were reviewed for relevance, and references were checked for additional studies. Key elements were abstracted from relevant articles. Articles were categorized using a framework adapted from Salas et al. (2001), focusing on four levels of information: trainees' attitudes, understanding of principles, demonstration of behaviors, and organizational impact.

analysis.sample_description: The study used data from the Department of Defense (DoD) military healthcare system's M2 data mart, encompassing inpatient, outpatient, and pharmacy files for 2002–2004.  The specific clinical areas were labor and delivery, surgery, and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). A clinical advisory panel of 15 experts (3 RNs, 10 physicians) participated in the measure rating process.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved ranking measures based on median teamwork-relatedness and soundness scores.  For the empirical testing, rates were estimated, correlations between measures were assessed, and sample size calculations were performed to detect a 30% change from the 2002 rate.  The analysis also involved examining the feasibility of constructing measures using available data.

sections.title: Evaluation Approach and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The evaluation uses a Context-Input-Process-Product (CIPP) model.  Data collection involved using an AHRQ database, project proposals, focus groups with project teams, and individual interviews with principal investigators. Data from the AHRQ database were used to identify projects, funding, and contact information.  RAND extracted and coded data from proposals to characterize projects.  Focus groups and interviews used written protocols to document grantee experiences and obtain feedback on the initiative.

sections.title: Evaluation Approach and Methods: Monitoring Progress and Maintaining Vigilance
sections.methods_summary: The assessment draws upon written materials, documents, interviews with AHRQ staff, other federal agency staff, representatives of state reporting systems, and principal investigators of patient safety demonstrations.  The section examines progress in establishing and using national standards and measures for patient safety reporting systems, data availability on health system performance, and the use of patient safety measures in accreditation processes.

sections.title: Evaluation Approach and Methods: Patient Safety Epidemiology/Effective Practices and Tools
sections.methods_summary: A MEDLINE database search of articles published in English between July 2003 and June 2004 was conducted.  The number of articles and projects addressing epidemiology for various patient safety issues are presented. Interviews were conducted with principal investigators of AHRQ-funded projects to gather information on new research and field tests on patient safety practices and tools, their contribution to new knowledge, and progress in documenting effects on patient safety outcomes and costs.

sections.title: Evaluation Approach and Methods: Building Infrastructure for Effective Practices
sections.methods_summary: Interviews were conducted with representatives from 35 national organizations involved in patient safety activities.  A descriptive analysis and formal network analysis of patient safety partnerships were performed.  In-depth interviews were conducted with ten leaders of consumer organizations focused on patient safety and quality, and key informants from health care organizations were also interviewed.  Documents and articles were collected from literature searches and interviewees.

sections.title: Evaluation Approach and Methods: Achieving Broader Adoption of Effective Practices
sections.methods_summary: The evaluation used information from published documents, interviews with patient safety grantees, interviews with AHRQ project officers and principal investigators, and discussions with individuals from AHRQ, the Coordinating Center, and the Patient Safety Grantee Steering Committee.  Web site and library database searches were conducted to identify products from AHRQ- and HRSA-funded projects. Interviews were conducted with AHRQ project officers and 14 funded projects across six programs to assess the use of existing program vehicles in translating research into practice.

sections.title: Evaluation Approach and Methods: Preparing for Dissemination of Patient Safety Innovations
sections.methods_summary: The evaluation examined AHRQ's preparation for dissemination of patient safety findings and products, including the development of an inventory of FY 2000-FY 2001 project work and synthesis of findings.  Information was gathered from interviews with AHRQ project officers and principal investigators, and discussions with individuals from AHRQ, the Coordinating Center, and the Patient Safety Grantee Steering Committee.  The evaluation also examined AHRQ's dissemination activities and its role as a change agent, drawing on existing literature.

sections.title: Evaluation Approach and Methods: Product Evaluation: Selection of Outcome Measures
sections.methods_summary: Interviews were conducted with leaders of AHRQ-funded reporting demonstrations and representatives from additional state reporting systems to gather information on the use of patient safety measures.  Data resources and measure sets were identified for analysis of national patient safety trends.  An inventory of patient safety measures used by AHRQ grantees and state reporting systems was developed.  The evaluation used a conceptual framework to guide the identification and analysis of measures to assess the initiative's progress.

analysis.sample_description: The study involved a variety of stakeholders including AHRQ staff, federal agency staff, state reporting system representatives, principal investigators of patient safety projects, leaders of national organizations involved in patient safety, leaders of consumer organizations, and key informants from health care organizations.  The number of participants varied across data collection methods.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data analysis methods included descriptive analysis, network analysis, and synthesis of findings from multiple sources.  The evaluation also involved identifying and assessing candidate outcome measures for future analysis.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A two-part methodology was used. The first part involved integrating data from multiple sources (Logistics Integrated Database (LIDB), Equipment Downtime Analyzer (EDA), etc.) and using hurdle regression analysis to quantify the effects of age on vehicle repair costs and downtime.  The second part involved using the regression models and data as inputs for the VaRooM spreadsheet-based vehicle replacement model, which was modified to assess RECAP options.  The model's sensitivity to various inputs was tested.

sections.title: Predicting the Effects of Aging on HMMWV Costs and Availability
sections.methods_summary: Data on 21,700 HMMWVs from FY2000-FY2002 were analyzed. Predictor variables included vehicle age, annual usage, initial odometer reading, vehicle type, and location. Outcome variables were repair costs (parts and labor) and downtime.  Data sources included the Logistics Integrated Database (LIDB) and the Equipment Downtime Analyzer (EDA).  Two-part hurdle regression analysis was used to model the effects of predictors on repair costs and downtime, addressing the issue of zero-inflated data.  Data cleaning and imputation techniques were applied to handle missing and erroneous data points.

sections.title: Application of the Vehicle Replacement Model
sections.methods_summary: The VaRooM spreadsheet-based vehicle replacement model was adapted and used to estimate optimal replacement and recapitalization (RECAP) ages for HMMWVs.  Regression results were used to derive model inputs (number of vehicles by age, odometer reading by age, annual mileage by age, maintenance cost by age, and vehicle downtime by age).  The model was run under three sets of assumptions (base case, replace-earlier, replace-later) to assess sensitivity.  The model was modified to incorporate RECAP options, requiring additional inputs (year of RECAP, RECAP cost, and post-RECAP age).

analysis.sample_description: A sample of 21,700 HMMWVs from active units in FORSCOM, USAREUR, USARPAC, EUSA, and TRADOC, with data from fiscal years 2000-2002.  The sample included 15 HMMWV variants at 12 locations. Data cleaning reduced the final sample size to 20,345 for some analyses.
analysis.analysis_approach: Two-part hurdle regression models were used to analyze repair costs and downtime, addressing the issue of zero-inflated data.  A spreadsheet-based vehicle replacement model was used to determine optimal replacement and RECAP ages, incorporating regression results as inputs and testing sensitivity to various assumptions.

sections.title: Technical Approach
sections.methods_summary: Review of research reports, briefings, and technical papers provided by the Penn State research team. Meetings and discussions with key members of the Penn State research team and Air Force Research Laboratory personnel.  Availability of refined chemical oil and decant oil and potential market for high-value coke products were established based on publicly available information and interviews with petrochemical and coke production consultants and industry members.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is not a study involving a sample of individuals or entities in the traditional sense.  The analysis focuses on existing data and industry information related to coal-tar and co-coking processes.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis of production constraints based on available data on coal tar, decant oil production, and petroleum coke markets.  Qualitative assessment of the feasibility and economic viability of the processes.

sections.title: Study Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study collected data from lenders, insurers, and trackers involved in the lender-placed market for residential flood insurance.  Three types of information were gathered: quantitative data on the number of policies issued and loans tracked; perceptions of advantages and disadvantages of force-placing policies through the private market versus the NFIP (via in-person and telephone interviews); and samples of insurance policies to compare private and NFIP terms.  Separate procedures were used to recruit samples of insurers, lenders, and trackers.  Data extrapolation methods are described for each data source (insurers, lenders, trackers), acknowledging the strengths and weaknesses of each approach.  The chapter concludes by discussing the characterization of uncertainty in the estimates.

primary_methods: data collection from multiple sources (insurers, lenders, trackers)
analysis.sample_description: Samples of insurers, lenders, and trackers were selected based on conversations with knowledgeable parties in the lender-placed flood insurance market.  The insurer sample aimed to include the eight largest insurers.  The lender sample was drawn from the top 300 single-family home mortgage lenders ranked by number of 2003 home purchase originations. The tracker sample included firms believed to track the majority of loans. Response rates are reported for each group.
analysis.analysis_approach: Independent estimates of the number of lender-placed policies were constructed from data provided by insurers, lenders, and trackers. Separate estimates were developed for primary and gap policies.  Extrapolation methods are detailed for each data source, acknowledging the limitations of each approach and emphasizing the importance of consistency across estimates to increase confidence in the findings.  Quantitative statistical analysis (e.g., confidence intervals) was deemed unnecessary given the small sample sizes, but the consistency of findings across data sources is highlighted as a means of increasing confidence.

sections.title: Objectives and Approach
sections.methods_summary: Literature review of empirical research on traditional credit counseling effectiveness and the role of delivery modes.  Consultation with a bankruptcy study group of experts (academic, government, and private sector) to provide feedback on literature review results.  Two briefing sessions with the study group, including representatives from credit counseling associations in the second session.

sections.title: Review of the Research
sections.methods_summary: Review of existing literature on credit counseling, online instruction, online training courses, financial literacy training, and prepurchase homeownership counseling.  Specific studies and reports are cited and analyzed to assess the extent to which empirical research has identified operational measures of effectiveness and the role of delivery modes (in-person, phone, internet).

analysis.sample_description: The literature review included studies on credit counseling, online instruction, online training, financial literacy, and homeownership counseling.  The expert consultation involved a bankruptcy study group with members from academia, government, and the private sector, as well as representatives from three credit counseling associations.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved a qualitative review and synthesis of findings from the literature and expert consultations to assess the existing knowledge on measuring the effectiveness of prebankruptcy credit counseling and the influence of delivery modes.

sections.title: The Conceptual Model and Decision-Support Tool
sections.methods_summary: This section details the development of an economic model using a Cobb-Douglas production function to estimate the profits derived from employing undocumented workers.  The model's parameters are estimated using firm-level data on resources, costs, revenues, and profits.  A decision-support tool is created to implement the model, allowing users to input data and generate profit estimates under different assumptions (fixed vs. variable capital).  The tool incorporates Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) data on wages and benefits.

sections.title: Concluding Summary (Overview of Methodology)
sections.methods_summary: This section summarizes the overall methodology:  using an economic model based on profit maximization and a Cobb-Douglas production function to estimate the increased profits from employing undocumented workers.  The model uses firm-level data and accounts for different capital assumptions (fixed or variable).

sections.title: Appendices A, B, and C
sections.methods_summary: These appendices provide detailed mathematical steps for solving the production function parameters and profit maximization problems under different capital assumptions (variable and fixed).

analysis.sample_description: The study does not explicitly define a sample of firms.  The methodology focuses on developing a model applicable to individual firms, requiring data on their workforce, costs, revenues, and profits.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis uses a Cobb-Douglas production function to estimate the relationship between inputs (labor, capital, raw materials) and output.  The model is solved to find the profit-maximizing combination of inputs, both with and without the employment of undocumented workers. The difference in profits represents the gains from employing undocumented workers.  The analysis also considers two scenarios: fixed capital and variable capital.

sections.title: RAND Evaluation of the Arkansas Tobacco Settlement Program: Evaluation Methods
sections.methods_summary: The evaluation uses a mixed-methods approach combining policy analysis, process evaluation (using the FORECAST model), and outcome evaluation.  Data collection involves annual site visits, periodic conference calls, and analysis of administrative and survey data (BRFSS, YRBSS, Natality Data Public Use File, hospital discharge data, Synar inspections, Arkansas Adult Tobacco Survey). Outcome evaluation compares actual outcomes to baseline trends, adjusted for demographic changes, and uses multivariate analysis (logit and least squares regression) and comparative analysis (within-state and interstate comparisons).

analysis.sample_description: The outcome evaluation focuses on population-level measures rather than just program participants, using data from various sources including BRFSS, YRBSS, birth certificates, hospital discharge data, and Synar inspection reports.  Specific sample sizes and descriptions are provided within the relevant chapters.
analysis.analysis_approach: Outcome evaluation compares observed changes to baseline trends, adjusted for demographic factors using multivariate regression (logit and least squares).  Comparative analysis is used to compare trends in Arkansas with those in neighboring states and within Arkansas across different regions or groups with varying levels of program activity.

sections.title: Methodology, Scope of Analysis, and Organization of This Report
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a qualitative risk analysis, drawing on data from various sources including the Pennsylvania State Rail Plan, FRA's National Rail Safety Action Plan, Department of Defense Strategic Rail Corridor Network, previous rail security studies, and public information from transit agencies.  Federal and state authorities were reviewed to identify potential state-level actions. A qualitative analysis of risk factors (threat, vulnerability, consequences) was conducted using empirical data on terrorist threats to rail, safety data from FRA and FTA, and descriptions of Pennsylvania's rail system.  A review of federal and state actions, along with interviews with officials, responders, and railroad personnel, informed the identification of possible state-level actions to improve rail safety and security. A literature review of post-9/11 rail security studies was also conducted.

analysis.sample_description: Not applicable; this is not a study with a defined sample in the traditional sense.  Data were drawn from existing sources and interviews with various stakeholders.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of risk factors (threat, vulnerability, consequences) based on existing data and expert interviews.  The analysis focused on identifying potential state-level actions within existing legal and regulatory frameworks.

sections.title: Methodology for Stage 3
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for Stage 3 of the evaluation, which involved several data collection methods.  Semi-structured interviews were conducted with Foundations for Living (FFL) tenants in Huntingdon and those who remained in Papworth Everard to understand their experiences and aspirations.  Similar interviews were conducted with 'development stakeholders' (partners involved in the project). Case study research was conducted on four organizations providing comparable interventions, involving site visits, focus groups, interviews, and literature reviews.  Finally, a postal questionnaire was sent to private flat owners at Bradbury Place, and a 'citizen survey' was commissioned for members of the public in Huntingdon.

analysis.sample_description: The sample included FFL tenants in Huntingdon and Papworth Everard, development stakeholders, private flat owners at Bradbury Place, and members of the public in Huntingdon.  The case studies involved four organizations with comparable interventions.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report mentions analyzing interview data to assess FFL's performance against expectations and identifying key findings from interviews and case studies.  Specific analytical techniques are not explicitly detailed.

sections.title: Measuring Sexual Assault: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of existing data from various sources (National Crime Victimization Survey, National Crime Survey, etc.) to assess prevalence rates.  Discussion of definitional, methodological, and data issues affecting prevalence estimates.  Comparison of prevalence rates across different studies and populations (community, college, military).

sections.title: Investigative and Legal Processes: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Statistical analysis of survey data (National Crime Victimization Survey) and administrative case records from specific jurisdictions.  Comparison of findings across different data sources.  Discussion of strengths and weaknesses of different data sources (e.g., large-scale surveys vs. agency-specific data).

sections.title: Victim Advocacy Programs and Services: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Assessments of program effectiveness using both objective (resource availability, client usage rates) and subjective (victim perceptions) measures. Program evaluations using external criteria and client usage rates.  Surveys of program clients to assess program impact.  Discussion of limitations of studies analyzing only one or two programs.

sections.title: Health Care Programs and Services: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Quantitative comparisons of Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) programs with traditional models of care. Pre- and post-studies of SANE programs, cross-site comparisons, and internal comparisons.  National surveys of SANE programs.  Detailed evaluations of small numbers of SANE programs.  Evidence-based guidance for medical treatment. Literature reviews summarizing research on emergency evaluations and health care interventions.

sections.title: Investigative and Legal Processes: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Statistical analysis of survey data and administrative case records.  Analysis of victim, perpetrator, and incident-related factors to explain investigative and legal decisions.  Examination of factors predicting legal outcomes (prosecution decisions, trial outcomes, conviction, sentence length).  Qualitative methods (interviews) to describe interactions between prosecutors and victims.  Use of mock jurors to examine perceptions of trial processes.

analysis.sample_description: Descriptions of study samples vary widely across studies, including community samples, college students, military personnel, and victims presenting for treatment. Sample sizes also vary considerably.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis approaches vary widely, including descriptive statistics, regression analysis, qualitative thematic analysis, and statistical modeling to explain various outcomes.

sections.title: Building the Qatar Student Assessment System & Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The report details the development and implementation of the Qatar Student Assessment System (QSAS), focusing on the Qatar Comprehensive Educational Assessment (QCEA).  This involved collaboration with international contractors (ETS, CTB/McGraw-Hill, CfBT, NORC) and included the development of a national, standardized, standards-based assessment using multiple-choice and open-ended questions.  The QCEA was administered to a large sample of students (approximately 88,000) across different school types.  The report also mentions the use of performance assessments and in-class formative assessments, though details on their methodology are limited.

sections.title: Purpose and Approach of This Report
sections.methods_summary: The authors relied on three sources: review of literature on accountability, standards-based education, and assessment theory; review of meeting minutes (July 2002-July 2005) among stakeholders; and review of internal memos from RAND and the SAO.  This is primarily a descriptive methodology, relying on document review and analysis of existing data.

analysis.sample_description: Approximately 88,000 students in Ministry, private Arabic, and Independent schools (approximately 95% of the target population) participated in the QCEA across multiple years.  The sample varied by grade level and assessment type across the years.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report primarily describes the process of assessment development and implementation.  While the QCEA results are mentioned, the report explicitly states that a detailed analysis of the validity of the results is beyond its scope.  The analysis of the process itself is largely descriptive, drawing on document review and meeting minutes.

sections.title: Assessment Process
sections.methods_summary: A series of structured interviews with staff members during on-site visits to five home-based programs in July 2008.  Data were also gathered from representative case files (open and closed) and other relevant materials. Data from various sources were combined to generate a consensus CPC score for each provider. Scores for the five providers were averaged to determine the overall CPC score for each domain.

sections.title: Assessment Process and Correctional Program Checklist (CPC) Description
sections.methods_summary: The Correctional Program Checklist (CPC) was used to assess five home-based programs.  The assessment involved structured interviews with staff, review of case files (open and closed), and examination of other program materials.  The CPC, based on research from the University of Cincinnati, assesses program adherence to principles of effective intervention across five domains (leadership and development, staff characteristics, quality assurance, offender assessment, treatment).  The resulting scores were categorized as highly effective, effective, needs improvement, or ineffective.

analysis.sample_description: Five home-based programs providing services to juvenile probationers in Los Angeles County, selected by the Los Angeles County Probation Department. One provider was selected from each of the county's five supervisory districts.
analysis.analysis_approach: The Correctional Program Checklist (CPC) scores were calculated for each program across five domains.  Individual domain scores were then aggregated to create capacity and content scores, and finally an overall CPC score.  These scores were then categorized into four levels of effectiveness.

sections.title: Method
sections.methods_summary: A Bayesian hierarchical model was used to analyze the effects of Business Improvement Districts (BIDs) on crime rates.  The model used Poisson distribution for crime counts and incorporated a natural cubic spline to model the time trend.  Random effects were included for area and error terms to account for overdispersion. A Bayesian approach with flat priors was used for parameter estimation.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The study used multiple data sources: in-depth interviews with BID officials, examination of BID budget data, systematic social observations of BID areas, and a household survey of 737 randomly selected households in BID and comparison neighborhoods.  A multilevel modeling approach was used to analyze the data.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Census tract-level data from the 2000 census were used to create a sampling frame and match BID and non-BID neighborhoods on 10 socioeconomic and demographic features.  A list-assisted sampling method was used to select 737 households.  Areal interpolation was used to reconcile data from different geographic units (census tracts, police reporting districts, BIDs). Multilevel logistic regression models were used to analyze the relationship between individual, family, neighborhood characteristics, and youth violence.  A neighborhood cluster (NC) approach was also used to estimate neighborhood effects with greater precision.  Models included random intercepts for neighborhoods and random coefficients for neighborhood attributes.

analysis.sample_description: The study used multiple samples:  a sample of 30 Business Improvement Districts (BIDs) in Los Angeles, a household survey of 737 households (362 in BID areas and 375 in matched comparison areas), and data on officially reported crimes from the Los Angeles Police Department.
analysis.analysis_approach: Bayesian hierarchical modeling, multilevel logistic regression, and descriptive analysis were used to analyze the data.  The analysis included examining direct associations between BIDs and youth violence, the role of neighborhood mediators, and heterogeneity in BID effects.

sections.title: Approach and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative study using semi-structured interviews with stakeholders from three SHERPA-LEAP institutions (UCL, LSE, Birkbeck).  The study proceeded in three stages: exploration (exploratory interviews and internal workshop), specification (further interviews to validate initial findings), and analysis and synthesis (aggregation of findings and a second workshop with project team and board members).  The sample of interviewees aimed to represent different stakeholder groups (lecturers, researchers, heads of department, senior management, external relations, library, IT).

analysis.sample_description: Stakeholders from three different-sized SHERPA-LEAP institutions (UCL, LSE, and Birkbeck College, University of London) selected based on research focus and disciplinary heterogeneity.  Interviewees were chosen to represent various stakeholder groups, including lecturers, researchers, heads of department, senior management, external relations staff, library staff, and IT staff.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis and synthesis of interview data.  Two workshops with project team members and project board members were used to cluster findings, identify key issues, and assess the feasibility and acceptability of suggested interventions.

sections.title: Research Design and Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach.  Demand was assessed by surveying subject-matter experts (primarily colonels) who rated the importance of over 100 types of experience for 1100 O-4 to O-6 14N jobs.  Supply was assessed using historical personnel records from the Air Force Personnel Center (AFPC) to identify the experience, education, and training of current intelligence officers. A gap analysis compared supply and demand.  The study also mentions the potential use of flow analysis (a simulation model) to assess alternative futures.

sections.title: Analytical Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a three-step analytical approach: 1) Determine demand by identifying intelligence jobs and their needs; 2) Analyze supply by reviewing field-grade officers' personnel records; 3) Perform a gap analysis to compare supply and demand. Data sources included the Consolidated Manpower Data Base, Uniform Officer Records, and the Manpower Programming and Execution System database.

sections.title: Demand Analysis Methodology
sections.methods_summary: 1,076 jobs were categorized into 90 job categories with similar experience requirements. Subject matter experts rated over 100 types of background and experience as 'critical,' 'important,' or 'useful' for each job category and grade level (O-4, O-5, O-6).  The ratings were verified against available job requisitions.  Analysis focused on operational, organizational, functional, command, and AFSC prefix experience.

sections.title: Supply Analysis Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Historical personnel records from AFPC (1978-2005) were used to identify the education, training, and experience of 14N officers.  Rules were developed to translate positions held into five experience categories (operational, organizational, functional, command/leadership, and specialty).  The accuracy of experience assignment was verified through interviews with 14 officers.  Limitations of the approach, such as incomplete data and changes in organizational structures, are discussed.

sections.title: Gap Analysis and Flow Analysis
sections.methods_summary: A gap analysis compared the experience required for jobs with the experience accumulated by officers holding those jobs.  The analysis considered five experience categories and different levels of criticality.  The study also explores the potential use of flow analysis, a simulation model, to optimize the flow of officers through jobs and assess the implications of alternative futures and policy changes.

analysis.sample_description: All 14N field-grade officers (majors, lieutenant colonels, and colonels) in the Air Force intelligence career field.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis comparing job requirements with officers' accumulated experience, categorized by type and criticality.  Qualitative aspects (proficiency) were not assessed.  The potential for using flow analysis (a simulation model) to optimize officer development and assignment is discussed.

sections.title: Study Design and Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: Desk research to identify 12 international research evaluation frameworks.  8 frameworks selected for further analysis based on discussion with the CAHS Panel Chair. Case study template developed and reviewed by the CAHS Panel Chair. Case studies completed using desk research, email contact, and telephone interviews with key informants. Case studies reviewed by individuals in respective organizations. Findings analyzed in a RAND Europe internal workshop.

sections.title: Analysis of Evaluation Frameworks: Methodology and Methods
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of eight research evaluation frameworks across five key elements: objectives, outcome measures, levels of aggregation, timing, and evaluation methods.  Qualitative comparison and mapping of frameworks to explore interdependencies between these elements.  The analysis is descriptive and comparative, not statistical testing due to small sample size and lack of control for other variables. Figures and tables are used to illustrate the relationships between the key elements.

sections.title: Case Studies: Methodologies
sections.methods_summary: Each case study describes the framework's background, basic description, technical aspects (objectives, attribution, costs, consequences of evaluation, stakeholder involvement), and data collection methods.  Methods vary across case studies and include:  document review, interviews, surveys, bibliometrics, citation analysis, macroeconomic modeling, microeconometric modeling, cost-benefit analysis, expert panels, and network analysis.  Specific data sources and techniques are detailed for each framework.

analysis.sample_description: Eight international research evaluation frameworks (LUMC, MORIA, PART, Vinnova, Payback, DIUS, EU, CDMRP) were selected for in-depth analysis. The selection aimed to balance novelty and context of use.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative comparison and mapping of frameworks across five key elements to explore interdependencies.  Descriptive analysis of case studies to illustrate methodologies and data sources.

sections.title: Study Purpose and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Examined samples of high-forfeiture cases (15 highest-forfeiture cases per year from 2002-2006 from IRS-CI and USSS) and major-case funded cases (all cases from IRS-CI and USSS that closed in those years and received major-case funding). Quantitative analysis supplemented by interviews with agents from IRS-CI and USSS.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Three phases: (1) Development of analytic framework (interviews and document review); (2) Data collection (case details requested from IRS-CI, USSS, and ICE on high-forfeiture and major-case funded cases); (3) Data analysis (quintile analysis, comparison of high-forfeiture and major cases, supplemented by interviews).

analysis.sample_description: High-forfeiture sample: 15 highest-forfeiture cases per year per agency (IRS-CI and USSS) from 2002-2006.  Major-case sample: All cases from IRS-CI and USSS that closed during 2002-2006 and received major-case funding. Note: Data collection resulted in fewer cases than initially requested.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis involved dividing cases into quintiles based on forfeiture value to identify associations between case characteristics and forfeiture levels.  Qualitative data from interviews were used to supplement the quantitative findings and provide context.

sections.title: Chapter 1.2 Method
sections.methods_summary: Literature review of government-initiated and independent evaluations of reforms since 1999, and international educational literature on aspects of primary maths education central to reforms in England.  Focus on key publications rather than a systematic review of all literature.  Included evidence from UK and other countries with similar reforms (e.g., US).

sections.title: Chapter 3.1 Introduction
sections.methods_summary: Overview of government-initiated evaluations: Earl et al. (2003), Ofsted (2002, 2005, 2008).  Table 3-1 summarizes the focus and evaluation methods of each study.

sections.title: Chapter 3.2.1 Data
sections.methods_summary: Surveys and interviews with those involved in implementing the NNS. Postal surveys to 500 schools (2000 and 2002), numeracy consultants (2002). Site visits to 10 schools and 17 other schools and LEAs, including observations and interviews.

sections.title: Appendix A: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Describes the method for computing average point scores on the Key Stage 2 mathematics test using data from the National Pupil Database.  Assigns points to each attainment level (1-6) to calculate average point scores for each year.

sections.title: Chapter 4.2.1 Data
sections.methods_summary: Comparable data on Year 4 pupils in 1997/98 and 2001/02.  Tests assessed conceptual understanding and skills.  Samples of 1328 pupils (1997/98) and 1291 pupils (2001/02) from 35 schools selected by quota sampling based on five variables (size, religious affiliation, socio-economic status, attainment, value added). Classroom observations, interviews with teachers, headteachers, coordinators, and pupils.

sections.title: Chapter 4.3.1 Data
sections.methods_summary: Written responses to eight division problems from 275 pupils in 1998 and 308 pupils in 2003 from the same set of schools (one school changed).

sections.title: Chapter 4.4.1 Data
sections.methods_summary: In-depth interviews with 30 final-year primary B.Ed. students at one university.  Sample included those who readily agreed to participate.

sections.title: Chapter 4.5.1 Data
sections.methods_summary: TIMSS data: mathematics and science assessments, student, teacher, and school questionnaires.  Includes mathematics achievement of Year 5 pupils (1995 and 2003) and Year 9 pupils (1995, 1999, 2003).

analysis.sample_description: The samples varied across studies, including schools, teachers, pupils, and teacher trainees.  Sampling methods included quota sampling and convenience sampling.  Representativeness of samples varied.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis methods varied across studies, including descriptive statistics, comparisons of average scores and standard deviations, and qualitative analysis of interview and observation data.  Some studies used more sophisticated methods like difference-in-difference analysis.

sections.title: Methodology: Executive Summary
sections.methods_summary: This guidebook draws heavily on lessons learned in current conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan. It presents the results of research on best practices in this area.

sections.title: Methodology: Chapter 2 - What You Need to Know Before You Go
sections.methods_summary: The chapter emphasizes the importance of understanding the economic and infrastructure operational and mission variables present in the area of responsibility for mission analysis and COA development during the commander’s MDMP (military decision-making process) for stability operations.  It describes using PMESII-PT and METT-TC variables to gather information on how local people make a living, how the economy could recover, and how the Army can measure the effectiveness of its efforts by measuring outcomes, not inputs or outputs.

sections.title: Methodology: Chapter 2 - Measuring Effectiveness
sections.methods_summary: The chapter describes methods for evaluating the effectiveness of projects and initiatives by focusing on outcomes rather than outputs or inputs.  It suggests qualitative and quantitative indicators of a more stable and secure situation (decline in violence, displacement, etc.) and improvements in the local economy (increased wages, purchases of goods, etc.).  It also outlines methods for collecting information from various sources (government data, NGOs, observations, interviews).

sections.title: Methodology: Chapter 6 - Agriculture
sections.methods_summary: The chapter describes using the World Bank’s Damage and Reconstruction Needs Assessment Toolkit for pre-deployment mission analysis and using military or civilian engineers for route reconnaissance and facilities assessments.  It also mentions collecting weekly information on food prices and monitoring crop and livestock conditions through interviews with local farmers and visits to local markets.

analysis.sample_description: The study draws on experiences from Iraq, Afghanistan, Bosnia, Kosovo, Liberia, and other stability operations.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of best practices and lessons learned, supplemented by quantitative indicators where available.

sections.title: Approach and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach combining quantitative and qualitative data.  Quantitative data was collected through a web-based survey of PSOs (52% response rate), analysis of PSO deployment data from the Oakland Police Department (OPD), and official crime statistics (January 1, 1998 - April 30, 2008).  Qualitative data was gathered via semi-structured interviews and focus groups with OPD staff.  Interrupted time series analysis was used to assess the impact of PSO deployment on crime rates.

sections.title: The Time Series Analysis Process
sections.methods_summary: Details the interrupted time series analysis used to assess the impact of PSO deployment on crime rates.  This includes descriptions of ARIMA models, the model-building process (identification, estimation, diagnosis), and the selection of a transfer function to model the intervention effect.

analysis.sample_description: The web-based survey was distributed to 50 PSOs, with 26 responding (52% response rate).  The crime statistics analysis included data from January 1, 1998 to April 30, 2008.  The interrupted time series analysis focused on 20 beats with Measure Y-funded PSOs deployed for at least one year by April 2008.  12 sworn officers and one civilian staff member participated in interviews and focus groups.
analysis.analysis_approach: Interrupted time series analysis with ARIMA modeling was used to assess the impact of PSO deployment on violent and property crime rates in each beat.  The analysis controlled for trends, seasonality, and other forms of serial correlation.  Qualitative data from surveys and interviews provided contextual information and insights into the implementation and perceived effectiveness of the PSO program.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Longitudinal analysis of classification structure changes; 18 interviews with Air Staff, MAJCOM, and AFPC personnel; review of historical documents and manpower/personnel data; cross-service analysis.

analysis.sample_description: 18 interviews with Air Staff, major command (MAJCOM), and Air Force Personnel Center (AFPC) specialty classification personnel and users of the structure and associated systems, such as functional managers, assignment managers, and occupation analysis specialists.
analysis.analysis_approach: Longitudinal analysis of major changes in the classification structure. Data analysis and cross-service analysis to help shed light on potential issues. Comparative analyses of historical documents and manpower and personnel data to verify information and clarify potential issues and extant patterns.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: Literature review of public libraries and funding issues; selection of 15 comparison libraries based on shared characteristics with Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh (CLP); interviews with 17 library directors and individuals involved in library management or funding.  Three broad factors affecting financial sustainability were identified: demand for library services, advocacy effectiveness, and organizational form. A framework was developed to assess how these factors affect CLP's financial stability, resulting in nine opportunities for improvement.

sections.title: Data, Methods, and Analysis Framework
sections.methods_summary: Literature review using databases like LISTA, OCLC, ERIC, and Google Scholar; selection of 15 comparison libraries based on shared characteristics with CLP; interviews with 11 library directors (75% response rate) and 6 individuals from non-profit or governmental agencies involved in library management or funding.  Analysis involved identifying broad factors affecting financial sustainability from the literature and interviews, organizing these factors into three themes (demand for services, advocacy, organizational form), and developing a framework to assess the impact of these factors on resource sustainability. The framework considered three strategies for balancing resources: seeking additional funds, reducing expenses, and improving efficiency.

analysis.sample_description: 15 comparison libraries selected based on shared characteristics with CLP, not a statistically representative sample.  17 interviewees including 11 library directors and 6 individuals from non-profit or governmental agencies.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of literature and interview data to identify three broad factors affecting financial sustainability.  A framework was developed to assess these factors against three strategies for resource balance (increase funding, decrease expenses, improve efficiency), leading to the identification of nine opportunities for CLP.

sections.title: Section Six: Security (10%)
sections.methods_summary: Scoring rubric applied to assess preparedness in security-related areas.  Points assigned based on completion of listed items.

sections.title: Section Seven: Regional/Local Distribution Site (14%)
sections.methods_summary: Scoring rubric applied to assess preparedness in regional/local distribution site operations. Points assigned based on completion of listed items.

sections.title: Section Eight: Controlling Inventory (3%)
sections.methods_summary: Scoring rubric applied to assess preparedness in inventory control. Points assigned based on completion of listed items.

sections.title: Section Nine: Distribution (10%)
sections.methods_summary: Scoring rubric applied to assess preparedness in distribution operations. Points assigned based on completion of listed items.

sections.title: Section Ten: Dispensing Prophylaxis (24%)
sections.methods_summary: Scoring rubric applied to assess preparedness in dispensing prophylaxis. Points assigned based on completion of listed items.

sections.title: Section Eleven: Hospitals and Alternate Care Facilities Coordination (3%)
sections.methods_summary: Scoring rubric applied to assess preparedness in coordination with hospitals and alternate care facilities. Points assigned based on completion of listed items.

sections.title: Section Twelve: Training, Exercise and Evaluation (10%)
sections.methods_summary: Scoring rubric applied to assess preparedness in training, exercise, and evaluation. Points assigned based on completion of listed items.

sections.title: Evaluation Approach
sections.methods_summary: Mixed-methods approach combining quantitative analysis of Technical Assistance Review (TAR) data with qualitative data from site visits to nine metropolitan areas (five early CRI entrants, two later entrants, and two non-CRI areas).  Qualitative data included interviews with federal, state, and local officials, review of CRI plans and after-action reports, and analysis of smaller-scale outbreaks.  Quantitative analysis involved comparisons between CRI sites with different levels of program exposure and qualitative comparisons between CRI and non-CRI sites.  The analysis used a conceptual framework (logic model) to guide the identification of key aspects of readiness and to assess CRI's contribution to those aspects.

analysis.sample_description: Nine metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs) were selected for in-depth study: five early entrants to the Cities Readiness Initiative (CRI), two later entrants, and two non-CRI MSAs.  The sample was chosen to represent variations in state and local public health structure and geographic region.
analysis.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis of TAR data involved comparisons of scores across time (early vs. later entrants), functional areas, and cohorts. Qualitative analysis used a logic model to identify key aspects of readiness and to assess CRI's contribution.  Qualitative data were analyzed to identify patterns of evidence consistent with the hypothesis that CRI impacted planning and preparedness. Comparisons were made between CRI and non-CRI sites to consider similar trends.

sections.title: Literature Review Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Systematic review of literature on palliative/end-of-life care, focusing on health and economic outcomes.
