Primarily used systematic reviews to identify parameters of interest for health outcomes; a more expansive search was conducted for economic outcomes.  PubMed and six health economics databases were searched for English-language publications (1990-2008).

sections.title: Economic Modeling Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A Markov model was developed to estimate the current costs of end-of-life care in England for cancer and organ failure patients.  The model tracked patients through three states (hospital, hospice, home/community care) over a 365-day period.  Data sources included the Office of National Statistics (ONS), Hospital Episode Statistics (HES), and the Minimum Data Set (MDS). Transition probabilities between states were calculated using a combination of these data sources. Univariate sensitivity analysis was conducted to assess the impact of uncertainty in model parameters (hospice length of stay, hospital admissions, daily costs).

sections.title: Appendix B: Detailed Modeling Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This appendix provides a detailed description of the Markov model, including the rationale, data sources (HES, ONS, MDS), assumptions (e.g., Markov property, fixed transition probabilities), calculation of transition probabilities, cost estimation (using Coyle et al. 1999 data, adjusted for inflation), and sensitivity analysis.  Specific calculations for transition probabilities are shown, along with explanations of how data from different sources were combined and used to estimate model parameters.  Limitations of the model and data are also discussed.

analysis.sample_description: Patients in England in their last year of life suffering from either cancer or organ failure (heart or respiratory).
analysis.analysis_approach: A Markov model was used to simulate the progression of patients through different care settings (hospital, hospice, home/community care) over a year.  Costs were calculated based on the time spent in each setting and the associated daily costs. Sensitivity analysis was used to assess the impact of uncertainty in model parameters.

sections.title: Approach and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the research approach, focusing on effective social programs in the US.  It outlines the selection criteria for programs (rigorous evaluations demonstrating effectiveness), the categorization of programs (early childhood, K-12 education, youth development, employment and welfare), and the data collection process. The inventory of statistically significant outcomes (favorable and unfavorable) is described, along with the classification of outcomes into key domains and the methodology for analyzing the monetization of benefits in benefit-cost analyses (BCAs) for each stakeholder group (government, participants, non-participants).

sections.title: Use of BCA to Evaluate Social Programs and the Role of Shadow Prices
sections.methods_summary: This section provides a primer on cost and outcome analysis methods (cost analysis, cost-effectiveness analysis, cost-savings analysis, benefit-cost analysis), highlighting key principles.  It emphasizes the importance of comparing programs to baselines or alternatives, comprehensive cost measurement (including shadow prices), causal impact measurement, discounting future costs and benefits, and recognizing uncertainty through sensitivity analysis.  The concept of shadow prices in BCA is explained, including the valuation of outcomes based on willingness to pay, adjustments for market distortions, and the handling of intangible benefits.

sections.title: Selection Criteria and Programs Covered in Review
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the criteria used to select social programs for review.  The primary sources were three organizations (Blueprints for Violence Prevention, RAND's Promising Practices Network, Coalition for Evidence-Based Policy) that employ strict standards for identifying effective programs with scientifically sound evaluations.  The criteria included strong research design (preference for randomized controlled trials), adequate sample sizes, low attrition rates, and demonstrated program effectiveness.  The section also explains the process of broadening the initial set of programs to include additional evaluations that met the criteria or offered relevant BCAs.

sections.title: BCAs for Programs Covered in This Study; Outcomes Measured and Monetized; Shadow Prices Used in BCAs
sections.methods_summary: This section details the analysis of benefit-cost analyses (BCAs) for 22 of the 39 programs. It categorizes the BCAs into standalone and multi-program studies (Aos et al. studies).  It describes the methodology for analyzing the monetization of outcomes, including the use of tables to show which outcomes were monetized and how (statistically significant vs. not, projected vs. observed).  The section then delves into the specific shadow pricing methods used for various outcome domains (child/youth and adult education, health, substance abuse, crime).

primary_methods: Review and synthesis of existing literature
analysis.sample_description: 39 effective social programs identified by three organizations using rigorous evaluation criteria.  Programs span various policy areas and life stages.
analysis.analysis_approach: The study reviews and synthesizes existing benefit-cost analyses (BCAs) and program evaluations to assess the state of the art in measuring and using shadow prices to value social program outcomes.  It classifies outcomes based on the established methodology for generating economic values and identifies areas for methodological improvement.

sections.title: Analytical Approach and Case Study Selection
sections.methods_summary: This section details the four perspectives used to analyze ART policy (regulatory, economic, clinical, and wider healthcare and welfare tradition).  A comparative framework is presented, linking these perspectives to ART policy outcomes. The selection of three case study countries (UK, France, and Italy) is justified based on a selection matrix considering welfare state type and ART regulatory restrictiveness.  The data collection process involved a literature review and analysis of data sources to enable a structured comparison.

analysis.sample_description: Three European countries (UK, France, and Italy) were selected as case studies to represent a variety of welfare state types and ART regulatory approaches. The selection was also influenced by data availability, researcher expertise, and language capabilities.
analysis.analysis_approach: A conceptual framework was developed to analyze ART policy from four perspectives: regulatory, economic, clinical, and wider healthcare and welfare tradition.  These perspectives were linked to ART policy outcomes (direct, indirect, and externalities). The analysis involved comparing the characteristics of the ART systems in the three countries, explaining the differences, and assessing the consequences for outcomes.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources used in the study, including Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission (HSCRC) inpatient discharge data (2000-2007) and District of Columbia Hospital Association (DCHA) inpatient data (2000 onward).  Population data for calculating hospitalization rates were obtained from the U.S. Census Population Division's County Characteristics Resident Population Estimates File and the American Community Survey.  The methodology involved calculating hospitalization rates by dividing the number of hospitalizations by the population size for specific age groups.  Zip code mapping to Public Use Microdata Areas (PUMAs) was also addressed to account for inconsistencies in geographic data.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses all inpatient discharges from Maryland hospitals (2000-2007) and from District of Columbia hospitals (2000 onward) for Baltimore City residents. Population data from the U.S. Census and American Community Survey are used to calculate rates for different age groups.
analysis.analysis_approach: Hospitalization rates were calculated by dividing the number of cellulitis-associated hospitalizations by the corresponding population size for each age group.  Data were analyzed across different geographic levels (city, PUMA, zip code) to identify trends and variations in hospitalization rates.

sections.title: Data and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the data sources used in the study, including Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission (HSCRC) inpatient and emergency department discharge data (2000-2007 for inpatient, 2002-2007 for ED), and District of Columbia Hospital Association (DCHA) data.  It describes the methods for classifying inpatient hospitalizations and ED visits as ambulatory care sensitive (ACS) using established algorithms from Billings et al. (2000). Population data are drawn from U.S. Census Bureau data, including County Characteristics Resident Population Estimates and American Community Survey data.  The use of PUMAs (Public Use Microdata Areas) to approximate neighborhood-level analysis is explained due to limitations in zip code-level population data.  The methodology for calculating ACS rates (dividing ACS events by population counts) is clearly outlined.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses the universe of inpatient and ED discharges from Maryland hospitals for Baltimore City residents, supplemented by data from District of Columbia hospitals for Baltimore City residents to improve accuracy. Population data are used from the U.S. Census Bureau at the city, PUMA, and zip code levels.
analysis.analysis_approach: ACS rates are calculated by dividing the number of ACS hospitalizations or ED visits by the appropriate population count.  Time trends are analyzed for different age groups and compared across Baltimore City, other Maryland counties, and the District of Columbia.  Spatial variation is explored using PUMAs and zip codes.  Payer mix for ACS events is also analyzed.

sections.title: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study employed surveys for four groups: anesthesiologists (ANs), certified registered nurse anesthetists (CRNAs), directors of anesthesiology (ANDIRs), and surgeons.  The AN and CRNA surveys gathered data on demographics, employment, time usage, technology preferences, and future plans.  A stratified random sample was used for the ANDIR survey, purchased from a vendor.  The surgeon survey data was obtained from a pre-existing RAND study.  Analysis methods included probit/regression analysis, demand-based analysis (DBA), and econometric analysis (including equilibrium and disequilibrium models).  Sample weights were used to account for nonresponse and sampling bias.

sections.title: Summary of Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Surveys of ANs and CRNAs on demographics, employment, time use, technology preferences, and future plans were conducted in 2007 in collaboration with professional organizations.  ANDIRs were surveyed using a stratified random sample. Surgeons were surveyed to gather broad details on AN and CRNA usage. Data were used to characterize the labor markets and assess shortage/surplus using three approaches: survey-based analysis, demand-based analysis (DBA), and econometric analysis.

sections.title: Summary of Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Three approaches were used to analyze shortage/surplus: 1) Survey-based analysis of workforce-related questions; 2) Demand-based analysis (DBA) using national averages of clinical hours worked to calculate FTEs and demand based on service volume and time per service; 3) Econometric analysis estimating statewide supply and demand, considering wages and other state-level factors.  The economic approach was preferred due to its more extensive use of information.

sections.title: Technical Details on Demand-Based Assessment
sections.methods_summary: Describes the mathematical formulas and assumptions used in the demand-based analysis (DBA), including calculations of FTE employment, demand for labor, and shortage estimation under different assumptions about labor supply and procedure times.

sections.title: Technical Details on Econometric Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Details the econometric models used, including log-log specifications for labor supply and demand, estimation methods (two-stage least squares and maximum likelihood), and the treatment of disequilibrium.  The calculation of elasticities and the use of instrumental variables are also explained.

analysis.sample_description: The study used surveys of anesthesiologists (ANs), certified registered nurse anesthetists (CRNAs), directors of anesthesiology (ANDIRs), and surgeons.  Sampling methods varied by group, with stratified random sampling used for ANDIRs and a convenience sample for ANs and CRNAs via professional organizations.  The surgeon sample was from a pre-existing study.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved descriptive statistics, probit/regression analysis to examine heterogeneity, demand-based analysis (DBA) to assess shortage/surplus based on FTEs and service volume, and econometric analysis (equilibrium and disequilibrium models) to estimate supply and demand relationships, incorporating wages and other state-level factors.  The study also included scenario planning to project future labor market conditions.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research involved a literature review focusing on the links between alcohol price and income, consumption, and harms; secondary analysis of quantitative data on alcohol taxation, affordability, consumption, and harms; an online survey of members of the European Alcohol and Health Forum and the Committee on National Alcohol Policy and Action; and a workshop with representatives from various sectors.

sections.title: Estimation Strategy
sections.methods_summary: A first-difference approach was used to explore the relationship between alcohol affordability and consumption, addressing the non-stationarity of the variables and eliminating the association of independent trends.  The model was estimated in natural logarithms to interpret coefficients as elasticities. Robust standard errors were used to account for potential violations of regression assumptions. A dynamic model was also estimated to distinguish between short-term and long-term effects.

sections.title: Estimation Strategy
sections.methods_summary: A first-difference approach was used to analyze the relationship between alcohol consumption and harm indicators (fatal traffic accidents, non-fatal traffic injuries, liver cirrhosis, and homicide).  Natural logarithms were used to interpret coefficients as elasticities.  Robust standard errors were employed.  A traffic density variable was included to control for potential confounding effects.

analysis.sample_description: The quantitative analysis included data from 20 EU countries (AT, BE, CY, DE, DK, EE, ES, FI, FR, GR, IE, IT, LT, LV, NL, PL, PT, SE, SK, UK) for the years 1996-2003.  The survey targeted members of the European Alcohol and Health Forum and the Committee on National Alcohol Policy and Action. The workshop included experts and stakeholders in the alcohol field.
analysis.analysis_approach: Regression analysis using a first-difference approach to examine the relationships between alcohol affordability and consumption, and between alcohol consumption and harm indicators.  Elasticities were calculated to quantify the relationships.  Robust standard errors were used to improve the reliability of the estimates.  Dynamic models were used to separate short-term and long-term effects.

sections.title: Study Approach
sections.methods_summary: International benchmarking using qualitative and quantitative methodologies.  Interviews with coalition partners and media analysis were also included.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Two-stage approach: 1) Data-driven research (literature review and internal RAND workshop); 2) Perception-driven research (interviews and media analysis).  Data sources included national defense white papers, publications from research institutes, and media reports.  Qualitative and quantitative data were analyzed. Interviews were conducted with representatives from comparator countries and service/civilian personnel with experience working with the Netherlands Armed Forces. Media analysis involved identifying articles using search terms, categorizing them by topic and tone, and entering them into a database.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Assessments of strategic posture were made by the RAND Europe study team and an external reviewer during a half-day expert workshop.  The assessment considered stated defense policy, defense planning assumptions, and the number of forces deployed in recent and current expeditionary deployments.

analysis.sample_description: Comparator countries selected based on joint training, operations, or deployments with the Netherlands Armed Forces (e.g., Canada, Denmark, Australia, Germany, UK, US). Interviews included representatives from comparator country governments (primarily defense attachés) and service/civilian personnel from the UK and US.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative assessments were made using numerous sources, while quantitative data comparisons were restricted to consistent sources to minimize methodological differences. Data on defense spending, personnel deployments, and equipment platforms were analyzed and compared across countries. Media articles were categorized by topic and tone to assess perceptions of the Netherlands Armed Forces.

sections.title: Research Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research involved four main steps: 1) developing a typology of medical regulatory systems; 2) characterizing the medical regulatory system of each of the ten countries according to this typology, using available documents and key informant interviews; 3) conducting a cross-country analysis to identify key messages and issues relevant to the GMC; and 4) drawing conclusions and implications for the GMC, and making recommendations for further research.  The typology was developed through a literature review and interviews with 20 GMC staff. Data collection involved key informant interviews and desk-based research (internet, legal documents, online literature).

analysis.sample_description: Ten countries (Egypt, Germany, Greece, India, Italy, Nigeria, Pakistan, Poland, South Africa, and Spain) were selected based on the countries of origin of the ten largest groups of non-UK qualified doctors registered with the GMC.  The number of key informant interviews varied by country, with a range of interviewees from various positions within medical regulatory organizations and related fields.
analysis.analysis_approach: A cross-country comparative analysis was conducted to identify similarities and differences in medical regulatory systems across the ten countries.  This analysis used the previously developed typology to ensure consistency and comparability across countries. The analysis focused on identifying key messages and issues of particular interest to the GMC.

sections.title: Methods and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study used a series of six workshops, one in each of six government regions.  Each workshop involved two Crime and Disorder Reduction Partnerships (CDRPs) and 4-6 practitioners from each CDRP.  The workshops were designed to be flexible, allowing practitioners to identify important issues. The findings are not representative of a systematic survey but offer valuable insights from participating practitioners.

analysis.sample_description: Six workshops were held across England, each involving two CDRPs and 4-6 practitioners per CDRP. Agencies represented included police, local councils, and Drug and Alcohol Action Teams (DAATs).  Health services were under-represented. Participants were selected by regional government offices.
analysis.analysis_approach: The findings from the workshops were analyzed and synthesized to identify key themes and issues.  Comments were not attributed to specific individuals or agencies to protect anonymity and because representation was not systematic.

sections.title: Evaluation Methods
sections.methods_summary: Qualitative and quantitative analyses; document review; site visits with stakeholder interviews; surveys of workers, agencies, consumers, and grantees; multivariate and longitudinal analysis of survey and web-based data.

sections.title: Survey Methods
sections.methods_summary: Mail surveys to agencies, workers, and consumers; cluster sampling design (all participating agencies, random sample of workers and consumers within agencies); comparison group of non-participating agencies;  incentives for participation; repeat mailings and reminder letters; coordination with local evaluation efforts; Flesch-Kinkaid readability scale used for survey questions; categorical response options to minimize response variability; advisory panel review of survey instruments; OMB approval.

sections.title: Statistical Modeling
sections.methods_summary: Multivariate regression model with random effects;  seven-category initiative structure;  Hausman test to assess independence assumption; robust standard errors clustered by state; sensitivity analysis to assess impact of Washington sample.

analysis.sample_description: Ten demonstration projects funded by CMS, involving various state agencies and non-profit organizations.  A comparison group of non-participating agencies, workers, and consumers was also included.  Sample sizes varied across states and initiative types.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of implementation processes and outcomes. Quantitative analysis included multivariate regression to assess the association of initiative types with worker and agency responses, and longitudinal analysis of turnover, vacancy, and retention data from surveys and web-based reports.  Random effects modeling was used to account for state-level variation.

sections.title: Appendix A: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study employed a three-phase approach.  Phase 1 involved scoping the issues through literature review and discussions with the client, followed by a review of scientific literature and policy documents on the technical, economic, and societal aspects of convergence.  A model of the changing information delivery chain was developed and validated through expert interviews. Phase 2 consisted of three case studies (UK, US, South Korea) using a case study protocol, reviewing policy reports, evaluations, annual reports, and conducting semi-structured interviews with stakeholders. Phase 3 involved a Capabilities, Limitations, Opportunities, and Threats (CLOT) analysis of each case study, assessing appropriateness, coherence, and impact, as well as robustness and flexibility.  The findings were then compared across cases.

analysis.sample_description: Three case studies were conducted: United Kingdom, United States, and South Korea.  Stakeholder interviews included experts from the research community, telco regulators, government policy staff, representatives from incumbent operators, public broadcasters, new media firms, and other stakeholders.
analysis.analysis_approach: A three-phase approach was used, culminating in a comparative analysis of the three case studies using a CLOT framework to assess appropriateness, coherence, impact, robustness, and flexibility of the regulatory approaches.

sections.title: Research Question and Approach
sections.methods_summary: The RAND National Defense Research Institute (NDRI) was asked to apply its computer simulation models to assess the complexity and feasibility of managing the new grade- and end-strength accounting rules.

sections.title: Overview of Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Computer simulation models were used to assess the complexity and feasibility of managing the new end-strength accounting rules.  The model's function, assumptions, and inputs are described in subsequent chapters.

sections.title: Model Description and Procedures
sections.methods_summary: A computer simulation model, similar to SimCity, was used.  The model simulates hundreds of officers, assigning, promoting, and retiring them over a simulated 100-year period.  Entity characteristics (officers, services, positions) are defined, and the model tracks various officer characteristics over time.  Key quantitative inputs include grade and end-strength limitations, number of positions, and percentage of RC officers in external positions.  Business rules govern processes such as promotion selection, assignment prioritization, and retirement.  The model initializes with simulated officers, then runs a second time using data from the first run to create a more realistic starting point.  The model includes procedures for O-6 accessions, officer information updates, retirement date setting, assignment availability determination, job-score calculation, job assignments, involuntary retirements, promotion number and timing calculations, assignment and vacancy forecasting, and handling of RC officers on active duty.  The model does not allow for fractions of people or positions.

analysis.sample_description: The model uses hundreds of simulated officers in grades O-6 through O-10, representing active and reserve components across the Army, Navy, Air Force, and Marine Corps. The model runs for a simulated 100 years (400 quarters).
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis focuses on system-wide outcomes, such as the ability of each service to manage its personnel within end-strength limitations.  The analysis examines the frequency, magnitude, and duration of end-strength violations to assess the feasibility and tractability of the new accounting rules.  Multiple scenarios were modeled, varying the number of joint pool positions open to Reserve Component GFOs.

sections.title: Introduction and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach, primarily relying on existing data from national and international sources such as the EMCDDA and UNODC.  It supplemented these data with expert interviews in 18 selected countries representing various regions and drug market characteristics.  The study also involved developing new estimates of the global drug market size and economic costs, though limitations in data availability prevented robust global cost estimations.  Methodological challenges are discussed in a separate report.

sections.title: Data Collection and Estimation Methods (Cocaine and Heroin Production)
sections.methods_summary: Relied on existing estimates from the UNODC (aerial observations and ground surveys) and the U.S. government (International Narcotics Control Strategy Report).  The authors acknowledge the substantial differences and limitations of these estimates.

sections.title: Data Collection and Estimation Methods (Cannabis and ATS Production)
sections.methods_summary: Acknowledges the difficulty in estimating cannabis and ATS production due to dispersed and often indoor cultivation.  Existing estimates rely on seizure data, which is considered a questionable source due to the inability to separate changes in seizures from changes in enforcement efforts.

sections.title: Data Collection and Estimation Methods (Consumption)
sections.methods_summary: Primarily used general population surveys (e.g., ESPAD) for cannabis and ATS. For cocaine and heroin, relied on estimates from various sources including criminal justice and treatment data due to limitations of general population surveys in capturing frequent users.  Detailed methodological issues are discussed in a separate report.

sections.title: Data Collection and Estimation Methods (Drug-Related Problems)
sections.methods_summary: Collected data on drug-related deaths, HIV, and crime.  Acknowledges limitations in data availability and comparability across countries due to differences in definitions and data collection methods.

sections.title: Data Collection and Estimation Methods (Economic Cost Estimates)
sections.methods_summary: Attempted to develop new economic cost estimates using a consistent methodology for nine Western countries.  Concludes that the exercise is infeasible due to inconsistencies in existing data and concepts across countries.

analysis.sample_description: 18 countries selected to represent various regions of the world, including major drug producing and consuming countries, countries with recently transitioned regimes, and countries with diverse drug policy approaches.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative analysis of existing data, supplemented by expert interviews.  Economic modeling was used to estimate market size and revenues, but limitations in data availability prevented robust global cost estimations.

sections.title: Chapter 5: The Organization of the Trade - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used to analyze the organization of the drug trade.  The authors relied heavily on existing literature, including court transcripts (wiretaps), interviews with traffickers, and analysis of market data (prices, quantities).  The approach is primarily qualitative, drawing on case studies of specific organizations and markets in the US and Europe to illustrate the characteristics of the trade's structure.  Quantitative data, such as seizure information, is used to support qualitative observations.

analysis.sample_description: The sample varies across subsections.  Chapter 5.1 uses Adler's (1985) study of 65 high-level dealers and smugglers in Southern California. Chapter 5.2 uses Fuentes' (1998) work based on court transcripts and interviews with five senior traffickers. Chapter 5.3 draws on various sources regarding European smuggling, including Interpol reports and other studies.  The overall sample is not explicitly defined but consists of various studies and data sources.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis is primarily qualitative, using case studies to illustrate the organizational characteristics of drug trafficking.  Quantitative data, such as seizure information and price data, is used to support the qualitative findings and to make inferences about market competition.

sections.title: Approach and Census Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Two-phase study. Phase 1: Comprehensive census of personnel in seven Air Force centers (January-February 2008) using a survey questionnaire to collect data on demographics, experience, training, and time spent on cost estimation tasks. Phase 2: Face-to-face interviews with commanders in three product centers (May-July 2008) and focus groups with cost estimators to gather information on workforce adequacy, composition, competencies, and training needs.  Data analysis involved entering survey responses into a spreadsheet for analysis.

sections.title: ACAT Program Analysis Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Examination of the proportion of ACAT I, II, and III programs with assigned lead estimators based on a list provided by SAF/AQX.

analysis.sample_description: The study included 374 cost estimators across seven Air Force product and logistics centers.  Interviews were conducted with commanders and staff at three of the four product centers (ASC, ESC, and SMC). Focus groups included samples of lead and non-lead cost estimators.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive analysis of census data and interview responses.  The report focuses on areas of agreement across respondents and centers, providing an aggregate overview of strengths and weaknesses.

sections.title: Chapter 3: A process for constructing a global estimate of the burden of illicit drug use
sections.methods_summary: This chapter outlines a conceptual framework for estimating the global burden of illicit drug use.  It proposes two approaches (A and B). Approach A focuses on costs directly attributable to drug use (treatment, health outcomes, lost productivity, intangible costs of addiction). Approach B adds the costs of societal responses (criminal justice, harm reduction, prevention). The framework acknowledges the challenges of consistent cross-national measurement and advocates for a narrower set of universally applicable indicators, prioritizing those with established international consensus and relatively consistent measurement across countries.  The chapter emphasizes the use of past-year prevalence of illicit drug use as a consistent measure, acknowledging limitations in not being able to differentiate between types of users or substances.

sections.title: Chapter 4: Difficulties in constructing a global estimate: the need for further refinement
sections.methods_summary: This chapter details the challenges encountered in applying the framework from Chapter 3.  It discusses limitations in data availability, leading to a reduction in the number of countries and cost elements considered.  The chapter analyzes data from the European Union, highlighting inconsistencies even within a region with coordinated data collection efforts (EMCDDA).  Data collection methods for various indicators (drug treatment, injection drug use, HIV/AIDS, Hepatitis C, Hepatitis B, problem drug use, drug-related deaths, drug-related offenses) are described, emphasizing the variations in data sources, sampling methods, and definitions across countries.  The chapter highlights the difficulties in obtaining consistent estimates for non-fatal productivity losses and drug-induced crime due to methodological and definitional inconsistencies in the literature.

sections.title: Chapter 5: Determining the unit cost of drug-related harms
sections.methods_summary: This chapter focuses on the challenges of establishing consistent unit cost estimates for the indicators identified in Chapter 4.  It describes the methods used to obtain unit cost estimates for various harms (lifetime medical costs of HIV infection and Hepatitis C, cost of Hepatitis B, intangible costs of addiction, cost of law enforcement for drug offenses).  The chapter details the sources and methods used for each cost estimate, highlighting variations in approaches across countries.  For example, it explains the use of previous studies, adjustments for inflation, currency conversions, and different modeling approaches (Markov models) to estimate lifetime costs of diseases.  The chapter also discusses the use of top-down approaches for estimating law enforcement costs, acknowledging the limitations of this method and the variations in data availability and definitions across countries.

primary_methods: Data compilation and analysis from existing national studies and reports
Cost estimation using various methods (top-down, bottom-up, Markov modeling)
analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from a variety of sources, including national studies, reports from the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA), and other national health and criminal justice statistics.  The specific countries included vary depending on data availability and quality.  The chapter focuses on a subset of developed countries with relatively good data, including the United States, Canada, Australia, the UK, Spain, France, Italy, Germany, and the Netherlands.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves a comparative review of existing national studies, followed by an attempt to construct a consistent estimate of the economic burden of drug use across a selected group of countries.  The analysis highlights the challenges of cross-national comparison due to differences in data collection, definitions, and costing methods.  The study uses both top-down and bottom-up approaches for cost estimation, depending on the availability of data.

sections.title: General Approach
sections.methods_summary: The research involved a review of peer-reviewed and gray literature, semistructured qualitative interviews with 41 individuals from 39 organizations, and an expert panel meeting with 9 experts and 21 attendees.

sections.title: Literature Review
sections.methods_summary: A search of PubMed using multiple search terms yielded 94 articles.  12 empirical articles were selected based on inclusion/exclusion criteria, supplemented by 6 additional articles.  The review was further supplemented with gray literature and news articles from LexisNexis Academic Universe.

sections.title: Interviews
sections.methods_summary: Semistructured interviews were conducted with 41 individuals from 39 organizations representing various sectors of the healthcare industry and related expertise (see Table 1.1).

sections.title: Expert Panel Meeting
sections.methods_summary: An expert panel meeting was held on April 22, 2010, with 9 experts and 21 attendees.  Three primary topics were discussed: current policy and practice considerations, emerging retail clinic trends, and issues and questions for federal policy consideration.  Appendix B provides participant list and discussion overview.

sections.title: Appendix A: Methods
sections.methods_summary: Details the literature search strategy in PubMed, including search terms used.  Describes the supplementary search in LexisNexis Academic Universe and the inclusion/exclusion criteria for articles (Figure A.1).

analysis.sample_description: The interview sample included 41 individuals from 39 organizations representing retail clinics, trade associations, experts, health systems, professional associations, health insurance representatives, urgent care centers, public health departments, and federal agencies.  The expert panel consisted of 9 experts.
analysis.analysis_approach: The findings from the literature review, interviews, and expert panel meeting were combined and presented thematically.

sections.title: Appendix B: Estimating Health Literacy - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Developed two predictive models of health literacy using data from the National Assessment of Adult Literacy (NAAL).  The first model was a linear model predicting mean health literacy score. The second was a linear probability model predicting the percentage of the population scoring at the “above basic” level.  Public Use Microdata from the 2007 American Community Survey and demographic data from the 2000 Census Summary File 3 were used.  Replicate weights were used to account for sampling error in NAAL and the ACS. Design effect adjustments were used for the Census SF3 files.

sections.title: Appendix C: Data Source and Health Outcomes in Prototype Mapping Tool - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Data on health outcomes for the public-access version of the mapping tool came from Missouri’s 2007 County-Level Study (CLS), a survey of 49,513 individuals using methods standardized by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS).  The CLS differed from the BRFSS in sample construction to ensure accurate county-level estimates.

sections.title: Appendix D: Neighborhood Sociodemographic Characteristics and Health Services Data - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Demographic data from the 2000 Census Summary File 3 (SF3) was used for census tracts and counties.  The 2007 American Community Survey (ACS) Public Use Microdata Sample (PUMS) was used for PUMAs.  Definitions of variables such as age, race, education, marital status, poverty, language spoken at home, length of residence in the U.S., and linguistic isolation are provided.

sections.title: Appendix E: Health Plan Data - Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Healthcare Effectiveness Data and Information Set (HEDIS) data were obtained from several health plans, including Missouri Medicaid.  Due to concerns about confidentiality and data linkage, these data were not included in the publicly accessible version of the tool but were incorporated into a secure, sponsor-only version.

analysis.sample_description: Appendix B describes the NAAL sample (nationally representative sample of English-speaking U.S. adults). Appendix C describes the Missouri County-Level Study (CLS) sample (49,513 individuals in Missouri).
analysis.analysis_approach: Appendix B details the development of two linear models (one for mean health literacy score and one for percentage above basic health literacy) and the use of probability weights and design effect adjustments to account for sampling error and uncertainty in data sources.

sections.title: Analytic Approach
sections.methods_summary: Four-step process: 1. Analyze defense planning guidance and translate requirements into logistics workloads. 2. Identify maintenance mission-generation units and manpower requirements. 3. Evaluate maintenance network performance, focusing on efficiencies and effects on aircraft availability. 4. Use an integer linear program to develop an optimization approach for identifying minimum-cost maintenance network designs and trade-offs of centralization levels.  A range of options between enhancing operational effectiveness and extracting savings are presented.

sections.title: Methodology for Rebalancing C-130 Maintenance Resources
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used to calculate maintenance-related manpower requirements for the C-130 fleet.  It includes: determining existing manpower authorizations using FY 2008 unit manning documents; calculating maintenance workloads for peacetime and contingency operations using the Logistics Composite Model (LCOM); assessing inventory pipelines for centralized operations; examining scheduled maintenance tasks (ISO inspections, HSCs, refurbishments) and their centralization; analyzing deferrable maintenance (NGFs); evaluating off-equipment component repair centralization; determining mission-generation maintenance manpower requirements (differing slightly for standard and specialty aircraft); computing component repair pipelines and transportation costs; and using an optimization model to design C-130 repair networks, considering various parameters (TAI, geographic dispersion, OPTEMPO, economies of scale, personnel costs, aircraft shuttle costs, facility costs).

sections.title: Methodology for Assessing the Effects of Integrated Maintenance (HVM)
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the methodology used to assess the high-velocity maintenance (HVM) concept. It involves comparing performance parameters of existing PDM and CRF processes with estimated HVM process parameters.  Data from Air Force Total Ownership Cost–Cost Analysis Improvement Group (FY 2005–July 2008) and Warner Robins ALC (FY 2007–July 2008) were used to estimate PDM costs, labor hours, productivity, and flow times.  A comparison model was developed using Warner Robins estimates to determine the cost and performance parameters of the HVM process, adjusting demand to match the total aircraft inventory (TAI) and considering shuttling costs.  Facility costs were assumed to be the same as for a new CRF facility.

sections.title: Analysis Summary
sections.methods_summary: This section summarizes the findings of the analysis, highlighting key results and implications for the Air Force.

sections.title: Appendix A: Maintenance Manpower Authorizations
sections.methods_summary: Details the procedure for refining MPES data to determine C-130 wing-level maintenance manpower levels.  It describes the process of segregating manpower records using AFPE codes, FACs, and ORGTs; differentiating between full- and part-time personnel; addressing multiple-MDS and associate unit issues; and separating authorizations into standard and specialty authorizations.  It also discusses associate arrangements considered under the Total Force Integration (TFI) concept.

sections.title: Appendix C: Modeling C-130 Maintenance with the Logistics Composite Model (LCOM)
sections.methods_summary: Explains the use of LCOM, a stochastic discrete-event simulation model, to determine manpower requirements for C-130 maintenance.  It describes the model's fundamentals, focusing on the interplay of resources (manpower, equipment, facilities, spares) and the process of satisfying sortie demands.  It details the process of running the C-130 LCOM model, including constraining manpower levels to ensure sortie success rates and applying man-hour availability factors (MAFs).  It also describes the adaptation of AMC's C-130 LCOM models (home-station, FOL, RMF) to account for regionalized maintenance constructs.

sections.title: Appendix D: Integer Linear Programming Model
sections.methods_summary: Describes the integer linear programming model used to address the facility location problem for CRFs.  It defines sets, parameters, and decision variables, including the number, location, and capacity of CRFs, assignment of operating locations to CRFs, and manpower requirements.  The objective function minimizes annualized costs (construction, transportation, personnel).  Constraints ensure that each operating location is assigned to a single CRF, total repair capacity meets demand, and facility capacity matches the number of repair teams.

sections.title: Appendix B: Analysis of ISO Inspections and HSCs Using REMIS
sections.methods_summary: Describes the analysis of REMIS data for ISO inspections and HSCs.  It details the data collection and error-reduction process, including the use of work unit codes, sorting of records, and manual consolidation of data.  It explains the calculation of fly-to-fly times, on-aircraft flow times, and maintenance man-hours (MMH).

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the Air Force's Resources Management Information System (REMIS) covering a five-year period (January 2002 to January 2007) for C-130 maintenance data.  Additional data sources include FY 2008 unit manning documents, Program Analysis and Evaluation (PA&E) guidance documents, Air Force Total Ownership Cost–Cost Analysis Improvement Group data, and Warner Robins ALC data.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves a combination of quantitative and qualitative methods.  Quantitative methods include the use of the Logistics Composite Model (LCOM) for simulation, integer linear programming for optimization, and statistical analysis of REMIS data.  Qualitative methods include discussions with personnel at operating locations and a review of relevant Air Force documents and guidance.

sections.title: Methods of Assessing the Impact of Arts and Humanities Research
sections.methods_summary: Four methods were used: interviews with senior Cambridge arts and humanities researchers (22 interviewees from all main faculties and departments), a survey of all arts and humanities researchers at the University of Cambridge (39% response rate from 737), interviews with external users of research outside the University of Cambridge (17 interviewees from arts journalism, radio broadcasting, a national museum, public festivals, international academic publishers, parliament, law and architecture professions, and international business), and four detailed case studies of arts and humanities research at the University.

sections.title: Approach and Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The study adapted the Payback Framework, originally developed for health services research, to analyze the impacts of arts and humanities research.  The framework was modified to include new categories of impact (academic impact, impact on policy and practice, wider societal impacts, and economic impacts), a new interface ('teaching'), and a revised logic model of the research process. Four sources of evidence were used: key informant interviews with senior Cambridge researchers (13 interviews with 22 academics), a survey of all arts and humanities researchers at Cambridge (289 responses from 737, 39% response rate), four detailed case studies, and key informant interviews with external experts (15 interviews with senior figures from various sectors).

analysis.sample_description: The study included interviews with 22 senior Cambridge academics representing all major faculties and departments, a survey of 737 arts and humanities researchers at Cambridge (289 responses), 17 external experts from various sectors, and four detailed case studies.
analysis.analysis_approach: The adapted Payback Framework was used to analyze the data, focusing on categories of impact and a logic model of the research process.  The analysis considered both academic and non-academic impacts, including teaching's role.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This report is a literature review.  The authors collected data on vehicle crash deaths among service members and reviewed over 500 citations, selecting those of particular relevance (focused on military populations, summarized other research, or were methodologically rigorous).  The authors did not conduct new research.

sections.title: Data Analysis for Chapter 2: Deaths from Motor Vehicle Crashes
sections.methods_summary: Analysis uses three common measures of crash fatalities: absolute numbers, deaths per vehicle miles traveled (VMT), and death rates per 100,000 population. Data are drawn from NHTSA's Fatality Analysis Reporting System (FARS) and CDC's National Vital Statistics publications.  Limitations are noted regarding the lack of VMT data for service members, making it difficult to calculate fatalities per VMT for a direct comparison with civilian data.

sections.title: Data Analysis for Chapter 3: Factors Influencing Crash Rates for All Vehicles
sections.methods_summary: Analysis examines demographic and behavioral factors influencing crash rates.  Data sources include laboratory studies and epidemiological studies (FARS and other databases).  The authors acknowledge limitations in isolating the effect of specific causes due to multiple contributing factors in crashes.  Five studies specifically focusing on military personnel are reviewed, using adjusted odds ratios to compare groups while controlling for other variables.  The authors describe how odds ratios are interpreted.

sections.title: Data Analysis for Chapter 4: Factors Influencing Motorcycle Crash Rates
sections.methods_summary: Analysis examines demographic, socioeconomic, and behavioral factors influencing motorcycle crash rates. Data sources include NHTSA data, including the National Occupant Protection Use Survey.  The authors discuss limitations in comparing data across different sources and the difficulty in determining the relative importance of various trends contributing to increased motorcycle fatalities.

sections.title: Data Analysis for Chapter 5: Predicting Risky Driving
sections.methods_summary: Analysis examines predictors of risky driving behaviors (DWI, seat belt use, speeding, aggressive driving).  Data sources include surveys linking personality measures (sensation-seeking, impulsivity, deviance) with self-reported risky driving behavior and traffic violations.  The authors discuss the use of summed scores for multiple risky driving behaviors and review studies using various data sources and samples (including military and civilian populations).

sections.title: Data Analysis for Chapter 6: Effectiveness of Safety Interventions
sections.methods_summary: Analysis reviews the effectiveness of various safety interventions (media campaigns, high-visibility enforcement, changes in regulation, alcohol treatment, technological approaches).  The authors discuss the methodology of evaluating media campaigns, highlighting challenges in isolating campaign effects from other factors.  They review studies using comparison of alcohol-related accident rates before and after policy implementation, comparisons of geographic areas, and high-visibility enforcement (HVE) campaigns.  They also discuss the use of brief interventions for alcohol problems and the limitations of technological approaches.

sections.title: Data Analysis for Chapter 7: Effectiveness of Motorcycle Training and Other Policies
sections.methods_summary: Analysis reviews the effectiveness of motorcycle safety policies (helmet laws, licensing restrictions, rider training, personal protective equipment).  The authors discuss studies using comparisons across states, before-and-after assessments of law changes, and reviews of existing literature.  They examine the effectiveness of different types of licensing restrictions (learner's permits, GDL, tiered licensing) and rider training programs, noting mixed results and suggesting areas for further research.

analysis.sample_description: The study sample for the literature review includes over 500 citations, with a subset selected for detailed review based on relevance to military populations, methodological rigor, and the extent to which they summarized other research.  Specific studies of military personnel are identified and described.
analysis.analysis_approach: The primary analysis approach is a qualitative synthesis of findings from the reviewed literature.  Quantitative analysis is limited to descriptive statistics (e.g., percentages, averages) and odds ratios from existing studies.  The authors discuss limitations in data availability and the challenges in isolating the effects of specific factors due to multiple contributing causes of crashes.

sections.title: Framework Development and Data Analysis
sections.methods_summary: A unique framework combining needs assessment, asset inventory, and best practices was developed based on community values and a literature review.  Existing secondary data on child and family well-being, community assets, and evidence-based research were systematically reviewed to identify strategies at the intersection of these three approaches.

sections.title: Community Engagement and Framework Application
sections.methods_summary: A series of community meetings were held to gather input on community values regarding investment prioritization.  A literature review informed the development of a hybrid framework combining needs assessment, asset inventory, and best practices. This framework guided the analysis of secondary data to identify priority investment areas.

sections.title: Needs Assessment Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Objective criteria based on social indicators from KIDS COUNT and other indices were used.  Parish averages were compared to Louisiana and U.S. averages to identify high-need areas in education, poverty, and health.  Distance from the average served as the benchmark for establishing need.  Existing secondary data were used to avoid collecting new data, allowing for easy comparison of a wide range of indicators.

sections.title: Asset Identification Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A macro-level asset inventory was conducted focusing on organizational, institutional, and governmental resources relevant to the priority need areas. Secondary data sources such as workforce statistics and information on private and public organizations were used.  The analysis considered both the quantity and quality of assets.

sections.title: Best Practices Methodology
sections.methods_summary: Information from the Promising Practices Network (PPN) website was used, considering both 'Proven' and 'Promising' evidence standards.  The focus was on the best available evidence, not solely on randomized controlled trials.

analysis.sample_description: The study focused on Caddo and Bossier Parishes in Louisiana, involving diverse stakeholders from various sectors (nonprofits, businesses, government, etc.) participating in community meetings.  The data analyzed were existing secondary data from sources like KIDS COUNT and other publicly available datasets.
analysis.analysis_approach: A qualitative and quantitative approach was used.  Qualitative data were gathered through community meetings to understand community values and preferences. Quantitative data analysis involved comparing parish-level data on various social indicators to state and national averages to identify high-need areas.  The analysis used a novel framework that integrated needs assessment, asset inventory, and best practices to identify priority investment areas.

sections.title: Research Approach and Methods
sections.methods_summary: The research employed a mixed-methods approach combining document review and key informant interviews.  Initially, an online survey was planned but was replaced with a second round of key informant interviews.  The document review analyzed internal DG SANCO documentation on data management and a sample of publicly available documents produced during various policy stages. Key informant interviews (24 interviews with 25 individuals) covered all directorates and units, aiming for representation across policy stages.  The selection of interviewees was purposeful, guided by Unit 02 to ensure coverage of different policy stages and directorates.  The limitations of the methodology are acknowledged, particularly the reliance on perceptions of a selected group of staff and the limited triangulation of findings due to a shortage of internal documents.

analysis.sample_description: The key informant interviews involved 24 interviews with 25 individuals, purposefully selected by Unit 02 to represent all directorates, units, and policy stages (policy setting and planning, impact assessment, policy evaluation and enforcement, inter-institutional process, and communication). The sample was not evenly distributed across directorates or units. The document review included internal DG SANCO documents on data management and a sample of publicly available documents from different policy stages and directorates.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis relied heavily on the key informant interviews, resembling a perception audit.  The document review classified documents based on data source, data type, and type of analysis performed.  The analysis also considered the DIKW hierarchy (data, information, knowledge, wisdom) and the distinction between data and information. The report focuses on areas for improvement while acknowledging existing strengths within DG SANCO.

sections.title: Data Collection and Description of the Tobacco Sector
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the data sources used to characterize the tobacco sector in the EU, including Eurostat data on gross turnover, number of enterprises, and employment.  The data are presented in tables and figures, and the limitations of the data are discussed.

sections.title: Methodology for Estimating Administrative Burden
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used to estimate the administrative burden of the Tobacco Products Directive on businesses and Member States.  It involved key informant interviews with business representatives, a survey of businesses, and a review of existing studies.  The challenges in differentiating between regulatory and business-as-usual costs are discussed.

sections.title: Methodology for Baseline Scenario Forecasting
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the methodology used to forecast future smoking prevalence, mortality, morbidity, healthcare costs, employment, and excise duty collection under a baseline scenario (no policy changes).  It involves statistical modeling of past trends in smoking prevalence using WHO and OECD data, and the limitations of the models are discussed.

sections.title: Econometric Modeling of Employment Share and Tax Revenue Impacts
sections.methods_summary: This section details the econometric approach used to model the relationship between smoking prevalence and employment in the tobacco sector (manufacturing, wholesale, and retail).  It uses regression analysis with control variables (firm size, labor costs, skilled labor, technological progress) and data from Eurostat, WHO, and OECD.  Four different forecasts are presented to account for uncertainty.

sections.title: Administrative Burden and Compliance Cost Data Collection
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the data collection methods used to assess administrative burden and compliance costs.  It involved questionnaires sent to tobacco manufacturers and retailer associations, supplemented by key informant interviews.  The limitations of the data, including the small sample size and potential for overestimation, are discussed.

analysis.sample_description: The sample for the administrative burden and compliance cost assessment included a small number of tobacco manufacturers and retailer associations, with limited representation from Central and Eastern Europe.  The sample of manufacturers was nearly comprehensive for cigarettes, but less so for other tobacco products.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved quantitative modeling of health and economic impacts, using econometric and health economic modeling techniques.  A multi-criteria decision-making framework was used to compare policy options, combining quantitative and qualitative information.

sections.title: Study Design and Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the study design, sample selection, data collection procedures, and statistical analysis.  The study combined patient safety and medical malpractice claims data aggregated at the county level in California from 2001-2005. Patient safety data came from the Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project (HCUP) state inpatient database using Patient Safety Indicators (PSIs). Malpractice claims data were obtained from four major California medical liability carriers.  Analysis involved linear regression models with fixed effects for California counties, controlling for stable demographic differences.  Poisson regression models were also used as a robustness check.

analysis.sample_description: Patient safety and medical malpractice claims data from California counties for the years 2001-2005. Data on malpractice claims were obtained from four of the largest physician medical liability carriers in California, representing over 50% of the non-self-insured physician market. Patient safety data were derived from the HCUP state inpatient database using Patient Safety Indicators (PSIs). Four counties with very small populations were excluded from the analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: Linear regression models with fixed effects for California counties were used to examine the relationship between annual frequency of adverse events (PSIs) and malpractice claims, controlling for stable demographic differences across counties and including year as a predictor.  Poisson regression models were used as a robustness check.

sections.title: Chapter Two: Methods
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology used in the study, including the description of the health reform scenarios modeled (baseline and alternative scenarios), the outcomes measured, options not modeled, and a comprehensive explanation of the COMPARE microsimulation model.  It covers data sources (SIPP, MEPS-HC, Kaiser/HRET, SUSB), model architecture, how individual and firm behavior were modeled (utility maximization), and the calibration process.  It also discusses the handling of inertia in firm decision-making and other assumptions made.

analysis.sample_description: The model uses a synthetic U.S. population derived from the 2001 Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP),  Medical Expenditure Panel Survey, Household Component (MEPS-HC), and the 2006 Kaiser Family Foundation and Health Research and Educational Trust (Kaiser/HRET) Employer Health Benefits Annual Survey.  Firm size data was augmented with information from the Statistics of U.S. Businesses (SUSB).
analysis.analysis_approach: The COMPARE microsimulation model was used to project how individuals, households, and firms would respond to health care policy changes.  Individual behavior was modeled using a utility maximization framework, while firm behavior was modeled using a group choice model and a logit regression.  Sensitivity analyses were conducted by varying key parameters (firm size eligibility for exchanges, tax credits, penalties, administrative load, inertia, risk pooling).  The model was calibrated to reproduce the status quo.

sections.title: Study Purpose and Methodological Approach
sections.methods_summary: The study aimed to understand the current state of CKD care through telephone interviews and site visits.  In 2006, 15 telephone interviews were conducted with CKD practices. In 2007, on-site case studies were performed at six practices to gather detailed descriptive data about CKD care. The case study approach was chosen to generate detailed descriptive data that could not be obtained through quantitative methods.

sections.title: 2006 Telephone Survey and 2007 Case Studies
sections.methods_summary: The 2006 telephone survey involved 15 semi-structured interviews conducted by Dr. Rettig using a pre-developed interview instrument (provided in the appendix). Interview notes were summarized, reviewed by interviewees, and finalized. Key themes were identified and shared with interviewees. The 2007 case studies involved site visits to six CKD clinics/practices. Semi-structured interviews (1.5-2 hours) were conducted with clinic directors and other physicians. Interview notes were written immediately after each visit, reviewed by interviewees, and finalized.  Interviewees also provided relevant materials. The final write-up for each clinic was reviewed by the research team.

analysis.sample_description: 15 CKD practices participated in telephone interviews; 6 CKD clinics/practices participated in on-site case studies.  The case study sites were not a representative sample but were chosen for their illustrative purposes.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data to identify key themes. Descriptive analysis of case study data to illustrate challenges and models of CKD care.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.methods_summary: Analysis of reported allegations of recruiter irregularities, comparison of contract characteristics of those signing contracts in the final days of the recruiting month with those signing earlier in the month using Army contract data.

sections.title: Data and Research Objectives
sections.methods_summary: Access to each service's data on recruiter irregularities from 2006-2009, including information on the number of production recruiters and applicants. Micro data on individual Army enlistees and individual recruiters were also obtained.  The study re-examines the extent of substantiated allegations, the number of substantiated allegations as a fraction of production recruiters, and cycles in irregularities related to the Army recruiting calendar.  The effects of the recruiter management system on recruiter behavior are also explored.

sections.title: Data Description and Limitations
sections.methods_summary: Data on recruiter irregularities from each service (Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps) for 2006-2009 (2007-2009 for Air Force).  Micro-data on allegations provided by Army and Navy, with limitations noted for Navy data prior to May 2007.  Individual-level Army enlistment data (2000-2008) and recruiter data (2006-2008) were used.  Challenges in matching data across different datasets are discussed, highlighting the need for improved data quality and integration.

sections.title: Analysis of Army Contract Data
sections.methods_summary: Comparison of applicant characteristics for Army contracts signed at the end of the recruiting month versus earlier in the month.  Regression analysis used to compare means of various characteristics (demographic, qualification-related, contract outcomes).  Robustness checks performed using alternative samples, specifications (different time periods, definitions of 'end of month', inclusion of control variables).  A method for inferring the overall extent of unreported irregularities is described, based on assumptions about the increase in irregularities at the end of the month and the effect of irregularities on bad conduct discharges.  This involves using a formula derived in Appendix B.

sections.title: Appendix A: Overview of Recruiting Policies and Procedures
sections.methods_summary: Summary of each service's policies and procedures for handling recruiter improprieties, including definitions of different types of improprieties and procedures for reporting and investigating allegations.

sections.title: Appendix B: Derivations
sections.methods_summary: Derivation of the relationship between changes in contractee characteristics at the end of the recruiting month and recruiter irregularities.  Mathematical formulas are presented to show how the observed differences in contractee characteristics depend on the increase in irregularly recruited contractees and the difference in probabilities of bad conduct discharges between irregularly and normally recruited individuals.  A method for estimating the overall share of contracts involving irregularities is derived.

analysis.sample_description: Data from the Army, Navy, Air Force, and Marine Corps on recruiter irregularities (2006-2009), individual-level Army enlistment data (2000-2008), and individual-level Army recruiter data (2006-2008).
analysis.analysis_approach: The study uses a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative analysis of existing datasets with qualitative descriptions of policies and procedures.  Quantitative analysis includes descriptive statistics, regression analysis, and the development of a statistical model to estimate the prevalence of unreported irregularities.

sections.title: Literature Review Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A systematic literature review was conducted using PubMed and websites of relevant international organizations.  Search terms included combinations of "use/utilization/consumption/prevalence", "therapy/treatment/medication", "international/cross-national/Europe/America", and "variation/difference/comparison" linked to specific medicines or disease areas.  Inclusion criteria focused on studies exploring cross-national variation involving at least two countries, published from 2000 onwards, and limited to high-income/OECD countries with a focus on Europe, Canada, and the United States.  Studies were excluded if they focused on cost-effectiveness, safety, clinical trials, etiological studies, patient adherence, or were review articles (except as sources for identifying additional studies). Data extraction from eligible studies followed a common template including study objective, design, year, population, data source, outcome measures, and key findings.  For osteoporosis, due to a lack of eligible studies, patient preference studies were also considered.

analysis.sample_description: Studies included were limited to those comparing medicines usage in high-income/OECD countries, with a particular focus on Europe, Canada, and the United States. Studies published from 2000 onwards were included, and those in languages other than English, German, or French were excluded.
analysis.analysis_approach: Data were extracted from eligible studies using a common template, and a narrative summary of findings was provided.  For osteoporosis, due to limited eligible studies, patient preference studies were included to offer indirect evidence.

sections.title: Methodology: Estimating the Differential Cost of Retaining Production-Only Tooling
sections.methods_summary: Obtained master tooling lists from contractors. Analyzed lists to determine tools needed for sustainment vs. production-only. Estimated costs of wrapping, packing, transporting, storing, and maintaining production-only tooling using contractor task sheets and the Conex storage approach. Scaled administrative and planning costs based on tool count. Categorized tools by size to estimate wrapping, packing, transporting, and storing costs. Computed the number of Conexes needed. Independently verified and updated cost parameters. Excluded ultimate disposal costs as they are roughly the same for both options.

sections.title: Methodology: Estimating Restart Costs
sections.methods_summary: Three scenarios considered: hypothetical, transition, and future.  The timing of funding influences cost and activities.  The F-22A cost model from an earlier RAND report was used, updated with current inflation and labor rates.  Nonrecurring restart costs included planning and administration, facilities reestablishment, tooling reorganization, personnel rehiring, and supplier requalification.  Costs were estimated based on square footage, number of tools, labor hours, and labor costs.  Loss of learning was assumed to not be mitigated by smartbooks.  Final shutdown costs were taken from a previous RAND study.

sections.title: Methodology: Critical Supplier Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Identified critical suppliers with unique capabilities difficult to recreate after production ends.  Discussed capabilities and potential issues for each supplier based on information provided by the suppliers themselves.  Suppliers were ranked by the potential impact of their unavailability on a restart.

primary_methods: Data analysis of existing tooling lists
analysis.sample_description: The study analyzed data from all F-22A prime contractors and their suppliers, encompassing nearly 40,000 unique government tools.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involved cost estimation for different scenarios (continued production, shutdown and sustainment, shutdown and retain), considering factors like loss of learning, low-rate production, and supplier capabilities.  The analysis relied heavily on data from previous RAND studies and updated information from contractors.

sections.title: Appendix E: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: A triangulated, multi-method approach was used, combining semi-structured interviews with academics and early career researchers, a survey of data experts, and a conference session with European criminologists.  The literature review involved a bibliometric search (Web of Science, RePEc), supplemented by Google searches, targeted journal searches, and expert consultation.

analysis.sample_description: Ten semi-structured interviews with academics and early career researchers; a survey sent to data experts in various European locations; approximately 30 European criminologists participated in a conference session. The literature review sample was not explicitly defined but included sources from Web of Science, RePEc, Google searches, targeted journal searches, and expert recommendations.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach is described as a synthesis of findings from the interviews, survey responses, and conference session.  The literature review aimed to identify data collections, discuss factors affecting international CCJ statistics, and develop ideas for smarter aggregation of data. No specific statistical techniques beyond descriptive statistics are mentioned in this section.

sections.title: Methodology and Organization
sections.methods_summary: The study used a mixed-methods approach.  First, a review of existing academic and quasi-academic literature was conducted to identify patterns and insights. Second, articles from the business press were collected to gather commentary and examples of authentication methods used in various sectors.  The primary method involved semi-structured interviews with representatives from various organizations (defense contractors, healthcare organizations, government agencies, financial firms, a foundation, and technology providers). Interviewee selection was not random, influenced by self-selection among organizations reluctant to discuss network security.

sections.title: Literature Review for Authentication Technologies
sections.methods_summary: A literature review was conducted to build a dataset of information describing the spectrum of authentication technologies.  The search included academic publications, commercial reports, and other sources such as the ACM Digital Library, Cambridge Journals Online, EBSCO, IEEE Electronic Library, Ingenta Connect, Gartner publications, ISI Web of Science, Science Direct, Springer LINK, DTIC, ISI Conference Proceedings, OCLC Papers First and Proceedings, and OCLC Business Management Practices.  Searches used broad and specific terms related to authentication and technology.  The results were manually reviewed and categorized into four groups: what a user knows, what a user has, what a user is, and what a user does. Technologies were further categorized by maturity level (ubiquitous, implemented, prototype, emerging, niche).

analysis.sample_description: The interviews were conducted with representatives from six defense contractors (FFRDCs), four healthcare organizations, one government agency, two financial firms, one foundation, and four technology providers.  The selection was not random and was influenced by self-selection among organizations.
analysis.analysis_approach: The findings from the literature review and interviews were analyzed to identify patterns and insights regarding the factors influencing organizations' decisions to adopt or reject multifactor authentication.

sections.title: Part I. Laboratory Testing
sections.methods_summary: This section details the methodology for the laboratory testing phase.  It describes the data sources (de-identified e-prescriptions from two vendors), data exclusion criteria (out-of-scope and inadequately specified prescriptions), methods for matching e-prescriptions to RxNorm CUIs (automated and manual matching using two NDC-to-CUI mappings), assessment of RxNorm concept stability over time (comparing April and October 2009 RxNorm distributions), and analysis of consistency between the two NDC-to-CUI mappings.  The analysis included assessing overall coverage, concept replacement rates, and classifying mismatches based on clinical significance.

sections.title: Part II. Live Pilot Testing
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines the methodology for the live pilot testing. It covers use cases and pilot software development (adding RxCUIs to e-prescribing transactions), site selection (physician office-pharmacy pairs meeting specific criteria, data from Surescripts), site visits (baseline and follow-up visits with qualitative interviews, observations, and time-motion workflow observations), interview protocol (semistructured interviews tailored for different respondent types), and interview coding (digital recording, transcription, coding in Atlas.ti, reliability testing using Cohen's Kappa).

primary_methods: Automated and manual matching of e-prescriptions to RxNorm CUIs
Comparison of RxNorm distributions over time
Analysis of consistency between NDC-to-CUI mappings
analysis.sample_description: A sample of 20,135 de-identified ambulatory e-prescriptions from two e-prescribing system vendors was used for laboratory testing.  For live pilot testing, five physician offices and three linked pharmacies were selected based on criteria including use of specific software and prior transaction volume.
analysis.analysis_approach: Analysis included calculating coverage rates, concept replacement rates, and classifying mismatches based on clinical significance. Qualitative data from interviews were coded and analyzed thematically.  Statistical analysis using Cohen's Kappa was used to assess inter-rater reliability.

sections.title: Research Objectives and Approach
sections.methods_summary: Extensive literature review and development of an analytical approach based on a 2009 Deputy Secretary of Defense memorandum.
