The analytical approach involved adopting definitions of assessment criteria, interpreting those definitions, and developing a questionnaire.  Interviews with civilian leadership and contractors, as well as observation of the work environment, were recommended.

sections.title: Overview of Current Policy and Guidance
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the existing policy and guidance used to inform the development of the analytical approach.  It outlines four major restrictions on the use of contractors and identifies pending and proposed changes to law and policy.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.methods_summary: The analytical approach is based on a 2009 Deputy Secretary of Defense memorandum, which provides a decision-tree method.  The researchers adopted definitions from existing guidance and instructions for inherently governmental functions, personal services, exemptions from private-sector performance, and problems with contract administration. A questionnaire (Appendix C) was developed to assess contractor functions against these criteria.  The methodology also involved interpreting laws and policies, assessing the mission, roles, and tasks of the organization, and using a rubric for determining the applicability of in-sourcing criteria. Interviews, workplace observations, and narrative descriptions were also considered helpful for clarifying issues and gathering additional information.

analysis.sample_description: The sample is not explicitly defined, but the methodology focuses on assessing contractor functions within the Department of Defense, potentially encompassing various organizations and positions.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis approach is primarily qualitative and interpretive, relying on the researchers' interpretation of existing laws, policies, and guidance to develop a framework for assessing contractor functions and determining the appropriateness of in-sourcing.  The questionnaire is designed to elicit information relevant to applying the established criteria, and the analysis involves applying a rubric to assess whether specific functions meet the criteria for in-sourcing.

sections.title: References
sections.methods_summary: This section lists references used in the report, not methodology.

sections.title: Our Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section details the research approach, including the selection criteria for quality measurement systems and resource allocation models.  The criteria for selecting quality measurement systems included focusing on ambulatory care, measures currently in use, and high-stakes applications (pay-for-performance or public reporting).  Resource allocation model selection was based on literature review and prior work by the authors, focusing on Australia, Canada, England, and New Zealand due to their early adoption of quality measurement systems linked to resource allocation. Data collection involved reviewing published and grey literature from various sources (bibliographic databases, the World Wide Web, governmental and non-governmental agencies).

sections.title: Overview of Quality Indicators in Current Use
sections.methods_summary: This section describes the classification of indicators into domains of quality (using Donabedian's framework), analysis of what indicators measure and don't measure, discussion of efficiency measures, the importance of local priorities, and examples of quality indicators in each domain.  The methodology involved reviewing 18 indicator systems in six countries and categorizing over 826 quality indicators into nine domains.  The authors used Donabedian's structure-process-outcome framework to further classify indicators.  Analysis included examining the relative weight of different quality domains across countries and identifying gaps in measurement (e.g., lack of efficiency and equity measures, focus on common conditions with solid evidence bases).

analysis.sample_description: The study reviewed 18 quality measurement systems from six countries, extracting 826 quality or performance indicators.
analysis.analysis_approach: The indicators were classified into nine domains of quality and further categorized using Donabedian's structure-process-outcome framework.  Qualitative and quantitative analysis was conducted to assess the strengths and weaknesses of existing indicator sets, including data requirements, context for indicator development, and stakeholder involvement.  The analysis also examined the relative weight of different quality domains across countries and identified gaps in measurement.

sections.title: Approach
sections.methods_summary: This section details the study sample selection, which involved a two-step process to ensure representation of various program types.  A modified resource cost model (RCM) was used for cost analysis.  Data were collected through in-person semi-structured interviews with program directors, using a data collection instrument modeled on those used in previous studies (CQO and LA ExCELS).  Both monetary expenditures and 'hidden' costs (volunteer labor, donated resources) were included.  Costs were calculated in three ways: per child-hour, per year per full-time equivalent (FTE) child, and per year per enrollee.  Limitations of the study, such as inconsistencies in data disaggregation across programs and the non-representativeness of the sample, are also discussed.

analysis.sample_description: 12 out of 47 early childhood education (ECE) programs participating in the Saint Paul Early Childhood Scholarship Program were selected. The sample was stratified to include each type of participating program (family child care homes, for-profit and nonprofit centers, Head Start, and public school preschools) and program structure (full-day and half-day programs operating year-round or for the academic year).  The selected programs served two-thirds of the children receiving scholarships in 2010.
analysis.analysis_approach: A modified resource cost model (RCM) was employed.  Program costs were calculated per child-hour, per year per FTE child, and per year per enrollee.  Both monetary and in-kind costs were considered.

sections.title: Approach to Assessing Current Practices in Cold-Case Investigations
sections.methods_summary: A web-based survey was developed with the assistance of an expert panel and fielded by the University of Baltimore's Schaefer Center for Public Policy.  A stratified sample of 5,000 agencies was drawn from a Bureau of Justice Statistics database.  Response rates were analyzed by agency type, size, and region.  Multivariate analysis was used to examine factors associated with cold-case arrest rates.

sections.title: Approach to Conducting Case-File Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Four jurisdictions were selected based on survey results: three focusing on homicides (District of Columbia, Baltimore, Dallas) and one on sexual assault cases (Denver).  Up to 200 case files per site were reviewed.  Due to limitations in available databases, case selection relied on cold-case investigators providing equal numbers of solved and unsolved cases (case-control design).  Data abstraction forms were used to collect information on victim characteristics, crime context, motivation, human capital, physical evidence, basis for opening the investigation, and actions taken by investigators.

sections.title: Case-File Analysis Results & Statistical Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Data from the four sites were analyzed across several categories.  For the homicide cases, logistic regression was used to predict case resolution based on various factors categorized by temporal sequence (crime context, initial investigation, basis for opening cold case, investigator actions).  Robust standard errors were used to account for differences across sites.  A similar logistic regression was performed on the Denver sexual assault data to predict conviction rates given a CODIS hit.

analysis.sample_description: A stratified sample of 5,000 law enforcement agencies for the survey; up to 200 case files per site (District of Columbia, Baltimore, Dallas, Denver) for the case file analysis, with a case-control design for the homicide cases and a sample of all CODIS hits for the sexual assault cases.
analysis.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, bivariate and multivariate analyses (logistic regression) to identify factors associated with cold case clearance and conviction rates.

sections.title: Chapter 2: The Travel Demand Models
sections.methods_summary: This section details the model alternatives (modes, destinations, train stations), the architecture of home-based and non-home-based travel demand models, and the mathematical formulas used for calculating logsums, tour frequency, and distribution over modes and destinations.  It describes the input data (highway and public transport skims, zonal data) and the process of combining tour frequency and mode-destination models within the TravDem framework.

sections.title: Chapter 3: Segmentation and Chapter 4: Operation of Application System
sections.methods_summary: Chapter 3 describes the segmentation of the population into various groups based on socio-economic factors for both mode-destination and tour frequency models.  It explains the trade-off between detailed segmentation and model run time, and the use of mean proportions for certain variables. Chapter 4 details the operational steps of the application system, including creating scenario directories, copying input files, running station choice LOS processing, running the TravDem models, post-processing, and copying output files.  It also discusses the use of environment variables in ALOGIT to manage file paths and run times for different components.

sections.title: Chapter 5: Verification and Validation
sections.methods_summary: This section outlines the validation methods used to assess the accuracy of the updated travel demand models.  Five key tests were conducted: 1) replication of logsums from the estimation phase, 2) comparison of observed and predicted tour rates, 3) comparison of observed and predicted mode shares (using RMS(MF) and RMS(MM) measures), 4) comparison of observed and predicted mean tour lengths (using RMS measures), and 5) comparison of application elasticities to estimation values.  The data sources for validation include the Household Travel Survey (HTS) and the 2006 Census data.  The analysis includes calculating percentage differences, root mean square (RMS) errors, and elasticities using a constant elasticity formulation.

analysis.sample_description: The study uses data from the Sydney Household Travel Survey (HTS) and the 2006 Census, covering the Sydney Statistical Division, Illawarra SD, and Newcastle Statistical Sub-Divisions.  The sample size and weighting procedures are described in detail within the document, varying by analysis.
analysis.analysis_approach: The analysis involves comparing model outputs (tour rates, mode shares, tour lengths, elasticities) to observed data from the HTS and Census.  Root Mean Square (RMS) error is used to quantify the difference between model predictions and observed values.  Elasticities are calculated using a constant elasticity formulation to assess the model's responsiveness to changes in various factors (fuel cost, car time, PT fare, PT in-vehicle time).

sections.title: Data Collection and Analysis
sections.methods_summary: Multifaceted approach to identify programs including web searches, review of documents, consultations with experts, and snowball sampling.  Data collected through interviews (30-60 minutes) with program representatives or from publicly available documentation.  Analysis involved categorizing programs into a typology of activities and describing program characteristics across various dimensions (branch of service, targeted participants, deployment phase, domain, approach, scale, clinical and nonclinical issues, evidence-based interventions, evaluation status, data collected).  Response rate calculated using American Association for Public Opinion Research's Standard Definitions, Response Rate 3.  RAND analysis section addressed specific questions regarding program goals, barriers, evaluations, and data collection.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: A multifaceted approach was used to identify programs, including web and media searches, reviewing public domain documents, consulting with military personnel and nonprofit organizations, obtaining DoD program lists, consulting with RAND experts, and snowball sampling.  Data collection involved interviews (30-60 minutes) with program representatives or using publicly available documentation for non-respondents.  Response rate was calculated using the American Association for Public Opinion Research's Standard Definitions, Response Rate 3.  Analysis involved categorizing programs based on their activities and characteristics (branch of service, targeted participants, deployment phase, domain, approach, scale, clinical and nonclinical issues, evidence-based interventions, evaluation status, and data collected).  A RAND analysis section addressed specific questions about program goals, barriers, evaluations, and data collection.

analysis.sample_description: 652 potential programs identified; 211 met inclusion/exclusion criteria and are included in the report.  24 programs included based on publicly available data due to lack of response to interview requests.  A large number of entities were deemed ineligible after further investigation.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative analysis. Programs were categorized into a typology of activities and described across various dimensions using descriptive statistics.  A RAND analysis section provided a structured assessment of each program based on specific questions.

sections.title: Methods
sections.methods_summary: The researchers consulted with the Center for Faith-Based and Neighborhood Partnerships to identify toolkit topics based on community relevance, government initiatives, and health needs.  They created an outline specifying the toolkit's framework, content type, access method, and end-user benefits.  The toolkit was organized into nine sections.  Peer-reviewed and gray literature was reviewed, including the Affordable Care Act, peer-reviewed literature on CFBOs' roles in health promotion, materials from federal agencies, and the CFBNP's existing Capacity Building Toolkit.  Overview sections and one-page primers were created. Two stakeholders reviewed the toolkit content for clarity, scope, and cultural competency.

analysis.sample_description: Two key stakeholders representing the target audience of community and faith-based organizations.
analysis.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of existing literature and stakeholder feedback to inform toolkit content and design.

sections.title: Study Scope and Research Method
sections.methods_summary: This research involved a review of existing literature (peer-reviewed articles, military testing reports, DoD and service policy documents, online and printed resources from each service).  Data was verified through discussions with service representatives involved in test development or selection decisions.

analysis.sample_description: The study covers all five military services (Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, and Coast Guard) and focuses on standardized tests explicitly used for officer commissioning programs, branch/specialty assignments, commissioning, and promotion.
analysis.analysis_approach: The report documents how standardized test scores are used in selection decisions, including considerations of predictive validity, bias, and adverse impact.  Analysis is primarily descriptive, based on the collected information.

sections.title: Annex 3: Research Methodology
sections.methods_summary: This section details the two-phased research approach. Phase 1 involved a literature review using targeted Google searches and input from interviewees. Phase 2 consisted of 22 semi-structured interviews (approximately one hour each) with individuals from various organizations (UK, US, Australia, UN, EU, World Bank).  The interviews focused on evaluation methods for stabilization efforts, challenges to effective monitoring and evaluation, and best practices.

analysis.sample_description: 22 individuals from the United Kingdom, the United States, Australia, the United Nations, the European Union and the World Bank.
analysis.analysis_approach: The interviews were analyzed thematically to identify current practices, challenges, and best practices in monitoring and evaluation of stabilization interventions.  The literature review informed the interview questions and the interpretation of interview data.

sections.title: Connecticut-Specific Adjustments to COMPARE Model
sections.methods_summary: Reweighted COMPARE microsimulation model data to reflect Connecticut's distribution of workers and firms, accounting for race, insurance status, employment status, firm size, age, and poverty. Recalculated Medicaid eligibility using Connecticut-specific criteria. Calibrated the model to reflect Connecticut-specific population projections. Adjusted health care spending to match state health insurance expenditure accounts (SHEAs) and projected expenditures using historical growth rates. Accounted for the SAGA program by assigning SAGA status based on income, Medicaid eligibility, and current public health insurance coverage. Calibrated the model to reflect the transfer of 45,000 individuals from SAGA to Medicaid. Identified state government employees and reweighted a subset to represent all state government workers. Assumed state pays entire premium for state government workers and 70% for family members.

sections.title: Overview of the Approach to Estimating ACA Effects on Connecticut
sections.methods_summary: Used RAND's COMPARE microsimulation model to estimate the effects of the ACA.  The model accounts for the individual mandate, employer penalties, subsidies, and Medicaid expansion.  The model considers individual and employer choices regarding health insurance based on financial incentives and risk. Parameters were chosen to be consistent with economic theory and empirical estimates.

sections.title: Methodological Appendix: Overview of COMPARE Model
sections.methods_summary: Used RAND's COMPARE microsimulation model, which is based on a nationally representative population from SIPP, MEPS, and Kaiser/HRET employer survey data. Individuals in the model make insurance enrollment decisions based on cost-benefit analysis. Firms decide on insurance offerings considering worker preferences and costs, accounting for Medicaid/exchange subsidies and penalties for not offering coverage. Premiums are determined endogenously based on predicted enrollee expenditures.  Actuarial values for different types of plans are specified.

analysis.sample_description: Nationally representative population of synthetic individuals and firms derived from SIPP, MEPS, and Kaiser/HRET employer survey data, reweighted to reflect Connecticut demographics.
analysis.analysis_approach: The COMPARE model simulates individual and employer choices regarding health insurance based on financial incentives and risk, and projects the resulting changes in private and public sector spending.  The model accounts for the individual mandate, employer penalties, subsidies, and Medicaid expansion.  Results are compared to projections of what would have occurred without the ACA.
